column2: New York City's 15 largest mutual savings banks, which have combined assets of about $17-billion, are seeking high-yielding mortgages on commercial and industrial properties outside New York State, a survey of top executives at these banks indicated yesterday.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., June 19 Miss Nancy May Gross, daughter of Mrs. Elsie May Gross of New Rochelle and Albert P. Gross of New York, was married this afternoon to Barrie Wayne Blase, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred H. Blase Jr. of Maywood, Ill.
An off-duty patrolman shot and killed an alleged mugger and captured his accomplice early yesterday on West 132d Street, the police reported.
Efforts to end the 57-day-old strike against the World Journal Tribune, Inc., will resume today after a weekend recess.

The General Aniline and Film Corporation announced over the weekend that it intends to make an offer to purchase all the outstanding stock of Hall Harding, Ltd., a British manufacturer of sensitized material used far document reproduction.
The Avco Corporation had estimated net earnings of $8.3million, or 60 cents a share, in the second fiscal quarter ended May 31, James R. Kerr, president, reported over the weekend.

LONDON, June 19 Stuart W. Don picks up the black bowler, stands for a moment under the gleaming Chemical Bank medallion hanging across the sidewalk at 10 Moorgate, then dashes off in a cab to a ceremony at Westminster Abbey.
Senator Robert F. Kennedy declared yesterday that he favored re-election of President Johnson in 1968 and that he had "no plans to run for anything other than United States Senator in 1970."
WASHINGTON, June 19 A Federal Power Commission official has strongly suggested that electric utilities should not be given more natural gas for fuel so as to reduce air pollution.

FROMBORK, Poland, June 19 (AP) Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski suggested today that Communist authorities were acting "like children" in trying to prevent a copy of the painting "Black Madonna of Czestochowa" from being paraded at celebrations of the thousandth anniversary of Christianity in Poland.
A Jesuit editor and a Methodist minister have asked permission from the Soviet Government to ship 10,000 siddurim, or Jewish prayerbooks, into the Soviet Union.
A $2.3-million project, intended to provide comprehensive medical care for 20,000 children of low-income families in the Bellevue Hospital district, was announced yesterday.
Dr. Alexander G. Bearn has been appointed chief physician and head of the department of medicine at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center effective Sept. 1, it was announced yesterday.
DeCoursey Fales, a retired banker and a leading yachtsman, died yesterday at Doctors Hospital after a brief illness. Mr. Fales, who had homes in New York City and Gladstone, N.J., was 78 years old.

HUE, South Vietnam, Monday, June 20 Loyal Government forces cordoned off the hospital room of the militant Buddhist leader Thich Tri Quang today after having taken over full control of this city, which has been a center of antiGovernment agitation.

Mr. and Mrs. R. Stuyvesant Pierrepont Jr. of New York and Locust Valley, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Louise Rutherfurd Pierrepont to John Dapray Muir, son of Mr. and Mrs. Brackett Muir of Washington. A summer wedding is planned.

THE number of freshmen who reach college with a working knowledge of bridge has increased substantially in recent years. In the New York area, this can be partly attributed to the annual series of free lessons given to teen-age beginners by the experts of the New York Card School.
Several large Protestant denominations and secular groups have agreed to pool their resources in a multimillion-dollar effort to stimulate the construction of low-rent housing throughout the nation.

The last-ditch effort of the Democratic majority in the City Council and Board of Estimate to keep the fifteen-cent transit fare regardless of state law or the damaging effect on Mayor Lindsay's budget may masquerade temporarily as good politics, but it is a poor service to the public.

Billy Casper defeated Arnold Palmer by four strokes yesterday to win the United States Open golf championship at the Olympic Country Club in San Francisco. Casper shot a 69 in the 18-hole playoff to 73 for Palmer. They had tied at 278 at the end of the regulation 72 holes Sunday.

WHITE PLAINS, June 20 William J. Yates, long time real estate representative of the Rockefeller family in Pocantico Hills, denied today that the late John D. Rockefeller Jr. had tried to move Route 117 away from his home.

RICHMOND, June 20 (AP) The Board of Supervisors of Prince Edward county was cited for civil contempt by the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit here today for paying out $180,000 in tuition grants to parents of white school children.

Lawrence A. Fleischman, the Detroit businessman who is one of the country's leading art collectors, is moving here to become a partner in the Kennedy Galleries at 20 East 56th Street, a major art dealer.
Employes of Haryou-Act intend to pay the agency's back Federal taxes themselves, Livingston Wingate, executive director of the Harlem antipoverty agency, said yesterday.
The credit markets, which weathered in good order the pressures associated with corporate tax and dividend payments in mid-June, have suddenly turned bullish.

ALBANY, June 20 A bill that would require virtually every child in the state to be immunized against polio before he would be allowed to attend school was passed today by the Assembly. Senate approval is considered certain.

FORT KNOX, Ky., June 20 (AP) A spokesman at Fort Knox said today that the San Jose State sprinter, Tommy Smith, was given his release from an R.O.T.C. training program because he was not physically fit to take part in the program.

WASHINGTON, June 20 The Fifth Amendment's privilege against self-incrimination does not permit a driver to balk at giving a sample of his blood for a test to determine if he is drunk, the Supreme Court ruled today. The Court's vote was 5 to 4.

ST. LOUIS, June 20 The new Busch Stadium in St. Louis, the Cardinal management kept telling everyone, was built for speed. The New York Mets discovered how true that is in their first visit here and lost to the Cards, 4-2, tonight.
CHELSEA, N.Y., June 20- About 5 per cent of the water in New York City faucets now is from the Hudson River, engineers said today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, June 21 American seamen unloaded Chinese-made arms and ammunition today from a trawler that had been driven ashore south of Saigon by United States Coast Guard cutters.
LONDON, June 20 (AP) Speaking over his airliner's intercommunication microphone, Capt. Frank Stone said to his 100 passengers:

Hume Cronyn and Jessica Tandy, husband and wife offstage, will portray those roles in Edward Albee's next play, "A Delicate Balance." Previews will begin Sept. 12 for the premiere at the Martin Beck on Sept. 22.
Carlo Vinti, president of the Vinti Advertising Company, 400 Madison Avenue, died Sunday of a heart attack in his home at 530 East 72d Street. He was 70 years old.
Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange increased to a total of 10,742,219 shares at the close of business on June 15, the Big Board reported yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 20-Secretary General Thant today denounced the war in Vietnam as "one of the most barbarous" in history and called the situation "very urgent, very critical." Mr. Thant has proposed steps to peace to some of the parties principally concerned.
Steel production rose fourtenths of 1 per cent last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
A three-judge panel in Criminal Court ruled yesterday that drunkometer and coordination tests for persons charged with drunken driving were unconstitutional under a recent Supreme Court ruling.

How should first-graders be introduced to information about sex? How can teen-agers be encouraged to discuss their sexual confusions in the classroom? What should a school do when a young child is molested, when a teen-ager becomes pregnant or when there is an "epidemic" of sexuality in school?
ATLANTA, June 20 (UPI) Gene Oliver hit two homers tonight, including a tie-breaking two-run drive in the seventh inning, to lead the Atlanta Braves to a 7-5 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.
ALBANY, June 20 Governor Rockefeller said today that leaders of the politically divided Legislature were having trouble finding enough votes to pass the compromise tax package for New York City.
A Greenwich Village civic leader charged New York University yesterday with including too many fairy tales in its plans for a library on the south side of Washington Square.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) The Supreme Court set aside today criminal contempt sentences imposed in two cases in Federal Court in New York City because of a decision on June 6 that jury trials are required when sentences exceed six months.

LONDON, July 20 Dennis Ralston, America's top-ranking player, used three racquets today to win from 18-year-old Robert Lutz of Los Angeles, 7-5, 6-2, 3-6, 6-4, in the opening round of the Wimbledon tennis championship today.

A driver lost control of his car in rush-hour traffic on Nostrand Avenue in Brooklyn yesterday evening injuring eight pedestrians, himself and two passengers in his car. He also knocked over a parking meter, struck two automobiles, damaged two stores and finally broke the plate glass window in a third store, wounding the store's proprietor and his wife with the broken glass.
IN the spring of 1964, when he carried 225 pounds on a 5-foot-11-inch frame and his stomach pushed heavily outward and downward, William Earl (Billy) Casper Jr. was a terrible grouch.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 20 Mr. and Mrs. Edward C. Kennard have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Wren Kennard, to Brynn Frederic Aurelius of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. William McKinley Aurelius of Ridgewood, N.J., and Chautauqua, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, June 20 By a majority of only one the Supreme Court today sustained the principle that race, color and the design of furthering civil rights equality furnish no special privilege when the issue is violation of the general enforceable public ordinances.
JERICHO, L.I., June 20- Mrs. Murray Gordon of Elmwood won the qualifying medal today in the 63d annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship here.
HAMPTON, Va., June 20 A Marine Corps attack bomber crashed in flames in a residential area of the vacation suburb of Buckroe Beach tonight after colliding with another marine jet.

The keen primary fight over a new Manhattan surrogate has had one important side benefit. It has underscored the desirability of abolishing the Surrogate's Courts and thus drying up a major source of political patronage.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., June 20 Two teams tied in the Westchester County Golf Association's 36th British Victory Cup golf tournament at Siwanoy Country Club today. James Maver and Ford White of Winged Foot had a gross best-ball of 34, 33 67 and Willie Turnesa and his nephew, Mike Turnesa Jr. of Knollwood, posted 35, 32 67 and will play off over 18 holes on the same course at a future date.
PARIS, June 20 (Reuters) Pierre Montet, Egyptologist and writer on Egyptian history, died here last night. He was 80 years old.
Earl C. Palmer, for nearly 50 years a tugboat captain, died yesterday in Long Branch, N.J. He was 74 years old.
KANSAS CITY, June 20 (AP) Tommy Agee tripled across a run in the fifth inning tonight, then doubled and scored in the eighth as the Chicago White Sox defeated the Kansas City Athletics, 3-1.
New York City's first community antenna television service, designed to provide improved picture reception in homes, has started operating in the Inwood section of upper Manhattan.

NORTH BERGEN, N.J., June 20 John J. Roe, a wellknown Hudson County banker and Mayor of this township from 1951 to 1955, died yesterday at Riverview Hospital in Red Bank at the age of 65. He had moved to Middletown from North Bergen earlier this year and lived at 319 Cooper Road.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 20 Just as he did yesterday, Billy Casper overcame a lead by Arnold Palmer today. This time, as he outscored his celebrated rival, 69 to 73, it brought him the United States Open golf title.

CINCINNATI, June 20 (AP) Gov. Warren E. Hearnes of Missouri urged 12 other Midwest Governors today to take the lead in assuming "our responsibilities on urban mass transportation" and not leave it entirely up to the Federal Government.

ANAHEIM, Calif., June 20 A dropped fly ball by the Minnesota center fielder, Tony Oliva, helped California rally for three runs in the seventh inning tonight as the Angels defeated the Twins for the eighth time in nine meetings this year, 5-3.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 20 The Surgeon General of the United States Public Health Service, Dr. William H. Stewart, today appraised nationwide efforts to stem air pollution as "far from adequate" and "deficient."

KAY BOYLE makes her stories out of the stuff of history. Character, setting, all the usual ingredients are pres ent, but the subjects that historians like to tackle are what stimulate her pen. Even a man who has not closely read the newspapers these last three decades would have no trouble charting the course of the West from her tales; the rising Nazi threat, the ...
WASHINGTON, June 20 A group of secretaries in the White House will begin shortly a regular Thursday morning prayer
The Baltimore Orioles and the two Robinsons, Frank and Brooks, tangle with the New York Yankees tonight in a double-header at the Yankee Stadium.
Chalmers Dancy Clifton, a figure in the musical life of the city for 45 years, died Sunday morning at Lenox Hill Hospital after a heart attack. He was 77 years old and lived at 150 East 61st Street.
RANGOON, Burma, June 19 -One day last week The Daily Guardian of Rangoon published a three-column picture of a riot scene at Kyaukme, a railroad station northeast of Mandalay.

In characterizing the student protest movement as the creature of the Communist party, the Senate Internal Security subcommittee has impugned the idealism and seriousness of purpose of many young Americans.
Elmer Brown, president of the International Typographical Union, is coming to New York tomorrow to assist the mailers local here in resolving its dispute with the World Journal Tribune, Inc.

WASHINGTON, June 20 The Supreme Court today dismissed an appeal brought by New York State to validate three alternate plans for electing members of the State Legislature. The plans called B, C and D would have been used in last fall's election.
WASHINGTON, June 20 The House Banking Committee failed to complete action today on legislation to curb interest rates that commercial banks can pay on time deposits.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 111.1 on Friday from 111 on Thursday.

Mr. and Mrs. La Vern Kuper of Tulsa, Okla., have announced here the marriage of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Ann Kuper, to Robert Lessing Rosenwald Jr., a great-grandson of Julius Rosenwald, the philantropist, who was president of Sears, Roebuck Co.

A routine flying patrol by a Grumman Albatross from Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn which was scheduled to last four or five hours became a 10-hour flight yesterday after it was learned that the Big Toy, sailing in the Newport-to-Bermuda classic for the first time, was missing.

Some of the youngsters took a dip. Others just enjoyed the feel of hot sand between their toes. Still others climbed mountains, sat in the dark interiors of igloos, or became Army men, fire-engine men or Tarzan men. A few of the more sophisticated devoted their time to such games as "No Touching the Ground" or "Hot Peas and Butter" or "Roundup."

When the American tanker Texaco Massachusetts and the naphtha-laden British tanker Alva Cape collided last Thursday in the narrow channel of Kill Van Kull there was no explosion, no fire for fully three minutes.
Mr. and Mrs. James G. Gillon have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Priscilla Sousa Gillon, to Edward Foote Ulmann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander E. Ulmann of New York.
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., June 20-Development of a laser requiring no external energy is moving so fast that it will probably be achieved within a year or two.
ELIZABETH, N.J., June 20 (AP) Representative Florence P. Dwyer, who has represented the Sixth District in Congress for seven years, says she will run in the next election from the new 12th District.

WASHINGTON, June 20 The Republican National Committee today tightened the checkrein on its sometimes-fractious Young Rebublicans affiliate and ordered action taken on charges of bigotry against some Young Republicans in New Jersey.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 20 Gen. Abdul Haris Nasution emerged today as the most promising candidate for chairman of the People's Consultative Congress, which convened here this morning.
A pill has helped improve memory in persons suffering from the symptoms of senility, initial tests by an Albany, N.Y., psychiatrist indicate.

Edward P. Fehling, treasurer of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association for the past eight years died Sunday night in Mary Immaculate Hospital, Jamaica, Queens, of a heart attack. He lived at 117-16 226th Street, Cambria Heights, Queens.
HONG KONG, June 2 (Reuters)-Peking authorities are urging people to put up big, erybody putting up such posters everywhere to scare and unmask the regime's enemies.
The top-seeded team was eliminated yesterday in the quarter-finals of the Amateur Athletic Union's national onewall handball doubles championships on the Coney Island municipal courts.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) The Washington Senators downed the Cleveland Indians tonight, 4-2, and knocked the Indians into third place, half a game behind the Detroit Tigers. The victory gave the Senators the series, 3-1.

ROSLYN, L.I., June 20 St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Patricia Alison Corey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan L. Corey, to Robert Sylvanus Montgomerie, son of Mrs. M.S. Montgomerie of Newport, R.I., and Hunsdon in Hertfordshire, England, and R.V.C. Montgomerie-Charrington of London.
LONDON, June 20 If British ballet has a boy-most likely it is the remarkable David Wall who pulled off a distinctive double at the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, yesterday.
Louis Moretti has been named operations vice president in the Molded Products division of the Amerace Corporation.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 20 With Coast Guard search flights from Bermuda canceled because of the distance to the contestants and the Navy and Coast Guard escort vessels hampered by low visibility, the Newport-to-Bermuda yacht race developed into a guessing game today.

HOUSTON, June 20 (AP) Rusty Staub's run-scoring double and Chuck Harrison's single scoring Staub in the eighth inning led the Houston Astros to a 4-2 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers tonight. The defeat was Don Drysdale's fifth straight.

WASHINGTON, June 20 Gray hair has had its day. For years the cosmetics industry has made it possible for women to age without graying, and now the advertising industry is about to pass the same miracle for men.
CHICAGO, June 20 Anyone who is looking for prophetic new designs in home furnishings at the four major yearly markets is in the wrong pew.

Ernest Cardone, a 22-yearold apprentice jockey rode five winners at Aqueduct yesterday, to increase his first-place lead in the local jockey standings. Cardone scored four victories in a row, including the daily double. He had seven mounts on the nine-race card finishing out of the money in the two races he failed to win.
WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP)-The Supreme Court called today for reargument of an appeal by Time, Inc., from a $30,000 damage award under the New York privacy law.

OLSZTYN, Poland, June 20 (AP) Archbishop Boleslaw Kominek of Wroclaw rejected last night the Polish Communist regime's attempt to build him up as a rival to Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, the Roman Catholic Primate of Poland.
The Cities Service Company announced here yesterday the appointment of Charles J. Waidelich as staff vice president in charge of coordination of operations.

Mrs. Elsie D. Kenerson Sanborn, a leader of the United Hospital Fund of New York and the wife of Victor P. Sanborn, a New York Telephone Company business manager, died Sunday in a Brooklyn hospital. She was 60 years old and lived at 150 Greenway Terrace in Forest Hills, Queens.
Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary declared yesterday that the city did not have the police strength it needed because of budget limitations.
MIDNIGHT, Miss., June 20 The civil rights march through Mississippi moved within 75 miles of Jackson today and marchers said they would reach that city by Sunday.
The Federation of Jewish Philanthropies elected Samuel J. Silberman, an industrialist and philanthropist, president last night at a meeting of the board of trustees.

LONDON, June 20 A severe shortage of dollars and disappointment over the failure of Prime Minister Wilson's personal efforts to end the five-weekold seamen's strike brought renewed pressure on the pound today.

Roy Foster, realty investor, has purchased three five-story apartment and store buildings at 507-11 Third Avenue, the northeast corner of the avenue and 34th Street. The sellers were Edward A. Brennan Jr. and members of his family.

WASHINGTON, June 20 The dumping of Gov. Karl F. Rolvaag yesterday by the Minnesota Democratic-Farmer-Labor party convention is symptomatic of the ferment disturbing the consensus Lyndon B. Johnson has tried to impose on his party.

In one of the year's stormiest annual meetings, the voice of the chairman of S. Klein Department Stores, Inc., barely rose above the Wagnerian chorus of stockholder complaints yesterday to plead for the time and opportunity to "make money again."

CAIRO, June 20-Three times in the last eight years the revolutionary Socialists of Syria's Baath party have chased, like suddenly eligible debutantes, to Cairo to seek a political marriage of convenience with President Gamal Abdel Nasser. The first time, in 1959, Mr. Nasser, against his better judgment, ...
CRAIOVA, Rumania, June 20 Communist China held up Rumania's independent Communism today as an example for all Communist nations to follow.
A $125,000 award against a manufacturer for using libelous statements to fight a competitor was unanimously upheld yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
STAMFORD, Conn., June 20 Bindley M. Gillespie, an industrialist and yachtsman, died yesterday. He was 54 years old and lived at 125 Ocean Drive West.

BUFFALO, June 20 Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson aimed a stinging attack at the Rockefeller administration tonight, blaming "Nelson, Judson and Spad" for evils ranging from corruption to pollution to the high cost of whisky.

The hemispheric conference of foreign ministers scheduled for August has apparently been saved. The result was in doubt right up to the very end after two tough weeks of negotiation in Washington. A compromise text on trade and aid has been reached which must have been a real compromise, because the Latin Americans are not especially happy and the North American negotiators are not sure of Senate approval.
Prices on the London stock market turned irregularly higher yesterday in moderately active trading despite the weakness of the pound on foreign exchange markets.
Yesterday from 7:30 A.M. until 12:30 P.M. five young men on roller skates raced around the fifth-floor stacks of the New York Public Library's main branch at Fifth Avenue and 42d Street.

CAPEZIO, which started in 1887 as a fount of ballet slippers, will open a new shop today in a basement that has been designed on three levels at 177 Macdougal Street. Two other Capezio shops are already in existence; the dancetheater one at 49th Street and Broadway and the one called a showroom at 61st Street and Broadway where fashion shoes are sold.
WASHINGTON, June 20 President Johnson ordered today the establishment of a computer-based file of information on the poisonous potentialities of all chemicals and drugs used by man.
MIAMI, June 20 A new Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs took office today in Havana and two deputy ministers were dismissed, the Havana radio said.
Lynda Bird Johnson, accompanied by eight Secret Service men and Susan Schein of New York, a school friend, left by jet plane last night for Madrid and a vacation in Spain.
That season of vacations, swimming, golf, tennis, baseball, light novels and heat will arrive today at 4:33 P.M., Eastern daylight time. Its name is summer.
TENAFLY, N.J., June 20 When school reopens here after vacation in September, Tenafly students will be learning and reciting with the aid of a tape recorder and closed-circuit TV.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., June 20 Ralph M. Osmun, a retired vice president and director of the L.D. Caulk Company, dental supply concern, died yesterday at East Orange General Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived at 23 Woodland Avenue.

The Indiana Dunes are a precious resource for the millions of people in densely crowded Chicago and Gary, Ind. This beautiful and scientifically interesting stretch of Lake Michigan's shore is unique in the region.

HOLLYWOOD, June 20 Jack Valenti, the new president of the Motion Picture Association of America, laid before industry leaders today a series of programs designed to stimulate development of creative talent, improve rapport with young filmmakers and build a more effective system of industry self-regulation.
HAMILTON, N.Y. Before essayist and critic Susan Sontag broke into print, the words "summer" and "camp" were almost synonymous. They used to add up to a period of alfresco fun and games.

LIKE everything else, the houseparty play has undergone changes in a generation or two. Instead of a country house, it now takes place in a luxury apartment. Instead of a group of guests appropriate to the nineteentwenties or thirties, it now includes a second-generation Jew, a frank homosexual, a Black Muslim girl.

ROSAMOND, Calif., June 17 Frank Yslas was wiping a customer's windshield at his gas station here as a tremendous sonic boom suddenly thundered across the landscape, rattling his garage windows and causing the car to shudder.

WASHINGTON, June 20 The Supreme Court agreed today to take a second look at the constitutionality of the oath denying Communist association that New York State requires of its public school, university and college teachers.
WASHINGTON, June 20 Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision and a dissenting opinion in the case of drunk-driving tests:
DETROIT, June 20 (AP) Seventh-Day Adventists were told today that their churches were still holding regular services in Communist China and that Chinese bibles were being distributed on the mainland.

Continental Airlines, Inc., announced yesterday it had placed orders for 10 new jet airliners. It also took options on five more and signed an interim agreement to lease another five, also with an option to buy.

ROME, June 20 Dr. Gunnar Myrdal, the Swedish economist, said today that the earth's hunger crisis and the threatened population explosion made land reform an "urgent matter for survival" in the underdeveloped countries.

An American voluntary agency denied yesterday that aspirin it had donated to Algeria in the winter of 1963 had been included in a four-ton shipment of medicine given to the Vietcong earlier this year by the Algerian Government.

WASHINGTON, June 20 McGeorge Bundy, president of the Ford Foundation and a former Presidential adviser, called today for a clear-cut declaration by West Germany accepting the Oder-Neisse border with Poland as a part of any European peace settlement.
The Air Force is shopping for computers, and in a big way.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 20 (UPI)-A special Federal census report revealed today that the typical family purchasing power of Negroes and other minority groups in Los Angeles declined by $400 from 1960 to 1965.

MAPLEWOOD, N.J., June 20 William Hoard Adams, chairman of the science department at Maplewood Junior High School, died yesterday of a heart attack while playing ball in the yard of his home with his 5-year-old son, William Thomas.

The Chicago North Western Railway announced yesterday that it had reached its goal of getting acceptances to its exchange offer from a majority of holders of Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad stock.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., June 20 Mr. and Mrs. Matthew Hale of Alexandria and Westport, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Preston Hale, to Jon Michael Sheeser, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. LaRue Sheeser of Olean, N.Y. An Aug. 27 wedding in Westport is planned.
In another frenzied day of trading, wheat and soybean futures set life-of-contract highs on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday.
Stock prices seesawed in quiet trading yesterday, ending with a slight decline.
The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company announced here yesterday the election of John W. Lapsley and James A. O'Connor as vice presidents.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) Controller of the Currency James J. Saxon quarreled today with a Department of Justice suit in a State College, Pa., bank case, and announced that his office would fight the department "to the Supreme Court, if necessary."
Thousands of needy old people are being informed this month that the law no longer requires their children to support them and the response from both generations seems to be one of great relief.

WASHINGTON, June 20 Julian Bond, the 26-year-old Negro pacifist who was denied his seat in the Georgia Legislature after making anti-Vietnam war statements, was granted a hearing today by the Supreme Court.

Mr. and Mrs. Reginald S. Tonry of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Helene Tonry, to James George Manczak, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Manczak of Crystal Lake, Ill.

The Communist party, U.S.A., said yesterday it had invited "fraternal delegates" from 85 countries to attend its national convention starting tomorrow. The State Department said it had instructed consuls to deny visas for such visitors.
OTTAWA, June 20 The new $800-million wheat and flour sale to the Soviet Union was hailed on all fronts today as giving a great and sustaining impetus for the Canadian economy.
WASHINGTON, June 20 Yields on the new issues of Treasury bills fell to their lowest point in six months in today's weekly auction.
High hopes were abundant in the money and capital markets yesterday as investment bankers headed toward the largest weekly volume of new issues in more than a year.

The city plans to use a new state law soon to identify the owners of hundreds of slum buildings here and hold them responsible for making repairs, Buildings Commissioner Charles G. Moerdler said yesterday.

White, Negro and Puerto Rican proponents of an educational park in Brooklyn, who, according to their attorney, "have caught the Board of Education in the act of extending segregation," will ask Dr. James E. Allen, the State Education Commissioner, to intervene on their behalf.
WESTBURY, L.I., June 20 All Ben Webster wants out of 1966 is to get through it.
HARRISBURG, Pa., June 20 (UPI) The Roman Catholic bishops of Pennsylvania took a firm stand today against the state's distribution of birth control information to families on relief.
The American Stock Exchange traced an irregular pattern yesterday as the pace of trading continued slow.
SHUSHAN, N. Y., June 20 Trout fishing fans will find that not only is the season at its peak right now, but water conditions in New York State also are generally better than in several years.
Ann Luckey Bowman, a concert singer and voice teacher, known professionally as Ann Luckey, died Saturday of a heart ailment at the Meadow Lake Infirmary Unit in Hightstown, N.J. She was 81 years old.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 20 (AP) Vice President Humphrey indicated today that he would look with disfavor on a September primary race against Lieut. Gov. A.M. (Sandy) Keith by either Gov. Karl F. Rolvaag or Robert E. Short, Minneapolis businessman.
The Astor and Sheraton-East Hotels will close in the next few weeks to make way for skyscraper office buildings. The closings will come some months sooner than expected.

DAMASCUS, Syria, June 20 The split between left-wing and right-wing bishops of the ancient Eastern Orthodox Patriarchate of Antioch over the election of a new Bishop of Latakia in northwestern Syria has been "frozen" until about July 20, when a new meeting of the Episcopal Synod of Antioch is scheduled.
James Speed Pirtle, a furniture consultant, died Sunday at Madison Avenue Hospital. He lived at 230 East 50th Street.
DETROIT, June 20 (AP) Automobile production continued to decline last week, partly because of plant shutdowns for changeovers to 1967 models.
WASHINGTON, June 20 The Supreme Court limited today the right of arrested civil rights demonstrators to remove their trials from state courts to the Federal courts.
The Democratic voters in Brooklyn's Thirteenth Congressional District have an opportunity in the primary on June 28 to improve the standards of their representation in Congress.

STRATFORD, Conn., June 20 At yesterday's mati nee the American Shakespeare Festival Theater opened this season's second play, which is not by Shakespeare. "Murder in the Cathedral," T.S. Eliot's celebrated drama about Thomas Becket, was written in 1935. This production is good enough to test the play's power of theatrical survival.
WASHINGTON, June 20 (UPI) The Supreme Court agreed today to examine a wideranging challenge by the American Civil Liberties Union to practices in Arizona's juvenile courts.

The departure of Nicholas Johnson as Federal Maritime Administrator augurs a period of possibly up to a year of relative inactivity and little change in Federal maritime affairs, shipping sources said here yesterday.
DANANG, South Vietnam, June 20-Four weeks ago today, Buddhist dissidents marched out of the Tinh Hoi Pagoda, their key bastion here, and surrendered to Government troops.
Herbert Alan Leeds has been named executive head of Gimbels-Pittsburgh, effective Sept. 1, 1966, Bruce A. Gimbel, president of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., announced yesterday.
Hirsch Jacobs, who has led the list of national trainers 11 times in the last three decades, entered Physicians Hospital yesterday morning for a rest. His son John said that the 62-year- ...

The election of Alex E. Schneiderman as senior vice president and a member of the executive committee of the United Mortgagee Servicing Corporation has been announced by David S. Loeb, the company's president.
Russell P. Westerhoff, president of Ford, Bacon Davis, Inc., was elected yesterday to the additional posts of chairman and chief executive officer.

WASHINGTON, June 20 Divergent testimony was presented today on the merits of a proposal now before both houses of Congress that would bar ships built or rebuilt outside the United States or documented under foreign registry from carrying cargo restricted to United States vessels.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art, racing to get its house in order for its 100th anniversary in 1970, is in the midst of $4.5million worth of moving and building, all within the 16building yabyrinth it occupies on the Eastern side of Central Park.
WORCESTER, Mass., June 20 Miss Lorna Roxanne Erickson was married to Philipps Barry Palmer Saturday afternoon in the First Baptist Church by the Rev. Dr. Gordon M. Torgersen.
Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer, who will retire at the end of the month as director of the Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton, hopes to write a history of 20th-century physics.
Former Police Commissioner Francis W.H. Adams challenged Senator Robert F. Kennedy yesterday to a television debate on the Democratic primary fight for Manhattan surrogate.
WASHINGTON, June 20 Housing starts declined drastically in May, the Census Bureau reported today.
WASHINGTON, June 20 A bill to grant Americans the right of access to Federal records cleared Congress today and was sent to President Johnson.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 20 John O'Hara, the author, and Mrs. O'Hara of Princeton and Quogue, L.I., have announced the engagement of Mr. O'Hara's daughter, Miss Wylie Delaney O'Hara, to Ens. Dennis Holahan, U.S.N.R., son of Mr. and Mrs. James Holahan of Darien, Conn.

ACF Industries, Inc., and its subsidiaries, a maker of equipment for the railroad, automotive and aerospace fields, registered the highest earnings in its 67-year history, for the third successive year ended April 30.
City antipoverty officials announced yesterday that they had cut their request for Federal funds for the fiscal year beginning July 1 to meet Washington's $36-million program.

BUJUMBURA, Burundi, June 20 (Reuters) The Kabaka (King) of Buganda, who vanished almost a month ago when his palace was shelled and part of his bodyguard slain by Ugandan troops, arrived here today suffering from malaria.

NORTH JUDSON, Ind., June 20 Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Gumz have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marcia Lynn Gumz, to Robert Hicks Devlin Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Devlin of Mount Kisco, N.Y. The wedding is planned for September.

Dr. Elliott S. Shapiro, the outspoken Harlem elementary school principal whose name has become synonymous with efforts to improve education for Negro children, has been appointed director of the Center for Cooperative Action in Urban Education in Rochester.
OTTAWA, June 20 Chester Ronning, Canada's special envoy, has returned from a new peace-feeler mission to North Vietnam without any immediate report of progress on ending the Vietnamese war.
WASHINGTON, June 20 Six unionists who have been convicted twice of conspiracy in the filing of false non-Communist affidavits won the right today to a third trial.
Senator Jacob K. Javits proposed yesterday that the Federal Government spend $35-billion in the next decade as part of a "Marshall Plan" for Negroes and other minority groups.
HACKENSACK, N. J., June 20 Frank Froehling scored two quick victories today in the Eastern clay courts tennis singles championship at the Oritani Field Club.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 20 (Reuters) Two artillery shells fired by American paratroops landed in a village churchyard, killing a 12-yearold South Vietnamese boy and wounding six men, the official Vietnam press agency reported today.
WASHINGTON, June 20 King Faisal of Saudi Arabia arrives tomorrow for a threeday state visit.
BEN ZUCKERMAN, an institution on Seventh Ave nue for more years than he cares to remember, is proving that fashion rules exist for him to break.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 20 Miss Lynda Donelia Wagoner, daughter of the Rev. Walter D. Wagoner and Mrs. Wagoner, was married here today to Fredric V. Vogel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank P. Bogel of Little Falls, N.J. The United Church of Christ ceremony was performed in the garden of the Wagoner home by the bride's father and the Rev. C. Shelby Rooks.

The outlook for the economy during the remainder of this year provides a basis for a possible rally in stock prices of significant proportions, according to the Standard Poor's weekly Investment Advisory Survey.

LONDON, June 20 Prime Minister Wilson hinted strongly today that Communist pressure on the leadership of the National Union of Seamen was responsible for prolonging the maritime strike, which is now in its sixth week.
LIKE many residents of great cities, Stathis and Nia Kelaidis hadn't been aware of the glories at their own door until tourists pointed them out.

PLANDOME, L.I., June 20 Mr. and Mrs. Cedric Raymond Lane of Plandome have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Laura Alice Lane, to Lars Charles Mazzola, son of Mr. and Mrs. L. Charles Mazzola of Springwater, N.Y. The wedding is planned for Aug. 6.

HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., June 20 Paul Kelly, who failed to survive the cut in the United States Open last week on the narrow fairways at the Olympic Country Club course in San Francisco, shot accurately on the wider fairways here today to take the Westchester Professional Golfers' Association title.

The Maritime Administration announced yesterday the addition of eight cargo ships to its Vietnam blacklist, bringing to 18 the number of foreign-flag ships that have called at North Vietnamese ports, thus becoming ineligible to carry Governmentfinanced cargoes out of United States ports.
WASHINGTON, June 20 The Supreme Court ruled today that its new restrictions on police interrogations would not be retroactive.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., June 20 Carl Van Duyne, a Princeton University junior, held the lead after seven of 11 races of the North American intercollegiate single-handed sailing championship on Raritan Bay today. Van Duyne had 69 points after today's six races.
ATLANTA, June 20-The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. appealed today for an end to talk of "black power" among some Negro leaders.

BONN, June 20 The Christian Democratic party's executive today expressed its complete confidence in Dr. Rainer Barzel, who had created a storm with his suggestion in the United States last week that Soviet troops might be allowed to stay on in a united Germany.
THE Summer Tournament of the Westchester Con tract Bridge Association ended Sunday night at Iona College in New Rochelle.

PITTSBURGH, June 20 (AP) Carlos Ortiz, cut over the right eye, saved his world lightweight championship tonight by stopping Johnny Bizzarro, a bouncy hit-and-run artist, in 2 minutes 29 seconds of the 12th round at the Civic Arena.

W. Averell Harriman sharply condemned South Africa's racial policies last night as "an abuse" of freedom and applauded Senator Robert F. Kennedy for having visited that country and spoken out against discrimination.

LONDON, June 20 The Government has persuaded the major cigarette companies to eliminate all advertising on radio and in movie theaters, Health Minister Kenneth Robinson told the House of Commons today.
MOSCOW, June 20 The Soviet Union has again turned to Canada for wheat and flour, purchasing 336 million bushels at a cost of $800-million in Canadian currency.

Fifty-five garage employes at Rockefeller Center crossed the picket line yesterday of striking air-conditioning operators. The garage workers had walked off their jobs in support of the engineers when the strike began June 7 at more than 100 office buildings.
The American Motors Corporation is still fighting to shed its economy-car image.
CINCINNATI, June 20 (AP) -Governor Rolvaag said today he was "leaving the door open" on whether to run for re-election without support from his party.

WASHINGTON, June 20 Despite reports that Seattle and other cities were thinking of canceling regattas, Lee Schoenith of the American Power Boat Association said today he doubted the three deaths in yesterday's President's Cup Regatta would have any effect on the remaining eight events of the 10-regatta unlimited hydroplane racing schedule.
NEW DELHI, June 20 The other night, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi set aside affairs of state and went to a movie. She has not been allowed to forget it.
The spot rate on the British pound continued its renewed sinking spell yesterday in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here.

Eighty-six shows for Broadway, Off Broadway and the road were financed for $15,078,084 for the fiscal year that ended May 31. This was revealed yesterday in a report issued by New York State's Attorney General, Louis J. Lefkowitz. The figures were prepared by his assistant, David Clurman, head of the Theatrical and Syndication Bureau.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, June 21 Thich Tri Quang, the militant Buddhist leader who was placed under virtual arrest yesterday by Premier Nguyen Cao Ky, was taken from his hospital room in Hue this morning by heavily armed paratroops. He was reported to have been taken to a Government villa in Hue.
YONKERS, June 20 Paul Ferrero of Mohansic won the Westchester County public-links golf championship today with 73, 66 139 at Dunwoodie Golf Course.

NEWTON, Conn., June 20 Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Crawford Benedict Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carolynne Lee Benedict, to David Hugh Royce, son of Mrs. Henry Royce of Brookfield and the late Mr. Royce. An April wedding is planned.
PORTLAND, Me., June 20 (UPI) Gov. John H. Reed, a Republican who is a strong supporter of President Johnson's Vietnam policy, won renomination tonight in the Maine primary.
The Civic Assembly, a new group made up of 75 organizations concerned with the management of New York City, held its first meeting yesterday.
Smith, Barney Co., New York investment bankers, announced yesterday the election as directors of Winthrop S. Curvin, John L. Montgomery Jr., Frederick Frank and Thomas F. Githens.

WASHINGTON, June 20- The Senate ethics committee began closed hearings today on charges of official misconduct by Senator Thomas J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut. It immediately ran into controversy over how it was handling its first formal investigation.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20 (AP) Milton J. Shapp, Democratic candidate for Governor of Pennsylvania, and his family divested themselves today of all stock in the Jerrold Corporation, an electronics company that Mr. Shapp founded 18 years ago, to avoid any possible conflict of interest.

MOSCOW, June 20 President de Gaulle arrived in grandeur today and announced France's desire to break the "harmful spell, the rigid confrontation" of the two political blocs formed around the United States and the Soviet Union.

LOS ANGELES, June 21 (AP) A one-year contract involving about 450 grape pickers in the Delano vineyards was signed here today by Schenley Industries, Inc., and the National Farm Workers Association, an independent union.
As the temperature soars, the demand for cold dishes increases. Two cold soups to whet summer appetites are iced mushroom soup and cantaloupe soup, both of...
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 21 The second United Nations Cocoa Conference, expected to adjourn tomorrow, appeared tonight to have failed again to adopt an international agreement on the commodity.
Donald S. Macdonald has been re-elected president of the Real Estate Board of New York for a second term. He is executive vice president of Douglas Gibbons-Hollyday Ives, Inc.

MEDINA, Ohio, June 21 (AP) Heat and rough footing along U.S. Highway 42 reduced the number of marchers in a "Walk for Decent Welfare" from about 100 to less than 30 today the second day of the 155-mile trek to a rally at the State Capitol on June 30.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 21--A sharp conflict of views is developing between some segments of industry and Government over the right approach to air pollution abatement.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 21 American troops have killed 69 of the enemy in an intense engagement in a valley near the central coast, about 240 miles north of Saigon, a United States military spokesman said today. He said American casualties so far had been light.
MADRID, June 21 (AP)--Lynda Bird Johnson slept through lunch today, the first day of her vacation in Spain, and was late for a tour of the royal palace, a sightseeing attraction.
BUCHAREST, June 21 (Reuters) Chou En-lai, Premier of Communist China, returned from a provincial tour tonight to resume talks with Rumanian leaders.
WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) President Johnson signed today five bills authorizing the sale of about $500-million of materials from Federal stockpiles.

The Conservative party has suddenly become a confused issue in the Democratic party primary campaign in Brooklyn's 12th Congressional District. A local Conservative club has endorsed Representative Edna F. Kelly, a Democrat, for re-election. Her reaction added to the confusion.

PORTLAND, Me, June 21 (AP) A confident John H. Reed, already Governor of Maine longer than any other man, looked ahead today to his third stiff general election test do the forthcoming November battle with Democratic Secretary of State Kenneth M. Curtis.
The president of a major advertising agency advised his colleagues in the business yesterday not to try to appeal to teen-agers by trying to talk their language.

So far, the bond market seems to be carrying its heavy load of new issues this week without too much difficulty.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 21 John H. Moran, an assistant professor of philosophy at Manhattan College, was shocked today to find in the mail box of his home at 35 Flint Avenue here a post card that said a book borrowed from the local library in 1945 had not been returned and he owed $1,288,03 in fines, plus 6 per cent interest.

Paperboard production rose 16 per cent with 460,000 tons in the week ended June 18, from 396,400 tons in the corresponding 1965 week, the Paperboard Group of the American Paper Institute reported yesterday.
CAIRO, June 21 Darryl F. Zanuck, board chairman of 20th Century-Fox, has held high-level discussions here on the possible production of the multimilliondollar movie, "Justine," in Egypt.
James H. Meredith said yesterday that he would resume his walk to Jackson, Miss., probably on Friday, joining the marchers at Canton, about 30 miles from the state capital.

With some dazzling earnings news at hand, Tiffany Co. stockholders had reason to be a contented group yesterday. About 75 of them, mostly men, crowded the board room of the big jewelry, watch, silverware and china store yesterday. They asked some keen but pleasantly non-controversial questions.
THE women who want their cake and fashion too have never had it so good.

SAN JUAN, P.R., June 21 (UPI) Puerto Rico defeated Cuba, 76-71, tonight in a Central American and Caribbean Games basketball game that nearly turned into a riot when a spectator tried to pull down the Cuban flag.

CINCINNATI, June 21 The Presidential campaign of 1968 must be on, because Gov. George Romney of Michigan described himself here today as a Republican who is "as conservative as the Constitution, as progressive as Teddy Roosevelt, and as liberal as Mr. Lincoln."

PRINCETON, N.J., June 21 Prof. and Mrs. John Turkevich have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Tamara Grot Turkevich, to Daniel John Skvir, son of the Very Rev. and Mrs. John Skvir of Jersey City.

Paul B. Zuber, a lawyer prominent in the civil rights movement several years ago, was sharply rebuked yesterday in a unanimous opinion handed down by the Appellate Division, State Supreme Court, in Brooklyn.
Two men were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury in connection with what the Government said was a hoax on coin collectors and dealers.
HONG KONG, June 21 North Vietnam was reported today to have rejected a United States proposal for the opening of peace talks while both sides reduce military activities.

Dressed in a yellow helmet and slicker, the Commissioner of Public Works walked through part of a 2.7-mile long tunnel 34 feet under the Lower East Side yesterday and was pleased that not a drop of water fell on him.
Secretary General Thant has performed a useful service in focusing attention again on the real problem in Vietnam, which is to move toward a negotiated settlement of the Communist insurrection.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (UPI) Dick McAuliffe hit a triple and a double to spark the Detroit Tigers to a 5-2 victory over the Washington Senators tonight and provide Dennis McLain with his 11th pitching triumph of the year.

HOLLYWOOD, June 21 (UPI) Sammy Davis Jr., admitting he was "apprehensive and nervous," said today that he would lead a group of show business personalities to Mississippi this weekend to help support the civil rights march.

The president of New York University denied yesterday charges that the university was trying to bilk the United States Government by constructing a building largely for administrative purposes with Federal funds earmarked for a library.

BONN, June 21--Christian Democratic deputies of the Bundestag sharply attacked their Bundestag leader, Dr. Rainer Barzel, as a result of his speeches in Washington and New York last week in which he suggested that Soviet troops might be allowed to stay on in a united Germany.

ST. LOUIS, June 21 The mystery about why the San Francisco Giants felt they couldn't use Bob Shaw grew deeper tonight as Shaw pitched the New York Mets to a 2-1 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals, allowing four hits.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 21 President Zalman Shazar of Israel arrived here today with his wife on the first visit of state to a Latin American country. Crowds stood in the rain to cheer the 77-yearold Israeli leader as he began a six-week tour of Uruguay, Chile, Argentina and Brazil.
Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary announced yesterday the appointment of Detective Hector M. Velez as his personal faide on Puerto Rican affairs.
Edward W. Thomas, chief of New Jersey's motor vehicle inspection bureau, died Monday in Memorial Hospital. He was 56 years old.

Supreme Court Justice Arthur G. Klein declared yesterday that the proposal by Supreme Court Justice Samuel J. Silverman that the Surrogate's Court be consolidated with the State Supreme Court was "ill-conceived, ill-considered and illtimed."
A thousand tickets for the Batman Concert to be held in Shea Stadium Saturday have been stolen from the offices of Mal Braveman Associates at 15 East 48th Street, between Fifth and Madison Avenues.

DETROIT, June 21 This city is no slouch culturally or socially. As if to prove it, the art-minded added a new South Wing to their aristocratic old Detroit Institute of Arts, and then celebrated the opening last night by emerging formally dressed from their suburban Grosse Pointe, Bloomfield Hills and Birming ham lairs for a $100-a-plate dinner.
A long-term leasehold on the 35-story office building at 50 Broadway, between Beaver Street and Exchange Place, has been sold to a group of investors headed by Marvin Finell of Beverly Hills, Calif.

Robert E. Williams, president of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company since last November, has been elected to the additional post of chief executive officer, it was announced yesterday in Youngstown, Ohio.

NEW ORLEANS, June 21 (UPI) Five men identified as Ku Klux Klansmen and another described as an applicant for Klan membership were indicted by the Orleans Parish grand jury today in connection with a series of fire-bombings in 1965.
COLUMBIA, S.C., June 21 (UPI) Gov. Robert E. McNair today accused Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach of trying to violate the secrecy of ballots cast by illiterate Negro voters.

WOODLAWN, Md., June 21 The flickering lights of computers burn late in the sprawling electronic chancellery of the Medicare program here as 11,000 employes of the Social Security Administration headquarters near Baltimore get ready to pay the hospital costs of 19 million older Americans starting July 1.

Prof. Rex DeVern Hopper, retired chairman of Brooklyn College's department of sociology and anthropology and director of a controversial Army-sponsored research project, died Friday of a heart attack in his Washington home. He was 67 years old.

LIVERPOOL, England June 21 (AP) Brian London, the former British heavyweight champion, defeated Amos Johnson in the seventh round tonight when the seventh-ranked contender from Medina, Ohio, was disqualified for butting.
WASHINGTON, June 21 (UPI) The House and Senate approved compromise legislation today to tighten restrictions on the activities of agents representing foreign governments and business interests.

The Rev. P. Arthur Brindisi, pastor of Westminster Presbyterian Church, Utica, has been elected moderator of the Synod of New York of the United Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. His election was uncontested.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP)--Senator Mansfield, in praising Mr. Thant's efforts, said he believed the three-point plan would get "every consideration from President Johnson" if there was some sign that the Communists might accept it.

All three factors combined to give South a serious headache in the diagramed deal.
One of mid-Manhattan's most heavily traveled crosstown streets 57th Street will be repaved this summer from Third to Eighth Avenue.

The Soviet purchase of 336 million bushels of Canadian wheat, over three years, is not expected to have any salutary effect on a depressed world charter market, shipping sources indicated here yesterday.
The Columbia Broadcasting System announced yesterday that it had set aside $500,000 to encourage authors to write original and significant dramas for television.

THE Ford team that finished one, two, three in the 24-hour race at Le Mans, France last weekend, was honored at dinn last night in the Le Chanteclair Restaurant, 18 East 49th Street. Rene Dreyfus, a former French national driving champion, and his brother Maurice,...
The spot rate on the British pound recovered moderately yesterday in fairly active trading on foreign exchange markets here.
Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower handed over yesterday the stamp collection he amassed during his eight years in the White House to Cardinal Spellman.
The American Stock Exchange registered a moderate advance yesterday as volume increased despite a halt in trading because of ticker trouble.

WASHINGTON, June 21 George D. Woods, president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank), said today he would begin a campaign early next month to win increased funds for the International Development Association, the softloan arm of the World Bank.

MADRID, June 21 (Reuters) The body of a Roman Catholic nun, who died 342 years ago, is being medically examined because of a legend that says it has remained undecayed through the centuries by a miracle.

"It's like being introduced to the banking business." That's the way one horseman described yesterday's victory in the filly division of the National Stallion Stakes, which heads today's card Aqueduct.

HAMPTON, Va., June 21 (AP) A 12-acre area of this coastal city, long conditioned to, the scream of jet engines and the clap of sonic booms, began to dig out today from the blitz of a Marine Corps bomber crash.

The engagement of Miss Rhoda C. Levine to Ira Krull, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Krull of the Bronx, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Levine of Riverdale, the Bronx. A September wedding is planned.

WASHINGTON, June 21 Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara, appearing before a Senate subcommittee, ruled out today any question of granting West Germany independent control over nuclear weapons in the foreseeable future.

HARTFORD, June 21 State and local policemen combined today to arrest 37 alleged narcotics peddlers in raids described as the largest narcotics crackdown in the state's history. About 10 others are being sought.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) William P. Bundy, the Assistant Secretary of State for Far Eastern Affairs, flew to Ottawa today, presumably for a report on the latest Canadian peace approach to North Vietnam.
Comsat's proposed rates for Pacific circuits were challenged yesterday by ITT World Communications, Inc.
United Air Lines, Inc., has placed a $220-million order for 18 more DC-8-61 jet airliners and another half dozen DC-8F jet freighters, it was announced yesterday by George E. Keck, president.

BALTIMORE, June 21 (AP) The major manufacturers have agreed to comply with the first minimum standards for automobile tires, which go into effect July 1 in Maryland, Motor Vehicles Commissioner John R. Jewell announced today.

MILAN, Italy, June 21 Ferdinando Innocenti, president of the Innocenti Corporation of Milan and one of Italy's leading industrialists, died today at his villa here after he was taken ill while on vacation at Lake Varese, a nearby resort. He was 74 years old.
HOUSTON, June 21 (AP) John Bateman drove in four runs three on a bases-loaded double as the Houston Astros downed the Los Angeles Dodgers, 7-4, tonight.

The American Electric Power Company has extended for the second time its offer to purchase at $100 a share the common stock of the Michigan Gas and Electric Company. The new extension will expire on Wednesday, July 20, but is subject to earlier termination.

MONTREAL, June 21 (Canadian Press) the movement of freight from the Port of Montreal's waterfront sheds to railway cars remained stalled today as some 600 railroad freight handlers continued a strike.
ANAHEIM, Calif., June 21 (AP) Ed Kirkpatrick drove in four runs with a single and homer tonight as the California Angels beat the Minnesota Twins, 10-7.
The State Board of Social Welfare, which determines welfare policy throughout the state, agreed yesterday to review its rules for giving clients information about birth control.

NEW DELHI, June 21 The Indian Government announced tonight a sweeping liberalization of restrictions on imports. The purpose is to provide more raw materials and spare parts for the country's lagging industrial machine.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., June 21 George Bruce Brooks of Jackson, Nash, Brophy, Barringer Brooks, a New York lawyer for more than 50 years, died at his home here yesterday. He was 76 years old.
WASHINGTON, June 21 After a project by Mayor Lindsay to the Defense Department, the Navy has apparently reversed a decision to abandon providing fire protection at the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 21 Kialoa II, the big masthead sloop belonging to John B. Kilroy of Los Angeles, was nearing Bermuda today as the leader in a race from Newport that had three yachts in difficulty.

SAIGON, Wednesday, June 22 (AP) Premier Ky's military Government eased its blockade of Saigon's Buddhist Institute for one hour today in a conciliatory gesture. But the regime maintained its tough position by promptly arresting as draft dodgers several youths who emerged.

Five City Councilmen sought a Council investigation yesterday of alleged "discriminatory application and enforcement" of the state's Condon-Wadlin Law in a variety of labor disputes here among many groups of city workers since 1950.
MINEOLA, L.I., June 21 Fourteen Nassau County villages elected mayors and trustees today. The only contests were in Bayville and Atlantic Beach, where the incumbent mayors were re-elected.

Ludwig Olshansky will play Mozarts Piano Concerto No. 24 in C minor with the Brooklyn.
LONDON, June 21 (Reuters) A brother of the Kabaka (King) of Buganda asserted today that at least 15,000 people had been killed in Uganda during the last month.

SAN JUAN, P.R., June 21 (AP) Two members of Cuban athletic teams at the 10th Central American and Caribbean Games defected today and took asylum in the United States.
PARIS, June 21--A small Renoir painting of a pensive young woman was sold today for $290,000. It was believed here to be a record price for a Renoir of its size, about 18 by 15 inches.
Negotiators for the World Journal Tribune, Inc., presented a package proposal to the Newspaper Guild yesterday in an effort to end the 58-dayold strike.
Baroness Mary de Schaeck, widow of Baron Paul de Schaeck, an Austrian nobleman, died yesterday in her home at 225 East 74th Street. She was 63 years old.

DUSSELDORF, West Germany, June 21 (Reuters) Konrad Adenauer, former West German Chancellor, accused the United States today of commanding rather than leading the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. He described Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara as a "very harsh man."
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 111.4 on Monday from 111.1 on Friday.

BONN, June 21 Kai-Uwe von Hassel, Minister of Defense, said today that West Germany would buy enough American military equipment, especially transport vehicles, to meet its commitments under its offset purchase agreement with the United States.

WHILE the Cincinnati Reds and the Atlanta Braves, both supposed to be pennant contenders, have grievously disappointed their followers by floundering, the down-rated Houston Astros have been flexing muscles and acting tough, almost as if they felt they actually belonged up there with the big boys. These precocious youngsters have remained in the first division all season, much too young to realize how much consternation they have caused.
At 3:15 yesterday afternoon the temperature in the city reached 93 degrees, the highest so far this year. Seventy-eight minutes later summer arrived.

BALTIMORE, June 21 Mr. and Mrs. Harry Adelberg have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janet Adelberg, to Clive Jay Davis of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Herman Davis of Brooklyn. An August wedding is planned.
Stock prices advanced smartly in brisk trading yesterday. The upswing was led by actively traded issues in the electronics, airline and office-equipment groups.
About 35 persons were standing in line at 3:30 P.M. yesterday when the subscription period expired for stockholders in the mammoth International Business Machines Corporation rights offering.
