LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 21 (AP)--The Federal Bureau of Investigation and a telephone company were ordered today to answer charges of wiretapping in a $4.5-million lawsuit.

HOUSTON, June 21 John W. Mecom, an oil millionaire, resigned today as head of the Texas National Bank of Commerce in an apparent aftermath of a collapsed financial deal with Houston Endowment, Inc., a foundation created by the late Jesse Jones.
MOSCOW, June 21 President de Gaulle, casting himself in the role of a sympathetic but stern envoy from the West, pressed on the Soviet leaders today his message that the days of power blocs are over.

In the old, if not best, American tradition the Democrats, who this year control both houses of the New Jersey Legislature for the first time in half a century, have pushed through a typical gerrymander bill realigning the Garden State's fifteen Congressional districts. They have drawn boundaries to strengthen doubtful Democratic districts and concentrate G.O.P. power in a few hopelessly Republican areas.
WASHINGTON, June 21 Television broadcasts are "not likely" to be relayed by satellites directly to homes, the president of the Communications Satellite Corporation said today.

The Glidden Company achieved record sales and earnings in the nine months ended May 31, according to the results reported yesterday by the diversified producer of paints and other coatings, resins, chemicals and foods.
HACKENSACK, N.J., June 21 Frank Froehling won a pair of matches today and advanced to the quarter-finals of the Eastern clay-court tennis championship at the Oritani Field Club.
Bunker Hill has been one of the market's mystery stocks of late, and the mystery turns out to be somewhat baffling to Mr. C.E. Schwab, the company president.
LONDON, June 21 William Hogarth, General Secretary of the National Union of Seamen, denied any knowledge today of extraneous political control over the British maritime strike.
WASHINGTON, June 21 A Senator presiding at hearings on the antipoverty program suggested today that Sargent Shriver liberalize his agency's family planning rules.

WARSAW, June 21 (AP) Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski declared here tonight that the Polish regime had violated religious and civic rights because, in a manner "unworthy of state authority," it feared the Roman Catholic community.
The police in Brooklyn received a phone call last night reporting a ship collision in the Narrows, and within minutes a Coast Guard helicopter and harbor police launches set out to investigate.

Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Arthur Edward Paget of Tring, Hertfordshire, England, have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Caroline Hermione Paget, to Dr. Theodore Bennett Robbins of New York. He is the son of Mrs. Chandler Robbins 2d of Gloucester, Mass., and the late Mr. Robbins. An autumn wedding is planned.
The benevolent manner of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company's president was not able to placate critics at yesterday's annual stockholders' meeting.

Wheat and soybeans were still the leading actors in some dramatic futures trading yesterday. Both set further contract highs. Later in the session, traders added an anticlimax to the recent days of frenzied trading and rising prices by rushing to take profits.

J. Raymond Jones, the Democratic leader of Manhattan, must be feeling desperate about the outcome of next Tuesday's primary race for surrogate. He has borrowed the shabbiest trick of his Harlem rival, Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr., and raised the cry of racism.
PURCHASE, N.Y., June 21 Adie von Gontard scored six times as Greenwich overcame a four-goal deficit and defeated Blind Brook, 12-8, at Blind Brook Polo Club today.

If you were asked to guess who has been underwriting the largest program of awards in the arts during the last 20 years, you probably would say the Ford or Rockefeller Foundation. But you would be wrong. It is the State Department through its international exchanges under the 1946 Ful-...
The City Planning Commission defended Mayor Lindsay's public housing program yesterday as an important weapon in fighting "hopelessness" in the city's slums.

SIR MALCOLM SARGENT, tanned, slim and suave as well as all men of 71 would probably be if they could, came to Philharmonic Hall last night to begin his third season of "Promenades" with the New York Philharmonic.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, June 21--Among the many virtues of the widely based Holland Festival is the emphasis it places upon dance, enfolding in its festive grasp both the very internationally oriented Netherlands companies, and also including dance visitors from overseas.
In a move to combat gypsy taxicabs, the Independent Taxi Owners Council began issuing new vehicle identification emblems to its members yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 21 The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has protested to the Government that a Georgia hospital transferred patients to fool Federal investigators into believing it had complied with nondiscrimination requirements of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.

Mr. and Mrs. Solomon Goodz of Ste. Sophie, Quebec, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carol Goodz, to Lewis R. Kaster. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin C. Kaster of New York. Plans have been made for a fall wedding.

CAIRO, June 21 The Soviet Union and China are vying for control of the leftist AfricanAsian Writers' Organization scheduled to meet in Peking to discuss solidarity with North Vietnam, well-placed Asian sources said today.
WASHINGTON, June 21 With the Arabic greeting "Ahlan wa Sahian," or "Welcome," President Johnson warmly greeted King Faisal of Saudi Arabia today as he began a 10-day state visit to the United States.

Gulf States Land and Industries, Inc., moved into the black during the first five months of this year and should increase its earnings during the rest of 1966, C. Leslie Rice, president, said yesterday.
ROME, June 21 Pope Paul VI was reported today to have received with great interest a proposal presented by an American rabbi for a conference of world religious leaders of all faiths.

An Episcopal priest, the Rev. James A. Gusweller, is conducting his own investigation of the fire that reduced his church to a stone shell last December and of what he considers to be related criminal activities on West 84th Street near Columbus Avenue.

A NOVELTY in television news commentary was introduced last night when Eric Sevareid of the Columbia Broadcasting System gave a half-hour personal analysis of the war in Vietnam. Only sparing illustrations were employed; essentially the program consisted entirely of Mr. Sevareid's own words.
GENEVA, June 21 Christian A. Herter, President Johnson's special trade representative, will arrive here July 4 for talks as the Kennedy round of tariff-cutting negotiations nears the showdown stage.

GLEN RIDGE, N.J., June 21 Richard F. Cook, head of financial public relations for the Ethyl Corporation, New York chemical producers, died yesterday in Mountainside Hospital, Montclair. He was 45 years old and lived at 9 Hathaway Place.

LUCERNE, Switzerland, June 21 (AP) Nelson Pessoa of Brazil finished 3 points ahead of Frank Chapot of Wallpack, N.J., and won the European equestrian championship today at an international horse show.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 21 (AP) Roberta Albers of Miami, the defending champion, led the advance to the second round of match play today in the women's collegiate golf tournament.

MANCHESTER, N.H., June 21 Mr. and Mrs. Louis C. Wyman have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jo Ann Wyman, to James Barry Coughlin. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Coughlin of Concord.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 21 A peaceful settlement of the five-year-old Kurdish guerrilla war against Iraqi authority appears likely, according to information received here by Kurds loyal to Gen. Mustafa alBarzani, the rebel leader.

Frank E. Kennamer Jr., an assistant general counsel for the Securities and Exchange Commission, said in Federal Court here yesterday that it was "a nearly impossible task to define a rule fitting all situations" in which corporate insiders may or may not trade in their companies' stock.
All New Yorkers are invited to an early nineteenhundreds costume party on the Mall in Central Park tonight, to launch the 49th season of Guggenheim Memorial Concerts by the Goldman Band.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) Cigar wholesalers went before the Senate Antitrust subcommittee today in an appeal to legalize exclusive territorial franchise contracts between manufacturers and distributors.
WASHINGTON, June 21 The airlines have been warned bluntly to reduce flights into Washington National Airport or have them reduced by the Government.
Mayor Lindsay wielded his economy ax yesterday and announced that he had effected immediate savings of more than $200,000 a year.

NANCY, France, June 21 Although the Tour de France, a 2,641-mile, 22-day bicycle race around France with a dip into Italy, is all work and no play for the 130 competitors, the scenery can be educational.

The fire that followed the collision of two tankers in New York harbor last Thursday apparently started with an explosion on an escorting tugboat, according to testimony presented yesterday to a Coast Guard Board of Inquiry in the Custom House.
ALBANY, June 21 Governor Rockefeller has endorsed a bill to provide immediate and long-term financial help for the City University, thus apparently assuring the measure's passage.

SAIGON, Wednesday, June 22 (AP)--Three captured United States fliers were paraded before an anti-American rally in North Vietnam and threatened by a shouting crowd which demanded that the pilots be put on trial, according to the Hanoi radio.

Mayor Lindsay urged this city's Representatives yesterday to press in Congress for additional Federal funds that would at least restore the $16-million the Government cut from city antipoverty projects.
The first quarter-century of summer band concerts in Bowling Green Park was celebrated yesterday when the Downtown Manhattan Band gave the first of this summer's series of 12 weekly concerts.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 21 Lieutenant General Suharto was assured today nearly two more years as Indonesia's de facto ruler.

INDIANOLA, Miss., June 21 The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. said today that he and... other civil rights leaders would return to Philadelphia this week "with a large segment" of their Mississippi marching force and "straighten the place out."

CHICAGO, June 21 (AP) Juan Marichal yielded 10 hits, including three home runs, but became the first major league pitcher to win 13 games as the San Francisco Giants rallied to defeat the Chicago Cubs, 9-7, today.
At the age of 98, Sebastian Spering Kresge stepped down yesterday as chairman and a director of the variety and general merchandise chain bearing his name.

The momentum of national economic expansion is too great to justify fears of a decline this year, but "the business boom is expected to lose some steam" in early 1967, said William C. Freund, chief economist of the Prudential Insurance Company.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 21--Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. J. Richard Poisson, formerly of Princeton, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Elizabeth Poisson, to William Parker Westcott. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter U. Westcott of Chatham, N.J., and Pownal, Vt.
WASHINGTON, June 21 The recent steep increases in consumer prices moderated in May, the Labor Department reported today.
Prices on the London stock market drifted off yesterday amid growing gloominess in the seamen's strike.
J. Burch McMorran, State Superintendent of Public Works, accused the Lindsay administration yesterday of unwarranted "interference" in the planning for superhighways aided by state and Federal funds.
SHUSHAN, N.Y., June 21 This is a fable, with apolo gies to Aesop, a story of innocence and arrogance, in which innocence prevails.

TORONTO, June 21 A leader of American Reform Judaism sharply indicted leaders of all faiths tonight for what he described as their failure in not going beyond the "statement phase" in molding public opinion to achieve peace in Vietnam.
ALBANY, June 21 After bitter wrangling, the Senate postponed today a vote on new taxes for New York City because of a lack of votes.

YAZOO CITY, Miss., June 21 Tonight at a rally in Yazoo City, Dr. King lashed out at the student committee's policy of advocating "black power" and at the Deacons for Defense and Justice, which urges Negroes to arm themselves in self-defense.
Deputy Mayor Timothy W. Costello told 300 elderly persons in east Harlem yesterday that Mayor Lindsay was exploring ways to put the elderly to work helping each other.

THE importance of childhood experience in formation of adult character was known to generations of writers before it became a cliche of modern psychology. Most writers, we can be sure, have been tempted to write about that unique, marvelous or dreadful experience, their own childhood. Many have done so; few with such radiant success as Jon and Rumer Godden in their delightful volume of joint...
MAYS LANDING, N.J. June 21 (AP)--The owner of a nudist camp here has apologized to a Negro woman who was barred from the park, the chief of the state Division on Civil Rights said today.

The City Council voted overWhelmingly yesterday to ask the Legislature to pass the tax package agreed on by state and city leaders. However, during a heated debate, Council members made it clear that no one was happy with the Albany com promise.
L. Judson Morhouse, former chairman of the state Republican Committee, was released yesterday in his own custody from Sing Sing prison at Ossining, N.Y., pending appeal.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 22 (AP) The Israel Philharmonic Orchestra tonight inserted a correction in its program brochure explaining the recent decision of the orchestra's board to lift a ban on the playing of the works of Richard Wagner and Richard Strauss.
WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) Congress completed action today on a bill that will require the breakup of the Alfred I. du Pont estate in Florida and the Washingtonbased Financial General Corporation.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 21 Secretary General Thant will visit the Soviet Union this summer to enlist Soviet support for his drive for peace in Southeast Asia, highly placed diplomats said today.

The North Vietnam Communist party has sent a cabled message to the Communist party, U.S.A., professing "great encouragement" at opposition by some Americans to the Johnson Administration's policy in Vietnam.
San Francisco Oakland Helicopter Airlines, Inc., reported an agreement yesterday that will bring a profit this year to the company, which lost $342,739 in 1965, according to M.F. Bagan, president.
Directors of the Meredith Publishing Company elected Darwin D. Tucker yesterday as president. He succeeds Fred Bohen, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer.
SYDNEY, Australia, June 21 Arthur A. Calwell, leader in the Australian Parliament of the Opposition Labor party, was shot but not seriously wounded as he left a political rally in Sydney tonight.

In a clamorous sequence that the Mets would have envied, the Yankees split a doubleheader with the league-leading Baltimore Orioles last night, but in the process lost one of the wildest arguments in the history of Yankee Stadium.
A comprehensive plan for lower Manhattan from Canal Street to the Battery was released by the City Planning Commission yesterday.

IN his two years of absolute rule, King Faisal Abdel Aziz al-Saud al-Faisal of Saudi Arabia has unfolded economic and social reforms designed to transform feudal customs and attitudes that had remained virtually unchanged...

Directors of the Horn Hardart Baking Company took no action here yesterday on the dividend normally declared at this time. In the two preceding quarters, the company paid $1 a share, with the last payment on April 1.

WASHINGTON, June 21--The Senate ethics committee decided today that its investigation of charges of official misconduct by Senator Thomas J. Dodd on behalf of Julius Klein will require the testimony of Mr. Klein, after all.
DETROIT, June 21 (AP) The 56-year-old manager of a Detroit cartage concern was charged today with a $5-million warehouse receipts fraud.
WASHINGTON, June 21 An auto safety bill going beyond the Administration's proposals was unanimously approved by the Senate Commerce Committee today.

PARIS Exactly 25 years ago Adolf Hitler turned upon his partner in depredation and launched more than 250 divisions in a massive attack on the Soviet Union. The object was to bring down Stalin and destroy Communist Russia. Instead, it ended by bringing down Hitler and destroying Nazi Germany.
The Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University will increase the number of physicians it is training by 25 per cent, as part of an increased enrollment in several of its programs.

NOW that Bergdorf Goodman has hired Jo Hughes (who for 12 years acted as fashion counselor for leading socialite matrons at De Pinna) to start as sales coordinator in August, the Bergdorf beauty salon is enticing society's daughters with Hugh Harrison. Mr. Harrison...
