Economic forecasters seem to be in agreement that the boom in business activity has undergone a change in character. They are, however, in sharp disagreement about what the change will mean. The consensus now is that the boom has lost some of its vigor and momentum and much of the inflationary psychology that had been present earlier in the year.
WASHINGTON, June 21 When President Johnson appointed Abe Fortas to the Supreme Court, it was widely predicted that he would be a liberal Justice.

WASHINGTON, June 21 The Senate Foreign Relations Committee will report to the floor tomorrow a bill to put three of its members on the committee supervising activities of the Central Intelligence Agency.
Chester L. Morrison, who retired this year after 15 years as a senior editor of Look magazine, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 66 years old.
The beautification of City Hall continues. Some years ago it was cleaned and brightened up on the outside, then a little later it was floodlighted at night.

The election of Dr. Laurence McKinley Gould, former president of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, as chairman of the board of trustees of Prescott College, which will open at Prescott, Ariz., this fall, was announced yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 21 (AP) Samuel Goldwyn won a $1,242,500 out-of-court settlement today at the finish of a 16-year legal battle against Twentieth CenturyFox film corporation and major theater chains.
ELIZABETH, N.J., June 21 Getzel Wachtel of 318 Monmouth Road, a former real estate broker here, died yesterday at his home.
WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) Seven women members of Congress urged President Johnson today to go beyond his present recommendations for wiping out sex discrimination in jury service.
ALBANY, June 21 The Assembly killed today a Lindsay administration bill that would have permitted the state for the first time to build state parks and recreation areas in New York City.

HINGHAM, Mass., June 21--The marriage of Miss Clara H. Perkins of South Dartmouth, daughter of Charles B. Perkins of Wakefield, R.I., and the late Mrs. Elizabeth Nowell Perkins, to Clay V. Stites took place here this afternoon. The bridegroom is the son of Mrs. Edgar Stites of Margate, N.J., and...

The Association of Personnel Agencies of New York, spokesman for the more than 1,200 private personnel agencies in the state, announced yesterday the election of Anthony Kane as president for the year beginning July 1.

The associate director of the Congress of Racial Equality said yesterday that the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. "shows a basic misunderstanding of what the Negro on the farm and on the streets is really asking for."

RIVERHEAD, L.I., June 2l In five contests in 16 elections today, Suffolk voters upset two village administrations: in North Haven and Belle Terre. The results of the elections where there were contests follow.
Civilian experts on poverty, delinquency, civil liberties and psychiatry will lecture probationary policemen during the fall, in the start of a major revision of police training here.

ALBANY, June 21 The Republican majority in the State Senate, shaken by widespread upstate protests against the state's new medical care law, pushed through 11 amendments today designed to lessen its scope and cost.

Frank H. Van Derbeck, who retired in 1964 after having been a hardware manufacturers' sales representative here for many years, died Friday of a heart attack in the home of his son, the Rev. Holmes N. Van Derbeck, in Springfield, Mass. He was 89 years old and lived at 4 Green Acres Drive, Verona, N.J.

WASHINGTON, June 21 Through a spate of hearings on Capitol Hill, through Gaullist diplomacy in the Kremlin and through political ferment along the Rhine, the pressure is building up for a new American answer to an old and perplexing European riddle; Which should come first, German reunification or East-...
WASHINGTON, June 21--The Republican National chairman, Ray C. Bliss, said today that overconfidence was the main threat to G.O.P. victory in this November's elections.
JERSEY CITY, June 21 Tension continued tonight in an ethnically mixed downtown neighborhood after two nights of clashes between Negroes and Puerto Ricans.

William L. Kallman, a retired fuel industry executive, died at his home early Monday, after returning from the 50th reunion of his class at Yale University. He was 71 years old and lived at 40 East Ninth Street.
King Faisal of Saudi Arabia will be the official guest of the city and Mayor Lindsay when he arrives at La Guardia Airport tomorrow evening for a week's visit.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 21 (UPI) The atomic-powered carrier Enterprise, the world's largest warship, returned home today after eight months of launching attacks against enemy forces in Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) Miss Hilda Siff, a social science analyst in the research division of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, died today of a heart attack in her home.

The Delaware Hudson and the Erie-Lackawanna Railroads plan to ask the Interstate Commerce Commission by July 11 to delay the merger of the Pennsylvania and the New York Central Railroads, pending the inclusion of the Delaware and Hudson and the Erie-Lackawanna in a merged railroad.
PARIS, June 21 The Western allies sharply quesioned the French today on the basic role French forces in Germany will play in Western defenses in the future.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 21 There being no greater wagering risk in harness racing than betting on 2-year-old trotting fillies, it was hardly surprising that the fans poured only $139,318 into the mutuel machines for tonight's seventh edition of the $27,074.25 Proximity at Roosevelt Raceway.

Waterfront employers in the Port of New York have reported that less than half of the dock force of 22,500 longshoremen get full-time work at their regular piers and that the others fill out their Monday through Friday work week by working for employers other than their regular companies.

When Mrs. Nathan Franco of Queens Village was a pupil in Junior High School 115 in Manhattan she and her schoolmates used to sing a song that began: "To thee, First City of our land" a musical tribute to New York City.
Benton Bowles, Inc., announced yesterday the election of Alfred L. Goldman as executive vice president.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 21 The United States Air Force turned its attention yesterday to a column of 10 water buffalos sighted along a road just north of the Mugia Pass on the Laotian-North Vietnamese border.
The "old boys" of P.S. 10 came back to their old school and their old neighborhood yesterday. Both were gone.
Kentucky will have two outdoor shows in honor of Daniel Boone, the state hero, within 60 miles of each other.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 21 Final briefs were filed today in the Government's legal battle against the $3.75-billion merger of two California banking giants. The Controller of the Currency, James J. Saxon, is vigorously supporting the banks.
CHICAGO, June 21 (AP) Four Puerto Rican community organizers from New York said today they would lead Chicago Puerto' Ricans in a protest march on City Hall next Tuesday.
RANGOON, Burma, June 19 At this time of the year the famous Burma Road is almost impassable because of landslides and washouts.
MURRAY HILL, N.J., June 21 Computers are now getting into the movie-making business, though Doris Day and Rock Hudson need not fear for their jobs.
WASHINGTON, June 21 King Faisal of Saudi Arabia was honored at the White House tonight at one of the rare stag state dinners given in this century by a President.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) Senate-House conferees were reported to have reached tentative agreement today on a 3.2 per cent pay increase for some three million persons now on active duty in the military and other uniformed services.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., June 21 In the last few years the home of Max Epstein on Glenview Road here has been robbed seven times. The family losses in jewels, furs and household items total nearly $200,000.
WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) A 10-year Congressional struggle to liberalize Federal bankruptcy laws succeeded in the Senate today.
Mrs. Pat Edrich of New York, seeded first, had little trouble in gaining the third round of the annual Rose Taubele Memorial tennis tournament yesterday despite an injured right arm.

The Allied Stores Corporation, operator of Stern Brothers, Gertz Long Island, and more than 100 other department stores, expects its sales in the present fiscal year to exceed $1-billion for the first time, Theodore Schlesinger, president, said at the annual meeting here yesterday.
Troubled by the growing deterioration of Bryant Park, Parks Commissioner Thomas P. F. Hoving has called a meeting tomorrow of the area's community leaders to discuss plans to restore the park.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 21 Thich Tri Quang, a prisoner in a Saigon maternity clinic, vowed tonight to continue his campaign to bring down the Government of Premier Nguyen Cao Ky.

PLEIKU, South Vietnam, June 21 (UPI) Capt. William S. Carpenter Jr., hero of the recent fighting near Kontum, said today he was "reluctantly" becoming an aide to Gen. William C. Westmoreland, United States commander in Vietnam.
GLASGOW, Scotland, June 21 For the first time in British naval history, and only for the time being, two women will officially be part of the crew of a warship.

SUMMIT, N.J., June 21 Howard H. Edge of 40 Prospect Hill Avenue, an industrial engineer and a brother of the late Gov. Walter E. Edge of New Jersey, died today at Overlook Hospital. He was 95 years old.
JERICHO, L.I., June 21 Mrs. Murray Gordon of Elmwood, the medalist, led the way into the second round of the 63d Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship today.

ONE the world's leading bridge writers arrived in New York Tuesday, en route to the Summer National Championships in Denver next month. He is Tannah Hirsch, a South African who has been working for a newspaper in Israel for the last six years.

WESTERHAM, England, June 22--Chartwell, the manor house whose illustrious owner once declared that a day away from it was "a day wasted," was opened today to the public as a memorial to Sir Winston Churchill.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 22--MIG-17 jet fighters shot down a United States Navy F-8 Crusader yesterday over North Vietnam. It was the first American aircraft lost to enemy jets in over a year.
Top officials of the Newspaper Guild and the World Journal Tribune, Inc., sought yesterday to remove the final obstacles to a settlement of the 59-day-old newspaper strike.

WHEN Pierce Egan, the British historian, wrote the first definitive work on boxing in 1818, he referred to the sport as "the sweet science." If that phrase ever had any basis in fact--which is doubtful--it certainly could not be applied to George Chuvalo of Canada and Oscar Bonavena of Argentina, a pair of rugged heavyweights who will attempt mayhem on each other in Madison Square Garden tonight.
The voice of the people has been heard in Washington Square Park. By 1967, or 1968, the park is expected to be a greener place, with pleasant pathways, a new fountain display and no roads.
The Lindsay administration's sincerity in the ambitious new plan for the redevelopment of lower Manhattan was questioned yesterday by the Port of New York Authority.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., June 22 --Mr. and Mrs. William James Fleming have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Doris Gay Fleming, to Howard Joel Woronov, son of Mr. and Mrs. Emanuel M. Woronov of Syracuse, N.Y.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, June 22 (Reuters)--Danish pilots of the Scandinavian Airlines System returned to work today after an eight-day strike over pay and working conditions.
Two policemen have been transferred from a Harlem precinct and are under investigation as a result of charges involving perjury and the alleged beating of a 46-year-old former convict.
Jackie Robinson has shelved his plan to organize an interracial life insurance company and has decided instead to become a major stockholder and officer of an existing company.

CINCINNATI, June 22 (AP) --The Midwestern Governors' Conference asked Congress today to eliminate all tolls on cargo shipped on the St. Lawrence Seaway as the 13-member group closed its fifth annual conference.

BENTON, Miss., June 22-- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and two other civil rights leaders asked President Johnson today to send Federal marshals to protect a second march on the courthouse at Philadelphia, Miss., on Friday.

OCEANPORT, N.J. June 22 (UPI)--Pete Anderson brought Indian Sunlite up from 12th place today and the 3-year-old bay thundered down the stretch for a $40.40-for-$2 victory payoff in the $23,575 Post-Deb Stakes at Monmouth Park.
A Securities and Exchange Commission investigation of activity in Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation stock has been forwarded to the Justice Department for possible criminal prosecution.

Stockholders of the American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., and the Electric Bond and Share Company were assured yesterday by their managements that growth is continuing along lines projected in the past.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP)--The Senate passed a bill today designed to prevent the theft of pet animals for use in research and to require greater care of research animals.

The Mayor's Committee on Scholastic Achievement, asserting complete independence of the city, challenged last night both Mayor Lindsay's authority to abolish it and his statement that he was saving $50,000 a year by doing so.

Howard J. Samuels, Democratic aspirant for the Govnorship, renewed his proposal yesterday that delegates meet two or three weeks before the convention for a secret ballot to pick the party's candidate.
A three-alarm pier fire in South Brooklyn tied up traffic on the Belt Parkway for more than an hour yesterday, causing cars to back up in both directions for more than a mile.

CINCINNATI, June 22 (AP) --Bill Mazeroski's wild throw allowed Jim Maloney to score the winning run in the ninth inning tonight as the Cincinnati Reds defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 4-3. The victory was the Reds' fifth straight.

TORONTO, June 22--Amid a 90-minute sharp debate, marked by frequent gavel-banging to stop interruptions and objections, spiritual leaders of American Reform Judaism adopted today a statement that scored the Administration's policy in Vietnam.

ALBANY, June 22--With the Chancellor of the City University looking on, the Assembly passed a bill today to bail the university out of its financial difficulties and guarantee admission this fall to 2,278 qualified freshmen who had been rejected because of a lack of facilities.

Mayor Lindsay is fighting back against the Federal Government's refusal to grant the city $8-million to strengthen enforcement of the housing code and improve community facilities in eight areas of the city.

ALBANY, June 22--Governor Rockefeller signed a bill today raising the minimum hourly wage in the state to $1.50. The 25-cent increase, which will go into effect Jan. 1, will give New York the highest minimum wage in the nation.
Mayor Lindsay was reconsidering early today the city's plans to give an official dinner and reception tonight to visiting King Faisal of Saudi Arabia.
St. John's University announced yesterday the appointment of a layman to the second highest policy-making post of the 96-year-old institution.

WASHINGTON, June 22-- King Faisal of Saudi Arabia was momentarily ruffled today by being asked at a news conference which he considered the greater enemy: Israel or the United Arab Republic. His reply was a mixture of regal vehemence and ambiguity.

HOUSTON, June 22 (AP)-- Sandy Koufax allowed 10 hits, but staggered to his 13th victory as the Los Angeles Dodgers beat Houston, 5-2, tonight before 50,908 fans--the largest crowd to see a baseball game in the Astrodome.
THE PRESIDENT Signed the Bail Reform Act of 1966; met with King Faisal of Saudi Arabia and later attended reception given in his honor by King Faisal at the Saudi Arabian Embassy.

New York, sometimes a visionless city, was presented with a vision this week. The City Planning Commission released a sound, comprehensive design for the future of the area from Canal Street to the Battery, the city's compacted, dramatic heart and historic core. The proposals range from an immediate solution for critical circulation problems in the congested financial district to creation by the year 2000 of a spectacular new waterfront of parks, plazas and walk-to-work housing.
WINNIPEG, Man., June 22-- A general election in Manitoba tomorrow promises clues that may be highly significant for the political future of Canada.

The country's graduate schools are facing a floodtide of applications and a crisis of shortages in staff and facilities. Within three years it may be more difficult to get into a graduate shool than it has been to get into an undergraduate one.
LONDON, June 22--Sotheby's art auction house today demonstrated once again that the value of a painting is not determined by its size.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 22 (UPI)--The Lutheran Church in America re-elected today as president for a four-year term the Rev. Dr. Franklin Clark Fry of New York, who has headed the body since it was formed in 1962.

JACKSON, Miss., June 22-- The Meredith march headquarters here disclosed plans today for massing thousands of Mississippi Negroes, along with white marchers, in a "freedom rally" at the steps of the State Capitol Sunday afternoon.
ALBANY, June 22--The Legislature repealed two of the three sections of the state's 53year-old railroad full crew law today after only an hour of debate.
Robert W.G. Vail, a leading librarian and bibliographer, died Tuesday in Albuquerque, N.M. He was 76 years old.
MARIMEKKO of Finland believes that simplicity is the root of sophistication.

Thirty Reform Democratic leaders charged yesterday that the Democratic and Republican leadership in Manhattan made a package deal involving not only the Surrogate's Court, but three other judicial posts as well.
POMPANO BEACH, Fla., June 22--A tense calm spread through the drab Negro section on the northwest edge of this coastal resort tonight, 24 hours after, a brief riot shredded its usual racial peace.
TOLEDO, Ohio, June 22 (AP) --The Soviet Union won its 13th straight Greco-Roman world wrestling championship today, although one of its defending champions had to settle for second place.

ROME, June 22--A large majority of the experts who will report to Pope Paul VI on the birth-control problem early next week will favor a change in the Roman Catholic prohibition on chemical and mechanical contraception, according to informed sources.
The $15 parking ticket placed on the automobile used by President Johnson's daughter, Lynda Bird, on a recent visit to New York was paid for yesterday in Traffic Court.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22-- Mrs. Nathalie Wilson Clothier, wife of Robert C. Clothier, a former president of Rutgers University, died today of a heart attack, two days before their 50th wedding anniversary. She was 76 years old and lived in Haverford.

"AT the rate the Israelis are going," my consort said during the 1956 Suez crisis, "I won't be at all surprised to hear that they've reached Casablanca." It didn't turn out that way. In the first place, neither Suez nor other points of interest in North Africa were Israeli prime targets.

Lady Brilliance contributed an eponymous performance in the National Stallion Stakes, Filly Division, at Aqueduct yesterday. The Maryland-bred daughter of Globemaster and Staretta, owned by Leonard P. Sasso and ridden by Johnny Rotz, won the 5 -furlong event by eight lengths, to the satisfaction of many in the crowd of 24,389 who made her the favorite in the betting.
The London Stock Exchange was depressed again yesterday by uncertainties arising from fears that the seamen's strike will be prolonged.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 22--Behind his blazing serve and deep volley, America's topranking Dennis Ralston beat Alex Metreveli of the Soviet Union, 6-0, 4-6, 6-4, 6-4, and found himself ideally situated in the Wimbledon tennis draw, today.
This room, with its peaked, beamed ceiling, is the only one containing the original features of the old house before it was bought, expanded and transformed by Sir Winston.
MOSCOW, June 22--President de Gaulle suggested today that France and the Soviet Union should work toward a "new alliance" for scientific and other intellectual pursuits.

WASHINGTON, June 22-- Representative L. Mendel Rivers, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, raised the possibility today that the period of direct draft liability during peacetime might be cut "substantially" below the current age level of 26.
Four common stock offerings were made yesterday and all were oversubscribed. A 500,000share offering of Okonite Company stock was brought to market by a Lehman Brothers syndicate at $17 a share.
Bob Crespino, who caught four touchdown passes inside the 10-yard line last season, returned his signed contract yesterday to the New York Giants of the National Football League.
A $25-million, tax-supported civic center will be built on 23 acres in the heart of downtown Birmingham, Ala., it was announced here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP)--The House passed by a 374-to-10 vote today a bill to broaden the unemployment insurance system to cover 3 million more workers. However the measure ignored other recommendations made by President Johnson.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 111.5 on Tuesday from 111.4 on Monday.

A 52-year-old truck driver for the Department of Sanitation dived into the Harlem River yesterday and rescued a boy who fell from a bulkhead at 132d Street. It was the driver's second rescue in two months.

THE second largest dog show in the United States will be held Saturday and Sunday in Los Angeles. It's the Kennel Club of Beverly Hills fixture. With an entry of 3,330, it is surpassed only by the International in Chicago, with 3,402.

Samuel J. Lefrak's dream of turning part of Queens Boulevard into an area of large office buildings moved a step closer yesterday with the announcement that a payment center of the Social Security Administration was about ready to move to its new Queens home right next door to Lefrak City.
The pirate radio stations that ring the British Isles represent a form of hazardous economic opportunism born of the youthful appetite for rock 'n' roll music.

LONDON, June 22--Prime Minister Wilson promised the House of Commons today that he would provide details next week on his thinly disguised charge that Communist pressure on the leadership of the National Union of Seamen was largely responsible for prolonging Britain's maritime strike.

Governor Rockefeller announced yesterday that the New York State Commerce Department would open an "office of international commerce" in Tokyo to develop sales in the Far East for New York businessmen.

Sixteen of Brooklyn's 40 general hospitals are obsolete and 12 others need major renovations, according to a study made public yesterday by the Hospital Review and Planning Council of Southern New York.

Secretary Rusk's offer to finance an enlarged International Control Commission in Cambodia contributes to containment of the war in South Vietnam. By responding favorably to Prince Sihanouk's proposal, the United States has indicated its desire to limit the conflict; it has also opened the way for a mechanism that could hamper Vietcong use of Cambodian territory as a sanctuary and supply route.
Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that the Legislature had "an obligation" to pass the city's tax program.

The timidity the Legislature has shown on authorizing new taxes to meet New York City's financial crisis stirs fresh anxiety about its mustering enough courage to break the deadlock over a new state law to prevent civil service strikes.

BARCELONA, Spain, June 22--Generalissimo Francisco Franco, still Spain's master politician after 27 years in power, made a triumphant entry today into Barcelona, the capital of the recalcitrant Catalonian region.

The Jewish Family Service elected Donald C. Samuel as president of its board of directors at its annual meeting last night. Lester Ginsburg was re-elected to one vice presidency, and Edward B. Bermas was elected to the other.

The big trading volume Tuesday on the Chicago Board of Trade was reflected yesterday by a delayed opening of an hour and a half. For the world's largest commodity trading center, it was the longest delay anyone remembers in its 118year-old-history. This is testimony to the huge amount of paperwork involved despite the use of computers for clearing operations.
Two of the nation's leading car makers reported yesterday sharp gains in new-car sales, but a third announced a decline for the mid-June period.

Here's a paradox for you. The volume of trading on the Big Board will cross the 1-billionshare mark early today, a level reached much later--Sept. 22-- last year. Yet trading volume in the last five weeks is off 50 per cent from the rate of the six preceding weeks.

The chemical division of the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company announced yesterday that it would build a $10-million plant for the production of silica pigments at its chemical complex at Lake Charles, La. Production is to get under way early in 1968.

WASHINGTON, June 22-- "We are going to do our duty and we will not be scared off." With that decision a year ago this month, James Patrick Boyd Jr., for 12 years a trusted aide of Senator Thomas J. Dodd and for eight years his administrative assistant, finally cut ...

Three gamblers who pleaded guilty to conspiring to bribe the police for protection and to operating a numbers game as a felony were sentenced yesterday to 2 to 3 years in prison by Supreme Court Justice Abraham J. Gellinoff.
UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., June 22--Dr. Louis Francis Peck, professor of English at Pennsylvania State University, died last night at Centre County Hospital in Bellefonte. He was 61 years old.
The two principal candidates for Manhattan Surrogate conceded yesterday that the race had created a political furor beyond their expectations and that neither of them was very happy about it.
The "lady," 9 feet 6 inches tall and demurely robed--her name is Justice--was joined atop City Hall's tower yesterday by three bare-chested men --Pete Kane, John Skochylas and Tony Leach.
WASHINGTON, June 22-- The nation's surplus of exports over imports rose by $100-million in May to about $295-million, the Commerce Department reported today.
PITTSFIELD, Me., June 22-- Dr. Roland E. Morse, a dentist who practiced in New York from 1923 to 1963, died of cancer yesterday in Sebasticook Hospital. His age was 68.
The Metropolitan Fair Rent Committee has appointed Jerry Singleton as executive vice president, it was announced yesterday by Edward Sulzberger, president of the committee.
NEWARK, June 22 (UPI)-- Frank Rotella Jr., head of the New Jersey Ku Klux Klan, resigned his post today without explanation.

CONWAY, N.H., June 22-- Announcement has been made by Mrs. Robert H. Kennett of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Julie Kennett, to Shumway Pitkin Marshall, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Shumway Marshall.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) --Dick McAuliffe led off the game with a home run and Willie. Horton hit a grand slam in a five-run first inning as the Detroit Tigers routed the Washington Senators, 12-2, tonight.

HACKENSACK, N.J., June 22--Herb Fitz Gibbon of West Point, N.Y., the second-seeded player, defeated James Stephens of Riverside, Conn., 6-0, 6-1, today and reached the quarterfinals of the Eastern clay courts championship at the Oritani Field Club.

New Yorkers, who were told last week that they will have to pay more to borrow to buy a car or repair their homes, were told yesterday by the New York Bank for Savings that they will get more on their savings accounts.
CHICAGO, June 22 (AP)-- A coroner's jury ruled today that the drowning of a woman on a boating outing with Charles Walgreen 3d, heir to a drug store chain fortune, was an accident.

I.T.T. World Communications, Inc., said yesterday that it was "gratified over the decision of the Communications Satellite Corporation to reduce charges to common carriers for certain circuits to the Pacific."
Fulton Industries, Inc., of Atlanta, a producer of industrial and consumer textiles, die castings and pre-engineered metal buildings, is planning further diversification.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, June 22--The Government has requested a meeting of the Western Hemisphere's foreign ministers to set the stage for the withdrawal of the Inter-American Peace Force from the Dominican Republic.

JERICHO, L.I., June 22-- Three players from Westchester and one from New Jersey reached the semi-final round of the 63d annual women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship today over the 5,894yard par-71 Meadow Brook course.

BONN, June 22--Government circles in Bonn rejected today a charge by India that West Germany was "dragging its feet" on promised economic aid because of Indian plans to set up a trading agency in East Germany.
WASHINGTON, June 22-- Three Representatives of Long Island moved today to get the Federal Government to act on noise abatement.
Secretary of Commerce John T. Connor said here last night he expected a "modest" increase in the wholesale and consumer price indexes during the rest of the year.

Eaton Yale Towne, Inc., had estimated net earnings of $13,202,000, or $1.78 a share, for the second quarter, on sales approximating $208,891,000, according to a report yesterday of John C. Virden, chairman, and E.L. Ludvingsen, president.
Henry B. McFarland, the 72year-old suspended warden of the Hudson County jail in Jersey City, was sentenced yesterday in Federal Court here to six months in prison and fined $1,000 for perjury.

The staff of the City Planning Commission drafted a decision approving New York University's controversial library project even before a public hearing was held on the case, a Greenwich Village lawyer said yesterday.
A major estate-planning question that is not always given sufficient thought is how life insurance proceeds should be paid to beneficiaries.

CINCINNATI, June 22--Mr. and Mrs. John Hazen Perry have announced the engagement of Mr. Perry's daughter, Miss Priscilla Pollard Perry, to John Paul Houston Morris, son of Mrs. Paul Houston Morris of Washington and the late Colonel Morris of the Army.

Some dramatists who left television to write for the stage and motion pictures said yesterday that they welcomed the Columbia Broadcasting System's proposal to bring back original and significant drama. They said they would be interested in writing scripts for "C.B.S. Playhouse" if permitted

National Periodical Publications; Inc., which owns the copyrights and trademarks of Batman and Robin, filed suit yesterday charging five large merchandising organizations here with selling merchandise that has not been properly licensed.
NEWARK, June 22 (UPI)-- Four teen-age boys were charged with juvenile delinquency today in the second sniper shooting here in two days.

BATON ROUGE, La., June 22 --Assailing the national press, the Supreme Court and liberals generally, Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama told a joint session of the Louisiana Legislature today that the Federal judiciary "is sitting as a continual constitutional convention, changing and altering the law from day to day."

ALGIERS, June 22--The United Nations Special Committee on Colonialism wound up its month-long tour in Africa here today with a resolution calling upon all states and international institutions to refuse their assistance to Portugal and South Africa until these countries abandon what it called their "policies of colonial domination and racial discrimination."
The election of William H. Berry as an executive vice president was announced here yesterday by the Continental Insurance Companies.
HOLLYWOOD, June 22--A new "try-out circuit" for plays and musicals seems to be developing among the theaters-inthe-round that are proliferating across the nation.
The American Stock Exchange reported yesterday the changes carried below in the shareholdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.
SYDNEY, Australia, June 22 --Arthur Calwell, leader of the Opposition Labor party, left the hospital today to fly to his home in Melbourne.
CHICAGO, June 22 (AP)--A three-run fifth inning in the opener and seven runs in the first three innings of the finale gave the San Francisco Giants 3-2 and 9-5 victories over the Chicago Cubs today.
HONOLULU, June 21--Hawaii's Administration is astounded by a Federal move that Gov. John A. Burns views as a threat to the sovereignty of the newest state.

The Theater Guild has sold the picture rights to one Broadway play before it ever appears, and is dealing for another that just finished its run. The play sold is "Say Who You Are," the Keith Waterhouse-Willis Hall comedy now in its second year in London, which will have its opening here Sept. 29 at the Booth Theater.
A man died under the wheels of a train at the IND Utica Avenue station in Brooklyn yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, June 22--The Federal Government's antipoverty legal aid program ran into serious opposition today as leaders of the American Trial Lawyers Association announced their disapproval of the program in its present form.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., June 22 --Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Barclay Giddings Johnson of Plainfield and Point o'Woods, Fire Island, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Allan Johnson, to Richard Franklin Moseley, son of Mrs. John D. Bowe of Bernardsville and Ray Franklin Moseley Jr. of Kansas City, Mo.

WASHINGTON, June 22 --Senator Thomas J. Dodd's former administrative assistant testified in an open hearing today that the Senator made a trip to West Germany in 1964 under "cover" of official business to help salvage a $150,000a-year contract for Julius Klein a Chicago public relations man who had pleaded for his help.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP)--To meet urgent electrical needs in Vietnam, the Army is reactivating 11 World War II oil tankers for conversion into floating power plants.

CHICAGO, June 22--The problem of how an exploding population can live well in less space is being tackled by many furniture designers and manufacturers exhibiting this week at the June International Home Furnishings market here.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., June 22--The engagement of Miss Ruth Adora Gross to Thomas Charles Bove of Maplewood has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Russell Charles Gross, parents of the future bride. Mr. Bove is the son of Mrs. Lawrence Bove of Waterford, Conn., and the late Mr. Bove.
CLEVELAND, June 22-- Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall said here today that the battle against water pollution could be won or lost in Lake Erie.

Mrs. Pat Edrich of New York and the three other seeded contenders in the Rose Taubele Memorial tennis tournament reached the semi-final round yesterday at the New York Tennis Club, 3081 Harding Avenue, the Bronx.

On the theory, perhaps, that he who runs away may live to fight another day, Senate Democrats have forced a postponement of the Legislature's action on Mayor Lindsay's tax program until after next Tuesday's primary elections. Joseph Zaretzki, the Democratic minority leader in the Senate, upset the schedule for a vote this week by insisting that it would take members until Wednesday, the day after the primary, to give the tax measures adequate study.

Herrera Says Aim Is to Lift Group's Influence in World by Joint Trade Policy WASHINGTON, June 22-- Felipe Herrera, President of the Inter-American Development Bank, proposed today a fullfledged Latin American common market that would go far beyond the present free-trade area and include all the Latin American countries. Mr. Herrera provided the terms of his proposal in detail.
It was 50 years ago yesterday that the New York Stock Exchange took on a new page boy--John Aloysius Coleman, by name.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 22 --Robert C. Decker, senior vice president of the New York advertising company. HolleyThomas, Inc., and president of the, Syracuse Alumni Association of Central New Jersey, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Princeton. He was 48 years old.

LONDON, June 22--The head of one of the pirate radio stations that broadcast to Britain was shot and killed late last night under mysterious circumstances. A day earlier his station had been seized by an unidentified raiding party.
John I. Henry, director of communications for The New York Times Company, was elected yesterday as president of the Digitronics Data Acquisition and Transmission Association.
NEW DELHI, June 22-- Prime Minister Indira Gandhi had Kumaraswami Kamaraj to dinner tonight. By evening it was already the most talkedabout dinner party of New Delhi's summer social season.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (UPI)--Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of Brooklyn, accused "some Northern liberatarians" of hypocrisy today for failing to support President Johnson's fair-housing proposal.

WASHINGTON, June 22-- Senator J.W. Fulbright, Democrat of Arkansas who is chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, postponed today the reporting of a bill that would put three members from his panel on the committee supervising activities of the Central Intelligence Agency.

GENEVA, June 22--The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations will resume cooperation with the International Labor Organization tomorrow when the United Nations agency's executive board meets for a one-day session.

The Lee Higginson Corporation, a Wall Street investment company reported to be considering a merger with the securities concern of McDonnell Co., Inc., said yesterday that it was not considering any merger proposals.
Without benefit of legal counsel, the Baltimore Orioles defeated the New York Yankees, 3-0, last night at Yankee Stadium.

WASHINGTON, June 22-- Leonard Bernstein, the music director of the New York Philharmonic, has been commissioned by the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts to compose a major "dramatic work" for the center's opening here in 1969.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 22-- The Conservative party in Nassau County suffered a setback today when the State Supreme Court ruled that a Republican candidate for Congress did not have to accept its support.

Carlos Ortiz, who stepped out of the ring as a battered and barely successful defender of his lightweight championship Monday night, stepped into the political arena yesterday. He said his fight for a state Senate seat would be his toughest bout to date.
The election of Robert P. Gerholz as a director was announced yesterday by Mack Trucks, Inc.

ST. LOUIS, June 22--All sorts of immediate and historic goodies fell to the New York Mets tonight on a 10-inning, two-run single by Cleon Jones that produced a 2-0 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

LONDON, June 22--Morihiro Matsuda of Tokyo, who spent most of his cash assets on an $11,184, two-page advertisement headed "Idea for Peace in Vietnam" in The New York Times, has gone into debt to publish a longer and more expensive advertisement in The Times of London tomorrow.

"THE striped linings were designed by Julian Tomchin," Chester Weinberg announced at the opening of his fall fashion collection a few weeks ago. The next day Donald Brooks informed the audience at his showing that the leopard prints and polar bear scarves were the work of Mr. Tomchin.

Legal actions arising from the collision last Thursday of an American tanker and a British tanker in Kill van Kull, involving more than $1-million in claims and counterclaims, were initiated in Federal District Court here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 22-- Specialists at the National Heart Institute and other research centers are considering a major program to assess a strikingly new method of treating heart attacks in man.
A major executive revamping is under way at the CampbellEwald Company in anticipation of the retirement next fall of Henry G. Little as chairman and chief executive officer.
NEW JERSEY'S hunting regulations have been set following a public hearing a few days ago.
LONDON, June 22--Prime Minister Wilson suffered an embarrassing if not major political setback today in a meeting of the Parliamentary Labor party.

A decline of 3,148,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend, total supplies were 202,470,000 barrels, compared with 205,618,000 a week earlier and 204,134,000 a year ago.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (UPI)--The Senate approved today by voice vote without debate a $700-million five-year extension of the library services and construction program. The bill now returns to the House for action on minor Senate amendments.

Record sales and earnings were registered by the Hooker Chemical Corporation in the three and six-month periods ended May 31, F. Leonard Bryant, chairman, and chief executive officer, reported yesterday.

The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company posted yesterday an interest rate of 5 7/8 per cent on loans to dealers secured by government securities. This was 1/8 of a per centage point higher than had been charged by most banks previously and the highest rate seen in New York City in some years.

WASHINGTON, June 22-- Savings and loan associations in New York City will be permitted to pay up to 5 per cent on certain savings accounts under a pair of rules approved by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.
The spot rate on the British pound remained relatively steady yesterday in moderate trading on foreign-exchange markets yesterday.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 22--The executive council of the Episcopal Church gave unanimous approval today to participation in a national ecumenical agency to encourage and coordinate church involvement in community organization projects.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 22--The deadlock between the United States and the Soviet Union over the time and place to draft a treaty banning military use of celestial bodies has been broken.
DARIEN, Conn., June 22-- The Superintendent of Schools in this affluent, all-white community is leaving for a new job, with a parting warning that the atmosphere in Darien is still "most unhealthy."
RANGOON, June 19--Youngsters at High School 1 held a mass meeting last week to condemn "road devils."

BOSTON, June 22 (AP)-- Lightly rated and lightly weighted Fast Count, a 3-yearold brown colt, outduelled Pluck, the 7-10 favorite, to win the 32d running of the $82,200 Massachusetts Handicap today at Suffolk Downs.

The election of H. Donald Borger as chairman and chief executive officer was announced yesterday by the Consolidated Natural Gas Company. He succeeds E.H. Tollefson, who is retiring June 30 after 36 years with the utility system.
The Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra will tour the United States next year following its appearance at Montreal's Expo '67.
MONTREAL, June 22 (Canadian Press)--The Verdi Opera Festival opened at Montreal's Place des Arts last night with Mario Del Monaco, Renata Tebaldi and Tito Gobbi singing the lead roles in "Otello."

BOSTON, June 22 (UPI)-- Don Demeter's double scoring Carl Yastrzemski with two out in the ninth inning gave the Boston Red Sox a 6-5 victory tonight over the Cleveland Indians after the Indians won the opening game, 3-2, with the help of Rocky Colavito's two homers.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., June 22--Doctors in Suffolk County are turning away sick patients who come for treatment under the state's new medical aid plan.

Sporting a red-white-and-blue blazer and a straw hat, Mayor Lindsay welcomed more than 35,000 New Yorkers to Central Park Mall last night. The festivities opened this summer's Guggenheim Memorial concerts by the Goldman Band.
CARACAS, Venezuela, June 22 (AP)--Terrorist machine guns opened fire on a patrol car last night and killed two policemen near Central University.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 22--President Sukarno said today that the People's Consultative Congress, Indonesia's highest policy-making body, had no right to vote him out of office.
YAZOO CITY, Miss., June 22 (UPI)--The driver of the flatbed truck carrying newsmen following the Mississippi march quit his job today, announcing "I was placed here by the Ku Klux Klan."

Harriet Beecher Stowe believed that "Oldtown Folks," not "Uncle Tom's Cabin," was her masterpiece. The novel was published in 1869, and it will be put out again next Monday by Harvard University Press.

WASHINGTON, June 22-- President Johnson signed into law today a bail reform measure that will allow poor defendants awaiting trial in Federal courts to be released without bonds under certain conditions.
Gerry Lindgren, a refreshingly unsophisticated child of nature, arrives in town today, hoping for rain, a national championship and another chance to run against the Russians.

STRATFORD, Conn., June 22--Frank Hauser's rep utation as a director has preceded him from England. There, since 1956, he has run the Oxford Playhouse (in the town, not the university) and has won praise as a producer of exceptional plays, new and old. Now, for the American Shakespeare Festival, Mr. Hauser has directed "Twelfth Night," which opened last evening, and the result is puzzling.
A house and garden tour will be held on Saturday from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. to benefit the Akin Free Library at Quaker Hill, Pawling, N.Y.

TEMPLE CITY, Calif., June 22 (UPI)--A $3,000 magnesium cube used in the United States moon program was recovered today from a junkyard where it was sold for $28.14 by two trash collectors who had allegedly stolen it.
The Kinney Service Corporation and National Cleaning Contractors, Inc., announced yesterday that the antitrust action that had sought to restrain the merger of the two companies had been settled.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 22-- Left-wing Arabs in Beirut, Damascus, Cairo and Baghdad are denouncing King Faisal of Saudi Arabia, who is visiting the United States.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP)--The fourth Medal of Honor for heroism in Vietnam will be presented tomorrow by President Johnson to First Lieut. Charles Q. Williams, a 32-year-old wearer of the green beret of the Special Forces.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 22--Kialoa II, the 73-foot sloop owned by John B. Kilroy of Los Angeles and manned by a driving crew of Californians, gained the first laurels of the Newport-to-Bermuda race tonight by being the first yacht to finish. She arrived at 10:05 P.M.

WASHINGTON, June 22-- The Administration won a major victory today when a House subcommittee approved President Johnson's demonstration cities bill, which Mr. Johnson hopes will transform cities into "masterpieces" of American society.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation has received a $29,836,692 Navy contract for production of radar sets and also $10,216,000 of an $18,466,000 Air Force contract to design and produce mobile air control radars.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, June 22--Six members of the Rhodesian Parliament, who oppose the policies of Prime Minister Ian D. Smith, boycotted the first formal session of Parliament since Rhodesia seized independence from Britain Nov. 11.

MOSCOW, June 22 (AP)-- The Soviet Government said today that it was not insisting that the withdrawal of United States troops from Vietnam was a condition for an agreement to halt the spread of nuclear weapons.

When William Penn cast about for a suitable name to give the chief city of the colony he founded, he must have thought of the literal meaning of the Greek word, philadelpheia. St. Paul used the word in his Epistle to the Romans: "Be kindly, affectionate one to another with brotherly love."
The Communist party, U.S.A., opened its first national convention since 1959 last night, and its chief spokesman, Gus Hall, declared the party had "fought its way out of political isolation."

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 22 --Dr. Eric Layne, assistant chief of psychology service at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Lyons since 1953, died Monday at East Orange Veterans Hospital. He was 48 years old and lived at 55 Franklin Place here.

More than 300 persons attended the formal opening of the St. Regis-Sheraton Roof and Penthouse last night. The Penthouse has been newly redecorated in shades of ivory, gold, pearl and rose pink to blend with the baroque Roof.
A 72-year-old mariner set sail alone yesterday in an 11 -foot yawl-rigged dinghy on a trans-Atlantic voyage he described as a "vacation."
The nation's electric power production rose 11.3 per cent in the week ended June 18, from the level in the corresponding 1965 week, it was reported by the Edison Electric Institute yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Abraham S. Weiss of 200 Central Park South and Putnam Valley, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Wendy Beryl Weiss, to Burton J. Lipsky, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Lipsky of Cherry Hill, N.J., and New York. An Aug. 28 wedding is planned.

The head of United Neighborhood Houses--the federation of city settlement houses--charged yesterday that "ineptness" and "footdragging" by the city's top antipoverty officials hed led to a lack of funds and the elimination of projects.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 22-- The morning line, which lists in advance the likely favorites in a race and their probable odds, indicated that the $89,111.13 Realization Trot may develop into the season's most exciting harness race. The top three of the eight starters in Saturday way are closely grouped. One was held today at 8-5, another at 9-5 and a third at 2-1.
ARMONK, N.Y.--A small apothecary jar with $175 worth of saffron was one of the ingredients lined up the other day on a hilltop terrace here in readiness for a paella barbecue.
Federal mediators took a step of their own yesterday to end the 47-day-old strike that has stopped Carey bus service to and from the major metropolitan airports.

Authorities of the Monmouth County prosecutor's office at Freehold, N.J., will question tomorrow a woman who heard a child screaming near her home Monday night but did not report it to the police until the next morning.

DENVER, June 22--An Aug. 20 wedding here is planned by Miss Cecily Grant Coors and Anson Herrick Garnsey. Their engagement has been announced by the future bride's mother, Mrs. Adolph Coors 3d. Mr. Garnsey is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William S. Garnsey 3d of Greeley.
The American Stock Exchange posted a modest advance yesterday in moderate trading.

The assets of private noninsured pension funds increased by more than $6-billion during 1965 and by the end of the year amounted to a book (cost) value of $58,087,000,000, according to a survey issued by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Stock prices continued to advance yesterday as volume on the New York Stock Exchange rose by almost a million shares over Tuesday's brisk pace.

WASHINGTON, June 22--The current hearings before the House Armed Services Committee are disclosing a fundamental source of the glaring inequality of the military conscription system that the factual examples of it have obscured.

THOMAS LUX, the California star who won the re cent United States amateur chess championship by sweeping the opposition 7-0, produced a compelling oddity in the second round of this seven-round Swiss system.
PHILADELPHIA, Miss., June 22--An uneasy calm returned to Philadelphia today after yesterday's outbreaks of violence in which Negro marchers were beaten and a white man was shot.
New bond issues totaling offered to investors yesterday financing days in a year. In

FLORENCE, S.C., June 22 (AP)--Federal Judge J. Robert Martin issued an order today allowing Federal observers to accompany illiterates into voting booths during Tuesday's runoff primary in South Carolina.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, June 23--Government troops and policemen occupied the headquarters of the unified Buddhist Church in a surprise raid at dawn today.

NOROTON, Conn., June 22-- Mr. and Mrs. Lindley M. Franklin Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janet Franklin, to Thomas R. Peifer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mark E. Peifer of Mifflinville, Pa.

LONDON, June 22--An announcement by Vauxhall, the British subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation, that it will cut back production by eliminating night shifts, may indicate hard times for American concerns in this country.
WILMINGTON, Del., June 22 --Miss Elizabeth Maynard Henry of New York and David Zachariah Walley Jr. of Lookout Mountain, Tenn., plan to be married here in August.
WASHINGTON, June 22-- New York State came out today against a proposal to establish a national wetlands conservation area off the South Shore of Long Island.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., June 22 (UPI)--Dr. J.H. Jackson of Chicago, president of the National Baptist Convention, a large Negro organization, said today that cries of "black power" did not speak for millions of his race.
CHICAGO, June 22 (AP)-- A leader in Chicago's Puerto Rican community took a seat today on the Mayor's Commission on Human Relations and singled out understanding as the key to peace in the community.
ALBANY, June 22--Legislative leaders put off until after next Tuesday's primary election what they could not do today--approve New York City's tax package.
The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company announced here yesterday the election of Harry P. Barrand Jr. as executive vice president of the banking department, a new post.
The establishment here of a Swiss Center was described yesterday as a demonstration of the Alpine nation's economic vitality by Dr. Frederick T. Wahlen, former President of Switzerland.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (UPI)--France plans to set off her first test explosion of a hydrogen bomb in the Pacific in 1968, informed diplomatic sources said today.
SUMMIT, N.J., June 22-- Loren E. Bennett, formerly of this city, director of staff engineering for the Western Electric Company in New York, died Monday at Williamsburg, Va. His age was 64.
Arthur J. Goldberg, the United States representative to the United Nations, got a favorable first review of his new book yesterday from Ambassador Piero Vinci of Italy.

WASHINGTON, June 22-- The State Department in effect confirmed today reports that North Vietnam was still asking for an end to all bombing of its territory as a condition for peace talks or gestures of any kind.
Consumption of newsprint in the United States set records for May and the first five months of 1966, the American Newspaper Publishers Association reported yesterday.
LUCERNE, Switzerland, June 23 (AP) The United States Equestrian Team captured the Prix Des Nations team jumping event, highlight of the international horse show, today.

WASHINGTON, June 23 The big institutional investors pension funds, mutual funds and life insurance companies are not only becoming everlarger holders of common stocks. They are buying and selling stocks at an ever-swifter pace.
The nation's banking system experienced tighter money conditions in the week ended Wednesday than in the preceding week, which had been widely heralded as a critical period for the money market.

After much vacillation Governor Rockefeller has come to the support of the well-conceived legislative plan to assure the fiscal soundness of the City University. The bill follows closely the recommendations that emerged from hearings conducted by State Senator Manfred Ohrenstein; its key provision is the establishment of a City University Construction Fund to provide the borrowing power for a $400-million expansion program.
The Univac Division of the Sperry Rand Corporation announced yesterday that it had received a multimillion-dollar contract from the United Aircraft Research Laboratories for a computer system.

Dr. Joseph Macy, a dentist in the Bronx for the last 40 years, died Wednesday at Montefiore Hospital of a heart ailment. He was 64 years old and lived at 1049 Grand Concourse, where he also maintained his office.
BONN, June 23 West Germany intends to give France interim permission to keep her 72,000 soldiers and airmen in this country after they leave allied command on July 1.

BONN, June 23 The Bundestag approved today a special law granting safe-conduct to the East German Communist leaders who are scheduled to debate West German Social Democrats in Hanover next month, thus removing the only legal obstacle to joint debates on both sides of the partition line.
LONDON, June 23--Hopes rose today for a break in Britain's maritime strike when leaders of the National Union of Seamen and the shipowners suddenly resumed talks.
IN the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., June 23 (UPI) Pageos 1, a balloon satellite designed to help man map the earth's surface with unusual accuracy, was launched into polar orbit from this base today by a Thor-Agena D rocket booster.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), June 23 A historical account of a Jewish-Christian sect living in Jerusalem shortly after the time of Jesus has been found by a Hebrew University professor.

TARRYTOWN, N. Y., June 23 William J. Cannon of 159 Neperan Road, vice president and general manager of the Tarrytown Daily News, a unit of the Gannett chain, died yesterday in Phelps Memorial Hospital at North Tarrytown. He was 72 years old.
LISBON, June 23--Fortynine Jehovah's Witnesses, 35 of them women, went on trial here today charged with refusing to respect Portuguese laws, particularly the draft.
WASHINGTON, June 23 Secretary of State Dean Rusk attempted early this morning to persuade Mayor Lindsay not to cancel his reception for King Faisal of Saudi Arabia, reliable sources said.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 23 Secretary General Thant does not consider North Vietnam's reaction to the most recent United States attempt to arrange peace talks an irrevocable rejection, authoritative sources reported today.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., June 23 A few minutes after the tournament committee had set a playoff date, Tony Vileno came in with a 74 to win the Metropolitan Seniors Golf championship today.

Jesse Gray, the flamboyant Harlem rent-strike leader, and two of his followers were dragged from the steps of City Hall and arrested yesterday after refusing police requests to end a sit-down demonstration.

The Soviet agreement to open negotiations on a treaty banning military activity on celestial bodies is an important indication that Moscow does not consider Vietnam an obstacle to disarmament agreements with the United States.
SPRING LAKE, N. J., June 23 The New York State Bankers Association proposed today that lenders be required to state, in terms of a simple annual interest rate, the maximum cost of a consumer loan.

The Communist party, U.S.A., asserted yesterday that it was "growing significantly among youth," primarily collegians. But a report to its 18th national convention voiced alarm at the "almost all-white membership in many youth organizations on the Left."
The Parks Commissioner announced plans yesterday for an early curfew, a strict ban on drinking, and assorted daytime entertainment to upgrade Bryant Park, just west of the New York Public Library.

PARIS, June 23 On this warm, sunny day a leading French newspaper, France-Soir, previewed the winter styles of a leading fashion house, showing a model almost smothered by fur clothes. The newspaper noted: "It will be the Russian style this year."
TOLEDO, Spain, June 23 (UPI) Lynda Bird Johnson unveiled a bronze bust of her father today at the United States Embassy in Madrid and then set out on a tour of Spain's romantic provincial cities.

PANAMA, June 23--Thieves broke into the National Museum on Tuesday, smashed a display case specially designed to be burglar-resistant and got away with irreplaceable gold artifacts--lip ornaments, frogs, eagles and other items--fashioned by Indians before Columbus found the New World.

TOKYO, June 23 Apparently encouraged by a split in Premier Eisaku Sato's LiberalDemocratic party on policy toward China, the Socialist opposition announced today a nationwide drive to force the Government to expand relations with Peking.
THE master-point plan of the American Contract Bridge League has been a great financial success in its 30-year history, but whether it has been a social success is open to doubt. At the club...
BUCHAREST, Rumania, June 23 Chinese-Rumanian friendship suffered a severe setback this evening in a rally for Chinese-Rumanian friendship.

BRICK TOWNSHIP, N. J., June 23 Paul Becker, editor and publisher of The Ocean County Daily Observer, died last night at Point Pleasant Hospital, to which he had been admitted two weeks ago suffering from diabetes. He was 52 years old.

COLD SPRING, N. Y., June 23 Dr. Gordon J. Steiner, professor of accounting since 1937 at Manhattan College, the Bronx, died yesterday in the Julia L. Butterfield Memorial Hospital here after a long illness. He was 55 years old and lived on Maple Lane, Valhalla Heights, in Cold Spring, and at 3 Sadore Lane, Yonkers.
Woman's Day will begin a new campaign next week in which the starring roles are played by wives of New York advertising men. And none of the ad men work at the magazine's own agency, de Garmo, Inc.

Plans again are being made to bring "Bang the Drum Slowly," Mark Harris's novel about baseball, to the musical stage, with songs by Harold Rome. The latest to undertake the venture is Max J. Brown, formerly an investor in many David Merrick offerings.
PARIS, June 23--Three French communities have been classified in effect as depressed areas in anticipation of the departure of United States military installations.

Army medical researchers said yesterday they were ready to distribute a new antimalaria drug to American soldiers in Vietnam to combat the severe form of the disease that has resisted usual treatment.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 23 (Reuters) The Provisional People's Consultative Congress rejected today President Sukarno's impassioned defense of his policies, and members urged a complete ban on Communism throughout the country.

WASHINGTON, June 23 He looks like one of the rich young heroes out of an F. Scott Fitzgerald story set in the 1920's, and in a way, he is, James Wadsworth Symington has the breeding, the blood, the bones and, like his mother, just a trace of bohemianism to lend a little zing. The first
ST. LOUIS, June 23 (UPI) James H. Meredith, on his way to rejoin the Negro march in Mississippi, said today that President Johnson was a part of a "white supremacy structure" that must be changed.
Brand extension in the cigarette business has apparently caused another account loss for an agency.

WASHINGTON, June 23 The House Banking Committee, buffeted by uncertainty and conflicting pressures from financial institutions, abandoned today, at least temporarily, the effort to write legislation limiting interest rates commercial banks may pay on "consumertype" time deposits.
NEW HAVEN, June 23 About 30 Television actors, writers, producers and directors, are expected to attend a conference on television drama at Yale University from Monday through Wednesday.
PARIS, June 23 The Monaco Parliament today passed a law designed to break the hold of Aristotle Onassis, the Greek shipping magnate, on Monte Carlo's gambling and tourist facilities.
Miami June 23 (UPI) A Cuban refugee who said life in Cuba "was not fit for a dog" arrived here today after fleeing the Communist island under gunfire with his scrawny white dog "Pichi."

CHICAGO, June 23 (AP) Willie Mays pounded the 521st home run of his career today to tie Ted Williams for third place in the records as the San Francisco Giants scored a 6-4 victory over the Chicago Cubs.
Wall Street is now debating the likelihood of a color-television set in nearly every home. And the deliberations have considerable significance for the holders of color-television stocks.

The Police Department has assigned more than 1,000 patrolmen and policewomen to augment patrols at park, beach and recreation areas to deal with possible disorders among the city's youth during the summer school vacation.
The United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday that it would follow a price increase on railroad and industrial axles initiated recently by Standard Alliance Industries, Inc.
The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company announced yesterday that it would build a multimillion-dollar plant at Marysville, Ohio, for the manufacture of rubber conveyor belting.

The Dana Chapel of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church was the setting here yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Toni Suffern Tailer, daughter of T. Suffern Tailer of 988 Fifth Avenue and the late Mrs. Elsie Sturgis Tailer, to Laird...

Politics, nationalism and religion combined to make an explosive mixture in which King Faisal of Saudi Arabia has figuratively been consumed. No one comes out of this embarrassing imbroglio with honor.
BILOXI, Miss., June 23 A Federal grand jury has returned indictments against 15 alleged Ku Klux Klansmen in connection with the firebomb slaying of a Hattiesburg, Miss., Negro leader last January.

When speculators are enthusiastic over a market, it doesn't take much to kindle more interest. That became apparent yesterday when grain and soybean traders apparently bought heavily as a result of a talk by Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey to a group of farm editors in Washington.
WASHINGTON, June 23 The Treasury auctioned $1billion of one-year bills today at an average discount rate of 4.697 per cent, the lowest for this issue since last November.

Oscar Bonavena has a face that seems to have been hacked from low-grade marble with a chipped chisel. Last night, at Madison Square Garden, that face absorbed the best George Chuvalo had to offer, which was hardly anything at all. Bonavena won a split decision, upsetting the favored Chuvalo.

WASHINGTON, June 23--The House Foreign Affairs Committee rebuked its Senate counterpart today for cutting the $3.4-billion foreign aid bill and limiting its scope to show its displeasure of the Administration's foreign policy.

Sales of leading chain stores and mail order houses increased moderately last month, rounding out five full years in which volume had risen each month from the level of the corresponding period a year ago.
WINNIPEG, Man. June 23 The commanding strength of the Conservative Government of Manitoba was reduced to the barest majority in today's general election.
HOUSTON, June 23 (AP) Bob Gibson's four-hit pitching and Phil Gagliano's run-producing single in the eighth inning tonight carried St. Louis to a 2-1 victory over Houston.

PALO ALTO, Calif., June 23 For its third annual Summer Festival of the Arts, Stanford University took as its theme 20th-century innovations from 1900 to 1939. The ambitious 109-event festival opened last night with an innovation of its own by presenting the Orchestre de la Suisse Romande in its American debut, led by Ernest Ansermet. The eminent 82-year-old conductor is, of course, no stranger to this country, having appeared with most of our major ensembles.
WASHINGTON, June 23 The suppression of political turmoil in South Vietnam has revived discussion here of intensification of American air attacks on North Vietnam.
A patrolman accused of lying in an alleged Harlem brutality case last November was later assigned as an interpreter on the Civilian Complaint Review Board from Feb. 14 to June 1.
BRASILIA, June 23 (UPI) Four Americans were convicted in Federal Court today of having smuggled rare tantalite ore from Brazil. The ore is used in processing steel.

Roy Francis Nagle, a 27year-old former marine who was convicted of the sniper slaying of a teen-age girl on June 3, was sentenced yesterday to serve 40 years to life by Supreme Court Justice Irwin D. Davidson.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 23 A broadcast by the Baghdad radio indicated tonight that peace negotiations between the Iraqi Goverment and Kurdish rebels in the north of Iraq were moving quickly toward success.

THE program says that Montgomery Hare, the author of "Command Performance," once wrote a column for The New York Post, Possibly this explains why one of his characters is named for the late Post columnist Fletcher Pratt. It is a dubious compliment, but it is the most interesting point about the evening.

RIDGEFIELD, Conn., June 23 Prince Chambliss, who two years ago transferred from an all-Negro school in Birmingham, Ala., to study and live in this wealthy, suburban community, was graduated with honors from its high school today.

A real New York combination, Owner Sam Lefrak, Jockey Ernie Cardone and Trainer Buddy Jacobson, were in the spotlight at Aqueduct yesterday in the Summer Festival, the race that is named for the annual campaign to promote New York as a summer festival. Their horse, Flame Tree, a Floridabred 3-year-old colt, won the one-mile race, scoring over Mr. Right by a neck in 1:35 3-5 and returning $6.20 for $2 to win.
A monument to President F. Kennedy, the first public memorial to be erected in his honor in Italy, will be unveiled in Rome Nov. 22, the third anniversary of his death.

KARACHI, Pakistan, June 23 Communist China signed an agreement with Pakistan in Karachi today to provide machinery, foreign exchange and technical assistance for the establishment of a heavy engineering complex in West Pakistan.
URBANA, Ill., June 23 (AP)--Dr. Albert J. Harno, former dean of the University of Illinois Law School, died yesterday in La Jolla, Calif. He was 77 years old.
WESTPORT, Conn., June 23--Gail Hulick, 10 years old, piloted Drift Wood to the small pony hunter championship today in the opening session of the four-day Fairfield County Horse Show.

WASHINGTON, June 23 A senior Republican of the House Armed Services Committee cited the case of George Hamilton, the Hollywood actor, today to support his charge that the draft discriminates against the poor.
The International Business Machines Corporation indicated yesterday that its $377.8-million offering of capital stock was 92.5 per cent subscribed by its own stockholders.

WASHINGTON, June 23 Hearings into charges of alleged misconduct by Senator Thomas J.Dodd erupted today into an angry dispute and a protest by Mr.Dodd that the Senate ethics committee was treating him unfairly.
BOSTON, June 27 (AP) Rocky Colavito hit a two-run homer and Fred Whitfield, Jim Landis and Chico Salmon also contributed home runs today as the Cleveland Indians beat the Boston Red Sox, 8-6.

The marriage of Miss Mary Gentry Buckner to Douglass Nelson Loud took place yesterday afternoon at the Brick Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Dr. D. Reginald Thomas performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Gilbert Darlington. A reception was held at the Pierre.

VIENNA, June 23 (AP) A new air-traffic agreement has been concluded between the United States and Austria, allowing the Austrians to fly to New York and Washington, the Foreign Ministry announced here today.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) The Federal Communications Commission today authorized the Communications Satellite Corporation to build six synchronous satellites for a global commercial communications system.
The last time Charlie Greene ran at Randalls Island was almost the last time he ran anywhere.
DUBLIN, June 23 Though packets of uncashed checks are growing larger and bank notes are becoming scarcer and decidedly dog-eared, Dubliners are getting along ingeniously without their banks.

Dr. Seymour Lion Kahn, a dentist and associate visiting specialist in orthodontia at Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx, died of a heart attack yesterday in his home at 518 Parsons Boulevard in Malba, Queens. His age was 46.
A sharp reversal in the last half hour of trading depressed most issues on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 23 Francis Cardinal Spellman, Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York, was honored here tonight as "Clergyman of the Year."

John H. Walker, former president and chairman of the Bay Ridge Operating Company, marine operations of 34 Whitehall Street, died Tuesday in his home at 645 East 17th Street, Brooklyn. He was 82 years old.
PHILADELPHIA, June 23 (AP) Steve Arlin, Ohio State's two-time All-America pitcher, signed with the Philadelphia Phillies today for a bonus believed to be $100,000.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 23 (AP) Ronald Reagan has ruled out help from Barry Goldwater, his Presidential choice in 1964, and today welcomed some vigorous primary foes who joined his campaign for Governor of California.
Henry A. James, who retired in 1956 after more than 55 years as a cotton textile merchant, died in his home Wednesday night. He was 76 years old and lived at 630 Park Avenue.

District Attorney Aaron E. Koota of Brooklyn announced yesterday that he would move on Monday for the dismissal of a murder indictment against George W. Whitmore Jr. in the slaying of Mrs. Minnie Edmonds.

Presented Medal of Honor to Army Lieut. Charles Q. Williams; met with U.S. Ambassadors Raymond Thurston, Somali; Henry Stebbins, Uganda; and Henry Byroade, Burma; saw former Treasury Secretary Robert Anderson; signed several bills; notified Martin Luther King that Gov. Johnson of Mississippi had assured him law and order would be maintained there.

WESTBURY, L,I., June 23 Roquepine of France, the 5-yearold mare whose 3:24 2/5 clocking in capturing last January's $100,000 Prix d'Amerique was the fastest in the history of Europe's most famous trotting race, today was named as the third entry in the $100,000 Roosevelt International. The race will be staged at Roosevelt Raceway on July 9, a Saturday.

The General Acceptance Corporation, a consumer and commercial loan company of Allentown, Pa., plans to acquire the Pioneer Finance Company of Detroit, in exchange for General Acceptance securities pursuant to a reorganization plan.
WASHINGTON, June 23 The Maritime Administration has approved the United States Lines' request to convert three of five general cargo ships now under construction to full container-carrying vessels.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) The Detroit Tigers disposed of Washington's starting pitcher in the first inning for the third straight night and beat the Senators, 6-1, tonight. Earl Wilson and Larry Sherry combined to hold the losers to five hits.
STRATFORD, Conn., June 23 There is something about "Julius Caesar" is it age, is it performance? that has the flavor of a silent screen melodrama done in sound.

BETHESDA, Md., June 23 (AP) Edward J. Reardon, retired Washington correspondent for The Herald News of Passaic and Clifton, N. J., died in a hospital today, apparently of a stroke. He was 65 years old.
The City's 142 public health clinics will open this morning without any of their 1,500 doctors in attendance because of a dispute with the city over pay and other contract provisions.

WASHINGTON, June 23 Mayor Lindsay urged the Senate today to reject a series of reductions and restrictions that the House Education and Labor Committee had introduced into the Administration's antipoverty bill.

TEL AVIV, June 23 (Reuters) The Israel Philharmonic Orchestra will begin three weeks of concerts in the Soviet Union in November, according to a dispatch from Moscow to Kol Israel, Israel's broadcasting service.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 23 An urgent appeal from Secretary General Thant to Archbishop Makarios, President of Cyprus, ended a crisis today that had led Turkey to threaten direct action against the island.
The new Manhattan Opera Company last night gave the first of 22 performances it will present in English this summer each Tuesday and Thursday on the Mall in Central Park.
Mayor Lindsay yesterday canceled an official dinner for King Faisal because the Saudi Arabian monarch said Wednesday that he considered friends of Israel to be enemies of his nation.

GLENDALE, Calif., June 23 (AP) Fans, friends and show business personalities paid final tribute today to Ed Wynn, the comedian, eulogized as one who "made a rich and meaningful thing of life." Mr. Wynn, who was known as "The Perfect Fool," died of cancer Sunday at 79.

LEE, Mass., June 23 The Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival opened its 34th year in this Berkshire town yesterday afternoon with a performance by 40 members of the graduating class of the New York City High School of Performing Arts.
WASHINGTON, June 23 Senator Robert F. Kennedy recently submitted the name of one of his early political sponsors in New York State, Peter J. Crotty of Buffalo, for clearance for a Federal judgeship.
