OTTAWA, June 23 (Canadian Press) The amount of gold in Canada's official holdings of gold and United States dollars totaled $1,060,700,000 in terms of United States dollars on May 31, the lowest in more than a year, the Bank of Canada reported today.

WASHINGTON, June 23 The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, citing the need to ease relations between the police and Negroes in Baltimore ordered a Federal judge there today to enjoin the local police from illegal searches of Negroes' homes.
The devices that have been trusted time and the bulldozer have not cured the problems of "the worst block in the city."

The three-cornered contest for the Democratic nomination for Surrogate in New York County quickened yesterday with developments in court, in two unions of city employes, in the Negro community and in more campaign statements.
The Sherwin-Williams Company, a leading producer of paints and varnishes, registered a 12.3 per cent increase in earnings in the nine months ended May 31, on a sales gain of 8.7 per cent.
WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP)--President Johnson signed today a bill to increase monthly dependency and indemnity payments to parents and children of veterans whose deaths were service-connected.

Clarence Childs, who is fast, and Roosevelt Davis, who is big, signed 1966 contracts yesterday with the New York Giants of the National Football League. Childs is a kickoff returner and defensive back, Davis is a defensive end.

LONDON, June 23 Dennis Ralston beat Keith Diepraam of South Africa in a baffling melange of the magnificent and the mediocre as three Americans reached the round of 16 on this stormy day of tennis at Wimbledon.
The London stock market turned firm yesterday as optimism was revived over efforts to end the long seamen's strike.
The Museum of Modern Art began its fifth season of "Jazz in the Garden" concerts, last night with a program by the Ruby Braff Septet.

AREA A Bluefish are the attraction along most of the New Jersey coast, with those chumming and trolling picking up the fish in such standard spots as the Acid Waters and Barnegat Ridge. Boats fishing the bottom are taking some good-sized porgies and seabass. A few kingfish are in the surf.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost of dining in any particular establishment.
Five football players from high schools and preparatory schools in the Metropolitan area were honored with scholar-athletic awards yesterday at Leone's Restaurant.
The National Better Business Bureau announced here yesterday the election as chairman of John R. Miller, vice president and general manager of Hearst Magazines, Inc.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 23 The second United Nations cocoa conference adjourned tonight after repeating the failure of its 1963 meeting to establish an international agreement on the commodity.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 23 South Vietnamese troops have resumed heavy action in the I Corps area, in the northern part of South Vietnam, broadening the cam paigning that they shared elsewhere with Americans and other allied troops through the politically tumultuous spring.

CHICAGO, June 23 "This," said the lamp company executive, grasping a fluted, conical fruitwood lamp base with a brass gallery at the bottom and bulbous brass decoration just under the shade, "is a sort of Louis the XVI-Sheraton. It's one of our new lamps."

Mrs. Pat Edrich of New York, the favorite, and Louise Gonnerman of River Edge, N. J. who was seeded second, gained the final of the annual Rose Taubele Memerial tennis tournament yesterday at the New York Tennis Club in the Bronx.

CHICAGO, June 23 The American Medical Association has asked the Federal Government for a voice in the administration of free health care for the needy under Title 19 of the Social Security Amendments of 1965.

Fifteen hundred cats face possible death by starvation and thirst in sealed buildings on the 290-acre New York Naval Shipyard at Brooklyn after it closes tomorrow, the Save-A-CatLeague charged yesterday.

An antibiotic as effective against viruses as penicillin is against bacteria would be a medical dream-come-true. This dream seems a step closer to reality with a recent discovery by a University of Florida researcher.

MELBOURNE, Australia, June 23 (UPI) A new contract to sell to Communist China an additional 600,000 tons of wheat, including off-grade and weatherdamaged grain, was announced here today by the Australian Wheat Board.

POCANTICO HILLS, N. Y., June 23 The engagement of Miss Bonnie Susan Veit, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Veit of Pocantico Hills and Milford, Conn., to West Point Cadet Robert M. Echols Jr. has been announced by the prospective bride's parents. The future bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Echols of Birmingham, Ala.

The New York Herald Tribune News Service, formerly operated by the now merged Herald Tribune, will not be continued when the latter resumes publication as one of the World Journal Tribune's newspapers, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP)--A $6-billion water pollution control program aimed at cleaning up the nation's rivers was approved today by the Senate Public Works Committee.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 23 The leftist revolutionary Government of Syria has asked the United States for help in the critical food shortage in the country. This is the first time Syria has asked for such help from the United States since the drought of 1961.
American broadcasters are looking for Negro and Puerto Rican job applicants, but they are having trouble convincing members of those groups of their sincerity.

TORONTO, June 23 American Reform Judaism has stepped up its activity in the last year to "open the doors of the synagogue for the unchurched and the unsynagogued," with particular emphasis on the non-Jew who may seek to embrace Judaism as his faith, an influential Reform rabbi said today.

John O. Ross, former president and board chairman of the J.O. Ross Engineering Corporation, makers of atmosphere control systems, paper coating and printing equipment and other industrial machinery, died of cancer Tuesday at his home at 39 East 79th Street, He was 81 years old.
GENEVA, June 23 The Soviet Union today raised its price for a pledge not to use nuclear weapons against a state that has renounced the possession of such arms.

THE fourth season of "Promenade" concerts is closing on a positive note with Sir Malcolm Sargent serving up some epicurean conducting on the podium, and the box office at Philharmonic Hall rolling in some impressive statistics.

The Department of Commerce has issued directives to 14 manufacturers of men's apparel to produce combat uniforms for Vietnam. Those who refuse to comply face, the possibility of stoppage of their civilian production.
The Board of Education, bowing to protests by teachers, canceled plans yesterday to open city schools two days earlier than usual next fall.

PURCHASE, N. Y., June 23 Greenwich, Conn., defeated Myopia, Mass., 10-9, in sudden death in the second overtime period at Blind Brook Polo Club tonight in the semi-final round of the Northeastern intra-circuit tournament.
WASHINGTON, June 23 President Johnson received as surances today from Governor Johnson that the state would provide protection tomorrow for civil rights demonstrators in Philadelphia, Miss.
NOVOSIBIRSK, U.S.S.R., June 23 President de Gaulle was welcomed to Siberia today by several hundred thousand flag-waving citizens.

The leasehold on a 16-story building at 405 Park Avenue, the northeast corner of 54th Street, has been sold by Countrywide Realty, Inc., to a client of the law firm of Kahr Spitzer Howard for cash over a leasehold mortgage of $3.1million.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., June 23 Supervisor Evans K. Griffing ferried over from his home town of Shelter Island this morning in good legislative voice. His was one of 10 equal voices on the Suffolk County legislative body, the Board of Supervisors.

WASHINGTON, June 23 Does the Federal Reserve know what it is doing and what it is trying to accomplish? This somewhat disquieting question has been raised, in ever-so-gentle terms, from within the Federal Reserve System itself.

AUGUSTA, Ga., June 23 (AP) Pat H. Rice Jr., former president of the Georgia Associated Press Association, died yesterday of a heart attack While vacationing at Jekyll Island. He was 62 years old. Mr. Rice was vice president and general manager of Southeastern Newspapers, Inc.
A late wave of selling sent stock prices tumbling yesterday as a flood of rumors engulfed Wall Street, setting off a new war of nerves between bulls and bears.

POMPANO BEACH, Fla., June 23 Thundershowers and conversation cooled tempers in this East Coast resort city today, easing the threat of resumed violence of the kind that flared in the Negro section the last two days.

The wholesale commodity price index rose to 111.7 on Wednesday from 111.5 on Tuesday.

LONDON, June 23 The courtesies of the South Arabian delegation's farewell at the Foreign Office today were tinged with bitterness.

WASHINGTON, June 23 The White House is conducting one of its most intensive talent searches in recent months in an attempt to find the right man to replace John deLaittre as the Republican member of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.
BANGKOK, Thailand, June 23 "Button Your Lip," the United States Air Force's weekly Klong Times today told its readers among 18,000 United States airmen stationed in Thailand.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) Representative Samuel S. Stratton, Democrat of New York, introduced legislation today to tighten a Federal law under which New York State adopted its controversial new plan of medical care.

LOS ANGELES, June 23 (UPI) Paul (Bear) Bryant, 53 years old, the head football coach of the University of Alabama, was released from a hospital today and immediately flew to Atlanta en route home to Birmingham. Bryant collapsed while making a speech at a football clinic on Monday at Pepperdine College.

John Joseph Corry, a retired administrative supervisor for the Irving Trust Company, died of a heart attack Sunday in Karlstad, Sweden, where he was visiting during a tour he was making with his wife. He was 65 years old and lived at 570 82d Street, Brooklyn.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 23 (AP) A Navy pilot told today how he shot down a North Vietnamese MIG-17 even though his jet was shot through with 70 shell holes and was almost "uncontrollable at high speeds."
Treasury bill prices continued to show unusual strength yesterday while other short-term interest rates were increased.
The spot rate on the British pound closed somewhat firmer yesterday in moderate trading on foreign-exchange markets here.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 23 Mrs. E.C. Kip Finch of the Country Club of New Canaan shot a 41, 39 80 at the Round Hill Club today to gain a onestroke victory in the one-day tournament of the Women's Westchester-and-Fairfield Golf Association.
Bronx Borough President Herman Badillo accused Mayor Lindsay yesterday of "total, complete and abject surrender" in the face of strong community opposition to two public housing projects in Queens.
GREENWICH, Conn., June 23 Richard H. Ayers, vice president and a director of the Chase Bag Company, died today in Greenwich Hospital. He was 55 years old and lived on Taconic Road.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) The man chosen to be the new Director of Central Intelligence stepped out of the official shadows briefly today to disclaim any policymaking role for the Central Intelligence Agency.

PARIS Although his disgruntled allies bleakly disagree with him, there is a cold Cartesian logic in de Gaulle's policy toward both NATO and the Soviet Union. LONDON, June 23--The seizure of a pirate radio station and the killing of its owner seemed likely today to force early Government action against unauthorized broadcasters.

CANTON, Miss., June 23? Mississippi highway patrolmen routed 2,500 civil rights demonstrators tonight with a thick fog of tear and irritant gas after the demonstrators had attempted to pitch camping tents on public school property.

The calmest man in the collision between the American tanker Texaco Massachusetts and the British tanker Alva Cape in Kill van Kull on June 16 was a 260-pound oiler from Jacksonville, Fla. He slept through it all.

JERICHO, L. I., June 23 Mrs. Albert Bower of Pelham and Mrs. A. Sherburne Hart of Essex County will meet tomorrow in the 36-hole final of the 63d annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 23 Pending developments from computers in New York, which under a new system will figure in what order each yacht places in her class and where she stands in the fleet position, there were certain solid results today that did not need electronic assistance in the Newport-to-Bermuda yaent race.

SAN JUAN, P. R., June 23 (AP) Mexico won the silver medal in the men's basketball tournament of the Central American and Caribbean Games today by defeating the Virgin Islands, 76-54, Puerto Rico had won the gold medal by beating Cuba last night.

Minority groups in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn have been made politically impotent through gerrymandering, it was charged yesterday in a suit filed in United States District Court in Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, June 23 The United States took steps today to prepare for the withdrawal of its forces in the Dominican Republic.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 23 Buddhist leaders reacted mildly today to a Government raid on the headquarters of the Unified Buddhist Church.
BONN, June 23 Julius Klein, the public relations man, denied today that he had pressed Senator Thomas J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, to travel to West Germany on his behalf two years ago.
WASHINGTON, June 23 An air travel explosion is making obsolete the limits foreign nations place on service by United States carriers, the airlines' chief spokesman said today.
CINCINNATI, June 23 (AP) Homers by Milt Pappas, the pitcher, and Vada Pinson in the fifth inning brought the Cincinnati Reds a 5-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 23 Railroad freight traffic generated by carloadings on United States railroads in the latest week ended June 18 was the highest in 22 years. Intercity truck tonnage in the latest week was ahead of the volume in the corresponding week of 1965.
The State Supreme Court yesterday upheld the Lindsay administration's controversial plan for a civilian-dominated complaint review board to hear charges against policemen.

CHICAGO, June 23 (UPI) Tommy Bolt, his temper calmed by four straight birdies, shrugged off his only bogey of the day on Medinah's tough No. 3 course today and grabbed the first-round lead in the $100,000 Western open with a threeunder-par 68.

DETROIT, June 23 The Governors of the American states almost sound these days as if they were going the way of the modern kings. They still have their official mansions, planes and police outriders, but their power is declining nonetheless.

The true issues in next Tuesday's primary race for Manhattan surrogate have become somewhat obscured by various irrelevancies. The worst of these is the gratuitous and completely unfounded issue of race which has been injected by J. Raymond Jones, the Democratic leader of Manhattan, and his allies. As an "issue," this charge is beneath contempt and deserves no further discussion by anyone.
ATHENS, June 28 (Reuters)--A seven-month crisis in church-state relations caused by the election or transfer of 17 bishops in defiance of a Government ban ended tonight.
WASHINGTON, June 23 President Johnson awarded today the Medal of Honor, the nation's highest military decoration, to an Army first lieutenant who said he would rather have it than be President.
The Bristol-Myers Company, a producer of drugs and toiletries, announced yesterday the election of Philip I. Bowman to the new post of senior vice president.
New-car sales of the General Motors Corporation fell 14 per cent in the middle 10 days of June, the company reported yesterday.
STOCKHOLM, June 23 (Reuters) The Swedish foreign Ministry announced tonight that Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin had canceled his planned visit to Sweden next month.

Of 10 important developments needed to make flying "the safest form of transportation," a Survey of air safety measures shows the discovery of a fuel that will not burn explosively is "the most striking potential."

Alfred G. Nowakoski, who from 1943 to 1953 managed real estate owned by Trinity Protestant, Episcopal Parish, died yesterday in Nice, France, where he had resided recently He was 78 years old and had lived in Bedminster and, Maplewood N.J.

In the difficult months for everybody in city and state politics Since Mayor Lindsay discovered the gravity of New York's fiscal emergency and drafted his tax program to meet it, the Democrats of the City Council have for the most part played a generally responsible role. They have had their lapses, but they have kept political by-play within reasonable limits, and supported the Mayor's case at Albany.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 24 Souvenir and Silver Lining an old-timer and a youngster both ridden by 26year-old Carlene Blunt, each won an open jumper class today as the Middlesex County Horse Show got under way.
Albert Axelrod grinds painfully on a lot of his fencing opponents' nerves. He his 45 years old, nearly twice the age of some of his opponents, and doesn't let them forget it.

NOVOSIBIRSK, U.S.S.R., June 24--The "Chicago of Siberia," as this city is sometimes called, flexed its great industrial muscle and mobilized its scientists, dancers and musicians today to impress President de Gaulle.

SPRINGFIELD, Mo., June 24 In Christ Episcopal Church here today Miss Jane Ellen Weigel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Richard Weigel Jr., was married to Richard Hunter Austin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Yates Austin Jr. of Waynesboro, Va., formerly of Scarsdale, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by Canon George Wilson.

The newest satellite in the sky, the balloonlike Pageos 1, has successfully settled into a high, near-circular orbit as a reference point of star-bright intensity for mapmakers in the nation's five-year effort to determine the exact size and shape of the earth.
WASHINGTON, June 24 Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach said today that he regretted the use of tear gas against civil rights marchers in Canton, Miss., last night.
Top officials of the striking New York Newspaper Guild and the World Journal Tribune expressed confidence yesterday that they would be able to settle their dispute on Monday or Tuesday.

PHILADELPHIA, Miss., June 24 The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and 300 civil rights marchers returned to downtown Philadelphia today and braved a speeding car, three bottles, two eggs and hundreds of shouts of "nigger."

SAN FRANCISCO, June 24 The DiGiorgio Corporation, a main target in the drive to organize California's grape pickers, suffered a setback tonight in an election it sponsored to determine if its vineyard workers at two ranches wished to be represented by a union.

LONDON, June 24 Dr. Arthur Waley, the distinguished translator of Chinese and Japanese literature, has been permanently paralyzed from the chest down as a result of an automobile accident that broke his spine.
The police of one of the busiest precincts in New York are advising suspects of their right to remain silent, but the suspects are talking anyway.
Two patrolmen under investigation on charges of brutality were suspended from the force yesterday on two charges of perjury. Their departmental trial is scheduled to begin on Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, June 24 President Johnson discovered today that great courage can come in small packages.

NORFOLK, Conn., June 24 E. Kendall Gillett of Norfolk, who retired in 1949 as an investment adviser with Loomis Sayles Co., Inc., investment counselors at 270 Park Avenue, New York died yesterday at Charles Hungerford Hospital in Torrington. He was 81 years old.
CLEVELAND, June 24 A municipal official and Negro leaders warned today that this industrial city faced a "volatile" racial crisis this hot, muggy weekend. They called for emergency measures.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 24 Susan Lenahan rode Roses Are Red to the large junior hunter championship and Kip Rosenthal piloted Good Boy Dee to the small junior hunter crown today at the Fairfield County Horse Show.
WASHINGTON, June 24 (UPI) The National Academy of Sciences-National Research Council announced today it would study the medical usefulness of 3,000 to 4,000 drugs introduced between 1938 and 1862.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., June 24 The death of Lieut. John R. McDonough, Naval Reserve air pilot, in an accidental crash at sea on Monday has been reported to his parents, Mr. and Mrs. John F. McDonough of South Orange by the Navy, it was learned today. The 27-yearold officer lived at 264 Walton Avenue here.
MADISON, Conn., June 24 Richard C. Donnelly, Simeon E. Baldwin Professor of Law at Yale University, died of cancer today at his home here. He was 51 years old.
PHILADELPHIA, June 24 (AP)--Roberto Clemente, Jesse Gonder and Willie Stargell hit homers in support of Bob Veale's five-hit pitching tonight as the Pittsburgh Pirates defeated Philadelphia, 3-1.
The Waterfront Commission has suspended five longshore workers linked to thefts from piers in Manhattan and Brooklyn.

Eight-oared crews from the New York Athletic Club, the Vesper Boat Club and the Penn Athletic Club Rowing Association of Philadelphia and the Union Boat Club of Boston will race today in one of the feature events of the 98th open rowing regatta of the N.Y.A.C.

The city of Le Mans in France, where, last Sunday, the annual 24-hour motor race ended in unprecedented victories for first, second and third places by cars of the Ford Motor Company, has several other associations for Americans. Modern aviation, for instance, had its first real take-off in Le Mans and the American Wilbur Wright, at the controls of his biplane, achieved it.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 24 (Reuters) Indonesian intellectuals demanded today that President Sukarno resign.
The American Stock Exchange ended the week bearish yesterday, with most stocks declining in quiet trading.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) A Civil Aeronautics Board report today on a jet airliner accident at Kansas City, Mo., a year ago brought to light new Government steps to cope with the hazards of high-speed landings on wet runways.

W.R. Grace Co. will continue to maintain its major role in the chemical industry while expanding in food and other areas of potentially lucrative return on capital investment. J. Peter Grace, president, told the New York Society of Security Analysts yesterday.
CAIRO, June 24 "I have no business seeing you," said the elderly lady. "It is very risky. You must promise not to mention my name or even that you have seen me."
A Queens elevator operator died yesterday in a two-alarm fire in an office building at 92-32 Union Hall Street in Jamaica.
The unemployment insurance bill just passed by the House of Representatives is a gutted version of the excellent proposals President Johnson sent to Congress a year ago.
MOSCOW, June 24 (AP) Two American women received big ovations today in the opening of the final round of the Tchaikovsky competition for young singers.
HONG KONG, June 24 Peking spurned today a proposal by Senator Mike Mansfield for a meeting between Secretary of State Dean Rusk and Communist China's Foreign Minister, Chen Yi.

TOKYO, June 23 With a general election approaching, pressures are increasing for Government action to curb the spiraling price rise. Specific programs to restrain price increases and protect the consumer were urged this week by two important groups and supported in the press.
Three employes of the Department of Traffic used bull horns yesterday to warn pedestrians of the dangers of jaywalking on 34th Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenue.
FROM the Boer War to the age of James Bond, Allen Welsh Dulles has had a deep interest and, not infrequently, a quiet hand in world-shaping events.
John B. King, the second highest-ranking official in the city school system, will leave his post as Executive Deputy Superintendent on Sept. 1.
Commissioner Howard R. Leary will fly to England on Monday to attend the second national conference on research and teaching in criminology at Cambridge University, it was announced yesterday.
CLEVELAND, June 24 (AP) Mike Hershberger got three key hits tonight as Kansas City defeated Cleveland, 7-5, despite two home runs by Rocky Colavito.

WASHINGTON, June 24 Peter J. Crotty, the Buffalo Democratic leader, was one of six or eight potential candidate whose names Senator Robert F Kennedy forwarded to the American Bar Association for an estimate of their qualifications.

BOSTON, June 24 (UPI) Attorney General Edward W. Brooke of Massachusetts, who refused to support Barry Goldwater for President in 1964, said today that he had received a $100 contribution from Mr. Goldwater for his Republican campaign for the United States Senate.

A damage suit for $2-million was filed yesterday by the owners of the British tanker Alva Cape against the American tanker Texaco Massachusetts, her owners, Domestic Tankers, Inc., and her operators Texaco, Inc.
ST. LOUIS, June 24 (AP) Interco, Inc., formerly the International Shoe Company, had record first-half sales in 1966, M.R. Chambers, chairman and president, said today.

WASHINGTON, June 24 Senator Thomas J. Dodd interceded with former Chancellor Konrad Adenauer of West Germany on behalf of Julius Klein, a Chicago public relations man, the Senate ethics committee was told today.
MEXICO, Mo., June 24 H.L. Beynon, vice president of the A.P. Green Refractories Company, died Tuesday at Audrain County Hospital. His age was 57.
AUSTIN, Tex., June 24--Reasons why Jack Ruby should have a new trial were given today before the three-man Texas Court of Criminal Appeals by lawyers.
Mrs. Helen Meehan Riley; president of the Barnard College Alumnae Association and the wife of George W. Riley, a lawyer of Tucson, Ariz., died there Wednesday. Her age was 64.
With grace and good humor, Saudi Arabia's King Faisal made it clear yesterday that he was not angry at the United States because he had been snubbed by Mayor Lindsay and Governor Rockefeller.

BOSTON, June 24 (AP)--Luci Baines Johnson, accompanied by her fiance, Patrick J. Nugent, arrived in Boston by plane today from Washington to attend the national convention of the American Optometric Association.
William Conover, former president of the Gray Manufacturing Company, makers of dictating and other equipment, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 301 East 66th Street, His age was 65.

Thirteen young women were presented last evening at the Westchester Catholic Debutante Cotillion of the Knights of Columbus in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. With their fathers as escorts, they were presented to the Most Rev. James McManus, Auxiliary Bishop of New York.

PALO ALTO, Calif., June 24 After the excitement of its opening on Wednesday, when the Orchestre de la Suisse Romande made its American debut here the third Stanford Summer Festival of the Arts moved on last night to a recital by Grant Johannesen. The American pianist's excellent program, flawlessly played, was no letdown as a musical contribution, but it suggested a closer look at the nature of the festival.

LONDON, June 24 Talks between the National Union of Seamen and British shipowners were suspended tonight. Whether they will be resumed depends upon the union's executive committee, which will meet tomorrow to decide the next move in the 40-day-old maritime strike.
For a while yesterday it looked as if today's Batman rock 'n' roll concert in Shea Stadium, for which more than 20,000 tickets have been sold, would not be held.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24 Eleven book publishers and two distributing concerns were charged with conspiracy to violate the Sherman Antitrust Act in a suit filed today in United States District Court here.
LOS ANGELES, June 24 Richard M. Nixon outlined today his plan for an intensive nationwide program of speechmaking on behalf of the Republican party between now and the general elections in November.

WASHINGTON, June 24 With one week to go before the start of Medicare, most eligible hospitals were in compliance with the regulations, and officials were optimistic over chances for a smooth start July 1.
DETROIT, June 24 (UPI) Despite the beginning of shutdowns for the 1967 model change-over, the auto industry is increasing production this week over last week, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.

The International Development Association is running out of money. This important affiliate of the World Bank has committed over $1.7 billion in loans since its inception in 1960 and needs a fresh transfusion of funds to continue in operation. Unlike the World Bank, which can raise funds in the, capital markets, I.D.A. has to depend on contributions from the rich countries, including the United States.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 24 With the political crisis dwindling, at least for the moment, the United States is prepared to re-emphasize its program of economic, social and political development for South Vietnam.

BRUSSELS, June 24 (Reuters) Belgium's two largest steel producers announced today they were planning a merger to form a company of "European size" required by the continuing development of the European Common Market.

The Dana Chapel of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church was the setting here yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Pamela Young Johnson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Cooper Johnson Jr. of 5 Beekman Place and Menemsha, Mass., to Vaso Runyan Medigovich, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Medigovich of Akron, Ohio.
WASHINGTON, June 24--Lieut. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, director of Selective Service, told the House Armed Services Committee today that he favored drafting nonfathers in the 26-through-34 age category.
New York's greatest track and field show in two years perhaps its best ever starts today on Randalls Island.
The 49-day-old Carey bus strike appeared to be nearing an end yesterday.

LONDON, June 24 A diplomatic informant who has just arrived in London from Baghdad said today that he felt it unlikely that the present talks between representatives of Gen. Mustafaal Barzani of the Iraqi Government would result in settlement of the five-year-old Kurdish War.

MOSCOW, June 24 Barbara Rondelli, an American finalist in the Tchaikovsky singing competition, received an orchestra score from New York by air today, enabling her to sing her chosen part before the judges.

WASHINGTON, June 24 Although Georgetown still has a corner on being the right address in the capital, a new contender for that status is Watergate East where, according to ads, "your address will be compared to Nob Hill in San Francisco, Park Avenue in New York and ... Beacon Hill, Boston." If price is a factor for rightness, Watergate is in.
JERUSALEM, (Israeli Sector) June 24 New York's official boycott of King Faisal was front page news here today, but there was no evidence that the incident had created much of a stir among Israelis.
The spot rate on the British pound dipped in moderate trading on foreign-exchange markets here yesterday.

Ninety-four degrees Thursday, Ninety-four degrees yesterday. Maybe 98 degrees this afternoon. But there will be no water today for the thirsty, sunburned lawn at 27 Borage Place in Forest Hills, Queens.

LONDON, June 24 Walter P. Chrysler Jr., paid the highest price that has ever been paid for a painting by Van Gogh today, when he bought the "Portrait de Mademoiselle Ravoux" for the equivalent of $441,000.

BAYONNE, N.J., June 24 A concert in Hudson County Park here by the award-winning 328th United States Army Band tomorrow afternoon will mark the beginning of a new era for the expanding Military Ocean Terminal-Bayonne.
SAN FRANCISCO, (AP) The Bank of America, the world's largest, finally came to terms with a cat.
WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) The Women's Army Corps is getting a new director, Lieut. Col. Elizabeth P. Hoisington of Newton, Kan.
LONDON--The Treasury has taken a tough line against companies wishing to transfer their headquarters abroad to escape high British taxes.

CARTHAGE, Miss., June 24 (AP) A rural Roman Catholic mission school for Negroes near here was destroyed by fire early today. The Federal Bureau of Investigation said it was looking into possible violations of Federal law.
NORTH STAMFORD, Conn. June 24 John Harrison Quayle Jr., a partner since 1945 in Oliver Quayle, a New York investment counseling firm, died today in his home on Cedarwood Road. His age was 59.
WASHINGTON, June 24 The Export-Import Bank expects to announce in about a month a major innovation in its operations a "rediscount facility" for export finance paper of commercial banks.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 24 Miss Sara Josephine Terwilliger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald L. Terwilliger of Allenhurst, was married here today to Lieut. (jg.) David Henry Guenther, U.S.N.R., son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry H. Guenther of Hornell, N.Y. The Rev. L. Dudley Rapp performed the ceremony in Trinity Episcopal Church.
CAPE KENNEDY, June 24 (UPI) The space agency said today it had delayed the first launching of a picture-taking satellite into orbit around the moon from July until August, at the earliest.

HOUSTON, June 24 Miss Susan Galt Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Earl Appleton Brown Jr., will be married tomorrow evening to Richard Hanley Barry, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Richard Barry of Dallas. Msgr. William F. O'Brien, assisted by the Rev. Francis Monaghan, will perform the ceremony in St. Anne's Roman Catholic Church.
Elston Howard broke Juan Pizarro's heart last night with one swing of his bat.
Mrs. Ida Stern, a Brooklyn housewife, emerged from the 1,520-seat Criterion. Theater yesterday afternoon, blinked into the 94-degree sunlight and sighed, "I feel drunk."

Miss Guerrie Louise Brown was married yesterday to Talmage Van Bennett Robertson Jr. in St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. James Sheridan. The bride is the daughter of John Leslie Brown of Little Switzerland, N.C., and the late Mrs. Anita Self Brown. Her husband is the son of Mrs. Robertson of Baltimore and the late Mr. Robertson.
YAKIMA, Wash., June 24 (AP) Mrs. Joan M. Douglas was granted a divorce in Superior Court here today from Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas.
JERICHO, L.I., June 24 Mrs. Albert Bower of the Pelham Country Club won the 63d annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship today.
The stock market staggered through an indecisive session yesterday.
"I like Buckpasser," said Clocker Lawton, who makes his living answering horseplayers who ask, "Who d'ya like?"
MIAMI, June 24 (AP) A 21-year-old Bay of Pigs veteran accused of trying to hijack a plane and divert it to Cuba was found not guilty tonight by a Federal Court jury.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 24 (AP) South Vietnam's constitution can be written and approved by a simple majority which will be elected Sept. 11, the Government decreed today.
Dr. Charles D. Schwarz of 88 Central Park West, who had been a staff surgeon of the Beth Israel Medical Center, died on Tuesday in Lenox Hill Hospital, He was 62 years old.

The silence hung heavy yesterday over the New York Naval Shipyard on the final day of its existence as a ship cradle and a haven for the binding of combat wounds of United States warships for more than 165 years.
The London Stock Exchange was firm yesterday on new hope that the British seamen's strike might be settled soon.

A New York record of sorts was established by the Wheatley Stable's Successor, the six-length winner of a 5 furlong sprint on the card. The colt paid $2.20, $2.20 and $2.20 for $2 across the board, in the 10 horse field. Aqueduct's mutuel department could not find a similar return for a maiden 2yearold race with such a large field in its archives. The runner-up, Richroband, paid $7.40 for place and $2.20 for show.

DETROIT, June 14 (AP) Zoilo Versalles and Jerry Zimmerman each drove in three runs tonight as Minnesota defeated Detroit, 9-2, in the second game of a double-header and halted the Tigers' six-game winning streak.
CHICAGO, June 24 (AP) Eight persons were arrested tonight as the police attempted to prevent a recurrence of racial trouble that has plagued a South Side public park all week.

Matthew J. Eder, executive vice president of the Uptown Chamber of Commerce in Manhattan, died yesterday at Terrace Heights Hospital, Hollis, Queens. He was 67 years old and lived at 85-86 Santiago Street, Hollis.

The Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn, the second largest savings bank in the country, announced yesterday that it intended to increase its interest rate on regular savings accounts to 5 from 4 per cent July 1.
LONDON, June 24 Dennis Ralston reached the quarterfinals at Wimbledon today by beating Pierre Darmon of France, 4-6, 6-3, 6-4, 6-4, and the weapon that counted most was his delicate touch on the lob.
CINCINNATI, June 24 (AP) Johnny Edwards drove in four runs with two singles as the Cincinnati Reds routed the San Francisco Giants, 12-1, tonight for their seventh consecutive victory.
HONG KONG, June 24 Communist China is reshaping its 15-year-old system of higher education because the party has found it to be politically unreliable.

ATLANTA, June 24 (AP) Claude Osteen, the Los Angeles Dodgers' pitcher, started a fourrun, eighth-inning scoring spree with a single tonight and led the Dodgers to a 4-0 victory over the Atlanta Braves.
N. Paul Loomba has been appointed vice president of operations research by the Ogden Corporation, a diversified operating concern.
HACKENSACK, N.J., June 24 Top-seeded Frank Froehling of East Orange, N.J., paced the field into the semifinals of the Eastern clay-courts tennis championships today at the Oritani Field Club.

SPOLETO, Italy,. June 24 Gian Carlo Menotti opened his ninth annual Festival of the Two worlds here tonight with a beautifully staged and dramatically intense new production of Claude Debussy's "Pelleas and Melisande."

BERLIN, June 24 East German-West German talks on wall-crossing permits for West Berliners broke down today amid growing indications that the Communists were seeking to hold off contacts with the West Germans for the present.

ROME, June 24--Pope Paul VI expressed regret today that "our sincere and disinterested efforts" for peace in Vietnam had failed to resolve the crisis, now aggravated by the "terrible prospect of the possible extension of the conflict."

WASHINGTON, June 24 The Justice Department denied today charges by lawyers for Robert G. Baker that evidence against the former Senate Democratic secretary had been obtained by wiretapping or electronic eavesdropping.

KARACHI, Pakistan, June 24 Pakistan's former Foreign Minister, Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, today ended a rail journey from Rawalpindi to Karachi during which he was accorded enthusiastic welcomes at major stations.

LOS ANGELES, June 24--Hume Cronyn warned today that the nation's burgeoning regional theaters would not achieve their rich potential unless their leaders were able to divert more money from the construction of opulent new theaters into the development of new companies and new acting talent.
A charge of police brutality was made yesterday against a patrolman by a city employe who claimed he was roughed up because he was unable to produce his driver's license and car registration.

HONOLULU, June 24 A Harvard dropout of the nineteen-thirties who now spends a third to a half of his time flying around the world by jet plane looking after his company's diversified interests is looking forward today to a "$70million week."

A quick look at a pair of partnership hands is usually sufficient to determine the most desirable contract. If the East-West hands in the diagramed deal were covered one would probably decide that seven hearts would be the best spot for North-South.

Miss Patricia Perkins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Perkins of 201 East 62d Street, formerly of Weston, Conn., was married yesterday to Alfred Trecartin Ogden 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Ogden of New York and Stonington, Conn. The Rev. Leopold Damrosch performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Resurrection. A reception was held at the Union Club.

WASHINGTON, June 24-A Tax Court judge has held that a woman who receives money and expensive presents from "her admirer" does not have to pay taxes on them if she can show that they were gifts and not payments for "services rendered."

BUFFALO, June 24 A White Ball, with white flowers in a predominantly white decor, was held this evening at the home of Mrs. Edward H. Butler for the presentation of her granddaughter, Miss Kate Butler Righter. The party was given jointly with Mr. and Mrs. James H. Righter of New York and Buffalo, the debutante's parents.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., June 24 Kennard G. Keen Jr., vice chairman of the board and former president of Arndt, Preston, Chapin, Lamb Keen, Inc., Philadelphia advertising agency, died here today at the age of 58.
TORONTO, June 24--Reform Jewish spiritual leaders concede that a reappraisal of traditional Jewish thinking is needed to meet the challenge of a secular, scientific-oriented society.

The Canoe Place Cabaret Theater will open July 5 at Shinnecock Canal in Hampton Bays, L.I. It will be under the auspices of John H. Morris Jr., in association with Williard Benner and Jay Allan Ornstein.

PARIS, June 24 (Reuters)An. international consortium of banks, led by S.G. Warburg of London, will underwrite a $15million Eurodollar bond issue jointly for two Austrian power companies, Elektrizitaetwirtschafts, A.G., and Donaukraftwerke, A.G.
TEL AVIV, June 24--The Israeli Philharmonic Orchestra's decision to lift the unwritten 28-year ban on the music of Richard Wagner and Richard Strauss is to be reviewed.
BUENOS AIRES, June 24 (AP) Two Argentine Air Force brigadiers were ordered under 25 days' house arrest today because of statements about the political situation, authorized military sources reported.
WASHINGTON, June 24 The House Appropriations Committee approved a $58.6-billion defense money bill today, almost $1-billion more than President Johnson requested.

Mrs. Pat Edrich of New York, the first-seeded player, won the Rose Taubele Memorial tennis tournament for the second straight year yesterday after dropping the first set of the final to Louise Gonnerman of River Edge, N.J., at the New York Tennis Club, in the Bronx.

Allen W. Dulles, former Director of Central Intelligence who was United States intelligence chief in Switzerland during World War II, has published the first of two articles containing heretofore secret details of his negotiations with Nazi generals that led to the surrender of almost a million German fighting men in Italy on May 2, 1945.

Two men were indicted yesterday by a Bronx County grand jury for violating the state law against dueling. It was the first such indictment in the Bronx since the law was passed in the early 19th century, according to District Attorney Isidore Dollinger's office.
CHICAGO, June 24 (AP) Homero Blancas and Kermit Zarley, former golf teammates at the University of Houston, shot two-under-par 69's today to share the second-round lead in the $100,000 Western Open.

Department of Commerce directives issued during the week ordering men's garment manufacturers to produce cotton combat uniforms for Vietnam have effectively brought about negotiations for the full 1966 requirements.

The Barber Oil Corporation and the Great Plains Development Company of Canada, Ltd., announced yesterday they would form a new Canadian exploration company to conduct a fiveyear old oil and gas expolortion program in Canada.
HOUSTON, June 24 (AP) Dave Nicholson drove in one run with a triple and scored two others tonight in leading the Houston Astros to a 4-1 victory over St. Louis.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 24 Arab leftists made capital today of snubs to Saudi Arabia's King Faisal by Mayor Lindsay and Governor Rockefeller, roundly condemning not only the United States, but also the conservative monarch himself.
WASHINGTON, June 24 A New Hampshire industrial engineer was granted a patent this week for what he calls his endless breadloaf system.
Net operating earnings of Schenley Industries, Inc., for the nine months ended May 31 rose to $16,590,902, or $3.23 a common share, the company reported yesterday.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., June 24 "The stage is set for another increase in the prime rate," the chairman of a leading New York City bank said here today at the 70th annual convention of the New York State Bankers Association.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands "It wasn't a big bank but it had a very old and good name. It is in the tradition of those private, family banks that built their reputations for centuries on doing business with kings and czars."
FRANKFURT, Germany, June 24 (AP) Cassius Clay, the heavyweight champion, will meet Karl Mildenberger of Germany on Sept. 10 in a world title fight at Frankfurt's 79,000-seat soccer stadium.
The election of William J. Klauberg as United States Lines vice president for the Far East has been announced.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 24--Thunderbird, a sloop of the Cal 40 persuasion of racing yachts belonging to T. Vincent Learson of Rye, N.Y., gained the pinnacle of American off-shore racing tonight by becoming the main winner of the biennial Newport-to-Bermuda competition.
The 11 dissident stockholders planning a proxy fight for control of the Canadian Javelin Company own a combined total of 3,765 shares of the concern.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., June 24 Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Hamilton have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Beatrice Alice Hamilton, to Nicholas Pell Sparkman, son of James D. Sparkman of New Rochelle and the late Mrs. Sparkman.

CANBERRA Australia, June 24 (UPI) Military advisers of the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization (SEATO) bluntly warned today that the threat of Communist Chinese aggression was growing in Southeast Asia despite the "improved" military situation in Vietnam.
The H.J. Heinz Company set records in sales and earnings in the fiscal year ended April 27, the annual report disclosed yesterday.
Steve Chilcott, a 17-yearold catcher who batted 500 for Antelope Valley High in Lancaster, Calif., has been signed to a substantial bonus contract, the New York Mets said yesterday.

Made presentation of Young American Medals; received report from Gardner Cowles of Look magazine on his trip to Africa; saw John Crimmins, new Ambassador to the Dominican Republic; saw Herbert Kamm, editor, New York World Journal Tribune.

WASHINGTON, June 24 The House Foreign Affairs Committee was accused today by its Republican members of "an abdication of responsibility", in approving a two-year authorization of foreign aid programs.
ESTORIL, Portugal, June 24 Don Juan de Borbon y Battenberg, exiled pretender to the Spanish throne, received here today the title of Protector of the Brotherhood.

More than 600 Orthodox rabbis from the United States and Canada will gather on Monday in Fallsburgh, N.Y., in the heart of the Catskills, to attend the four-day annual meeting of the Rabbinical Council of America. The theme of the gathering will be "The Crisis in Modern Religious Thought."

HAMILTON, N.Y., June 24 Dr. Omar C. Held, former associate dean of the college and professor of psychology at the University of Pittsburgh, died of Parkinson's disease here on Wednesday. He was a diplomate in clinical psychology of the American Psychological Association and belonged to Sigma Xi, the science honor society, He held a Ph.D. from Pittsburgh.
Thirty-four antipoverty workers were arrested yesterday when they staged a sit-down demonstration on the sidewalk in front of Governor Rockefeller's office here.

CANTON, Miss., June 24 The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. reached a compromise with city officials tonight that left the more militant demonstrators in the Mississippi civil rights march openly disgruntled and on the verge of mutiny.
BARCELONA, Spain, June 24 By defiant choice, Barce lona is an ambivalent, if not schizophrenic city culturally, politically, linguistically, economically and architecturally.

WASHINGTON, June 24 The index of primary market prices rose two-tenths of 1 per cent to 105.8 (1957-59 equals 100) during the week ended June 21, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. Farm products and processed foods advanced in price while industrial commodities averaged unchanged.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 24 Fred R. Zeller, Republican candidate for Governor of Connecticut in 1958, was sentenced today to serve a prison term of one year and a day to three years for having embezzled $26,297 from the First Baptist Church of Stonington.
OMAHA, June 24 (AP)--Yellow Transit Freight Lines, Inc., of Kansas City, Mo., announced the acquisition today of the controlling interest in Watson-Wilson Transportation System, Inc., of Omaha.

WASHINGTON, June, 24 (AP) Some 30,000 farm workers in sugar beet and cane production would be covered by Federal minimum wage and maximum hour standards under an amendment approved today by a Senate Labor subcommittee.

The marriage of Miss Victoria Wendell Ganz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Victor W. Ganz of 1175 Park Avenue, to Ronald Joseph DeFelice took place here yesterday afternoon. WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) The Senate confirmed today the nomination of Ross D. Davis of New York to be Administrator for Economic Development in the Commerce Department.
The General Instrument Corporation scored the highest sales, earnings and order backlog for any quarter in its 43year history in the first fiscal quarter ended May 31.

The Site Selection Board paved the way yesterday for Mayor Lindsay to authorize the projected new $6.5-million municipal parking garage in Long Island City, Queens, The board's vote was unanimous.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 112.1 on Thursday from 111.7 on Wednesday.

The onset of the ice ages that repeatedly buried much of North America was not abrupt as many have believed, but gradually over millions of years, it is reported in this week's issue of the journal Science.

Former Assemblyman Michael G. Rice, a Democrat, who represented the old Sixth District in Queens from 1954 until last year, died yesterday of a heart attack on the way to St. Francis Cardiac Hospital in Port Washington, L.I. His age was 41.

Moccasin will head the field of 10 fillies in the $100,000 added Coaching Club American Oaks at Aqueduct today. The Claiborne Farm's representative, who won all eight of her starts in 1965, has recovered from the back injury that kept her out of the Mother Goose two weeks ago. She is expected to be the 8-5 favorite in the 1 -mile race. In her 1966 campaign, Moccasin has won only one of four races.

FRANKFORT, Ky., June 24 The Kentucky Court of Appeals ruled today that Jefferson County cannot issue $400,000 in revenue bonds to pay for construction of a factory for an industry that went ahead and constructed the plant without public funds.

CHICAGO, June 24 Many of the fabrics and wallpapers and some of the floor coverings shown at the International Home Furnishings Market here this week were designed to complement the English style furniture that is also being shown here in great volume.
TORONTO, June 24 (AP) The Toronto waterfront was tied up today as 200 longshoremen walked off the job.

WARSAW, June 24 (AP) Shouting Polish Roman Catholics charged into a cordon of motorcycle policemen trying to clear the streets tonight after Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski had received one of his wildest ovations in 10 weeks of celebrations of the millenium of Christianity in Poland.

DETROIT, June 24 The mother of seven children ranging in age from seven to 21 has been named executive director of the new Institute for Continuing Education of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Detroit. The chorus of birdsong diminishes, as always When hot days come, though it still is heard in the cool of morning and evening. There are various theories about the reasons birds sing, but beyond all speculation is the fact that most of them are now too busy to sing. Their nestlings need a protein-rich diet, chiefly insects, and most of the parent birds' daylight hours are spent gathering food for them.

Archaeologists have dug up pools dat ing to 3,700 B.C., the Egyptian Pharaohs cooled off in pools within their palaces (the Greeks preferred theirs heated) and after 1850, the elite of European and American society swam in floating baths built inside large barges anchored to riverbanks. Stripes are racing into fall, whirling up, down and around on little knitted wools that tick off the days from summer to autumn with ease. Blazer stripes, awning stripes, old-school stripes in no-school colors are headed toward a smash-success season. The young will add barber-pole stockings, shiny patent shoes. The less adventurous will play it straight. But for any fashion-thinking woman, it's a multi-striped year.

But this his has not always been true of the Muskingum; it is a long river, but frequently a shallow one. BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 25 Representative Donald J. Irwin today avoided the threat of a primary election on the issue of Vietnam as he was renominated for a third term in Congress by the Democrats of lower Fairfield County.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 25 The British team of three yachts was established as winner of the Onion Patch Trophy today as the final order of business in the Newport-to-Bermuda race. TOURS, France As one of the major gateways to the well-traveled chateau country of the Loire Valley, this historic and hospitable city generally winds up at the bottom of the tourist's crowded itinerary. PASSENGER trains will run again in Maine next month for two days, that is. IT is now two years since the New York City school system eliminated the I.Q. from pupils' records. Banned under the pressure of groups that claimed the I.Q. was unfair to the culturally deprived, it has been replaced by achievement tests. Meanwhile, a great deal of effort is being put into developing new, nonverbal scales to measure schoolchildren's abilities while eliminating the troublesome factor of language.

The sale of furnishings valued at $2-million will precede the demolition of the Sheraton-East Hotel on Park Avenue between 51st and 52d Street. The hotel, which will close July 9, will be replaced by a 44-story office building.

Kaufman and Edna Ferber. Well man, this is what you can look forward to on the night of Sept. 27 that date's official now, as are the names that follow:
The Communications Satellite Corporation has announced a series of executive reassignments.
GLENS FALLS, N. Y., June 25 (AP) Wyman S. Bascom of Fort Edwards, a former member of the New York State Power Authority, died today in Glens Falls Hospital. He was 81 years old.

WARSAW, June 23-A Roman Catholic Archbishop again repudiated tonight a Government attempt to split the church in Poland by advancing him as a leader the clergy should follow in preference to Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski.
Many of the nation's coeds will count themselves lucky to spend the summer as baby sitters, camp counselors or variety store clerks.

TRENTON, June 25 The 190th session of the Legislature completed its work this week except for one more Assembly session on redistricting technicalities and the state never will be quite the same again.

CHICAGO, June 25 Buckpasser, the 3-year-old colt who was forced to miss all three portions of the Triple Crown because of a hoof injury gave Braulio Baeza, his jockey, the fastest one-mile horseback ride on record today.
BANGKOK, Thailand, June 25 (Reuters) Thailand will send peace corps volunteers to the United States as a reciprocal gesture for American Peace Corps volunteers dispatched to Thailand.

This nation of nearly five million people is two very distinct countries. There is the capital city: supermarkets and traffic jams, tasteful new buildings and busy commercial life, and beyond the urban slums that eat into the city from all sides the wide, shaded streets of the subuzrbs and the drably adequate housing projects of the growing middle classes.
SYDNEY, Australia, June 25 William McMahon, Federal Treasurer, and Australia's six state Premiers have completed the annual exercise of dividing the nation's financial cake.

THE Guggenheim Museum is presenting a most pleasant aspect just now, light and airy and air-conditioned with a new exhibition that puts no strain on the observer in spite of its educational premise, plus a couple of side-bars (a term used in the trade, having nothing to do with alcohol) it the form of miniature exhibitions filling the leftover space agreeably.

King Faisal of Saudi Arabia declared yesterday that political Zionism and not Judaism as a religion had been his target when, at a Washington news conference on Wednesday, he criticized Jews for helping Israel.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., June 25 The New York Athletic Club defeated the Penn A.C. Rowing Association and the Vesper Boat Club of Philadelphia today in the featured eight-oared race for the Stanley A. Wilde Trophy and carried off top honors in the club's 98th open regatta.

WEATHER, always is of great concern at an out door show. At today's 27th annual Staten Island fixture, though, there is no cause for worry. It is being held on the 80,000 square foot Cromwell Center roofed pier at Tompkinsville, overlooking New York Bay, with protection ...

MINNEAPOLIS, June 25 (AP) Minnesota Republicans broke a state convention stalemate late today by relaxing endorsement requirements and chose Harold E. Levander, 55year-old lawyer, as the party's choice for Governor after 15 deadlocked ballots.

ROSLYN, L. I., June 25 Miss Ann Lansing Raymond, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey F. Raymond of Locust Valley, was married today to Joseph Brown Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Brown of Greenvale and Mattituck, L. I. The Rev. Harold Whitmarsh performed the ceremony in Trinity Episcopal Church, assisted by the Rev. Nils Blatz.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, June 25 "Rhodesian cats have been saved from sanctions," The Rhodesia Herald announced recently.

WASHINGTON, June 26 A federation of 102 private, profitmaking hospitals warned the Administration today that its members may boycott the Medicare program starting Friday unless they are reimbursed for capital costs.
BONN, June 25 Chancellor Erhard raised anew today the question of West Germany's sharing nuclear armaments.
Determined economic belttightening is a basic requirement for solution of the United States balance-of-payments problems, three leading bank officials said last week.

In St. James Episcopal Church here yesterday afternoon, Miss Leslie Dean Hanifen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Lloyd Hanifen of New York and Georgian Bay, Ont., became the bride of Franklin John Charles Martin of Toronto and London. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Frank Martin of Toronto.
EAST GREENBUSH, N.Y., June 25 John Keller patted a 16-foot runabout named No Pra-Lem and savored the thought of getting up at 4 A.M. tomorrow to compete in the Hudson River Marathon.
The Episcopal Church of the Ascension was the scene yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Sarah Louise Fryer to Martin Lewis Leibowitz.

JACKSON, Miss., June 25 Several hundred city, state and county policemen were mobilized today in preparation for a rally on the Capitol grounds tomorrow by several thousand civil rights demonstrators.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 25 Outnumbered by African newcomers, older members of the United Nations are casting about for ways of countering the challenge to their leadership.
STANTON, Del., June 25 (AP) Regal Gleam, a 15-to1 shot owned by Patrice Jacobs, upset the favored Family Gallery in a stirring photo finish today to win $24,500 Blue Hen Stakes at Delaware Park.
STUTTGART, Germany, June 18-The United States Seventh Army in West Germany is strongly feeling the impact of the war in Vietnam.

PERRIS, Calif. Here, in the midst of the California potato fields, is a 10-acre streetcar mu seum at which a visitor can take a ride on a streetcar like the one named Desire or browse among 62 other trolleys, now collectors' items.

Rabbi Samuel Schrage, the Hasidic leader who organized a civilian anticrime patrol called the Maccabees in a Negro-white Brooklyn neighborhood, will be sworn in tomorrow as assistant executive director of the Youth Board.

HARRISON, N.Y., June 25 Miss Alana June Martin, daughter of Mrs. Lester Martin of New York and the late Mr. Martin, was married here this evening to Lewis Burke Frumkes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Frumkes of Harrison. Rabbi Jacob Shankman performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold L. Ginsburg, brother-in-law and sister of the bride.

WHITE PLAINS, June 25 The marriage of Miss Ellen J. Mahoney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jeremiah J. Mahoney of Elmsford and Pompano Beach, Fla., to Bruce McLanahan took place this afternoon. The bridegroom is a son of Mrs. William G. Heaphy of Wilton, Conn., and John D. McLanahan of New York.
In the last few weeks, a ship's captain, a former State Department employe, a stewardess and a retired automobile dealer each deposited $500 toward a new career.
Atlanta has had the biggest building spurt ever during the first half of 1966, despite the national and local shortage of mortgage money.

HOUSTON, June 26 The rental of office space throughout most of the United States and Canada has continued to reflect the impact of an expanding economy on the companies that occupy the major buildings.
ONE of the weaknesses of standard bidding methods becomes evident when the opening bidder has a balanced hand with 19 or 20 points and his partner is very weak.
Victor Gruen Associates has announced the appointment of Crawford C. Westbrook as an associate and head of planning in the concern's office here. Mr. Westbrook has been the coordinator since 1961.

HONG KONG, June 26 (AP) -- Some of the 40 or 50 American-trained Chinese atomic scientists working on Communist China's nuclear weapons have been caught in Peking's antiparty purge. The Hong Kong Star reported today.
WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) President Francois Duvalier of Haiti indicated today that discussions were under way for resumption of United States aid and said he was sure it would be resumed.

Fred Talbot and Fritz Peterson turned in their best performances as Yankee pitchers to give the New Yorkers a sweep of their double-header with the Chicago White Sox, 7-2 and 2-0, at the Stadium yesterday.
LONDON, June 26 The major whaling nations will get together here tomorrow to see if they can strengthen the agreement they made last year to conserve Antarctic whale stocks.

The program just submitted to Mayor Lindsay for coordinating all the city's activities in employment, welfare and education represents the most intelligent approach any metropolitan center has yet developed toward meeting the monumental challenges involved in the war on poverty.
F. Henri Klickmann, a composer, music arranger and editor, died Saturday in Knickerbocker Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived at 561 West 141st Street.
Summer operations of United States and Soviet Union shipping in Arctic waters off Greenland and along the Siberian coast are expected to be affected by abnormally severe ice conditions.
WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., June 26 John (Buck) Fulp of Anderson, S.C., gained his second victory of the season today in the series for the United States road-racing automobile championship.

NORWALK, Conn., June 26 Dr. Julius M. Rogoff, a pioneer in scientific research on the adrenal gland, died last night at Norwalk Hospital after a brief illness. He was 82 years old and lived on South Beach Drive on Bell Island.
HAUPPAUGE, L.I. June 26 Suffolk County's Democratic chairman, Lawrence Delaney, yielded to a leadership challenge tonight and announced his retirement.
NOYACK, L.I., June 26 Two Bronx youths who disappeared late yesterday when their small boat capsized in the little Peconic Bay, northwest of here, are missing and presumed drowned.

Pan American World Airways announced last week that it would be the first airline to use in scheduled service a system for making automatic aircraft landings. There was no indication when this would be.

SARATOGA, Calif., June 26 If you don't like what you hear in the Music at the Vineyards summer series, there is something to see a spectacular vista from the side of the Santa Cruz Mountains across the Santa Clara Valley to the distant Coast Range. The chances are, however, that you will enjoy the music, for the programs are chosen with taste and are expertly performed.

CANBERRA, Australia, Monday, June 27 Secretary of State Dean Rusk said on his arrival here yesterday for the 11th annual meeting of the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization that he saw no prospect of an early peace in Vietnam. The conference opened today.

The Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers last week announced the award of four graduate scholarships. Tuition fees for two semesters and living expenses are included in each of the awards, which this year will total $12,500.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., June 26 Miss Margaret Mary Brockbank, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas W. Brockbank, was married today to Richard Henry Lowright, son of Mrs. Raymond C. Lowright of Hershey, Pa., and the late Mr. Lowright. The ceremony was performed in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Pius X by Msgr. Clement J. Rieger.
LONDON, June 26 Dr. Immanuel Jakobovits of the Fifth Avenue Synagogue in New York was reported tonight to have been chosen to be Chief Rabbi of Britain and the Commonwealth.

John R. Arwood, who has been assistant to the general manager of the European Division of Sea-Land Service, Inc., has been appointed manager of the company's Far East Division. M.R. McEvoy, president of the company, made the announcement.

ANAHEIM, June 26 (AP) Brooks Robinson hit a tiebreaking single in a four-run eighth inning today, then singled across another run in a three-run ninth as the Baltimore Orioles belted 20 hits and whipped the California Angels, 12-7.

THE two strongest players in the Soviet Union the world champion, Tigran Petrosian, and the most recent challenger, Boris Spassky have been added to the roster of the Pratigorsky Cup Tournament, which begins July 17 in Los Angeles.

IN his first magnificent book about animal behavior, "King Solomon's Ring" (1952), Konrad Z. Lorenz, the Austrian natural ist and ethologist, contrasted the aggressive behavior and inhibitions thereon of doves and wolves. The dove, by apocryphal reputation sweet and peaceful, is in fact one of the cruelest of animals and will mutilate and destroy members ...
Charges of political deals and denials of deals were heard yesterday as the closely contested race for the Democratic nomination for New York County surrogate neared its decisive phase.
CORDELE, Ga., June 26 (AP) Bands of Negroes roamed through Cordele late today, tossing rocks, bottles and bricks at cars after whites and Negroes clashed at a state park near this south Georgia city.
The Inter-American Development Bank has announced a $10-million borrowing in Japan in freely convertible yen to foster the development of its member countries.
Future construction activity in the nation, which had registered strong monthly gains through the first quarter of this year, eased slightly in May.

WARSAW, June 26 About 1,000 anti-Government demonstrators marched up and down Warsaw's main street tonight, chanting slogans and singing hymns, and broke up only after riot policemen had twice charged into their ranks.
DETROIT, June 26 (AP) The Minnesota Twins staged two five-run rallies today and defeated the Detroit Tigers in both ends of a double-header, 7-5 and 7-1.
The Municipal Bond Women's Club of New York has elected Mrs. Margaret M. Burns of the Marquette de Bary Company as president. Mrs. Burns succeeds Jeannette F. Boondas of DempseyTegler Co., Inc.
The Ford Foundation began a major program yesterday to upgrade the quality of higher education in the South.
A House subcommittee has just completed hearings on a bill that is modest in scope but is of vital importance to the New York metropolitan area and could set a valuable precedent for the nation.

The Yankees play the Mets tonight at Shea Stadium in the fourth annual Mayor's Trophy Game. A crowd of more than 45,000 is expected for the game, which benefits the metropolitan area's sandlot baseball program.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., June 26 An absolute monarch held a seminar today and praised the free enterprise system before a group of scholars and men of affairs gathered at the treeshaded Pocantico Hills estate of the Rockefeller family.

A Carey bus filled with passengers left Kennedy International Airport at 3 P.M. yesterday for the East Side Airline Terminal at 37th and First Avenue as the company resumed its airport service after a 50day strike of its drivers and station personnel.

IF you believe The Worker, Gus Hall, whose election as general secretary of the Communist Party, U.S.A., was announced yesterday, is an allAmerican boy. Born in a snow-swamped log cabin in Minnesota of poor parents. Educated in the school of hard knocks.
HACKENSACK, N.J., June 26--Top-seeded Frank Froehling of East Orange had to rally today to win his second tennis tournament in eight days.

WASHINGTON, June, 26 A Congressional legal expert proposed here today that the United States withdraw from the 1960 Convention for the Safety of Life at Sea unless that international convention can be amended to afford better protection from fires for United States passengers.
LONDON, Monday, June 27 Radio City, the pirate radio station that was seized last week by a mysterious boarding party, was back on the air today, as eight members of the boarding party came ashore.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) The Food and Drug Administration opens hearings tomorrow on meprobamate, the technical name for what millions of Americans have come to call Miltown and Equanil, two widely used tranquilizers.

A 20-year-old woman found by the police yesterday at the side of the Henry Hudson Parkway, bruised and her clothes ripped, said that she had jumped 248 feet from the George Washington Bridge into the Hudson River Saturday night.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 26 West Germany, having established itself as the East European Communist countries' biggest trading partner in the West, in on the verge of improving its political relations in the region, too.
Hundreds of persons phoned village police stations in southwestern Westchester last night when a rumbling tremor was heard and felt in the area.

Ch. Barberry Knowe Blizzard a dark-silver brindle Scottish terrier owned by Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Statler of Woodcliff Lake, N.J., was named best of 828 dogs at the Staten Island Kennel Club show yesterday at Cromwell Center (Pier 6), Tompkinsville.

Since 1954, when Roger Bannister of England ran history's first sub-four-minute mile, that mystical outdoors barrier has been breeched 225 times by 72 men. The first 224 of those miles were run out of town. The 225th was achieved on Randalls Island yesterday by Jim Ryun, the 19-year-old University of Kansas freshman.
Dr. E. Elton Trueblood warned yesterday that blurring the distinctions between different religions for the sake of ecumenism meant the weakening of religion as a force for change in society.

IRVINGTON, N.J., June 26 The Rev. Maurice Cowan, cantor emeritus of Temple B'nai Jeshurun, Newark, died yesterday at Presbyterian Hospital, Newark, of a heart ailment. He was 76 years old and lived at 16 Marshall Street.

In an effort to "allay public anxiety," the Commissioner of Health denied yesterday that the walkout of 1,500 Health Department specialists constituted an emergency. "Essential patient services are being maintained," he asserted.
ATLANTA, June 26 (AP) Sandy Koufax became the No. 1 pitcher in the major leagues this season when he posted his 14th triumph today as the Los Angeles Dodgers edged the Atlanta Braves, 2-1.

THERE is a certain element of doubt about the possibility of the Yankees and the Mets clashing in the World Series; the only guaranteed meeting between these titans will come tonight at Shea Stadium. They will play in the annual Mayor's Trophy Game, with all proceeds going to the sandlot baseball program in the Metropolitan area.

The city will attempt to enlist major banks here as collection agencies for its new personal income and net earnings taxes. The purpose would be to cut the high cost of administering the new tax program.

The National Bureau of Economic Research, a private institution organized in 1920 that pioneered in developing many of the economics tools in use today, disclosed in its 46th annual report, to be made public today, that it is working on several new ones.

An antiquated operating room table collapsed during surgery at Morrisania Hospital, poorly maintained operating room lights fell on a surgeon at Bellevue, an overworked X-ray tube exploded at Jacobi Hospital, and three registered nurses one night made up the entire professional nursing staff of the 850-bed Harlem Hospital.

Vandals invaded the new Mount Carmel cemetery in the Glendale section of Queens over the weekend, toppling more than 100 gravestones, markers and stone benches. They tore down plot fences and damaged four pieces of the cemetery's motorized equipment.
WASHINGTON, June 26 The following is a list of loans and other aid extended last week by United States and other international lending agencies here:

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., June 26 St. Luke's Episcopal Church was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Patsy Gilchrist to Jonathan Mayhew Wainwright. The Rev. Samuel Davis performed the ceremony. A reception was held at the Maidstone Club.

VIENNA, June 26--Vienna is the home of music, psychology, baroque palaces and pastries. So what better place could Rudolf Nureyev find to unveil his balletic vision of the 20th-century dispossessed man? The question, you will understand, is rhetorical, for it was, in fact, Vienna that Mr. Nureyev chose first last year for his "Swan Lake," with its strange "Freudian" Siegfried, and now this season for his first totally new modern ballet, "Tancredi."
Intervention by the Federal Maritime Commission on behalf of American wool importers has succeeded in staving off temporarily a proposed increase in freight rates on raw wool.

MOSCOW, June 26 (AP) Jane Marsh, a 24-year-old soprano from New York, today became the first American to win a prestigious top prize in the Tchaikovsky International Music Contest since Van Cliburn won the piano award in 1958.
BATH, England, June 26 In the cream-and-gold setting of Bath's Georgian Guildhall yesterday, incense smoldered and Yehudi Menuhin sat crosslegged on the stage facing Ravi Shankar.

Following are the contests for Republican, Democratic and Conservative nominations for public office in tomorrow's primary in Manhattan, the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens. There are no contests in Richmond. There are no Liberal contests. Unopposed candidates are automatically nominated and their names will not appear on the ballot. Asterisks (*) denote incumbents. This does not mean they are necessarily incumbents in the districts in which they are running because of Federal Court ordered reapportionment.
INDIANAPOLIS, June 26 (UPI) A university, a reformatory and a steel company will join tomorrow in a program to get inmates out of the reformatory and into jobs in the steel industry.

CENTERPORT, L.I., June 26 (AP) Bill Cox Jr. of Noroton, Conn., won the Mid-Atlantic Finn Class sailing championships as the two-day, five-race series concluded today on Huntington Bay, off Long Island Sound.
With 100 yards to go in the 130-mile Hudson River Marathon yesterday, Cliff Reif had picked up what looked like the winning momentum.

The creation of a powerful single agency to merge, overhaul and direct all of the city's efforts to aid the poor has been recommended in a report by Mitchell Sviridoff, who was appointed by Mayor Lindsay to reorganize the city's antipoverty program.

KATONAH, N.Y., June 26 A distinctive and distinguished musico-dramatic work was given its American premiere late this afternoon when the Caramoor Festival staged Benjamin Britten's "Curlew River" in the Spanish Courtyard of the mansion on the festival grounds here.

LENINGRAD, June 26 President de Gaulle yesterday witnessed not only the launching of a satellite into orbit but also the firing of an intercontinental ballistic missile that landed in Eastern Siberia, French officials today said.

BARCELONA, Spain, June 26 Paintings by Picasso, Miro Calder and Tapies and manuscripts of Jean-Paul Sartre and Simone de Beauvoir have helped to pay the equivalent of $42,583 in fines levied by the Spanish Government against 33 Barcelona artists and intellectuals.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 26 The Rev. Joseph Patrick Lynch, a biologist and for the last four years a member of the mission band of the New York Province of the Roman Catholic Church, died today in St. Francis Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived at St. Andrew on Hudson, a novitiate here.
The first "talking typewriters" and "language laboratories" for general use in training retarded and emotionally disturbed children in state institutions will be installed this summer.

For most of his twenty years in the Senate A. Willis Robertson of Virginia has been overshadowed by his recently retired colleague, Harry Flood Byrd. To the irreverent he was sometimes known as "Byrd's other vote." But the automatic working of the seniority system carried Mr. Robertson to chairmanship of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.
John H. Potter, a retired theatrical manager, died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital, after an illness of several months. He was 78 years old and lived in Little Ferry, N.J.
State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz asked the public yesterday to assist his office on Primary Day tomorrow.
PITTSBURGH, June 26 Steel mills were displaying confidence about future business last week.
DUBLIN The Irish economy is in trouble. Part of the explanation lies in the republic's intimate economic relations with Britain.

Albert F. Stoll of Montclair, N.J., chairman of the board and president of the Russell Stoll Company, Inc., New York, manufacturer of electrical equipment, died yesterday in Memorial Hospital, at the age of 75.
WESTPORT, Conn., June 26 Dave Kelley of Ridgefield, Conn., rode three champions and three reserve champions at the Fairfield horse show today.
James Farmer said yesterday that he wondered whether he made the right decision earlier this year when he resigned as the national director of the Congress of Racial Equality.
"Jim Ryun for President!" two young fans, juniors at nearby Bryant High School, were shouting after the Kansas freshman's record New York mile at Downing Stadium yesterday.

HONG KONG, June 26 (Reuters) North Vietnam's official newspaper Nhan Dan, commenting on speculation of increased United States air attacks unless Hanoi agrees to peace talks, said today the North Vietnamese armed forces would continue to talk with guns.

JACKSON, Miss., June 26 A wave of 12,000 to 15,000 singing, shouting marchers brought the long civil rights march through Mississippi to an end today by crowding around the State Capitol and demanding immediate and widespread reforms in the treatment of Negroes.
