SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 26 An American major general was recently questioning a North Vietnamese captain who had deserted. The general was curious about the enemy's policy on rotation of troops.
Civil rights groups, home town mayors, beauty queens, entertainers and Governor Rockefeller and Senator Robert F. Kennedy marched yesterday in the Puerto Rican community's annual Fifth Avenue parade.
It has been found that certain atomic particles, identical except in being of opposite electrical charge, do not behave in an equal although opposite manner.

PARIS, June 26 Seven lengths off the lead and running 14th in a field of 20 after a mile, Danseur rallied to win the Grand Prix of Paris today under the deft handling of Yves St. Martin, a jockey with good hands and a good head.

Miss Judith Elbaum, daughter of Moshe Elbaum, city editor of The Jewish Daily Forward, and Mrs. Elbaum of Elmhurst, Queens, was married last evening to Marvin Schwartz, son of Mrs. Maurice Schwartz of New York and the late Mr. Schwartz, the actor.
BONN, June 26 (AP) The Soviet Union and West Germany will begin talks in Moscow July 13 to step up trade between the two countries, Germany's Foreign Office announced over the weekend.

A traditional profit-leverage factor used by the nation's big retail chains, that of anticipation discounts, is now in a state of flux because of the recent increases in the prime rate. A further rise in the pime rate, reported possible in banking circles last Friday, would aggravate the situation further and could conceivably lead to price increases by apparel producers.

The decision of nearly 1,500 doctors to stay away from their part-time jobs in community health centers, as a means of pushing the city into giving them tenure and higher pay, highlights the sick state of municipal labor relations.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) About 1,000 persons gathered today in Lafayette Park across Pennsylvania Avenue from the White House to denounce violence against civil rights workers in Mississippi and to demand Federal action. There was entertainment between speeches, including a song, "Let It Shine," by Lena Horne.

HYANNIS, Mass., June 26 (AP) A Los Angeles optometrist, his wife and their four children, returning from an outing on Nantucket Island, were killed today when their single-engine rented plane crashed in woods near Barnstable Municipal Airport.
An offering of $175-million of bonds by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) is the highlight of this week's schedule in the credit market.
HACKENSACK, N.J., June 26 Tragedy struck the Papoutsakis family again yesterday when Steven Papoutsakis, 12 years old, drowned with a friend in the Hackensack River in Teaneck.
CAPE MAY COURT HOUSE, N.J., June 26 (AP) Marshall Bainbridge Jr., retired publicity director for the Garden State Race Course, died at Burdette Tomlin Hospital here today. He was 73 years old.
LONDON, June 26 Thirtytwo leading British literary and public figures are protesting the rejection by the Soviet Embassy here of a petition delivered last month on behalf of Soviet Jews.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 26 (AP) United Nations economists predicted today a continued expansion in the world economy this year, with brakes applied in some areas and the developing countries operating under continued handicaps.

CHICAGO, June 26 Ron Santo, Chicago Cub third baseman and a leading candidate for the All-Star team, who had just stretched his hitting streak to 25 consecutive games, suffered a fractured cheekbone today when he was hit in the face by a pitch. He will be out of action for about 10 days.
It's quite an experience for the average person to sit in on a "closing" session, during which the sale of a home is consummated.

CLEVELAND, June 26 An explosive fire destroyed a supermarket early today in an area of the city that has been the target of racial violence for four straight nights. No one was injured but damage was estimated at $45,000.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 26 Red Shoes, a 10-yearold chestnut mare, who had her owner discouraged two months ago, won the open jumper championship at the Middlesex County horse show today with 12 points.

FORTVILLE, Ind., June 26 (AP) Jack Glock of Oconomowoc, Wis., won the 20-gauge title in the fifth annual Mid-America skeet championships at the Indiana Gun Club yesterday, but he had to break 235 straight clay targets to do it.

CHICAGO, June 26 The New York Mets completed the most successful tour in their history today by splitting a doubleheader with the Chicago Cubs. They won the second game, 8-2, after losing a 7-0 opener marked by pitched-ball injuries to Ron Santo and Adolfo Phillips of the Cubs.

The Organization of American States is taking a worthwhile gamble in agreeing to start removing the Inter-American Peace Force from the Dominican Republic immediately. The troops are to be out of the country within ninety days, after which the republic will again be a sovereign and independent state.

CHICAGO, June 26--The taking of those harmless and presumably ineffective sugar pills called "placebos" can result in lowered blood pressure and improvement in acne, according to reports to the American Medical Association today.

CHANDIGARH, India, June 26 The "organic city" of Le Corbusier is growing a second head. This gleaming new capital on the searing plains of the Punjab, planned and partly designed by the late French architect, will now become what one leader here calls a "twoheaded, three-tongued administrative political monstrosity."
The election of Gus Hall as general secretary and Henry Winston as national chairman was announced by the Communist Party, U.S.A., as its 18th national convention ended here last night.

ATLANTA, June 26 (UPI) Mario Andretti led every lap today to win the second annual $80,000 Atlanta 300. A crowd of 27,500 watched the defending United States Auto Club champion average 139,319 miles an hour in his Dean Racing Enterprises rear-engine Ford.
The racing career of Kauai King, who was recently syndicated for the greatest sum in thoroughbred history, ended yesterday with the discovery that the 3-year-old had broken down.

WASHINGTON, June 26 The right to protest and dissent from the Government's policy in Vietnam was strongly supported by Jewish organizations today at the annual meeting of the National Community Relations Advisory Council.

CINCINNATI, June 26 (AP) Gaylord Perry pitched five perfect innings and allowed only two hits today as the San Francisco Giants stopped the Cincinnati Reds' winning streak at eight games with a 10-0 victory. The Giants hit five homers, two by Tom Haller.
Domestic new orders for machine tools last month were the highest for any May in the last 14 years, the National Machine Tool Builders Association reported over the weekend.
CHICAGO, June 26--Dr. James Z. Appel, outgoing president of the American Medical Association, warned doctors today against increasing fees after Medicare takes effect Friday.

The Establishment Theater Company and Will Geer will share the $500 annual Lola D'Annunzio award. The company was selected for "its contribution to Off Broadway this season." Mr. Geer was named for "his contribution over the years to the Off Broadway theater" and for his performance as Robert Frost in "An Evening's Frost."
The Douglas Aircraft Company has announced that it will unveil the first Super 62 DC-8, the world's longest-range commercial jetliner, tomorrow at its Long Beach, Calif., plant.

WASHINGTON, June 26 Secretary of Commerce John T. Connor said today "a key decision" affecting defense procurement related to Vietnam would have to be made "along about the middle of the fall of this year."

WASHINGTON, June 26 Under Secretary of State George W. Ball attempted today to discourage current reports that the Johnson Adminisration was approaching a decision to extend the air war in North Vietnam by bombing fuel dumps at Haiphong.
GREENWICH, Conn., June 26 Victor R. Coudert, retired newsprint sales executive, died today at his home, 12 Grahampton Lane. He was 74 years old.
CHICAGO, June 26 (UPI) Billy Casper closed with a oneunder-par 70 today and successfully retained his Western open golf title on Medinah's No. 3 course with a 72-hole total of 283.
Max Geuter of Frankfurt, Germany, won the foils title last night by capturing six of seven matches in the final round of the United States fencing championships.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay South America's smallest republic is slowly drawing back from the verge of national economic disaster that nearly enveloped the country one year ago.
ALBANY, June 24 Senators Harrison J. Goldin and Jerome Schutzer have a problem: They are sharing an office here and opposing each other for renomination in Tuesday's primary election.

The Old Dominion Foundation has made a grant of $25,000, the New York Shakespeare Festival's largest single donation this year, it was reported yesterday by Joseph Papp, the festival's founder-producer. The money has been earmarked for the 275-seat theater in the former Astor Library on Lafayette Street, south of Astor Place.
The City of New York is planning radical changes for the Federal Foreign Trade Zone or free port on Staten Island and may even move the station to another area of the waterfront.

LAWRENCE, L.I., June 26 Miss Myra Grosof, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Nathan S. Grosof, was married today to Richard Bennett Cooper, son of Federal Judge Irving Ben Cooper and Mrs. Cooper of New York. Rabbi Joel Y. Zion performed the ceremony in Temple Israel.
MOSCOW, June 26 A bitter dispute between actors of Moscow's popular Theater of Satire and Valentin N. Pluchek, its stage manager, is being followed with amusement and concern by Soviet intellectuals.

TRENTON, June 26--A number of New Jersey's Democratic leaders, alarmed by an apparent growing, grass-roots dissatisfaction in the state with President Johnson's Vietnam policy, are seriously considering breaking with the President on Vietnam in the fall election campaign.
WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) The Interior Department announced tonight the allocation of $18,275,000 to the states for fish and wildlife restoration.
WASHINGTON, June 26 After endorsing a call for a meeting of Western Hemisphere presidents, the Johnson Administration is looking for proposals that it can put before them.
WASHINGTON, June 26 (UPI) President and Mrs. Johnson stayed at home and did not attend church services today, the fourth day of a heat wave here.

CHICAGO, June 26 (UPI) Mrs. Narcissa Niblack Thorne, widow of James Ward Thorne, a Montgomery Ward Co. heir, and designer of prized miniature rooms that have been seen by thousands of visitors to Chicago's Art Institute, died today at her home on the Near North Side. She was 84 years old.

LONDON, June 26 (UPI) The Kabaka (king) of Buganda Sir Edward Mutesa, said today he escaped from his palace in a taxi when Uganda troops attacked it last month. He said his brother, Prince Henry, fled in a bus.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 26 Two United States marines who escaped from their Vietcong captors told today how they had managed to disarm their guards and fled. For four days they eluded pursuers and at one time Vietcong guerrillas came within a few feet of their hiding place.

An enterprising young woman who shares with Parks Commissioner Thomas P.F. Hoving the idea that "parks are for people" made a bid here Saturday night to become the city's first hostess to give a black-tie picnic and dance in Central Park after dark. She did not succeed.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 26 United States marines and South Vietnamese troops battered enemy troops from four sides yesterday in a new operation in the marshy flatlands north of Hue.
Dr. James R. Kreuzer, a professor of English at Queens College, has been named dean of students, effective Sept. 1.

SCARBOROUGH, Ont., June 26 With the support of American and Soviet officials, a proposal for an experimental suspension of underground nuclear tests was advanced here today by a nongovernmental conference on the problems of preventing the spread of atomic weapons.

Deputy Mayor Timothy W. Costello predicted yesterday that settlements with unions representing 96,000 public employes, whose contracts expire this week, would be "reasonable for the city and fair for workers."

BOSTON, June 26 (AP)-- Fred Valentine and Ken Harrelson hit home runs today and helped Jim Hannan gain his first victory this season as the Washington Senators defeated the Red Sox, 9-3, after Boston had won the first game of their double-header, 13-7.
MEXICO CITY, June 25 One of Mexico's leading bankers has warned against efforts to "Mexicanize" foreign-controlled companies here.
LENINGRAD, June 26 President de Gaulle drove to Leningrad's only functioning Roman Catholic Church this morning, attended mass and took communion.
Scientists have learned how to "fingerprint" germs, a technique that may soon lead to new and faster methods of detecting and identifying disease.

LUCERNE, Switzerland, June 26 (AP) Kathy Kusner of Arlington, Va., captured the final event in the week-long international horse show today after an all-American jumpoff with Crystine Jones of Bloomfield Hills, Mich.

Funeral services will be held today for Capt. Graham C. Lewis, master of the British tanker Alva Cape, and seven German seamen in his crew who died in the collision June 16 with the Texaco Massachusetts in the Kill Van Kull.

WASHINGTON, June 26 The Johnson Administration has developed an unusual plan for settling construction labor disputes. The plan could lead to a moderation of the large pay increases negotiated in the construction industry.
Dr. Jakobovits declined to comment last night on a report that he would be asked to become Chief Rabbi of Britain.
MONTREAL, June 26 The solemn divine liturgy of St. John Chrysostom, one of the five ancient rituals of Eastern Orthodoxy, was celebrated this morning atop Mount Royal.
New York University announced yesterday the appointment of Dr. Lewis Thomas as dean of its School of Medicine and deputy director of its Medical Center.

Richard K. Manoff, Inc., was recently assigned the advertising of Hebrew National Kosher Foods, Inc. It's not the biggest account in the world, but for Mr. Manoff, chairman and president of the agency, it has been one of his biggest pleasures.

Negotiators for the Newspaper Guild, which is on strike against the new World Journal Tribune, Inc., and for the drivers' and mailers' union, will meet with the publishers today at the Publishes Association of New York, 220 East 42d Street, in another effort to end the 64day old stoppage.

OLD GREENWICH, Conn., June, 26 Forty-five teen age boys put some extra polish on their carefully casual exteriors last night, picked up 45 equally casual young women and headed for the opening of a new night spot here called The Sound.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., June 26 Dr. John Dane, who practiced medicine and surgery in this village for more than a half-century, died Friday at Orange Memorial Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived at 117 Vose Avenue.
Senator Robert F. Kennedy proposed yesterday that the United States, take "some initiatives" toward getting Communist China into the United Nations.
The "Bell Telephone Hour" will take its cameras behind the scenes of this summer's Berkshire Festival at Tanglewood for a one-hour program to be televised next fall.
Plans for making the Times Square area "a showcase for the American people" were disclosed yesterday by James L. Marcus, coordinator of Mayor Lindsay's campaign to clean up the area.

Cambridge University Press, which has for more than a year planned a program of facsimile reprints of its most sought out-of-print books, has made known the first seven titles in the series. They will be ready by the fall, probably in November.
NEWPORT, R.I., June 26 Newport roared back into the nineteen-twenties last night and everyone seemed to enjoy the trip.

Three floors, containing a total of 60,000 square feet of space, have been taken by Ernst Ernst, certified public accountants, in the black-square office building at 140 Broadway in the financial district.

MIAMI BEACH, June 26 The board of directors of the 986,000-member National Education Association today unanimously recommended a merger with the American Teachers Association, a Negro professional organization. Final approval for the unification is expected Tuesday from the N.E.A.'s delegate assembly.
MOSCOW, June 26 Andrei D. Sinyavsky and Yuli M. Daniel are both in ill health after four months in a Soviet labor camp, according to friends of the two writers in Moscow.
The United States Lines has begun what it says is the fastest door-to-door container ship movement in the North Atlantic.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 26 Miss Johanna Elizabeth Jones, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roy J. Jones of Auburn, Ind., was married here today to Lieut. William Edris Dock, U.S.A., son of Mrs. Frances Skinner Edris of Balboa, Calif., and the late Herman Anthony Dock.
LONDON, June 27 Both Britain and Rhodesia were reported today to have given ground sufficiently during three weeks of talks in Salisbury to justify continuation of the meetings.
During batting practice, Ralph Houk, the Yankee manager, noticed an unusual sign being carried through the stands in this banner-happy ball park.

CINCINNATI, June 27 (UPI) Pete Rose doubled in one run and scored another in the first inning tonight as the Cincinnati Reds downed the Los Angeles Dodgers, 3-1. Milt Pappas received his seventh pitching victory.

Joseph M. Judge, chief architect for the Board of Higher Education, died Saturday in Mary Immaculate Hospital, Jamaica, Queens, after a short illness. He was 68 years old and lived at 110-31 73d Road, Forest Hills, Queens.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., June 27 (AP) A businessman injured in a cocktail lounge disturbance involving Frank Sinatra does not intend to file any criminal complaint, his lawyer and the police said tonight.
The case of the dismissed teachers of St. John's University has been taken to the ecclesiastical courts of the Roman Catholic Church.
BUENOS AIRES, Tuesday, June 28--President Arturo U. Illia dismissed the commander of the army early today but the officer defied the order in a steadily deepening political crisis in Argentina.
ANYONE interested in the future of wildlife in the United States is aware or should be of the precarious situation of eagles. They are on a downhill road.

Instead of cleaning out their desks on the last day of school yesterday, about 700 pupils said good-by to their 148-year-old Junior High School 3 in Greenwich Village by dancing the frug, cha-cha and hora.
Harris, Upham Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday the election as vice presidents of Joaquin Titolo, John A. Hautman and William D. Van Dyke 3d.
Bernard (Boom Boom) Geoffrion, the Montreal right wing with the crackling slap shot, was bought yesterday by the New York Rangers for the waiver price of $30,000.

ST. LOUIS, June 27 (AP) Willie Mays moved into third place on the career home-run list with a two-run shot in the first inning that lifted the San Francisco Giants to a 2-1 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals tonight.

MIAMI, June 27 Premier Fidel Castro welcomed Cuban athletes returning from the 10th Central American and Caribbean games today, but he did not deliver a speech at the ceremony, which was held in Santiago.

WASHINGTON, June 27 The Federal Reserve Board announced today an increase in required reserves that banks must hold against time deposits of more than $5-million. The reserve rate was raised to 5 per cent from 4 per cent.
The discovery reported yesterday that nature favors an atomic particle with positive electric charge over its negatively charged sister has led to a rash of experiments to test its implications.
Shareholders of Sterling Drug, Inc., and the Lehn Fink Products Corporation approved yesterday a merger of the two companies at separate meetings in Wilmington and New York.

WASHINGTON, June 27 The request by Senator Dodd's counsel today that Senator Bennett of Utah be disqualified as a member of the Senate Special Committee for "clear prejudgment" of the charges of Dodd's misconduct that the committee is investigating, was strictly for the record.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., June 27 Wilfrid A. Gervais, recently retired manager of contracts for the international division of the General Electric Company, died yesterday in the White Plains Hospital of cancer. He was 54 years old and lived at 1 Carlyle Place.

CYNWYD, Pa., June 27 Steve Ogilvy of New Rochelle, N.Y., seeded second, advanced to the third round of the United States senior clay-court tennis championship today by defeating Leo Bloom, a former University of Pennsylvania player from Reading, 6-2, 6-2, at the Cynwyd Club.
John Eliot Woolley, former advertising director of Life's international editions, died Sunday in Palm Beach, Fla., after a long illness. He was 68 years old and lived at 167 East 82d Street.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (UPI) The House passed and sent to the Senate today legislation to increase size and weight limits on parcel post packages. Rates would be raised by about 8 cents a parcel.
WASHINGTON, June 27 Senator Thomas Joseph Dodd has time and again surprised his colleagues by flouting Senate tradition.

Red, white and blue Medicare plaques will be on display Friday in at least 90 per cent of the state's hospitals. The markers will proclaim the readiness of the hospitals to assist the 1,943,000 New Yorkers 65 years old and over who carry matching red, white and blue Medicare cards.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (UPI) Offshore petroleum exploration and development, already up sharply, must be stepped up further to meet future energy needs, the president of the American Petroleum Institute said today.

The Northern Illinois Gas Company reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the 12 months ended May 31. The utility noted that weather in the 1966 period had been 2.4 per cent warmer than normal.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 27 The leadership of the Croatian Communist party has condemned Vaceslav Holjevac, a partisan hero in World War II who is generally rgarded as a liberal party official, for authorizing the award of prizes to two dissident Marxist philosophers associated with the magazine Praxis.
LONDON, June 27 Dr. Arthur David Waley, the eminent translator of Chinese and Japanese literature, died today at the age of 76.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange were off by fractions yesterday as uncertainty continued over the outcome of the seamen's strike.
TORONTO, June 27 (AP) Some 150 checkers on the Toronto waterfront who walked off their jobs Friday after one of them was charged with a liquor violation voted today not to return to work.

NEWARK, June 24 A Mexican divorce decree won by David Kislak, chief of a large real estate, mortgage banking and insurance firm with headquarters here, has been declared invalid by the Chancery Division of Superior Court.
MOGADISCIO, Somalia, June 27 (Reuters) President Aden Abdulla Osman today refused to accept the resignation of the Government of Premier Abdirizak Haji Hussein.

MIAMI BEACH, June 27 The powerful department of classroom teachers of the National Education Association voted overwhelmingly today to recommend that the association expel any of its state or local affiliates not racially integrated by June 1, 1967.

LOS ANGELES, June 27 Some of Hollywood's top film stars were criticized here last night for their failure to assist the growth of the regional theater movement, their "ridiculously high wages," and their lack of help to students of the theater.
TEL AVIV, June 27 Rabbi Zalman Sorotzkin, chairman of the Council of Torah Sages, died in Jerusalem last night. He was 86 years old.
TRENTON, June 27 Gov. Richard J. Hughes and several other New Jersey Democratic leaders joined today in reaffirming their support of President Johnson's policy on Vietnam.
WANTAGH, L.I., June 27 Dr. Leo R. Ryan, principal of Forest Hills High School, Queens, since 1946, died today of a stroke in his home at 3301 Cayuga Place. He was 62 years old.

RAY BROWN of New York and Michael Kassay of Hicksville, L.I., achieved on Sunday the unusual feat of successfully defending a regional championship. They teamed with Agnes Gordon and Nat Gerstman of Buffalo to capture the Open Teams in the New England Regionals at Swampscott, Mass.
SARK, Channel Islands, June 27 (Reuters) Desmond Young, an adventurer and writer best known for his biography of the German Field Marshal Erwin Rommel, died here today at the age of 74.
Mayor Lindsay is expected to announce shortly the appointment of Herbert L. Haber to the new post of City Director of Labor Relations.

ATHENS, Ga., June 27 (AP) Questioning of prospective jurors was completed tonight and attorneys prepared to choose the 12 who will try three white men charged with conspiracy in the slaying of Lemuel A. Penn, Negro educator.

SAN MATEO, Calif., June 27 Mr. and Mrs. Alan H. Ames have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alice Proctor Ames of New York, to Nathaniel Holmes Morison 3d of Middleburg, Va. A wedding in August is planned.

Amid cheers for the losers, jeers for the winners and a certain amount of vocal criticism of the Mayor of New York, the New York Yankees defeated the New York Mets, 5-2, in the annual Mayor's Trophy game at Shea Stadium last night.

The Consolidated Laundries Corporation, whose services in the East range from laundry and dry cleaning to rental of furs and phone-answering services, is planning to add a widely diversified group of businesses through a proposed acquisition of Dunhill International, Inc.
One of the Port of New York Authority's oldest employes and in the early nineteen-twenties the agency's only switchboard operator will retire this week after 45 years of service.

LONDON, June 27 A 22year-old baronet, Lieut. Sir Ranulph Twisleton-WykehamFiennes, was accused today of having set fire to a can of gasoline in the idyllic English village of Castle Combe, where 20th Century-Fox is filming "The Story of Doctor Dolittle."
The spot rate on the British pound was up slightly in fairly active trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday.
The National Association of Accountants announced yesterday at its annual conference here the election of Firman H. Hass as president.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 27 (Reuters) South African mine operators were advised today to stop hoping for a worldwide revaluation that would raise the price of gold.

ALBANY, June 27 All industrial air pollution control equipment installed within the next seven years would be exempted from property taxes under the terms of a bill passed unanimously today by the State Senate.

ALBANY, June 27 Governor Rockefeller persuaded legislative leaders to amend a bill, already passed by the Legislature, that increases state funds for supplying textbooks to students in private and parochial schools.

"The Odd Couple," Neil Simon's comedy starring Eddie Bracken and Pat Hingle, will be transferred Aug. 1 from the Plymouth Theater to the Eugene O'Neill Theater. The author owns a half interest in the latter house.

WASHINGTON, June 27 President Johnson withheld endorsement today of controversial legislative proposals advanced by the National Commission on Food Marketing to preserve competition in the food industry and to aid consumers and farmers.

MONTREAL, June 27 Archbishop Iakovos, head of the Greek Orthodox Church of North and South America, disclosed today that the Standing Conference of Orthodox Bishops of the two continents would enter into formal dialogue this fall with the Roman Catholic Church.
It was a very bubbly occasion, complete with champagne, a rock 'n' roll combo and about a dozen strippers.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) The Senate passed by voice vote and sent to the House a bill authorizing five Government demonstration plants on fish protein concentrate research at a cost of $5- million.
The Federal Reserve Bank of New York announced yesterday the appointment of Angus A. MacInnes Jr. as vice president in charge of the Buffalo office.

Four floors with a total of 50,000 square feet of space, have been leased by Goodbody Co., stock brokers, in the 30-story office building being erected by the Rudin Management Company at 55 Broad Street, northeast corner of Beaver Street, in the financial district.
WASHINGTON, June 27--A man who came to the aid of an embattled Indiana State trooper received today the first $5,000 Carl M. Loeb Jr. Award for Citizen Valor.
CHICAGO, June 27 (UPI) A Federal judge refused today to ban the recital in a kindergarten classroom of a "We thank you" verse that two protesting parents said was a prayer.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 27 United States Navy pilots attacked a large underground fuel dump in North Vietnam yesterday, sending a fireball and thick black smoke 3,000 feet into the air.

Harold F. Hendee, former research director for R.K.O.-Radio Pictures and recently a member of the editorial staff of The Reader's Digest, died of a stroke Friday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 87 years old and lived at 408 East 58th Street.

Government bond prices dropped sharply in quiet trading yesterday amid talk of increased interest rates on loans to brokers and prime corporate borrowers. Some long-term issues dropped as much as half a point in a worried market.

AN edible gift may be the solution to the problem of what to present to a weekend hostess. The most elegant of such gifts is probably fresh caviar, which has the advantage of being small, but is also expensive (about $46 for 14 ounces). All the leading specialty stores will pack the caviar in dry ice for safe transport.

The defending champions retained their titles at the national fencing championships yesterday at Long Island University. Janice Romary of Los Angeles captured her third straight crown in women's foil and the New York Athletic Club successfully defended its saber team title.

The Custom House Guide, a 2,000-page publication issued annually, is now available, according to John F. Budd, publisher of the guide, now in its 104th consecutive year of publication. It is published at 26 Beaver Street, New York, N.Y. 10004.
WASHINGTON, June 27 Senator Thomas J. Dodd denied today every charge of misconduct raised against him during three days of open hearings before the Senate ethics committee.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 27 The American University of Beirut conferred degrees on 561 graduates today at the 97th commencement exercises, which marked the beginning of the celebration of the university's centennial year.

WASHINGTON, June 27 A leading foreign policy expert warned the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that a "serious dialogue" between Presidents Johnson and de Gaulle had become essential in the continuing controversy over the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's military future.

The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation displayed yesterday at its Burbank, Calif., plant the first full-scale structural model of its proposed design for the future United States supersonic transport plane.

WASHINGTON, June 27 A high State Department official and an anthropologist joined today in stressing the dangers to academic integrity that they viewed as inherent in official intelligence agencies' support of social science research.
A gust of late selling knocked down stock prices yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) Joseph Laitin, who has been assistant White House press secretary for more than a year, is leaving the President's staff.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 27 A crashing fall has cost Roy Emerson his Wimbledon tennis title. The great Australian was beaten by Owen Davidson today after hurtling into the umpire's chair and pull- ing a shoulder ligament so badly that the match became a mockery.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange opened with gains, but a slide began shortly after noon that accelerated as the day wore on.
WASHINGTON, June 27 Archaic laws are keeping man from reaping the protein harvest of the seas as rapidly as scientific advances would permit, the Marine Technology Society was told today.
Steel production eased ninetenths of one per cent last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (UPI)--The Justice Department said today that a bill to east antitrust regulations dealing with franchises would "lead to damaging restrictions on competition throughout the distribution area of our economy."
What is the high cost of money doing to the earnings of leading commercial banks?

DETROIT, June 27 (AP) Gale's Roostertail, with Jerry Schoenith driving, turned in an average speed of 108.252 miles an hour today as three hydroplanes qualified for next Sunday's running of the Gold Cup race on the Detroit River.
WASHINGTON, June 27 The Johnson Administration has agreed to accept some exemptions in the open housing section of its civil rights bill to increase the bill's chances of passing Congress this year.

CANBERRA, Australia, June 27 The outlook for Southeast Asia has improved, representatives of the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization said in speeches and reports given today at the start of a threeday conference of the organi- zation's council.

Enthusiastic buying sent soybean futures yesterday on still another round of new lifetime highs. The prices of all contracts rose the limit of 10 cents a bushel, indicating that the interest of traders on the long side of the market remained strong.

Great Power of the Wheatley Stable contributed a noteworthy performance in the $31,275 National Stallion Stakes for 2-year-olds at Aqueduct yesterday. Taking the lead in the stretch of the 5 -furlong test, the son of Bold Ruler and High Voltage scored by 2 lengths over Herbert Allen's Favorable Turn, with Edward Scharps's Native Prince next. Great Power, ridden by Braulio Baeza, was timed in 1:04 3-5 and paid $6.20 for $2.

Net earnings of the General Tire and Rubber Company for the six months ended May 31 are estimated at a record $23,722,000, equal to $1.38 a share. This would be a gain of 24.3 per cent from the $19,219,000, or $1.11 a share, earned in the period a year ago, according to the report yesterday of T. F. O'Neil, chairman, and M. G. O'Neil, president.
The new United Steamship Company freighter Nebraska made her debut here yesterday and received a traditional port welcome.
The Lindsay administration overcame yesterday the last legal obstacle to the formation of a civilian-dominated review board to hear complaints against policemen.
ALBANY, June 27 Senate Majority Leader Earl W. Brydges said today that he might postpone legislative action on new taxes for New York City until the 15-cent transit fare was raised.

WEST HARTFORD, Conn., June 27 Mr. and Mrs. Richard Bartlett Park have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Maylah Park, to J. David Weissman, son of Mr. and Mrs. G. Benjamin Weissman of Guilford.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., June 27 Leo B. Shohan, deputy director of planning and program research for the New York City Housing and Redevelopment Board, died early today of a heart attack at his home here, 409 Valley View Road. His age was 51.

Roy Wilkins, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said yesterday that they exclusion of its representatives from the rally that ended the Mississippi civil rights march in Jackson Sunday was "a petty act."
WASHINGTON, June 27 (UPI) The Justice Department filed a lawsuit today charging Philadelphia, Miss., officials with failure to provide adequate protection for civil rights marchers last week.
Joel J. Tyler, City Licenses Commissioner, is considering changes that would make it easier to sell tickets to Broadway shows.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, June 28 (AP)--"I wanted to join the Army. It's something I lacked. I wanted to fight here."

The Newspaper Guild of New York and the World Journal Tribune, Inc., reached "agreement in principle" early today on a new contract that could end the guild's strike against the new publishing enterprise.

The synthesis of secretin, the hormone that gave birth to the science of endocrinology, or study of hormones, has been achieved for the first time by scientists at the Squibb Institute for Medical Research in New Brunswick, N.J.
LONDON, June 27 (AP) Sir Winston Churchill took pride in holding a card in the bricklayers union, but he had doubts about his skill.

Officials of the Girl Scouts of America have canceled the group's 1968 national roundup. Mrs. H.R. Price Jr., the national president, informed 450 local councils of the decision of the national board in a letter. She gave no reason.
Twenty-five members of the National Tool, Die and Precision Machining Association got together here yesterday and provided a refreshing change from the usual run of trade association meetings.

LONDON, June 27 (UPI) More than 1,500 seamen in four ports rejected today an offer by ship owners. The offer had been tentatively accepted by union leaders as a "basis for negotiations" toward ending Britain's seven-week maritime strike.
City officials discussed ways yesterday to reorganize the municipal hospital system to relieve chronic problems that have plagued hospitals here for two decades.
Charges of disorderly conduct against George Lincoln Rockwell were dismissed in Criminal Court here yesterday after a motion for dismissal by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's office.

LITCHFIELD, Conn., June 27 The largest number of subscribers in the history of the Litchfield Horse Show Ball are expected at this year's dance Saturday. It will be in a mountain setting at the Mohawk Ski Lodge in Cornwall. The dinner and dance will be followed by an early morning snack supper.

CHICAGO, June 27 (AP) Four-thousand shares in the family-held plumbing fixture manufacturer, the Kohler Company, of Kohler, Wis., were purchased today for $450,000 by the Commercial Discount Corporation, Chicago, in an unusual courtroom auction.
The General Electric Company has elected Robert C. Wilson as a vice president, it was announced yesterday by Fred J. Borch, president and chief executive officer.

An indictment charging George Whitmore Jr. with murder in the slaying of Mrs. Minnie Edmonds was dismissed yesterday in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn on the "reluctant" motion of District Attorney Aaron E. Koota.
CHICAGO, June 27 Dr. James Z. Appel, outgoing president of the American Medical Association, said today that the problem of birth control was medical and was not, nor should it be, a religious issue.

WASHINGTON, June 27--Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz said today that labor and management had agreed to give "most serious consideration" to his proposal for resolving a key construction contract dispute.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 27 The weapon's sound is terrifying and stupendous, like a chorus of kettle drums played by giants. Its sight is equally stunning, with hundreds of incandescent bursts of light winking their way up a South Vietnamese mountain ridge.

EUGENE, Ore., June 27 The 20-year-old editor of the student newspaper at the University of Oregon took the stand today in a crowded courtroom and repeated her refusal to identify seven persons who were the sources for an article on the use of marijuana on the university's campus.
Steel importers charged yesterday that the domestic steel industry had only itself to blame for rising steel imports.

MILTON, Mass., June 27 Mr. and Mrs. John E. Sheldon have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane McIntosh Sheldon, to Jon M.A. McLaughlin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm McLaughlin of New York. A wedding in August is planned.
LONDON, June 27 Denis Healey, the British Minister of Defense, made a public apology today for critical remarks about President de Gaulle.

The state's two-month-old medical assistance program, which could pay all the doctor, dentist, hospital, nursing home and prescription drug bills for as many as seven million people, has stirred the most intense public controversy in recent years upstate.

LONDON, June 27 The long lost 15th-century translation of the first nine books of Ovid's "Metamorphoses" made by William Caxton, the first English printer, was sold here today at Sotheby's art auction house for $252,000.
The $3.5-billion-a-year furniture industry, midway through what is apparently its second record year, is operating amid many of the signs of a seller's market.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) The Senate passed today a bill to increase by about 4 per cent dependency and indemnity compensation payments to parents and children of a veteran who died as a result of serviceconnected causes.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 27 (UPI) A young man, who had been identified as a bank robber by two witnesses and by viewers of a bank motion picture film of the holdup was freed today after another youth admitted the crime.

THE protagonist of Alberto Moravia's newest novel is a novel. Since such a book cannot do away with people alto gether, there are people in it. But they are only incidentals to his larger concerns: the relation of the real to the fictive, how even the raw material of a novel has already been subtly altered by the novelist, the place ...

WASHINGTON, June 27 The United States has quietly reinspected a closely guarded Israeli atomic power plant and affirmed its tentative conclusion that the plant was not being used for making atomic weapons.

Paris, June 27 (Reuters)--Peugeot is considered almost certain to set up an automobile assembly plant in Malaysia as the result of a visit here by Malaysia's Commerce and Industry Minister, Dr. Lim Swee Aun, it was disclosed here today.
A two-year-old boy and a young woman died yesterday in separate plunges from Manhattan buildings.
Two new patterns in flatware, one in silver plate, one in stainless steel, are being brought out by Oneida Silversmiths and will be in stores by early September.

The engagement of Miss Patricia Mary Enid Boucher to Donald MacQueen Street Jr. of St. George, Grenada, in the West Indies, has been announced here. Miss Boucher is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Denis Wilfrid Boucher of Glenageary, in County Dublin, Ireland. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Street of New York and Clarks Falls, Conn.
Officials and volunteers will be on the lookout today for "secret badges" and other clues to possible fraud in the primary election.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 27 A curious footnote to the months of anti-Government agitation in Danang and Hue has been provided by the Government's circulation of documents attributed to a professor at the University of Hue.
WASHINGTON, June 27. House conferees on the $17billion military authorization bill have agreed to drop an amendment that would order the Defense Department to build two atomic-powered frigates.
BURGOS, Spain, June 27 (UPI) A car carrying two United States Secret Service agents had two flat tires today and slowed Lynda Bird Johnson's travels through Spain.
The Correction Department took a major step last night toward assuming the traditional police role of holding suspects overnight before their arraignment in Criminal Court in the morning.
Denouncing what he called "this intolerable situation," Dr. Henry T. Heald quit yesterday as chairman of the state commission preparing for next year's state Constitutional Convention.

WASHINGTON, June 27 The direct cost to the nation's balance of international payments of the military operations in Vietnam rose to an annual rate of $500-million in the first quarter of this year, a Commerce Department report indicated today.
EASTON, Conn., June 27 (AP)--Helen Keller, who overcame the double handicap of deafness and blindness to dedicate her life to helping others, marked her 86th birthday quietly and happily today.
A 23-year-old pacifist who was arrested more than four months ago for refusing induction into the Army moved yesterday in Federal Court for dismissal of the charge for lack of prosecution.
ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, June 27 Fear has spread through the white community of Katanga Province after more than two years of uneasy peace between the races here.
Two men who have made it on Broadway in different areas of the theater have found a place in the city to get away from it all.
JERSEY CITY, June 27 The Hudson County Police Department and the Hudson County Boulevard Police Department, separate entities for half a century, were consolidated today.
A lawyer for Gamble-Skogmo, Inc., said yesterday the company might extend the deadline and raise the price on its tender offer for 500,000 shares of First National Stores, Inc.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 27 (AP) The Minnesota Twins capitalized on three walks and three Cleveland-errors for four runs in the sixth inning tonight to set back the Indians, 6-2.
WASHINGTON, June 27 Three-month and six-month Treasury bill rates moved in opposite directions today, with the shorter bills showing another decline compared with last week's auction.
Two British paratroopers who embarked late in May on an Atlantic crossing by rowboat were spotted by a merchant ship on Sunday 315 miles east of Cape Cod, the Coast Guard reported yesterday.

FALLSBURG, N.Y., June 27 United States Orthodox rabbis will establish in the near future, at a cost of $3-million, a research institute in Israel to promote spiritual relationships between the religious communities of the two countries.
DETROIT, June 27 (AP) The 8-millionth car of the 1966 model year rolled off an assembly line today, marking the second time in automotive history, that the figure was reached.

American track officials, eager to avenge last year's stunning upset by the Soviet team in Kiev, loaded up the men's track and field team yesterday with 60 athletes. Two decathlon stars remain to be picked.
There was intense pressure yesterday toward higher interest rates both for loans and for savings accounts.
BALTIMORE, June 27 The Congress of Racial Equality announced today that it would actively support and oppose candidates running in the state primary and governorship elections this year.
TRENTON, June 27 The State Supreme Court ordered today an unusual public hearing to determine whether every scrap of prosecution evidence should be turned over to defendants before their trials.
HOUSTON, June 27 An architect told today how his firm had computerized the planning of an office building to create a building that would produce the greatest possible return for a client.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 27 (AP) Raymond Sovey, a scenic designer who executed elaborate settings for many Broadway productions, but was perhaps best known for his selection of props for Thornton Wilder's sceneryless "Our Town," died Saturday night at a hospital here. He was 72 years old.

NEW VERNON, N.J., June 27 Mr. and Mrs. Richard W. Grefe have announced the en- gagement of their daughter, Miss Marjorie Diane Grefe, to Gary Morris Cook. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gene E. Cook of St. Paul. A September wedding is planned.

STOCKHOLM, June 27 What is widely regarded as the single most important art exhibition in Europe this summer the immense survey documenting the age of Queen Christina of Sweden (1626-1689) opens here Wednesday at the National Museum.

Dr. Frank Tannenbaum, director of university seminars at Columbia University, was stabbed and robbed last night in the elevator of his apartment house at 315 West 106th Street, between Riverside Drive and West End Avenue.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (UPI) The Senate confirmed today the nomination of Rosel H. Hyde to be the new chairman of the Federal Communications Commission. It also confirmed Nicholas Johnson to be a new member of the Commission.

DENVER, June 27 The controversy over the proposed remodeling of the West Front of the United States Capitol erupted violently here on the first working day of the 98th national convention of the American Institute of Architects.

The city's Health Department reported that 55 of the 113 child health stations and other clinics were unable to operate yesterday, the fourth day of a work stoppage by department specialists. Last Friday, 39 centers were not functioning.

Earnings of the Ashland Oil and Refining Company in the fiscal year ending on Sept. 30 will rise to about $40-million, or between $2.30 and $2.40 a share, on estimated sales of $675-million, the company's top executives predicted yesterday.
Helen Bonfils, president of The Denver Post, has purchased 17,705.6 shares of stock in the newspaper, it was announced yesterday.

LONDON, June 27 A report from London in Saturday's New York Times that it was Walter P. Chrysler Jr. who had paid a world record price for a Van Gogh painting, "Portrait de Mademoiselle Ravoux, was incorrect.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., June 27 Mr. and Mrs. Elbert L. Rhoads have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sybil Rhoads, to Joseph Falcone Jr., son of Mrs. Falcone of Bethlehem, Pa., and the late Mr. Falcone.
LONDON, June 27--The loudspeaker at the London airport waiting room announced a further delay in Flight 869 to Dublin.
Mrs. Mae Polen Ginsberg, home furnishing designer, died at her home Sunday after a long illness. She was 59 years old and lived at 25 Central Park West. She was the widow of Louis Ginsberg.
BUENOS AIRES, June 27 Dr. Illia called his Cabinet into urgent session today amid increasing indications that the military might be moving toward a take-over.
WASHINGTON, June 27 Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson urged America's young people today to "dream the impossible dream" and make the nation beautiful again.

CHICAGO, June 27 (UPI) A planted bomb exploded today, wounding two union organizers and shattering the car of a union leader who has fought a running battle with the Teamsters for control of Chicago's cab drivers.

The anguish of Negroes living in the Watts section of Los Angeles, as expressed in their prose and poetry, will be the subject of a one-hour documentary the National Broadcasting Company will televise in August.

Voters throughout the state will cast ballots today in primary elections highlighted by a fiercely contested Manhattan surrogate contest. All three camps made electioneve victory predictions in the surrogacy race, which is drawing national attention.
ANAHEIM, Calif., June 27 (AP) Frank Robinson powered two late rallies with doubles to- night as the Baltimore Orioles defeated the California Angels, 4-1, for their 29th victory in the last 39 games.

SOMERVILLE, N.J., June 27--Mr. and Mrs. Louis Holland have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marilynne Holland, to John Blacker Freeman, son of Prof. Ira M. Freeman and Mrs. Freeman of Bound Brook.
Rotterdam, the world's busiest ocean cargo port, has started a massive expansion program aimed at tranforming a 5,400acre North Sea tract into sites for industrial plants.
EVEN the girl with the most adventurous fashion sense is likely to turn to the traditional when she selects a wedding dress to the despair of bridal consultants and store buyers.

The more grumbling there is in Congress and the country about slow progress in the war on poverty, the more certain Sargent Shriver seems to become that victory is already in sight. In testimony before a Senate subcommittee last week, the director of the Office of Economic Opportunity set 1976 as his target for abolishing poverty in America. His rose-tinted glasses get rosier by the minute.

The New York State Legislature, now waiting nervously for the passing of Primary Day before putting its members to the grim duty of voting on New York City's tax measures, has been in session longer than any of its predecessors since 1911. Unfortunately, the length of its session bears no relation to the record of its accomplishments, which are pitifully few.

WASHINGTON, June 27 The State Department reacted cautiously today to a proposal that the United States and the Soviet Union enter into an experimental suspension of underground nuclear tests under a system of "verification by challenge or invitation."

One of the five persons killed Saturday afternoon in a six-car collision on the Northern State Parkway near Shelter Rock Road, Nassau County, was identified yesterday as Michael (Mickey) Bowers, an ex-convict and waterfront leader of the notorious Local 824 the "Pistol Local" of the International Longshoremen's Association.

The sweeping reorganization of the city's antipoverty program, which was proposed by Mitchell Sviridoff in a report released Sunday, drew praise yesterday from city officials and cautious optimism and questions from local antipoverty agencies.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 27 The yachts that made the Newport-to-Bermuda race the largest of all time continued to leave here today. They included 14 that began a new contest to the Virginia Capes, 620 miles away. It was sponsored by the Cruising Club of Virginia and the Royal Bermuda Yacht Club and provided those who wanted more exercise at sea a competitive way to get closer to home.

Miss Alison Jane Kramer and Pierre Jacquin were married in Paris yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Louis des Invalides. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Marcel Thorel, who also celebrated the nuptial mass. A reception was held at the Ritz.

NEW DELHI, June 27 At least 40 persons were burned to death and more than 30 injured Saturday night when an overcrowded bus caught fire near Agra, according to reports received here tonight. Agra is 120 miles southeast of New Delhi.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, June 27 (AP) The Vesper Boat Club of Philadelphia, the 1964 Olympic champion, had its first workout on the River Thames today in preparation for the four-day Royal Henley Regatta opening on Wednesday.
KIEV, U.S.S.R., June 27 President de Gaulle arrived in the capital of the Ukraine tonight on the third leg of his swing around the Soviet Union.
TRENTON, June 27 The state Assembly gave final legislative approval today to a slightly abridged edition of a Democratic congressional reapportionment plan and then adjourned for the summer.

FALMOUTH, Mass., June 27--Today is the 120th anniversary of the birth of Hiram Baxter, the man who invented the family vacation. Oddly enough, Baxter's name is almost forgotten today, though without his pioneer work such well known inventions as Henry Ford's automobile production line, Howard Johnson's fried clams and Junius Bromo's celebrated seltzer would mean practically nothing to the modern American.
CORDELE, Ga., June 27 (UPI) A Negro involved in a racial incident in this south Georgia town yesterday was charged today with assault with intent to murder Sheriff Earlie Posey of Crisp County.

WASHINGTON, June, 27 (UPI) Seeking to show that many persons who have used tranquilizers made with the drug meprobamate became addicts, the Governments opened hearings today on its reasons for tightening access to the drug.

PASADENA, Calif., June 27 (UPI) The sun will rise on the moon early Wednesday morning, but scientists said today they would wait at least several days before attempting to reactivate Surveyor 1, America's camera on the moon.
The offer of the Chicago North Western Railway to exchange its stock for that of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad expired yesterday and the C. N.W. announced that it would not be extended.

WANT an old croquet ball painted with a wild mosaic design for $35? How about a child's washboard with the metal part gilded and a picture of a ghostly horseman on the wooden section at the top for $15. Or consider a Coca-Cola bottle encrusted with paint in startling color ...

SAN RAFAEL, Calif., June 27 (AP) Ken Rosewall of Australia finished 1 point ahead of his countryman, Rod Laver, in the final standings yesterday and won the $2.525 first prize for the singles title in the Peacock Gap professional tennis tournament.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 27 The Committee of 24 on Decolonization has returned from Africa with a general resolution endorsing all struggles against colonial rule and calling on United Nations members to give aid, including arms, to the rebels.

Today's primary election is of unusual importance for the state, the city, and the major political parties. As the first test of the new law that set primaries in June, it will be watched with interest to see whether it brings out a larger percentage of voters than the customary August or September date. It will succeed if enough independent, intelligent voters turn out to counterbalance the clubhouse vote on which political machines thrive.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) The Senate passed and sent to President Johnson today legislation that will permit litigants who win suits against the Government to collect court costs.

To the Weather Bureau, it was "a stagnant mass of warm air" that moved into the city yesterday from the Southwest when a "cool air bubble from New England dissipated." To New Yorkers, however, it was just plain hot-101 degrees at 3:35 P.M.
A Gold Medal of Honor will be presented to Samuel Ratensky, vice chairman of the City Housing and Redevelopment Board, by a group of architects and engineers associations.

BONN, June 27 Dr. Rainer Barzel asserted today that there was a need to keep French troops in West Germany after they leave the command of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization Friday. He insisted that the "legal problems" arising from their new status should not be overemphasized.
Plans for a far-ranging drive to stamp out two ancient diseases bilharziasis and trachoma in Saudi Arabia were discussed yesterday by King Faisal and President Nathan M. Pusey of Harvard University.
BONITA, Calif., June 27 Miss Lucy Brookes Burch, a cum laude graduate of Vassar College, and George Whitman Steers, a cum laude graduate of the Columbia Law School, plan to marry here Aug. 27.
Fredrick M. Eaton, a partner in the New York law firm of Shearman Sterling, was appointed yesterday to the board of the First National City Bank.

If the residents of a community cannot come to the theater they can have the theater come to them. The Theater in the Street, the professional company that gives free outdoor performances in New York City, seeks to accommodate them.

HUDSON, N.Y., June 27 High on a hill overlooking the Hudson River Valley, Governor Rockefeller signed a bill today that will enable the State Department of Education to operate the old Frederic Edwin Church estate as a museum and public park.
WASHINGTON, June 27 A 14-year branch in the Jewish community relations field ended today when the American Jewish Committee reaffiliated with the National Community Relations Advisory Council.
OTTAWA, June 27 Dmitri S. Polyansky, a First Deputy Premier of the Soviet Union, called today for Soviet-Canadian cooperation in keeping the peace and preventing war.
City Council President Frank D. O'Connor charged yesterday that Mayor Lindsay had "given up" on saving the 15-cent transit fare and was merely standing by while the Transit Authority increased it.

Mayor Lindsay's decision to appoint a municipal director of labor relations represents the first specific step toward substituting order for chaos in negotiations between the city and its unionized employes. With city-employed doctors now away from their jobs and contracts covering 100,000 other municipal workers expiring this week, the need is clear for a single high-level official to bargain for the city and to integrate over-all labor policies.

A 20-year-old woman who said Sunday that she had jumped 248 feet from the George Washington Bridge into the Hudson River told the police yesterday from her hospital bed that as she fell she hit the side of the bridge.

ERNIE TERRELL strums the guitar and throws left jabs with a methodical exactitude. He makes sweeter music and provides livelier action with his guitar than he does with his fists. The oversize song-and-dance man will temporarily put aside that phase of his twin-faceted career in Houston tonight to fight Doug Jones in a bout that lacks the ingredients that made the Dempsey-Firpo and Louis-Schmeling brawls such rabble-rousers.
Bryant Park was closed at 10 o'clock last night, two hours earlier than usual, as part of a drive to rid the park of people characterized as undesirables.

WASHINGTON, June 27 President Johnson instructed the Government's top medical men today to re-examine their priorities to determine whether too much energy was being spent on basic research and not enough on translating laboratory findings into tangible benefits for the American people.

The Corning Glass Works had the highest sales and earnings for any quarter in its 115-year history, raising the results for the 24 weeks to June 19 to a record, the semiannual report disclosed yesterday.

HOUSTON, June 27 Ernie Terrell, who has been called "that holdin', huggin', squeez- in', waltzin' man," is slightly favored to retain his World Boxing Association heavyweight championship tomorrow night in a scheduled 15round bout with Doug Jones at the Sam Houston Coliseum here.
HONG KONG, June 27 Foreign Minister Clien Yi asserted today in Peking that Communist China's enemies would gain nothing from the purge now sweeping the country.

President Francois Duvalier of Haiti has just cheerfully said that he is sure the United States is going to resume the economic aid that was cut off in 1963. The wish is father to his thought. So is his bland disregard for right and wrong and for what his Government deserves or rather does not deserve.
TURIN, Italy, June 27 (AP) The Fiat Company disclosed tonight it had concluded an agreement with Poland for a Warsaw factory to turn out Fiat cars under license.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 27 The creation of the first national agency to encompass all major Lutheran denominations in the country became assured today when the Lutheran Church in America voted to join the proposed Lutheran Council in the U.S.A.

CHICAGO, June 27 Some lung cancers evidently grow so fast that they are virtually incurable by the time they are big enough to be seen on Xray films, scientists reported today to the American Medical Association.

For a brief twenty minutes, Roy Emerson seemed destined yesterday to move within grasp of a cherished goal: becoming the first man in thirty years to win three Wimbledon tennis championships in a row. Mr. Emerson was well on his way to ousting an unranked fellow-Australian in a quarter-final when he skidded on the slick grass and fell against the umpire's chair. He heard a crack in his shoulder and felt a sharp pain.

Don Rubell of New York and John Reese of Hewlett, L.I., the favorites, swept into the third round of the New York State clay-court tennis championship yesterday at the North Shore Tennis and Racquets Club in Bayside, Queens.
JACKSON, Miss., June 27 The civil rights march through Mississippi has made it clear that a new philosophy of "black consciousness" is sweeping the civil rights movement.
Ship owners of 12 maritime countries have been given until Sept. 1 to comply with a Federal Maritime Commission request for information relating to their freight rate structures.
The chief spokesman for the nation's millinery industry accused department store managers yesterday of failing to recognize the changing patterns of women's headwear sales.
HONOLULU, June 27 Seven years after statehood Hawaii is riding high on the economic wave.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 27 The creation of the first national agency to encompass all major Lutheran denominations in the country became assured today when the Lutheran Church in America voted to join the proposed Lutheran Council in the U.S.A.

CHICAGO, June 27 Some lung cancers evidently grow so fast that they are virtually incurable by the time they are big enough to be seen on Xray films, scientists reported today to the American Medical Association.

For a brief twenty minutes, Roy Emerson seemed destined yesterday to move within grasp of a cherished goal: becoming the first man in thirty years to win three Wimbledon tennis championships in a row. Mr. Emerson was well on his way to ousting an unranked fellow-Australian in a quarter-final when he skidded on the slick grass and fell against the umpire's chair. He heard a crack in his shoulder and felt a sharp pain.

Don Rubell of New York and John Reese of Hewlett, L.I., the favorites, swept into the third round of the New York State clay-court tennis championship yesterday at the North Shore Tennis and Racquets Club in Bayside, Queens.
JACKSON, Miss., June 27 The civil rights march through Mississippi has made it clear that a new philosophy of "black consciousness" is sweeping the civil rights movement.
Ship owners of 12 maritime countries have been given until Sept. 1 to comply with a Federal Maritime Commission request for information relating to their freight rate structures.
Most stocks on the American Stock Exchange again showed declines yesterday.

General Mills, Inc., reported yesterday that estimated net earnings of $23.3-million set a record for the fiscal year ended May 29, up 14 per cent from the $20,383,919 earned in the preceding fiscal year.
ROME, June 28 (AP) Cardinal Spellman arrived today for the dedication of three transmitters for the Vatican radio, one of them a gift from the Cardinal to Pope Paul VI.

DETROIT, June 28 (AP) Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon and Gov. George Romney of Michigan took turns attacking bigness in government today but were silent about what took place at a 45minute private meeting they held.

ANDREW A. ROONEY, who has fashioned such delightful televison essays on doors and bridges, added another success to his growing repertory last night. This time, over the network of the Columbia Broadcasting System, it was "An Essay on Hotels," a drolly written look at the swank hotels, the mushrooming motels, the cavernous horrors of Miami and flophouses.

Tommy Trotter, the racing secretary and handicapper at Aqueduct, went knocking on doors yesterday. The reason was an apparent apathy by horsemen to the $25,000-added Vagrancy Handicap, the feature on today's Big A program.
The International Business Machines Corporation announced the election here yesterday of Amory Houghton Jr., as a director. He is the chairman of the Corning Glass Works.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, June 29 (UPI) A 20-year-old pianist from Beverly Hills, Calif., lost out to a Russian teen-ager early today but was accorded the greatest ovation at the Tohaikovsky Interational Piano Competition since Van Cliburn won the first contest in 1958.
Robert V. Roosa, a partner in the New York banking firm of Brown Brothers, Harriman Co., was elected yesterday to the board of the American Express Company and the American Express Company, Inc.

Tentative agreement was reached yesterday on a contract to end the 22-day-old strike by air-conditioning engineers and helpers at 95 large Manhattan office buildings represented by the Realty Advisory Board.

Officials of the World Journal Tribune, Inc., renewed negotiations with the pressmen and mailers unions yesterday after having reached agreements in the early morning hours with the striking Newspaper Guild and with the Newspaper Deliverers.
Dr. James E. Allen Jr., the State Education Commissioner, restrained the New York City Board of Education yesterday from proceeding with plans to build seven new schools in East Brooklyn.
Irwin S. Meltzer, president of the Beaunit Corporation, said yesterday that the "present installed capacity of polyester fibers is still insufficient for the demand of tomorrow."
Four men were killed and nine were injured yesterday afternoon when the crippled tanker Alva Cape was again racked by fire and explosions at her anchorage in Gravesend Bay.
Lieut. Gen. Juan Carlos Ongania, who yesterday assumed the provisional Presidency of Argentina, had until the last few years avoided a political role.
The Condec Corporation of Stamford, Conn., manufacturers of machinery, has contracted to buy the 466,000square-foot plant of Conde Nast Publications, Inc., in nearby Greenwich.
OMAHA, June 28 Miss Ruth Erskine Wardle and David Rodick Scott have made plans to marry this August in Bronxville, N.Y.

Saw Fernando Ortuno, new Costa Rican Ambassador; lunched with Defense Secretary McNamara; addressed delegates to the Conference on the Status of Women Commissions; sent memorandum to Federal department heads urging the use of electronic computers, but at the lowest possible cost; met with Congressional leaders; announced the resignation of David E. Bell as director of A.I.D. and the nomination of William S. Gaud, deputy A.I.D. director, to succeed him.

The military coup against President Illia gives no promise of solving any of Argentina's serious problems. The Johnson Administration is right to go through the motions undoubtedly temporary of suspending diplomatic relations with the new military junta. Washington's sharply worded statement puts a finger on the really dismaying feature: "The United States regrets the break in continuity of democratic constitutional government in Argentina."

HUNTINGTON, L.I., June 28 Frank M. Corso, a Bethpage attorney, led John A. Brush, a "peace candidate," tonight for the Liberal nomination for Representative in the Second Congressional District in central Long Island.

TWO weeks before their point induction into the Hall of Fame at Cooperstown, Charles Dillon Stengel and Theodore Samuel Williams will be reunited in St. Louis as part of the ceremonial hoopla for the AllStar game on July 12. The baseball brass doesn't often think of such warmly sentimental gestures and that's what makes any display of imaginative window-dressing especially welcome.

ATHENS, Ga., June 28 The Justice Department reopened today its case here against two of the four Georgia Ku Klux Klansmen the state has failed to convict of murder in the shotgun killing in 1964 of Lemuel A. Penn, a prominent Negro educator.
TOKYO, June 28 After operating in the background for many years, Japan's business leadership is about to use its influential voice openly on the delicate question of the country's defense.

A FINE example of how racing teams may be op- erated successfully without direct factory participation has been provided in the first five events of this year's United States Road Racing Championship for sports cars.

WASHINGTON, June 28 Before leaving Williams College in 1935, Richard Mc- Garrah Helms had been chosen the junior who best exemplified the traditions of the school, permanent president of his class, president of the senior honor society, editor of the school paper, ...
WASHINGTON, June 28 The International Association of Machinists said today it would strike against five major airlines on July 8 unless a new labor agreement was reached by then.
RIO DE JANEIRO, June 28 The military overthrow of the Argentine Government underscores the decline of United States influence on LatinAmerican political developments.
Charles Revoir, a Long Island restaurateur, died yesterday at the Long Island Jewish Hospital in Lake Success after a long illness. He lived at 142 Maple Boulevard, Long Beach, L.I.

WASHINGTON, June 28 The House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee, on the opening day of week-long hearings on a bill that would prohibit the Government from obtaining military cargo space through competitive bidding, today heard two Administration witnesses oppose the measure.
The Anaconda Company, a large copper producer, announced here yesterday the election as a director of Robert L. Hoguet Jr., executive vice president of the First National City Bank.
IN this kind of weather with its beating heat, there are several things one can do to get his mind off the torrid temperature. For example, he can turn to the Congressional Record.

A 36-year-old man who has spent 23 years in a state prison, was ordered released yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals because he was not adequately protected by a state court when he pleaded guilty to second-degree murder at the age of 13.

COLD SPRING, N.Y., June 28 Miss Winifred Berner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. T. Roland Berner of New York and Cold Spring, was married today to Leroy Monroe Parker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph L. Parker of Tulsa, Okla. The Episcopal ceremony was performed in the Mekeel Corners Chapel by the Rev. John G. Mills.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 28 There is wide recognition that ultimate success or victory in the war in Vietnam will depend on political as well as military action.
The city's Director of Finance declared yesterday that unless new city taxes were enacted by midnight tomorrow, city employes might not get paid on time for a while.
A bigamist who offered bigamy as a defense for bigamy has won a point in court.

In the gloomy and fastemptying west ballroom of the Commodore Hotel last night, a waiter walked in at 11:15 and, with quiet finality, trundled away a table full of glasses that had been waiting for liquor that never appeared. Thas was a certain sign that the Klein-for-Surrogate campaign had come up a loser.

Amid forecasts of a world population expansion, which by the end of the century could more than double the present total of 3.3 billion, a business executive called yesterday for "programs for the control of population growth that are acceptable on moral, cultural and religious grounds."
ISTANBUL, Turkey, June 28 (Reuters) Fuad Koprulu, former Turkish Foreign Minister and one of the founders of the country's Democratic party, died here today. He was 76 years old.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 28-A bookmaking and policy operation that reportedly did a $30-million a year business was broken up by the Nassau County District Attorney's office and the New York City police today.
WASHINGTON, June 28 President Johnson announced today his intention to nominate three new judges to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit in New Orleans.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 28 Former Representative Stephen B. Derounian, a strong supporter of former Senator Barry M. Goldwater, defeated William J. Casey in today's Republican primary contest in the Third Congressional District.
CANBERRA, Australia, June 28 Consideration of the Vietnam conflict dominated discussions today in the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization's Council of Ministers.
The spot rate on the British pound was practically unchanged in quiet trading on foreign-exchange markets here yesterday. The currency closed at $2.7897, down 1 point from Monday.

Dr. Frank Tannenbaum, director of university seminars at Columbia University, who was slashed and robbed in the elevator of his West Side apartment house Monday night, identified two suspects yesterday as his attackers.
Journalistic records are dotted with cases in which editors and reporters have gone to jail rather than reveal their sources.
WASHINGTON, June 28 The House Banking and Currency Committee approved today President Johnson's large new program to rehabilitate city slums. The vote was 18 to 8 with seven abstentions.
WHITE PLAINS, June 28 Joseph L. Hutner won the Democratic nomination in today's primary election for Representative from the 26th Congressional District, in eastern Westchester County.

TOKYO, June 28 (AP) Typhoon Kit, bringing 78-mile-anhour winds and torrential rains, swept across the east-central Pacific coast of Honshu today, leaving at least 32 people dead. Honshu, the biggest of Japan's four main islands, includes the site of Tokyo.

Paperboard production rose 22.5 per cent with 477,100 tons in the week ended June 25, from 389,400 in the corresponding 1965 week, the Paperboard Group of the American Paper Institute reported yesterday.
HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, June 28 (Reuters) American oarsmen will present a strong challenge at the 127year-old Royal Henley regatta, which gets under way on the Thames River tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, June 28 (UPI) Companies must give women the same life insurance, illness and accident benefits as men, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission said today.

Soybeans behaved more like Mexican jumping beans yesterday than a basic food crop. In futures trading, prices of the beans dropped 4 cents a bushel at the opening, as traders rushed to take profits following Monday's sharp rise to new high ground.

Overseas communications rates may be headed for some reductions in the near future based upon the announced intention yesterday of ITT World Communications, Inc., to cut its rates for providing alternate voice-data communications service.
WASHINGTON, June 28 The Republican Coordinating Committee said today that the Administration had "failed tragically" to prepare for the start of the Medicare program.

ROCHESTER, June 28 Mrs. David J. Rosenthal has an- nounced the engagement of her daughter, Miss. Sondra June Rosenthal, to Harvey Melvin Burg. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Saul Burg of New Hyde Park, L.I. An Aug. 14 wedding is planned.

That huge electric scoreboard at Shea Stadium, feeling frisky in front of 56,367 people at Monday night's Mayor's Trophy game, advertised the next series this way: "Phils phlit into town phor three-game series...."

An immense "Man" in stainless steel by Alexander Calder has been commissioned for Expo 67, the Canadian world exhibition that will open next April in Montreal. Mr. Calder's largest work, the metal "Man," a work of about 46 tons, will measure 67 feet in height and 94 in length. It is intended the reflect the theme of Expo 67 "Man and His World."

PARIS There are indications that London has made a major policy decision and is now determined to maintain a power position in the Indian Ocean and Singapore regions until Britain has been accepted as a member of the European Community forming around the Common Market. Britain apparently plans to hold the existing line in Asia until "Europe" can eventually be induced to assume these worldwide British responsibilities.

LONDON, June 28 Prime Minister Wilson charged in the House of Commons today that Britain's Communist party was trying to take over the striking National Union of Seamen and destroy the Government's antiinflation policies.

The engagement of Miss Monica Camillus Meagher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter W. Meagher of Brooklyn and of Washington, Conn., to Paul Joseph Brinson, son of Walter J. Brinson of Kenmore, N.Y., and the late Mrs. Brinson, has been announced by the future bride's parents. A wedding in August is planned.
WASHINGTON, June 28 Ralph Nader, the automobile safety crusader, wrote a new text today on the danger of natural gas and petroleum pipelines that could have been titled "Unsafe at Any Pressure."
Mayor Lindsay defended the city's specialized high schools yesterday against criticism that they were elite institutions that violated the principle of equal opportunity for all students.
A plan sponsored by King Faisal of Saudi Arabia for a major international conference next April to rally the spiritual power of Islam and increase political cooperation was disclosed here yesterday.

LONDON, June 28-Prime Minister Wilson expressed the hope in the House of Commons today that despite criticism of President de Gaulle by a British Minister, the visit to Britain next week by Premier Georges Pompidou would prove "very fruitful."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 28 About 10,000 South Vietnamese construction workers who have been striking for higher wages for nine days are expected to return to their work on United States Government projects tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, June 28 The interest rate war between banks and savings-and-loan associations became, openly, today also a war among the Government agencies that regulate them.
CARACAS, Venezuela, June 28 (Reuters) President Raul Leoni today condemned the overthrow of President Arturo U. Illia and said that Venezuela would refuse to recognize Argentina's new junta.
