THIS is the peak of the local strawberry season and the berries are pouring into the city from Long Island and New Jersey.

"THIS President," an unnamed Johnson associate is said to have said, "wants the world to look to his clock." Of course, Philip Geyelin, diplomatic correspondent for The Wall Street Journal, adds, the world will not work to President Johnson's or anybody else's clock. Mr. Geyelin's dramatic, almost comically titled, book documents ...
ATTLEBORO, Mass., June 28 Dr. Donald Lemen Clark, professor emeritus of rhetoric at Columbia University, died in a nursing home here yesterday. He would have been 78 years old on Thursday.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 28 Premier Nguyen Cao Ky is considering a series of changes in his Cabinet.

Arthur M. Blaine of 1560 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, chief of the land section of the New York office of the Public Housing Administration, died Monday in New York University Medical Center. He was 64 years old.
WASHINGTON, June 28 President Johnson is reported to be furious about several recent disclosures in the press about his military plans in Vietnam, and this time he has some reason to complain.

WASHINGTON, June 28 President Johnson announced today the resignation of David E. Bell as head of the Agency for International Development and his intention to nominate William S. Gaud, deputy administrator, to succeed Mr. Bell.
WASHINGTON, June 28 The House Judiciary Committee refused by a vote of 17 to 15 today to strike the open housing section from the Administration's civil rights bill.

Democratic organization candidates appeared early today to have beaten back most of the primary challenges by insurgents in contests for nomination as delegates to next spring's State Constitutional Convention.

State Supreme Court Justice Samuel J. Silverman yesterday won the bitter Democratic primary fight for the Manhattan Surrogate nomination. The victory, by an unexpectedly wide margin, bolstered Senator Robert F. Kennedy's power in the Democratic party in New York State.
MOSCOW, June 28 (UPI) Mrs. Zinaida Nikolayevna Pasternak, the widow of Boris Pasternak, the Nobel Prize winning writer, died today at her suburban home in Peredelkino. She was in her late 60s.

Six top officials in the Lindsay administration face the prospect of a payless payday this Friday, unless they can prove to Controller Mario A. Procaccino that they were residents of the city at the time they were appointed.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 28 Two American advisers and six South Vietnamese sailors were rescued from the South China Sea yesterday 12 hours after their 55-foot junk sank 10 miles offshore south of Saigon.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 28 Merceno of Norway and Carmelo of Italy became today the fifth and sixth horses named to start in the eight annual Roosevelt International Trot, at Roosevelt Raceway Saturday July 9.
CINCINNATI, June 28 (AP) Sammy Ellis scattered five hits as the surging Cincinnati Reds downed the Los Angeles Dodgers, 3-1, tonight for their 10th victory in the last 11 games.

LOS ANGELES, June 28 The Federal Commissioner of Reclamation, Floyd E. Dominy, asserted today that opponents of two proposed power dams on the Colorado River were engaging in "unprincipled misrepre- sentations."

No more than one player from any team was named yesterday to the starting infields for the All-Star Game in St. Louis July 12. But an injury to Ron Santo of the Chicago Cubs may result in two San Francisco infielders playing for the National League.
CHICAGO, June 28 A way of relieving serious and persistent pain without drugs of major surgery was described here today.
The National Heart Institute, one of the Government's National Institutes of Health, said yesterday it had awarded its first contracts for production of heart pumps.
Thirty-five sputtering motor scooters and lightweight motorcycles snorted into Park Avenue between 36th and 37th Streets yesterday morning for a "wheel-in" protest against parking regulations.

ALLENDALE, N.J., June 28 Mr. and Mrs. Milton Elwood Annich have made known the engagement of their daughter Miss Ellen Gail Annich, to Philip Baird Lovell. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leander B. Lovell of Bronxville, N.Y.
WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) Provisions to help restore rail passenger service were urged today as part of a bill to create a department of transportation in the Cabinet.

Representative Adam Clayton Powell promised State Supreme Court Justice Harry B. Frank over the telephone yesterday that he would appear in court here July 19 to defend his conduct in the defamation case against him.

WASHINGTON, June 28 A Republican advisory, committee urged Congress today to create a blue-ribbon commission of 16 "highest-caliber" civilian and military experts to examine the nation's defense policies.

"SWEET LIGHT IN A DARK ROOM," a Czechmade romantic drama with English subtitles, directed by Jiri Weiss and featuring Dana Smutna and Ivan Mistrak, will have its American premiere at the Lincoln Art Theater, 225 West 57th Street.
Mayor Lindsay has honored one of the city's oldest musical families by naming George F. Seuffert as an unpaid consultant to expand free music programs and opportunities in the five boroughs.

William Wyler, the art lover and film director, yesterday morning strolled through a third-floor showroom at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue, and paused in front of a 55-inch by 96-inch abstract painting.

CHICAGO, June 28 Nearly 200 persons, most of them Puerto Ricans, marched on City Hall today to protest alleged police brutality and the failure of the city administration to recognize Puerto Rican problems.
WASHINGTON, June 28 James R. Hoffa has overcome open opposition to his program to retain influence in the International Brotherhood of Teamsters even if he is jailed.
BOSTON, June 28 Five Yankee errors opened the door tonight to a 5-3 victory for the the last-place Boston Red Sox.
The Weather Bureau said Monday, when the temperature reached 101 degrees, that it would be cool yesterday. It wasn't. The high for the day was 93 degrees at 1:05 P.M.

FALLSBBURGH, N.Y., June 28 An appeal to the Administration to convene immediately a White House meeting among leaders of the major faiths to stem an "increasing divisiveness" over its Vietnam policy was made here today.

HOUSTON, June 28 Ernie Terrell ground out a slow, dull, rough unanimous decision over Doug Jones tonight to retain his World Boxing Association heavyweight title before 9,346 booing, catcalling fans in the Sam Houston Coliseum.

LONDON, June 28 The salaries of British corporate directors and their dealings in their own companies' shares will become public knowledge under a new set of rules published today by the London Stock Exchange.

Several International stars will be in the opposing line-ups when Torino A.C. of Italy, meets Bayern-Munich of West Germany in a soccer match at Randalls Island tomorrow night. The game, sponsored by The Inter Soccer Club of New York, will start at 8 P.M.

A benefit dance is being arranged for July 9 by friends of the Eugene O'Neill Memorial Theatre Foundation in Waterford, Conn. A tent will be erected on the foundation's 95acre grounds for an evening of cocktails, dinner and dancing. The chairman is Mrs. George C. White of New York and Waterford. Co-chairmen are Mrs. Joseph N. Gorra and Mrs. Joseph S. Rosenthal.

WARSAW, June 28 (UPI)- The Polish Government newspaper said today that the Roman Catholic Church tried to draw the population on Sunday into a widespread anti-regime demonstration that was broken up by the police with clubs.
GEORGETOWN, Guyana Lionel Ifill, 160 pounds, Guyana, outpointed Roy Lee, 160, Jamaica, 10 rounds.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 28 (UPI) David Stucki, the 4-F civilian who almost got into the Vietnamese war in another man's uniform, will be going home soon, officials said today. The United States Consulate here told the 21year-old San Franciscan that his exit visa was being processed.
The Police Department is worried about the increasing use of mail-order keys to steal cars.
"David Frost's Night Out in London," which the American Broadcasting Company will televise next season, will include visits with Sir Laurence Olivier Peter Sellers and Albert Finney.
WACCABUC, N.Y., June 28 John L. Hussey, president of Faber Co., stockbrokers at 67 Wall Street, New York, died today in his home on Mead Street. His age was 59.
The report of the Allegheny Airlines, Inc., showed a drop in earnings, despite higher revenues.

WELLESLEY HILLS, Mass., June 28 Dianne Kania of Boston, Laurie Cohen of New York and Beth Reese of Philadelphia won the best-ball tournament today in the Junior Interclub team golf matches. The event was a prelude to tomorrow's ...

MADISON, Wis., June 28 (UPI) A 7,500-pound elephant pulled the 3-year-old daughter of a Princeton University professor into its cage and mauled her to death today as the child tried to feed it popcorn at the Vilas Park Zoo.

DETROIT, June 28 (AP) Miss Chrysler Crew posted the fastest time of any of today's four qualifiers for Sunday's Gold Cup race on the Detroit River. The qualifying speed averaged 105,847 miles an hour.

IT'S concert time at Lewisohn Stadium again. The 1966 season of summer musical events there began last night with a tribute to the woman who founded them in 1918 and presided over them in her inimitable fashion until a few years ago. She was Mrs. Charles S. Guggenheimer, the irrepressible "Minnie" to thousands of Stadium fans for nearly five decades.

"The United States Navy in World War II," compiled and edited by S.E. Smith, will be published by Morrow on Oct. 17. This is an anthology of articles by naval experts, authors and journalists. The material, mostly contemporary accounts from the war, has been arranged to provide a narrative history. Rear Adm. E.M. Eller has written an introduction.
GUATEMALA, June 21 A new constitutional regime under a civilian President will go into office July 1, carrying with it a great deal of hope and expectation.

WASHINGTON, June 28 About 500 maritime industry and maritime labor officials attending a special two-day "Save Our Shipping" conference here were urged today to "build a big enough fire under the Administration to make it move."
New York University Medical School proposed yesterday that it take over administrative services at Bellevue Hospital in a move to cut red tape that has impaired patient care.
MIAMI, June 28 (AP) A big patch of squalls south of Cuba in the Caribbean where the first hurricane of the season, called Alma, was born turned into a tropical depression today.

TENAFLY, N.J., June 28 Miss Jill Dorn Eisner was mar- ried this evening to Bruce I. Siegal of Fort Lee, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Siegal of Marion, S.C. Rabbi Arthur Hertzberg performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Eisner.

EUGENE, Ore., June 28- Annette Buchanan, a 20-year old co-ed, was convicted of contempt of court here today for her refusal to name student sources of an article she wrote on the use of marijuana at the University of Oregon. She was fined $300, the maximum, but was not sentenced to jail.
KANSAS CITY, June 28 (AP) The Kansas City Athletics downed the Baltimore Orioles, 4-3, tonight for their fifth victory in the last six games.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 28 The Pequot Yacht Club crew of Southport, captained by Mrs. Lawrence W. Carstensen, won both races off Indian Harbor Yacht Club today for a 3 point lead in the Western Connecticut area elimination series to determine a qualifier for the annual Syce Cup regatta.

AMARILLO, Tex., June 28 (UPI) Ernest O. Thompson, a member of the Texas Railroad Commission for 32 years and an internationally known authority on petroleum and gas conservation, died in a nursing home early today. He was 74 years old.
WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) The Civil Aeronautics Board's Bureau of Operating Rights recommended today approval of the proposed acquisition of Pan American-Grace Airways (Panagra) by Braniff Airways.
The stock market took another slide yesterday.

Several major New York City banks, led by the First National City Bank, said yesterday that they planned to make "selective" increases in the rates they charged on loans to security dealers secured by stock-exchange collateral.

ONE of America's strongest husband-and-wife part- nerships bids farewell to New England today. Michael and Katherine Cappelletti are moving from Cambridge, Mass., to Washington, D.C., where Cappelletti, now a fully qualified lawyer, will take up a position with the Justice Department.
The first reports of progress in the labor dispute between the Doctors Association and the city came yesterday as the work stoppage by Health Department specialists went into its fifth day.

SCRANTON, Pa., June 28 Dr. Harry Goodfriend, a retired eye specialist, who was a physician in this city for more than a half century, died yesterday in Moses Taylor Hospital, where he had been a patient since Friday. He was 77 years old.

WASHINGTON, June 28 The president of the American Political Science Association told a Senate hearing today that increasing involvement by defense and intelligence agencies in financing social research in foreign countries ran the risk of cutting off access in these countries to American scholars.
WASHINGTON, June 28- The House Commerce Committee is moving toward approval of what its chairman predicts will be a "strong" auto safety bill.
Prices drifted down on a broad front on the London Stock Exchange yesterday as uncertainty continued in the seamen's strike.
WASHINGTON, June 28 A serious dispute is building up over a proposed move by the Agriculture Department to restrict sharply imports of a mix of sugar and butterfat that is used in making ice cream.

The Rev. J. Phillip Anshutz, who retired in 1957 after having been priest in charge of the Holy Spirit Prostestant Episcopal Church, Bay Parkway and 82d Street, Brooklyn, since 1937, died Thursday in the Flushing (Queens) Hospital and Medical Center. He was 86 years old and lived at 147-37 Ash Avenue, Flushing.
Mayor Lindsay welcomed 1,100 college students into the New York City Urban Corps yesterday afternoon at a convocation at Columbia University.

ANAHEIM, Calif., June 28 (UPI) Willie Horton hit a three-run homer and drove in five runs and Jake Wood knocked in four runs tonight as the Detroit Tigers routed the California Angels, 15-3. The winners had 20 hits.

LONDON, June 28 The Beecham Group, Ltd., a big British, pharmaceutical company, is setting up a financial subsidiary in Luxembourg to raise capital on the international Eurodollar market to finance expansion.

HARTFORD, June 28 An air of hope and goodwill played over the surface of the first statewide conference on the arts in Connecticut through yesterday's morning and afternoon sessions. Delegates from all over the state representing amateurs and professionals in drama, music, dance, photography ...
WASHINGTON, June 28 Scientists failed tonight to reactivate Surveyor I after its silence through the frigid, twoweek lunar night.

NEW CITY, N.Y. June 28 (AP) Louis V. Mills, former mayor of Middletown, N.Y., defeated both Martin B. McKneally of Newburgh, former national commander of the American Legion, and Joseph J. Eley for the Republican congressional nomination today in the four-county 27th District.
ST. LOUIS, June 28 (UPI) Bob Bolin of the San Francisco Giants pitched 6 1/3 innings of no-hit ball tonight, then coasted to a two-hit 7-1 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

The F.W. Woolworth Company has made its second move toward diversification in three years with an agreement in principle to acquire the Gateway Sporting Goods Company, Kansas City, Mo., for $14.7-million in cash.
The election of William H. Wilson as president of the Addressograph-Multigraph Corporation was announced yesterday in Cleveland.
MOSCOW, June 28 Aram Khachaturian, the Soviet composer, disclosed today that he would go to the United States to conduct his own works there for the first time.

WASHINGTON, June 28 Administration officials, apparently reflecting the feelings of President Johnson, described themselves today as angry and upset by recent reports that the United States was about to bomb oil storage depots near Haiphong, which is the port for Hanoi.
William A. Strauss, president of the Independent Natural Gas Association of America, said yesterday he would have expected "plaudits rather than criticism over our safety record."
Two major grants to Oxford University totaling $7.5-million were announced yesterday by the Ford Foundation.

The Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service, ocean shipping agency for the Armed Forces, yesterday told about 50 representatives of American steamship lines to be ready to submit offers for more than 1.6 million tons of trans-Atlantic military cargo by July 20.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 28 Leaders of the Lutheran Church in America adopted this evening a resolution asserting that an affluent nation has the responsibility to assure that every citizen has enough income to be guaranteed a "minimal standard of living."

OCEANPORT, N.J, June 28 (UPI) Carry Forward II, an Irish colt owned by the Jaclyn Stable, scored his first victory of 1966 today, rallying in the stretch to win the $6,000 feature race at Monmouth Park by 1 lengths.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 28 A hundred years ago three of the large, plush yachts of those days engaged in the first trans-Atlantic race in the dead of winter. They were Henrietta, Vesta and Fleetwing, all fully supplied with professional muscle.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 28 A spate of sensational newspapers has enlivened Jakarta newsstands, which were almost empty in the period after the Communist coup attempt of last Oct. 1.
PASO ROBLES, Calif., June 28 (AP) Central California's strongest earthquake in 11 years jolted a wide area last night, but did little damage.
The American Enka Corporation set records in sales and earnings for the 24 weeks ended June 19, Phillip B. Stull, chairman and president, reported yesterday.

PARIS, June 28 A German panzer commander, veteran of the conquests of Poland and France, was formally named today to be commander in chief of allied forces in Central Europe. His prospective appointment was reported June 15.
THE mother of the Mod movement conceded yes- terday that "we're cooling it a bit."
CRANFORD, N.J., June 28 (AP) Winds and lightning toppled trees and power lines tonight, sparking at least a dozen minor fires in parts of Union and Somerset Counties.
William Thomas Grant, who made his name a household word through his chain of general-merchandise stores, retired yesterday on the day after his 90th birthday.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 28 Mrs. Billie Jean King came out of the rut to overpower Annette Van Zyl and join Margaret Smith, Maria Bueno and Mrs. Ann Haydon Jones in the semi-finals of the Wimbledon tennis championship today.

Lawrence Levine, co-counsel for a group of dissident Canadian Javelin Company stockholders, said last night that it would be "practically impossible" for the insurgents to make a significant show of force if the concern's annual meeting was not put off.

CORDELE, Ga., June 28 (UPI) Four bands of roving Negro teen-agers set small fires to a school and two automobiles as they ran through this south Georgia town last night and early today, heaving bricks at passing cars and store windows.

COLUMBIA, S.C., June 28- Negroes today lost their strongest bid in this century to break the South Carolina Legislature's color line as four Negro candidates were defeated in the Democratic primary runoff.
The Chock Full O' Nuts Corporation plans to establish a nationwide chain of low-budget roadside restaurants, to be known as Chock Jr., according to a company announcement here yesterday.

A decision handed down by the United States District Court here on June 5, 1965, that Edward Lamb, a Toledo industrialist, and Edward Lamb Enterprises, Inc., must pay more than $1.29-million for a "shortswing" stock-conversion action was reversed here yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

The directors of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., authorized yesterday the filing of applications with the New York State Public Service Commission and the Securities and Exchange Commission for the issuance of 500,000 shares of series E cumulative preferred stock. The shares had been previously authorized by stockholders.

Although Governor Rockefeller last week signed a bill aimed at saving the old Metropolitan Opera House, there are many obstacles in the way of deciding the fate of the historic old house, whether it stays or goes.

VOLGOGRAD, U.S.S.R., June 28 President de Gaulle and the Soviet leaders will issue a joint declaration calling for regular consultation between the two Governments and for a communications system resembling the Soviet-United States "hot line," French officials said today.
The Freeport Sulphur Company announced yesterday it was planning to spend $50-million to enter the phosphate-fer tilizer business.

HALSTON, a designer who has been accustomed to talking only through his hats, has enlarged his fashion vocabulary. He expressed himself in head-to-toe terms yesterday as Bergdorf Goodman unwrapped his made-to-order millinery collection for fall, a special series

CYNWYD, Pa., June 28 Bryan (Bitsy) Grant of Atlanta reached the third round of the United States senior clay-court tennis championship today by defeating Col. Nicholas Powel of Washington, 6-3, 6-0, at the Cynwyd Club.

Accelerated by traffic growth Pan American World Airways and Northwest Orient Airlines reported yesterday sharply increased earnings for May and the first five months of this year over results in the corresponding periods a year earlier.
PITTSBURGH, June 28 (AP) Run-scoring singles by Roberto Clemente and Jose Pagan in the fifth inning lifted the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 4-3 victory over the Houston Astros tonight.

City Councilman Theodore S. Weiss won an apparent 61-vote victory yesterday in a Democratic primary disputed by his opponent, Representative Leonard Farbstein. Mr. Farbstein was seeking renomination in Manhattan's 19th Congressional District.
CHICAGO, June 25 With the start of Medicare on Friday, leading specialists are discounting predictions that hospitals will suddenly be overcrowded.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 28-United States Navy pilots bombed a fuel dump near Vinh in North Vietnam yesterday, the second attack on a fuel dump in the area in two days.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 28 Oswald Clyde Buchanan, who retired in 1958 after serving as treasurer of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation since July, 1942, died today at Greenwich Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived at 20 Church Street.
The World Bank's $175-million of bonds was offered publicly yesterday at a yield of 5.39 per cent the highest ever offered by the bank in the United States and the securities sold out quickly.

WASHINGTON, Donald F. Turner has completed his first year as the head of the Justice Department's Antitrust division but a year has proved too short to demonstrate with any clarity the kind of antitrust chief he will be. But there are some hints.

ROME, June 28 Pope Paul VI today received the final report of his commission to study family problems and spent an hour with a Cardinal who is a member of the commission and who is reported to favor liberalization of the church ban on artificial contraception.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, June 28 Leaders of the leftwing Government of the former French Congo were reported to have taken refuge in a Brazzaville stadium tonight, protected against insurgent army forces by Cuban soldiers of the Presidential Guard.
YONKERS, June 28 Luther H. Tate, principal of the Fieldston School in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, died at his home here Sunday night. He was 69 years old.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 28 (AP) A week-long strike of first-aid men and nurses ended today at the atomic test site near here.

BUENOS AIRES, June 28 Argentines who flock to see their portrait in the current stage hit, "Los Projimos" ("The Neighbors"), have found little to calm their frayed nerves during the current political crisis.
The world of advertising and marketing is a strange one indeed.
LONDON, June 28 Prime Minister Wilson said today that Queen Elizabeth would not be deterred by incidents in Northern Ireland from making a visit scheduled to begin Monday.
Heizaburo Okawa, the Japanese national foil champion, was the only fencer who went undefeated through the quarterfinals and semi-finals of the United States national epee championships yesterday.

In the barrel-and-dollar conscious world of the oil man, Ernest Othmer Thompson was a mighty figure. He possessed a virtually boundless reserve of knowledge about petroleum, which was placed at the disposal of his country and on oil officials from other lands.

HOUSTON, June 28 Leading operators of office buildings took a look today at rental conditions and trends throughout the United States and found them to be good, with only a few soft spots in isolated areas.

An English professor has rigged up a barbed-wire fence and outdoor floodlights and organized a "vigilante" group to help track down suspected arsonists who have endangered his upper West Side brownstone.

The Johnson Administration loses one of its ablest and hardest working executives with the resignation of David E. Bell. A veteran of the Kennedy-Johnson Administrations, Mr. Bell has served with distinction in two most critical posts. He proved an effective director of the Bureau of the Budget. He was even more effective and forceful in running the nation's foreign-aid program as head of the Agency for International Development.

Samuel J. Smallman, who retired last year after having been president for more than 20 years of I. Smallman Sons Company, manufacturers of wallets and other leather goods, died Saturday in his home at 8141 Crespi Boulevard in Miami Beach. His age was 55.

Ray Ellsworth, a freelance writer who specialized in contemporary American music, died Sunday of a lung ailment in Methodist Hospital of Brooklyn. He was 47 years old and lived at 134 Prospect Place, Brooklyn.

David Merrick, who has expressed an ambition to fill each of Broadway's 34 legitimate theaters with one of his attractions, is occupying three now and, so far, has already booked five more for the 196667 campaign.

TORONTO, June 28 (AP) Dr. Robert I. Harris, former president of the American Orthopedic Association, died last night in a hospital at Banff, Alberta, where he had been attending a convention of the Canadian Orthopedic Association. He was 76 years old.
WOODSTOCK, N.Y., June 28 Frances Maule, a writer and early campaigner for women's suffrage, died here today. She was 88 years old.
ALBANY, June 28 Governor Rockefeller announced today that he was proclaiming Friday, July 1, as Eisenhower Golden Wedding Day.

JERUSALEM (Israeli sector), June 28-Abie Nathan, the restaurant owner who made a dramatic peace flight to Port Said four months ago, ended a three-day peace march this evening in a throng of several thousand at the Parliament building.
MADRID, June 28 (AP) The military take-over in Buenos Aires provoked a wave of activity in and around the well-guarded home in exile here of the former Argentine President, Juan D. Peron.

JERSEY CITY, June 28 William P. Kern, former postmaster of Jersey City, died yesterday in Mountainside Hospital, Montclair. He was 73 years old and had lived at 20 Knollwood Avenue, Montclair, since his retirement in 1963.
Heizaburo Okawa, the Japanese national foil champion, was the only fencer who went undefeated through the quarterfinals and semi-finals of the United States national epee championships yesterday.

In the barrel-and-dollar conscious world of the oil man, Ernest Othmer Thompson was a mighty figure. He possessed a virtually boundless reserve of knowledge about petroleum, which was placed at the disposal of his country and on oil officials from other lands.

HOUSTON, June 28 Leading operators of office buildings took a look today at rental conditions and trends throughout the United States and found them to be good, with only a few soft spots in isolated areas.

An English professor has rigged up a barbed-wire fence and outdoor floodlights and organized a "vigilante" group to help track down suspected arsonists who have endangered his upper West Side brownstone.
OAK PARK, Ill., June 28 Raymond L. Hoefler, sales executive of the Zenith Radio Corporation of Chicago, died yesterday in West Suburban Hospital. He was 67 years old.
GREENWICH, Conn., June 28 Mark Estes won the medal in the Westchester sectional qualifying round today for the Metropolitan Golf Association's junior championship.

GENEVA, June 28 Wil- liam C. Foster, United States disarmament negotiator, ex- pressed concern today over what he termed the "new obstacles" raised by the Soviet Union to an accord to halt the spread of nuclear weapons.

MOSCOW, June 28-The West German Government was accused today of having mailed "suspicious questionnaires" to Soviet citizens of German origin who are considered eligible to receive pensions for service in the German armed forces under Hitler.

Don Rubell of New York, John Reese of Hewlett, L.I., Robert Barker of Port Washington, L.I., and Peter Fishbach of Great Neck, L.I., the four top favorites in the New York State clay-court championship, reached the round before the quarter-finals yesterday at the North Shore Tennis and Racquets Club in Bayside, Queens.

Charges of deliberate delays by election inspectors, alleged violations of the electioneering law and one arrest marked yesterday's primary election. In the words of Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz, the election was "absolutely routine."
The American Institute of Men's and Boys' Wear, the consumer and public relations agency of the men's apparel industry, announced yesterday a restructuring of its organization.

The primary objective of Dunhill International, Inc., in its merger negotiations with the Consolidated Laundries Corporation was to secure for its stockholders the greatest possible amount of cash, Dunhill's senior executive said here yesterday.

The Phillips Petroleum Company disclosed last night it had agreed at the request of the Justice Department to put off its proposed purchase of the Tidewater Oil Company's Western refining and marketing facilities until July 14.

ATLANTA, June 28 (UPI)- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s Southern Christian Leadership Conference decided today to "go it alone" in a Mississippi summer campaign because of disagreements with other civil rights organizations.
Hamilton Fish Jr. won the Republican nomination in the 28th Congressional District yes- terday. He defeated Alexander Aldrich, a cousin of Governor Rockefeller, by a surprisingly wide margin.

CHICAGO, June 28 (AP ) Don Lock's three-run homer in the first inning and a solo blast by Mike McCormick, the winning pitcher, led the Washington Senators to a 4-1 triumph over the Chicago White Sox tonight.
The New York Shakespeare Festival Mobile Theater Company weathered a heavy shower last night and put on a strong performance of "Macbeth" in Washington Square.
SANTA DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, June 28 The first troops to leave the Dominican Republic in the withdrawal of the Inter-American Peace Force sailed from the port of Haina at noon today.

CHICAGO, June 28-Dr. Charles L. Hudson, the new president of the American Medical Association, today minimized the impact of Medicare on his profession and proposed a broad program of "self-examination" to meet any changes brought about by the law.

Blair Co., Inc., offered yesterday stock and debentures in a new company, Standard Computers, Inc., and the offering was quickly oversubscribed. The issue consisted of $2-million of 6 per cent convertible debentures and 100,000 shares of stock in units of one debenture and 50 shares of stock at a price of $1,250.
TEL AVIV, June 28 The Israeli censorship board today banned "La Bonne Soupe" by Feilicien Marceau several hours before its scheduled premiere by the Habimah Theater.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., June 28 (AP)-President Johnson is doing only a "fair job" in Vietnam, 43 per cent of 277 magazine publishers said in a poll conducted here today.

WASHINGTON, June 28 Dr. Jerome B. Wiesner, Presidential science adviser in the Kennedy Administration, suggested today that the United States could agree "with very little risk" to its national security to a ban on underground nuclear tests without inspections.
Expansion of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People's voter registration campaign in Mississippi was announced here yesterday by Roy Wilkins, executive director.

WHITE PLAINS, June 28 State engineers were accused in State Supreme Court here to- day of showing "unprecedented pell-mell haste" in building a road in Pocantico Hills for the benefit of Governor Rockefeller and his family before an injunction could block it.

WASHINGTON, June 28--The United States moved quickly today to express its disapproval of the military ouster of President Arturo U. Illia of Argentina, but appeared undecided over what, if anything, to do about it.

BUENOS AIRES, June 28 A three-man military junta overthrew the civilian Government of President Arturo U. Illia today and named a retired army commander, Lieut. Gen. Juan Carlos Ongania, as Provisional President of Argentina.
The weary mother, rose to one leg and the other birds danced around the nest as the first flamingo to be born at the Bronx Zoo emerged into the world at 7:20 A.M. yesterday.
Ray Stark, executive vice president and production head of Seven Arts Productions, has resigned his positions with the film concern to produce movies and plays.
The Bronx Democratic organization of former Representative Charles A. Buckley cut into the strength of the Reform movement in hotly contested legislative primary elections yesterday.
A twin-engined plane bound for Teterboro Airport crashlanded in the front yard of a house in Hasbrouck Heights, N.J., about 6 P.M. yesterday after an engine failed.

The marriage of Miss Robin Michael Enders, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Enders of Beverly Hills, Calif., to Anthony Hall Browne took place here yesterday afternoon. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard S. Browne of Madison, N.J. Msgr. S.J. McGovern per- formed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of St. John the Martyr.
LONDON, June 28 Now already nine years old, Brit- ain's youngest experimental dance group, the Western Theater Ballet, opened its first West End season tonight at the Sadler's Wells Theater.
Annette Buchanan, managing editor of the student newspaper at the University of Oregon, has now been found guilty of contempt of court in a case that should never have been brought.
LONDON, June 28-Balliol College, Oxford University, announced today the establishment of a Felix Frankfurter Fellowship in honor of the late United States Supreme Court justice.
The high cost of borrowing at home and abroad emphasizes the key role now being played by monetary policy. It also raises questions about its effectiveness in controlling business activity.
The election of E.D. Loughney as an executive vice president of the Gulf Oil Corporation was announced yesterday. He has been a senior vice president of the company since 1964.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) The House Government Operations Committee approved today President Johnson's proposal to combine existing agencies into a Cabinet-level Department of Transportation.

For the first time since she was involved in an armed conflict with Pakistan last fall, India will receive a substantial amount of aid from an international lending agency. The funds will be used to help build up the country's railway system. The International De-...
There's no immediate threat to the Smiths, the Browns, the Millers or the Cohens, but the name of Rodriguez is taking up more space than ever in the new Manhattan telephone directory issued today.
VANCOUVER, B.C. June 29 (Canadian Press) Details were announced yesterday for a huge waterfront development in downtown Vancouver to cost up to $275-million.

HOUSTON, June 29 A widening world of automation that would affect both rent payer and rent collector and reach below the big-business level into smaller offices was suggested today by a specialist in computers.
Julia Richman High School in Manhattan, an all-girl school since it was opened in 1913, will become coeducational in the fall of 1967.
OCEANPORT, N.J., June 29 (AP) Assagai, a 3-year-old colt, defeated 12 rivals in the 32d running of the $23,750 Long Branch Stakes at Monmouth Park today.

A decline of 4,544,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend, total supplies were 197,926,000 barrels, compared with 202,470,000 a week earlier and 200,715,000 a year ago.

The day when a United States jetliner in regular passenger service, is landed by computer is near.
The New York Urban League yesterday announced the election of Dr. Albert C. Stewart, a research chemist, as board chairman of the 56-year-old civil rights organization.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 111.5 on Tuesday from 111.9 on Monday.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 29 (AP) Lieut. Gen. Joseph H. Moore says the United States has enough of an air force in South Vietnam to do any job it is called upon to do.

Riese Brothers, operators of the Childs restaurants and Calico Kitchen chains, have leased 3,500 square feet of corner store space in the 30story office building under construction at 866 Third Avenue.

A sweeping realignment of the senior executives of the May Department Stores Company was announced yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders here. The personnel changes, which become effective Feb. 1, are designed to propel younger executives.

WOODLANDS HILLS, Calif., June 29 (UPI ) Isabel Dawn, one of several actresses who played Tondeleyo in the New York stage play "White Cargo," died today of a pulmonary infection at the Motion Picture Country Home and Hospital. Her age was 62.
GREENWICH, Conn., June 29 Robert D. Magill, of 102 Putnam Park, Greenwich, a former economist, died yesterday at Greenwich Hospital at the age of 88.

ATLANTA, June 29 (AP) Billy Williams's two-run homer capped a seven-run ninth-inning rally that gave the Chicago Cubs a 9-5 victory over the Atlanta Braves today.
WASHINGTON, June 29--On Capitol Hill today, President Johnson's decision to bomb oil depots at Hanoi and Haiphong was regretted, praised, denounced and accepted with resignation.
ATLANTA, June 29 (AP) The question of possession of Lee Harvey Oswald's guns was taken under advisement today by the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 29 The Vietcong mauled a United States Army squad and inflicted moderate casualties on a South Vietnamese Marine battalion in attacks late last right and early this morning.
Her Majesty's Government have noted with regret that United States aircraft have attacked North Vietnamese targets touching on the populated areas of Hanoi and Haiphong.

The trustees of the New Haven Railroad reported yesterday that the road showed a net loss of $960,361 on revenues of $10,618,888 in May. In the period last year, the road had reported a net loss of $1,538,816 from revenues of $9,937,592.

ELKINS PARK, Pa., June 29 The engagement of Miss Patricia Ann Bricker to Dr. Jerome I. Cohen has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Melvin I. Bricker, parents of the future bride. Dr. Cohen is the son of the late Dr. David Cohen and the late Mrs. Dorothy Saligman Cohen, both of Philadelphia.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) Farm product prices increased one-third of 1 per cent during the month ended June 15, the Agriculture Department reported today.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., June 29, Gin has been selling well in the liquor shops for several weeks now, Collection plates have been getting heavier in the handsome shingled churches. And splashes of plaid
DOVER, Del., June 29 (AP) Gov. Charles L. Terry Jr. said today that E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. had pledged a twoyear program to cut in half its acid discharges into the Delaware River.

Even though reforms he suggested during the primary campaign could reform him out of a job if he is elected a New York County Surrogate, Supreme Court Justice Samuel J. Silverman said yesterday, after winning the Democratic nomination on Tuesday, that he thought the reforms should be pressed.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) A four-year extension of broad Presidential powers for dealing with any nuclear attack, or threat of it, cleared Congress today.

Three Western railroads asked the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday to consolidate the merger application of the Chicago North Western and the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific with the Chicago, Rock Island had Pacific's "merger, control and purchase proceedings" now in progress in Chicago.
When a family needs cash, it must know how to borrow it at the least possible cost. The need may arise from an emergency situation, such as an accident, illness or eco-... nomic loss.
CAMBRIDGE, England, June 29--Roy Jenkins, Britain's Home Secretary, declared himself in favor of radical changes in the British penal system as he opened a conference on criminology today.

LONDON, June 29 Death and the awareness of death form the subject of Kenneth MacMillan's ballet, "The Song of the Earth," seen at the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, tonight in a double bill with Frederick Ashton's "Daphnis and Chloe."
Three firemen have been nominated for Fire Department commendations for their rescue of a man from a burning apartment on Park Avenue early yesterday morning.
BAYONNE, France, June 29 (Reuters) Organizers of the Tour de Franc bicycle race investigated tonight a "general strike" by tour riders that held up the race for four minutes today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 29 United States bombers struck close to the heart of Hanoi and Haiphong today in raids that military informants said had damaged the gasoline and oil supplies of North Vietnam severely.
The American Stock Exchange reported yesterday the changes carried below in the shareholdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.

CANBERRA, Australia, June 29 Member nations of the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization concluded a three-day meeting today and issued a communique that noted Communist setbacks during the last year, but viewed the situation in the treaty area as still the "most dangerous in the world."

GROSSE POINTE, Mich., June 29 Mr. and Mrs. Donald Revere Flintermann have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Charlotte Flintermann, to John Morley Fink, son of Mrs. George Rupert Fink and the late Mr. Fink, who was a founder and president of the National Steel Corporation. A September wedding is planned.

The Council surveyed conditions in the treaty area as a whole and found encouraging signs of progress. It noted that greater efforts than ever before are being made to advance the welfare of the people of the area, and that economic conditions in general are improving.
A scanner on a rocket above the earth's atmosphere has found evidence indicating that a star may be in the process of birth nearby.
MANY small duplicate bridge clubs operate on a seasonal basis. Some in New York City close for the summer season, while others in resort, areas reverse the procedure.

The sharp decline in prices that swept the bond market Monday and Tuesday became more moderate yesterday as dealers attempted to weigh the chances of an increase in... the prime rate of commercial banks.

THE recent "2000" tournament at Chicago's Edge water Beach Hotel was studded with class; 12 masters and 20 experts all with approximately 2,000 official rating points played a sixround Swiss. The Indianapolis grand master Robert Byrne took first place, winning four games and drawing two. His nearest rivals, Roy Wenzel and Phil LeCornu of Chicago and Dr. Erich Marchand of Rochester, were a half point behind.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 29 The Government, following its anti-inflation program, officially announced tonight that it was continuing coffee-support prices at the present level, despite angry demands from growers for an increase.

YPSILANTI, Mich., June 29 Majesty is our theme majesty in Michigan. The Ypsilanti Greek Theater opened its first season last night with a production of the only extant Greek trilogy, that titanic masterpiece,...
The City Council yesterday raised property taxes to the highest level in the city's history.
The spot rate on the British pound gained slightly in fairly active trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. The currency closed at $2.7998, up 1, from Tuesday.

Mrs. Florence Gelfand, mother-in-law of Deputy Buildings Commissioner William J. Diamond, was fined $540 in Housing Court yesterday for 13 violations on two Lower East Side buildings she owns at 239 and 241 Henry Street.

ST. LOUIS, June 29 (UPI) Orlando Cepeda hit a 500-foot home run into the upper leftfield stands in the sixth inning today to power the St. Louis Cardinals to a 2-1 victory over the San Francisco Giants before a crowd of 29,119. The winners fielded brilliantly, coming up with five double plays.
KARACHI, Pakistan, June 29 Premier Chou En-lai and President Mohammad Ayub Khan met for more than 3 hours at Rawalpindi, Pakistan's interim capital, today.
Capt. Arthur H. Peterson, a Sandy Hook pilot of ships for more than 50 years, died Monday at his home, 354 Van Duzer street, Stapleton, S.I., after an illness of three months. He was 79 years old.

Sammy Davis has notified the William Morris Agency that he will not do business with it after he finishes a current run in Toronto unless the booking agency obtains a franchise from the American Guild of Variety Artists, it was revealed yesterday in Manhattan Supreme Court.

MOSCOW, June 29 President de Gaulle and Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet party leader, were understood to have failed today to overcome their basic disagreement on the questions of Germany and European security.

WASHINGTON, June 29 A civil rights leader said today that the movement was facing a major conflict with organized labor because unions were not moving fast enough to eliminate segregated locals and seniority lines.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 29 In the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Conception here this afternoon Miss Margaret Patricia Fitz-Gibbon was married to Ens. Anthony Wayne Broomall, U.S.N., by the Rev. Charles F. Theobald.

President Johnson has now taken one of the longest and gravest steps in the inexorable escalation of the Vietnamese war. The bombing of the oil storage tanks on the edges of Hanoi and Haiphong was foreseen and virtually foretold by President Johnson himself the other day when he said to newspapermen that "we must continue to raise the cost of aggression at its source" meaning North Vietnam.
Negotiators for the World Journal Tribune, Inc., and Mailers Union No. 6 tried yesterday to resolve the manpower problem that has blocked a settlement of their dispute.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) The Federal Bureau of Investigation, on President Johnson's orders, has opened an intensive inquiry into whether United Sattes officials informed newsmen in advance about the decision to expand the bombing in North Vietnam to oil facilities in the Haiphong-Hanoi area.
WESTBURY, L.I., June 29 What was described by Roosevelt Raceway officials as a "wildcat strike" prevented the departure of an Alitalia airfreight plane from Rome today, thereby stranding two trotters
WASHINGTON, June 29 Federal Reserve Board officials reacted cautiously today to the increase in the prime rate by the Chemical Bank.

MIAMI BEACH, June 29 The cost of the war in Vietnam is preventing the Federal Government from doing all it has promised for education, according to a report on school finance issued today by the National Education Association.
ALBANY, June 29--Governor Rockefeller signed today a bill increasing state aid to public schools by $100-million for the coming school year.
WASHINGTON, June 29 The United States lost $86-million of gold in May, the largest monthly loss in a year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

A tentative agreement was reached yesterday between the Doctors Association and the city, covering wages, security and fringe benefits for the specialists who work in the Health Department's centers and clinics.

WASHINGTON, June 29 The "Save Our Shipping" conference of representatives of the nation's maritime industry appointed today a five-man committee to take the plight of the industry directly to the White House.

WASHINGTON, June 29 Record purchases of Government and Government-agency securities, and a new high in purchases of mutual fund shares dominated individual savings figures in the first quarter of this year, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

WINNETKA, Ill., June 29 Mr. and Mrs. Middleton Miller have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Estelle Miller, to Eugene Ramiro Cashman Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Cashman of Wilmington, Del., and Siasconset, Mass.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., June 29 Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Robertson of Lioyd Harbor and Delray Beach, Fla., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Hoffman Robertson, to Walter Charles Meier, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Meier of Cold Spring Harbor.

"CRAFTSMEN USA '66" is an exhibition at the Museum of Contemporary Crafts of 268 award winning objects ranging from the wit of a knitted mobile to the poetry of a posy pot. The handsomely mounted exhibition, which will continue through Sept. 11, includes pottery, glass, metalwork, textiles and jewelry.
Two once-powerful New York City Democratic organizations were further shaken, if not upset, by the results of Tuesday's Congressional primary elections.

"Fortnight," as a good many literates know, derives from a Middle English expression meaning 14 nights. "Shibboleth," as fewer may know, was used as a password by the Gileadites to detect the enemy Ephraimites, who could not pronounce "sh," just as the Yanks on Bataan used "lallapaloosa"...

A registered secondary offering of 760,000 shares of common stock of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company was placed on the market yesterday by an underwriting group managed by Lehman Brothers. The stock was priced at $30.25 a share.

HOWELL, Mich., June 29 William F. Andersen, 68-yearold retired director of the budget and procedure section of the General Motors Corporation, was found shot to death in his home here yesterday. Dr. Boyd N. Shertzer, the Livingston County Medical Examiner, said today that the death was a suicide.
OTTAWA, June 29 Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson said today that the Canadian Government "regretted" the United States bombing of oil installations at Hanoi and Haiphong.
Price changes on expoxy pipe and aluminum sulphate were announced by producers yesterday.

Charles Rosenthal, the founder of Riverside Memorial Chapel, a funeral home, and a pioneer in modern funeral concepts, died of a heart attack in his home Tuesday night. He was 89 years old and lived at the Adams Hotel, 2 East 86th Street.
PORT CHESTER, N.Y., June 29 A new $4-million hospital building that golf enthusiasts helped to finance was opened today by the United Hospital here.
WASHINGTON, June 29 Secretary of Commerce John T. Connor swore in James W. Gulick as Acting Maritime Administrator today.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (UPI) Negotiators for the five major airlines broke off talks with the International Association of Machinists today be cause of a walkout at Eastern Air Lines in San Juan, Puerto Rico.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 29 The 3.3 million-member Lutheran Church in America today joined the growing list of major Protestant bodies calling for the end of capital punishment.

MIAMI, June 29 Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba, in his first public speech since May 1, tonight welcomed as heroes the Cuban athletes returning from the 10th Central American Games in Puerto Rico. The speech was monitored here.

Frank Robinson of the Baltimore Orioles joined Jim Bunning and Schoolboy Rowe in the select circle of men picked for both leagues All-Star teams when he was named yesterday to the American League starting outfield.
The appointment of Joseph A. Lee Jr. as a senior investment adviser to the Rockefeller family was announced here yesterday by Laurance S. Rockefeller, chairman of Rockefeller Bros., Inc.
The appointment of the Rev. Cyril P. Meyer, dean of the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences at St. John's University, as academic vice president of the university, was announced yesterday.

The Roman Catholic diocese of Brooklyn announced last night a $60-million program for the construction of medical facilities in Brooklyn and Queens and for modernization and expansion of present facilities.
ALBANY, June 29 Hooting Republicans nearly walked out of the Assembly in noisy confusion today when Speaker Anthony J. Travia blocked a G.O.P. attempt to amend the state's new medical care law.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 29 The largest of transAtlantic races began today with boisterous seas and high easterly winds rattling those aboard the 42 yachts to their teeth.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) The Senate passed by voice vote today a bill to broaden the Federal-State Employment Service in an effort to make it more effective in matching jobs and manpower.

MOSCOW, June 29 the Soviet Union offered no immediate hint today that the Kremlin felt called upon to intensify its com- mitment in Vietnam following the bombing of fuel installations at Hanoi and Haiphong by United States aircraft.

NEWARK, June 29 The widow and the mother of a 21year-old Army private who died of pneumonia a day after he was admitted to the Fort Dix hospital sued the United States Government today for $1.1-million.

The New York Fencers club won the national men's foil team fencing title for the second straight year last night, going through the final round of the Amateur Fencers League of America competition undefeated at Founders Hall, Long Island University, Brooklyn.

MOSCOW, June 29 (Reuters) A Russian journalist, Yevgeny Kobelev, reported from Hanoi today that United States aircraft dive-bombed objectives north of Gialam, an eastern suburb of the North Vietnamese capital of Hanoi.
Mayor Lindsay is preparing an executive order that will grant administrative autonomy to the municipal hospitals and health centers in order to cut red tape that has impaired patient care.

Met with Commission on Health Manpower; met with group of Southern education leaders to receive report on future of education in the South; greeted Australian Prime Minister Harold Holt and later gave luncheon in his honor; met with Y.M.C.A. youth governors.
The Bates Manufacturing Company has elected Arthur J. Smyth as a director, Arnold L. Ginsburg, president of the diversified textile producer, announced yesterday.
Stock prices fell sharply yesterday as the market reacted to the intensification of the war in Vietnam.
King Faisal of Saudi Arabia sought to assure top American industrialists yesterday that his regime would maintain a political and economic climate favorable to foreign investment in his country.

Operations of all restaurants and other food services at the Trans World Airlines Flight Center at Kennedy Airport will be taken over by Restaurant Associates tomorrow. The restaurants include the Lisbon Lounge and Dining Room, the London Club, the Paris Cafe and the employes' cafeteria.
LONDON, June 29 The Labor Government introduced today in the House of Commons its long-promised bill to nationalize the British iron and steel industry.
SAN MARINO, Calif., June 29 Miss Susan Kemper and Thomas H. Snyder 2d plan to be married here in August. Their engagement has been announced by the future bride's mother, Mrs. Stover Kemper.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 29 (AP) Harvard University announced today the election of David Rockefeller of New York as president of its Board of Overseers.

GENEVA, June 29 Officials of the European Economic Community express doubt that the principal issues in the Kennedy round of trade negotiations can be resolved before next March or April or possibly May.

WASHINGTON, June 29 Strong support for a measure now before Congress that would prohibit the Federal Government from allocating its ocean cargoes competitively to the lowest bidder was expressed here today.

Volkswagen and DaimlerBenz, West Germany's two largest automotive producers, announced yesterday a decision to set up a joint company to buy or manufacture parts for both companies with joint foreign plants or selling agencies.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 29--Secretary General Thant voiced "deep regret" today over the United States bombing of "the heavily populated areas" of Haiphong and Hanoi.
BOSTON, June 29 The New York Yankees hit four home runs tonight three in succession in the third inning and then nearly lost a six-run lead before defeating the Boston Red Sox, 6-5.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 29 (AP) Gov. Edmund G. Brown today named Ronald W. Haughton, a Michigan industrial relations expert, to investigate a disputed union representation election at two DiGiorgio Corporation grape farms.
The seamen's strike in Britain has ended not with a bang but a whimper. It was a costly affair for all participants.
Prices fell sharply on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.

The Hughes Aircraft Company and the Teleprompter Corporation announced yesterday that Hughes had acquired a "substantial but minority interest" in Teleprompter's New York community antenna television system.
SPOLETO, Italy, June 29 The Italian police intervened today to demand more clothing for the women of the Sierra Leone National Dance Troupe.

PITTSBURGH, June 29 (AP) United Air Lines announced today it would terminate service at the Williamsport and the Harrisburg-York airports Friday in accordance with an order last week by the Civil Aeronautics Board.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., June 29 (AP) Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower voiced support today of President Johnson's decision to bomb oil storage facilities at Hanoi, capital of North Vietnam, and at Haiphong.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (UPI)--Senate and House negotiators agreed today on a $17.5-billion defense budget. Included was language to prod the Pentagon into building nuclearpowered escort vessels.

KANSAS CITY, June 29 (UPI) The Baltimore Orioles capitalized on four walks and Boog Powell's two-run single for three runs in the seventh inning and scored a 5-2 victory over the Kansas City Athletics tonight.
