ALBANY, June 29--Senate leaders struggled again today to round up enough votes to pass New York City's tax program, and again they failed.
The General Cable Corporation announced the election here yesterday of Alan T. Wenzell as a director.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, June 29--Insurgent army troops in Brazzaville, capital of the former French Congo, appeared to have the upper hand today in their revolt against the Government.

WASHINGTON, June 29--Even as black smoke rose over Hanoi and Haiphong after today's air strikes on petroleum installations, top military men at the Pentagon were looking toward further escalation of the war effort.
CHICAGO, June 29 Dr. Milford Owen Rouse, the speaker of the American Medical Association House of Delegates who has been chosen president-elect, is a 63-yearold Dallas gastroenterologist.
WELLESLEY HILLS, Mass., June 29 For the second straight year the Philadelphia junior girls golf team won the Mrs. Frank Enos Trophy by defeating Boston and New York today.

HOUSTON, June 29 Two days ago Hugh Benbow planted his brown alligator shoes on a hotel-room rug and offered the winner of the Ernie TerrellDoug Jones fight for the World Boxing Association heavyweight title $50,000 to meet his fighter, Cleveland Williams. He was amiably ignored, as children and fools are.
A $1.7-million housing development is planned on a 16-acre estate in Scarsdale, formerly owned by Walter Winchell, the columnist.

MOSCOW, June 29 (Reuters) Yevgeny Yevtushenko, Russia's former angry young poet, set the seal on his return to official favor at a mass poetry reading here tonight and hinted that he was no longer considered a heretic.
BUENOS AIRES, June 29--Argentina's new military rulers completed their take-over today with the installation of Lieut. Gen. Juan Carlos Ongania as President.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) The Senate confirmed today President Johnson's nomination of Walter R. Mansfield to be district judge of Southern New York.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 29 Premier Abdel Rahmanal Bazzaz of Iraq announced a plan in a radio speech from Baghdad tonight to end the five-year-old guerrilla war with Kurdish tribes in the northern part of his country.
Two brokers and a corporation were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury in a $2million fraud against a Belgian insurance company.

A Negro housewife who said that a white policeman forced her to partially undress in the back of a Harlem bar "to prove that she was a woman," filed a $300,000 damage suit against the city yesterday. She charged "extreme humiliation."

George M. Shriver Jr., district Manager of the United States Lines Baltimore office, has retired after 35 years of service, the company announced yesterday. He has been succeeded by Richard H. Cromwell Jr., who had served as deputy manager of the office.
Thousands of New Yorkers over 65 have been streaming into the city's 16 Social Security Administration offices this week with questions about Medicare.
Sales of used machine tools set a record for May, the Machinery Dealers National Association reported yesterday.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange moved up on a broad front yesterday following the settlement of the seamne's strike.
Higher standards for promo- [ tion have been put into effect in the city school system in an effort to improve academic performance.
WASHINGTON, June 29 Despite the apparent lessons of the landslide defeat suffered by the Republican party in 1964, conservative Republican strength keeps turning up in all areas of the country.
LINCOLN, Neb., June 29 (UPI) A spokesman for Gov. Frank B. Morrison said today that President Johnson would arrive in Omaha at noon tomorrow for a speech.

PARIS, June 29 Thirty-six hours before the withdrawal of French forces from the allied command, the North Atlantic Council today designated the builders of its largest project, a $280-million air warning network to extend from Norway to Turkey.
The cost of business borrowing at the nation's banks started to move up another notch yesterday.
BERLIN, June 29--The East German Communist party destroyed today the slim lingering hope for the long-heralded exchange of debates on reunification between leaders of East and West Germany.
BERLIN, June 29--An East German court sentenced an American citizen to 27 months in prison on a traffic charge earlier this month, the United States mission in West Berlin said today.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., June 29 (AP) The space agency will try tomorrow to put an experimental satellite into orbit around the moon.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (UPI) The House Commerce Committee defeated by one vote today an amendment that would have clearly included trucks in its auto safety bill, informed sources reported.
Two of the largest stockholders of the Elgin National Watch Company were appointed yesterday to senior management posts with the large watch manufacturer.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 29 Gov. Edmund G. Brown and George Christopher, the moderate Republican leader, exchanged letters at a peace conference today. The exchange could have an effect on the California gubernatorial election.

WASHINGTON, June 29 A committee of citizens authorized by Congress to study the Federal system of public welfare declared today that the system itself was "a major source of the poverty on which the Government has declared unconditional war."
Across the nation yesterday, savings institutions were under pressure.

"Russian Night" was the official billing of last night's concert at Lewisohn Stadium by the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra, but it should have been "Elman Night." It marked Mischa Elman's 5,000th public appearance since the 75-yearold violinist made his debut at the age of 13.

TRENTON, June 29 (UPI) The State Supreme Court upheld today the constitutionality of New Jersey's railroad subsidy program and the right of highway commissioner Dwight R.G. Palmer to permit curtailments of service under the program.
WASHINGTON, June 29 There were moves in both houses of Congress today to stop the proposed $34-million extension of the Capitol's West Front, which overlooks the Mall.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (UPI) Senator John G. Tower, Republican of Texas, issued information yesterday that indicated the Defense Department would make further efforts to cut back foreign petroleum purchases.

CYNWYD, Pa., June 29 Dr. Reginald Weir of Fair Lawn, N.J., advanced to the quarterfinals of the national senior clay-court tennis championship today by upsetting Steve Ogilvy of New Rochelle, N.Y., 6-1, 6-2, at the Cynwyd Club. Ogilvy had been seeded second.
WASHINGTON, June 29 With the air strikes at Hanoi and Haiphong, the Johnson Administration hopes to inflict great pschological as well as military damage on North Vietnam.
Bellman Bob Eissner helped a German guest find an early train to Rochester in the New York Central timetable, then handed it across the counter and said: "You can keep it. We won't need it anymore."

NANTUCKET, Mass., June 29 Sooner or later every summer reaches a climactic moment when someone cries, "Let's go to the beach!" Going to the beach is pleasant enough for people who like sand under their toenails. Those who don't, unfortunately, have to go to the beach anyhow.

Hillard Elkins, producer of "Golden Boy," starring Sammy Davis, has been enjoined, on motion of Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz, from "soliciting or offering investments in theatrical productions," un-...

MONTREAL, June 29 (AP) A compromise agreement between the union representing 600 freight handlers in the port of Montreal and the Canadian Pacific and Canadian National Railways has ended a nine-day work stoppage, a union spokesman said today.
LONDON, June 29 The leaders of Britain's National Union of Seamen decided today to end the 45-day-old maritime strike.
CHARTER boatmen and sports anglers are becom ing increasingly concerned over the scarcity of two of the more important game fishes usually found in this area now swordfish and tuna.
OTTAWA, June 29 A visiting Soviet official and Canada's External Affairs Secretary clashed over United States action in Vietnam at an official dinner here last night.
WASHINGTON, June 29 President Johnson reaffirmed today his determination to thwart Communist aggression in South Vietnam.

Early this month, Arthur C. Fatt, chairman and chief executive officer of Grey Advertising, Inc., smiled as he told stockholders that he was not unaware of an automotive void in the agency's client list.
The nation's electric power production rose 10.5 per cent in the week ended June 25, from the level in the corresponding 1965 week, it was reported by the Edison Electric Institute yesterday.
EARLY in "Nevada Smith," an overstuffed Western drama which opened at the Victoria and Festival Theaters yesterday, Steve McQueen is counseled: "Revenge is not God's way."

The National Association of Accountants wrapped up an annual convention here yesterday with in-depth discussions of a sensitive matter the adequacy of statements that accountants prepare for shareholders.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 29--The structural steel skeleton of a new international trade center juts up 18 stories, a monument to the lost dreams of Indonesia's President Sukarno. Work on the building ceased in April as part of the austerity program of the nation's new leaders.

Mrs. Ligia Bezumavicius Bieliukas, a leader in the Lithuanian underground during World War II, died Tuesday night in Montefiore Hospital, the Bronx. She had collapsed from a severe asthma attack while driving to her home in Richmond Hill, Queens. She was 42 years old, and the wife of Bronius Bieliukas.
Chevrolet formally announced yesterday a new sports compact car called the Camaro to compete with the successful Mustang of the Ford Motor Company.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 29 (AP) A small band of hikers who left Cleveland June 20 in a "march for decent welfare" have their goal in sight a big rally tomorrow at Ohio's State Capitol.
Strong statements deploring the bombing raids on the outskirts of Hanoi and Haiphong were issued yesterday by United States Protestant and Jewish leaders.
The Maritime Administration and its Maritime Subsidy Board yesterday approved the sale of Moore-McCormack Lines' Pacific Republics Line to the Grace Line for $5.7-million.
Last week the New York Mets concluded the most successful road trip in their fiveseason history by winning eight games against six defeats.
Rising short-term interest rates in the United States are exerting a considerable influence on interest rates in all countries of Western Europe, a high Federal Reserve official said here yesterday.
Bobbie Brooks, Inc., one of the women's apparel industry's largest companies, is going into the cosmetics business.
Leading executives of some 250 New England corporations were urged yesterday to lend their influence and prestige to a drive to locate a $370-million atomic accelerator on Long Island.
WASHINGTON, June 29 Sargent Shriver has acted to squelch rumors that he is reluctant to use antipoverty funds for family planning projects.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 29 A further indication of Chinese dissatisfaction with the neutralist policy of the Rumanian leadership has emerged from the vist of Premier Chou En-lai to Albania.
For speculators who like the long side of the soybean market it was another day of heavy volume, rising prices and some new life-of-contract highs, despite one possible damper on their enthusiasm.
PITTSBURGH, June 29 (AP) Roberto Clemente hit a ninthinning single to center, driving in Matty Alou with the run that gave the Pittsburgh Pirates a 6-5 victory over the Houston Astros tonight.

THE turning point in the career of Cookie Rojas undoubtedly came during a winter league game in Puerto Rico a few years ago. The team he had been playing second base for was suddenly without a catcher, a situation that brought a feeling of helplessness to Luis Olmo, the old Dodger outfielder who was serving as manager. He still was groping for a solution when the earnest, hard-working Rojas made his offer.

BETHESDA, Md., June 29 Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Kermit Wilkins of Bethesda and Passaic, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Diane Theodora Wilkins, to Jay Howard Rosenberg, son of Dr. and Mrs. Seymour J. Rosenberg of Washington.
Sulphur dioxide levels in midtown and downtown Manhattan, where most New Yorkers work, may be at least double the levels in the uptown area where the city's air-pollution laboratory is located.
Republican Senator Jacob K. Javits said yesterday that he deplored "very much" the fact that "we now have a candidate for Surrogate who has been rejected by his own party."
Fifteen of the 54 heads that grinned down on midtown for half a century from the roof of the old Vanderbilt Hotel were trucked to an art gallery yesterday.

Henry F. Chartier, former president of the racket-ridden Local 32-E of the Building Service Employes International Union, was sentenced yesterday to one year in prison. A jury had found him guilty of violating the Taft-Hartley Law in accepting a $6,000 loan from an employer of members of the local.

CINCINNATI, June 29 (AP) Don' Drysdale, winning his first game since May 30, singled twice during an eight-run third inning tonight that carried the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 9-5 victory over the Cincinnati Reds.

MODERN OCCASIONS. Selected and edited by Philip Rahv. 369 pages. Farrar, $6.95. ONE great problem facing the contemporary writer is to make his nightmares enjoyable. If he can't do that, he is not likely to have any audience at all.

Harry Mesard, a trial lawyer for 50 years, died Tuesday in Long Island Jewish Hospital, New Hyde Park, Queens, of a heart attack. He was 72 years old and lived at 9 Archway Place, Forest Hills, Queens.

A 6 per cent wage increase will go into effect tomorrow for 15,000 undergarment and negligee workers under a new contract between Local 62 of the International Ladies Garment Workers and a group of employer associations.

PATRICK J. FRAWLEY JR., the 43-year-old presi dent of Eversharp, Inc., is giving unusual financial backing to his conviction that a private industrial company can play an activist role in championing anti-Communism and rallying a strong patriotic ferver with spiritual overtones.

WASHINGTON, June 29 Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara today attributed the timing of the United States bombing attacks near Hanoi and Haiphong to increasing infiltration into South Vietnam and recent moves to camouflage the North Vietnamese oil storage and distribution system.

The State Supreme Court ruled yesterday that the city could suspend the public cart license of the Erb Strapping Company, Inc., because of the concern's refusal to allow an examination of its books and records of ownership, operation and control.
CHICAGO, June 29 (AP) Frank Leahy, the former Notre Dame football coach, announced today the forming of a well-financed professional football league, which will begin operations in 1967.

TENAFLY, N.J., June 29 A short, slender 16-year-old from Columbia High in Maplewood today carded a 34, 36 70, two under par at the Knickerbocker Country Club to win the Jersey section qualifying medal for the metropolitan junior championship.
The B.V.D. Company, an apparel manufacturer, announced the appointment here yesterday of Harry C. Isaacs as senior vice president.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 29 James W. Harley, director of traffic for the United States Rubber Company from 1943 until his retirement in 1958, died today in Mountainside Hospital here. He was 72 years old and lived at 12 Tuers Place, Upper Montclair.

ATHENS, Ga., June 29 Three cartons of sawed-off shotguns, pistols, clubs with carved swastikas and a heavy chain welded to a swivel handle were brought into the Federal courtroom here today in the trial of three Ku Klux Klansmen for intimidating Athens Negroes.

IN THE year 2000, when Shirley Temple will be 72 and the moon may be a tourist stop, women may be able to change the color of their dresses by blowing a supersonic whistle, buy their wardrobes prepacked in cans and spray on their accessories.

THE top Coty Award for fashion design for 1966 goes to Dominic Toubeix, a 39-year-old Parisian who joined the house of Matty Talmack three years ago and is now a partner in the concern. Sixty-two fashion editors cast their ballots Tuesday.
Stockholders of the Bank of New York and the Empire Trust Company approved overwhelmingly yesterday a proposed merger of Empire Trust into the Bank of New York.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (UPI) Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, urged Congress today to reinstate a draft lottery policy that Lieut. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, director of the Selective Service System, said had not worked in World War II and would not work now.
The Rev. Andrew J. McKeon, founding pastor of Blessed Sacrament Roman Catholic Church in Valley Stream, L.I., died Sunday in South Nassau Communities Hospital in Oceanside. He was 71 years old.
CORDELE, Ga., June 29 (UPI) An all-night curfew was imposed on this south Georgia town today after whites and Negroes exchanged gunfire for 90 minutes early this morning.
CHICAGO, June 29. The House of Delegates of the American Medical Association adopted today a resolution that recommended direct billing of patients by every member under Medicare.

The Republic of France moved yesterday in Federal Court to recover eight sketches by the French impressionist, Paul Cezanne. They are reported to have been stolen sometime before 1962 from the Cezanne Museum at Aix-en-Provence.
ANAHEIM, Calif., June 29 (AP) Ed Kirkpatrick's homer with two aboard capped a fiverun second inning tonight as the California Angels broke a fourgame losing streak with a 6-2 victory over Detroit.

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 29 Mrs. Thorne Dempsey of Piping Rock carded a three-over-par 75 today for a total of 149 and increased her lead to six strokes in the Women's Long Island Golf Association 54-hole medalplay championship. Mrs. Dempsey posted nines of 37 and 38 on the 5,616-yard Nassau Country Club course.
MIAMI, June 29 Cuba produced 4,455,000 tons of sugar this year, the Havana radio announced today.

LONDON, June 29 Prime Minister Wilson reaffirmed general British support of the United States policy in Vietnam today but declared that "we must dissociate ourselves" from the American bombing of oil storage installations at Hanoi and Haiphong.

Louis W. Noel, a limited partner in the private banking and brokerage firm of Laidlaw Co., died Tuesday night at St. Luke's Hospital after a long illness. He was 79 years old and lived at 120 East End Avenue and at Murray Bay, Que.

As the Legislature enters the last throes of its political ordeal on the Lindsay tax program, some fundamental questions arise about the future of New York and, incidentally, other large American cities. Put in practical terms, the most urgent of these questions is how to avoid taxation so onerous as to be self-defeating and destructive of the very values sought to enhance the quality of metropolitan life.
WIMBLEDON, England, June 29 It will be Dennis Ralston of the United States against Manuel Santana of Spain for the Wimbledon title, the highest honor in tennis.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (UPI) Members of the House Interior Committee said today they would make another attempt on the House floor to authorize the kind of Indiana Dunes National Lakeshore they wish established at the southern tip of Lake Michigan.
PARIS, June 29--France told her allies today that "until further notice" her troops in West Germany would fulfill the missions assigned them in case of conflict.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (UPI) Vice President Humphrey's future daughter-in-law has pneumonia again and her scheduled July 9 marriage to his son, Robert, has been postponed.

PHOENIX, Ariz., June 29 (UPI)--An 11-year-old boy told today of slipping aboard a commercial jetliner last night and flying across the Pacific from Tokyo on an empty ticket folder and an empty stomach.
Union contracts covering more than 100,000 construction project workers in the city expire at midnight tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 29 The United States has begun, with a deliberate lack of haste, to consult other nations in the Western hemisphere about the question of resuming relations with Argentina's new military government.
Jack J. Valenti was elected president of the Association of Motion Picture and Television Producers at a meeting of the group in Hollywood yesterday.
ADEN, June 29 (AP) Yemen's Premier, Maj. Gen. Hassan al-Amry, has been shot and is critically ill in a Cairo military hospital, the Aden radio said tonight.

HANOVER, N.H., June 29 Dr. Frank Millett Morgan, director of the Clark School here from 1927 to 1953 and a former mathematics professor at Dartmouth College, died yesterday at the college infirmary. He was 79 years old.
WASHINGTON, June 29 The Senate Agriculture Committee approved today a two-year pilot program of school breakfasts for needy children and a threeyear extension of the school milk program.

After a protracted period of negotiations, Federal and state regulatory authorities have succeeded in arranging a takeover of the financially troubled Van Nuys Savings and Loan Association, Van Nuys, Calif., by the Equitable Savings and Loan Association of Long Beach, Calif., West Coast sources said last night.

WASHINGTON, June 29 The House Judiciary Committee approved President Johnson's civil rights bill today after accepting a compromise amendment to the open housing section that would exempt the vast majority of individual home sales.

WYNNEWOOD, Pa., June 29 Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Louis Rovner have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sheila Gail Rovner, to Dr. Lawrence Charles Parish of Philadelphia, son of Dr. and Mrs. Fred Arthur Parish of Brockton, Mass. A July 31 wedding is planned.
The election of Robert E. Holley as president was announced here yesterday by the Association of Investment Brokers.

The Cenco Instruments Corporation has reached an agreement to purchase 75 per cent of the Clinomobil Hospitalwerk, Hanover, Germany, makers of fully equipped, mobile medical clinics and hospitals that operate on roads, rails and water.
MOSCOW, June 29 (AP) Jane Marsh of New York, the only non-Russian first-prize winner at the third International Tchaikovsky Competition, received stormy applause at a winners' concert tonight.
Modena, Italy, June 29 (UPI) Ferrari is entering two 12cylinder cars in the Grand Prix of France auto race, the company said last night.

AN exhibition of contemporary embroidery is an extra added attraction for summer visitors to Old Westbury Gardens. The show will run until Aug. 1 in the red ballroom of the manor house, the former John S. Phipps country home. Among the embroiderers whose work is on... view are Beryl Dean, Mariska Karasz and Erica Wilson.

An injunction against a book about Howard R. Hughes, manufacturer, aviator and motion picture producer, was ordered yesterday by Judge Frederick V.P. Bryan in the United States Court for the Southern District of New York.
Federal authorities have ordered the owners of the ruined tanker Alva Cape to take the ship to sea and sink her.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, June 29 With the band of the Scots Guard appropriately playing the "My Fair Lady" score at tea-time, the 115th annual Royal Henley Regatta began today with six United States schoolboy crews and one college eight, Harvard's, all victorious.

The New York primary election proved that a good issue can bring out enough independent voters to overcome the Democratic organization's regulars, when a strong fight is made under vigorous leadership. That leadership was provided this time by Senator Robert F. Kennedy, whose prestige as the most influential Democrat in this state has now been considerably enhanced.
TORONTO, June 29 (Canadian Press) North American Gas, Ltd., has been asked by the Toronto Stock Exchange to explain certain expenditures listed in its recently issued 1965 annual report.

WASHINGTON, June 29--"A new law of the sea" is needed to keep the growth of marine science from producing "a new breed of submarine pirates," a Congressman warned today.
The police Department plans to visit campuses of Negro colleges in the fall to recruit new policemen.
ROME, N.Y., June 29 Mr. and Mrs. Edward Comstock 2d have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Myrick Comstock, to Peter Brandt Evans, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Evans of Clinton.

Queen Empress did what was expected of her in the $27,150 Vagrancy at Aquequct yesterday. Opposing only three others in the seven-furlong test for fillies and mares, the Wheatley Stable star scored by 2 lengths over Petite Rouge. Mount Regina and Admiring were next in order.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 30--Arthur J. Goldberg told the Security Council and Secretary General Thant tonight that a halt in the bombing of North Vietnam would not end the war.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 30-- President Abdel Rahman Arif of Iraq today crushed an attempted coup d'etat by air force officers and a former premier, Brig. Gen. Arif Abdel Razzak, a supporter of President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic.
DENVER, June 30--The debate over the proposed extension of the West Front of the United States Capitol continued to split the convention of the American Institute of Architects here today.
A Chicago police detective was named yesterday in Federal Court here by the Government as one of the masterminds of a nationwide ring that extorted hundreds of thousands of dollars from homosexuals.

Miss Carolyn C. Holzer and Peter Z. Konigsberg were married yesterday evening at the Regency by Rabbi Louis C. Gerstein and Rabbi David de Sola Pool. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Julian R. Holzer of 70 East 77th St., and her husband is the son of Louis Konigsberg of 65 Central Park West and the late Mrs. Konigsberg.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 30 (AP)--The district attorney said here today he would prosecute Federal Bureau of Investigation agents for wiretapping a hotel-casino.

ALBANY, June 30--Democrats and Republicans in the Assembly agreed today to reduce the scope and cost of the state's controversial new medical-care law. But party leaders disagreed on how much the two-month-old law should be changed.
LYDDA, Israel, June 30-- Chief Justice Earl Warren arrived here tonight for the dedication July 4 of a peace forest and memorial to President Kennedy.

YPSILANTI, Mich., June 30 --"The Birds" was written almost 50 years after "The Oresteia," but the Aristophanes comedy seems much more remote than the Aeschylus trilogy, at least as both are performed at the Ypsilanti Greek Theater.

Fresh from directing a major political victory, Senator Robert F. Kennedy is expected to endorse one of the Democratic candidates for Governor before the party's nominating convention in early September.
Three Army privates who have orders to report this month for embarkation to Vietnam said yesterday they would not go.
RAHWAY, N.J., June 30-- Bernard Rapp, assistant to George Stewart, the advertising credit manager of The New York Times, died today of a heart attack on his way to work. His age was 47.

Management's slate of directors was elected by a wide margin yesterday after Canadian Javelin, Ltd., turned down a request by a group of dissident stockholders to delay, the annual meeting for 60 days.

ALBANY, June 30 (AP)-- The Senate's Democratic minority leader, Joseph Zaretzki, was taken ill today at the Capitol during a recess.
BANGKOK, Thailand, June 30--Veiled in official silence, the United States military build-up in Thailand is continuing.

THE American male may be giving up his last escape hatch: the businessmen's convention. They are becoming family affairs, with more and more wives and youngsters joining their husbands at the sessions and having a bang-up time of it.

A chapter in New York bookpublishing history ended yesterday and a new one began when M. Lincoln Schuster sold his half-interest in Simon and Schuster, Inc., to his partner, Leon Shimkin. The price was reported to be $2-million.
Charles E. Eble, president of Consolidated Edison Company took issue yesterday with a contention that the utility was "the largest single producer of foul air in the city."

ATLANTA, June 30--John Lewis, who was regarded as a militant figure in the civil rights movement during his three years as chairman of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee, has resigned from the organization and taken issue with its new concept of "black power."

Patrick J. Frawley Jr., chairman of the Schick Safety Razor Company, yesterday accused executives of the Columbia Broadcasting System of exercising faulty judgment in banning a Schick-sponsored program from its stations.

Charles S. Vercelli, vice president and advertising manager of Macy's New York, died yesterday at Harkness Pavilion, Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, after a heart attack. He was 51 years old and lived at 87-19 Corona Avenue, Elmhurst, Queens.

ALBANY, June 30--A bill to provide broad financial help for the City University, worked out after weeks of touch-andgo bipartisan negotiations, is scheduled to win final passage in the Senate tomorrow and to be signed by Governor Rockefeller immediately afterward.
LONDON, June 30--The difficulties of being "con temporary," as they say, are all around in ballet.

HONG KONG, Friday, July 1 (Reuters)--Communist China said today that United States bombing at Hanoi and Haiphong was a serious escalation of the Vietnam war and warned it would lead the United States one step nearer the grave.

The New York Civil Liberties Union is planning to fight for a civilian-dominated review board next fall in debates, speeches and public appearances.
WASHINGTON, June 30-- The passport to Medicare benefits is a red, white and blue card. Social Security offices around the country are being swamped with questions about how to use the card.

WASHINGTON, June 30-- The Federal Aviation Agency plans to announce tomorrow that 13 airlines have agreed to severe restrictions on their use of the Washington National Airport, including a 500-mile limit on nonstop jet flights.
Yesterday was Freedom Day for a small, exuberant people.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP)--The police arrested 12 Quakers who engaged in a silent sit-in in the Senate gallery today to protest Congress's adjournment for the holiday at what they contend is a time of crisis in Vietnam.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 30--United States and South Vietnamese military authorities outlined today a broad plan to ease wartime crowding and congestion that have been strangling Saigon.

The RCA Sales Corporation, a subsidiary of the Radio Corporation of America, announced yesterday the election of Jack K. Sauter to the new post of executive vice president, sales operations. Richard W. Hanselman was named vice president, product planning and development.

CEDARHURST, L.I., June 30 --Temple Beth-El was the setting here this evening for the marriage of Miss Dale Sandra Koslow, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Koslow of Woodsburgh, to Jon H.I. Grouf, son of Mr. and Mrs. Meyer Grouf of Woodmere and New York. Rabbi Edward T. Sandrow and Rabbi Irving Miller officiated, assisted by Cantor Samuel T. Dubrow.
NEWARK, June 30--New Jersey will start collecting a 3 per cent selective sales tax tomorrow.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost of dining in any particular establishment.

The thermometer zoomed up to 96 degrees yesterday and New York seemed more like a skillet than a summer festival. As the Independence Day weekend approached, there was no certain sign of relief from the heat.

The Astor Hotel, which was officially closed to guests yesterday, will keep a 10th-floor suite open through August for use by an International Business Machines training school, which has a lease on the facili ties until then.

WASHINGTON, June 30-- Mr. and Mrs. Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. of Washington and Wellfleet, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katharine Bancroft Schlesinger, to Gibbs Kinderman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Kinderman of Palo Alto, Calif.
WASHINGTON, June 30-- The Patent Office announced today the granting of a contract that will eventually put 3.25-million patents on microfilm.

Hyman Friedman, a felt hat manufacturer, died yesterday at Doctors Hospital, Freeport, L.I., after a long illness. He was 89 years old.

FALLSBURG, N.Y., June 30--The Rabbinical Council of America, the largest Orthodox body in the country, elected Rabbi Pesach Z. Levovitz of Lakewood, N.J., as its president today. He succeeds Rabbi Israel Miller of New York City.

The First National City Bank announced yesterday its entry into the Australian consumer finance market through the acquisition for $3.5-million of a 50 per cent interest in the Waltons Credit Corporation, Ltd., the sales finance subsidiary of Waltons, Ltd., a leading Australian retailer.

LONDON, June 30 (Reuters) --Leaders of Britain's National Union of Seamen today tackled mounting opposition to their back-to-work order, while shipping companies struggled to sort out their strike-battered schedules.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 30--United States and South Vietnamese Government officials today approved a pay raise for 40,000 construction workers at American military projects.

GREEENWICH, Conn., June 30 --Mrs. Muriel Wiggin Selden, a leader in charitable and cultural activities and the wife of Lynde Selden, retired vice chairman of the American Express Company, died yesterday in her home here at 40 Field Point Park after a long illness. Her age was 68. She also had a residence at 110 East 57th Street in New York.

The Lincoln Savings Bank, which has assets of roughly $900-million in its eight offices in Brooklyn, Queens and Nassau, celebrated its hundredth birthday yesterday by declaring a 5 per cent dividend rate's for the third quarter, up from 4 per cent.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange declined yesterday for the fourth consecutive session, although a late rally sharply reduced early losses.

The quarter-final berths in the New York State tennis championship were filled yesterday with the advance of Robert Kahn of New York, William Tully of Pelham, N.Y., and Steve Stockton of Garden City, L.I., at the North Shore Tennis and Racquets Club in Bayside, Queens.

Despite slightly larger sales, net income of the Kroger Company in the 24 weeks ended June 18 decline to $l,906,043, or 92 cents a share; Jacob Davis, president,' reported .yesterday. KARACHI, Pakistan, June 30 --Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China left Rawalpindi for Peking today, ending a twoday visit during which President Mohammed Ayub Khan of Pakistan assured him that the friendship between the two countries would last "over the years."

ALBANY, June 30--The Senate voted tonight for a New York City income tax on residents and a levy on the earnings of commuters. But the tax package bogged down again in the Democratic-controlled Assembly.

King Faisal of Saudi Arabia flew to Geneva yesterday with the conviction that he had won new United States support for his efforts to modernize his desert kingdom and to rally other Islamic nations to form a shield against Communist penetration.

WASHINGTON, June 30-- President Johnson gave high praise today to the Central Intelligence Agency, a hearty "Well done" to its outgoing director, and warm greetings to its new one.
ROME, June 30--Pope Paul VI today marked the third anniversary of his coronation with a solemn pontifical mass and, later, with the dedication of three new transmitters of the Vatican radio.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 30 (AP)--Songs and chants of about 1,000 marchers rang through the streets of downtown Columbus today as a 155mile "march for decent welfare" reached its goal.
