EVREUX AIR FORCE BASE, France, June 30--The United States armed forces began their withdrawal from France today, 22 years and 24 days after their landing in Normandy.
Labor contracts between the city and nearly 100,000 of its employee expired last midnight with no mention of the word "strike."
LONDON, June 30--Hints were dropped today that Prime Minister Wilson's Government was studying a new British initiative to bring peace to Vietnam.
A number of price changes, chiefly on the up side, were announced yesterday for a variety of materials in the chemical, plastics and metals areas.
Day after day this week soybeans have set new life-of-contract highs, and yesterday all contracts went through the routine again. The question arises in some observers' minds: How much longer?
North American Philips, Inc., made a major move yesterday towards standardizing tape-recorder cartridges.
Joseph B. Gorab, president of Chrysler Mills, Inc., textile manufacturers, died of a heart attack Wednesday at his home in Rehoboth, Mass. He was 58 years old.
WASHINGTON, June 30-- The Government wound up its fiscal year today, having spent more and collected more than in any other year, including those of World War II.

CANBERRA, Australia, June 30 (UPI)--Secretary of State Dean Rusk delayed his departure from Australia today and met with British Foreign Secretary Michael Stewart. Mr. Stewart said later that Britain regretted the United States decision to bomb near Hanoi and Haiphong, a comment Prime Minister Wilson made yesterday.

Five men were sentenced yesterday to indeterminate terms up to five years in the rape of an Israeli nurse last October. Justice Albert H. Bosch recommended in Queens Supreme Court the five be made to serve maximum terms.
A new approach in the sale of male formal wear was announced yesterday by S. Rudofker's Sons, Inc., manufacturer of After Six formal apparel.

Participated in swearing in ceremonies for Richard M. Helms as Director of Central Intelligence; signed several bills; sent report to Congress of the U.S. Food for Peace accomplishments in 1965; flew to Nebraska and Iowa to address Democratic meetings.

WARSAW, June 30 (UPI)-- More than 1,500 well organized demonstrators tonight tried to storm the United States Embassy, smashed glass doors and windows and painted "Johnson should be hanged" on an embassy display case.
EUGENE, Ore., June 30 (AP) --District Attorney Robert Frye said today he would not again try to force Annette Buchanan, University of Oregon student editor, to disclose the names of news sources.

IT would take a computer to keep track of all the avail able variations of the Parsons table in New York department stores. Bloomingdale's offers 7,000 possibilities in its wood line alone. Add the range of choice at four other New York department stores, and the figure begins to become astronomical.
Paper stocks in this dull market are colorless, and the analysts who specialize in this end of the business are wondering why.

Ethel Merman, star of "Annie Get Your Gun," now at the New York State Theater, said yesterday she was planning to return here in the Irving BerlinHerbert and Dorothy Fields musical after the revival ends its six-week stand on July 9. The resumption is scheduled to start the week of Sept. 19.

WASHINGTON, June 30--The Johnson Administration may finally get over its agony in Vietnam--it may even achieve its military objective in the end-- but it will probably never regain the confidence it has lost in its judgment and veracity.
BUENOS AIRES, June 30-- The new Argentine military regime arrested the brother of the deposed President, Arturo U. Illia, this afternoon.
Federal antipoverty officials, announcing the approval of $11-million in summer programs yesterday, laid down a stringent set of special conditions for Haryou-Act.

ONE thing leads to another. Or so it seems. Not long ago the peculiar posi tion that Rogers Hornsby assumed in the batters' box was discussed here. He stood in the deepest rear corner of the box and should have been vulnerable to outside pitches. But he stepped in toward the plate and that beautifully level swing enabled him to average .402 over one breathtaking fiveyear span.
MOBILE, Ala., June 30 (AP) --S.I. Newhouse of New York announced tonight the purchase of a controlling interest in The Mobile Press Register, Inc., in a multimillion-dollar transaction.
Prices were narrowly mixed in moderate trading on the London Stock Exchange yesterday.
In a game remarkable for clean play and an abundance of goals, Torino of Italy gained a 3-3 tie with Bayern Munich of Germany before a crowd of 9,211 at Randalls Island last night.
NORTH BERGAN, N.J., June 30--Twenty-two persons were injured here today in a head-on collision of an automobile and an indepedent line bus.
Controller Mario A. Procaccino said last night that the city was ending its 1965-66 fiscal year with a balanced budget despite the fact that general-fund revenues fell $7million short of estimates.
CHICAGO, June 30--The American Medical Association's policy-making House of Delegates refused today to rescind a resolution that approved a form of hospital boycott under Medicare.
BOSTON, June 30--The New York Yankees, with three second-stringers in the line-up, made more errors than home runs against the Boston Red Sox tonight, with the predictable result.

ALERTNESS in defense is one of the distinguishing marks of the expert. Many players not far below the expert category failed to find the winning defense on the diagramed deal, which was played in the New England Regional Open Pair Championship last week-end.
The Federal Reserve continued to keep a tight rein on the money markets during the week ended Wednesday, figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York showed.

CYNWYD, Pa., June 30-- Top-seeded Harry Hoffman Sr., the 1957 titleholder from Philadelphia, bowed in the quarterfinal round of the United States seniors clay-court tennis championship today to George Ball, an English teacher at Copaigue (L.I.) Junior High School. The scores were 5-7, 8-6, 7-5.

FOR its second summer of festival concerts in Phil harmonic Hall, the New York Philarmonic is turning this year to the creative world of Igor Stravinsky, the music that influenced it and the music influenced by it. The series of nine programs, many of which will be repeated, opened last night, with Leonard Bernstein conducting a concert entitled "Stravinsky and American Music."
TOKYO, June 30--Wild shrieks in the Budokan, Japan's stately hall for the martial arts, tonight signaled yet another triumph for the Beatles.
WASHINGTON, June 30-- The Medicare program begins tomorrow amid predictions of a smooth start for the most extensive expansion of Social Security since the first law was passed in 1935.

MADRID, June 30--Four labor leaders were arraigned in court here today on charges of illegal activities following Monday's scheduled demonstration by workers during which the police arrested 182 people.
Mr. and Mrs. Austin A. O'Hara of New York and Southampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alice Myra ...

An order ending all passenger service on the 71-mile line of the New York, Susquehanna and Western Railroad, effective today, was issued yesterday by Irving Maidman, chairman and chief executive officer of the line.

ALBANY, June 30--The state's supplemental budget, which picks up the expenses not anticipated when the main budget is passed early in the legislative session, will reportedly be in the vicinity of $300million this year.
Negotiations in the 67-dayold newspaper dispute at the World Journal Tribune, Inc., were recessed yesterday until Tuesday.
MANCHESTER, N.H., June 30--Miss Helen Brightwell Taft and Ens. Timothy Goodrich Jones, U.S.N., have made plans to marry in December.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) --Officials of the Smithsonian Institution today urged a Senate public-works subcommittee to approve a bill requested by President Johnson to authorize a Joseph H. Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden here.
Chad Mitchell left his own vocal trio a year ago to become an actor. He returned to New York this week as a cabaret performer, with a supporting cast of four musicians.
At a stormy membership meeting yesterday, the Doctors Association rejected the city's proposal to end the work stoppage by specialists at the Health Department's medical centers and clinics.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 30 (AP)--Gaylord Perry, aided by Jim Hart's two-run homer in the fourth inning, gained his 11th victory of the season today as the San Francisco Giants downed the Atlanta Braves, 3-1.
ALBANY, June 30--Following is the roll-call vote by which the State Senate tonight passed the city income tax on residents and the earnings levy on commuters:
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 30 (UPI)--Fred Whitfield drove in three runs and scored twice today to lead the Cleveland Indians to a 4-0 victory over the Minnesota Twins.
PRINCETON, N.J., June 30 --Miss Ann Rachel Ginsburgh, daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Al bert Ginsburgh, was married this noon to Michael Gary Hofkin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Hofkin of Philadelphia.

The vision of Medicare patients' streaming out of municipal hospitals this morning and presenting themselves for admission to medical centers as private patients--a vision that haunted some hospital administrators during the winter months,--was all but dispelled yesterday.
BILOXI, Miss, June 30 (UPI) --Prohibition ends in Mississippi tomorrow, but the state will get drier before it goes wet.

Earl Hines, the jazz pianist who will be leaving for the Soviet Union on July 7 for a sixweek tour sponsored by the State Department's Cultural Presentations Program, introduced the group he will take with him last night in the garden of the Museum of Modern Art. His concert was the second in the Museum's "Jazz in the Garden" series.
Mrs. Tommy Angell, a 42-year-old lawyer from Berkeley, Calif., led the Pannonia Athletic Club of San Francisco to the women's team foil title yesterday in the national fencing championships.

LEOPOLDVILLE, The Congo, June 30--President Joseph D. Mobutu took up the mantle of the late Patrice Lumumba in an Independence Day speech today in which he declared war on "the money powers" and promised to free the Congo of economic colonialism.
PEKING, June 30 (Reuters) --A Communist Chinese conference was reported today to have concluded that "antiSocialist bourgeois agents" had seriously undermined cultural work in China's army.
WASHINGTON, June 30-- The Defense Department told Congresses today that it favored changing the draft system so that men 19 or 20 would be taken ahead of older men.

MOSCOW, June 30--President de Gaulle's principal reason for making his spectacular two-week swing around the Soviet Union was to break down the political, economic and emotional barriers that separate Eastern and Western Europe.
Following is a transcript of President Johnson's speech in Omaha yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

ROME, June 30--News of the United States bombings "cannot be received without regret and also not without anxiety," L'Osservatore Romano, the Vatican City newspaper, said in a brief front-page editorial comment.

Cooperation among business, industry and government has brought about overseas transportation conditions that may mean $250-million more a year in American beef and livestock exports, it was reported yesterday by John Harllee, chairman of the Federal Maritime Commission.
Months of rumors were laid to rest yesterday, with word that Hertz was moving its domestic advertising account out of Norman, Craig Kummel, Inc.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) --Senator Clifford P. Case joined today in an attack on two proposed dams on the Colorado River. He contended that they would "destroy" a part of the Grand Canyon.

The Temporary Commission on City Finances declared yesterday that the compromise tax program was only "a brief stopgap" measure that would have to be supplemented "at the earliest possible time, perhaps in a special session of the Legislature after the November election."

The beginning of Medicare ushers in a new way of life for millions of Americans. Those over 65 and those in need now have the precious security of knowing that their medical bills will no longer be a ruinous or calamitous burden. This assurance provides a measure of independence and dignity that for older citizens is in many respects as important as the services that will be available to them.
CHASKA, Minn., June 30-- Mickey Wright broke par, set the pace and took an important step toward her fifth women's United States Open golf title today.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., June 30 --George D. Ellis, who retired in 1958 as vice president in charge of finance of Combustion Engineering, Inc., died yesterday in his home at 16 Fox Meadow Road here. He was 68 years old.
The spot rate on the British pound moved up 5 points, to $2.7903, in moderately active trading on foreign-exchange trading markets here yesterday.
The futility of pitching behind the New York Mets' batting order finally was brought home to Bob Shaw last night in Shea Stadium.
Stock prices took another steep tumble yesterday but managed to recover a large part of their losses in an afternoon recovery.

MIAMI BEACH, June 30-- A top official of the United States Office of Education said here today that he did not "have much faith" that school administrators would lead the way toward desegregation of the nation's classrooms.
NOTTINGHAM, England, June 30 (Reuters)--England dismissed the West Indies cricket team for 235 runs when the third test began today. But England lost three wickets with only 13 runs scored.
The new chairman of the department of medicine at the New York University School of Medicine will take over today. He is Dr. Saul J. Farber, who succeeds Dr. Lewis Thomas.
National Football League club owners met at the Plaza Hotel for seven hours yesterday and discussed their three-weekold peace agreement with the American Football League.

DETROIT, June 30--Mr. and Mrs. Stanley A. Boris have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jeanne Marie Boris, to Dr. Charles Martin Wynn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur E. Wynn of Forest Hills, Queens, New York.
The election of John Kostuik as a director was announced yesterday by the Molybdenum Corporation of America, a producer of molybdenum columbium and rare earths.

Many a man who earns money in the city is wondering which of the new city taxes he will have to pay--the income tax to be imposed on residents or the lower earnings tax to be levied against nonresidents.
Following are excerpts from the concluding statement of the third report of the Temporary Commission on City Finances:

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 30--Following is the text of a letter front Arthur J. Goldberg, United States representative at the United Nations, to Frank Corner of New Zealand, this month's President of the Security Council:
MOSCOW, June 30--France and the Soviet Union declared today their intent to collaborate with each other as a catalyst around which all Europe would refashion itself in confidence and peace.

Half the field for the eighth annual Roosevelt International Trot, set for Roosevelt Raceway on the night of July 9, arrived yesterday at Kennedy International Airport. Three-- Pluvier III of Sweden, Roquuepine of France and Merceno of Norway--made the flight from Stockholm.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) --The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today adoption of a fee schedule for brokers and dealers who are registered with the commission but not members of the National Association of Securities Dealers.

FREDERICK, Md., June 30 (AP)--Two United States girls' records were broken and another was tied tonight at the opening session of the National Amateur Athletic Union women's and girls' outdoor track and field championships.

About 700 men, women and children marched in front of the United States Mission to the United Nations yesterday in protest against the war in Vietnam and the bombing of oil depots near Hanoi and Haiphong.

The biggest name on the day's card at Aqueduct yesterday was the King Ranch's Buffle, who has established himself as one of the nation's best 3-yearolds through his having finnished second in the Belmont ...
WIMBLEDON, England, June 30--It will be Mrs. Billie Jean King of the United States against Maria Bueno of Brazil Saturday for the Wimbledon crown.

GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass., June 30--Australis, the defending national high-point champion, pulled into a tie for the lead in the open jumper division of the Great Barrington horse show tonight by winning a time class.

ALDERSON, W. Va., June 30 (AP)--Bernice Geiger, the 64year-old widow from Sheldon, Iowa, who was convicted in 1961 of embezzling $2.1-million from her father's bank, will be released tomorrow on parole.

MOSCOW, June 30--Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin strongly condemned tonight the United States air attacks against oil depots in the outskirts of Hanoi and Haiphong, but he did not indicate that the Soviet Government planned to increase military aid to North Vietnam in response.
KOTTAYAM, India, June 30 --Prime Minister Indira Gandhi barnstormed through the Communist stronghold of Kerala today in an effort to rally her divided and dispirited Congress party.

DETROIT, June 30 (AP)-- The American Motors Corporation today became the first United States automobile company to complete its 1966 model production. American Motors built 300,000 cars, compared with 391,000 in the 1965 model run.
WASHINGTON, June 30-- Railroad freight traffic volume and intercity truck tonnage in the latest week ended June 25 were both considerably ahead of 1965.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., June 30--Missy Warden of Syosset, L.I., in the under16-years division; Anne Stuhler of Westfield, N.J., in the 14-year classification and Laurie Tenney of Scarsdale, N.Y., in the under-12 group, won New York State girls' tennis championships at the Ardsley Country Club today.
LONDON, June 30 AP)-- Cassius Clay will defend his world heavyweight title against Brian London of Britain at Earls Court Stadium on Aug. 6, the promoter, Jack Solomons, said today.
Directors of Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation increased the board from 12 to 13 members and elected Richard D. Zanuck as a director.
COLCHESTER, England, Julie 30 (Reuters)--Margery Allingham, one of England's leading mystery writers, died in a hospital here today at the age of 62.
The Morton Street pier is a concrete slab with a middling view of Hoboken, but to Greenwich Villagers who fought to getit reopened to sun bathers, it is Acapulco-on-the-Hudson.
A new televison commercial for Schaefer beer may make you think twice when you're having more than one.

A merger proposal is being studied by two giant,insurance-company groups that carry the Continental name but are unrelated. The groups, each of which have about $2 billion in assets, are the Continental Insurance Companies of New York and the Continental National American Group of Chicago.

Five persons, including a teacher, were arrested yesterday morning at a busy Harlem intersecton when a group of demonstrators forcibly prevented school teachers from entering the controversy-plagued Public School 175.
Electric power was halted for about a minute yesterday afternoon in the area between 56th and 58th Streets east of Fifth Avenue.

Mrs. Lydia Buhl Melhado of New York, daughter of Christian Henry Buhl of Detroit and Mrs. Thomas Morrison of Detroit and New York, was married yesterday to Francis Bartow Farr, also of New York. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Farr of Southampton, L.I.

The city's Board of Assessors whose functions were largely abolished by the new charter went out of existence last night. In an executive order, Mayor Lindsay transferred the 27 employes of the board to the Director of Finance, Roy M. Goodman, who will have jurisdiction over the assessors' remaining tasks.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Russell E. Whitmeyer of New York and Lancaster, Pa., of the engagement of Mrs. Whitmyer's daughter, Miss Emily Benedict McAlpin, to Frederic David Marusi, son of Mr. and Mrs. Augustine R. Marusi of Red Bank, N.J.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 30--The Soviet Union called on the Trusteeship Council today to set a deadline for the United States to grant independence to the Pacific islands it holds as a trust territory.

CHICAGO, June 30--Harold Leonard Stuart, president of Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., one of the nation's largest investment banking firms, died here this morning of cancer at Passavant Hospital. He would have been 85 years old next month.
Mayor Lindsay gave an informal luncheon yesterday to honor 35 citizens who, in his view, have made contribution's toward New York City's greatness.
West Coast Line yesterday announced that it would begin cargo handling operations on Tuesday at Pier 64, Hudson River, at West 24th Street.

The credit brake is being pressed down with increasing vigor. The new move by commercial banks raising interest rates for the third time in little more than six months followed on the heels of Federal Reserve action that placed further restrictions on the availability of credit. So money will be scarcer and more expensive than ever.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 30--United States officials are quietly putting into effect an important change in their handling of prisoners of war.
DES MOINES, Iowa, June 30 --President Johnson journeyed today to the nation's fertile agricultural heartland to try to shore up his Administration's sagging popularity with farmers.

WASHINGTON, June 30--A boycott by doctors of hospitals that lump radiologists' and other specialists' fees with hospital bills would bring an immediate Justice Department inquiry into the action, a department spokesman said today.

BUCHANAN, N.Y., June 30 --Fishermen in the Hudson Valley are now as contented as power-users because the nuclear-fueled generating plant of the Consolidated Edison Company is no longer a death trap for fish.
LYNN, Mass., June 30 (AP)-- A full shift returned to work at General Electric plants here and in Everett for the first time in three weeks as a strike that had made more than 9,000 idle was settled.
LOS ANGELES, June 30) (UPI)--The district attorney's office has closed the book on the scuffle June 8 between Frank Sinatra and Frederick Weisman, a retired food manufacturer.
KANSAS CITY, June 30 (UPI)--Luis Aparicio, Boog Powell and Dave Johnson combined for 10 hits today to pace a 19-hit Baltimore attack and lead the Orioles to an 11-3 rout of the Kansas City Athletics.
BONN, June 30--West Germany informed France today that it would agree to the continued stay of French forces in this country after tomorrow, when they leave the NATO command, "for the time being."

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, June 30--The Vesper Boat Club of Philadelphia, a crew of post-college oarsmen who stand for disciplined dedication without expectation of material gain, will row here tomorrow for the last time together if they lose, and the next to last time if they win.
ATHENS, Ga., June 30-- The Justice Department produced a surprise witness today as the conspiracy trial of three Georgia Ku Klux Klansmen neared a close.

N.B.C. International, a division of the National Broadcasting Company, will help South Vietnam set up a four-station national television network. The stations will transmit school and adult education programs as well as cultural and informational material.
The combination of increased interest rates on bank loans and intensification of the Vietnam war pushed bond prices down sharply yesterday.
IN the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

TOKYO, June 30--Japanese leftists today promised mass protests against the United States bombing of North Vietnamese oil depots close to Hanoi and Haiphong, but the Government accepted the attacks as "unavoidable in view of the circumstances."

WASHINGTON, June 30-- Two weeks ago Arthur Emil Hess's wife and two of his three daughters "took him by the ear," drove him to a store and bought him a navy blue suit for his birthday. The family had to treat the 6 foot 1 inch head of the house like a boy needing discipline ...

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 30--External aid to India's economy was supplemented today through a $23-million credit from the International Development Association, which yesterday announced a similar credit of $68-million.
Mayor Lindsay was urged yesterday to assume a direct leadership role in the affairs of the city school system.
BONN, July 1 France notified members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization today that she would take all her military aircraft out of West Germany by Oct. 1, according to reliable sources.

MILWAUKEE, July 1 (AP)--A homemade bomb exploded early today against the rear door of a linoleum store operated by John Gilman, former executive secretary of the old Wisconsin Civil Rights Congress. No one was injured.

The first of 47 summer concerts of popular music was held last night at the Wollman Memorial Skating Rink. The program marked the official opening of the first annual Rheingold Central Park Music Festival.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 1 Vice President Aleksandar Rankovic, who was second only to President Tito in the leadership of the ruling League of Communists, was ousted today from his top party jobs.
The World Bank's successful sale of $175 million in new bonds caps twenty years of increasingly successful operation.

ALBANY, July 1 The State Senate voted final passage today for a bill that will allow the City University of New York to carry out a virtually unlimited expansion program. It guarantees admission this fall to 2,278 qualified freshmen who had been rejected for lack of facilities.
BALTIMORE, July 1 Shouts of "black power" reverberated tonight at the 23d annual convention of the Congress of Racial Equality.
American Airlines, Inc., showed increased earnings for the month of May and first five months this year in its report issued yesterday.

Lawn watering with automatic sprinklers was banned in Staten Island yesterday by Robert D. Clark, the Acting Commissioner of the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, for what he called "flagrant violation" of water use regulations.

The Rev. George C. Wyatt Jr., associate chaplain of St. Luke's Hospital Center, an Episcopal institution, died yesterday of a heart attack there. He was 60 years old and lived at 814 Amsterdam Avenue.

Philip Lovejoy, former general secretary of Rotary International, died here Wednesday at the Paramount Hotel, 235 West 46th Street. For the last four years, Mr. Lovejoy who was 72 years old, had been living in Ormond Beach, Fla. He was in New York with his wife en route to a European vacation.
The keel of what is described as the largest aluminum-hulled catamaran to be built in this country has been laid in Baltimore at the yard of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation.

LAST night, Lewisohn Stadium was well filled, the night was beautiful and so was Renata Tebaldi. Shouts of "Brava Renata" were tossed up a little more frequently than the firecrackers and sparklers that could be heard and seen over the stadium wall.
All seven top Lindsay administration officials whose residency qualifications have been questioned received their pay checks yesterday.

WASHINGTON July 1 A survey of educational opportunities ordered by Congress has shown that predominantly Negro schools are inferior to those attended largely by whites and that this tends to widen the achievement gap between the races.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1 (UPI) Federal District Judge Ralph C. Body announced today that he would "carefully review" all aspects of the conviction of Ralph Ginzburg, New York publisher who is under sentence for mailing obscene literature.
ATHENS, Ga., July 1 The Federal Government's conspiracy case against three Ku Klux Klansmen went to an allwhite, jury in the United States District Court here this afternoon.
CORDELE, Ga., July 1 (AP) -Four Negroes were arrested during the night in this middle Georgia community for violating a curfew imposed after violence erupted between whites and Negroes.

BUENOS AIRES, July 1--A wave of uneasiness swept the Argentine Jewish community of 500,000 people today after police squads arrested several shopkeepers and closed their stores in the largely Jewish-owned Galeria Internacional.
BIENHOA, South Vietnam, July 1 Premier Nguyen Cao Ky predicted today that United States air strikes would "very soon" force the enemy commanders to request a cease-fire.

Federal Judge William B. Herlands yesterday returned to the Dutchess County Court the case against Dr. Timothy Leary, former Harvard University staff member, and two friends who were charged with possessing marijuana and LSD, the halucinatory drug.

THIS anthology of writings on Greece is not easy to categorize. It is not a travel er's guide, for many of the places and sites have been changed since the words were written; it is not a celebration of Greece as "the golden moment of the past"; it is not solely an analysis of the Greek character and the Greek way. It is a mixture of all three.
LONDON, July 1 The Tower of London, where the only thing that swung in the old days was the axman's blade, was swinging to music for the Establishment last night.

The Cloud Casino of Roosevelt Raceway, Westbury, L.I. will be the setting for the International Ball in behalf of Boys Towns of Italy on July 10. Toby F. Coletti, president of the Long Island Federation of Labor, is chairman of the event.

HONOLULU, July 1 John F. Kennedy Jr., the 5-year-old son of the late President, was treated here this afternoon for first- and second-degree burns suffered when he fell into the coals of a dying cookout fire earlier today on Hawaii Island.

Elder-Beerman Stores, Inc., has filed suit for damages of $15-million in the United States District Court in Dayton, Ohio, against Federated Department Stores, its Rike-Kumler Company division, and more than 60 other concerns.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 1 Mrs. Diane Placon Carson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Kenneth Plancon, was married today to R. Neale Van Delft, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Van Delft of Westport. The Rev. Dr. Henry E. Robinson performed the ceremony in the First Church of Christ Congregational.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) Los Angeles radio listeners will soon be able to tune in on 16 almost solid hours of advertising seven days a week.

Four major lumber associations reported a decrease of 1.8 per cent in production for the week ended June 25, compared with the level in the corresponding 1965 week. Output fell 2.3 per cent from the preceding week.
Several of Mayor Lindsay's cabinet members emerged from their weekly meeting yesterday morning wearing orange buttons inscribed, "DC."

Announcement has been made here of the marriage in Savona, Italy, of Miss Maria Luisa Caroggio and Edward Murphy Duval, son of Mrs. Donald H. Allen of 1150 Fifth Avenue. The wedding was performed June 22 at the Oratorio dei Santi Pietro e Caterina
SAN ANTONIO, July 1--President Johnson's aides today came up with a new technique of retroactive polishing of the President's oratorical style.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 1 The Nassau County Commission on Governmental Revision recommended a reapportionment of the Board of Supervisors today. It proposed that the present six-member board be expanded to 12 members elected from Assembly Districts instead of from towns and cities.

CHASKA, Minn., July 1 Mickey Wright found one of the ponds on the course today and didn't like it. After a 6 there and a second round of 78, the former titleholder dropped back into a tie for the lead in the women's United States Open golf championship. She was tied at 149 with Sandra Spuzich.
Most issues on the American Stock Exchange registered solid gains yesterday, marking the first upward movement of the week on the exchange.
Another in the long series of attempts to get diplomats and foreign consular officials to comply with parking regulations will be started Aug. 1, the Police Department said yesterday.
RICHMOND, July 1 Winfred Mundle, a 57-year-old Negro insurance executive, was chosen Vice Mayor today, the first of his race to hold the post in this former capital of the Confederacy.
WASHINGTON, July 1 Dr. Perry D. Teitelbaum, an economist with Resources for the Future, Inc., died Tuesday at Doctors Hospital of a heart attack. He was 40 years old and lived in Silver Spring, Md.
Steamfitters and mosaic and terrazzo helpers struck the city's builders yesterday morning after a midnight contract deadline passed without new agreements.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) Twelve Quakers who engaged in a silent sit-in in the Senate gallery yesterday pleaded guilty today to charges of unlawful entry and were fined $100 each with the alternative of 30 days in jail. All are expected to pay the fines.
BALTIMORE, July 1--The Medicare program, affecting Americans over 65, got off to a smooth start today.

The holiday weekend stakes program at Aqueduct will be introduced by today's 59th running of the Saranac Handicap. This one-mile handicap for 3year-olds has attracted 10 starters, making for a gross of $57,800 and a purse of $37,570 to the winner.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) Stokely Carmichael said to day that the Administration's civil rights bill was a sham" and saw newsmen walk out on him when he refused to comment on leadership changes within the rights movement.
The extra $1.8-million in antipoverty money the city gained from an increase in Neighborhood Youth Corps jobs has proved a mixed blessing for local groups running special summer programs.
Former Poice Commissioner Vincent L. Broderick became a partner yesterday in the law firm of Phillips, Nizer, Benjamin, Krim Ball.
GUATEMALA, July 1 Julio Cesar Mendez Montenegro took the oath today as President of Guatemala and immediately issued an appeal to Communistled guerrilla forces to lay down their arms.

The new proposal for an experimental suspension of underground nuclear tests, which could halt proliferation of nuclear weapons, deserves top priority in SovietAmerican disarmament discussions. Although the proposal was made at a nongovernmental conference in Canada, its endorsement there by Soviet officials indicates the possibility of official Soviet acceptance.
ST. CATHARINES, Ont., July 1 Armbro Flight captured the $8,300 Canadian trotting championship with a 6 length victory over Betsy Herbert tonight at Garden City Raceway.
THE HAGUE, July 1 The police tonight arrested 86 youths who had demonstrated before the United States Consulate in Amsterdam against United States policy in Vietnam.
New York City park visitors will find more organized diversion this summer than ever before, if the weather permits everything to go off according to schedule.
HARTFORD, July 1 Senator Thomas J. Dodd was greeted with a standing ovation at the convention of Connecticut Democrats that opened here tonight.

Around dawn this morning, Coast Guard cutters will start hosing down the decks and strakes of the battered tanker Alva Cape in Gravesend Bay, and a crew of salvage men on a barge will approach gingerly to free the burned vessel from her anchor.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 1 Manuel Santana defeated Dennis Ralston of the United States, 6-4, 11-9, 6-4, today in a fiesta of glorious tennis and became the first Spaniard to win the Wimbledon championship.
A civilian fire prevention inspector, Matthew Rizzo, was arrested yesterday on charges of demanding and accepting $30 while inspecting Regents Exhibits, Inc., 42-48 23d Street, Long Island City.
PARIS, July 1 President de Gaulle returned from the Soviet Union today to a comparatively quiet reception in Paris that contrasted with the receptions he had received from the Russians.

The City Council last night enacted legislation that includes an income tax on residents and an earnings tax on commuters. Taken together with other taxes enacted in the State Legislature and the Board of Estimate, the program will yield the city an additional $253-million annually. This is less than half of the $520.5-million originally requested by Mayor Lindsay.

ALBANY, July 1 The perennial proposal to raise state legislators' salaries picked up momentum tonight in the frenzy of the Legislature's adjournment drive. But there were strong doubts over whether anything would come of it.

BALTIMORE, July 1 (AP) Billy Short, a left-hander who was making his first major league appearance in four years, pitched a six-hitter as the league-leading Baltimore Orioles edged the Minnesota Twins tonight, 2-0, and swept a double-header.
OZARK, Ala., July 1 (AP) Alabama traffic accidents killed 24 persons during a 24-hour period ending today. Many of the victims were women and children.

QUOGUE, L.I., July 1 A. Hunt Marckwald Jr. of 111 East 80th Street, New York, a partner in W.E. Hutton Co., stockbrokers at 14 Wall Street, New York, died here today in his country home. He was 56 years old.
ENGLEWOOD, N.J., July 1 Michael M. Burris, consulting engineer, landscape architect and land planner, died yesterday at the Englewood Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived at 485 Engle Street.
ALBANY, July 1 Following is the roll-call vote by which the State Assembly authorized a New York City earnings tax on commuters tonight:

MOSCOW, July 1 Leonid I. Brezhnev, General Secretary of the Soviet Communist party, called on United States policy makers today to give more serious thought to the possible consequences of their "impulsive" actions in Vietnam.
FRANKFORT, Ky., July 1 (UPI) Kentucky laws regulating nudist societies were declared unconstitutional today in an unanimous opinion of the state's highest court.

WASHINGTON, July 1 The handwriting on the card, simple and backward-sloping, conveys a message at once concise and poignant: "For Bill Greer whom the President loved, and who was with him until the very end. Thank you."

BERLIN, July 1--An East German court has sentenced Miss Mary Hellen Battle of Oak Ridge, Tenn., to four years in prison on charges that she tried to help an East German flee to the West, the United States mission disclosed today.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 1--The American Hospital Association has told President Johnson that it expects few difficulties in putting into effect the Medicare program.
The New York State Council on the Arts announced this week that it had given $128,900 in grants to 16 special projects.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 1 (UPI) A United States attempt to put a satellite into orbit around the moon failed today. Officials said that instead the spacecraft, Explorer 33, would become a farranging satellite of the earth.

WASHINGTON, July 1 The Federal Aviation Agency announced today severe restrictions on flights to the Washington National Airport that are expected to have worldwide implications for airlines and private aircraft.
WASHINGTON, July 1 The three-month Treasury bill rate climbed by three-tenths of a per cent today and reached the highest level on record, the Treasury disclosed tonight.

Higher education in the South is on the move. The moral economic drain of a divided society that has depressed the general welfare by denying educational advancement to Negroes has also left Southern colleges and universities far behind the mainstream of American academia. Some Southern educational leaders have been trying hard to catch up.

PEKING There was not the turmoil at the College of Iron and Steel Technology when I visited it as there was later at Peking University in the wake of the current purge. But its absence did not mean that the modern institution had been passed over by the "great Socialist cultural revolution."
Mrs. Hattie Klee Straus; widow of Simon W. Straus, the financier, died yesterday in her residence at the Alrae Hotel, 37 East 64th Street. She was 96 years old.

AN 800-year-old guild very much alive today, the Worshipful Company of Goldsmiths in London, is proving its vitality and showing the fruits of its fine traditions in an exhibition which has just begun an American tour in San Francisco.
The police are baffled, Railway Express doesn't want to be quoted and Fenster Associates, Inc., says it feels "rather ridiculous." And Ron Hunt or at least an $8,000 portrait of him is still missing.

GENEVA, July 1 Leaders of the World Council of Churches expressed to President Johnson today the "resentment and alarm" they said the intensification of United States bombings in Vietnam was causing among many Christians.
WASHINGTON, July 1 Communist China has apparently doubled the size of its construction force in North Vietnam in the last six months, State Department officials said today.

HENLEY, England, July 1 (UPI) The Turn Und Sports Club of East Berlin beat the favored Vesper Boat Club of Philadelphia by three-quarters of a length today in the semifinals of the Grand Challenge Cup in the Henley Regatta. The German crew turned in the fastest time of the year on the famed Thames River course.
CHICAGO, July 1 (AP) Gary Peters raced home on a passed ball by Mike Ryan with two out in the 13th inning tonight, giving the Chicago White Sox a 2-1 victory over the Boston Red Sox.
ALBANY, July 1 Following is the roll-call vote in the Assembly tonight authorizing an income tax for residents of New York City:
ALBANY, Saturday, July 2 After three months of deadlock and two weeks of rounding up the votes, the Legislature gave final approval to New York City's $253-million tax package last night.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 1 A licensed skipper will be mandatory on all seagoing fishing vessels of 25 tons or more, as a result of action taken June 22 by the United Nations International Labor Organization. A spokesman said here today that this and two other key changes were approved at the I.L.O. convention in Geneva.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (UPI)--A leader of the Maryland Ku Klux Klan asked Governor Rockefeller of New York yesterday to guarantee protection to Klansmen for a planned march through Harlem on Aug. 1.

SIMLA, India, June 30 The first premonsoon showers are sifting through the dark pine forests, and the top of Elysium Hill is lost in mist. Another "season" is drawing to a close at the "queen of Indian hill stations."
LONDON, July 1 Three paintings by El Greco were sold at Christie's, the art auction house, today for the equivalent of $267,540.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 1 Life has returned to normal in Baghdad following yesterday's abortive coup d'etat, according to travelers arriving in Beirut on the first flight from the Iraqi capital today.

Richard Korn, president of the American Council for Judaism, said yesterday that no representative of the council visited King Faisal of Saudi Arabia or any of his aides during the King's visit to this country.
City Council President Frank D. O'Connor will officially announce what is already obvious that he is a candidate for Governor in a flying tour of seven cities next Thursday.

Locals of the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists were given permission yesterday to establish "informational picket lines" at stations and facilities of the Columbia Broadcasting System in support of the radio announcers' strike against KCBS in San Francisco.
RICHMOND, July 1 (AP) There may not be much point in saving your Confederate money, but if you can find any preCivil War Virginia bonds around the house Virginia will redeem them.
Walter Kidde Co., Inc., is planning to add automotive products and business-machines equipment to its already diversified industrial line through a consolidation with the Dura Corporation.
The New Jersey Public Utility Commission yesterday directed that commuter service for 200 passengers be resumed Tuesday on the New York, Susquehanna and Western Railroad.
SAIGON, Saturday, July 2 William C. Westmoreland, the American commander in Vietnam, asserted today that allied forces were winning the war here.
BOUTIQUES, those refreshing oases of radical fashion where the eccentric grew into the norm, keep busting out all over.

Mr. and Mrs. Edwin F. Russell of New York have announced the engagement of their eldest daughter, Miss. Serena Mary Churchill Russell, to R. Stephen Salant Jr., son of Robert S. Salent of Locust Valley, L.I., and the late Mrs. Margaret Earle Brownell Salant.

Dr. Abraham Berliner, a dental specialist, died Thursday in the Veterans Administration Hospital, Manhattan. He was 53 years old and lived at 25 Central Park West. His office was at 200 Central Park South.
ALBANY, July 1 A move to overhaul the largely ineffective Condon-Wadlin Law that forbids strikes by public employes may prove to be the most important casualty of the legislative session.
ATLANTA, July 1 The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. said tonight that he would refuse to appear publicly with any civil rights speaker who might advocate racial violence.

Two young Russian priests who were suspended after they accused the Soviet Government of unlawfully suppressing religion have been disclosed also to be the authors of a strong attack on the readiness of church leaders to capitulate to "unlawful" demands of the state.

The recent price fireworks in soybeans spent itself yesterday. Perhaps it was the influence of the long July 4 weekend, or perhaps the spectacular highflying prices scared traders. In any event, there was a lull.

NORWOOD, N.J., July 1. Miss Shirley A. Bradshaw of New York, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph G. Bradshaw of Pontiac, Ill., was married today to George M. Gillette Jr. of Fort Lee, a commissioner of the Bergen County Park Commission. He is the son of Mrs. Harry De Baun of St. Petersburg, Fla., and the late Mr. Gillette.

WILTON, Conn., July 1 Miss Catherine Arria Dixwell Chase, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Epes Dixwell Chase, was married this afternoon to Harrison McCann Bilodeau, son of Mrs. Arthur Willis Jr. of Milton, Mass., and the late Dr. Charles Cloudman Bilodeau.
All four top-seeded players in the New York State championship made their exits yesterday in the quarter-final round at the North Shore Tennis and Racquets Club in Bayside Queens.

TOKYO, July 1 The Japanese Government and shipbuilders hope to begin studies soon on the feasibility of constructing 500,000-deadweightton tankers, more than three times the tonnage of the world's largest ship, the 150,000-ton tanker Tokyo Maru.
Rear Adm. Gordon McLintock, superintendent of the Merchant Marine Academy, Kings Point, L.I., announced yesterday the appointment of Comdr. Richard D. O'Leary as regimental officer of the college.
LONDON, July 1 The Government published today terms of a bill to bring into public ownership the nation's 13 largest iron and steel companies.

MONTREAL, July 1 The 18th biennial congress of the Greek Orthodox Church of North and South America voted "whole-hearted" support today of the United States stand against "all aggression, particularly in Vietnam."

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP)--The State Department announced today that it had turned down a request by Gus Hall, general secretary of the Communist party, for permission to go to Communist China, North Vietnam, North Korea and Cuba.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and subsidiaries continued to thrive through the three-month and 12-month periods ended May 31.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 1 The Newport Jazz Festival opened its 13th season tonight with the musicians playing on the first permanent stage in the festival's history.
BOSTON, July 1 (AP)--David O'Brien, 19 years old, convicted of burning his draft card, was sentenced today to a Federal Youth Correctional Center for an indefinite term.
Stock prices continued to rally yesterday but trading slowed sharply from the pace on Thursday, when the recovery began.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange were generally firm on scattered demand yesterday.
ALBANY, July 1 The Assembly passed a compromise package of four amendments tonight designed to reduce the scope and cost of Medicaid, the state's controversial new medical-care law.

GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass., July 1 Australis, the defending national high-point champion, moved into a commanding lead for the open jumper championship by winning the knockdown-and-out event tonight at the Great Barrington horse show.
Capital Cities Broadcasting, which has gone about as far as it can grow as a broadcaster, may soon point its acquisition antennas in new directions.

DAR ES SALAM, Tanzania, July 1 The ninth session of the liberation committee of the Organization for African Unity ended today with a statement condemning the secret talks between Britain and Rhodesia. The committee again called on the British Government to "apply immediately the use of force to topple the Smith regime."
Dave Micahnik got revenge on Paul Pesthy last night in leading Salle Csiszar of Philadelphia to the epee team title in the national fencing championships.

A NEW shape is happening to shoes. It began many years ago, long before most of its present-day wearers were born. It has a thick, stubby toe and a heavy, clumpy heel. It looks as if it came from the neighborhood thrift shop, and that is in fact where the current fashion began.

A COLLEGE education may prepare girls to face the commercial world but may not help them with the do mestic one a conclusion that has led Helen Sheller, 33 years a homemaker, to give a course in the art of homemaking.

NEWTOWN, Pa., July 1 Miss Caroline Potter Kerlin, daughter of Mrs. Ward Dix Kerlin Jr. of Langhorne, Pa., and the late Mr. Kerlin, was married today to Edwin Walter Kemmerer 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald L. Kemmerer of Champaign, Ill. The Rev. Robert G. Foulkes and the Rev. Bryant M. Kirkland performed the ceremony in the Presbyterian Church.
The most remarkable news about the city's school year, which ended Thursday, was the absence of news about open conflict over integration.
A virtually perfect game was pitched last night by Woodie Fryman, the Pittsburgh Pirates' left-handed rookie, as he defeated the New York Mets, 12-0, at Shea Stadium.
After incredibly protracted arm-twisting, trading and self-imposed torture, the Legislature has seen the light at least dimly and approved the reduced Lindsay tax program for New York City.
Miss Sally Matthys Dorst was married yesterday in the Wigrian Church here to H. Erich Heinemann. The Rev. Robert Smudski performed the ceremony.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, July 2 United States naval aircraft yesterday sank three North Vietnamese torpedo boats racing toward ships of the Seventh Fleet in the Gulf of Tonkin, an American military spokesman said today.

With summer here it means that children are going to have spare time or, to put it another way, poison ivy, barked shins, heat rash, tetanus shots for rusty-nail punctures, and tar on their clothes. There's something worse, though the lament, "There's nothing to do."
The spot rate on the British pound was lower in slow trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. Volume was very small, as is normal before a long weekend.

A partial power failure that lasted three-and-a-half hours at Kennedy International Airport delayed arriving planes up to 30 minutes and departing planes up to one hour, late Thursday and early yesterday, the Federal Aviation Agency said.

Dr. Linda Lee Weingarten, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lee Weingarten of New York, was married yesterday to Philip B. Scheffler, son of Mrs. Herman M. Scheffler, also of New York, and the late Mr. Scheffler Rabbi Joachim Prinz performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents at 68 East 86th Street.

BEAVER FALLS, Pa., July 1 (UPI) State narcotics agents arrested two California men here today and confiscated 137 vials of LSD in what the State Health Department said was the largest single confiscation of the hallucinogenic drug ever made in Pennsylvania.
THE deal shown in the diagram occurred in the recent world pair championship in Amsterdam, although one would not think so from the bidding.
New York City's department stores scored a substantial gain in business during June, as a result of hot weather and an additional late-opening Thursday night compared with last year.
WASHINGTON, July 1 Consumer installment credit rose by $493-million in May, seasonally adjusted, the smallest increase this year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

David Finn was yesterday elected chairman of the board of governors of the Jewish Museum, succeeding Mrs. Vera List, Mr. Finn, a trustee of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, which operates the museum, and chairman of Ruder Finn, a New York public relations agency, has been a museum governor since 1962.

ESSEX, Conn., July 1 Wolcott Phelps Robbins, a retired New York lawyer and a former secretary of the Manhattan Council of the Boy Scouts of America, died today after a long illness in his home on Trolley Lane. He was 90 years old.
LOS ANGELES, July 1 (AP) Mike Shannon hit a two-run homer off Sandy Koufax in the seventh inning tonight to give Al Jackson and the St. Louis Cardinals a 2-0 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.
Third Avenue has not only become chic in recent years, it's become big business for Manhattan's motion picture entrepreneurs.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., July 1 Miss Susan Townsend Opdyke, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Russell L. Opdyke, was married here tonight to Glenn Carl Waehner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph C. Waehner. The Rev. Dr. Harvey B. Hoffman performed the ceremony in the Greenville Community Reformed Church.
The official canvass of the primary election vote in the 19th Congressional District yesterday gave Representative Leonard Farbstein the Democratic nomination over City Councilman Theodore Weiss.

Mrs. Nancy Humpstone Gardiner and James Bronson Gardinet 2d, both of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cynthia Paulette Gardiner, to Ralph E. Giesey, son of Mrs. William C. Giesey of Detroit and the late Mr. Giesey.
VERONA, N.J., July 1 Arthur J. Young, treasurer of General Aniline Film Corporation, died at his home, 22 Woodland Avenue, today after a brief illness. He was 62 years old.
The Philco Corporation, the home appliances subsidiary of the Ford Motor Company, announced yesterday in Philadelphia the election of Robert E. Munz as vice president for industrial design.
ATHENS, July 1 (AP) Emanuel Loulakakis, a Minister without Portfolio in Premier Stephan Stephanopoulos's Cabinet, died early today after a long illness.

BABYLON, L.I., July 1 Announcement has been made by Mrs. John Harrison Tompkins of the engagement of her stepdaughter, Miss. Hope Tompkins, to Eben Whitman Ludlow, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alden Rodney Ludlow Jr. of Lawrence.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1 (AP) Bill White drove a homer into the left-field stands, singled in a run and scored two others tonight in leading the Philadelphia Phillies to a 7-0 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

The Pentagon's much-publicized but long-secret study of the draft laws, finally presented in outline form to the House Armed Services Committee, is a disappointing document. Its conclusions appear to be either statements of the obvious or far from convincing rebuttals to criticism of the present law.
DETROIT, July 1 (AP) Jim Gosger's two-run pinch-single capped a three-run fourth inning and sent the Kansas City Athletics to a 6-4 victory over Detroit tonight in the second game of a double-header.

The American Electric Power Company, in a surprise move yesterday, assigned to the Michigan Gas Utilities Company all of its rights in the stock of the Michigan Gas and Electric Company that had been tendered to American Electric under a tender offer of $100 a share.

John S. Grier, an account executive of Young Rubicam, Inc., the advertising and public relations agency, died yesterday in New York Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at 10 Dante Street, Larchmont, N.Y.

Stockholders of the Irving Trust Company approved at a special meeting yesterday formation of the Charter New York Corporation, a statewide bank holding company. Charter New York will acquire all the stock of Irving Trust and the Merchants National Bank and Trust Company of Syracuse.

IVY, Va., July 1 Miss Mary Scott Blake, daughter of Evernghim Blake and Mrs. Parker Blake of Charlottesville, was married this evening to John Holmes Birdsall 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Birdsall Jr. of Palm Beach, Fla.

JACKASS FLATS, Idaho, July 1 (AP) A dozen Kennedys and others in their party headed today into the rapids of Idaho's "river of no return." So far as Ethel Kennedy, wife of Senator Robert F. Kennedy, Democrat of New York, was concerned, the worst part was over the plane trip into the rugged wilderness area where the river voyage began this morning, down the middle fork of the Salmon River.
STOCKHOLM, July 1 (UPI) Sonny Liston, the former heavyweight champion, began a comeback campaign tonight by knocking out Gerhard Zech of Germany in the seventh round.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 1 (AP)--An around-the-clock "pray-in" was begun at a Roman Catholic cathedral in downtown Sacramento today to protest the reprimand of a priest for his activities in the Delano grape strike.

DUBLIN, July 1 (AP) Twenty-four horses, seven of them American-owned, will go to the post tomorrow for the fifth running of the Irish Sweeps Derby with the big question finding the one to beat England's Charlottown.
NOROTON, Conn., July 1 Peter Hansel of the Riverside Yacht Club today won the three-race single-handed sailing series that ended a week-long Finn symposium at the Noroton Yacht Club.
CLEVELAND, July 1 (AP) Sam McDowell, making his first start in two weeks, pitched a two-hitter tonight and struck out 13 as the Cleveland Indians defeated the California Angels, 5-0.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., July 1 The Episcopal Church of the Redeemer was the setting here today for the marriage of Miss Gail Lewis Roberts, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Roberts of Villanova, to Forrester Andrew Clark Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Clark of New York and South Hamilton, Mass.
WASHINGTON, July 1 Oblivion overtakes most men, even justices of the highest court of the land, but Louis D. Brandeis, most lawyers agree, has for a half-century stood the test of greatness.

LONDON, July 1 (Reuters) Ronald Shiner, a Cockney co median and film star who was once a Canadian Mountie, died yesterday in a hospital here. He was 63 years old.

SAIGON, July 1--Raises of 8 to 33 per cent will be granted to South Vietnamese employes of the huge American construction consortium engaged in work on most of the United States Government projects in the country, informed sources said tonight.

FREDERICK, Md., July 1 (AP) Pernetta Glenn scored a double in the dashes and Barbara Friedrich got off another record toss in the javelin tonight at the National Amateur Athletic Union women's and girls' outdoor track and field championships.

FAIRFIELD, Me., July 1 (UPI) On March 8, 1954, Carl Fisher came home from work and found his three children aged 6, 4 and 11 months had been drowned by his wife, Constance. She was unconscious nearby.
FRANKFORT, Ky., July 1 (UPI) The old South's only state civil rights act, in some respects stronger than the Federal Civil Rights Act of 1964, went into effect in Kentucky today.
The Bank of America, the nation's largest commercial bank, reported yesterday earnings, deposits and loans for the first half of the year increased from the comparable period a year ago.
Three major international conferences involving Jewish community leaders from all parts of the non-Communist world convene this week in Geneva and Brussels.
WASHINGTON, July 1 The New York Yankees, continuing to behave like candidates for Medicare, defeated the Washington Senators, 8-6, tonight, but it wasn't easy.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 1 Dr. Charles C. Thach, who retired in 1959 as an associate professor of government at New York University, died after a stroke today in Huntington Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived at 44 Brown's Road.

WASHINGTON, July 1--Gen. John P. McConnell, Air Force Chief of Staff, has warned Congress that the Tactical Air Command has been stretched to the limit of its present resources by the steadily increasing demands of the Vietnam war.

The North American Coal Corporation reported yesterday the signing of an agreement with at least six Eastern electric utilities that will assure completion of the $225-million Conemaugh mine mouth project in western Pennsylvania. It is understood that three additional utilities are members of the group.
CONCORD, N.H., July 1 Eldress Emma King, one of seven members of the Canterbury Shaker Colony near here, died at the community today. Her age was 93.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 1 (AP) The league-leading San Francisco Giants scored five runs in the eighth inning with the help of two errors by Woody Woodward, a wild pitch and a bases-loaded walk tonight and defeated Atlanta, 9-5.
SAIGON, July 1 The United States furnished South Vietnam with about $675-million worth of economic aid during the fiscal year that ended yesterday, American officials disclosed.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, July 1 Dr. Joaquin Balaguer took the oath as President today and pledged a regime of reform and austerity.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 1 Earl Laird, a handsome black gelding, is not so "sored up" as usual, so he will face 10 other horses tomorrow night at Roosevelt Raceway in the $50,000 American Trotting Championship.

MUIRFIELD, Scotland, July 1 (UPI) Bob Falkenburg of Los Angeles shot two birdies on the last three holes for a one-under-par 68 today and led the American contingent on the first qualifying round of the British Open golf championship.
The call by the Temporary Commission on City Finances for local taxes beyond those included in the Albany legislative package drew strong opposition yesterday from New York motorists.
WASHINGTON, July 1 A new plastic lens, pat ented this week by a New York engineer, eliminates both direct and reflected glare from lighting fixtures.

The union that represents the 240 lifeguards at Jones Beach has threatened to "effectively close down the beach" this weekend if about 25 former guards who are 35 years old and over have not been rehired by this afternoon.

WELLESLEY, Mass., July 1 Miss Susan Margaret Lee, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry R. Lee, was married this evening to Joseph Robert Gannon, son of Joseph Gannon of Brookline and the late Mrs. Elizabeth Blake Gannon. Msgr, John F. Harney performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church.
WASHINGTON, July 1 The Federal Home Loan Bank Board removed all restrictions today on interest rates that can be paid by savings and loan associations.
To many United States military men the tragedy of the bombing of the Haiphong and Hanoi oil installations was not that it was done but that it had been deferred for so long.

MIAMI BEACH, July 1 The National Education Association voted today to press for merger of separate white and Negro affiliates in 10 Southern states. But it is expected that most, if not all, of the states will meet a loosely defined "good faith" requirement.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., July 1 (UPI) Lee Roy Yarborough of Columbia, S.C., captured the pole position today for Monday's Firecracker 400 stock-car race at a record speed of 178,660 miles an hour.
The new city income tax will begin in the first week of September to cut into the paychecks of people employed here.

PAPEETE, Tahiti, July 1 For two years Papeete, a rambling South Pacific shack town of 25,000 people, has been bursting at the seams with preparations by the French for their first Pacific atomic explosion. The headquarters for the operation is here.
An unexpectedly light turnout of elderly patients surprised hospital administrators here yesterday, when Medicare went into effect.
Short-term interest rates continued to move upward yesterday, and bond prices continued to decline

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 1 Frank E. Beckley, former vice president of Cross, Austin and Ireland Lumber Company, 1245 Grand Street, Brooklyn, died yesterday at Mountainside Hospital here. He was 84 years old and lived at 89 Clinton Avenue.

With only one dissenting vote, more than 200 members of the Doctors Association ended yesterday the first medical walkout in the city's history. They decided to return to work in the city's 232 health centers, stations and clinics "as soon as possible."
The wholesale price index fell to 111.4 on Thursday from 111.6 on Wednesday.
EVERY Saturday morning Lewis Winter leaves his pre-Civil War house on West 20th Street and returns to the neighborhood where he had lived with his family until four months ago.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 1 (AP) Ground-breaking ceremonies were held today for an $11-million stadium, ending speculation about the proposed home for professional basketball and hockey teams.

Hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers, grown fretful by a week of heat and discomfort, scrambled out of the city yesterday for a Fourth of July weekend of diversion.

SYDNEY, Australia, July 1 Secretary of State Dean Rusk rejected today a suggestion that United States attacks on fuel installations at Hanoi and Haiphong in North Vietnam were designed to bring on a war with Communist China.
The National Council of Churches urged President Johnson yesterday not to pursue a policy of military intensification in Vietnam.

MADRID, July 1 In a major pastoral pronouncement on the application of the Ecumenical Council's directives, the Roman Catholic hierarchy of Spain has warned that it would be forced to "reject beforehand" a system of "oppressive arbitrariness" as much as a system based on "atheism or religious agnosticism."
A Queens bank employe who was "arrested" last October as a smuggler of gold bullion was revealed yesterday to have been a volunteer Government informant.
BRUSSELS, July 1 A fourday meeting of the Common Market's agriculture ministers ended here today in a desultory fashion.

The New York Times survey on business's social responsibility asked executives if they believed business was understood by professors and students and what they were doing to improve relations with the academic world.

MANY fine annuals can be used as edging plants. To qualify, they must be lowgrowing and bushy. A number range in height from only two or three inches to 10 or 12 inches. Many tend to grow much wider than tall.

DES MOINES, Iowa, July 2 (UPI)--A radio newsman and former official of the United States Information Service was arrested last night by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents and charged with bank robbery.

WASHINGTON, July 2--A senior legal expert at the Defense Department indicated today that members of the armed forces who refused to fight in Vietnam might be prosecuted under existing laws and regulations and, in extreme cases, might be sentenced to death.

WASHINGTON, July 2--The United States expressed regret today that France had resumed nuclear testing.

CASTRIES, St. Lucia, B.W.I.--Since the founding of America, the migration there has been westward. Even as late as the immediate post-World War II years, the old slogan, "Go west, young man," was heeded by thousands headed for California.

Mining men in southeastern Utah, in nearby Grand Junction, Colo., and in the Gas Hills district of Wyoming are once again prospecting for likely uranium claims, improving mill and ore-haulage facilities--and even talking of a uranium boom.

IN all the Rockies there is no region quite so Western as the high, golden land of Wyoming, where the latchstring is out at every lonely ranch and never is heard a discouraging word. Cowboys are as native to Wyoming as lobsters are to Maine. In an age of jeeps and pick-ups, the place still smells delightfully of sage and little dogies and saddles on a hot summer day.
