LONDON, July 4--The Rev. Billy Graham said today that the moral climate in Britain was better than he thought a month ago when he opened his Greater London Crusade.
Steel shares were firm on the London Stock Exchange yesterday following the disclosure on Friday of the terms of the Government's steel renationalization program.

The most important job facing the State Legislature as it winds up its session today is the passage of a workable law to prevent strikes by public employes. If the legislators leave Albany without adopting a substitute for the virtually useless Condon-Wadlin Act, their default will be an open invitation to stoppages in vital community services and to endless exactions from the public treasury to satisfy the demands of civil service unions.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 4 (UPI) President Johnson ordered today creation of a special task force to propose improvements in Federal activities to assist children with physical handicaps.

After the most careful thought and study the Transit Authority is regretfully forced to announce that the fare on the subways and buses of the New York City Transit System will be raised by 5 cents starting at 12:01 A.M. on July 5, 1966.
AUCKLAND, N.Z., July 4 A DC-8 airliner of Air New Zealand crashed while taking off on a training flight at the Auckland airport today. Two of the five crewmen were killed.

WILMINGTON, Del., July 4 (UPI) Paul Leahy, senior judge of the United States District Court, died last night in Wilmington General Hospital. He was 62 years old.
OCEANSIDE, Calif., July 4 (AP) The grandson of Sgt. Alvin York has broken family tradition by joining the Marines.

CHICAGO, July 4--Raymond M. Hilliard, nationally prominent welfare administrator, who had been Cook County Public Aid Administrator for 12 years, and formerly was New York's Welfare Commissioner, died today of a heart attack. He was 58 years old.

"The Right to Bear Arms," by Carl Bakal, which McGrawHill will issue on July 25, explores this country's heritage of arms and tradition of violence. The author contends that a lobby in Washington bears a degree of responsibility for 17,000 fatal shootings in the United States each year. He offers statistics showing that this country has a firearms homicide rate 5 to 50 times as much as that of countries with strict firearms controls.
SETE, France, July 4 (Reuters) Georges Vandenberghe of Belgium swept ahead of the world's best cyclists today to win the 13th stage of the Tour de France and cause another upset in this year's race.

BUFFALO, July 4 Edward Padula, producer of the Broadway-bound musical "A Joyful Noise" and several members of his company were injured in an automobile accident yesterday morning. The small private open-top bus they were riding in overturned after a collision ...

The United States, in the midst of a prolonged economic boom now in its 65th month, registered a much lower rate of depreciation of money last year than the other major industrial nations of the world.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 4 (UPI) Gaylord Perry scored his 12th victory of the season against only one loss by pitching the San Francisco Giants to a 3-2 dictory over St. Louis today after the Cardinals had defeated Juan Marichal, 6-2, in the opening game.
CHICAGO, July 4 (UPI) A prominent Ohio lawyer and his wife died today when a fire swept the suburban Lake Forest, Ill., home of their daughter and son-in-law.
PARIS, July 4 France added nearly $100-million to her reserves of gold and foreign exchange last month. It was the largest advance this year and extended a strong growth trend begun in March.
An expelled official of the Communist Party, U.S.A., has won a party admission that "police agent" charges against him have not been proved. His appeal for reinstatement is pending.
HOUSTON, July 4 (UPI) Joe Torre paced Atlanta's attack tonight as the Braves defeated the Houston Astros, 3-2, on a four-hitter by Ken Johnson.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 4 Robert V. Fingerhut, director of advertising and information of the Western Electric Company, died this afternoon while playing golf at the Essex Fells Country Club. He was 54 years old and lived here at 125 Gates Avenue.
BUDAPEST, July 4 (UPI) The Hungarian newspaper Magyar Nemzet has accused John Michael Montias, a Yale University professor, of spying for the Central Intelligence Agency.

The price of copper has been soaring so high that many producers fear that the present boom will be followed by a bust. So, evidently, does the Johnson Administration, which has given its blessing to a proposed United Nations conference aimed at stabilizing the production and price of copper.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., July 4 J. Edwin Dowling, vice president and associate general counsel of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, died last night in Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville. He was 63 years old and lived at 18 Barry Road here.
The measure I sign today, S. 1160, revises Section 3 of the Administrative Procedure Act to provide guidelines for the public availability of the records of Federal departments and agencies.

Bowing to grim necessity political, legal and fiscal New York City has increased the transit fare. While other cities long ago went to twenty cents and even a quarter, New York's fifteen-cent ride by subway or bus became the greatest travel bargain in the nation. The city broke with the nickel fare in 1948; the dime fare sufficed for only five years thereafter.
A funeral service for Deems Taylor, the composer, critic and writer, will be held at 1 P.M. tomorrow at Frank E. Campbell's Funeral Chapel, Madison Avenue and 81st Street.

GANGTOK, Sikkim, July 2 Behind the Himalayan mountain barrier, China has consolidated control over Tibet to the point where only the overthrow of the Peking regime is likely to restore autonomy to Lhasa.
TORONTO, July 4 (Canadian Press)--A new gimmick is being used on Bay street, heart of Toronto's financial district, in an apparent effort to run up the price of a speculative mining stock.

EASTON, Pa., July 4 Hazel Stanton, telegraph editor of The New York Journal of Commerce, died yesterday in Easton Hospital. She was 70 years old.

CHICAGO, July 4 B. Stuart Weyforth Jr., an insurance executive and president of the board of Goodwill Industries, died yesterday in the Presbyterian-St. Luke's Hospitall. He was 51 years old.

VENICE, July 4 (UPI)--Guards had to be placed at a creation in the Venice Biennale art show today because it tended to stab the overly curious viewer.

One subway rider blamed Mayor Lindsay yesterday for the 5-cent increase in the transit fare. Another said it was all the fault of former Mayor Robert F. Wagner. But almost all agreed with an elderly man who said the increase would be a burden.

CORDELE, Ga., July 4 (AP) A racially mixed crowd of more than 100 persons arrived by motorcade today to use facilities at a nearby state park where whites and Negroes fought eight days ago.

CYNWYD, Pa., July 4 The Atlanta team of Bryan (Bitsy) Grant and Larry Shippey won the national senior clay-court tennis doubles championship today for the second straight year and the sixth time since 1960. SALEM, Ind., July 4 (UPI) Roger McCluskey of Tucson, Ariz., won the feature United States Auto Club Race today at the Salem Speedway.

ALBANY, July 4--Before the Legislature adjourns this week, it is expected to pass a bill raising legislators' annual salaries from $10,000 to $15,000. The raise would take effect with the 1967 session.
WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP) The National Endowment for the Arts announced tonight grants totaling $2-million in direct assistance to the states and territories.

LONDON, July 4 The pound came under pressure again today as the Treasury announced that a sizable loss in gold and dollar reserves occurred last month, when British merchant seamen were on strike.
The Franklin National Bank reported yesterday gains for the first half of 1966 in earnings, deposits and resources.
WASHINGTON, July 4 A searching effort to rethink and, eventually, to reshape the strategy of United States assistance to Africa has concluded its first phase here.

The youngest horse in the field, the 3-year-old Buffle of the King Ranch, and the oldest trainer in the race, 85-year-old Max Hirsch, proved the winning combination in the $110,900 Suburban Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday.

HANAE MORI, Japan's best-known designer, shows three versions of pants in her current collection, dis played during her recent visit here, but she hasn't yet gathered enough courage to show them in her own country. "Maybe I will after this, but it is America that is the pants country," she said as she showed her suggestions for fall and winter at-home, evening and resort wear, borrowed from a variety of Eastern cultures and costumes.

The National Foreign Trade Council, a nonprofit group with more than 600 corporate members, announced yesterday it had lowered its estimate of this year's United States export surplus by more than a billion dollars.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. July 4 (AP) Sam McQuagg completed a climb from rookie to the top of the class in one year when he drove a 1966 Dodge Charger to victory today in the Firecracker 400 over a field of the best stock car drivers in America.

The former United Parcel Service building occupying the west blockfront of First Avenue between 38th and 39th Streets has been completely leased with the renting of the ninth floor to the Green White Construction Company.
GREENWICH, Conn., July 4 Thomas Hume won his second Shields Class race in two days today, scoring with Pantomime during the Indian Harbor Yacht Club regatta.

THE game wardens of Pennsylvania operated more than fishing schools last year. During the instruction they tabulated 8,129 answers to questions on 1,300 questionnaires in learning what people like to do with fishing rods.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., July 4 (A.P.) Richard Buchan of Henderson, N.C., defeated Ricky Smith of Indianapolis in an 18hole playoff today to win the Professional Putters Association's $10,000 national championship tournament.
DETROIT, July 4 (AP) Production of 1966-model automobiles headed into the final weeks today.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 4 (AP) President Johnson signed a bank holding company bill today that requires the multimillion-dollar Alfred I. du Pont estate in Florida to be split up within five years.

HAMBURGERS for a picnic, a barbecue or family meal need not be dull. Using a ground chuck of good quality (or ground round if a dry style of hamburger is preferred) is important for obtaining good taste. There are also several usual and unusual additions that can be made to the meat, and a variety of sauces makes possible other flavor variations.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 4 Richard A. Kaseler, who won the opening race on Saturday, placed fourth and second with Panatella today to win the annual Independence Day regatta of the Yacht Racing Association 110 Class, run by the Echo Bay Yacht Club on Long Island Sound.
PEKING, July 4 New political figures appear to be rising in the wake of the purge of leaders of the Communist party's Peking branch and other organizations.

COLORADO SPRINGS, July 4 (AP) Bobby Unser of Albuquerque, N.M., won the championship division of the Pikes Peak auto race today in the record time of 12 minutes 23.8 seconds for the twisting, 12-mile course.

DETROIT, July 4 (AP) Jose Cardenal and Jim Fregosi hit home runs in a five-run eighth inning tonight and led the California Angels to an 11-6 victory over the Detroit Tigers. Cardenal hit a three-run homer and Fregosi a two-run blast.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 4 A memorial to President Kennedy was dedicated in an informal atmosphere this morning atop a barren but historic hill outside Jerusalem.

LOS ANGELES July 4 (AP) John Roseboro's tie-breaking single in the sixth inning helped Don Sutton, a rookie, gain his first victory since June 2 as the Los Angeles Dodgers defeated the Cincinnati Reds, 2-1, today. The defeat was the sixth straight for Cincinnati.
The New York Securities Company announced over the weekend the election of Franklin A. Steele as a general partner in the New York Stock Exchange member firm.

The Great Northern Paper Company, a producer of newsprint, groundwood printing papers and kraft linerboard, is entering the field of softwood plywood manufacturing in the South, it was announced yesterday by Robert A. Haak, president.

LOS ANGELES, July 4 Gov. Richard J. Hughes of New Jersey, who is here to attend the National Governor's Conference, praised California's administration and said he would try to accomplish in his own state some of the things California has done.
MOSCOW, July 4 (AP) They Soviet Union announced today that tests of carrier rockets "to develop new space systems" had been successfully completed.

MUIRFIELD, Scotland, July 4 (AP) Two teen-agers took on the professional giants of the golf world Jack Nicklaus and Gary Player in practice for the British Open golf championship today and did very well.

President Johnson's appointment of a civilian commission to examine the working of the draft system appears to reflect his dissatisfaction with the study produced by the Pentagon. That study concluded that the draft is working effectively and did not need to be changed, but the new commission has been given a mandate to judge its fairness and to come up with meaningful reforms.
STANTON, Del., July 4 (AP) Great White Way, owned by Ogden Phipps and trained by Eddie Neloy, ran away from 11 other 2-year-olds today in Delaware Park's $25,250 Dover Stakes.
SUFFERN, N.Y., July 4 (AP) Six demonstrators protesting against virtually allwhite volunteer fire companies chained themselves together today and lay down in the road to halt a firemen's parade.
For some New Yorkers over the week-end, a trip to the "beach" was no more than an elevator ride.

The conventional Broadway premiere will undergo a drastic change if Alexander H. Cohen's experiment proves successful. The producer said yesterday he would give one or two weeks of performances during which newspaper, television and radio ...
Colby Stilson, a partner in Breed, Abbott Morgan, lawyers of 1 Chase Manhattan Plaza, died of a heart attack Sunday in his home, 580 Park Avenue. His age was 62.
WASHINGTON, July 4 If Detroit has job vacancies and Appalachia has job hunters, how do you bring the two together?
Accelerated programs to solve the critical shortage of automobile service mechanics are being sponsored by two major car companies and a tire manufacturer.

UNIONVILLE, Pa., July 4 The engagement of Miss Cristy West to Charles P. Noyes 3d has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. John C. West, parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Charles P. Noyes of Syosset, L.I., and the late Mrs. Noyes.

Capitol Records, Inc., has provided Hillard Elkins, Broadway producer, with $250,000 for the development of musical stage properties. In return, the record company will receive first refusal to the original album rights for three shows.

Nonfarm employment rose by 25,000 to 6,164,000, in the New York-Northeast New Jersey metropolitan area in May, the highest total for the month on record, the United States Labor Department reported yesterday.

LIME ROCK, Conn., July 4 Ed Lowther of McMurray, Pa., thrilled a crowd of 15,000 here today with an all-the-way victory in the feature race of a northeastern division national championship sports car meeting.

COLUMBUS, Ga., July 4 (AP) Republican Representative Howard H. Callaway told a cheering crowd in the Columbus fairgrounds tonight that he would carry the party's banner into the Governor's race on a states' rights theme in the November general election.
PAINTERS and sculptors are shaping furnishings that may lead to a drastic change in furniture design.
MOSCOW, July 2 A visitor returning to Moscow after a year's absence finds much that is the same and much that is subtly changing.

A quarterly magazine, The Long Island Office Space Selector, has been started by The Long Island Commercial Review, a regional business publication issued from offices at 3 Fairchild Court, Plainview, L.I. The new quarterly contains data on a total of 2,265,000 sqare feet ...
GOSHEN, N.Y., July 4 The F.O.F. Farm's Ember Hanover won the $15,542.25 Debutante Stake No. 20 for 2year-old pacing fillies at 128year-old Historic track today in straight heats.
For most of the 62 years that New York City has had subways, elevated lines, trolleys and buses, the lines have fought a losing battle for solvency.

NONGKHAI, Thailand, July 4 Across the green grass of a soccer field next to the town hall, husky young men in white shirts and Uniited States Army fatigue trousers marched earnestly back and forth, trying to keep in step.

PHILADELPHIA, Tuesday, July 5 The New York Mets, who never do things the easy way, took all of last night and a portion of this morning to sweep a double-header from the Phillies, 9-6 and 8-1. The holiday twilight-night twin bill began at 6 o'clock last night and ended at 1:44 A.M. today ...

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 4--Nearly three and a half months of political crisis that halted in late June have worked subtle but important changes in the character of South Vietnam's ruling military junta.

The nation's largest mutual savings bank, the Bowery Savings Bank, followed last night the recent path of many smaller savings banks by announcing that it was raising its interest rates to 5 per cent.

TOKYO, Tuesday, July 5, (AP) North Vietnam, apparently caught in the middle of the Peking-Moscow dispute, hinted today it would not seek major outside help following the United States air raids on oil depots in the Hanoi-Haiphong area.

Sweden's French-bred Pluvier III, the surprise winner of last year's $100,000 Roosevelt International Trot at Roosevelt Raceway, will start from the coveted No. 1 slot in the eighth edition of-the blue-ribbon event at the Westbury, L.I., half-mile course on, Saturday night. Last year Pluvier III had the No. 8 post.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 5 The powerful Hoa Hao sect conducted colorful annual rites today in memory of its founder, the prophet Huynh Phu So, who was murdered by Vietnamese Communists two decades ago.
The nation's heaviest satellite was launched into orbit yesterday in a critical test of man's capability to fly to the moon.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation's National Academy, which trains local acid state police officers, will be greatly expanded in 1969, Joseph J. Casper, an assistant director of the F.B.I., told academy graduates yesterday.
BALTIMORE, July 5 (AP) Ritter's Tavern, the scene of demonstrations by the Congress of Racial Equality, dropped a Negroes-only policy today and admitted white persons, too.

MADRID, July 5--A sudden influx of French tourists, ferrying their cars over from Morocco, has been delayed in Gibraltar by Spanish border restrictions that prevent the normal flow of traffic into Spain.

WASHINGTON, July 5 Two small banks at State College, Pa., have called off their planned merger following the filing of an antitrust suit against it. In announcing the cancellation of the merger plans, Controller of the Currency James J. Saxon attacked the suit as "a new low in antitrust enforcement."

ALBANY, July 5 The State Senate gave final legislative approval today to changes in the controversial Medicaid law. The action followed an angry debate in which a Democratic Senator charged that the state had been "blackmailed" by medical societies.
Vast quantities of garbage lay rotting on the city's beaches yesterday in the wake of the hot holiday weekend, confronting the Department of Parks with a situation it called "very serious."

SCARSDALE, N. Y., July 5--Mr. and Mrs. William F. Cullom have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Carroll Cullom, to Robert Powell Burwell. He is the son of Mrs. John Armistead Burwell of Middleburg, Va., and the late Mr. Burwell.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange eased slightly yesterday in light trading.

GREENWICH VILLAGE has long needed a hand- some, imaginative and comprehensively stocked cheese store. And what Greenwich Village needs, it gets. Cheese Village, Ltd., opened several weeks ago at 3 Greenwich Avenue.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 5 Robert L. Buell, retired United States Foreign Service officer, died today in his sleep at the home of his brother, the Rev. William Buell, the former headmaster of St. George's School, here. He was 68 years old and lived in the Georgetown section of Washington.
MIAMI, July 5 (AP) A Greek freighter bound for Vietnam with 9,500 tons of flour radioed for help from the Yucatan Channel today and all but the captain abandoned ship.
THERE are serpents with forked tongues and fiery eyes crawling over the walls and floor at Altman's these days. But no one is worried.

WASHINGTON, July 5 Political pressure crushed James Farmer's proposed project to combat illiteracy with an $860,000 antipoverty grant. Sargent Shriver, director of the Office of Economic Opportunity, was on the verge of signing the grant more than six months ago, but outside forces deterred...

DETROIT, July 5 (UPI) Two high police officials resigned today but denied their departure was linked with a grand jury investigation in which 18 policemen, a sheriff and a deputy sheriff had been indicted.
WASHINGTON, July 5 (UPI) The food and drug administration showed in a motion picture today laboratory dogs in frenzied death throes after heavy dosage with a tranquilizer drug used by many Americans.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 5 President Tito rejected today the suggestion of some Western commentators that the ouster of Vice President Aleksandar Rankovic would open Yugoslavia to the influence of Western liberal ideas.
Karl F. Scheidt, president and chairman of the board of the K.S. Canning Company in Bridgeport, Pa., died at his home in Gladwyn, Pa., yesterday. He was 70 years old.
Many city youngsters, who consider summer happiness a broom handle for stick ball and a fire hydrant for showers, were given some shiny new play equipment yesterday by the Police Athletic League.

New York City District Attorneys will be asked to make a full inquiry aimed at halting an increase in car thefts from public parking lots and garages, Commissioner of Licenses Joel J. Tyler said yesterday.
JOHNSON CITY, Tex., July 5 President Johnson said to- day that he was disappointed with the criticisms by a few allies of the United States air strikes against fuel dumps near Hanoi and Haiphong.
ALBANY, July 5 Everyone knew when the sun came up this morning that today was going to be the last day of the 1966 State Legislature even if it took all week.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) An Army board has reported it found "no evidence of malpractice or negligence" by Army hospital authorities in the death of Pvt. Donald Dilworth Jr. at Fort Dix, N.J., last April 11.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 5 (UPI)--Al Jackson yielded only two singles to the San Francisco Giants and dropped the league leaders to their fourth loss in the last five games today while pitching the St. Louis Cardinals to a 3-1 victory. The Giant run was unearned.
Lillian Smith, the author, quit the advisory committee of the Congress of Racial Equality yesterday, charging that "nihilists" and "old-fashioned haters" had taken over the organization.
The spot rate on the British pound declined sharply in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 5 Peking's carefully worded reaction to the bombings at Hanoi and Haiphong has reinforced the Administration's calculation that China will not directly intervene in the war at this stage.

FROM its Presidential appointment one week after the assassination of Presi dent John F. Kennedy in Dallas to the completion of a report of its findings 10 months later, the Warren Commission (formally, the President's Commission on the Assassination of President John F. Kennedy, headed by Chief Justice of the United States, Earl Warren) had
Mrs. Frances Bruhier's eyes still fill with tears when she recalls her months of wandering among city agencies six years ago in search of help for herself and her infant son.
HOUSTON. July 5 (AP) Baylor University College of Medicine is starting a threeyear study on a syphilis vaccine, it was announced today.
ALBANY, Wednesday, July 6 The Legislature gave final approval early this morning to a bill that would permit the construction in New York City of schools with apartments or offices above them.
AACHEN, West Germany, July 5 (AP) Nelson Pessoa of Brazil and Dr. Hugo Arrambide of Argentina won qualification jumpoffs today in the International Grand Prix competition at the Aachen horse show.

JOHNSON CITY, Tex., July 5 (AP) President Johnson said today his rating in nationwide public opinion polls was about 55 per cent "and that was a landslide when General Eisenhower defeated Mr. Adlai Stevenson."
OCEANPORT, N.J., July 5 (UPI)--Put-in-Bay, a 17-1 shot, won the $5,500 feature race at Monmouth Park today by 1 lengths.

OMAHA, Neb., July 5 (AP) Gov. Frank B. Morrison flew into Omaha tonight from the Governor's Conference in Los Angeles to lend a hand in stemming racial disturbances that have shaken the city the last three nights.
New-car sales in June presented a mixed picture, according to reports received yesterday from Detroit.
School opened yesterday for "Up the Down Staircase."

BONN, July 5 France asked West Germany today to clarify the functions of the proposed special representative who is to represent Bonn in dealings with Gen. Jacques Massu, commander in chief of French forces in West Germany.
MONTPELIER, Vt., July 5 (UPI) The Board of State Library Trustees voted by 4 to 1 tonight to retain the names of Niggerhead Pond and Niggerhead Mountain in Groton State Forest.

It was late afternoon of the Fourth of July. The streets of Manhattan, turning soft in the 98-degree heat, were nearly deserted. In his air-conditioned suite at the Plaza. Hotel, a cool Darryl F. Zanuck, wearing a blue kimono and slippers, paced back and forth, stopping occasionally to relight a cigar the size of an eight-inch firecracker.

CRANFORD, N.J., July 5 Jacob L. Klingaman of 36 Denman Road, a retired New York lawyer and a former vice President of the Customs Bar Association in New York, died last night at a nursing home in Plainfield. He was 88 years old.
LONDON, July 5 Closer Government supervision of the insurance business is being called for after the failure of a three-year-old company that wrote auto insurance at bargain premiums.

Bolivia went through the motions of a presidential election and has chosen the man who prepared the post for himself and who had only token opposition. President-elect Lieut. Gen. Rene Barrientos faces a typically difficult period in his unhappy country, as the violence accompanying his election indicated.

The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, the nation's biggest food chain, continued its recovery in sales and earnings in the first fiscal quarter, ended May 28. The company had shown a decline in sales and earnings in the fiscal years of 1965 and 1964.

The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. received a check for $100,000 yesterday from the people of Sweden for the work he is doing with the Southern Christian Leadership Council. It is the largest single contribution ever given to the civil rights organization.
The city's Health Services Administrator, Dr. Howard J. Brown, said yesterday that a major municipal hospital might have to be closed because of shortages of staff and equipment.
Ametek, Inc., a precision instruments and controls manufacturer, announced here yesterday the election of Robert L. Noland as executive vice president.
LOS ANGELES, July 5--Following are excerpts from Roy Wilkins's speech to the 57th annual convention of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People here today:

GENEVA, Duly 5 Britain and Canada appealed today at the 17-nation disarmament conference for an end to speech-making and a start on practical negotiations on the projected treaty to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons.
The rise in the New York City transit fare, which became effective yesterday, clashed head-on with one of the local stores' most important promotional days, theh post-July 4 clearances.
ALBANY, July 5 An attempt by three Reform Democrats to introduce a resolution calling for an investigation of the Surrogates' Courts got lost, in the Legislature's adjournment shuffle today.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., July 5 William J. Garrity, a paper manufacturer and a consultant to the paper industry since his retirement last year, died yesterday of a heart ailment at Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville. He was 67 years old and lived at 120 Hartsdale Avenue East, here.
OTTAWA, July 5 A dispute is developing between the United States and Canada over proposals to raise tolls on the St. Lawrence Seaway and to levy lockage fees on the Welland Canal.
Members of the Newspaper Guild of New York last night ratified a one-year contract with The World Journal Tribune, thus ending the strike that has prevented the new enter- prise from publishing.

Following are excerpts from Mayor Lindsay's news conference yesterday on the transit fare increase and the text of a memorandum from Daniel T. Scannell, a member of the Transit Authority, to City Council President Frank D. O'Connors.

The Board of Estimate yesterday deferred for at least two weeks a 5-cent increase in the fare on the bus lines operated by the Transit Authority's subsidiary, the Manhattan and Bronx Surface Transit Operating Authority.

All 232 of the city's health centers, stations and clinics were fully staffed yesterday as physicians, dentists and other medical aides returned to work after a walkout that began June 25 over a wage dispute.
Steel production fell 2.8 per cent last week, the American Iron aad Steel Institute reported yesterday.

ST. PAUL, July 5 Mr. and Mrs. Paul Eugene Villaume have made known the engagement of Mrs. Villaume's daughter, Miss Mary Catherine Angell, to Robert Goodman Murphy. He is the son of Mrs. Joseph E. Murphy of Brooklyn, New York, and the late Mr. Murphy.

VERONA, N.J., July 5 Maurice Readey, a civil engineer and former vice president of the E.F. Keating Pipe Bending Company of New York, died yesterday in the Veterans Hospital, East Orange. He was 78 years old and lived at 41 Mount Prospect Avenue here.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., July 5 The International Brotherhood of Teamsters convention today gave a roaring vote of confidence to James R. Hoffa's administration of the union and prepared to approve the paying of all legal expenses of his battles with the Government.
TRENTON, July 5 James Farmer, former national director of the Congress of Racial Equality, has been hired as special consultant on adult illiteracy, for New Jersey's antipoverty program.

A charge by the Department of Agriculture, made in Washington on Monday, that grain trading on the Chicago Board of Trade has been marked by illegal price fixing had little, if any, effect on trading there yesterday.
IN his heyday President Sukarno told an enthralled crowd in Jakarta that the only epitaph he desired was that of "Bung [brother] Karno, tongue of the Indonesian people."
JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 5 The People's Consultative Congress today stripped President Sukarno of his title of President for Life.

MAMARONECK, N.J., July 5 Mrs. Donna Floyd Fales of New York, the defending champion back from Wimbledon, and the five other seeded players advanced to the third round as the Eastern women's clay-court tennis championship opened today at the Orienta Beach Club. All had drawn first-round byes.
WASHINGTON, July 5--A United States military commander fresh from South Vietnam charged today that the Vietcong were continuing to take refuge in Cambodia to escape pursuit.
OAKDALE, L.I., July 5 A makeshift cross was discovered burning here last night on the front lawn of a private home that had been the setting for a racially integrated holiday party.

DETROIT, July 5 A consumer who faces the confusing array of automobile tires now on the American market may get the one best suited for his purposes, but many observers think his chances are less than even.

BUENOS AIRES, July 5 (Reuters) Argentina's new President, Lieut. Gen. Juan Carlos Ongania, appointed Nicanor Costa Mendez, a conservative lawyer and former Ambassador to Chile, as his Foreign Minister today.
Despite the grueling pace of his official routine at City Hall, Mayor Lindsay is managing to exercise regularly and keep physically fit, he said yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, July 5 Roy Wilkins, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, denounced the concept of black power tonight... as black racism that could only lead Negroes to a "black death."
PARIS, July 5 (Reuters) The boards of Pechiney and Trefimetaux plan to study ways to merge the two French metal companies.

Robert B. Karoff, founder and head of Karoff Originals Ltd., 57 East 11th St., a wellknown designer of hinged and folding furniture and novelties, died yesterday at Doctors Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at 146 Central Park West.

The members of the Curtis Cup team, which will meet a British squad of women amateur golfers in Hot Springs, Va., July 29 and 30, were announced by the United States Golf Association yesterday. Each has played at least one international match.
A new six-day-a-week newspaper will be published in Suffolk County this fall by Cowles Communications, Inc., it was announced yesterday by Gardner Cowles, chairman.

LOS ANGELES, July 5 (UPI) Ralph Nader, the critic of unsafe automobiles, denounced the National Safety Council today as a "mother hen" that is dominated by the automobile industry. He said the council has failed to campaign for basic changes in auto safety.

SEOUL, South Korea, July 5 The South Korea Foreign Minister, Lee Tong Won, declared today that unless the United States recognize South Korea's primary right to try United States servicemen for off-duty crimes, he would refuse to sign any status-offorces agreement.
Charles E. Keegan, a former City Alderman and Councilman, died of cancer Monday is Parkchester General Hospital, the Bronx. He was 73 years old and lived at 1469 West Avenue, the Bronx.
Ben S. Gilmer, executive vice president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, was elected yesterday to the board of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company.
Long lines stretched in front of many of the 835 change booths operated by the Transit Authority as the city adjusted to the new 20-cent fare yesterday.

Because the yachts in the Bermuda-to-Denmark race have not been supplying position reports, the United States Coast Guard discontinued announcements yesterday of the plotted progress of the 3,500-mile race.

Mr. and Mrs. Carl J. Schmid of New York, Fishers Island, N.Y., and Delray Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elaine Margaret Schmid, to Philip Edward Boylen. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. M. James Boylen of Toronto and New York.
CHICAGO, July 5 (AP) Thunderstorms rolled over the Midwest today as funnel clouds were seen in widely separated areas and high wind blew from the Dakotas to Tennessee.

ATHENS, Ga., July 5 (AP) A police officer testified today that one of six Ku Klux Klansmen charged with conspiracy clubbed an elderly Negro with a pistol during a demonstration at a drive-in restaurant.
MANILA, July 5 (AP) An airport crowd booed, jeered and shouted "Go to hell Beatles" today as the British rock 'n' roll quartet left the Philippines.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., July 5 (AP) Former President Harry S. Truman announced today that on the advice of his physician he would not attend the dedication of the Truman Center for the Advancement of Peace at Hebrew University in Jerusalem on July 11.
John J. Butler, president of Chateau Martin Wines, Inc., died on Monday at the Hospital for Joint Diseases. He was 61 years old and lived at 200 Forest Drive, Hillsdale, N.J.

Harry the Wig had a vision of sorts, one that curled the hair of most other standardbred horse owners, but will come to some degree of reality Saturday night during the post parade for Roosevelt Raceway's $100,000 International Trot. The owners just weren't ready for hair-pieces for horses.

KYOTO, Japan, July 5 While Japanese leftists demonstrated noisily today against United States actions in Vietnam, Secretary of State Dean Rusk appealed for Japan's backing in Southeast Asian policy. He sought this on a basis of national self-interest and not as a question of supporting an ally in trouble.
George Whitmore Jr. won a point in court yesterday in a move to gain freedom on bail.
Stock prices backed and filled yesterday as the market traced a lethargic course in the wake of the three-day Independence Day holiday weekend.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 5 Marshal Artur Costa e Silva, the Government's Presidential candidate, said today that Brazilians who agitated for elections by popular vote "just want to put the Communists back in power."

If this morning's newspapers had reported that 577 American lives, a new record, had been lost in Vietnam over the three-day July Fourth weekend, the nation would be shocked and reaction would be immediate from hawks and doves alike.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 5 Dr. Alto Edmund Feller, associate dean of medicine at the University of Virginia and a distinguished microbiologist, died yesterday while vacationing in North Carolina. He was 56 years old.

VALS-LES-BAINS, France, July 5 (Reuters) The French favorite, Raymond Poulidor, won the second half of the 14th stage of the Tour de France bicycle race today, improving his position as expected in the 20-kilometer (12 -mile) time trial.
Tight money and increased taxes are taking a toll of bank earnings in New York City.

The brook runs quietly now. Grass is thick on the banks above slow-moving water. Clumps of alders and willows shade peaceful pools. One can barely discern the current on a quiet, sun-lit day while bobolinks dart back and forth above the green fields.
Julie Harris has been signed to star in Guy Bolton's "Anastasia" on the National Broadcasting Company's "Hallmark Hall of Fame" series next season.

SINGAPORE, July 5 Britain's defense minister, Denis Healey, arrived today for talks with leaders of Singapore and Malaysia that will lead to a decision by Britain on the future size and deployment of her forces in the region east of Suez.

BERLIN, July 5 (AP) A former concentration camp doctor has been sentenced to life in prison by an East German court for conducting medical experiments on inmates, a West Berlin intelligence agency reported today.

The city's summer antipoverty program got off to a confused start yesterday, with the central office jammed with representatives of local groups who had not yet received their contracts, or in some cases, definate approval for the projects they are to run.
GENEVA, July 5 Secretary General Thant of the United Nationas chided the industrialized countries today for failing to expand aid to poorer lands.
DUBLIN, July 5 (UPI) Jim Osborne of Salt Lake City was busted from the Irish tennis championship today, bowing by 7-5, 6-4 to Dave Hickey of Ireland.

LONDON, July 5 British European Airways, already hobbled by flight cancellations and delays because of a faulty system of supplying spare parts, now apparently is facing a revolt of its senior pilots. The issue is the state-owned corporation's management.

Premier Pompidou's visit to London is potentially of far greater importance than President de Gaulle's highly advertised talks last week in Russia. Paris cannot influence Moscow much. But France could turn the key for British entrance into the Common Market, a move that could transform Europe, the Atlantic alliance, East-West relations and the future of the underdeveloped world.

CLEARWATER Fla., July 5 (AP) Women pilots in the 20th annual transcontinental Powder Puff Derby were set back a second time by bad weather today in their race from Seattle to Clearwater.

THE Trans-American sedan championship race at Bry- at Park, Loudon, N.H., on Sunday, has been lengthened to 250 miles. Entries, now more than 40, include the noted international drivers, Sir John Whitmore of England and Jacky Ickyx of Belgium.

PARIS, July 5 North Vietnamese militiamen are being trained for fighting conditions of the kind that would be created if the United States were to flood the country by bombing dikes or attempt a landing of troops from the sea, according to a French news agency report from Hanoi.

BERLIN, July 5 Britain's official entry, "Cul-de-Sac," an absurd film by Roman Polanski, full of black humor, gangsters, satire and desperation, won the Golden Bear Award for the best movie today at Berlin's 16th International Film Festival.
WASHINGTON, July 5 The United States, in an attempt to promote "Europeanization" of peaceful uses of the atom, has decided to end its bilateral Atoms for Peace program with France.
LOS ANGELES, July 5 (AP) Sandy Koufax won his 15th game tonight as the Los Angeles Dodgers downed the Cincinnati Reds, 1-0. The loss was the Reds, seventh in a row.

JOHNSON CITY, Tex., July 5--President Johnson, confronted with what appears to be rising racial tension in many of the nation's cities, stressed today the steps being taken to alleviate the sources of the tension.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 5 A United States Navy fighter-bomber crashed into the Gulf of Tonkin off North Vietnam early today during an attack on two boats suspected of being enemy torpedo craft. The pilot was rescued after five hours in the water.

HONOLULU, June 30 Just off important Hololulu thoroughfares like Kapiolani Boulevard and Kalakaua Avenue, ramshackle, termite-ridden little houses, some with leaky tin roofs, huddle along narrow streets.
BLANTYRE, Malawi, Wednesday, July 6 (AP) With bonfires lighting the hillsides and a 21-gun salute resounding, Malawi at midnight became a republic within the British Commonwealth.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 5 American Field Service, which each year sends exchange students from South Africa to the United States, is again coming under attack by Afrikaners.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 5 The four-day Newport Jazz Festival coasted to a close yes- terday with afternoon and evening programs that were an anticlimax after the high points achieved Sunday by Duke Ellington, Woody Herman and Buddy Rich.
George B. Anderson Jr., a salesman of heavy industrial equipment, died yesterday in New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital He was 75 years old and had lived in New Rochelle since 1926.
Negro and Puerto Rican policemen were quietly transferred over the Fourth of July weekend to parks, beaches and ghetto areas in a major effort to thwart any possible racial disturbances.
INDIANAPOLIS, July 5 (UPI) Tony Roche of Australia, Chuck Pasarell and Marty Riessen were beaten today in a wave of upsets at the Western clay-court tennis championships.

PHILADELPHIA, July 5 (AP) United States District Judge Ralph C. Body denied today a request by Ralph Ginzburg, New York publisher, convicted of mailing obscene literature, for reduction or suspension of a five-year prison sentence.

There is no widespread use of narcotics or drugs among students in the city's high schools or the state's colleges, according to a survey by the narcotics' subcommittee of the Medical Society of New York County.
The Consolidated Foods Corporation is planning to enter the chemical field through the proposed acquisition of the Oxford Chemical Corporation for an exchange of stock valued at about $10.5-million.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 5 Queen Elizabeth II flew home to Britain today after opening a new social science building that cost 300,000 at Queen's University here. But Northern Ireland did not relax.

Prime Minister Harold E. Holt of Australia endorsed yesterday the United States display of strength in Vietnam, calling it a "military necessity" for the security of other Asian nations threatened by Communism.
BALTIMORE, July 5 (AP)--Berthold Muecke Jr., vice president and general counsel of the Commercial Credit Company since 1953, has been elected chairman and chief executive officer.

MUIRFIELD, Scotland, July 5 The great names in golf are gathered here for the 95th British Open championship, which starts on the exacting Muirfield course tomorrow, amid cries that the rough is too high and fairways too narrow.
BOONTON, N.J., July 5 Lloyd Monroe and Don McWilliams of Essex Fells won the New Jersey pro-amateur golf championship today with a 32, 35 67 at the Knoll Golf Club.

The promotion of Jack W. Melchior to vice president for sales promotion of Macy's California was announced yesterday by Ernest L. Molloy, president of the R.H. Macy Co., Inc., division, who is presidentelect of the parent company.

Sugar Ray Robinson plans to return to the ring today and box two men in one day. Robinson, the former world middleweight and welterweight champion, is now 45 years old.

As the business expansion continues into the third quarter of this year, economists are busily engaged in speedometer watching. They are anxious to know whether the pace of the boom will slacken further or begin to speed up again.
OYSTER BAY, L.I., July 5 The annual fair of Christ Episcopal Church will be held at the church grounds and the parish hall, rain or shine, on Saturday from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M.
Two teen-age boys were pulled from the Harlem River yesterday morning and remained unidentified 12 hours later as they lay in critical condition at Jewish Memorial Hospital.
SOREL, Que., July 5 A native son who made good in the United States returned home briefly last week to forge a new link between one of America's industrial giants and the Canadian economy.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 5 Portugal's Foreign Minister today proposed early discussion with Secretary General Thant of Black Africa's demands for self-determination in the Portuguese Territories of Angola and Mozambique.

YELLOW SPRINGS, Ohio, July 5 In the Rockford Chapel of Antioch College this afternoon, Miss Mary Armington Ide, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Armington Ide of Plainfield, N.J., was married to Norman Gover. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. James Mell Gover of Somerset, Ky.

BECAUSE he is such an electrifying personality, Arnold Palmer brings with him an aura of built-in excitement when- ever he tees off in a major golf championship. He will be a focal figure again when the British Open begins today at Muirfield in Scotland over a course that bears the fancy but delicious club designation of the Honourable Company of Edinburgh Golfers.
JOHNSON CITY, Tex., July 5 (AP) The addition of a leading State Department adviser headed a list of nominations announced today by President Johnson. [Opening statement, Page 18.]
JERICHO, L.I., July 5 Jimmy Bostwick led the Long Island qualifiers for the New York State amateur golf championships today with a twoover-par 73 over the lush green course of the Meadow Brook Club.
The hot competitive fight for the saving dollar in New York City was hotter than ever yesterday.

LONG BEACH, L.I., July 5 This South Shore city's antipoverty headquarters was picketed by members of the Puerto Rican Civic Association yesterday in a demand for representation on the agency's board of directors.

NEW CITY, N.Y., July 5 Al Feminelli of Dellwood Country Club, playing his home course, shot a 35, 33 68 today to lead the Metropolitan Professional Golfers' Association qualifiers for the Thunderbird tournament.
The election of William B. Astrop as a vice president of the Stone Webster Securities Corporation was announced here yesterday.
HUNTINGTON STATION. L.I., July 5 Charles Elliot Rhodes, a retired New York lawyer, died here today in his home. His age was 68.
Moore-McCormack Lines signed a $63-million contract yesterday with the Ingalls Shipbuilding Division of Litton Industries of Pascagoula, Miss., for building four roll-on, roll-off cargo ships.
TRENTON, July 5 (UPI) You can get fined for killing a bear in New Jersey, but only if it's a native of the state.
The elections of two senior vice presidents were announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 5 (UPI) The Chicago Board of Trade appointed today a committee to study job-lot trading in grain futures in the light of Monday's charge by the Department of Agriculture that there was a "complete lack of competition" in such trading, a violation of the Commodity Exchange Act.

The engagement of Miss Deanne Rochelle Goldman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Goldman of Brooklyn, to Dr. Sanford Salz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Salz of Flushing, Queens, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents. The wedding is planned for next month.
FREIBURG, Germany, July 5 (AP) Georg von Hevesy, Nobel Prize-winning chemist, died today, the University Medical Clinic announced. He was 80 years old.

DETROIT, July 5 (AP) Ervin Pete Fox, the swift outfielder of three Detroit Tiger championship teams, died of cancer today in New Grace Hospital. He was 57 years old and had retired from baseball in 1945.

SANTA MARIA DEL MAR, Cuba, July 5 (Reuters)--Premier Fidel Castro said in an interview today that there could be no reconciliation with the United States until there was a complete change of system there.

OTTAWA, July 5 (Canadian) Press) Mitchell Sharp, the Finance Minister Sharp announced tonight that the Government proposes to raise the present 6 per cent ceiling on bank loan interest rates, and eventually to remove it when credit conditions become easier.
PARIS, July 5 The controversy between the West German Government and the French magazine Paris Match over charges of faked pictures of neo-Nazis reached a new dimension today.

CLEVELAND, July 5 (AP) Ted Uhlaender doubled home the tying run and Harmon Killebrew's sacrifice fly drove in the clincher as the Minnesota Twins rallied for a 4-3 victory over the Cleveland Indians tonight.
The election of Edwin L. Weisl, a senior partner of the New York law firm of Simpson, Thacher Bartlett, to the board of the Cenco Instruments Corporation was announced yesterday.
The Texas Gulf Sulphur Company and the Securities and Exchange Commission filed their post-trial memoranda with Federal Judge Dudley B. Bonsal yesterday.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York announced yesterday that the total volume of outstanding commercial paper fell by $188-million, or 2 per cent, in May. The decline to $11,372,000,000 was the first since December, 1965.

Mr. and Mrs. Harold Masius of 911 Park Avenue have announced the engagement of thei daughter, Miss Judith Florence Masius, to David Edward Behrend, son of Dr. and Mrs. Bernard Behrend of Philadelphia.

PHILADELPHIA, July 5 Larry Jackson joined Juan Marichal at the top of the Mets' most wanted list tonight as he pitched and batted the Phils to a 3-1 victory over New York. Jackson thus equalled the 15-0 won-lost mark that Marichal of the Giants owns against the Mets.

WASHINGTON, July 5 The 200th anniversary of the Declaration of Independence will be celebrated ten years from this week, and while Americans are not normally enthusiastic about ten-year plans, July 4, 1976, is a date worthy of some serious and sustained planning.

Count and Countess Gerd von Schwerin of Sao Paulo, Brazil, have announced here the marriage of the countess's daughter, Gabrielle, Countess Lambsdorff von der Wenge, to Eric Street of Westport, Conn., and New York, son of Wolcott Davenport Street of New York and Mrs. Ralph Shelly Ritter of Westport.

Richardson-Merrell, Inc., through its Mexican subsidiary, Richardson-Merrell, S.A. de C.V., announced yesterday that it had acquired for cash the three companies that make up the Larin candy enterprise of Mexico City.
An unusual media distribution plan has been worked out between the International Publishing Corporation and GiftPax, Inc., a company specializing in controlled-product sampling.
THE first swordfish to be taken at Montauk this season by rod and reel was hoisted on the dock Monday to celebrate the Fourth of July holiday.

PHILADELPHIA, July 5 Kenneth S. Gapp, librarian of the Robert E. Speer Library at Princeton Theological Seminary, died here today at Graduate Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived in Princeton, N.J.

ALBANY, Wednesday, July 6 The longest session of the Legislature in 55 years adjourned this morning, leaving behind at least two major unresolved issues overhaul of the Condon-Wadlin law, which forbids strikes by public employes, and the creation of new judgeships.

The chairman of the Middlesex County Chapter of the Congress of Racial Equality charged last night that there had been "a power grab by a small group of racists and black nationalists" at CORE's national convention in Baltimore.

YONKERS, July 5 George Schuck, a former controller and treasurer of Walter Kidde Constructors, Inc. of New York City, died of a heart attack yesterday in his home at 10 Ashton Road. He was 72 years old.
Thirty-two children and they driver were injured yesterday afternoon when a chartered bus returning from a day camp hit a pillar in Brooklyn, apparently after a tire blew out.

The new chairman of the Housing and Redevelopment Board said yesterday that the city would focus its urban renewal efforts on "our biggest and most difficult problems" Negro areas that have remained largely untouched during the first 17 years of the renewal program.

RIVERTON, Conn., July 5 The Northwestern Auxiliary of the Children's Services of Connecticut will hold its annual County Antiques Festival Thursday, Friday and Saturday from 12 noon to 7 P.M. at the fair grounds here.

The nation's railroads, which have had their share of disappointments over the years, are now hopeful that 1966 will be their best year ever. The prospects are reviewed in Railway Age, the trade publication, with all the puff and bluster of a model steam engine.

PITTSBURGH, July 5 (AP) The Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced today that it would make available commercially a control system that it called "a major step toward eventual automation in the basic oxygen steel-making process."
The police arrested five suspects in a cigarette burglary yesterday, but they were still searching last night for the victim of the theft.
ENGLEWOOD CLIFFS, N.J., July 5 Miss Cathy Bao and R. Bennett Bean plan to marry in December.

PHILADELPHIA, July 5 (AP) Twenty-nine demonstrators against the Vietnam war were fined $10 each and were ordered to pay $2.50 costs today on charges of disorderly conduct arising from their activities at July 4 ceremonies at Independence Hall.

ALBANY, Wednesday, July 6 The 189th session of the Legislature cranked laboriously to an end today after voting to give all its members large increases in pay and expense allowances. The increases come to almost $2.5-million.
LOS ANGELES, July 5 (AP) The Los Angeles Dodgers acquired Dick Stuart today for pinch-hitting duties and bought Jim Barbieri, a hard-hitting outfielder, from their Spokane farm.
WASHINGTON, July 5 The Defense Department is speeding development of a strap-on jet flying device that could make Buck Rogers green with envy.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 5 (UPI) The California National Guard disclosed today that more than one-third of its units that underwent intensified training for possible war call-up had failed a combat-readiness test.
JOHNSON CITY, Tex., July 5 (UPI) During the news conference at his ranch today, President Johnson was heckled constantly by a peacock.

Mrs. Lillia Washburn Stevens, founder of the Round Table Club and former president of the League of Business and Professional Women, died yesterday at Booth Memorial Hospital, Flushing, Queens. She was 94 years old and lived at 32-08 Parsons Boulevard, Flushing.

The leasehold for the 14story office building at 570 Broad Street in Newark has been bought by the FurmanWolfson Corporation, a publy owned real estate company, from clients of William Vieser, lawyer. The price was $1.72million over a first mortgage.

Two years ago Miss Shirley Jordan, a talented dress designer, had a small retail business in a Negro neighborhood and an uncertain future. Today she is a dress manufacturer serving scores of retail outlets that include Henri Bendel and the Corduroy Corner.
LOS ANGELES, July 5 A stern rebuke of state governments by one of the nation's top labor leaders marked the opening of the 58th annual National Governors Conference today.
IT was a heady day in fashion yesterday as two of the city's leading milli- ners paraded their thoughts for fall and winter.
PASADENA, Calif., July 5 (AP) Scientists are still trying to reactivate the camera battery of Surveyor 1, perched on the moon, a Jet Propulsion Laboratory spokesman said today.

Installation of $500 worth of radio telephone equipment on every merchant ship moving through the Port of New York might help to avoid serious future harbor accidents, the Coast Guard inquiry into the Texaco Massachusetts-Alva Cape disaster was told here yesterday.

David Cory, the author of 50 children's books, whose Jack Rabbit bedtime stories were syndicated in newspapers for 40 years, died Monday in his home at 2048 East 14th Street, Brooklyn. He was 93 years old.
EXETER, England, July 5 (Reuters) A physician must not disclose details of his patient's illness, even after his death, Britain's 600-member "doctors parliament" ruled here today.

STOCKHOLM, July 5 (UPI) Ron Clarke, a 28-year-old Australian accountant, broke two world records today when he ran 5,000 meters in 13 minutes 16.6 seconds and was timed en route at three miles in 12:50.4.

PARIS When Marshal Tito started his famous partisan war he was not yet fifty but most of his principal lieutenants were so young they called him stari, or "the old man." Now he is almost 75 and those of his original inner circle still alive have been tarnished and eroded by the decades.
SUN VALLEY, Idaho, July 5 (AP) Senator Robert F. Kennedy, Democrat of New York, and his family left Idaho today for Western Canada.
Michael Freyberg was sworn in yesterday by Mayor Lindsay in a brief City Hall ceremony as the $25,000-a-year-president of the Tez Commission and as head of the Department of Real Property Assessment.
BERNE, July 5 (Reuters) The Swiss retail price index (August 1939 equals 100) declined one-tenth of 1 per cent to 225.0 last month the first time in two years that it showed a decrease.

The Lower Eastside Neighborhoods Association opened its 1966 series of Evenings-by-theRiver orchestra concerts last night in the amphitheter of East River Park. The event honored the memory of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, who was honorary chairman of the concerts from 1955 until her death and who made a point of attending the opening event of the series every year.

The appointment of Gabriel Hauge, president of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company of New York, as chairman of the special projects committee of the National Conference of Christians and Jews was announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 5 Progress toward integrated housing is "encouraging" and "far larger than anyone had expected to find," the National Opinion Research Center, an affiliate of the University of Chicago, reported today.
HONG KONG, July 5 (Reuters) The Vietcong said today they were compiling a dossier of "crimes committed by the United States and its allies" to serve as material to try President Johnson.
LONDON, July 5 (Reuters) Rabbi Jacob K. Shankman, president of the World Union for Progressive Judaism called today on the Soviet Union to end what he called the suppression of its 3 million jews.
LONDON, July 5 Prime Minister Wilson announced today a pause "for further consideration of the respective positions" in the exploratory talks on the Rhodesian situation.
There are about 200 city-run bus lines serving New York. But as of yesterday, and for the immediate future, 74 of these are charging 15-cent fares while the remainder charge 20 cents.

A touring company is being organized under the name of the Arthur Miller Repertory Theater to perform three of Mr. Miller's dramas--"After the Fall," "Incident at Vichy" and "The Crucible"--primarily in colleges and universities. The tour will start in January under the auspices of Robert T. Gaus Associates, Inc., Ronald Muchnick and Yvette Schumer.

MRS. JOHN HANCOCK has hair the color of redwood and more interest in that tree than in her family tree although she intends, one day, to trace her husband's connection with the signer of the Declaration of Independence.

BETHESDA, Md., July 5 Brig. Gen. Robert C. Gildart, U.S.A., and Mrs. Gildart have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Mae Gildart, to Forrest William Wright, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Milton Wright of Garden City, L.I.
BUENOS AIRES, July 5 All eighteen officers of a credit union cooperative who were arrested over the weekend were released late today.
LONDON, July 5 The bill to reform Britain's law on homosexual conduct was reintroduced in the House of Commons today.
LAWTON, Okla., July 5 (AP) Civil rights leaders were unable today to persuade the Lawton City Council to adopt an ordinance aimed at forcing integration of a privately owned amusement park.
The National Cargo Bureau has issued a safety code aimed at averting damage caused by the improper stowage of bulk cargoes in ships.

The Liberal party moved yesterday in Federal court to reapportion New York State's Congressional districts. The suit was the first in New York to seek Congressional re- districting on a statewide scale. The party charged in its complaint that the present districting was unconstitutional and violated the United States Supreme Court's oneman, one-vote ruling of 1964.

MOUNT POCONO, Pa., July 5 (UPI) The head of a Binghamton, N.Y., electronics concern and a 20-year-old Johnson City, N.Y., man were killed today in the crash of a twinengine plane near Mount Pocono Airport.

Morgan J. Cramer has left the P. Lorillard Company, it was disclosed yesterday, and has joined the Royal Crown Cola Company as president of Royal Crown Cola International, Ltd., a wholly owned subsidiary that handles the large soft-drink bottler's corporate activities abroad.

HONG KONG, July 6 The Peking press depicted China today as a nation poised to assist the Vietnamese Communists following the raids by United States planes on Hanoi and Haiphong oil installations.

BONN, July 6 Provisional arrangements for the continued stay of French forces in West Germany were completed today with the appointment of a West German general to represent Bonn's "sovereignty" in dealing with Gen. Jacques Massau, commander of the 72,000 French troops in this country.

The Standard Metals Corporation has obtained an exclusive prospecting permit from the Santa Fe Pacific Railroad Company covering 2,280 acres of railroad land, it was announced yesterday by Boris Gresov, chairman and president of Standard.

The Continental Oil Company announced yesterday that it would float a sterling loan, equivalent to about $18.2-million in London through its British subsidiary for the construction of a refinery, according to Reuters.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 6 A Buddhist threat to boycott South Vietnam's national elections appears to be disappearing. The monks who lead the Unified Buddhist Church have not withdrawn their statements that they will boycott the elections, but their followers have begun to file for offices in the constitution-drafting assembly to be elected Sept. 11.

OTTAWA, July 6 (AP) Finance Minister Mitchell Sharp announced today that Canada's holdings of gold and United States dollars on June 30, totaled $2,341,800,000, down from the $2,412,200,000 held at the end of May.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., July 6 Ossie LeViness, a photographer for The New York Daily News, died yesterday of a heart attack at his summer home in Kiamesha Lake. He was 61 years old and lived at 128 Park View Drive.
AVON, N.J., July 6 Richard James Murphy, who headed a New York brokerage house bearing his name, died yesterday in his home at 235 Washington Avenue. He was 61 years old.

MIAMI BEACH, July 6-- The International Brotherhood of Teamsters created machinery today to elevate James R. Hoffa's candidate to the union presidency if Hoffa is sent to jail. The Teamsters also voted new financial benefits for Hoffa.

GLEN COVE, L.I., July 6 Miss Jean Sanders of Glen Cove, daughter of Mrs. Arthur S. Sanders of Edmonton, Alberta, will be wed to Dr. Gilbert H. Taylor of Glen Cove on Saturday at the Roman Catholic Chuch of St. John the Martyr in New York.

In their search for funds, borrowers have been increasingly turning away from such traditional lenders as banks and finance companies, and have been getting money instead directly from individuals, nonfinancial businesses and government at all levels.
BELGRADE, July 6 (AP) The Yugoslav Parliament will meet July 14 to elect a new Vice President, following the purge of Aleksandar Rankovic, it was announced today.

PATERSON, N.J., July 6 Complaints by citizens who said they could buy glue, tape and other items cheaper at retail than their school board was buying them for wholesale led John G. Thevos, the Passaic County Prosecutor, to order an inquiry yesterday into the board's spending practices.
The Fire Department rejected as "misleading" yesterday charges that it did not have enough, firemen in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn.
The city is negotiating with the Federal Government for the acquisition of the recently closed United States Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn, Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday.
Mayor Lindsay warned yesterday that the expansion of the Vietnam war could lead to "an episode of terror nuclear confrontation."

MUIRFIELD, Scotland, July 6 A remarkable 4 on the last hole gave Jack Nicklaus a 70 and a tie for the lead with Jim Hitchcock of England today in the first round of the 95th British Open golf championship under perfect conditions. Arnold Palmer, one of the favorites, took a 73.

SMITHTOWN, L.I., July 6 The engagement of Miss Eleanor Talcott Griffin to John Lammi has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Hancock Griffin Jr. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Lammi of London, Ohio.
The International Business Machines Corporation announced yesterday in Armonk, N.Y., the election of Walter J. Pedicord as a vice president and David L. Grove as chief economist, a new post.

DETROIT, July 6 (AP) United States District Judge Wade H. MeCree Jr. ruled today that Federal agents may not use a snooping device called a "pen register" to find out who makes telephone calls to whom.

DETROIT, July 6 (AP) A Federal judge settled a patent suit with multibillion-dollar implications for the steel industry today, ruling invalid a patent held by Kaiser Industries, Inc., on a revolutionary steel-making process.
The spot rate on the British pound recovered partly from its sharp decline of Tuesday in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday.

BONN, July 6 The West German Government attacked Mayor Willy Brandt and his West Berlin Government today for their handling of negotia- tons with East Germany on a new pass agreement.

GREAT NECK, L.I., July 6 Frederick Uhl, Mayor of Great Neck Plaza here for 24 years until his retirement in 1964, died today at Manhasset (L.I.) Medical Center. He was 83 years old and lived at 11 Overlook Avenue, Great Neck.

Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner announced plans yesterday for a four-year, nonsectarian liberal arts college to be built on a 299-acre tract at Woodridge, in the Catskills.

MADRID, July 6-- A group of "liberal" Roman Catholic Bishops held a private meeting here the other evening and angrily spoke of a "coup d'etat" by the church's conservative hierarchy.

CHICAGO, July 6 (AP) Roberto Clemente drove in five runs with a double and homer today and led the Pittsburgh Pirates to their 10th victory in the last 13 games, a 10-5 rout of the Chicago Cubs.
Tax-exempt bond yields rose sharply yesterday causing Louisiana to reject the bids it received on $30-million of revenue bonds because the interest cost was "just too high."
The most critical manpower problem facing the nation's largest airline is no longer a pilot scarcity but a shortage of mechanics.
CHICAGO, July 7, (UPI) The president of the National Safety Council, Howard Pyle, denied today Ralph Nader's charge that the council was "dominated by the automobile industry."

The husband and manager of Carol Channing acknowledged yesterday that he had paid $4,000 to the former Congressional investigator who had tried to "rig the rating" of the Broadway musical - comedy star's special television show on Feb. 18.
BONN, July 6 Lynda Bird Johnson inspected castles, cathedrals and Roman relics in West Germany's Rhineland today, under a gray, rainy sky.

BOISE, Idaho, July 6 (AP) The Idaho Savings and Loan Association, which claims more than 20,000 depositors in four Idaho cities, closed its doors today and its operation was taken over by the State Department of Finance.
El. Morocco, elegant diningand-dancing place of society for the last 35 years, has been sold for the second time in two years.

The Navy Department has named Rear Adm. George R. Luker, Commandant of the Third Naval District. Coming from Tokyo, where he has been Chief of the United States Military Advisory Assistance Group, Japan. Admiral Luker is expected to assume his new command, with headquarters at 90 Church Street, about the middle of August.

LONDON, July 6 (UPI) Pan American World Airways will expand its facilities at John F. Kennedy International Airport in New York by 300 per cent by 1970, Harold E. Gray, president of the airline, said today.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 6 (UPI) A new political party in Alabama, interested in Gov. George C. Wallace's possible Presidential aspirations in 1968, was announced today.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 7 The White House in Texas had no comment tonight on Prime Minister Wilson's announced trip to Moscow.

A triumvirate that has been stalking the business world for almost eight years became a duumvirate yesterday when Robert Huffines announced yesterday that he had resigned as chairman of Defiance Industries, Inc., and president of the B.S.F. Company.

Cyane, at 46 feet one of the average-sized yachts in the race from Bermuda to Denmark, was 350 miles southeast of Newfoundland yesterday. Her owner, Henry B. du Pont of Wilmington, Del, reported to his office by radio-telephone that all was well and the weather beautiful, but progress was slow.
BERLIN, July 6 The East Germans began today to move a stretch of the wall between East and West Berlin westward closer to the Reichstag Building in West Berlin.

WASHINGTON, July 6 The Administration presented a divided, almost confused front today on how to proceed toward a treaty to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons following President Johnson's statement yesterday expressing his desire to reach as "agreeable compromise" with the Soviet Union.
The Irving Trust Company, New York City's seventh-ranking commercial bank, reported yesterday a marked Increase in net operating earnings despite generally higher operating costs.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 112.6 on Tuesday from 112.2 on Friday.
GOSHEN, N.Y., July 6, (AP) Romulus Hanover established a stake record today in winning the $14,323 Goshen Cup in 2:01.2.
HONG KONG, July 6 Senior American officials say that another diplomatic approach will be made to persuade Hanoi to negotiate a settlement of the war in Vietnam.
UDON, Thailand, July 5 The Udon air base, like its counterparts at Nakhon Ratchasima, Ta Khli, Ubon and Nakhon Phanom, is a secret only in official Thai and United States pronouncements.

Dr. Laurence I. Schwed, a dentist here for more than 40 years, died yesterday of cancer at his home, 785 Park Avenue. He was 75 years old and maintained an office at 8 West 40th Street until his retirement in 1956.

Robert L. Meyers, previously furniture buyer at Bloomingdale's here, has been elected chairman and chief executive officer of Bonniers, Inc., specialty department store in Manhattan dealing in imports. He succeeds Goran F. Holmquist, who has retired.

Edward Pierrepont Beckwith, a retired research chemist and engineer who conducted some of the first experiments using tungsten as filament for electric lamps, died of a heart attack while driving Tuesday in Peekskill, N.Y. His car struck a standing automobile and stalled. He was alone at the time. attack while driving Tuesday in Peekskill, N.Y. His car struck a standing automobile and stalled. He was alone at the time.
Samuel Spitzbart was appointed yesterday as senior vice president in the mortgage department of the Security National Bank of Long Island.
The Lukens Steel Company, the first metals company to issue half-year results, reported yesterday record sales but little change in earnings from the period a year earlier.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 6 North Vietnamese defenders launched an unusually large number of surface-to-air missiles at attacking American planes yesterday, a United States military spokesman said today. None of the missiles hit a target.

MAYWOOD, N.J., July 6 Mr. and Mrs. Maurice J. Brick of Maywood and Candlewood Isle, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia M. Brick, to Harris A. Schwartz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Schwartz of New York.
BERRYVILLE, Va., July 6 (AP) Former Senator Harry F. Byrd was reported near death today at his estate, Rosemont.

A three-year projection of office space construction in Manhattan just completed by a company of office leasing specialists concludes that about 23 million square feet of new space will be completed in the borough by 1970. No buildings are expected to be completed in the last month of this year.

Though the Federal Medicare program for persons aged 65 or older went into effect last Friday, there apparently remains a good deal of confusion about what supplemental private insurance is being offered and whether it is worth buying.
LONDON, July 6 Is the Government doing enough to defend the pound?

CLEVELAND, July 6, (UPI) Tony Oliva snapped a 2-2 tie with a two-run eighth-inning double tonight, then threw out the potential tying run at the plate for the final out of the game as the Minnesota Twins beat the Cleveland Indians, 4-3. The defeat was the fifth straight for the Indians.

PHILADELPHIA, July 6 The marriage of Miss Frederica Rand Mann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Rand Mann, to John M. Levin took place today. The bridegroom is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Cyril M. Levin of Grymes Hill, Staten Island, New York.
The music of Leos Janacek will be played on Saturday evening at Caramoor, the estate of Mrs. Walter T. Rosen in Katonah, N.Y., to benefit the World Federation of United Nations Associations.

As he has done on the completion of each of his films, Alfred Hitchcock, the director, has once again taken to the road in the transparent disguise of film salesman, or, as the trade calls a peripatetic publicity man, tub-thumper.
