WASHINGTON, July 6 The Federal Government collected and spent nearly $16-billion more in the fiscal year just ended than in the previous year, the Treasury statement for June 30 showed today.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 6 The Larchmont Yacht Club crew, captained by Mrs. Richard H. Hunter, won the Westchester area elimination series of the women's sailing championship of Long Island Sound today. The Larchmont Yacht Club crew will sail for the Syce Cup, off Riverside (Conn.) Yacht Club, starting next Tuesday.

A young British couple and two Baptist ministers one British and one Dutch have been expelled from the Soviet Union for having tried to smuggle religious books into the country, the Moscow newspaper Trud said today.
The Transit Authority opposes any transfer arrangements between its bus and subway lines and is preparing a case against the use of transfers for presentation to the Board of Estimate.
WASHINGTON, July 6 A group of Negro doctors and dentists accused the Federal Government today of pouring money into Atlanta hospitals that are still almost totally segregated.
ALTHOUGH cooking has become an ardent pastime in the life of Madhur Jaffrey, her interest in cooking with a certain panache came about, as it has for many another young New Yorker, through necessity.

TOKYO, Thursday, July 7 (UPI)-- Dozens of captured American pilots were marched through the streets of Hanoi last night to the shouts and denunciations angry mobs, according to a Comunist broadcast monitored here today.
The Soviet Union has been giving a great deal of attention to unmanned probes of space since its last manned flight, in March, 1965.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 6 After nearly a year in Israel, the West German Ambassador Rolf Pauls, has answered his critics. The excercise has only attracted more criticism.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 6-- President Johnson conferred today on the Vietnam war with Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara and other advisers.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 6 (AP) Willie Mays's 524th career homer lifted the San Francisco Giants to a 3-2 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals today.
The Ford Foundation has extended an $80.2-million helping hand to 61 symphony orchestras.

LONDON, July 6 Britain and France sought today to arrest the deterioration of their diplomatic relations as three days of talks got under way in London between Premier Georges Pompidou of France and Prime Minister Wilson.
Mediators were unable yesterday to bring about contract agreements between The World Journal Tribune and the pressmen's and mailers' unions.

BALTIMORE, July 6 (AP) Boog Powell of Baltimore drove in 11 runs as the Orioles split a double-header with the Kansas City Athletics tonight, winning the opener, 11-0, then losing the finale, 9-8, in 11 innings.
This system was adopted by the junta in an effort to reduce Buddhist voting power and to give the junta a chance to promote the formation of strong anti-Communist, pro-Government coalition lists.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 6 (UPI) Top-seeded Dennis Ralston of Bakersfield, Calif., advanced to the quarter-finals of the Western clay-court tennis championship today by beating Bob Lutz of Los Angeles, 6-2, 6-4.

The Franklin National Bank, which blankets Nassau and Suffolk Counties with an extensive chain of retail offices, announced yesterday that it had loaned $400,000 to the First National Bank of Highland, N.Y.

The-Diners' Club, Inc., is turning to banks as possible foreign franchise holders, Al- fred S. Bloomingdale, chairman, president and chief executive officer of the credit-card concern, said here yesterday.
A number of savings and loan associations in New York City have decided to pay a 5 per cent dividend across the board on all their savings accounts.

PHILADELPHIA, Miss., July 6 (AP) Police Chief Bruce Latimer has been dismissed by the Board of Alderman, but Mayor Clayton Lewis said today that the action had nothing to do with the uproar that swept Philadelphia during civil rights demonstrations last month.
Abraham Straus has named Edward M. Berman, advertising manager, and Julian Taub, research director, as operating vice presidents, the Brooklyn-based department store group announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) Negotiations aimed at averting a nationwide strike against five airlines were adjourned tonight. A Labor Department spokesman said the parties were "still in serious disagreement."
The American Radiator and Standard Sanitary Corporation announced here yesterday that William D. Eberle had been elected a director and would become president Sept. 1.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 6 The Government struck back today against the Rev. Ian Paisley, the Moderator of the Free Presbyterian Church and the leader of Northern Ireland's Protestant extremists, who have conducted an increas- ingly virulent campaign in re cent months against the country's Catholic minority.

Roy Hamey, who succeeded George Weiss as general manager of the New York Yankees and who retired in 1963 after three pennant-winning seasons, will return to a more active scouting role in the Yankee organization.
Two Florida youths and a woman from Queens were arrested early yesterday after a gun battle that was reported to have followed a traffic dispute on the upper West Side.

Walter S. Mack, chairman, and two other officers of Great American Industries, Inc., denied in Federal Court here yesterday charges by the Securities and Exchange Commission that they had committed fraud aimed at running up the price of the company's stock.
BLANTYRE, Malawi, July 6 (Reuters) Dr. H. Kamuzu Banda was sworn in as the first president of the Republic of Malawi today amid a 21gun salute and cheers of 25,000 people.

POWDER SPRINGS, Ga., July 6 A wedding on July 30 is being planned by Miss Carol Marie Hoeschen and Gordon Judd Bockner. Mr. and Mrs. Harold A. Hoeschen have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Dr. and Mrs. Judd Bockner of Mamaroneck, N.Y.

MOSCOW July 6, (AP) Jean-Claude Magnan, the de- fending champion from France, and two former titleholders, gained the final round in the men's foil competition of the world fencing championships today.

Joseph H. Rooney, a member of the staff of the Inter-County Title Guaranty and Mortgagee Company, has been named assistant vice president. Mr. Rooney will also serve as assistant manager of the company's Jamaica, Queens, office.
GENEVA, July 6 U Thant, Secretary General of the United Nations, said today that he expected "some perceptible progress" soon at the 17-nation disarmament negotiations.

BOSTON, July 6 (AP) Kenneth P. O'Donnell said today he had enough signatures to get on the Democratic primary ballot for Governor. He named a close associate of the Kennedy family as his campaign manager.
AACHEN, Germany, July 6 (AP) Graziano Mancinelli, Italy's former world-champion rider, beat a top field today to win the international championship of the Aachen horse show.

Sales of new cars by the General Motors Corporation fell 10 per cent in the final 10 days of June from the levels of last Year.

Small losses again were prevalent on the London Stock Exchange yesterday as traders enthusiasm was dampened by fears of an increase in the bank rate and the possibility of new curbs on consumer demand.

SALLY VICTOR, who says her principle business ob- jective is "to design pretty hats that make women look prettier," calls her current collection "Dream World," but her feet are planted firmly on the ground.

SOME puzzled fans may have muttered "Who he?" when George Scott of the Boston Red Sox was elected by his fel- low American Leaguers as the starting first baseman for the All-Star game at St. Louis next Tuesday. Their surprise is understandable because the big rookie hardly has been around long enough to hammer his way into national consciousness. But New Englanders are much more aware of him, and they have been vastly impressed.

PHILADELPHIA, July 6 (AP) Federal Judge Ralph C. Body today ordered Ralph Ginzburg, New York publisher, to surrender to the United States marshal by noon July 12 to begin serving a five-year prison sentence for mailing obscene literature.
CHATTANOOGA, July 6 (AP) The Tennessee Valley Authority announced today contract awards with a possible total maximum of $1,212,679.
Recovering from losses earlier in the day, grain prices closed mixed yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, following the issuance of a private crop report.
PHILADELPHIA, July 6 (AP) Some 100 members of the Women's Strike for Peace, many wheeling baby carriages, picketed the United States Mission to the United Nations today.
Patti Page brought something new to Lewisohn Stadium last night a walkie-talkie microphone with which she strolled through the stadium singing a medley, of her recording hits.
Two banks have passed up what could have been a profit of $15,000 each on their huge stocks of subway tokens and will pass the money on to the Transit Authority.
The Douglas Aircraft Company has received an order from Swissair for two DC-8 super 62s worth about $18-mil- lion.

BRUSSELS, July 6 The European Coal and Steel Community is studying intensively a possible subsidy for coking coal that would probably cut into the upward trend of American exports to the Continent.

Paperboard production rose 17.1 per cent With 467,000 tons in the week ended July 2, from 398,900 tons is the corresponding 1965 week, the Paperboard Group of the American Paper Institute reported yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, July 6 Democratic Governors agreed today to soften a policy resolution on Vietnam rather than risk a partisan battle on the issue at the National Governors Conference.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, July 6 President Joaquin Balaguer declared last night that the Government-controlled sugar corporation, over which he has assumed personal direction, would have a deficit this month of 6 million pesos, about $6-million.
Bill requiring safety inspection of all new automobiles before delivery to consumer. Signed by the Governor.

"women of Violence: Memoirs of a Young Terrorist 1943-48," by Geula Cohen, will be issued by Holt, Rinehart Winston on July 18. She was the radio voice of the underground group and eventually was sentenced to nine years imprisonment.

Directors of Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., the big Chicago investment banking concern that was owned solely by the late Harold L. Stuart, will be given an opportunity to purchase stock or other assets of the corporation at book value.
LOS ANGELES, July 6-- Vice President Humphrey denounced black racism tonight.

The 29-ton Saturn rocketsatellite launched two days ago was intentionally blown up in space at the end of its fourth orbit, space agency officials disclosed yesterday in Washington. The vehicle was the heaviest ever orbited by the United States, Previously, it was understood that the rocket would remain in orbit' until it gradually fell into earth's atmosphere and burned up.
ALBANY, July 6 The 1966 Legislature, which adjourned this morning, wasn't quite the longest in history, but it generated the most bills.

WASHINGTON, July 6 When Harry Flood Byrd sank today into the coma whence consciousness of the living world has departed, the political principles on which his every public position was firmly founded had already become ancient history in his party and in the popular concept of the role of government in the United States.

PHILADELPHIA, July 6 A "Safe" bet last April would have been to say the Yankees would have a better won-lost mark than the Mets by the All-Star break. But with the break only five days off, the Mets and Yankees had won-lost marks of 34-44 tonight.
Arrests for murder, robbery and rape here are being made increasingly among people with previous arrest records.

FLORAL PARK, L.I, July 6 Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Titunik have made known the engagement of Mrs. Titunik's daughter, Miss Barbara' Helen Jonap, to Stuart MacLean Johnson, son of Mrs. W. MacLean Johnson of Ladue, Mo., and the late Mr. Johnson.
The American Broadcasting Company will televise live via Early Bird satellite the next world heavyweight championship fights from Europe.
BALBOA, Canal Zone, July 6 All Panama Canal performance records continued their decade-long climb to higher levels during the fiscal year 1966, which ended last week.
WASHINGTON, July 6 The Navy has assured pet lovers that all cats left friendless or homeless by the closing of the Navy Yard, in Brooklyn will be taken care of.

Melvin Dubin, who came within 918 votes of taking the Democratic nomination from Representative Abraham J. Multer in the June 28, primary, brought suit yesterday in State Supreme Court to have the result voided grounds of fraud and other irregularities.

Samuel Pond Jones, known as the Squire of Woodsfield, went through his professional life burdened with a nickname that had been applied to him by mistake, Sad Sam, the Cemetery Man, as sports- writers called him was, in fact, a whimsical and quietly humorous man, brimful of quips and backwoods humor.
The Missouri Pacific Railroad (Mopac) in the month through June 24, purchased an additional 200,000 shares of 50-cent preferred stock of the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway.
The election of Himan Brown as a director of the Royal National Bank of New York was announced yesterday.
WESTBURY, L.I., July 6 Dick, Baker, Stanley Dancer's chief aide, was concluding Noble Victory's third training tour of Roosevelt Raceway's main track yesterday morning.

DALLAS, July 6 (AP) J.W. Bateson who built a $10-a-week construction job into a multimillion-dollar business, died yesterday in Baylor Univer sity Medical Center after a brief illness. He was 57 years old.

UTRECHT, the Netherlands, July 6 Paul Taylor's "Orbs," given its world premiere at this year's Holland Festival, is a major work, indeed the most considerable and the most exciting that Mr. Taylor has yet given us.

Volkswagen, the world's fourth largest automobile manufacturer, has ordered about 700,000 of its cars recalled for the inspection of possible safety defects. About 197,000 of the cars are in the United States.
VIENTIANE, Laos, July 6 The North Vietnamese will apparently attempt to keep a steady flow of men and supplies via Laos to South Vietnam despite the monsoon rains, military sources here say.
DETROIT, July 6 (UPI) American Football League club owners decided today to wait until 1968 before adding a 10th team to the loop.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) Poland has threatened to refuse all mail bearing a new United State 5-cent postage stamp honoring 1,000 years of Christianity in Poland, a Government source said today.

A salvage expert testifying yesterday on the explosion and fire on the tanker Alva Cape on June 28, charged that the New York City Fire Department had interfered unnecessarily in the cargo salvage operation preceding the disaster.
NASHVILLE, July 6-- Miss Alice Lee Boswell and Donald Robert Love plan to marry on Aug. 20.

ROME, July 6 World public opinion is "perplexed and disoriented" by the American bombings at Hanoi and Haiphong, the current issue of the weekly Vatican paper, L'Osservatore Della Domenica, says in a critical editorial.

An exhibition of 75 art books published by Albert Skira will open today at the Hallmark Gallery, Fifth Avenue at 56th Street. The-show, called "Skira, the Man and His Work," will extend through Sept. 8.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (UPI) Paul Casanova doubled in a run in the eighth inning that gave the Washington Senators a 3-2 victory and a sweep of their double-header with the Chicago White Sox tonight. The Senators took the opener, 4-3.

BUCHAREST, July 6 The leaders of the Warsaw Pact nations ended their conference tonight by signing a communique that said they had drafted a statement about the Vietnamese war "in the light of the new criminal action by the American armed forces."

Poll-taking has become standard operating procedure for every self-respecting politician. But no other politician is so addicted to psephology the scientific study of the electorate as President Johnson. In reeling off a long series of poll results at his press conference the other day, the President revealed just how assiduous he is in using polls to obtain instant ratings at his standing in every part of the country.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., July 6 Dr. and Mrs. Stanley Goodman have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Goodman, to William Gar Richlin, son of Dr. and Mrs. Padie Richlin.

LOS ANGELES, July 6 (UPI)-- Claude Osteen, the pitcher, broke up a scoreless game in the eighth inning tonight by driving in John Kennedy with a single for a 1-0 Los Angeles Dodger victory over the Cincinnati Reds. The loss was the Reds' eighth in a row, and the second straight by 1-0 to the Dodgers.

The rider did the job just as well as his horse in the $36,850 Tremont Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday. The Wheatley Sta- ble's Successor, ridden by Braulio Baeza, took the 5 furlong test for 2-year-olds by a neck over George D. Widner's Bold Hour. Herbert Allen's Fa- vorable Turn was third.
OMAHA, July 6 Gov. Frank B. Morrison acted today to ease tensions and increase employment in Omaha's strife-torn Negro ghetto.
"Instant" movies dollied to within shooting distance of the living room yesterday.

JERSEY CITY, July 6 The new executive director of Jersey City's strife-ridden antipoverty agency was dismissed tonight, according to a reliable source. The move came after he had discharged his two top aides earlier in the day.
The American Stock Exchange reported yesterday changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and major stockholders of listed companies.
Stock prices rallied strongly yesterday as the market snapped out of its post-holiday lethargy.
CLEVELAND, July 6 (AP) A strike by 8,000 auto workers hit the Ford Motor Company's two engine plants and foundry in the suburb of Brook Park today.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., July 6 Miss Anne McKinstry and Ens. Gordon K. McDonnell, U.S.N., plan to be married Sept, 10 in the United States Naval Academy Chapel.
Miss Susan Starr Fletcher and Dr. William Ernest Boyle Jr. were married yesterday morning in the Roman Catholic Church of Corpus Christi. The Rev. Vincent Case performed the ceremony.
CHICAGO, July 6 (AP) Two Negro leaders, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and the Rev. Dr. J.H. Jackson, disagreed today over Dr. King's plans for a civil rights rally in Chicago Sunday.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., July 6 A four-mile riverfront park with sand beaches, fishing piers, marinas and bicycle and hiking paths is planned along the Hudson River from here to Ossining, the advisory committee of Governor Rockefeller's Hudson River Valley Commission announced today.

SAIGON, Thursday, July 7 (AP) Strong elements of the elite South Vietnamese Seventh Division destroyed, one of the main Vietcong medical and arms depots in the Mekong Delta in a major attack yesterday, a Government spokesman said today.
The Democratic leader of an important upstate county has lost a local primary contest and faces a follow-up battle tonight that could affect the nomination for Governor.
Mayor Lindsay lifted the job freeze at all 21 municipal hospitals yesterday.

LONDON, July 6-- A long-missing, unsigned landscape painting depicting the Judgment of Paris, by the 17th-century French artist Claude Gell e, called le Lorrain, was sold at Sotheby's art auction house here today for the equivalent of $490,000.

GENEVA, July 6 The United States announced today it would sign the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination that was adopted last December by the United Nations General Assembly.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 6 Sharp increases in the property evaluation of two famous hotels were announced here yesterday by the tax assessor in the wake of assessment scandals.
DETROIT, July 6 The automobile industry, under steady attack by safety critics in recent months, has a far-reaching influence over the reliability of today's tires.

WHEN women go hunting be it for clay pigeons or men they like to be dressed for the kill. Although there is no shortage of fashions for a manhunt, women have, in the opinion of Winchester-Western division of Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation, been limited to fatigue-like clothes for trap and skeet shooting.

THINKING ahead is par- ticularly important for a defender who may have to make a hold-up play. The appropriate play often depends on the assessment of partner's spot-card signal, and the calculations must be done in advance to avoid giving the game away to the declarer.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (UPI) The Justice Department says it is making "inquiries" to determine if Julius Klein, the Chicago publicist, should have registered as a foreign agent because of his activities in behalf of The Rheinmetall munitions company in Germany.

The New York City Opera has brought suit against the Long Island Arts Center, Inc., charging breach of contract regarding performances of "Die Fledermaus" and "Madama Butterfly." The opera company expected to give them at the Long Island Festival on July 31 and Aug. 13, respectively.

Dr. Jacob I. Hartstein, president of Kingsborugh Community College, announced yesterday the appointment of Dr. Ralph Edwards as dean of administration of the college at Manhattan Beach and Dr. Seymour L. Lachman, director of the mid-Brooklyn branch.
WASHINGTON, July 7 North Vietnamese jets have fired air-to-air missiles against American aircraft for the first time in the war, United States officials said today.
West Point cadets have won a cherished book they thought they had lost.
A postal employe charged with stealing six bags of mail addressed to persons all over the world was arraigned in Federal Court yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 7 The total monetary reserves of the world's non-Communist nations declined by nearly half a billion dollars in the first quarter of this year, the International Monetary Fund disclosed today.

PELBAM MANOR, July 7 Don Spero of the New York Athletic Club, the winner of the Diamond Sculls at Henley, England, last year, and William Maher of the Detroit Boat Club, the national champion, qualified for the singles sculls final at the world championship rowing trials today on the 2,000-meter course on Hunter's Island Lagoon.
Arthur J. Neumark, a general partner in the brokerage firm of L.F. Rothschild Co., died yesterday at the age of 68. He lived at 1111 Park Avenue.

CLINTON, Tenn., July 7 A D. Crenshaw, president of Magnet Mills, Inc., here and a former director of the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers, died yesterday at his home. He was 68 years old.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) The Agriculture Department increased 1966 import quotas today for sugar by 100,000 tons in a move to insure plentiful supplies for the heavy canning and food processing season ahead.

WASHINGTON, Friday, July 8 A strike affecting about 60 per cent of the nation's air travel was set for 6 A.M. today following a breakdown in negotiations yesterday between machinists and five major airlines.

The meeting participants consider the bombing of the environs of Hanoi city and of the port of Haiphong--the largest populated centers of North Vietnam--as a new and more dangerous step of the American policy of "escalation" of the war in Vietnam.

Confirming the expected, Frank D. O'Connor has declared his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for Governor. He left to others the luxury of any doubt over success. He will "win on the first ballot" at the September party convention and is confident that he can defeat Governor Rockefeller in November, return the state to the "liberal tradition" and rescue it from "inertia."
HARRISBURG, Pa., July 7 (UPI) A suit challenging the $1.4-million primary campaign expenditures of Milton J. Shapp, Democratic governorship candidate, has been filed in Pennsylvania.
DETROIT, July 7 (UPI) The American Football League club owners named a three-man committee today to work out the remaining details of their merger with the National Football League.
WASHINGTON, July 7 Intercity truck tonnag in the week ended July 2 was 3.2 percent ahead of the corresponding week of 1965.
MIAMI, July 7 (UPI)-- A letter that is believed to be by the poet Lord Byron was found in an uncatalogued book in the University of Miami's library, officials said today.
Two scientists who played leading roles in the observations of Mars by Mariner 4 believe the polar caps of that planet are white with dry ice.

Mrs. Elsie Kraus Kohn, a retired English teacher and the widow of Richard Kohn, died Wednesday in the Hospital for Joint Diseases and Medical Center. Her age was 78, and she lived at 360 Central Park West.
Pierre Bourdelle, a sculptor and teacher, died yesterday in Geneva at the age of 63. He lived in Oyster Bay, L. I.
AACHEN, Germany, July 7 (AP)-- An Italian team won the relay jumping contest of the Aachen horse show today. It was the fifth victory for Italy, in the six-day-old tournament.

The 33 members of the United Negro College Fund yesterday received a total of more than $3.3-million in aid. The money will be used for building construction and renovation, scholarship aid and expanded educational programs at the fund's member colleges and universities, which are all in the South.
BUENOS AIRES, July 7 Ricardo Horacio Illia, younger brother of the deposed President, was released by the police last night after having been held incommunicado since Thursday.

The car of tomorrow arrived in New York yesterday. It was an elegant blue creation placed on display on the main floor of Abercrombie and Fitch's sporting goods store at Madison Avenue and 45th Street. It will remain there until Aug. 20.
A figure of $55-million has been mentioned as the price the Federal Government wants the city to pay for the site of the New York Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn, Representative Hugh Carey said yesterday.

Remembrance of things past of battles long ago, of saddle leather creaking to the weight of troopers at the charge, of canvas straining at the bolt ropesis evoked by the death on the same day of a veteran of the old Army, and of a sailor-cum-writer, who recorded a maritime era now vanished.

What was to have become a garage for Department of Sanitation trucks in the Mt. Sinai medical complex will now be part of the hospital's expansion program. This came about when the Board of Estimate, in a rare action, reversed a position it had taken last year.

NEW DELHI, July 7 Prime Minister Indira Gandhi called tonight on the co-chairmen of the Geneva, conference Britain and the Soviet Union to arrange an immediate meeting of the conference in an effort to end the war in Vietnam.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 7 (UPI) Al Kaline hit a tworun homer and Dick McAuliffe squeezed home the eventual winning run tonight to give Detroit a 4-3 victory over the Minnesota Twins and halt the Tigers' five-game losing streak.
A coordinator of the W.E.B. DuBois Clubs was sentenced yesterday in Brooklyn Criminal Court for having interfered with the arrest of another club member during a near-riot March 5.
Homer M. Byington Sr., a former director of the State Department's Office for Western European Affairs, died at a nursing home in Stamford, Conn., yesterday morning. He was 86 years old.
New York has quietly abandoned the practice of giving keys to the city to distinguished visitors and honored guests.

When Pan American World Airways gave the Boeing Company last April 13 an order for 25 new giant 747 jet airliners capable of carrying 490 passengers about three times as many as the largest existing planes the manufacturer reserved the right to back out of the deal. by Aug. 1. The cancellation
The Cities Service Company announced yesterday its second acquisition proposal in the $100million area in two days.

WHEN a deal is over, experts often argue about the right bid, which may depend on judgment, style and other imponderables. The right play is less open to argument, because analysis will usually give a definitive answer.
TEL AVIV, July 7 The first Israeli judge to be charged with bribery pleaded not guilty today at the opening of his trial in Jerusalem.
OMAHA, July 7 (AP) The heavily Negro Near North Side remained quiet today following several days of riots.
BRUSSELS, July 7 Europe's first commercial plant for the reprocessing of nuclear fuels was dedicated by King Baudcuin today at Mol, Belgium.

YONKERS, July 7 In Temple Emanu-El here this evening, Miss Emily Alice Bardack, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Bardack, became the bride of David Kies, Son of Saul Kies and the late Mrs. Kies. Rabbi, Abraham J. Klausner officiated.

LONDON, July 7 British bookmakers, people seldom perplexed in this gambling nation, have cast jaundiced eyes toward World Cup competition, the forthcoming international soccer tournament among teams from 16 nations.
Floyd B. McKissick, national director of the Congress of Racial Equality, charged yesterday that Vice President Humphrey had expressed a "purely racist reaction" to the concept of black power.

ARGYLE, Minn., July 7 A flying crop-duster inadvertently sprayed this village last night with an insecticide dangerous to humans. After two passes over this town of 800 he discovered that the chemical he was using was not a mosquitocontrol substance but a lethal crop spray usually used in remote fields.

Councilman J. Raymond Jones has decided to stay on as New York County leader of the Democrats despite the drubbing the Reform Democrats gave his candidate for Surrogate in the primary election on June 28.
WASHINGTON, July 7(UPI) Benjamin H. Littleton, who retired in 1958 as senior judge of the United States Court of Claims, died here yesterday at the age of 76.

The Publishers Information Bureau reported to the Magazine Publishers Association yesterday that magazine ad revenue for the first half of 1966 reached "a record all-time high for the period" up 7.4 per cent above last year.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) An Eastern Air Lines stewardess suffered a head injury when her plane and another reportedly were in a near collision yesterday.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange advanced yesterday for the second consecutive session. Stocks were firm throughout the day although they failed to hold at their highest levels.

Mrs. Carmelite Geraghty Wilson, a supporting actress in Tom Mix and Mary Pickford films of the late nineteentwenties, died of a heart attack here yesterday at the Lombardy Hotel, 111 East 56th Street. She was 65 years old.
Figure beside Station Circle indicates current temperature (Fahrenheit); a decimal number beneath temperature indicates precipitation in inches during the six hours prior to time shown on map.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., July 7 The man chosen today as the potential successor to James R. Hoffa as president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters is a man who never pursued the role. Frank Edward Fitzsimmons, the 58-year-old Detroit Teamster vice president elected today as...

A proposal that X-rays and photographs of President Kennedy's body be examined by a committee of scholars and doctors was made public yesterday as a way to support the Warren Commission's findings that Lee Harvey Oswald alone killed the President.
LONDON, July 7 The House of Commons rejected tonight by a vote of 331 to 230 a Conserva- tive move that would have pledged unconditional British support of the United States in Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, July 7 The net flow of savings to savings-and-loan associations totaled $418-million in May, a reduction of almost 50 per cent from the $767-million growth a year earlier, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today.

MOSCOW, July 7 The new chief of Soviet genetics research, striving to strip the remnants of Lysenko mysticism from biology, has called for a reappraisal of the reputation of Ivan V. Michurin, plant experimenter acclaimed for decades as a founder of a Marxist biology.

MUIRFIELD, Scotland, July 7 Jack Nicklaus snatched a stroke lead halfway through the British Open today with two late birdies after Peter Butler of Britain had smashed the Muirfield course record with a magnificent 65.

WASHINGTON, July 7 The nation's 4,500 doctors who own and work in medical laboratories were accused by the Government today of overcharging the public for medical tests and conspiring illegally to keep everyone but themselves out of the medical laboratory business.
HOLLYWOOD, July 7 (AP)-- Anne Nagel, a movie heroine in adventures, mysteries and comedies for a quarter century, died yesterday in a hospital after surgery. She was 50 years old.

The weekly tabulation of statistics on the condition of major banks in leading cities has been revised, the Federal Reserve Board announced yesterday. The revision took effect yesterday with the release containing July 6 figures for major banks in New York City.
CLEAR, Alaska, July 7 (AP) A huge new ultrasensitive electronic eye has been put in use as another defense against a sneak missile attack on the United States, the Air Force disclosed today.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 7 The White House said today that a contract had been awarded to the University of North Carolina, for a major demonstration project on improved emergency medical services for persons injured in highway accidents.

BUENOS AIRES, July 7 (AP) Two Argentine Army officers denied today that they had any evidence that Ernesto Che Guevara, former Cuban Minister of Industry, had been in Argentina's northern territory of Misiones. Major Guevara was last seen in public in Cuba in April, 1965.
DAR ES SALAAM, July 7-- Communist China and Tanzania have signed an agreement to establish a joint shipping company.

GENEVA, N.Y., July 7 The engagement of Miss Judith Ann Howe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Howe, to Thomas Campbell Willers, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Willers of New York and Greenwich, Conn., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents.
The New York Yankees forestalled a doomsday of sorts last night by scoring five times in the ninth inning to defeat the Boston Red Sox, 5-2.
CLARKSVILLE, Va., July 7 Miss Virginia Draper and Gregory Burch Snyder, who is in the Naval Aviation Reserve Officers' Candidate Program at Pensacola, Fla., will be married Aug. 13 in Canton, Mass.
LIGONIER, Pa., July 7 Miss Stephenie Gillespie Bughman and Edward Sortwell Clement, who is serving with the Navy, plan to marry in September.
NEWPORT, Wales, July 7 (AP) Maria Bueno of Brazil reached the final of the Welsh lawn tennis championship today by defeating Norma Baylon of Argentina, 6-1, 6-1.
JERSEY CITY, July 7 The executive committee of Jersey City's troubled antipoverty program confirmed tonight the dismissal of its new executive director.
MADRID, July 7 Generalissimo Francisco Franco completed yesterday a two-week visit to Catalonia. He sounded and acted like a candidate who was campaigning hard for reelection.
TOKYO, July 7 The Premier of Japan advised the Chinese Communists tonight to avoid "isolation" and to get in tune with world trends for their own good.
ALBANY, July 7 The Court of Appeals ruled unanimously today that an indigent defendant cannot be sentenced to additional time in prison to "work out" a fine imposed by the judge.

A neatly rated performance by the Clearview Stable's Bushfighter enabled that 3-year-old son of Warfare to take the feature event at Aqueduct yesterday. With Ron Turcotte steering him, Bushfighter raced to a half-length victory over Prince Rico in the turf contest of 1 1/8 miles.

I have just been informed of the breakdown in negotiations between the five airline carriers Eastern, National, Northwest, Trans World and United Air Lines and the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, and the decision of the union to strike the carriers.
TO much of the clothes-buying public, designers' names like Balenciaga or Cardin mean about as much as the name Paul Poiret, a leader of the Paris couture before World War 1.

TOKYO, July 7 (AP) The North Vietnamese press agency announced today the names of two more American pilots it said were captured after their planes were shot down in North Vietnam, The Hanoi radio revived hints that captured fliers might be tried on charges of war crimes.
HARLINGEN, Tex., July 7 (UPI) Lawrence Gregory Nicolai, one of the first automobile editors and a longtime newspaper executive, died here yesterday after a long illness. He was 75 years old.
Harold Roth, former president of the Continental Vending Corporation, was indicted by a Federal grand jury here yesterday on charges of mail fraud and violations of the securities laws.

The names of 11 leading staff members of The World Journal, the projected afternoon daily to be published by the merger of three New York newspapers, were announced yesterday by Frank Coniff, editor of the paper.
The Police Department apologized yesterday to motorists who were caught in traffic snarls caused by the Lions International parade down Fifth Avenue Wednesday night.

The American Hockey League adopted yesterday a playing schedule for the 1966-67 season that includes Buffalo and delayed until July 15 a decision on the Bisons' request to suspend their franchise for one year.
GROSSINGER, N. Y., July 7 (AP) Joey Archer boxed five rounds today in a sharp workout for his title bout with the middleweight champion, Emile Griffith, at Madison Square Garden Wednesday night.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 7 (UPI) The San Francisco Giants rocked Cincinnati pitching for four home runs today including the 525th of Willie Mays's career, in a 7-5 victory. The defeat extended the Reds' losing streak to nine games.

The American Library Association expects 7,000 members to gather here next week to analyze the problems of their profession from helping people who cannot read to supplying materials for advanced scholars. The conference's theme is "Libraries and the Inquiring Mind."
WASHINGTON, July 7-- The Defense Department has issued instructions to the Army, Navy and Air Force to release servicemen who are the sole surviving sons in their families, it was learned here today.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., July 7 Mrs. Joseph A. Nesbitt of the Westchester Country Club won low gross with 41, 37 78 in the Women's Westchester-and-Fairfield Golf Association's annual Jane Robbins Memorial Trophy tournament at Mount Kisco Country Club today.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., July 7 James R. Hoffa and his candidate as potential successor were elected by acclamation today to five-year terms by the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

City Councilman Theodore S. Weiss brought suit in State Supreme Court yesterday for a new primary in the 19th Congressional District on the ground that the election on June 28 for the Democratic nomination was permeated with fraud.
WASHINGTON, July 7 The Surveyor 1 spacecraft took its first picture in 23 days today a familiar shot of one of its own feet.
HONOLULU, July 7. (AP) Edward Fern, a portrait painter, died of cancer Tuesday at a hospital on Maui Island. He was 57 and had came to Maui three years ago from Cincinnati.
ATHENS, Ga., July 7 (UPI) The Federal Government introduced a surprise confession today in the trial of three members of the Ku Klux Klan charged in the slaying of Lemuel A. Penn, a Negro educator.
A precedent-setting homefurnishings experiment for a department store will be touched off this fall at Macy's New York.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I. July 7 The carelessness of campers and the boisterousness of a growing number of surfers have prompted this town to consider its first stringent beach ordinance.

WASHINGTON, July 7 In the past few days the official line here on Vietnam has changed to moderate optimism. Not only the President and the Vice President, but Acting Secretary of State George Ball the resident pessimist in the Administration on this subject have all started suggesting that Hanoi is not only losing the war but knows it.
The spot rate on the British pound continued to improve yesterday in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here.

Announcement has been made here by Mr. and Mrs. Merlin Fisk of Athens of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Dana Fisk, to William Edward Pitts 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Pitts of Cadillac, Mich.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 7 Although they had never before seen the course, Ronald (Red) Smith Jr. and his partner Frank Granato of Manchester, Conn., put together a 67 today in the John G. Anderson Memorial golf tournament.

How the Declaration of Independence came to be written is the subject of the Broadwaybound musical "1776." Book, music and lyrics were created by Sherman Edwards, a former teacher of American history at the Weequahic High School in Newark. Norman Twain, colessee of the ANTA Theater, expects to present the $350,000offering here between Nov. 21 and Feb. 28.
The Phelps Dodge Corporation, a major domestic copper producer, announced here yesterday the election of James C. Donnell 2d and Edward V. O'Malley as directors.
BUCHAREST, July 7 The Warsaw Pact nations said today that they were ready to send "volunteers" to fight in Vietnam if Hanoi requested such help.

CATSKILL, N.Y., July 7 Miss Carol Lerner, daughter of Philip Lerner and the late Mrs. Lerner, and Jacob Lubetsky, son of Mrs. Benjamin Lubetsky of Mount Vernon and the late Mr. Lubetsky, plan to be married at Temple Israel here on Aug. 7.
The United States Weather Bureau, at 7 P.M. yesterday, made this forecast for Long Island Sound, Montauk Point to Block Island, New York Harbor, the lower Hudson River and nearby offshore waters.
Philip F. Rizzuto Sr., father of the sports announcer and onetime Yankee shortstop, died at his home in Queens early yesterday of a heart attack at the age of 74.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) Republicans accused the John son Administration today of fighting a sham battle instead of a genuine war against poverty.
Airlines, railroads and bus lines took emergency measures last night to meet the drastic disruption of transportation threatened by the strike scheduled for today against five major airlines.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 7 United States Navy fighter-bombers struck again today at the fuel storage tanks two miles northwest of the North Vietmanese port of Haiphong.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 7 There was something unusual about one of the Vietcong who gave himself up art recently near the drowsy outpost town of Kontum.
LOS ANGELES, July 7-- With only one dissent, the nation's Governors voted tonight to support America's policy of military defense of South Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, July 7 The State Department said today that reports from the American Embassy in Buenos Aires indicated that the new military regime in Argentina was not pursuing an anti-Semitic policy.

The Alexander Chapel of the First Presbyterian Church was the setting yesterday evening for the marriage of Miss F. Carolyn Hunter of Brooklyn to Ross L. Muir of New York. The Rev. William Bell Glenesk performed the ceremony.
A total of 1.1 billion gallons of water was drained from the city's reservoirs in the 24-hour period ended at 8 A.M. yesterday as the heat wave continued.

ENGLEWOOD, N. J., July 7 Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. George G. Tennant Jr. of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susanna Cutler Tennant, to Gunter Raimar Gretz, son of Wilhelm Gretz of Frankfurt, Germany, and the late Mrs. Gretz.
BONN, July 7 (Reuters) Lynda Bird Johnson attended a private ball given in her honor tonight by the United States Ambassador, George C. McGhee, at his residence here.

CLEARWATER, Fla., July 7 (AP) Mrs. Bernice T. Steadman, who owns a flying service in Flint, Mich., captured first place today in the 20th annual transcontinental Powderpuff Derby. Her co-pilot was Mary E. Clark of Jackson, Mich.
ROME, July 7 The formation of a provisional committee to carry out the recommendations on the apostolate of the laity made by the Ecumenical Council was announced today by the Vatican.
KINGS MOUNTAIN, N. C., July 7 (UPI) An umpire in the Western Carolinas League was permanently suspended today for punching a player.

The use of deodorant soaps followed by exposure to sunlight can sometimes result in an allergic rash, according to an editorial in the current issue of the Journal of the American Medical Association.

WASHINGTON, July 7--The Gulf Stream, or at least part of it, has shifted to within about 150 miles of the New England coast, according to a report issued today by the Environmental Science Services Administration.

The Investment Company Institute, the mutual fund industry's trade organization, has hired David Silver as its associate genral counsel. Mr. Silver, who was for five years a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission staff, has been general counsel of Investors Planning Corporation since he left the commission exactly a year ago.
The Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company announced yesterday a realignment of its senior management.
WHITE PLAINS, July 7 An emergency reapportionment plan calling for weighted voting by the Westchester County Board of Supervisors was ordered today by State Supreme Court Justice Gerald Nolan.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., July 7 Mrs. Donna Floyd Fales of New York, the defending champion who heads the draw; Marilyn Aschner of Holliswood, Queens, seeded second; Diane Matzner of West Hempstead, L.I., seeded No. 3, and Mrs. Adria Price of Sunnyside, Queens, No. 4, won quarterfinal matches at the Orienta Beach Club today in the women's Eastern clay courts tennis championship.
Dominique Lattinelli, an 18year-old high school student found sane after psychiatric tests, was indicted yesterday for crimes involving the placing of three bombs in lower Manhattan last May.

John J. Cassese, the president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, placed an 11volume bundle of 51,852 signatures atop the walnut desk of the city clerk yesterday and declared that a referendum to bar a civilian-dominated review board "will go on the ballot."

DARIEN, Conn., July 7 Joseph J. Lann of Putnam Country Club and Mrs. Lawrence H. Manheimer of Metropolis Country Club won the 18th annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association father-anddaughter championship today by scoring 42, 43 85 in selected-drive, alternate-stroke competition at Woodway Country Club.

The results of the first industry-sponsored good design program in housewares will be unveiled Monday in Chicago to store buyers attending the semiannual trade showings at McCormick Place there next week.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) Sargent Shriver, head of the antipoverty program, said today that the Head Start program to aid preschool youngsters had had effects everywhere on education.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, July 6-- The tourists had dutifully checked their cameras at the entrance, and Supreme Headquarters Allied Powers Europe was being explained to them by a very proper British officer. He was pointing to a giant organizational chart, on which national flags represented the nationalities of high officers.

GENEVA, July 7 The United States and the Soviet Union remained deadlocked today over the issue of how to monitor a ban on underground nuclear testing. Recent attempts by nonaligned nations have failed to open the way to a compromise.

The elusive Lee Konitz, an alto saxophonist who was the top man on his instrument in the cool school of jazz almost 20 years ago but whose career since then has followed an erratic path, made one of his infrequent local appearances last night in the garden of the Museum of Modern Art.

BOONTON, N.J., July 7-- Jim De Piro of Branch Brook, a former amateur champion, and Mike Burke of Deal moved into a two-stroke lead today at the halfway point of the 46th annual New Jersey open golf championship.

GLENDALE, Calif., July 7, (UPI) George I. Holmes, prominent in mining and horse racing, died yesterday in Glendale Sanitarium, after a long illness. He was 62 years old and lived in Laguna Beach and Yuma, Ariz.

EXPLORING the relationship between Igor Stra vinsky and the 18th century provided a felicitous evening of music in Philharmonic Hall last night. The occasion was the second in the series of programs by the New York Philharmonic called "A Festival of Stravinsky: His Heritage and His Legacy:"
Jacob Roth, a retired New York necktie manufacturer, died Wednesday in his apartment in the Esplanade Hotel, 305 West End Avenue, after a long illness. He was 75 years old.
Buildings Commissioner Charles G. Moerdler charged yesterday that his department had become a "half-toothless tiger" because of Assembly Speaker Anthony J. Travia and lenient Criminal Court judges.

LOS ANGELES, July 7 Roy Wilkins indicated today that further cooperation between the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and Civil rights organizations advocating black power had become virtually impossible.
GLYNDEBOURNE, England, July 7-- Glyndebourne's adventurous new policy produced a strange evening here last night with the staging of Handel's oratorio "Jephtha."

City Council President Frank D. O'Connor charged yesterday that New York State had "slipped badly" under Governor Rockefeller and pledged that if he became Gov- ernor his goal would be to make the state "once again" the "biggest, boldest and best in the nation."

CLEVELAND, July 7 (AP)--Negotiations broke off today between union and management officials at the Ford Motor Company in suburban Brook Park. A company spokesman said the one-day strike had brought further production cutbacks at other plants, with one Ohio plant scheduled to shut down completely tomorrow.

BUFFALO, July 7 (AP) A Great Lakes pilot, fearful of personal attack, pressed today for removal of Patrick J. Cullnan Jr. as president of the Licensed Tugmen's and Pilots' Protective Association of America.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (UPI) The Air Force announced today plans to negotiate a threeyear, $56-million contract with the Federal Electric Corporation to manage, operate and maintain technical facilities of the Western Test Range.

LOS ANGELES, July 7 (AP) The chief labor representative of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People accused Hollywood filmmakers and craft unions today of excluding Negroes from significant roles and jobs.

PARIS On July 8, 1965, President Johnson took the unusual step of nominating Cabot Lodge to a second tour as Ambassador in Saigon. This crucial job is about as agreeable as Vice Consul in hell, Now Lodge has finished another year of sweltering, restraining generals, juggling politicians, entertaining V.I.P. tourists and keeping construction workers out of jail.
No city administration has had the courage to forbid Fifth Avenue and other major arteries as parade grounds; and we regret to see that Mayor Lindsay's administration thus far is no exception.

A $30-million port and resort development, to make Montego Bay, Jamaica, the leading resort of the Caribbean, was announced yesterday by officials of the Government of Jamaica and a privately sponsored development corporation, Montego Freeport, Ltd.

WESTBURY, L. I, July 7 It appeared today that Pluvier III of Sweden, the winner of last year's Roosevelt International Trot, would be unable to defend his title in the $100,000, 1 -mile race at Roosevelt Raceway Saturday night.
Even before the New York Stock Exchange's new index of market action is off the drawing board and onto the ticker tape, the critics are out with comments on its shortcomings.

Countrywide Realty, Inc., of New York, has sold the operating leasehold on the Western Merchandising Mart in San Francisco to the Western Mart Company, a partnership of New York and California investors.
LONDON, July 7 Premier Georges Pompidou of France issued a veiled warning to the British today that they had better get their economy in order if they expected to enter the European Common Market.
Directors of the Curtis Publishing Company elected yesterday Proctor A. Sugg, a retired executive vice president of the National Broadcasting Company, to the company's board.
The second, third, fourth and sixth ranking commercial banks in the United States reported their net operating earnings for the first half of 1966 yesterday.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., July 7 Ray Floyd, the winner of last year's St. Paul's open and one of the youngest touring pros, was the only golfer to break par today in the first round of the second annual 36hole Concord invitation.

Warlock, the 38-foot fiberglass yawl belonging to Julian K. Roosevelt of Oyster Bay, L. I., notified United States Coast Guard headquarters here yesterday that she was abandoning the Bermuda-to-Copenhagen race and proceeding to the Azores. There were no details other than that the action was taken at the advice of the yacht's physician and that there was no immediate danger.

The American Committee to Preserve Abu Simbel will benefit from the New York premiere of the motion picture "Khartoum" at the Warner Cinerama Theater next Wednesday. Lowell Thomas and Spyros P. Skouras are co-chairmen for the black-tie event.
OTTAWA, July 7 Thirteen West Indian governments today welcomed stepped-up economic assistance from Canada, but insisted that what they need most is not aid but trade.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 7 The United States' explanation to the Security Coun- cil of the expansion of the air war in North Vietnam has met a cold, in some cases even a hostile, reception in the United Nations Secretariat and among many delegations.
CAMP KILMER, N. J., July 7 Paul C. Ketchersid, director of the Kilmer Job Corps Center, said today that he was resigning from his post.
ALBANY, July 7 The Court of Appeals upheld today the second degree murder conviction of Mark Fein, the 34-year-old Park Avenue executive. The ruling was made by a 6-to-1-vote.

AREA A The "in" place to be for big bluefish is far out up to 25 miles offshore. Charter boats from Barnegat Light have been taking blues of eight to 10 pounds, chumming with bunker or butterfish or trolling with red and and white feathers. Big blues also are hitting 15 miles off Brielle in deep water of the Mud Hole.
The election of John Peter Du Cane as a director was announced here yesterday by American Metal Climax, Inc., a producer of molybdenum, potash, aluminum, copper and lead.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (UPI) The Senate ethics committee will resume hearings July 19 on misconduct charges against Senator Thomas J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut., with testimony from Julian Klein, a Chicago public relations executive.
A 26-year-old Syracuse man, who, officials say, became conscience-stricken after defrauding the Government, has discovered it is far easier to start a flow of Federal cash than to stop it.

ELIZABETH, N. J., July 7 A July 21 wedding in Vienna is planned by Mrs. Linda Brailove and Dr. Raoul Kneucker, whose engagement has been announced by Mrs. S. Alexander Brailove, mother of the future bride. Dr. Kneucker is the son of Mrs. Therese Kneucker of Graz, Austria, and the late Dr. Alfred W. Kneucker of Chicago.

More than 250 passengers were delayed about an hour yesterday morning when a fire broke out in the engine cables of a New York Central train from Brewster scheduled to arrive in New York at 10:17 A.M.

The union has demanded a 53-cent-an-hour wage increase, implementation of a cost-of-living allowance and a reduction in wage progression steps. The airlines have offered a minimum 48-centan-hour wage increase, but insist on the existing progression steps. The airlines have rejected the cost-of-living allowance.

PHILADELPHIA, July 7 It may just be that the Mets will never want to return to New York. By whipping the Phillies, 9-6, today with a three-run ninth-inning rally, these New Yorkers continued to add to their astonishing road record for 1966.

"The Territorial Imperative," by Robert Ardrey, a book the author describes as a personal inquiry into the animal origins of property and nations, will be issued by Atheneum on Sept. 12. Mr. Audrey's theory is that attachment to a territory and protection of it is at the base of the social order. He tells animal stories to support his point that mankind has acquired this attachment from instincts formed during millions of years.
The New York Board of Title Underwriters has elected Daniel A. Whelan, who is executive vice president of the American Title Insurance Company, as its new president.

The domestic oil industry attacked yesterday a proposal to grant additional oil-import quotas to the petrochemical industry on the ground that it would cut profits for refiners and increase the cost of oil products to the public. Arlan's Department Stores, Inc., and King's Department Stores, Inc., have terminated their merger talks, it was jointly announced by both companies yesterday. Similar negotiations had been held and canceled in 1963 by the two discount chains.
GENEVA, July 7 Ambassator Goldberg suggested today that the Soviet Union "put up or shut up" on the issue of peace in Vietnam.
Mayor Lindsay created a Finance Administration yesterday that will consolidate all the taxcollecting and assessing functions of city government under Roy M. Goodman as Administrator.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 7 Prime Minister Ian D. Smith accused Britain today of intimidation during the recent informat talks that sought a basis for negotiations to end the crisis caused by Rhodesia's seizure of independence last November.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 7 (UPI) The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People planned today to appeal a judge's decision to deny custody of five children to their mother, a white woman who later married a Negro.
CAPE KENNEDY, July 7 (UPI) An airlines strike tomorrow would affect more than 1,000 union workers at the space center here.
The bond market lacked any neat pattern yesterday as continued high interest rates, underwriting syndicate terminations and moderate price swings dominated an indecisive session.
Executive appointments by two motion-picture companies were announced yesterday.
Sears, Roebuck Co. has canceled its plan to open a three-story department store in Hempstead, L.I, forfeiting in the process $179,455 in deposits and costs for plans.

NATCHEZ, Miss., July 7 (AP) Three men charged with murder in the death of Ben Chester White, a 65-yearold Negro, near here remain in jail at an undisclosed location awaiting action by the grand jury in November. The men are being held without bond.

WASHINGTON, July 7 The Senate Foreign Relations Committee formally reported today its approval of a $3.24-billion foreign aid program with all the enthusiasm of a small boy agreeing to visit the dentist.
LOS ANGELES, July 7 (AP) Don Drysdale's third hit of the game, a two-out infield single in the eighth inning, drove in the winning run tonight as the Los Angeles Dodgers beat the Atlanta Braves, 3 2.

ELIZABETH N. J., July 7 Mrs. Katherine McQueen Moore of 562 Walnut Street, formerly a director of the Oralwright Home for deaf and dumb children in New York City, died yesterday at her home. The widow of Thomas Asbury Moore, she was 80 years old.
The grain and soybean futures market continued to dominate activity in commodity futures yesterday.

Deputy Commissioner Herbert Halberg of the Department of Marine and Aviation said yesterday that the department would not renew two permits issued to a concrete company near Peter Cooper Village and Stuyvesant Town.

Two Congressional committees and three Federal agencies were urged yesterday by Senator Harrison A. Williams to take concerted action to alleviate navigational hazards in the New Jersey-New York port area in the wake of recent ship accidents.

Booming business in all phases of color television helped propel the Radio Corporation of America to its first billiondollar first half. Net income for the period, as well as sales and earnings for the quarter, also were at new highs.
'Licenses Commissioner Joel J. Tyler yesterday opened an investigation of the "Batman" concert at Shea Stadium June 25, following complaints by creditors that they had not been paid.
