Following a familiar pattern, the Democratic Reform movement took two steps forward and two steps backward in last week's primary.
The Federal Reserve has decided to tighten credit another notch in an effort to stem the expansion of bank credit.
Prices drifted down on the London Stock Exchange yesterday as investors found new causes for anxiety.
LONDON, July 7 (Reuters) The Australian Prime Minister, Harold E. Holt, told France and other West European nations today to play a more positive role in the Far East.
A STORE carrying a wide range of imported and unusual cooking accessories has opened at 252 East 52d Street, near Second Avenue.

Mrs. Felton McGowan of New York and Tarrytown, N. Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Jemma Susan McGowan, to Carl Edwards Van Winckel Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Van Winckel of Hamden, Conn., and Wolfeboro, N.H. An autumn wedding is planned.

MONTREAL, July 7 (AP) The General conference committee representing 52,000 nonoperating railway workers voted unanimously today to reject a conciliation board report. The report was presented yesterday by Justice Craig Munroe of Vancouver, B. C.
MOSCOW, July 7 Yevgeny Yevtushenko, the stormy young Soviet poet, addressed an emotional plea today to John Steinbeck, the American novelist, to raise his voice in protest against the war in Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) The American Heritage Foundation announced sponsorship today of a nationwide series of voter workshops aimed at increasing political activities at the local level.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) The House Republican leader, Gerald R. Ford of Michigan, said today that 2,434 Americans had been killed in Vietnam during what he called "the past six-and-one-half-month interval of indecision."
The Kennecott Copper Corporation and the Peabody Coal Company announced yesterday that officials had been discussing the possible acquisition of Peabody by Kennecott.

Austin J. Tobin, executive director of the Port of New York Authority, has asked that Mayor Lindsay be present at all future negotiations between his agency and the city over the projected World Trade Center.

WARSAW, July 7 (AP) United States Ambassador John A. Gronouski has dismissed as "still in the rumor stage" a reported Polish Government threat to refuse all United States mail bearing a postage stamp commemorating the Polish Christian millenium.

Next season, Lynn Fontanne will for the first time in 38 years appear in a play without her husband, Alfred Lunt. She will co-star with Julie Harris in the National Broadcasting Company's "Hallmark Hall of Fame" television production of "Anastasia."

INDIANAPOLIS, July 7 (AP) Three Western men players advanced to the quarter-finals in the Western tennis tournament today, but Karen Krantzke of Australia, the top-seeded foreign entrant, was upset in the women's quarter-finals.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., July 7 Garrie B. Haulenbeek, a former advertising sales representative, died here yesterday at the Brunswick Park Nursing Home. He was 81 years old.

Three Army privates who said two weeks ago that they would not report next Wednesday for transfer to South Vietnam were arrested by the military police here last night. Their furloughs had been abruptly canceled by their commanding general.
WASHINGTON, July 7 Importers of foreign cars are concerned over possible difficulties of complying with the Administration's automobile safety bill when it becomes law.
REDWOOD CITY, Calif., July 7 An industrial espionage case ended here today with the sentences of four months in jail for two men.

MORRISTOWN, N. J., July 7 The engagement of Miss Margaret Anne McClave to Donald Edward Craven has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Wilkes McClave, parents of the future bride, Mr. Craven is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Orvin William Craven of Garden City, L. I.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 7 Republican Leaders are seriously considering endorsing Stephen Maxwell, the Negro city attorney of St. Paul, as a candidate this fall against Senator Walter F. Mondale, a Democrat who was appointed two years ago to complete the term of Vice President Humphrey.
The Ford Motor Company is attempting to turn a modern, but consistent, face to its customers across the country.
Stock prices continued to advance yesterday, although recurring bouts of profit taking sapped the market of the vigor it had shown on Wednesday.
Intensive lobbying by maritime labor for an independent Federal maritime agency will get under way next week in Washington.

Mayor Lindsay broke ground yesterday for the city's first Federally aided community mental health center a psychiatric hospital in East Harlem that he said would "show the rest of the country how good health services can be delivered to the people."

ALBANY, July 7 The Court of Appeals ordered today an increase in the $30.4-million condemnation award to the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., whose operations were taken over by New York City four years ago.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 7 (AP) Representatives of some Roman Catholic and Buddhist splinter groups formed a new group today and urged a boycott of the Sept. 11 election for a constituent assembly. The assembly is to draft a constitution.

LOS ANGELES, July 7-- If the swift rise of Ronald Reagan from political obscurity carries him to the governorship of California next fall, he may play the decisive role in the 1968 Republican Presidential maneuvering.

PITTSBURGH, July 7 (UPI) I. W. Abel, president of the United Steelworkers of America, called today for a Congressional investigation of private employment agencies "as to their methods, charges and quality of service."

Nine members of the onetime Mafia family of Joseph (Joe Bananas) Bonanno were sentenced to serve 30 days in jail and $250 fines for contempt of court yesterday. They were given until July 27 to give themselves up.

Directors of W. R. Grace Co., meeting here yesterday, elected George W. Blackwood, Dr. Thomas G. Gibian and Edward L. Hutton as vice presidents. The company also announced formation of three chemical operating groups, with two of the new vice presidents heading two of them.

LONDON, July 7 (Reuters) Britain's Bristol Siddeley Engine Company and the French aviation company S.N.E.C.M.A. have signed an agreement with Pratt Whitney Aircraft in the United States to build their powerful JT9D jet engine in Europe.

ALBANY. July 7 The state's highest court ruled in effect today that it was unconstitutional for a Long Island school board to have barred Pet Seeger, the folk singer, from giving a concert last March in a high school auditorium.
BRIANCON, France, July 7-- This was the day the old pros set out to take the Tour de France away from the young pros.

Greenwich Village will be the scene of a walking tour at 2:30 P.M. Sunday sponsored by the Museum of the City of New York. The tour will go from Jackson Square to St. John's-in-the-Village via Bank Street. The group will meet at Jackson Square, 13th Street and Eighth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, July 7. A $449,580 Federal grant to underwrite most of the cost of setting up a new system of "portable parks" in New York City has been approved by the Department of Housing and Urban Renewal.

RYE, N.Y., July 7 Boy Scouts of the Hutchinson River Council in eastern Westchester County are sailing on Long Island Sound through the benevolence of a widow who left them $2.9-million with a provision that it be used just for waterfront activities.

PITTSBURGH, July 7 (UPI)-- A demand for a 17 per cent wage increase has been served on Westinghouse Electric Corporation by the Federation of Westinghouse Independent Salaried Unions, it was announced today.

ATLANTA, July 8 (UPI) Printers agreed late today to end a two-day unauthorized work stoppage that halted publication of Atlanta's two major newspapers the morning Constitution and the afternoon Journal.

IN an age in which many labor leaders stay long in power, Paul LeRoy-Siemiller is a late-comer to a top labor role that will be relatively brief. The tall, rough-hewn Midwesterner took control of the International Association of Machinists last, year when he was just four years away...

BETHLEHEM, Pa., July 8 Mr. and Mrs. Peter B. Bradley have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Lord Bradley, to James Edward Rinehart, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy Rinehart of Roanoke, Va.

Mr. and Mrs. Roy Gordon Davis of Cali, Colombia, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Rose Davis, to N. Maxson Terry Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Terry of Dover, Del. A December wedding is planned.

Mr. and Mrs. Stewart G. Anderson of 130 East End Avenue have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marilyn Louise Anderson, to Keith Richard Boyle; son of Mr. and Mrs. Keith E. Boyle of De Kalb, Ill. The wedding is planned for Aug. 13 in Riverside, Conn., where the Andersons are staying for the summer.
HARTFORD, July 8 David A. Wilson, a prominent lawyer who was Democratic State Chairman from 1931 to 1935, died today at St. Francis Hospital after a brief illness at the age of 84.

LOS ANGELES, July 8 Alarmed by the national attention focused on its dispute with the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee and the Congress of Racial Equality, the N.A.A.C.P. deleted today a critical paragraph of a resolution calling for a review of the association's relations with civil rights action groups.

The Erie-Lackawanna, Railroad and the Delaware Hudson Railroad both yesterday asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to delay the merger of the New York Central into the Pennsylvania Railroad, which now is scheduled to become effective Aug. 12.
A trade of city-owned land for the 292-acre New York Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn was suggested yesterday by Carl Madonick, city Real Estate Commissioner.

A report, which was later denied, that President Johnson had agreed to sell surplus grain to Communist China caused prices of the futures of such commodities to vary widely yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

PLEASANT VALLEY, N.Y., July 8 City Council President Frank D. O'Connor toured four Hudson Valley counties today in his campaign for the Democratic nomination for Governor. The leisurely tour through Greene, Columbia, Dutchess and Ulster Counties was in marked contrast to Mr. O'Connor's jet' trip yesterday to Binghamton, Buffalo, Rochester, Syracuse, Schenectady and Albany.
PRETORIA, South Africa, July 8 (Reuters) The South African Reserve Bank raised its discount rate today to 6 per cent from 5 per cent as the Government announced a new drive against inflation.

"The Negro American," a symposium edited by Talcott Parsons and Kenneth B. Clark, with a foreword by President Johnson, will be published by Houghton Mifflin on Aug. 4. The contributors are 30 leaders in the civil-rights movement and scholars. Mr. Parsons is professor of sociology at Harvard University and Mr. Clark is professor of psychology at the City College of New York.
Fire Chief John O'Hagan charged yesterday that salvagers had been slow in pumping volatile naphtha from the tanks of the damaged British tanker Alva Cape.

WASHINGTON, July 8 Thirty-three Republican chairmen from the "bedroom" counties of America took a look at a 40-million-vote potential today and tried to figure out the mechanics of corralling a bigger share of it.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., July 8 Don Spero of the New York A.C., the 1965 Diamond Sculls champion at Henley and twice the national titleholder, won the singles sculls final today in the world's rowing trials on Hunter's Island Lagoon.
The long-threatened end of the Paramount Theater was finally accomplished in a few hours yesterday afternoon at an auction in a smallish lobby behind the Broadway ticket-box.
PARIS, July 8 Science ministers from six European countries and Australia reached agreement here today on how to save their common space organization.
Those "worthless" uranium stocks that have been cluttering up the safety deposit box may be worth more than you think.
KARACHI, Pakistan, July 8 Former Foreign Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto will cease to be a member of the Pakistani Cabinet on Sept. 1, it was announced in Rawalpindi today.

CYNTHIA OZICK'S long, lapidary, Jamesian work is described as a first novel. But it has none of the visible signs of a novice. There is nothing hesitant or tentative either about the writing or its assured tone. She goes about her task with the gusto of a virtuoso. Her book consists of large individual scenes: a child's visit to Europe,...
WASHINGTON July 8 Rail carloadings in the week ending July 2 produced an estimated 13.8 billion ton-miles 6 per cent higher than the corresponding 1965 week.

BALTIMORE, July 8 (AP) Boog Powell led off the ninth inning with his 19th homer tonight, bringing the league-leading Baltimore Orioles a 2-1 victory over California. The loss snapped the Angels' winning streak at five.

ATLANTA, July 8 (AP) Jim Grabowski of Illinois and Donny Anderson of Texas Tech, two Green Bay rookies who reportedly cost the Packers close to $1-million, will meet tomorrow night as rivals in the AllAmerica football game at Atlanta Stadium.
A Northwest Orient jet liner with 84 paying customers aboard took off from Kennedy Airport last night despite the strike of machinists that has crippled Northwest and four other major airliners.
A General Electric official charged yesterday that the general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board was "escalating the probability of a national strike in the electrical industry."

Herbert L. Haber was sworn in yesterday as the city's first director of labor relations. He will not take over full time, however, until Aug. 1, when he will leave his present job as a labor relations executive with the Publishers Association of New York City.

The airline strike caused some frustration and many shattered vacation plans in the metropolitan area yesterday, but in general a fine balance was maintained between... travelers and available transport.
BERLIN, July 8 (AP) Scuffling broke out today at West Berlin's Free University during a demonstration against the Vietnam war.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 8 United States Navy fighterbombers sank two North Vietnamese PT boats and heavily damaged two others yesterday in a three-hour battle 30 miles east of Haiphong.

DUSSELDORF, Germany, July 8 North Rhine-Westphalia, which has the largest population of any West German state, votes Sunday in an election that could have far-reaching effects on the future of Chancellor Ludwig Erhard's coalition Government in Bonn.
LONDON, July 8 The inquiry into American allega-

George Gregory Jr. took a cultural swing through Harlem Thursday evening as he was getting ready for his tour of duty as "night mayor" of New York, the after-hours standby for Mayor Lindsay at City Hall. It was no tourist jaunt for Mr. Gregory, a city Civil Service Commissioner.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 8 (AP)-- An amended petition in a $1-million suit involving letters written by President Warren G. Harding adds the names of the New York Times Company and a trustee of the Ohio Historical Society as defendants.
GANGTOK, Sikkim The Gyalmo of Sikkim tucked her toes under the folds of her fleecy pink lounging robe and tackled the pile of mail and packages.
WESTBURY, L.I. July 8 Oxygen, ice packs and a horse's natural bent for racing may keep Pluvier III of Sweden in tomorrow night's Roosevelt International Trot at Roosevelt Raceway.

OKLAHOMA CITY, July 8 (AP) Oklahoma today welcomed home a favorite son, Lieut. Col. Thomas P. Stafford, and made his Gemini 9 spaceship partner, Comdr: Eugene A. Cernan, an honorary citizen of the state.

WHEN a player has a long; strong minor suit, three no-trump usually proves to be the best game contract. But this principle can be carried too far, and when the distribution is really freakish, 11 tricks may be easier to make than nine.

Thousands of businessmen, vacationers and military personnel were stranded in cities around the country and thousands more anxiously sought alternate means of transportation as the biggest airline strike in United States history started yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) The National Aeronautics and Space Administration hired the services of the Communications Satellite Corporation today in support of the Apollo astronaut program for a fee of $8.85-million a year.

A major job of rescheduling and reorganizing flights in and out of the Washington National Airport is under way among the 13 airlines affected by the new restrictions imposed by the Federal Aviation Agency.
WASHINGTON, July 8 The head of a Maryland engineering company was granted a patent this week for a "bow thruster" designed to enable pilots to maneuver ships in harbors and other narrow waterways.
Councilman J. Daniel Diggs filed a resolution with the City Council yesterday demanding that a committee be appointed "to study the legality and possibility of seceding from the State of New York."

Opposing Democratic factions in Brooklyn have charged, in separate court actions, that inspectors of the Board of Elections permitted fraud in the June 28 primary. The adversaries disagree, though, as to who defrauded whom.

EASTCHESTER, N.Y., July 8 Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Pohl of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Maureen Anne Pohl, to James Robert Fogarty Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Fogarty of Greenwich, Conn.
A crowd of 400 Negroes and Puerto Ricans threw bottles and ash-can covers at each other last night at crowded intersection in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn.
POMPANO BEACH, Fla., July 8 (UPI) A white grocer accused of striking a Negro boy, an incident that touched off a riot here June 22, pleaded not guilty in municipal court today.

The Charter New York Corporation, the bank holding company that controls the Irving Trust Company here and the Merchants National Bank and Trust Company in Syracuse, announced yesterday that it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering the sale of $35-million of 25year debentures.
BUCHAREST, July 8, (Reuters) Following, in official translation, are excerpts from the Warsaw Pact declaration issued by the Rumania news agency Agerpress today:

WASHINGTON, July 8 Defense Department sources re iterated today their contention that an aerial engagement yesterday between two North Vietnamese MIG-21 jets and two United States F-105 jets involved the first true use of air-to-air missiles by the enemy in the Vietnam war.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) The Agriculture Department reported today that land planted to cotton this year totaled 10,567,000 acres. This was 25 per cent less than last year's total and the smallest cotton acreage in nearly 100 years.

Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes has recommended changing the locks on parking meters as part of a broad plan to stop looting that has cost the city an estimated total of $3million in the last year.
MORRISTOWN, N.J., July 8 David L. Barrett, manager of fuel oil sales for the Humble Oil Refining Company in New York, died last night in his home on Blackberry Lane. His age was 61.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (UPI) The National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced an agreement today with the Communications Satellite Corporation for communications to support the Apollo program to land men on the moon in 1969.
SYDNEY, Australia, July 8 The opposition Labor party is trying to approach North Vietnam to initiate peace talks for Vietnam, where 4,500 Australian soldiers are fighting.

TOKO, July 8 (AP) Secretary of Commerce John T. Connor said today the United States was concerned because liberalization actions by Japan on imports since 1964 "have been few, despite several significant items liberalized over the past year."
ROME, July 8 (Reuters) A "Martian's" request for money and jewelry did not entirely surprise Fernando Russo, a 59year-old lawyer fascinated by space exploits, but the sequel surprised the "Martian."
THE Museum of Modern Art raised its admission price from $1 to $1.25 last week, but has thrown in a couple of small exhibitions that are well worth the extra two bits.
LONDON, July 8 Shortterm money rates continued to rise in London today, adding new fuel to the speculative fires about a possible increase in the bank rate.
BRUSSELS, July 8 The European Common Market's dispute about striped pants has been resolved.
The real-estate concern, that wants to tear down the old Metropolitan Opera House and erect a 40-story office building went to court yesterday to force the city to grant it a demolition permit.
The spot rate on the British pound declined yesterday in moderate trading on foreignexchange markets here.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 8 Miss Caroline M. Houser, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alton Houser of Pomeroy, Wash., was married today to James Parton, son of Mrs. Hugo Parton of Westport, Conn., and the late Mr. Parton. The Rev. Donald Judson Clark performed the Episcopalian ceremony in the Appleton Chapel of Harvard University. A reception was held in the courtyard of the Fogg Museum of Art.

The management of a holding company that controls one railroad, and wants to acquire control of another, can't understand the second railroad's opposition to its take-over bid. The holding company is the Mississippi River Corporation, headed by William G. Marbury. That company now owns 58 per cent of the voting stock of the Missouri Pa cific Railroad, ninth largest rail carrier from the standpoint of annual operating revenues.

Single-minded Federal bureaucracy got a jolt last spring when the people of Petersham, Mass. (population 876), let it be known that they were "not sure" they really wanted the new post office building that the Postmaster General was so thoughtfully planning for them.
WASHINGTON, July 8 The Surveyor 1 spacecraft "is dying" in its 36th day on the moon, scientists said late tonight.
American Metal Climax, Inc., announced yesterday a price increase, averaging 5 per cent, on its molybdenum products.

ONEONTA, N.Y., July 8 (AP)-- Trainmen at seven yards of the Delaware Hudson Railroad system walked off their jobs tonight in a dispute stemming from the abolition of positions by the carrier. The company immediately termed the action "an illegal strike."

ST. ALBANS, Vt., July 8 (AP) A 40-year-old train that has carried Presidents, Prime Ministers and royalty between Washington and Montreal will make its last trip Sunday, signaling the end of rail passenger service for the state of Vermont.

PATERSON, N.J., July 8 Mayor Frank X. Graves Jr. canceled days off and leaves for policemen today after windows were smashed and rocks and bottles were thrown at policemen in the city's predominantly Negro Fourth Ward.

BANGKOK, Thailand While the war thunders on in Vietnam, 400 miles to the east, and Communist terrorists ambush Government patrols in impoverished northeastern Thailand, this sweltering city is experiencing the pangs of prosperity, Western-style.

Mrs. Florence M. Ferguson, secretary of the Borough of Manhattan for 14 years, died Thursday at the Larchmont (N.Y.) Shore Club. The wife of Dr. Edward J. Ferguson, she was 60 years old and lived at 41 Dante Street, Larchmont.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 8 Foreign Minister Adam Malik said today that Indonesia would not sign an agreement with Malaysia until after the formation of a new Cabinet, expected in the next five weeks.
Fifteen American swimmers, more interested in national than personal glory, flew to Europe last night to compete in Warsaw and Moscow.
Dr. Eugene Friedberg, a podiatrist at 220 East 42d Street, died Thursday in his home at 12 Dongan Place, upper Manhattan. He was 5l years old.

THE preview of the season's furniture market at the Chicago Merchandise Mart a few weeks ago has in spired discussions of the growing English trend that department stores all over the country are selling. The trend is amazingly broad, since the new designs have been based on the range of English furniture styles from the 16th to the beginning of the 19th century.

The Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank, which has assets of about $1.5-billion, joined the ranks yesterday of the savings banks in New York City that are offering to pay their depositors a 5 per cent dividend a 4 per cent "regular" dividend, plus a one-half per cent "extra" dividend.

LIBERTY, N.Y., July 8 Capt. Hugo Sundstedt, a former Swedish naval pilot who aspired as far back as 1916 to be the first to cross the Atlantic in a seaplane, died today in Liberty Maimonides Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived in Ferndale.

AUSTIN, Tex., July 8 Ambulance drivers who make emergency calls are in interstate commerce and funeral homes which have such ambulance service are faced with paying their drivers the minimum wage and overtime, retroactive to 1964.
CHICAGO, July 8 (AP) Richie Allen's three-run homer in the fifth inning helped the Philadelphia Phillies to a 5-4 victory over the Chicago Cubs today in a game played under protest by the Cubs.

MONTREAL, July 8 (Canadian Press) The second of three groups of unions representing Canada's 92,700 nonoperating railway employes decided today to turn down a conciliation board report and to take a strike vote across the country.

Greece and Turkey seem to be more serious about trying for an agreement on Cyprus than at any time since the crisis erupted in December 1963. Unfortunately there are elements on the island itself that seem bent on provoking enough incidents to destroy this favorable climate and any chance for resolution of the conflict.

ALTHOUGH it is of modest size, the Sea Cliff Fish Market at 51 University Place towers head and shoulders (or is it head and backfin?) over most of its competitors in Manhattan. The fish is as fresh as can be found at any retail outlet in the city; the varieties are impressive from sea squab and squid to swordfish; and it is all prepared with consummate care.

BUKAVU, the Congo, July 8 (AP) Prince Charles Ndizeye of Burundi announced over the Bjumbura radio today that he had taken over as chief of state in that turbulent kingdom from his ailing father, Mwami Mwambutsa IV, Burundi's King.

WHITE PLAINS, July 8 John H. Crider, a winner of the Pulitzer Prize for editorial writing and a former editor in chief of The Boston Herald, died last midnight at his home at 216 Chelsea Road in Greenburgh. He was 60 years old.
ROME, July 8 (PI) Gen. Attilio Biseo of the Italian Air Force, a leading pilot here between the world wars, died at his home yesterday. He was 64 years old.
LONDON, July 8--The British and French Governments gave their long-awaited final approval today to building a tunnel underneath the English Channel.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 8-- Carl E. Stair, a fund-raising administrator for the world service of the Young Men's Christian Association in New York, died of a heart attack yesterday in the Princeton Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at 9 Horner Lane.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 8 Two friendly underdogs, Democratic candidates for the State Senate from adjacent Suffolk districts, found themselves unwilling rivals today through a typing error made by a Liberal party official.

WASHINGTON, July 8 The index of primary market prices advanced two-tenths of 1 per cent to 105.9 during the week ended July 5, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. Farm products rose in price while processed foods declined. Industrial commodities averaged unchanged.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 8 (AP) Three carloads of white yougsters moved through Sacramento's Skid Row. Shotgun blasts echoed off crumbling walls and two Negro men lay dead. Sixteen suspects were arrested.
WICHITA, Kan., July 8 (UPI) Plans for a round-theworld, nonstop solo flight in a modified sail plane were announced today.
UTSUNOMIYA, Japan, July 8 (AP) The walls caved in on a stretch of an irrigation tunnel near here today and 25 of the 65 workers inside were found dead in a gas-filled pocket, the police reported.
British Government bonds led stock prices to continuing declines on the London Stock Exchange yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 8 Even those who are not themselves trying to get somewhere by air may feel the result of the airline strike.

Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that the city and the Port of New York Authority were, considering bringing a third party into their negotiations over the projected $525-million World Trade Center on the lower West Side.
INDIANAPOLIS, July 8 (AP) Dennis Ralston of Bakersfield, Calif., the top-seeded player, led two other Americans and a foreign entry today into the semifinal round of the Western tennis tournament.

MAMARONECK, N.Y. July 8 A team of 21-year-old amateur golfers, John Baldwin and Steve Robbins, carded a record 61 and won diamond-studded medals and a paper gold star today. Their 10-under-par bestball tally over the East course of the Winged Foot Golf Club in the John G. Anderson Memorial tourney gave them a 36hole aggregate of 131.
A resourceful, if spendthrift, businessman in San Francisco discovered yesterday a way of getting to New York City by flying over the polar icecap and the Atlantic Ocean.
HONG KONG, July 8-- Military analysts say that North Vietnam would have little practical use for any major force of "volunteers" that Soviet-bloc nations might send to fight in the war.
George Washington's jacket wore a 31-year-old coating of grime yesterday but it will be as clean as his breeches after Raymond Stankiewicz finishes his job.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, July 8 (UPI) A group of Cubans hijacked a Soviet-built airliner from Cuba yesterday and landed in Kingston seeking political asylum, it was learned today. Nine Cubans were said to be in protective custody.
Four major lumber associations reported a decrease of 4.1 per cent in production for the week ended July 2, compared with the level in the corresponding 1965 week.
A threat by the city to close its six surviving retail enclosed markets by Aug. 1 has united fishmongers, bagel salesmen and vendors of Madonna and Buddha statuettes in a fighting front.

CAIRO, July 8 Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India arrived today for talks with President Gamal Abdel Nasser, who is expected to endorse her call for a new Geneva conference to try to end the war in Vietnam.
MORGANTOWN, W. Va., July 8 (AP) Paul A. Miller submitted today his resignation as president of West Virginia University to the school's board of governors.

Two laborers were seized early yesterday in Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn, where detectives said they were stealing brass railings from burial plots. The police estimated that $27,000 worth of ornamental brass railings had been stolen in the last six weeks.

PITTSBURGH, July 8 Matty Alou, Willie Stargell and Roberto Clemente, the National League's three leading hitters, and Bill Mazeroski, who is well down the list, lowered the boom on the Mets tonight in both ends of a double-header as the Bucs won, 10-2 and 9-2.
The Hudson River piers occupied by the Holland America Line were a mass of guitars, giggles and girls yesterday.

The United States Court of Appeals here upheld yesterday, by a vote of 2 to 1, a deportation order against an alien on the ground that he was a homosexual when he entered the country from Canada in 1955.

CRANFORD, N.J., July 8 (AP) Henry Bloch, a faculty member of Seton Hall University in South Orange, was appointed conductor and musical director of the Suburban Symphony Orchestra of New Jersey today.
LONDON, July 8 The World Union for Progressive Judaisn decided today to ask the Israeli Government to grant Reform rabbis in Israel the right to perform marriages and similar functions.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 8. (AP) The Minnesota Twins scored five runs after two were out, in the fourth inning, including two on Jim Kaat's home run, and downed the Detroit Tigers, 6-1, tonight.

MUIRFIELD, Scotland, July 8 Phil Rodgers shot a fantastic 30 on the back nine today and took a two-stroke lead in the third round of the British Open as Jack Nicklaus, the halfway leader, collapsed down the stretch. After 54 holes Rodgers was at 210 and Nicklaus at 212.
LONDON, July 7 Sir Anthony Milward, chairman of the beleagured British European Airways, said today that in three months the airline had slipped from "almost top" to "well down the league table."
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 8 The few hogs penned in Saigon's whitewashed stockyards look peaceful enough, but economic experts have warned that their scant numbers imperil the capital's stability.
LONDON, July 8 Fortysix old touring and racing cars will be auctioned tomorrow at the country estate near Southampton of Lord Montagu of Beaulieu, one of Britain's leading antique auto buffs.
Short-term interest rates continued to move upward yesterday.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., July 8 After relinquishing the lead twice to Bill Collins of Harrison, Ray Floyd of Fayetteville, N.C., settled down and won the second annual Concord invitation golf tournament by one stroke today.
NEWPORT, Wales, July 8 (AP) Maria Bueno displayed her finest tennis in a year today and defeated Annette Van Zyl of South Africa, 6-2,6-0, in the final of the Welsh championships.

Warlock, Julian K. Roosevelt's 38-foot yawl from Oyster Bay, L. I., which abandoned the race on Thursday, and Bradley Noyes's 43-foot sloop Tioga of Marblehead, Mass., were the only participants in the ocean race to Denmark reported to United States Coast Guard headquarters in New York yesterday.
BELGRADE, Mont., July 8 (AP)-- A rodeo rider kicked a plane's landing gear into place today while hanging out of the aircraft 9,000 feet above the ground.

With a new warning to city departments to hold down on expenses, Mayor Lindsay has begun the painful effort to live with the revenue program won after so much travail in Albany. Some hard lessons in politics and economics were taught in the legislative session, and others will be learned, administratively, in the months ahead.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 8 The South Vietnamese chief of state said today that North Vietnam should be invaded with ground troops "if it is necessary to end this war."

A fire on an oil company dock set 600 oil drums popping like huge firecrackers yesterday in the middle of a highly volatile petroleum area, at Perth Amboy, N.J. Fed by a northeast wind, the fire raged for three hours.
KLEINBURG, Ont. July 8 A Canadian couple, who 15 years ago bought their first painting, presented to the people of Ontario today an art gallery estimated to be worth nearly $1-million.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 8 (AP) Juan Marichal, supported by Jim Davenport's pinch-hit grand-slam home run, won his l4th game tonight as the National League-leading San Francisco Giants handed the Cincinnati Reds them 10th straight defeat, 7-2.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 8 The British Government forced Israel to withdraw an agreement to a cease-fire in the Suez campaign because it would have removed the justification for the British-French invasion of Egypt.

ALBANY, July 8 (AP) An upstate school board and the Civil Liberties Union asked a State Supreme Court Justice today to declare the state's new law on textbook aid unconstitutional. The law will provide state aid for supplying free textbooks to pupils in grades 7 through 12 in both public and nonpublic schools.

Coney Island was declared "a public nuisance" yesterday by the Department of Health because of the enormous amount of garbage from the Fourth of July weekend that still cluttered large stretches of the beaches.
Most issues on the American Stock Exchange advanced yesterday in quiet trading.

Every American will be hoping fervently that the reports, rumors, guesses and gossip about Hanoi's yearning for peace and Peking's willingness to accept an end to the Vietnamese conflict are true. But hopes, wishes and prayers do not end a war. There is not enough substance as yet to the information to lend confidence that it represents a genuine trend.
MOSCOW, July 8 (AP) Jerzy Pawlowski of Poland retained his saber title at the world fencing championships today. It was the 18th gold medal the Pole has won in major competition.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 112.1 on Thursday from 113 on Wednesday.

A cellar fire smoldered for about six hours yesterday in a city-owned building in Hell's Hundred Acres, drawing about 150 firemen, 35 pieces of fire apparatus and hundreds of spectators from the Foley Square area.

Federal Judge Sylvester J. Ryan reserved decision yesterday on a Securities and Exchange Commission motion for a preliminary injunction against Great American Industries, Inc., and eight other defendants, including Walter S. Mack, chairman, on charges of fraud in the sale of the company's stock.
The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday the appointment of Michael W. Moynihan to the new post of director of public affairs.
The Board of Estimate sent millions of dollars worth of capital improvements to Mayor Lindsay yesterday for authorization.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., July 8 Sumner F. Larchar, a retired vice president of Thomas A. Edison Industries here, died on Wednesday at Point Pleasant Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at Shore Acres in Point Pleasant.
BALTIMORE, July 8 (AP) Inmates rioted for two hours today at the Maryland Penitentiary, setting fire to four buildings, throwing rocks, bricks and clubs, and looting the commissary.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 8 President Johnson said today he had signed the bill creating the American Revolution Bicentennial Commission to plan this nation's celebration of the 200th anniversary of its independence.

Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that "highly organized, militant, right-wing groups" were seeking to kill the civilian-controlled police review board and disclosed that he was studying ways to block a public referendum on the issue.

Negotiations between the mangement of the World Journal Tribune, Inc., and the mailers' union to end the 75-day shutdown of the morning, evening and Sunday newspapers were recessed at 6 P.M. yesterday until 9 A.M., Monday, after a four-hour bargaining session.

The unsubsidized segment of the American merchant marine expects a ruling from the Federal Government on what it considers to be a matter of life and death can subsidized American lines continue to draw subsidies for the transport of military cargoes in competition with unsubsidized lines.
NEW DELHI, July 8 The United States agreed today to provide India with $150-million for imports of raw materials, components and spare parts.
Sammy Davis jetted in late last night from Miami, And judging by what happened at the Forest Hills tennis stadium he probably didn't even use a plane.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 8 (UPI) Striking members of the International Association of Machinists carried their strike against five airlines to the United States space center here today, disrupting some work at the Project Apollo site.
SEATTLE, July 8 (UPI) When Clifford Jones, 19 years old, stole a car, radio recently, he made sure he left his work badge, with his name on it, in the automobile.

HONOLULU, July 8 (AP) Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara has concluded talks with the United States military commanders in the Pacific in an attempt to solve the problem of supplying American troops in Vietnam.

Eli Lilly Co., a leading producer of pharmaceuticals, biological and antibiotic drug products, achieved record sales and earnings in the first six months of this year, according to the semiannual report issued yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 8 Federal grants totaling $23.9-million to finance existing antipoverty programs in New York City for the coming year were announced today by the Office of Economic Opportunity.
WASHINGTON, July 8 There is no sign here that the United States plans to mount or support a major ground attack against North Vietnam.
ROME, July 8 Arthur J. Goldberg, United States Representative at the United Nations, spent 50 minutes with Pope Paul VI today. What they discussed was not disclosed.
Patrick J. Concannon, a retired New York City police captain, died Thursday in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived at 43-23 169th Street, Flushing, Queens.

Bit by bit a badgered society is beginning to close in on the telephone pest. A few days ago the Senate passed a bill that would make it a Federal offense to engage in obscene calls across a state line, and now the New York Telephone Company has launched a campaign to protect its customers from the "aggressive telephone solicitor with a 'pushy' sales pitch."
KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., July 8 Sugar Ray Robinson announced today that "after 15 rounds next Wednesday, there will be a new middleweight champion."
THE concert performance of Mozart's "Don Giovanni" by, the Metropolitan Opera at Lewisohn Stadium last night drew the second largest audience of the two-week-old season.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, July 8 Former President Celal Bayar, who was sentenced to life imprisonment for crimes against the state after he was deposed in the 1960 military coup d'etat, was pardoned today by President Cevdet, Sunay.

Braulio Baeza had three victories at Aqueduct yesterday in seven attempts, but the cool Panamanian failed to win the race that he wanted mostly, the feature. And it wasn't for lack of trying, artistically or juridically.
CAMDEN, N.J., July 8 (AP) The new plan for reapportioning New Jersey's 15 congressional districts was upheld by a Superior Court judge today.
Education experts consider James Farmer's proposal to combat illiteracy an unconventional but promising venture.
Two patrolmen were suspended yesterday, after one was accused of having sold the other 10 gallons of gasoline for $1 from the service pump at Brookly Police Headquarters.
Joseph G. Munz, president of the Hamburg Savings Bank of Brooklyn, was elected yesterday as chairman of the savings Bank Life Insurance Fund of New York.

The United Shoe Machinery Corporation has acquired the Parker-Kalon division of the General American Transportation Corporation, it was announced yesterday by William S. Brewster, president of United.

ARGYLE, Minn., July 8 (AP) The townspeople were coming back and living was returning to normal here today after a partial evacuation of this northwestern Minnesota village following a spraying with a highly poisonous insecticide.

THE peripatetic art observer who travels the European exhibition circuit these days must be prepared to cope with every manner of esthetic and anti-esthetic sensation. The great museums still stand in all their aristocratic glory, but these repositories of the sublime masterworks of the past are anything but havens from the milling throng.
OMAHA, Neb., July 8 (AP) Nearly 200 Negroes most of them in their teens were signed up for city jobs today and 70 reported for work as Omaha moved to keep its promise to help find them jobs.
BERLIN, July 8 (AP) A former Auschwitz concentration camp doctor has been executed in East Germany for "crimes against humanity," A.D.N., the official East German news agency reported today.
BOONTON, N.J., July 8 Mike Burke, the 29-year-old pro at Deal, won the 46th New Jersey open golf championship by eight shots today with a 72hole total of 279 at the Knoll Golf Club.

WASHINGTON, July 8 A strike against five major airlines by the International Association of Machinists disrupted most of the nation's air travel today. No break appeared likely at least until negotiators meet again tomorrow.

OLD GREENWICH, Conn., July 8 Mr. and Mrs. Bradford N. Clark of New York and Old Greenwich have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sara Miranda Clark, to David Miles Reeves Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Reeves of Old Greenwich.
Overcoming early weakness, stock prices registered small gains in moderate trading yesterday.

SEOUL, South Korea, July 8 South Korean leaders told Secretary of State Dean Rusk today that the United States should strive for a military victory in Vietnam and reject any peace that signifies appeasement of the Communists.
ATHENS, Ga., July 8 Two Ku Klux Klansmen, previously acquitted of the murder of Lemuel A. Penn, a prominent Negro educator, have been found guilty under a Federal civil rights conspiracy statute.

GENEVA, July 8 Talks be tween key representatives of the major trading nations during the last week have shown the Kennedy round of tariffcutting negotiations to be "really on the road," a highranking international trade official said today.

PHILADELPHIA, July 8 (UPI) The United States Court of Appeals set a hearing for Monday today for arguments on an appeal by a New York publisher, Ralph Ginzburg, for a stay of sentence imposed on a conviction of sending obscene materials through the mails.
1 PLUVIER III of Sweden, a 7-year-old compactly con formed trotter, has won over mud, cinder and snow...He is the first foreign winner of the International to defend.
The summer season at the Plaza Hotel's Persian Room began this week and the first attraction was a delight.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 8 (AP) A temporary restraining order enjoining the fire fighters' union from attempts to force the city into collective bargaining was issued today after firemen had called a partial work stoppage.

The 5-cent fare on the Staten Island ferry is expected to be increased to 15 cents or 20 cents by the fall of 1967, the first deputy commissioner of the city's Marine and Aviation Department said yesterday. The deputy commissioner, Herbert B. Hauberg, said the city was losing $10million a year on the service.
The largest official delegation of Roman Catholic observers to attend a meeting of the World Council of Churches will participate next week in a "church and society dialogue" in Geneva.
The New York Football Giants made another move to strengthen their defensive line by obtaining Maury Youmans yesterday in a three-way trade among National Football League
The Columbia Broadcasting System and the National Broadcasting Company have protested a Defense Department decision to withhold films of the American bombing raids made on North Vietnam June 29.
A numbers racket said to have grossed between $1-million and $2-million annually was broken up yesterday when the police raided an apartment at 315 Fourth Avenue in Brooklyn and arrested five men.
Abercrombie Fitch has appointed three vice presidents, Earle K. Angstadt Jr., president announced yesterday.
The current airline strike isn't likely to affect major league baseball teams for at least a couple of days, since all of them are engaged in series that don't end until Sunday.
OTTAWA, July 8 Delegates to a Commonwealth Caribbean-Canada conference postponed indefinitely today a decision on the question of joining the Organization of American States.

CLEVELAND, July 8 (AP) More than 30,000 hourly workers of the Ford Motor Company at 13 plants in five states and Canada were left idle today as a result of a strike by about 8,600 employes at the company's three suburban Brook Park plants.

ST. LOUIS, July 8 (AP) Bob Bruce, a right-hander who had won only one of seven previous decisions, and Claude Raymond held St. Louis to three hits tonight as they pitched the Houston Astros to a 6-1 victory over the Cardinals.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (UPI) Trouble shaped up today for any physicians making profits from ownership in pharmacies, drug companies, repackaging companies and other businesses used by their patients.

TORONTO, July 8 (Canadian Press) George A. Drew, retired Canadian politician and diplomat, and Mrs. Phyllis Laidlaw McCullagh, widow of George McCullagh, former publisher of The Globe and Mail and The Telegram, were married here yesterday at Grace Church-onthe-Hill.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, July 8 Six noncommissioned officers were arrested today in the alleged plot to overthrow the Government of Prime Minister Dudley S. Senanayake last Feb. 17. Thirty people are now held in the case.

CHICAGO, July 8-- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. said today that the civil rights movement was "very, very close" to a permanent split over the black power issue and that civil rights leaders should meet immediately to patch up their differences.

SPARTANBURG, S.C. An industrial boom is advancing along the fringes of Interstate Highway 85 from Durham, N.C., to Atlanta. It is bringing new prosperity to the region, but it also has caused a severe labor shortage.
MYTHO, South Vietnam, July 7 Once again the United States Navy has a small, swift boat numbered 109.

The New York Yankees won a game and lost a game against the Washington Senators last night, but lost something really important when Mickey Mantle tore a muscle in his left leg after hitting two titanic home runs.

BUCHAREST, July 8 The Warsaw Pact nations issued a broadly worded invitation to the nations of Western Europe today to join them in "a general European conference for the discussion of questions related to insuring security in Europe."

The new 95,000-ton tanker World Standard, under construction in Japan for the fastgrowing shipping empire of Y.K. Pao, has been chartered before completion to a major American oil company, Mr. Pao announced here yesterday.

ABERDEEN, N.C., July 8 Mr. and Mrs. Joseph C. Robbins have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alice Jean Robbins, to Edwin B. Howard Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Belhaven, N.C. An Aug. 27 wedding is planned.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) The United States welcomed today India's call for a Geneva peace conference on Vietnam and suggested that a cease-fire could be the first order of business.
MINEOLA, L.I. July 8 Information on possible links between Long Island bookmakers and casinos in Las Vegas, Nev., has been turned up in a radio on the home of an asserted member of the Cosa Nostra.
DUBLIN, July 8 (AP) Kathy Harter of Seal Beach, Calif., and Margaret Smith of Australia gained the final of the Irish tennis championships today.

MELBOURNE, Australia, July 8 (UPI) The Juilliard String Quartet of New York tonight completed a highly successful nine-concert tour of Australia. They were, given a huge ovation by the audience at the Melbourne Town Hall and received a glowing review.

FORT DIX, N.J., July 8--Three Army privates who have announced that they would refuse to board ships for Vietnam next week will probably miss the ships because the Army is holding them here to investigate their antiwar activities.

The old saying that "you can't get there from here," attributed to a confused hayseed unable to figure a route home for a lost driver, seemed almost to come true yesterday for grounded airline passengers.

TRENTON, July 8 (AP) A merger of the Madison Savings and Loan Association into the Carteret Savings and Loan Association of Newark was approved today by State Banking Commissioner Charles R. Howell of New Jersey.
PARAMUS, N.J., July 8 Mr. and Mrs. David Johnstone of Montclair won a Women's New Jersey Golf Association mixed foursome tournament today with a gross best-ball 37, 36 73 at the Arcola Country Club.

OLD GREENWICH, Conn., July 8 Dr. Wendell J. Washburn of 1 Little Cove Lane, a physician in Greenwich for 45 years until his retirement in 1956, died of a heart attack today at his home. He was 72 years old.

Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday the formation of a task force on municipal archives to assure that historical records would no longer molder in damp cellars or be mutilated by collectors seeking autographs of Hamilton, Jay and other Revolutionary figures.
HATTIESBURG, Miss., July 8 (UPI)-- Carpenters supervised by two Mennonites began rebuilding today the home of Vernon Dahmer, which was burned by nightriders earlier this year.
CINCINNATI, July 8 (AP) Carol Mann shot a five-underpar 67 today and took a onestroke lead in the first round of the $20,000 Buckeye women's open golf tournament.
TURIN, Italy, July 8 The Tour de France began a loop through the Italian Alps today on a note of high drama and ended the act on a note of comic opera.

WASHINGTON, July 8 The issues in the strike by the International Association of Machinists against five major airlines revolve chiefly around wage increases and a cost-ofliving allowance in a proposed three-year contract.
The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit upheld yesterday the convictions of four men for conspiracy to import heroin from France and distribute it in this country.
LONDON, July 8 Mary Wilson has just received her first payment as a poet.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 8 The Saratoga Per forming Arts Center received its shakedown last night. For the first time, the $4-million installation created by Vollmer Ostrower Associates went through its paces, complete with dancers on stage, orchestra in the pit and nearly all of its 5,100 seats filled. It was a preview of the official opening that takes place tomorrow evening.

ATLANTA, July 9 (AP) Randy Johnson of Texas A. and I., a rookie quarterback with the new Atlanta Falcons of the National Football League, led the West to a 24-7 victory over the East tonight in the Coaches' All-America football game.
With the help of an assortment of municipal and civicminded friends, a real estate group is raising the roof on lower Fifth Avenue and all for the toy industry.
The Liberal party and the Conservative party examined the record of the 1966 State Legislature yesterday, and neither was happy with the lawmakers' performance.
MIAMI BEACH, July 9 James R. Hoffa plans next year to demand nationwide labor negotiations with leading grocery store chains and consolidation on a regional basis with big dairy companies.

Dr. Allison J. Vosseler, who had been director of surgery at Methodist Hospital of Brooklyn for many years, died Friday in New England Baptist Hospital in Boston, after a short illness. His age was 58.

THE free publication of "Story of O" in this country is an event of considerable importance not because the book has more than limited artistic or literary merit (it probably doesn't) or because it is in some way attractive (it isn't), but because it marks the end of any coherent restrictive application of the concept of pornography to books.

IF history teaches any lesson at all, it is that there are no historical lessons, Lucien Fevre wrote in a famous passage. Like most generalizations about history, this is only partly true. Some people suffer from a surfelt of history; they are in danger of being hypnotized by their past, of being overcome by its weight.

SOMERS, N.Y., July 9 When Rabbi Joseph Schapiro arrived at the synagogue of the Hebrew Congregation of Somers for Sabbath services this morning, he found the house of worship desecrated for the second time in six months.
Newsprint mill's in Eastern Canada have added nearly 400,000 tons of production capacity to their 1966 potential output by obtaining clearance for a seven-day operation.
Miss Nanci Carol Fried and Frederic Mark Alderman were married last evening at the Starlight Roof of the WaldorfAstoria by Rabbi Gerald A. Goldman.
HOUSTON, July 9 (AP) Workmen installed artificial grass in the outfield area of the Astrodome this week.

A Brooklyn man with a police record dating to 1953 was arrested at his home in Manhattan Beach early today in a raid that turned up 100 stolen credit cards and $5,000 in stolen American Express Travelers Checks.
PEKING, July 9 Communist China ruled out today a reconvening of the Geneva conference on Indochina unless the United States withdrew its forces from South Vietnam.

MADISON, Wis., July 6 David Carley, a candidate for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination who has forced the Vietnam war issue into the campaign, said today it had become the "No. 1 political question."
"He covers ground like an antelope, his strokes are fair, but he doesn't seem to follow the ball too well."
The victim of an attack has a better chance of being helped if there is only one witness, rather than several, according to a study being made here as a result of the Kitty Genovese murder.

IN Joseph E. Garland's powerful representation, Capt. James William Patillo emerges as the epitome of the Gloucester fisherman of the heroic period just before the Civil War. Before our eyes we see take shape a man who is a force of nature, born to drive ...
Three of the four announced candidates for the Democratic nomination for Governor attacked Governor Rockefeller yesterday on a variety of issues.
A revolving scholarship program for needy college seniors of average rather than superior academic standing has enabled 31 students to graduate this month.

ALGIERS, July 9 Algeria celebrated with great fanfare recently the return from Syria of the ashes of its great 19th-century resistance hero, Emir El-Hadj Abdelkader. The event, part of this year's Independence Day celebrations, had been the focus of the official press for three weeks.
As part of its "International Aid Day" late in June, South Vietnam released three stamps that acknowledge postally the help received from other nations. The symbolism of the ...
The National Teacher Corps, one of the most imaginative and least expensive educational proposals to come out of Washington, is in danger of death by starvation.

RICHMOND, July 9 An unusually hard and unsettling Congressional primary campaign in this usually politically placid state is coming to a climax this weekend. For the first time in memory, youthful, moderate challengers are being taken seriously in the Virginia Democratic primary, and some of them may even win.

Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday the appointment of a 23-man Executive Volunteer Corps that will have the dual job of trying to help local businessmen expand their enterprises and of attracting new business and industry to the city.

WE can't master change. It is too vast, too swift. We'd kill our selves trying. It is essential, however, to try to understand transformations directly affecting us. That may not be possible either, but we have no choice.

WADING RIVER, L.I., July 9 New York City's Public School 181M has horses, an ocean, a teacher who can make a child vandal wonder what happens next in the opera, and something even rarer for the 128 troubled youngsters who live here a mother's tender care.
LONDON, July 9 (AP) A young American climbed 60 feet in scaffolding around the dome of St. Paul's Cathedral early today, and set off a wild scare.
A man whose son drowned in a canoeing accident will continue his crusade for a canoe and rowboat safety measure that failed to win approval in the Legislature.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 9 The Elizabeth Housing Authority voted this week to crack down on moonlight moving by tenants of housing projects to avoid rent payments. The new policy is linked to an ordinance requiring all city residents to obtain a moving permit at City Hall.

THE scene is a honey-beige suite on the 39th floor of the Hotel Pierre. Pacing the floor like a prize jaguar in a velvet cage is Hollywood super star George Peppard. Polite, suspicious, careful, he looks like an all-American basketball player who has suddenly inherited his father's business.

RIO GRANDE CITY, Tex., July 9 A Roman Catholic bishop last night offered to negotiate with growers in behalf of thousands of farm laborers seeking higher wages in the fruit and vegetable growing center along the Texas-Mexico border.

WASHINGTON, July 9 Mr. and Mrs. John Moors Cabot of Washington and Manchester, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Tracy Cabot, to Bogislav von Wentzel. His parents are Mrs. Severs Eckert of Schweifeld, Germany, and the late Ernest Hasso von Wentzel.

ST. PAUL, Minn., July 9 (AP) Gov. Karl F. Rolvaag said today he would file in the Minnesota primary election in a bid for re-election despite failure to gain the endorsement of the Democratic-Farmer-Labor party.

POCANTICO HILLS, N.Y., July 9 The Pocantico Hills Residents Committee charged today that outsiders were spreading politically motivated falsehoods through this Sleepy Hollow estate community about the projected relocation of State Route 117.

GLADWYNE, Pa., July 9 The engagement of Miss Sharon Cooper to William Wallis Schwarze has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Donald Russell Cooper, parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Herbert Schwarze of Caldwell, N.J.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., July 9 Miss Marilyn Bankart, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Reginald Bankart, was married today to Thomas Walter Tucker 2d, son of Dr. and Mrs. Tucker of Spring City, Pa. The Rev. James Seth Stewart performed the ceremony in the Hitchcock Presbyterian Church.

WASHINGTON, July 9 An American and a European computer will talk with each other for a month by the Early Bird satellite this fall in a communications test with broad social and economic implications.
LOS ANGELES, July 9 There was a curious air of ineffectuality about the National Governors Conference that occupied 48 of the 50 state executives at the posh Century Plaza Hotel here this week.

BASEL, Switzerland Motorists entering this idyllic country usually head at once for the peaks, glaciers and alpine meadows, and their rewards are rich. For a change of pace, however, and perhaps a pleasant surprise, one should try driving at the lower altitudes of river level; the guideline for such a trip in Switzerland is, of course, the Rhine.
BALTIMORE, July 9 Jackie Warner's two-run homer gave the California Angels a 2-1 victory tonight over the Baltimore Orioles in the second game of a double-header with the American League leaders.

BELGRADE, July 9 There is only one historic personality," declared the Macedonian Communist at the historic Central Committee meeting of July 1 on Brioni Island. "That is Comrade Tito, and he has proved this by his activity at this plenum."
The two verbose declarations emanating from the Warsaw Pact meeting in Bucharest can be taken as a smoke screen designed to hide the organization's real problems.

A new deputy director, named yesterday to help conduct the city's summer antipoverty program, said that he would seek a $2-million loan from banks to get the lagging program in full operation by Tuesday.

LOS ANGELES, July 9 The 57th annual convention of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People ended today after calling on the board of directors to re-examine the basis of cooperation with all other national and regional civil rights groups.

There was a time when it led from farm to village, not directly but pasing other farms along the way. It wandered, following the valleys, avoiding the hills, because teamsters chose the longer, easier way for their draft animals-first oxen and later horses.

ATHENS, Ga., July 9 Two Ku Klux Klansmen previously acquitted by a Georgia State Court jury in the murder of Lemuel A. Penn, a Negro educator, were sentenced today to the maximum term of 10 years in Federal prison for having conspired to violate the civil rights of Mr. Penn and other Negroes.

WELLESLEY, Mass., July 9 Miss Lee Cameron Higgins was married today to Donald Chapman Pratt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Herman Pratt of Madison, Conn. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. Beverly Moore Higgins of Weston and Bradley Carter Higgins of Worcester.
Both sides in the 76-day-old strike against the World Journal Tribune Inc., prepared yesterday for new negotiations that are scheduled to resume tomorrow after a weekend recess.

AFTER all the initial commotion over "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?" all the wailing of the censors, the shouting of the reviewers and the mumbling and grumbling of those patrons who have come away stunned and confused there remains one simple statement to be made about this film: it is a magnificent triumph of determined audacity.

SEOUL, South Korea, July 9-- Secretary of State Dean Rusk, ending his Asian tour here, said today that he had found signs wherever he visited of a new interest in economic and social development coupled with a concern for a constructive peace.

WILLOUGHBY, Ohio, July 9 Mr. and Mrs. George E. Merryweather of Waite Hill have announced the engagement of Mr. Merryweather's daughter, Miss Juliet Irene Merryweather, to Thomas Goodwin Evans, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul T. Evans of Kirtland Hills.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) Four of the five airlines struck by the machinists union have a mutual-aid financial pact with four non-struck air carriers.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector) July 9 Four months ago, many Israelis were saying they were voluntarily giving up part of their pay to fight inflation. Last week they discovered they had been deluding one another.

SEVERAL novelists in the past few years have returned to the device of the diary form Tanizaki with "Diary of a Mad Old Man," Colin Wilson with "The Sex Diary of Gerard Sorme," Evan S. Connell Jr. with "Diary of a Rapist." In "Julian," from a mosaic of invented ...

AUCKLAND, N.Z., July 9 A speaker at a recent public meeting called for a reduction of New Zealand's ties with Britain in the interest of true nationhood. Few protests were heard and they came almost entirely from recent British migrants.

THE producers of "Hey, Landlord!" the series which N.B.C. will televise on Sunday nights next season, stand convicted of flagrant type-casting. How else explain, their choice of Sandy Baron as co-star of the weekly comedy series?

KARACHI, Pakistan, July 9 Hundreds of demonstrators today burned an effigy of President Johnson and an American flag in protests against the United States bombing of oil depots near Hanoi and Haiphong.

MUIRFIELD, Scotland, July 9 Jack Nicklaus of Columbus, Ohio, won the British Open today by one stroke from another American, Doug Sanders, and Dave Thomas of Britain with a four-round score of 70, 67, 75, 70 282. Nicklaus now has won all the major titles in golf open to professional players.

THE museum sign says, "Some like it dark," and a burly visitor gingerly lifts a tiny curtain to peer at the family of field mice within. "Ah," he breathes. Along the woodland trail troop four small boys, escorted by two women, one pushing a baby in a stroller. The nature center is perform ing its function.
Spectators in the Metropolitan area will be able to watch portions of Wednesday's Around Long Island Marathon from a variety of vantage points.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 9 (AP) A leading Roman Catholic spokesman said today that Catholics would support "any genuinely nationalistt platform" in the Sept. 11 election of an assembly to draw up a constitution.

Dr. and Mrs. John Corran McCauley Jr. of 7 Gracie Square and Willsboro, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Hamilton McCauley, to Robert Renfrew Trostle, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wayne M. Trostle of Rocky River, Ohio.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (UPI) Even if used to the fullest extent, technology can barely keep up with air and water pollution, a Congressional advisory panel reported today.
Two breed match shows and a match trial are scheduled for today in the nearby area.

DEAL, N.J., July 9 St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Anne Jones Evans to David Henry Gibbons. The couple's parents are David O. Evans of Elberon, the late Mrs. Evans and Mr. and Mrs. Henry B. Gibbons of Dallas.

WEST HARTFORD, Conn., July 9 Miss Loulie Gordon Hyde, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Holbrook Hyde, was married this afternoon to John Alfred Sutro Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Sutro of San Francisco. The Rev. Charles Wilding performed the ceremony in St. John's Episcopal Church. Mrs. Malcolm MacKinnon was matron of honor, and Donald M. Mackey Jr. was best man.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., July 9 The annual Silvermine Guild Chamber Music Festival will open tomorrow night in Silvermine's Gifford Hall with a concert by the Silvermine String Quartet and Robert Bloom, oboist. The program will consist of works by Cimarosa, Beethoven, Schubert and Britten.
Three warm weather ailments usually minor but sometimes serious enough to spoil several sun-filled summer days made the news last week: poison ivy, soap-caused sun rash and food poisoning.

The end of pollution of the seas by oil is in sight as a result of the coming into force next year of several amendments to the 1954 International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution of the sea by Oil.

THOUGH garden hoses are now made of dur able plastics that will withstand a great deal of hard wear and abuse, they will still develop leaks if carelessly handled or if the fittings have been damaged.

TURIN, Italy, July 9 With the bicycle riders in the Tour de France resting here today before heading for home through the Great Saint Bernard Pass tomorrow, nobody is saying the nasty word "doping" any more.
CAIRO, July 9 Egypt's population-control program, which has been gaining momentum over the last eight months, has been stimulated by a new $488,000 grant from the Ford Foundation.

PALERMO, Sicily After a mildly disappointing season last year, Sicily is taking steps to develop its tourist facilities, as well as to call world attention to its natural and archeological attractions.
Leaders of the National Committee for a Sane Nuclear Policy recommended yesterday that the draft be abolished and replaced by a professional volunteer force.

BELIZE, British Honduras, July 9 Just off a dark road two miles outside of town, the Premier of this self-governing British colony was denounced Thursday night as a "traitor" ready to "sell out" to neighboring Guatemala.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 9 The Security Council is still concerned officially not only with current crises but with Soviet troops that left Iran more than 20 years ago and British troops long since withdrawn from Egypt.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (UPI)-- Republicans were advised today to capitalize on their business connections and to help Negroes establish business careers as part of a drive to make the G.O.P. the nation's majority political party.

A WISE viewer never counts his specials before they bloom in the picture tube. But for the first time in many years there is an encouraging restlessness in the TV industry and it may augur an era of expanding creativity.
The New York County Lawyers Association made public yesterday its standing and special committees for 1966-67. The list was released by Mark F. Hughes, president of the organization.

LOS ANGELES, July 9 (AP) John H. Johnson, president of the multi-million-dollar Johnson Publishing Company, publisher of Negro oriented magazines, was awarded the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People's 51st Spingarn Medal yesterday.

ONCE again it is time for the "long hot summer," and one of the spots "ghetto watchers" are keeping their eyes on is Oakland, Calif., an industrial and port city of about 400,000 people on the east side of tranquil San Francisco Bay. PROVIDENCE, R.I. For decades, Rhode Island was the playground of millionaires, people who spent their summers in extravagant Newport villas and chateaus (which they belittlingly called "cottages"), sailed their yachts on Narragansett Bay and sunned on the sand of exclusive Bailey's Beach. There were few facilities for vacationists of moderate means; for many families, Rhode Island served merely as a corridor to Cape Cod.

Wilkes of Dallas, Pa. The Rev. James P. Curran performed the service at the Roman Catholic Church of Christ the King.

Replanking of the afterbody of the 12-Meter yacht Columbia has started as another major step leading to participation in the 1967 America's Cup races.

BUENOS AIRES, July 9 (Reuters) Mrs. Isabel Peron, third wife of the exiled former Argentine dictator, Juan D. Peron, left today to rejoin her husband in Madrid.

BLOCK ISLAND, L.I., July 9 Commodore Elias A. Safie won the 53d annual New York Athletic Club Block Island predicted-log competition today with remarkable 0.65 error percentage. Safie was only 341 seconds off his predicted time over the 103-mile course.

GAINESVILLE, Fla., July 9 In Holy Trinity Episcopal Church this afternoon, Miss Susan Belvin Bowers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Hood Bowers, became the bride of Buckley Crist Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Crist of Downingtown, Pa.

COASTAL anglers are enjoying the best bluefish season in years, and not many are worrying about next year. But since the voracious fish can be notoriously cyclic, at least some are wondering if this season might not be the bumper harvest before the famine. It has happened that way in the past.
ROME, July 9 Arthur J. Goldberg, chief United States delegate to the United Nations, flew today to the island of Ischia, near Naples, to confer with Italy's Foreign Minister, Amintore Fanfani.
The South has long been regarded as a poor relation in American higher education--its glories have been greater on collegiate athletic fields.

WASHINGTON, July 9 In the past six months the United States has been experiencing one of the steepest increases in interest rates on record, with benefits going to savers, costs increased for borrowers and mixed effects on financial institutions.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 9 Vladimir Kladunec, a senior official in the Slovenian secret police for many years, committed suicide Thursday in the wake of a nationwide Communist party purge of security organs, it was reported today.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) The nesting duck population has increased 37 per cent over a year, but is still below the long-term average, the Interior Department reported today.

PATERSON, N.J., July 9 Mayor Frank X. Graves Jr. reinstated leaves and days off for policemen today. These were canceled yesterday after earlier disorders in a predominantly Negro section of this city. Paterson was the scene of racial disturbances two years ago.
CAPE KENNEDY, July 9 The United States will open its moonport in Cape Kennedy to tourists starting July 15 on a seven-day-a-week basis.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., July 9 The marriage of Miss Deborah Marvin Devere, daughter of Mrs. F. Guild Devere of Scarsdale, and the late Mr. Devere, to Gordon C. Andrews, son of Mrs. William Alves, also of Scarsdale and Loring B. Andrews of Tucson, Ariz., took place here this afternoon.
PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., July 9 Cornelius E. Silbon of 124 East Broadway, a captain of sailing yachts, died yesterday. He had been master of the auxiliary schooner Carol for the late Felix Warburg.

WASHINGTON, July 9 The Administration put pressure on the striking machinists' union today to end its walkout against five major airlines as mediation efforts resumed amid gloomy comments about prospects for a quick settlement.

PARIS, July 10 Mr. and Mrs. Cyrus L. Sulzberger have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marina Beatrice Sulzberger, to Adrian Berry, elder son of the Hon. Michael Berry and Lady Pamela Berry of London.

CHICAGO, July 10 Two civil rights leaders moved today to heal the widening breach in the national movement over the issue of "black power." The two men ad dressed a rally of the newly designated Freedom Movement at Soldier Field. The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. said that "our power is in our unity."
MILWAUKEE, July 10 (AP) Don White of Keokuk, Iowa, drove a 1966 Dodge Charger to victory today in the 200-mile late-model stock car race at State Fair Park after leading most of the way.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 10 Strong southwesterly winds, reaching 25 knots, disrupted some of the classes in the TriClub championship series conducted today by the Bay Club in Huntington Bay. Two of the 110's were dismasted and seven of 14 starters in the Lightning Class failed to finish, two of them capsizing.

A break in a 12-inch water main in Greenwich Village early yesterday morning poured thousands of gallons of water into streets near Abingdon Square, collapsed sections of the streets and sidewalk and forced diversion of traffic in the area.

BRIDGEHAMPTON, L.I., July 10 David Pearson of Spartanburg, S.C., breezed to his 10th National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing Grand National championship victory of the season today on the 2.8mile Bridgehampton road course.

Two of the oldest Yiddish theatrical organizations, the Hebrew Actors Union and the Folksbiene, have joined forces to expand Yiddish theater activities. They will establish a Free Yiddish Theater for Senior Citizens in October as well as a center "to foster new, good writing for the Yiddish stage."
BUENOS AIRES, July 10--The business backers of Argentina's new military regime received their first dividend Friday when the Central Bank took control of the widespread credit-union cooperatives.
GRENADA, Miss., July 10 Highway patrolmen using clubs cleared two crowds of about 300 Negroes from the Grenada County jail area tonight while deputy sheriffs chased 100 jeering whites.

Malvina Hoffman, one of the few women to reach first rank as a sculptor, died of a heart attack in her sleep yesterday morning in her studio at 157 East 35th Street. She was 81 years old.

WASHINGTON, July 10 The Defense Department has saved more than $14-billion in the first four years of its cost reduction program, De- fence Secretary Robert S. Mc- Namara has informed President Johnson.

More than a third of the 700-odd United States commissioners are not lawyers, although they perform many functions demanding varying degrees of legal judgment. WASHINGTON, July 10 A spokesman for the Treasury Department denied tonight a report published today in The New York Times that Secretary of the Treasury Henry H. Fowler had taken sides in Virginia's Democratic primary to be held Tuesday.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 10 (UPI) Cliff Richey, the 18year-old Texan, upset Dennis Ralston for the second year in a row in the final of the Western clay-court tennis championship today. Cliff's older sister, Nancy, retained the women's crown.
GROSSINGER, N.Y., July 10 Emile Griffith finished heavy training today for his middleweight title bout with Joey Archer Wednesday at Madison Square Garden.

WALDEN, N.Y., July 10 Ch. Pinefair Password, a 3year-old black cocker spaniel from Greenwich, Conn., took his seventh best-in-show award at the Wallkill Kennel Club feature today at Bradley Field.

TEL AVIV, July 10 Exhibitors in the United States Pavilion reported sales of between $500,000 and $750,000 for the 16 days of the International Trade Fair which closed here over the weekend.
ATHENS, Ga., July 10 (AP) The police said today a white man was shot to death during a rock-throwing incident last night after his truck broke dawn in a Negro section.

The Coast Guard's work in the New York area will be helped immeasurably by its new location on Governors Island, Rear Adm. James A. Alger Jr., commander of the Third Coast Guard District, said here last week.

CHICAGO, July 10 Roman Catholic Archbishop John P. Cody gave sweeping support today to the newly designated Freedom Movement. WASHINGTON, July 10 Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz stepped into negotiations today aimed at ending the mechanics' strike against five major airlines. But there was no sign of an early break in the walkout.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., July 10 Miss Susan Katherine Low, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Low, was married today to Richard I. Bloch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacques Bloch of Livingston. Rabbi Rav Soloff performed the ceremony at the Bow and Arrow Manor here.

ARMONK, N.Y., July 10 E. Marvin Camp, vice president of the Chemical Bank New York Trust Company, in charge of the office at 10 Rockefeller Plaza, New York, died yesterday of a heart attack in his home on Sterling Road. He was 63 years old.

HARTFORD, July 10 The marriage of Miss Julie Alice Rich, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Robert Rich of West Hartford, to Joseph Abbott Ingelfinger took place here this afternoon.
