DENVER, July 10 Philip M. King, a mine operator and a onetime partner of the Mexican revolutionist, Francisco (Pancho) Villa, died of a heart attack Friday while on business here. He was 75 years old and lived at 930 Park Avenue, New York.

Four large corporate issues and two big tax-exempt issues dominate the capital market this week as Wall Street investment bankers continue to work their way through a relatively moderate supply of securities for sale in July.

KATONAH, N.Y., July 10-- Spectacular weather brought a good part of the audience early to the concert in the Caramoor Festival's outdoor Venetian Theater last night. After a stroll through Caramoor's beautifully tended woodlands and gardens, those present sat down to hear a bright program of rarely played music, the kind that is Caramoor's trademark.

Two 18-foot motorboats collided in Jamaica Bay yesterday, killing a woman passenger.

PORTSMOUTH, Va., July 10 (AP) An Italian freighter that was headed for dry dock began taking on too much water in the Atlantic Ocean off Cape Hatteras, N.C., today and began sinking. The 32 crewmen were taken aboard another vessel.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., July 10-- Bachelor's Bait, owned by Andy Murphy of New York, captured the open jumper championship by wining three of the five classes today at the TriStates Horse Show on the grounds of the Park Lane Hotel.

LOS ANGELES, July 10 (AP) Frank Bolling and Woody Woodward singled home runs in the fifth inning today to help Denny Lemaster gain his seventh victory as the Atlanta Braves scored their second straight triumph over the Los Angeles Dodgers, 2-0.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 10 Bruce Denton of Sands Point, L.I., rode Atlas, his 8-year-old chestnut gelding, to victory in two of three classes and won the jumper championship today at the Melody Farms Junior House Show with 12 points.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (UPI) A prominent Episcopal church has cut its financial contribution to the Washington diocese to underline its displeasure at the political involvement of the diocese's bishop, the Right Rev. Paul Moore Jr.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 10 Success will not slow down Canada's Armbro Flight, the 4year-old mare that scored a neck decision over France's Roquepine last night in the eighth annual International Trot at Roosevelt Raceway. PITTSBURGH, July 10 The New York Mets reached another milestone today the type teams don't want to brag about. They suffered the 500th defeat of their short history when the Pittsburgh Pirates, using speed and strong hitting, defeated the Mets, 9-4, before 26,150 at Forbes Field.

QUANLOI, South Vietnam, July 10--Four battalions of American infantrymen hacked their way through dense jungle near the Cambodian border today in futile pursuit of an enemy regiment they fought for nine hours yesterday, killing 184 enemy soldiers.

A sizable crowd gathered at Lewisohn Stadium on Saturday night to hear Victor Borge tell jokes, and wound up seeing him make his conducting debut here. Mr. Borge also played far more than his customary quota of untampered-with piano solos, ending the evening with part of Rachmaninoff's First Piano Concerto.

SILVER SPRING, Md., July 10 Philip Pearl, who resigned nine years ago as public relations director of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, died of a heart ailment. He was 62 years old ad lived today in Holy Cross Hospital, in Chevy Chase.
With the airline machinists' strike in its third day, travelers who insisted on flying from New York discovered yesterday that seats were available to many smaller cities.

WARSAW, July 10 (UPI) The powerful United States swimming team made a clean sweep of 11 events today on the opening day of a two-day dual meet against Poland.
A Queens man was found shot dead on the floor of his auto yesterday morning, possibly the victim of a holdup.

NOROTON, Conn., July 10 Carl Van Duyne of the Mantoloking Y.C. defeated 37 other Finn sailors and won the twoday Connecticut championship series today at the Noroton Y.C. The last four races were sailed in 5 to 10-mile-an-hour southerly winds.

HONG KONG, July 10 One of Communist China's leading ideologists, Chen Po-ta, was identified today as the "leader of the group in charge of the cultural revolution under the party's Central Committee."

INTERNATIONAL chess tournaments, even at the highest levels, are not exclusively confrontations of grand masters. Of necessity, any high-echelon event must be salted generously with less glamorous players, who are scrappy fighters in any company. These perennial and dangerous dark horses are the core, usually, of any tournament roster.

LOUDON, N.H., July 10 Allan Moffat, a 26-year-old Australian driver, electrified a crowd of 10,000 in winning the 250-mile Trans American sedan race today at Bryar Motorsport Park. The giant-killing job was done with an under-2-liter Lotus Cortina at an average speed of 67.995 miles an hour.
Firemen have been ordered to stop turning off illegally opened fire hydrants in "hostile" neighborhoods and to call on the police to do it instead.

SINGAPORE, July 10 About 200 Malaysian youths, in an anti-American demonstration, smashed the windows of the Lincoln Cultural Center in Kuala Lumpur today. The center, formerly the United States Information Service library, reopened last month after renovation.

SANTIAGO, Chile Eduardo Simian, Chile's Minister of Mines, has announced that within three months President Eduardo Frei's long-debated plan for fundamental reform of the copper industry would be in full swing.
BALTIMORE, July 10 (UPI) George Brunet gave the American League-leading Baltimore Orioles four hits today as the California Angels gained a 4-0 victory.

BETHPAGE, L.I., July 10 Dave Rizzo scored four goals to pace the Bethpage Polo Club to a 6-4 victory over Westbury for the Summer League championship today at the state park. Bethpage finished the campaign with a 4-0 won-lost record.

The 15th April in Paris Ball, whose theme is "Paris Loves New York," will be given Oct. 28 at the Waldorf-Astoria. It is being organized by a Paris committee headed by the Marquis Pierre de Montesquiou and the Baroness de Cabrol.

Miss Adrienne Dreier, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Augustus S. Dreier of North Plainfield, N.J., was married last evening to Andrew Terry Keats, son of Dr. and Mrs. Martin M. Keats of Mount Vernon, N.Y. The ceremony was performed in the Terrace Room of the Plaza by Rabbi Barry Greene.
WASHINGTON, July 10--Congress returns this week from a long holiday to resume the increasingly bitter "battle of the West Front."

IF mastery of any one bridge skill can be said to distinguish the average player from the expert, it is the art of counting the hand. To assemble crumbs of information from the bidding and play in order to build up a picture of one of the unseen hands requires a mental effort which few players are prepared to make.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 10-- America's newest cultural enterprise was formally inaugurated last night. The first festival of the Saratoga Performing Arts Center got under way with a lavish performance by the New York City Ballet Company of "A Midsummer Night's Dream." The rest of the month will be devoted to ballet. In August, the Philadelphia Orchestra will move in for almost a month of concerts.

PITTSBURGH, July 10 Steel officials were looking at some reassuring numbers last week. Order rates continued to indicate a definite rise in shipments in August. "If anything, we're going to have to raise our forecast," said one official.
WAKEFIELD, Mass., July 10 (AP) Tom Laris of the New York Athletic Club defeated Ralph Buschmann of Andover to win the New England 25kilometer road race today over the streets of Wakefield.
AACHEN, Germany, July 10 (AP) Neal Shapiro of Glen Head, L.I., rode Jacks or Better to victory today in the feature $3,750 Grand Prize event of the Aachen international horse show.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 10 Marvin Kapilow of Fleet No. 1 in Westchester, sailing with his wife, Marcia, won the Long Island Sound championship of the Ensign Class today. He gained the Nichols Trophy by adding a third and a fifth place to the 11th he acquired in the opening race yesterday. This is only Kapilow's third season of competition.

EMME, a milliner whose hats are currently being seen in the Broadway play "Mame" and who numbers many theatrical stars among her customers, has an obvious affection for the theater. She refers to herself as a "director" and Anello, her designer, as a "producer." Her current collection, based on the "complete" look, is the result of a series of out-of-town runs.

ROUEN, France, July 10 (AP) Dennis Hulme of New Zealand drove a BrabhamHonda to victory in the Grand Prix of France auto race today. The triumph was the seventh straight for the BrabhamHonda team in Formula 2 competition.
STONEWALL, Tex., July 10 President and Mrs. Johnson invited newsmen out today to see the now-completed model of the farmhouse where the President was born 58 years ago next month.

Shirley Booth will star in the two-hour television production of "The Glass Menagerie" scheduled for next season on the Columbia Broadcasting System. In the Tennessee Williams play, she will portray the mother in a Southern family immersed in emotional conflicts.
BOULDER, Colo., July 10 (UPI) The police questioned students and faculty today in the rape and murder yesterday of a college choir girl in a tower of a campus building.
LONDON, July 10 Britain may be headed for her fourth and possibly most severe sterling crisis since the Labor Government came to power in October, 1964.

Miss Donna Marie Sistaire, daughter of Mrs. David H. Hodges of Jamaica, Queens, was married yesterday to George C. Freeman, son of Mrs. Lotta Freeman of Hollis, Queens. The Rev. Robert Ross Johnson performed the ceremony in the St. Albans (Queens) Congregational Church.

The bees of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden some 20,000 of them have found such prodigious quantities of nectar and pollen in the blooms of the borough's linden trees and privet hedges that they have produced an unusually early bumper crop of honey.

MOSCOW, July 10 (Reuters) The Communist party newspaper Pravda today accused the American author Cornelius Ryan of trying to smear the Russian army in his book on the fall of Berlin, "The Last Battle."

HANKOE, Norway, July 10 (AP) Ernest Fay of Houston, sailed Pride to second place today and increased his lead in the three-race 5.5-meter sailing regatta for the King Olav Cup. Fay had also won the opening race yesterday.

ONE of the more unusual interviews of the Vietnamese war was shown on film Saturday evening when Howard K. Smith, correspondent of the American Broadcasting Company, talked with his son, Specialist 4 Jack Prescott Smith, who suffered multiple wounds in the battle of the Iadrang Valley late last year.
A person who uses his home for a business purpose may be entitled to a deduction from taxable income of part of its maintenance cost and, if he owns the house, depreciation.

Gene Robb, a newspaperman, used to be a French horn player. Combine these interests, and you get the first president of the Saratoga Performing Arts Center, which rang up its curtain for the first time Saturday night.

William A. Hyman, a prominent lawyer who was one of the first advocates of laws to govern the use of outer space, died Saturday at the Neurological Institute, Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 72 years old and lived at 25 Central Park West.
RYE, July 10 A quickly spreading fire at Playland, the Westchester County-owned amusement park here, destroyed three rides, a fun house and a half-dozen concession booths early this morning.

A NEW source of couturier designs for those who sew at home was tapped recently by The Singer Company (sewing machines) when it commissioned, 11 young designers actually 13 because two partnerships are represented in London, Paris, Rome and New York to turn out six original garments each. Twenty-five of the 66 ideas have been selected for patterns that will go on sale early next month.

SAVANNAKHET, Laos, July 9 The Royal Laotian Air Force is carrying on a spirited undeclared war against the Communists to the east and south of its headquarters here. A handful of young, mostly American-trained Laotians fly their obsolescent propeller-driv- en T-28 planes now primarily against the so-called Sihanouk Trail.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 10 (AP) Ken Rosewall of Australia won the Casino professional tennis tournament by beating Mal Anderson, another Australian, in a playoff today.

Miss Jane Helen Koppelman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving J. Koppelman of Harrison, N.Y., was married last evening to Arthur Blank 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Solo A. Blank of Jenkintown, Pa. Rabbi Lawrence W. Schwartz performed the ceremony at the St. RegisSheraton.

Joe Pasternak, the film producer, will be honored with retrospective showings of his films at the Gallery of Modern Art at Columbus Circle, starting tomorrow and continuing through Sept. 18. Mr. Pasternak will be at the gallery tomorrow through Saturday to introduce the compilation, called "Three Decades of Memorable Motion Pictures."

POST FALLS, Idaho, July 10 (AP) A heavily armed young woman who had escaped from jail tried to shoot her way out of an ambush at a motel here just before midnight last night and was seriously wounded after shooting an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

Wolf Franck of 250 West 104th Street, a writer and teacher, who wrote anti-Nazi radio propaganda in Paris after leaving his native Germany in 1933, died yesterday in New York Hospital following surgery.
LONDON, July 10 (AP) Sir Fordham Flower, chairman of the executive council of the Royal Shakespeare Theater, died last night. He was 62 years old.

The Republican minority leader of the City Council voiced doubt yesterday that the new city-state fiscal package would yield New York City as much revenue as forecast. He suggested a delay on budget changes pending three months' experience with receipts.
MADRID, July 10 (Reuters) Mrs. Isabel Per n, wife of the former Argentine dictator, Juan D. Peron, rejoined her husband today after nine months as his political representative in Argentina.
ATHENS, July 10--More than 80 people were injured today and 140 were arrested as Greek farmers, demonstrating for higher wheat subsidies, fought with the police near Salonika in northern Greece.
Senator Jacob K. Javits warned yesterday that the mining of Haiphong harbor might be "the next thing in contemplation" in the United States offensive in Vietnam.
A hit-and-run driver killed a 10-year-old girl on the Lower East Side yesterday morning as the child's mother watched.

SEOUL, South Korea Six American and four Japanese oil companies are competing to have a hand in the South Korean project to build the country's second oil refinery, capable of processing 60,000 barrels of crude oil a day.

Mayor Lindsay's first six months have by necessity been so completely preoccupied with fiscal problems of a most urgent nature that other reforms have had to wait. Now that he has got what little he could in the way of a revenue program, and nothing more can be expected soon from the adjourned Legislature, the midyear mark offers an opportunity to reassess goals.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 10 Milton A. Gordon, a New York investor, has announced here that he has signed an agreement with a Bucharest company for processing Rumanian pork products and selling them in the United States.

New York's first experience with a spring primary, except for Presidential years, has been successful. The Board of Elections reports that although final figures are not yet available, the largest voter turnout at an off-year primary in its history took place June 28. With no citywide office at stake, more than ...

Gordon N. Ray, president of the John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation, last night told United States librarians that they should view their institutions as "mind-saving stations" as well as repositories of information.
BONN, July 10--The Social Democratic party, the opposition party in West Germany's Federal Government, scored an important victory in today's elections in the key state of North Rhine-Westphalia.
PARIS July 11 Jacques Anquetil, the nonpareil of bicycle racing, abandoned the Tour de France today on the home stretch.
WASHINGTON, July 11 President Johnson returned here today after 11 days at his Texas Ranch and conferred with Secretary of State Dean Rusk.

WASHINGTON, July 11 The wholesale price index increased only one-tenth of a point in June, as food prices continued to decline and industrial prices recorded their smallest gain in the April-June quarter.

Even more than the Olympics, with their distracting overtones of nationalism, the dual athletic meets between United States and Soviet Union teams in the last eight years have helped build understanding among the young people of the two nations.
The money market was on tenterhooks yesterday, waiting for the Federal Reserve to raise its 4 per cent discount rate.
Dominick Dominick, Inc., a member firm of the New York Stock Exchange, announced the election yesterday of John G. W. Husted Jr. as a director and executive committee member.
TOKYO, Tuesday, July 12 (AP) Dr. Daisetsu Suzuki, Japan's foremost authority on Zen Buddhism and a widely read author on the subject, died today. He was 95 years old.
Samuel Cohn, an inventor and industrialist, died yesterday at Park West Hospital after a brief illness. He was 94 years old and lived at 150 Riverside Drive.

Nobody knows what the phrase "black power" really means, neither those who oppose it nor those who have given it currency. To Roy Wilkins it means "antiwhite power." To Dr. Martin Luther King it means "black supremacy." To Vice President Hubert Humphrey it means "apartheid." Given their interpretations, these three champions of the civil rights movement could not fail to pit their enormous prestige against the whole concept.

ATHENS, July 11 (AP)--A special Government commission ruled today that eight officers of the Greek cruise ship Lakonia, which burned and sank with a loss of 125 lives on a Christmas cruise in 1963, were guilty of negligence.
A strike shut 10 plants of the National Biscuit Company yesterday.
A $5-million expansion of its New York Harbor towboat fleet was announced here yesterday by Rear Adm. Edmond J. Moran board chairman of the Moran Towing and Transportation Company, Inc.
LOS ANGELES, July 11 Factional jousting that could adversely affect Gov. Edmund G. Brown's bid for a third term develped today in California's Democratic party.
The director of nursing for the Melbourne District Nursing Service of Australia said yesterday that "America is about 20 years ahead of Australia in nursing education and training."
Stock prices ended mixed in moderate trading; gold stocks, selected aerospace and specialty issues were the strongest; volume, 6,200,000 shares. Bonds were mostly off; transactions, $7,870,000.
WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) The Federal Aviation Agency said today it had adopted a rule aimed at limiting the construction of television antenna towers and other structures more than 2,000 feet tall.
Eastern Air Lines announced last night that 12,000 nonstriking employes would be put on leave of absence without pay at the end of working hours today.
LONDON, July 11(UPI)--The Yugoslav press agency Tanyug quoted reports from Hanoi today that about 60 captured United States airmen "will be tried as criminals" by a special court.
WASHINGTON, July 11 (UPI) The Internal Revenue Service has filed tax claims of $150,000 against Martin C. Epstein, ousted chairman of the New York State Liquor Authority, it was disclosed here today.

The American Library Association, meeting in New York in a week when President Johnson is about to sign a measure authorizing a $700-million fund for library services and Construction, is in an optimistic mood.

With the appointment of four civilian and three police members, a new board to review citizen complaints of official brutality and discourtesy became an agency of city government yesterday. The board is civilian-dominated. Among its members are two Negroes and a Puerto Rican.
MUKDAHAN, Thialand, July 9-"The Bangkok authorities know the situation, but they don't understand the enemy we face up here," said a high Thai official.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 11 (UPI) About 200 construction workers returned to their jobs at the Apollo moon project today despite continued picketing by striking airline machinists.
VIRGINIA BEACH, July 11 (AP) The 32 crewmen of the Italian freighter Paestum reached shore safely today after the vessel had filled with water and sunk off Cape Hatteras, N.C.

ST. LOUIS, July 11 (UPI) Members of the Baseball Writers Association of America voted unanimously today to recommend to the Hall of Fame that a special election be held next January to rectify the inequities in last year's balloting.
OTTAWA, July 11 Canada and the Soviet Union signed an agreement here today to open air service between Montreal and Moscow.

OKLAHONLA CITY, July 11 (UPI) Curtis Harris, attorney for Oklahoma County, said today that 26 teachers and administrators in the city's schools had resigned as the result of a six-month investigation of alleged homosexual activity.

The New York Stock Exchange disclosed yesterday that security-commission profits of its member firms rose last year to 5.8 per cent the highest return since 1961 thanks to "the extraordinarily high volume during the fourth quarter."

WASHINGTON, July 11 The United States protested to the United Arab Republic nearly two months ago over its action permitting the National Liberation Front of South Vietnam to establish a permanent office in Cairo, the State Department disclosed today.
GRENADA, Miss., July 11 City and county officials stiffened their resistance today to an attempt by Negroes to have all phases of community life opened to them.
A northbound commuter train killed an 11-year old Bronx boy when he went to get a turtle off the railroad tracks near the 194th Street viaduct yesterday.

A court dispute that for months has delayed plans for the development of one of the most valuable corners on Park Avenue, and in the city, has ended, at least temporarily, with a State Supreme Court decision in favor of the defendant, Miss Florence Lustig.
Mayor Lindsay's hope of using surplus Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority funds was dashed yesterday when Robert Moses disclosed he had committed $40-million in authority funds for improvements.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 11--The clandestine air war in Laos is growing.

MONTREAL, July 11, (UPI) The Canadian National Railroad has announced it will continue to operate its through passenger service from Montreal to New York despite an earlier announcement that it would discontinue the service.

The New York State Constitution clearly holds that public funds cannot, "directly or indirectly," be used to aid schools operated under religious auspices. In disregard of this prohibition the State Legislature last year passed a law that specifically provided public...
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 11 War has brought to Vietnam not only grim violence but also elements of comedy, absurdity and perplexing cultural mutations.
Five thousand subway riders were delayed just before the rush hour yesterday afternoon while a Transit Authority motorman chased and caught a dog on the tracks of the IRT Seventh...

A 92-year-old veteran of the Spanish-American War was killed yesterday by an automobile as he was on his way to a weekly get-together of other survivors of the war at the Veterans Administration regional office in Manhattan.

HARTFORD, July 11 The Rev. Dr. Loyd Foss Worley, active for many years in the Methodist Church in Connecticut, died yesterday at Hartford Hospital. He was 70 years old and had lived at 80 Garden Street here.
SPRING VALLEY, N.Y., July, 11 Miss Merle Roberta Chait and Morton L. Price plan to marry in September.

WASHINGTON, July 11 Airlines serving the badly congested National Airport here announced today that they would introduce 90 new takeoffs and landings at Dulles International Airport, 27 miles away in Virginia, on Aug. 7.

Assembly Speaker Anthony J. Travia called yesterday for a legislative investigation of Surrogate's Court here because of charges made during the recent campaign to nominate a Democratic candidate for the court.
For the second time in a year, Fanny Farmer has lost another suitor.

WASHINGTON, July 11 Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara said today that the United States was producing air munitions so much faster than they were being used in Vietnam that he was ordering a $1-billion cutback in production.
HOLLYWOOD, July 11 (AP) Sy Devore, Hollywood men's clothier, died of a heart attack today at his home. He was 57 years old.
MOSCOW; July 11 The Soviet national track-and-field team, in protest against the Vietnamese war, refused today to compete with the United States in their annual meet this year.

AMHERST, Mass., July 11 Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Davenport have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Davenport, to John Marshall Andrews, son of Mrs. Thomas Golphin Andrews of Oklahoma City and the late Judge Andrews...
Steel production fell 3.4 per cent last week, which included the July fourth holiday, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 11 Republican party proposals for overhauling the United Nations were viewed by most sources here today as simple partisan politics.
Almost $1-billion of new securities was priced yesterday as short-term interest rates rose to record highs and long-term bond prices dropped sharply.
WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) The Senate passed without debate today a bill to create a commission to study how best to combat traffic in pornography and other obscene and noxious materials.

WASHINGTON, July 11 Ignoring its own warnings of a wage-price spiral that could force a tax increase, the Senate passed today a Federal pay bill that cost double the sum sought by President Johnson. The vote was 81 to 0.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) The Justice Department approved in part today a bill to replace the present United States Commissioner system with salaried Federal magistrates. But it questioned the constitutionality of a key feature.
BOMBAY, India, July 11 (AP) Government officials decided today that largescale voluntary evacuation would be recommended Friday unless monsoon downpours replenished drying reservoirs by then.
WARSAW, July 11 (AP) The American all-star swimming team gave the Polish team another lesson tonight, easily winning all events in the second half of the two-day meet.
CHICAGO, July 11 (AP) Chicago beaches and piers were closed for several hours today while the threat of a sudden rise of water in the area endangered recreation seekers.

BONN, July 11 Five British seamen were rescued from the North Sea near the Dutch island of Schiermonnikoog by a West German rescue boat, the Georg Breusing, Sunday night. The men, who are suspected of having mutinied, were returned to the rescue boat's home port of Borkum.

LUCKNOW, India, July 11 (Reuters)--Authorities in Uttar Pradesh, India's most populous state, have arrested more than 1,100 people as an alliance of left-wing parties pressed ahead with plans for a general strike tomorrow.
MILWAUKEE, July 11 (AP)--Ralph Colla, a 17-year-old from Youngstown, Ohio, matched par 71 today to capture the first-round qualifying lead in the national public links golf tournament.
CALGARY, Alberta, July 11 (UPI) Senator Robert F. Kennedy, Democrat of New York, and his wife, Ethel, received a tumultuous welcome today from the 400,000 spectators on hand for the Calgary Stampede.
Two conclusions are to be drawn from the election results in the West German state of North RhineWestphalia:

ST. LOUIS, July 12 Sandy Koufax, who has the most successful arthritic elbow in baseball, and Dennis McLain, who is the only son-in-law of an allstar to make a major-league All-Star team, were named today as the starting pitchers for the 37th All-Star Game, to be played at new Busch Stadium tomorrow afternoon (2 P.M., New York time).

Despite all-day negotiations, the mailers' union and the World Journal Tribune, Inc., failed last night to reach a contract agreement that could help end the 78-day-old shutdown of the new publishing enterprise.

CHICAGO, July 11 The stage was set today for a test of strength between the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Mayor Richard J. Daley, one of the most successful of the Democratic bosses of big city machines.
"I JUST turned around and there was this igloo walking toward me," said a building porter who was an involuntary spectator yesterday at the outdoor hat show on West 39th Street.
A selloff in the last hour of trading put most issues in the loss column on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.

ORANGE, N.J., July 11 Russell A. Riley, executive assistant to the New Jersey Public Utilities Commission and former Mayor of this city, died today, apparently of a heart attack, at his summer home in Manasquan. He was 61 years old.
IF Emeric Partos, Bergdorf Goodman's fur designer, ever tires of ermine and sable, he can go right back where he started--designing in fabric.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 11--Candidates for a South Vietnamese assembly that will draft a constitution began filing today to run in elections scheduled to be held in September.
A number of major appointments have been announced in the marketing and publishing fields.
WESTBURY, L.I. July 11 Their Gallic pride piqued, the contingent from France at Roosevelt Raceway asked today for La Revanche.
A civilian-dominated police review board, whose seven members include two Negroes and a Puerto Rican, was appointed yesterday by Mayor Lindsay and Police Commissioner Howard R.Leary.
CONCORD, N.H., July 11 (AP) Citing prosperity under his administration, Gov. John W. King announced today that he would run for a third consecutive term.
WASHINGTON, July 11 More than two million teenagers, a big majority of them white, found permanent or temporary jobs in June.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 11 (AP) A national repertory theater for the deaf is being discussed this week at the 28th biennial convention of the National Association of the Deaf.
WASHINGTON July 11 (UPI) Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara's left ankle was put in a plaster cast today because of a chipped bone.

HOLLYWOOD, July 11 Negro leaders told representatives of the motion picture and television industries today at a special meeting that they would step up pressure for wider job opportunities for Negroes and a "more truthful" portrayal of Negroes in the mass media.

FRANKLINTON, La., July 11 (AP) Slowed by the sun and miles of marching, 242 Negroes tramped up to the courthouse here today in the climax to a voter registration march that has been termed a publicity stunt by Louisiana's Governor.
The city offered its 675 lifeguards a $1-a-day raise yesterday, but negotiators for the lifeguards' union rejected it as "completely unacceptable."
Morris J. Rubin, leader of a group of dissident stockholders of the Crucible Steel Company of America, promised yesterday a "relentless, intensive campaign" to win control of the company.
ATHENS, July 10 The Greek Government resolved today to outlaw the Communistcontrolled Gregory Lambrakis youth organization. The Government officially blamed the group for yesterday's rioting.
HONG KONG, July 11 Hsinhua, the Chinese Communist press agency, denounced today the latest moves to bring about peace negotiations on Vietnam and declared that a "new Munich plot" was in the making.
Thoroughly poised and in command of herself, Jane Marsh, the current darling of Moscow, returned home to the United States in triumph yesterday.

The Bankers Trust Company, the last of the major New York City banks to report its results for the first half of 1966, disclosed yesterday that its net operating earnings for the period were $21,763,000, or $2.39 a share, up 6.9 per cent from $20,349,000, or $2.24 a share, in the comparable months in 1965.
THE first comment most women seem to make when they see one of Gini Feyas's children's dresses is: "I had a dress like that once, my grandmother made it."

WASHINGTON, July 11 The Republican Coordinating Committee charged today that the Johnson Administration, through inept policy and lack of leadership, had weakened the United Nations and eroded American prestige in the world organization.
The wife who spends hours on the telephone detailing her marital woes to her confidantes may have a better chance for connubial peace than her more taciturn neighbor.
OCEANPORT N.J., July 11 The 20th annual Monmouth Turf Charity Ball and Carnival will be given July 30 in the clubhouse at the Monmouth Park Race Track here.

PURCHASE, N.Y., July 11 Representative Ogden R. Reid said today the Eastern Regional Office of the Federal Aviation Agency had recommended cancellation of regulations at LaGuardia Airport that cause noisy jet planes to fly low over eastern Westchester County instead of over Queens.
The city's drive for more industry will get new impetus today when Mayor Lindsay names the 21 members of the Public Development Corporation.

Plans for a four-mile riverfront park to be built alongside the Hudson River Expressway between Tarrytown and Ossining have been approved by the State Department of Public Works. Complete with sand beaches, fishing piers, marinas and bicycle and hiking paths, it will "put the Hudson River back into circulation for all the people to use and enjoy," its sponsors claim.
WASHINGTON, July 11 The two sides in the airline strike blamed each other today for prolongation of the walkout as Federal mediators reported no sign of progress in talks.

TORONTO, July 11 (Canadian Press) The Atlantic Acceptance Corporation, which went bankrupt last year, might have stayed alive had it not been for an $11-million "adventure in the Bahamas," a Royal Commission was told today.

The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday the appointment of Edward J. O'Rourke Jr. to its 32-member board of governors. Mr. O'Rourke, 40 years of age, is a vice president and director of Blyth Co., and succeeds James E. Thomson of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., who has resigned.

Joey Archer became an evenmoney choice yesterday to defeat the middleweight champion, Emile Griffith, in their 15-round title bout at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night.

ROCHESTER, July 11 The first urban-county delegation to the Democratic state convention to commit itself openly to a governorship candidate came tonight for Howard J. Samuels, millionaire upstate industrialist.

WASHINGTON, July 11 A veteran of three wars, William O. Wooldridge, became the Army's ranking enlisted man today. He received the insignia of Sergeant Major of the Army, the first man to hold that rank.
DETROIT, July 11, (AP) With more factory closings for the 1967 model changeover and a strike at a Ford plant, automobile production last week fell to its lowest point in nearly nine months.

"My Appointed Round: 929 Days as Postmaster General," the book written by former Postmaster General J. Edward Day, will be presented as a Broadway musical next season under the title, "Post Office." JERSEY CITY, July 11 The antipoverty program here closed its main office today to end a sit-in by about 50 supporters of its ousted-director, Roy M. Kennix.
OMAHA, July 11 (AP) Two massive power failures hit eastern Nebraska within a fivehour period today during which the temperature rose above 100 degrees.
BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y. July 11 The son of a former United States Open champion led the Westchester open golf tournament today.
BRUSSELS, July 11 (UPI) Queen Fabiola's third pregnancy was terminated Sunday by an emergency operation, the Royal Palace announced today.
A surprise strike by operating engineers--the men who run cranes, bulldozers and other heavy equipment--was reported at several major construction projects in New Jersey yesterday.

The Ford Motor Company, which first traveled the road to riches in a tin Lizzie, has zipped past the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) in a Mustang to become second in sales among the nation's industrial companies.

ST. LOUIS, July 11--Major league baseball was unable to break a deadlock tonight over financing the office of legal adviser to the players.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 11 George Ignatieff, Canada's new representative at the United Nations, presented his credentials today to Secretary General Thant. From 1962 until this March, he was his country's representative at the North Atlantic Council in Paris.

LONDON, July 11 The eighth World Soccer Cup tournament opened tonight amid traditional British pageantry but with a disappointing match between England and Uruguay.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 11 American pilots skirted thunderstorms over North Vietnam yesterday to bomb targets ranging from gas and oil depots to river fords.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 11 A blast from an air horn sounded at a quarter before 10 o'clock this morning and 55 young men who hope to play football for the New York Giants this season began to work their muscles on the green grass at Fairfield University.
DAYTON, Ohio, July 11 (AP) A hometown skipper set a world record yesterday in the finals of the Eastern Division United States powerboat championships at Eastwood Lake.

MONTAUK, L. I., July 11--When the fishing season is this far along and only a few swordfish have been caught or sighted, then something odd is happening.

LOS ANGELES, July 11 Joseph H. Salyers, general manager of Philharmonic Hall at Lincoln Center, in New York, has been appointed general manager of the new Southern California Symphony-Hollywood Association, it was announced today.

OXFORD, Miss., July 11 A Mississippi Negro who is scheduled for induction into the Army tomorrow filed suit here today to enjoin operation of the Selective Service law in Mississippi on grounds that no Negroes serve on draft boards.
Sol Neil Corbin's election as chairman of the long-stalled commission to plan the State Constitutional Convention was announced yesterday.

MILWAUKEE, July 11 (AP) Fifth-seeded Clark Graebner of Beachwood, Ohio, eliminated Gary Hockey of Australia from the national clay courts tennis, tournament today with an opening-round 6-3, 6-1 victory.
The B.V.D. Company announced the election here yesterday of C.T. Lanham as a director.

WASHINGTON, July 11 Yields on three-month Treasury bills hit a record high for the second successive week, the Treasury announced tonight. Yields on the six-month bills moved up to their highest level in more than six years.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 11 The Firefighters Union voted overwhelmingly tonight to end a four-day work slowdown that had led to the use of the National Guard to patrol the city's 44 fire stations.

STAMFORD, Conn., July 11 Miss Mary Arnold, who was executive secretary of the former Children's Welfare Federation in New York, died yesterday in Stamford Hospital. Her age was 84. Until recently she had lived at the Nestledown Convalescent Home and Hospital here.
Most prices on the London stock market closed at their lows for the session yesterday with mostly fractional losses on light selling.
So many people have decided that the Rheingold Central Park Music Festival is doing something right that extra performances have had to be given for the last two nights.

BOSTON, July 11--Dr. Paul M. Fye, director of the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, offered a note of caution today to investors expecting quick profits from expanding research in undersea riches.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., July 11 Mrs. Peggy Crump Ward, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Irving Crump of Oradell, was married today to the Rev. Clinton H. Blake Jr. of Englewood and Sugar Hill, N.H. The Rev. David Gillespie performed the service at St. Paul's Episcopal Church.
Following aggressive, concentrated new buying, cocoa futures closed 0.95 to 1.05 cents a pound higher on the New York Cocoa Exchange yesterday.
The television networks will present at least three hours of continuous coverage of the wedding of Luci Johnson and Patrick J. Nugent on Saturday, Aug. 6.

BONN, July 11 A West German spokesman said today that the Government would continue its present policies despite the defeat suffered by the governing Christian Democratic Union in yesterday's North Rhine-Westphalia state election.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 11 An insurance agent who the police said called them yesterday to report that he had found two young children in his office was arrested tonight and charged with making a false report.
The spot rate on the British pound lost further ground after earlier gains yesterday in moderate trading on foreign-exchange markets yesterday.

MARSHALLTOWN, Iowa, July 11 (AP) Jessie Binford, known as "the Conscience of Chicago" in her more than 60 years with the city's noted settlement house, Hull House, died Saturday in a hospital here. She was 90 years old.
ATLANTA, July 11 (AP) The taxpayer frustrated by red tape when he wants an answer from a Federal agency was given hope today.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., July 11 Dr. and Mrs. Rolf Kroll have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Karen Dagmar Kroll, to Bekir Sami Ural, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ekrem Ural of Hamburg, Germany, and Istanbul, Turkey.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 11 State officials worked today to prevent a mass resignation of nurses over wages at one hospital from becoming a regional walkout.
Stern Brothers, New York department store, has named Richard R. Champ as senior vice president, operations and control, Allan J. Bloostein, president, announced yesterday.

McGraw-Hill, Inc., is planning to acquire the privately-owned Medical World Publishing Company, Inc. The transaction would involve an undisclosed amount of stock. Trade sources estimated the deal would involve more than $10million.

When Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer announced plans to film "Doctor Zhivago," it prompted a film industry gag to the effect that M-G-M had acquired the novel under the mistaken impression that Boris Pasternak, the author, was the brother of Joe Pasternak, the M-G-M producer.

The Rumanian Communist party's recent decision to raise sharply the 1970 targets of its current five-year plan is attracting the attention of diplomatic observers as another indication of its increasingly independent attitude among ruling Communist parties.
The rise in city real-estate taxes could result in rent increases in about 4,000 rent-controlled apartments, Frederic S. Berman, Commissioner of Rent and Rehabilitation, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 11 American consumers appeared assured today of plenty of food without significant price increases although prospects for most crops were rated below last year's production.
The Molybdenum Corporation of America raised prices of its molybdenum products yesterday, against the wishes of the Government.
BALTIMORE, July 11 (UPI) An agreement was reached tonight between a Baltimore store and two civil rights groups after a demonstration earlier in the day.

The United Nuclear Corporation announced yesterday that it has contracted to sell to the Commonwealth Edison Company uranium oxide for a price that could run "well over $15million." The price will vary depending upon delivery dates.

A highly automated motorship, the Sweden Maru of the "K" Line, is scheduled to arrive in New York this morning on her maiden voyage from Japan. The 10,804-ton vessel, built by Kawasaki Shipyard, Ltd., of Kobe, Japan, is to dock at Pier 21, Staten Island.

WASHINGTON, July 11 In another relaxation of its travel restrictions, the State Department announced today that it would permit businessmen and athletes to go to China and four other Communist countries.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 11 Foreign Minister Adam Malik declared today that all political prisoners would be tried according to Indonesian law, and, he added, "Those proved innocent will be freed."
The appointment of William M. Allin as group vice president for the paper-products operations group of the Continental Can Company was announced here yesterday.
Stock prices weakened in late trading yesterday, losing most of the small gains made earlier in the day.

Paperback Originals. DRUM BEAT MADRID, by Stephen Marlowe, END OF THE TIGER and Other Stories, by John D. MacDonald; IT's COLD OUT THERE, by Malcolm Braly (Fawcett Gold Medal, 50 cents each); WHITE APACHEE, by Williams Forrest (Fawcett Gold Medal, 40 cents).
Britain's first permanent overseas trade center will be formally opened here today in Rockefeller Center.
ABOARD THE POINT LEAGUE, Off Vietnam, July 9 There are few lonelier places than the bridge of a patrol vessel at 2 A.M. off the South Vietnamese coast.
Five men were convicted in Federal Court here last night of conspiring to ship $2.8-million worth of heroin from France to the United States in an Army officer's home freezer last December.

WHITE PLAINS, July 11 The construction of a new $2,865,000 passenger terminal at the Westchester County Airport in Purchase was recommended to the County Board of Supervisors today by its engineering consultants.
ST. LOUIS, July 11 The neatest trick of the week has now been achieved: Getting everything to St. Louis for the 37th All-Star Game in spite of the airlines strike.

BLUM CAPTURES 3 RACES IN A ROW Wally Blum drew prolonged applause from the crowd of 31,013 as he stood in the winner's circle after the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday. He had just ridden the Bwamazon Farm's We Try Harder to a neck victory over Our Dear Ruth for his third consecutive success.
CHICAGO, July 11 (AP) Railroads operating out of Chi- cago to cities served by five struck airlines reported today that they were swamped with business during a normally busy season.

NEW MILFORD, Conn. With the world's champion Angus bull and 700 acres of Berkshire foothills, a Park Avenue chemicals executive has gone into the cattle breeding business 75 miles northeast of Times Square.

Safeway Stores, Inc., the nation's second-largest supermarket chain after the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, reported yesterday record sales and earnings in the 12 and 24 weeks ended June 18.
Whitney M. Young Jr., executive director of the National Urban League, said yesterday his organization would have nothing to do with such slogans as "black power."

Mr. and Mrs. Marcel D. Brucar have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mrs. Charlotte Brucar Fox, to Peter Temin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Temin of Philadelphia. The wedding is planned for Aug. 21 in the Massachusetts Institute of Technology Chapel in Cambridge, Mass.
WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) The Bureau of Labor Statistics said today that strike idleness in May reached the highest level for the month since 1959.
PALM BEACH, Fla., July 11 (AP) Mrs. Mary Alice Firestone, wife of Russell A. Firestone Jr., millionaire industrial heir, filed suit for $6-million today against Time, Inc., of New York.

MIAMI, July ll (AP) Three children died today in a car parked in the hot sun with the windows rolled up. They could have smothered or sweltered to death in temperatures that may have reached 130 degrees, officials said.

Protests to the planned merger of the New York Central Railroad into the Pennsylvania Railroad continued to pour into the Interstate Commerce Commission in Washington yesterday the last day for filing such petitions.
ONE day in 1916 Algernon David Black, then a teen-ager, stood on Broad- way and watched in horror as an angry crowd broke up a sidewalk meeting.
WESLACO, Texas., July 11 (AP) Nine striking MexicanAmerican farm workers, led by two clergymen, began today a 400-mile march to Austin, the Texas capital.
PHILADELPHIA, July 11 Ralph Ginzburg, New York publisher convicted of mailing obscene literature, won a stay of a five-year prison sentence today pending the outcome of a new appeal.
LONDON, July 11 Allegations that fake share certificates comprise the realizable assets of a cut-rate British auto insurance company now in receivership are to be investigated by the Board of Trade.
WASHINGTON, July 11 (UPI) Steel producers will have to set aside even more of their production for the war in Vietnam, the Department of Commerce announced today.

MOST players find themselves in a hopeless contract from time to time. But it is very rare indeed when a "hopeless" contract can only be beaten by an excellent defensive play and that declarer has the last word as a result of fine card-reading.

LONDON, July 11 Jaguar Cars, Ltd.,. one of the few remaining "specialist" auto manufacturers in Britain, will be acquired by the giant British Motor Corporation for 18.3million ($51.24-million) in securities, it was announced today.
The Gossett Academy of Dramatic Arts, 11 East l7th Street, has received $13,500 in antipoverty funds for a 10-week summer program designed to acquaint Lower East Side youngsters with the theater.
NEW CITY, N.Y., July 11 The flower of the New York political world gave itself over to sweaty abandon in the rolling hills of Rockland County today.

The Bronx County District Attorney's office said yesterday that it had broken a ring that set up auto accidents to cheat at least eight insurance concerns and 17 out-of-state truck companies out of thousands of dollars in claim settlements.
HONGKONG, July 11 Communist China has closed its doors to most categories of foreign visitors while the country is going through its political purge.

The Rutland Railway Corporation of Rutland, Vt., which is no longer a railroad but owns an interest in a shopping center, has agreed to acquire the David R. Webb Company, Inc., of Edinburg, Ind., for a total price in excess of $8-million.
WASHINGTON, July 11 A Federal District judge threw out today a suit by three Army privates seeking to enjoin Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara from sending them to Vietnam.

JERUSALEM, (Israeli Sector) July 11 A cornerstone was laid today near Hebrew University for a peace center that former President Truman said might provide "a fresh start" in finding ways to prevent war.
OTTAWA, July 11 Gen. A. G.L. McNaughton, often called the "father" of the Canadian Army, died of a heart attack today at his summer home in nearby Montebello, Que. He was 79 years old.

ST. LOUIS, July 11 In the immediate vicinity of the magnificent new stadium is a huge arch that symbolizes the fact that this metropolis is "The Gateway to the West." When the Houston Astros first gazed upon the eye-catching setup earlier this season, they were properly awed. Nellie Fox, the coach, also was puzzled.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 112.2 on Friday from 112.1 on Thursday.
LONDON, July 11 (AP) A manuscript of the 14th century poem "Piers Plowman" was auctioned at Sotheby's today for 28,000 ($78,400).
SOMERVILLE, N.J., July 11 Three automobiles with Texas license plates and one from New Mexico were parked today outside the new brick garden apartments in neighboring Finderne.

MADRID, July 11 "Letters to the Spanish People," a discussion of Spain's political future by opponents of the regime, has become the first book to be banned by the Government under the press law promulgated in April.
Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that the city had received a $598,265 Federal grant to help start the first municipal program for community mental health centers.

LOS ANGELES, July 11 Col. Donald Hull, executive director of the Amateur Athletic Union, is going to Moscow tomorrow to try to persuade the Soviet athletes to attend the two-nation track meet here July 23-24.

MOSCOW, July 11 (AP) The Soviet Union announced tonight that its government agencies have been instructed "to take all necessary measures" to carry out the Warsaw Pact pledge of increased aid for North Vietnam.

DANANG, South Vietnam, July 11 (AP) Sgt. Greg Pearson said today he could not say whether he would accept the Denver County Republican Convention's nomination for Congress until he had more information.

LONDON, July 11 Representatives of three million Congregationalists voted today to unite with the World Alliance of Reformed Churches. The alliance represents 10 million people under the presbyterian form of church government.
HARTFORD, July 11--The sportsman's spirit in some Connecticut drivers is apparently helping to keep the Merritt Parkway clean.

The West Side Federal Savings and Loan Association, the largest savings-and-loan association in New York, announced yesterday that it anticipated paying ha dividend of 5.1 per cent on all accounts during the third quarter.

Acting State Supreme Court Justice Benjamin Shalleck has awarded the Penn-Ohio Steel Corporation and three other plaintiffs a $1.55-million judgment, for "injurious falsehood," against the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company.
Mayor Lindsay's court patronage has been curbed by a bill that was passed quietly by the Legislature and signed July 1 by Governor Rockefeller.
The United States-Soviet track-and-field series opened July 27, 1958, in Moscow's Lenin Stadium against a background of Moscow-Washington tension.
Bankers have been privately warning the city that its credit will be endangered unless all of the city's revenue resources are used to meet general expenses.

MADISON, N.J., July 11 Mr. and Mrs. Russell D. Tipton have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Tipton, to Michael Joe Myers, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Cloyd Myers of Sterling, Ill. A fall wedding is planned.

BRUSSELS, July 11 The deputies of the world's 10 leading financial powers, which together make up the so-called Group of Ten, have finished a draft report on international monetary reform without a recommendation for a second stage of planning.

The Penn-Ohio Steel Corporation of Birdsboro, Pa., and three former company officers yesterday were awarded $1,550,000 in their suit for damages for intentional falsehood against the Allis Chalmers Manufacturing Company of Allis, Wis.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 12--Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Newmark have made known the engagement of Mrs. Newmark's daughter, Miss Diana Franklin Irwin, to Edward Keller. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert S. Keller of New Rochelle.
The airline strike is producing disruption in a variety of areas of commerce, from marketing of California strawberries to tourism in Bermuda.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 12--The purge of associates of Vice President Aleksandar Rankovic has reached the Secretariat of Foreign Affairs and several industrial enterprises, it was learned today.
The Drew Properties Corporation has established a nationwide mortgage brokerage service for building developments costing $1-million and more. The service will be of-...

The New York State Liquor Authority has extended the date for filing under the "affirmation" section of the state's liquor law from Aug. 12 to Sept. 12, it was learned yesterday. The section forbids distillers and wholesalers from selling their brands in New York at prices higher than in any other state.

IF educational television is to achieve maximum influ- ence the noncommercial medium will need in due course the immediacy and impact that attends simultaneous presentation of the same program in many cities. Live network broadcasting enjoys an importance that simply does not exist in the case of delayed showings of a program at different times and on different days in many communities.
The job that Mayor Lindsay took from Robert Moses yesterday--reducing to one the 11 jobs he once held simultaneously-- was first given to Mr. Moses by Mayor William O'Dwyer in 1946.
A triple-A utility bond issue was offered publicly yesterday priced to yield 5.75 per cent-- the highest rate since the period of high interest levels shortly after World War I.
WASHINGTON, July 12--The Surveyor 1 spacecraft took 257 photographs today, including shots of a shattered glass mirror on the box that contains its ailing battery.

The New York Bank for Savings, the third largest in New York, said yesterday it would pay a 5 per cent dividend rate on all deposits during the third quarter and that it would "consider a new dividend plan for the October quarter."

ROSELLE, N.J., July 12-- Dr. Perry A. Proudfoot of 527 Walnut Street, a physician here for nearly 40 years and physician in charge at the New Jersey State Prison in Rahway for many years, died yesterday at his home. His age was 76.
The city's chief health officer announced plans yesterday for a public burning of the thousands of wooden benches that he said symbolized dehumanized medical services in the city clinics.
BABA held a barefoot fashion show "at sea" Monday night, although the couturier hadn't planned it that way.
Directors of the Taft Broadcasting Company voted yesterday in Cincinnati to raise the company's quarterly dividend to 15 cents a common share.
It probably isn't true, as has sometimes been rumored, that Joseph E. Levine, the film pro- ducer-distributor, holds press conferences to ward off moods of depression and self-doubt.
I wanted very much to be in West Virginia tonight to speak to the American Alumni Council. What the weather has prevented, however, the miracle of electronics has made possible.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland July 12--Fifty thousand Ulstermen with bands and banners of the lodges of the Orange Order paraded once again today in observance of the 276th anniversary of the Battle of the Boyne.
LONDON, July 12 (AP)-- Prime Minister Harold Holt of Australia plans to return to Washington for more talks with President Johnson on his way home from Britain.
OMAHA, July 12 (AP)--The heat wave brought extreme conservation measures to Nebraska today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, July 13--Premier Nguyen Cao Ky announced today a reorganization of his Cabinet that puts in positions of responsibility men who believe in dealing fairly with anti-Government dissidents.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., July 12-- Frederic de Peyster Townsend, who retired in 1964 as a vice president of the Shaw Walker Company, office supplies dealers, died here yesterday in his home at 22 Claremont Road. He was 68 years old.
The three American prizewinners in the vocal division of the Tchaikovsky International Music Competition, held in Moscow last month, were honored yesterday at City Hall.
SYDNEY, Australia, July 12 --The police said today that a 19-year-old factory worker shot at the Labor party leader, Arthur Calwell, to gain notoriety.

The Liberal party's suit in Federal court to have New York State's Congressional district lines declared unconstitutional is the most recent of several legal attacks on them. Since it is based on the charge

NASHVILLE, July 12 (UPI) --W.R. King of Monterey filed suit yesterday for $500,000 here against the Eli Lilly Corporation of Indianapolis, charging "gross negligent misconduct" in connection with the death of his wife.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 12 --The fire fighters' union voted today to end its four-day slowdown.
The New York Central Railroad announced yesterday it was planning a new customer service in which a computer would telephone and advise customers whenever trains were not on schedule.
The Vendo Company, a Kansas City, Mo., producer of automatic merchandising equipment, announced yesterday the appointment of James W. Birkenstock as a director.
GENEVA, July 12--Canada rejected today a Soviet proposal to call an international conference to ban the use of atomic weapons as a first step toward the elimination of nuclear arsenals.

BRENTWOOD, L.I., July 12 --Six maintenance employes of the Brentwood school district have been suspended for up to 45 days, charged with having misused a school bulldozer at private vacation homesites upstate.

Two of the nation's top 10 industrial giants--the International Business Machines Corporation and the General Electric Corporation--reported yesterday record sales and earnings for the second quarter and first half.
GENEVA, July 12--The World Conference on Church and Society began a search here today for clear Christian answers to questions posed by rapid social change.
WASHINGTON, July 12-- The Johnson Administration has become increasingly concerned about the fate of American fliers captured by North Vietnam.

The margin by which Supreme Court Justice Samuel J. Silverman defeated Supreme Court Justice Arthur G. Klein for the Democratic nomination for Manhattan Surrogate was slightly reduced in the official canvass of the Board of Elections compared with the unofficial tall.

WARSAW, July 12 (AP)-- In the wake of the Soviet Un ion's cancellation of its track meet with the United States in Los Angeles, Poland withdrew today from scheduled competition with the same American team in Berkeley, Calif.

RICHMOND, July 12--Senator A. Willis Robertson and Representative Howard W. Smith, both top-ranking fiscal and racial conservatives in Congress and in Virginia's once-unbeatable Democratic oligarchy, apparently were narrowly defeated tonight.
OTTAWA, July 12 (Canadian Press)--A nine-man delegation from West Garmany will spend the next two days here investigating the possiblity of uranium purchases from Canada.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. July 12--United States administration of the Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands received a generally favorable report today from the Trusteeship Council. The report will be forwarded to the Security Council.

WASHINGTON, July 12-- New light is expected to be cast tomorrow on the Government's murkey eavesdropping policy when the Justice Department discloses details of its bugging of a Washington lobbyist's hotel suite.

PEKING--When a sage in Confucianist China donned a long gown, it was a badge of learning that gave him position, privilege, influence and economic security that enabled him to turn his back on physical work for life.
CHICAGO, July 12 (UPI)-- Japan's giant Toshiba Electronics Corporation is entering the United States consumer market.
WASHINGTON, July 12--In the last few days Hanoi and the Communist capitals of Eastern Europe have been talking about trying and executing the American fliers captured in North Vietnam.

Contract negotiations between lifeguards and the city continued yesterday, even as the lifeguards planned a meeting for tonight or tomorrow at which a decision would be made on strike action this weekend.
TOKYO, July 12--Premier Eisaku Sato expressed concern today over the expanded hostilities in Vietnam and called on North Vietnam to join in peace talks with the United States.
The Marine Midland Grace Trust Company announced here yesterday the election of Jean Boyer de la Giroday as a vice president.

The Ritter Pfaudler Corporation of Rochester, N.Y., has acquired 87.75 per cent of Barnstead Still and Sterilizer Company, Inc., of Boston, in exchange for 114,074 shares of Ritter Pfaudler common stock.
A 15-year old Queens boy was held for questioning yesterday, 12 hours after the body of a raped and strangled 6-year-old girl was found in a pile of rubbish behind a neighborhood garage.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (UPI)--Spokesmen for cotton growers and ginners urged the House Agriculture Committee today to approve low-interest Government loans to gins facing a difficult period because cotton production is being cut back by Government controls.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Congress approved today a compromise military procurement, research and pay-increase bill and sent it to the White House.
Brooklyn, which had been a city in its own right for 54 years until it was consolidated with New York in 1898, is growing steadily toward the milestone of 1 million dwelling units.

LOS ANGELES, July 12-- The Federal Government has unexpectedly reopened negotiations with Southern California water officials over how much it is willing to pay toward a $357-million atomic-powered sea-water desalting plant.
SRINAGAR, Kashmir, July 12--In the light from a single barred window high on the wall of the Kashmir central jail, a curious drama has been played out here in the last few days.
BRYN ATHYN, Pa., July 12 --Raymond Pitcairn, lawyer and self-taught cathedral architect, died today in Abington Memorial Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived here on his estate, Glen Cairn.
Howard Worth Smith, who apparently was defeated yesterday in the Virginia Democratic primary, is leaving behind him in the House of Representatives one of the foremost records in legislative dissent.

Mayor Lindsay at long last has dismissed Robert Moses from one of the key posts of his power, that of City Coordinator of all arterial highway construction that is built with Federal or state assistance. Symbolically, the Mayor's letter reached Mr.
VIENNA, July 12--The Austrian Government has decided to make 1967 a "Strauss Waltz Year," it was announced tonight.
WASHINGTON, July 12-- President Johnson said today that the Government had just cleared a passport for a leading American businessman to visit Communist China to carry on commercial discussions.
Austin N. Heller, who was sworn in last week as the city's Commissioner of Air Pollution Control, disclosed plans yesterday for a network of automated stations to measure pollution.
CHICAGO, July 12--Roving gangs of Negroes swept through a Near West Side neighborhood tonight, tossing Molotov cocktails at police cars and looting scores of stores.

Joseph L. Mankiewicz, winner of four Oscars, is planning to make his Broadway debut as the adapter and director of Friedrich Duerrenmatt's new comedy, "The Meteor." David Merrick is in the process of acquiring the rights to the play, which will be sponsored by Mr. Merrick's foundation in the fall of 1967.

"The Loves of a Blonde," a highly acclaimed Czechoslovak movie directed by Milos Forman, has been chosen as the opening-night presentation of the fourth annual New York Film Festival. The festival will begin Sept. 12 at Lincoln Center's Philharmonic Hall.
John deLaittre, a member of the Federal Home Loan Bank board whose term expired June 30, has been appointed executive vice president of the Mortgage Bankers Association, effective Nov. 2.

The Port of New York Authority late yesterday rejected a proposal by the Lindsay administration that the city and the authority submit to arbitration their differences over the controversial World Trade Center.
HANKOE, Norway, July 12 (Reuters)--Ernest Faye of Houston, won the King Olav Cup today in the 5.5-Meter international yachting competition.

Emile Griffith will stage the first defense of his world middleweight title tonight against Joey Archer in a scheduled 15round bout at Madison Square Garden. The fighters are rated even in the underground betting line.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall said today he was "leaning toward" recommending tax incentives for industries that installed anti-pollution devices.

The Sohio Petroleum Company announced yesterday in Cleveland that it had acquired for an undisclosed amount an interest in 179 oil and gas leases in eastern Kansas and northeast Oklahoma from the Layton Oil Company of Wichita, Kan.

WASHINGTON, July 12-- Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz indicated today that he would call for a guaranteed work plan in the New Jersey construction industry despite strong opposition to the proposal from the employers involved.
The new British Trade Center in mid-Manhattan was opened yesterday as a symbol of a nation "swinging into action, not into decay."
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 12 (UPI)--The Gemini 10 astronauts and their space machines went through a countdown rehearsal today for their flight next Monday.

Vera Francheschi an American concert pianist and the wife of Daniele Barioni, a tenor at La Scala opera house in Milan, died Monday night at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center after a long illness. She was 38 years old.

LONDON, July 12--Sterling, under heavy pressure, sank today to its lowest level since November, 1964. The price of gold edged higher. Silver was in great demand. The stock and Government bond markets continued shaky.
A SMALL summer cookbook that's good all year round may be overlooked because of its title "The Too Hot to Cook Book," by Miriam Ungerer (Walker and Company, $3.95).

MILWAUKEE, July 12 (AP) --Arne Dokka, the defendingn champion, shot a 30 to match the tournament record on the front nine and finished with a 65 today to win the medal in the National Public Links golf tournament.

Margaret Walker, a teacher and poet, recently received the $5,000 Houghton Mifflin Literary Fellowship Award for her novel, "Jubilee." Scheduled for Sept. 23 publication, the story deals with plantation life of the Negro in Georgia before, during and after the Civil War. It is
WESTBURY, L.I., July 12-- Gramel, one of the greatest trotting mares to have emerged from Australia, is to get her chance in the harness racing spotlight Saturday night at Roosevelt Raceway.
The Connecticut Board of Title Underwriters has elected Stanton S. Roller as president. Mr. Roller is vice president of the Chicago Title Insurance Company, Home Title division.
When Ted Williams, the honorary coach for the American League, arrived in the clubhouse, the first one to greet him was Lefty Gomez, the amiable screwball who once was a great Yankee pitcher.
The Shell Oil Company and the Trunkline Gas Company has signed a contract in New Orleans for the sale of one trillion cubic feet of natural gas.

LA JOLLA, Calif., July 12 (UPI)--Phillip G. Bent, an actor, and Peter Sachse, a folksinger, were killed today when their converted World War II training plane crashed 150 feet offshore while making a series of low passes over Windansea Beach. Both were 26 years old and had wives who are actresses.
H. Henry Masuda was appointed yesterday to the new post of president of the Continental Oil Company Far East, a subsidiary of the Continental Oil Company.
LONDON, July 12 (UPI)-- Brazil, the defending champion, opened bid for a third straight World Soccer Cup today with a 2-0 victory over Bulgaria at Liverpool.

ST. LOUIS, July 12--Brooks Robinson was unanimously elected the outstanding player in the 37th All-Star Game today after having taken a bus part way to St. Louis to perform before "my folks and a few of the guys I played ball with back in Little Rock."
LAWRENCE, Kan., July 12-- Mrs. Carol Ridenour Abernathy has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Carol Eleanor Abernathy, to Gilbert Carl Thelen Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Thelen of Richmond.
MINNEAPOLIS, July 12 (AP) --Jim Wiechers of Atherton Calif., shot a two-under-par 70 today and took the medal in the Trans-Mississippi amateur golf tournament with a 36-hole total of 137.
DAMASCUS, Syria, July 12 (Reuters)--Syria has canceled a contract with a British consortium for a 20-million ($56million) oil pipeline; Syria's Premier, Youssef Zeayen, announced today.

Steve Siegel of Teaneck, N.J., David Werchen of Whitestone, Queens, and Brian Gottfried of Cape Coral, Fla., the first three seeded players, reached the junior division fourth round of the Eastern junior and boys tennis championships yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, Queens.

Dr. Redford K. Johnson, former chairman of the board of the Alexander Hamilton Institute, an executive-training organization of 235 East 42d Street, died yesterday at his home in Hillsdale, N.Y. His age was 76.

ALBANY, July 12--Assembly Speaker Anthony J. Travia suggested the possibility today of calling the Legislature back into special session if an agreement could be reached to overhaul the Condon-Wadlin Law, which bars strikes by public employes.

SCHEFFERVILLE, Que., July 12 (AP)--The president of the striking Schefferville local of the United Steel Workers of America was found dead in Lake Tyke today and three fellow officers who accompanied him on a weekend fishing trip are missing, a police spokesman announced.
GENEVA, July 12--The start of an attempt to draft a treaty to preserve space and celestial bodies from earthly quarrels was marred today by a Soviet attack on United States policy in Vietnam.
The spot rate on the British pound continued to ease yesterday in moderate trading on foreign-exchange markets here.

MILWAUKEE, July 12--Following a 6-3, 6-2 openinground victory today over Luccio Baltazar of Mexico in the United States clay court tennis championship, Dennis Ralston said that this is the last year that he would play the amateur circuit to the exclusion of almost everything else.
ST. LOUIS, July 12--Johnny Keane, who came back to St, Louis today "to see a ball game," denied several reports that he was about to re-enter baseball.

ST. LOUIS, July 12--It took 10 innings to do it, in the face of stifling heat and near-stifling pitching, but the National League continued its mastery of the American by winning the 37th major-league All-Star Game today, 2-1.
CARNOUSTIE, Scotland, (UPI)--Arnold Palmer and Gary Player were tied for the lead at 147, a stroke ahead of Jack Nicklaus after the second day of the $25,000 Scottish tournament today.

ALGIERS, July 12--Officials of Algeria's only legal party are scheduled to meet with labor union officials tomorrow to discuss the arrests of 36 local and regional union leaders over the last 16 days. The threat of a general strike will hang over the talks.
The temperature climbed to 99 degrees at 2:59 P.M. yesterday, setting a new high for a July 12.

FENIT, Ireland, July 12 (UPI)--A lone American sailor brought his homemade 12foot sailboat into this small port on Ireland's southwest coast today, ending a 65-day crossing of the Atlantic from Florida.
An advance in steel-making technology was indicated in an announcement yesterday by the McLouth Steel Corporation. Directors of the company, which had sales last...
OCEANPORT, N.J., July 12 (AP)--Audley Farm Stable's Winnipeg II, who failed to win in nine previous starts this season, led from start to finish today in the 11-16 mile turf feature at Monmouth Park.

ST. LOUIS, July 12--The temperature was 100 degrees today when Vice President Humphrey, in shirt sleeves, lifted his right arm and threw a change-of-pace pitch in the general direction of the infield. Then Sandy Koufax threw a fastball in the direction of Dick McAuliffe, and the 37th AllStar baseball game was under way.

Three of New York City's top highway planners flew to Albany yesterday to discuss $1-billion worth of road projects with the state's chief highway official, who recently accused the city of delays that "make a sham out of all the costly planning" for new superhighways here.
(UPI)--Deputy Premier Chen Yi of Communist China told Japanese visitors in Peking yesterday that he expects the United States to attack Communist China, the Kyoto news service deported today.
MODERN and period furniture share equal billing in the new summer model rooms at Bloomingdale's, sometimes in the same setting.
An off-duty Port Authority patrolman was shot and seriously wounded early yesterday when he attempted to prevent the holdup of a Brooklyn tavern by two gunmen.
A 14-year-old boy who had received a minor injury in a midtown schoolyard testified yesterday that he had been refused a taxi ride home because of discrimination by the driver.

TORONTO, July 12 (Canadian Press)--The British Mortgage and Trust Company lent a C.P. Morgan-controlled company $1.2-million to buy shares in the Lucayan Beach Hotel Company, Ltd., in 1963, a Royal Commission was told today.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 12 --The Riverside Yacht Club crew, captained by Mrs. Horace A. Sawyer Jr., took a nearinsurmountable lead for the women's sailing championship of Long Island Sound today as the Syce Cup series opened off the Riverside Yacht Club.
LONDON, July 12 (Reuters) --More than 100,000 spectators watched tonight's three World Cup matches. The Brazil-Bulgaria game at Liverpool attracted the biggest crowd-- 47,308.
Plans for the formation of a fourth commercial television network, scheduled to begin operating in the fall of 1967, were announced here yesterday.

CEDARHURST, L.I., July 12--DeCourcy Lawrence Hard, a founder and former vice president of White Laboratories, Inc., a pharmaceutical company, died today at his home on Longwood Crossing here. He was 78 years old.

More than 1,000 college students working for the city government this summer with the new Urban Corps have yet to receive their first paycheck. The delay has caused many to borrow from friends and parents, take out loans, and seek credit from merchants.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., July 12 --Dan Stanton Jr. of the Huntington Country Club led the way into the semi-finals of the Long Island Golf Association junior championship with two victories at the Garden City Country Club today.

An attempted single-handed crossing of the Atlantic Ocean has ended in failure--but a safe failure. Jean Lacombe, a Frenchman living in New York, made a landfall on the southeast coast of Portugal 10 days ago, according to a letter received here by Clifton Tatro, a friend of Lacombe's.
ROCHESTER, July 12--"If you can't get along with John Burns," a long-time Democrat said recently, "you've probably got problems getting along with anybody in the human race."

Alexander Victor, landscape architect and chief of design for the Parks Department, died Monday in Lenox Hill Hospital after a long illness. He was 65 years old and lived at 67-15 181st Street, Flushing, Queens.

George Whitmore Jr. will be released from prison on bail this morning pending an appeal, it was indicated last night. He has been in custody more than two years after having "confessed" to three murders and a rape.

Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday the appointment of the 21 members of the Public Development Corporation, a quasi-official body whose aim is to stimulate industrial growth in New York City. The corporation immediately took action toward developing the abandoned New York Naval Shipyard into an industrial park to create thousands of jobs here.
Stock prices slumped sharply in the final hour of trading yesterday after having drifted slowly downward through most of the session.

WASHINGTON, July 12-- The long-smoldering political fight over the F-111 fighter plane has been fanned by a proposal that another type of "swing-wing" plane be substituted for the overweight Navy F-111.
John F. Merriam unexpectedly announced yesterday his resignation as chairman and chief executive officer of the Northern Natural Gas Company of Omaha, effective Aug. 1.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 112.6 on Monday from 112.2 on Friday.
The appointment of Werner Seiler as North American cargo manager for Swissair was announced yesterday by Hugo K. Mayr, general manager in North America for the privately owned Swiss carrier.

George J. Leness was elected yesterday as chairman and chief executive officer of the world's largest investment firm, Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., succeeding Michael W. McCarthy. Both men are 63 years old.

The New York Civil Liberties Union denounced John J. Cassese, the president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, yesterday for "injecting a thinly veiled racism" in his attacks on the civilian dominated police review board.

PARIS, July 12--The arrival in Paris today of the King of Laos; the return, empty-handed, of a French envoy from Hanoi, and preparations for a visit by President de Gaulle to Cambodia--these are the latest aspects of France's active policy in Southeast Asia.
Despite the absence of Soviet and Polish athletes, there will be major competition in California over the next two weekends for the United States national track-and-field teams.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 12--Art shows, two gala balls and a house tour are among the events scheduled for the Summer at this resort.
The concert at Lewisohn last night looked as good through folk glasses as it did through opera glasses.
