CAIRO, July 12--The Government of the United Arab Republic, increasingly concerned with a rise in crimes interfering with its socialist program, has drafted a new penal code, including the death penalty for major economic crimes that sabotage the national economy.
John W. Pacey, director of corporate communications for Philip Morris, Inc., died last evening at French Hospital after a long illness. He was 50 years old and lived at 2 Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn.

The notion that Europe catches pneumonia whenever the United States sneezes has apparently lost its hold on economists. Now they are saying that the United States may be vulnerable to the European disease of highlevel inflationary stagnation.
WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) --The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today a year's extension of the International Wheat Agreement.
James V. Lester was elected yesterday as executive vice president of ITT Europe, a subsidiary of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

Paperboard production rose 15.9 per cent with 326,800 tons in the week ended July 9, from 282,000 tons in the corresponding 1965 week, the Paperboard Group of the American Paper Institute reported yesterday.

ROCHESTER, July 12--John J. Burns was re-elected Democratic state chairman today at a state committee meeting whose harmony was shattered briefly by a debate on United States policy in the Vietnam war.
A turf race was the feature at Aqueduct yesterday for the third day in a row. And once again it was Walter (Mousie) Blum who brought home the winner.

The country's power producers have experienced a number of pretty black days as far as their public image is concerned--the blackest days of all, of course, coming as a result of the big Northeast power failure last Nov. 9.
The London stock market continued an easing trend yesterday with prices generally off fractions in dull trading.
DANANG, Vietnam, July 12 (AP)--Marine Sgt. Greg Pearson, in a letter to Denver Republicans, today accepted their nomination to run against a Democratic Congressman.

NORMAN NORELL, the gray-haired designer, who is still worshiped by rich women who do not feel like kids, performed no act of creation in terms of design Monday evening, but his undisputed talent for color and construction was never more skillfully displayed.

Although it will be another week or so before the P. Lorillard Company and the General American Transportation Corporation issue their results for the first half, managements of both concerns in separate meetings with security analysts yesterday indicated that figures would compare favorably with 1965.
European companies area squaring off by groups to compete this fall for one of the largest satellite contracts to be let by the small but growing European space program.
WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP)--The jet stream, a movement of high-flying winds, was partly blamed today for the heat spell that has been plaguing much of the country.
Raybestos-Manhattan, Inc., of Passaic, N.J., will acquire the physical assets of the Ames American Company's roll-covering plant in Columbus, Miss., it was announced yesterday.
Plans are taking shape for a feature film version of Lewis John Carlino's Off Broadway play, "Cages," with the participants numbering three recent Academy Award-winners.

Futures contract trading on the Chicago Board of Trade for the first six months of this year was up 9.4 per cent over the similar period of 1965, Warren W. Lebeck, executive vice president of the world's largest agricultural exchange, reported yesterday.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 12 --Smith Gormley Company, Inc., one of the state's largest general wholesale dry goods companies, announced today that it would go out of business by Jan. 1. The concern is 88 years old.
OSLO, Norway, July 12 (Reuters)--Ron Clarke of Australia ran the second fastest 10,000 meters tonight when he beat a strong international field to win in 27 minutes 54 seconds.

IN the six-hour race scheduled for the Marlboro, Md., course on Sunday, officials and working members of the Washington region Sports. Car Club of America will tune up for their biggest event of the season, the 12hour international for the...
The Liberal party announced yesterday that the Rev. Dr. Donald S. Harrington had been elected as its state chairman.
CHICAGO, July 12 (AP)-- Seven nuns sued General Motors Corporation and a Chevrolet dealer today, charging that a station wagon in which they were injured was in "defective and unsafe condition."

American Export Isbrandtsen Lines is planning to introduce the nuclear ship Savannah to three more countries--Yugoslavia, Tunisia and Libya--on her Mediterranean run, an official of the company confirmed yesterday.
LUCKNOW, India, July 12 (Reuters)--Policemen fired today on a crowd of demonstrators in Banda protesting rising prices. Five persons were killed and 60 injured.
LUSAKA, Zambia, July 12-- President Kenneth Kaunda threatened today to pull Zambia out of the Commonwealth because of Britain's attitude on Rhodesia.
ALGIERS, July 12--The new French-Algerian Cooperative Association, ASCOOP, has begun its exploration for oil in the Sahara, it was announced today.
WHY do people steal paintings? Mostly money? Well, that's the problem. If the stolen painting is famous, it's virtually impossible to sell. If it isn't famous, it's hardly worth the caper.
The Acme-Hamilton Manufacturing Company "is in better condition today than at any time in the past four or five years," Monroe J. Weintraub, president, said here yesterday.

Strabo V. Claggett, a business and financial consultant and a former investment banker who had been active in politics, died yesterday in Beth Israel Hospital after a brief illness. He was 74 years old and lived at 108 East 38th Street.
Endako Mines, Ltd., of Vancouver, B.C., said yesterday it was raising immediately prices of its molybdenum products by 10 cents (United States funds) a pound of molybdenum contained.
More than three hundred firemen fought an eight-alarm fire in 99-degree heat for three hours yesterday on a Brooklyn pier.
ST. LOUIS, July 12 (AP)-- Officials estimated today that the number of deaths caused by a heat wave in metropolitan St. Louis had risen to 25.
The New York Stock Exchange's ailing buttonwood tree on Broad Street has been replaced in an atmosphere of some mystery.

The Air Reduction Company, producer of industrial gases and chemicals, announced yesterday the appointment of Alfred N. Wohlwend as a corporate group vice president. Mr. Wohlwend, 49 years old, will be responsible for the company's chemical and plastics operations.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 12-- Worth Bingham was the eldest son of Barry Bingham and Mary Caperton Bingham, and the second son to die in an accident in less than three years. Jonathan, 21, was electrocuted March 7, 1964, while installing wiring outside the Bingham home in Glenview, a small community near Louisville.
Mayor Lindsay removed Robert Moses yesterday as arterial highway coordinator and replaced him with Arthur E. Palmer Jr., the Mayor's Transportation Administrator.

EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., July 12--A wingless metal capsule with a man inside dropped from beneath a bomber's wing today, maneuvered as it plunged earthward, then flattened out and glided to a safe landing on a dry lake near here.
JERSEY CITY, July 12-- Officials in the Federal Office of Economic Opportunity are reviewing the status of Jersey City Can-Do, the city's problem-ridden antipoverty agency, it was learned today.

Kenya's "little election" results have been hailed as an impressive victory for President Kenyatta and the ruling Kenya African National Union, but there was a more jarring aspect: Former Vice President Oginga, Odinga, attacked by the Government and forced out of K.A.N.U., demonstrated again his command of massive Luo tribal strength in his home country of central Nyanza.
Federal Reserve authorities were reported yesterday to have devised a new technique to keep money tight during the airline strike.

ONE of the distinguishing marks of the expert is that he plays the right card when "it does not matter." If the declarer has honors of equal value, and is going to play one of them, there is usually a right and a wrong card.
Mayor Lindsay said last night that he would sign the city's new tax program into law today.

More and more companies are turning to education in their advertising, under the banner of good corporate citizenship. One such institutional campaign is a year old this month, and the company is apparently so pleased with the results, that it will be continued at least another year.

The heavy hand of economic nationalism is clearly visible in the new banking legislation introduced in Canada's House of Commons. Finance Minister Mitchell Sharp has proposed severe restrictions on the size of any Canadian bank that comes under the control of foreign investors and a prohibition on any one foreign bank from owning more than 10 per cent of a Canadian bank.

The Tecnifax Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Scott Paper Company, will market Diazo microfilm duplicating machines developed and produced by C.B.S. Laboratories, Stamford, Conn., a division of the Columbia Broadcasting System.

LONDON, July 12 (AP)--An international play-writing competition and an experimental drama year will be sponsored by Coventry Cathedral in England and Valparaiso University of Indiana, it was announced today.
A bottle-throwing brawl broke out in Coney Island last night after an inter-racial dance sponsored by the Young Men's Hebrew Association there.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 12--The United States mission accused the Soviet Union today of blocking American efforts for peace talks in Geneva or elsewhere to end the war in Vietnam.

The engagement of Miss Lisa Ellen Moriber, daughter of Prof. and Mrs. Louis G. Moriber of Brooklyn, to Neal K. Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Miller of Bayonne, N.J., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents.
WASHINGTON, July 12-- Postmaster General Lawrence F. O'Brien asked the Senate today to end the parcel post confusion that has caused the average person to "throw up his hands."

About 250 nonmedical workers at two voluntary hospitals stayed away from their jobs for brief periods yesterday. The move was the first in a series of demonstrations over wages that threatened to bring a walkout of several thousand nonmedical employes from at least five large voluntary hospitals tomorrow.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 12 --Rick Farmer of the Knickerbocker Yacht Club, Port Washington, L.I., sailing Dynamite, and Tim Etchells of the Rocky Point Club, Old Greenwich, with Shannon, won the 6.3-mile Lightning Class race during the New York Yacht Club's 21st annual junior regatta off River--side Yacht Club today.
OTTAWA, July 12--The Liberals, who lost Prince Edward Island in the federal parliamentary elections last fall, won control of the provincial government there yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 12--A retired Army lieutenant colonel was arrested by Federal agents today on charges of conspiring to commit espionage for the Soviet Union while serving at the Pentagon in a staff position with the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

David Susskind will be the host of a new two-hour television series to be seen weekly in color on WNEW-TV starting in September. His "Open End" program, currently being rerun Sunday nights on WPIX, will go off the air after Sept. 18.

ALBANY, July 12--The Republican state chairman, Carl Spad, said today that party leaders hoped to reach agreement on a candidate for Controller to complete their statewide ticket by the end of this month.
The Surveyor moon craft is confounding all engineering expectations and predictions.
WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP)--Net income after taxes of the 13,547 commercial banks insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation climbed 10.1 per cent last Year above the 1964 level.
MOSCOW, July 12 (AP)--It looked like most Soviet youth clubs, complete with Communist symbols. But the tune was different.
Puerto Rico has made a strong plea to Washington to be allowed to expand its activities in the lucrative Caribbean holiday air traffic, it was learned yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 12-- President Johnson held out to Communist China tonight the prospect of eventual reconciliation, but he emphasized that the war in Vietnam might last a long time.

Fred W. Friendly, former president of news for the Columbia Broadcasting System, is writing a book about his experiences in broadcast journalism. Random House confirmed yesterday that it planned to publish the book, possibly in 1967.

UPPER BROOKVILLE, L.I., July 12--Mrs. Adolph Klein and Richard Klein combined for a 43, 35--78 to win the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association mother and son championship at the Mill River Club today. Par for the 6,310-yard course is 36, 36--72.

LUXEMBURG, July 12 (Reuters)--The Council of Ministers of the European Coal and Steel Community agreed here today that the group's High Authority should provide $30million dollars in loans to create 4,000 new jobs for coal and steel workers in the six member countries.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The prolonged drought over the Northeastern states has had a severe effect on stream flow and ground water levels, the Geological Survey said today.

GREAT NECK, L.I., July 12 --Mr. and Mrs. William Parsont have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rita Sue Parsont, to Michael G. Wolfson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lincoln W. Wolfson of Manchester, N.H.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., July 12--Despite an 8 at one hole during the last round, Frank Wharton, the Winged Foot Golf Club assistant professional, won the Westchester open golf championship by three strokes today.
WASHINGTON (UPI)--The way a driver sees and reacts in traffic may determine the kind of accident he will have, the United States Public Health Service reports.
After the roasting they took here last year, the "hot dogs" of offshore powerboat racing are approaching today's eighth running of the Around-Long Island Marathon with more caution.
The American Library Association will suspend from membership any institution or individual convicted of violating a federal, state or local civil rights law.

MONTAUK, L.I., July 12-- When the 3:30 and 4 A.M. wake-up calls came at Gerry Ruschmeyer's Lake View Hotel, at least one angler seriously considered whether it was really necessary for a complete existence to go out to sea at this hour to catch a fish.

KARACHI, Pakistan, July 12 --Finance Minister Mohammed Shoaib will leave the Cabinet of President Mohammad Ayub Khan on Aug. 25, it was announced here today. He will be replaced by Nabi M. Uqaili, 53year-old banker.
MONTLUCON, France, July 12 (Reuters)--A 25-year-old Frenchman, only two years a professional cyclist, appeared today on his way to winning the richest prize in cycling, the 2,260-mile Tour de France.

MOSCOW, July 12--Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India arrived today to present her ideas for peace in Vietnam to the Soviet leadership and to defend the principles of nonalignment in her country's domestic economy.
An area in central Harlem containing rows of old, dignified town houses has been proposed as an historic district by the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 12--United States Air Force jets twisted away from two enemy MIG-21's, two airto-air missiles and seven surface-to-air missiles while carrying out raids in North Vietnam yesterday.
WESTERLY, R.I., July 12-- Miss Delinda Jane Howell and Lieut. (jg.) Peter Ogden Dixon, U.S.N.R., plan to be married on Aug. 6 in San Diego, Calif.
MOSCOW, July 12--The Soviet Union and the United States exchanged warnings today that their cultural exchange program had been thrown into jeopardy by tensions over the Vietnamese war.

NANTUCKET, Mass., July 12 --Robert Worth Bingham, vice president and assistant to his father, Barry Bingham, publisher of The Louisville (Ky.) Courier-Journal and The Louisville Times, was killed here today in a freakish accident while driving to a beach. He was 34 years old.
WASHINGTON, July 12-- The Federal Power Commission asked all of the nation's electric power companies today to take special precautionary steps to avert power failures during the present heat wave.

WASHINGTON, July 12-- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee gave William S. Gaud its unanimous endorsement today as administrator of the Agency for International Development. He will succeed David E. Bell, who resigns July 31 to become vice president of the Ford Foundation.
Mayor Lindsay yesterday named Henry Shimen, a 60year-old career man in labor relations, to the long-vacant post of Commissioner of Labor.
Property owners along Third Avenue protested yesterday that assessments for the city's removal of the Third Avenue El in 1955 were premature.
TRENTON, July 12--Miss Deborah Amelia Moore of New York and Pvt. Herbert Stewart FitzGibbon 2d, U.S.A., will be married next month.

PARIS--Bobby Kennedy is now moving to make Africa a major American political issue and to associate his name with efforts to liberalize U.S. diplomatic attitudes toward that continent. Evidently he would like

ST. LOUIS, July 12--The game was a sizzler. So was the weather. It was the sort of day on which sensible men would have completed their chores as expeditiously as possible in order to escape from the inferno of Busch Memorial Stadium and seek hasty relief in the comfort of the air-conditioned indoors.
"John F. Kennedy: Years of Lightning, Day of Drums," the color documentary which recently concluded simultaneous engagements at the Lincoln Art

The marriage of Miss Judith E. Siegel of 525 East 82d Street to J. Robert Ellner, son of Mrs. Arthur S. Ellner of Hollis, Queens, and the late Mr. Ellner, took place yesterday afternoon in the Victorian Suite of the Carlyle.

CRANFORD, N.J., July 12-- William F. Schorn, an architect who specialized in hospitals and ship interiors, died today in Princeton (N.J.) Hospital after a short illness. He was 57 years old and lived at 9 Claremont Place.
Seatrain Lines, Inc., a recently acquired subsidiary of Transeastern Associates, Inc., announced plans last night for the acquisition of its larger parent corporation.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange received their worst setback yesterday since June.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Negotiations to end the five-day-old mechanics' strike against five airlines broke down abruptly today.
MIAMI, July 12 (AP)--Three small children found dead in a car parked in the hot sun with the windows shut were killed by a heat stroke, the Medical Examiner's office said today.

Kendall Industries, Inc., a diversified aerospace organization with headquarters in Monterey Park, Calif., has acquired the assets, equipment and land of Kinco, Inc., a heavy-duty industrial manufacturing concern in Montebello, Calif.
Dear Bob: In the spring of 1960, you were designated by Mayor Wagner to represent him in certain respects as to Federal and state assisted highway and related projects in New York City.

LEE, Mass., July 12--Tonight was a night of debuts at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, with the San Diego Ballet and their guest soloists, Niels Kehlet of the Royal Danish Ballet and Lone Isaksen of the Harkness Ballet, all performing for the first time at the Ted Shawn Dance Theater in the heart of the Berkshires.

GREAT FALLS, Mont., July 12--Here in "the big sky country" of Lewis and Clark, as Republican Gov. Tim M. Babcock prepares to run for the seat of Democratic Senator Lee Metcalf, an almost classic confrontation of conservatives and liberals is taking shape.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 12-- Ohio State University officials announced today disciplinary action against 39 students in what they termed "the worst cheating scandal" in the university's 96-year history.
GRENADA, Miss., July 12-- With the temperature at 101 degrees, the leaders of a civil rights protest movement decided against a street march here today and held a "swim-in" instead.

LISBON, July 12--Foreign Minister Alberto Franco Nogueira categorically rejected today a United Nations proposal for general talks on the Security Council resolution calling on Portugal to grant independence to her African territories.

MOSCOW, July 12 (AP)-- Tatyana Samusenko, a 28-yearold fencer from Minsk, the Soviet Union, won the women's foil title today at the world fencing championships, according to Tass, the official Soviet press agency.

SANDUSKY, Ohio, July 12 (UPI)--Nearly 11 inches of rain fell on this Lake Erie city of 33,000 today, turning streets into rivers and flooding homes, businesses and a hospital. Hundreds of residents were evacuated.
New-car sales by the Ford Motor Company in the first 10 day of July fell 12 per cent below last year's level for the comparable period.
The "little people" -- in some numbers -- are evidently investing $5,000 and up in new bonds of a Federal agency to earn a "safe" 5 per cent interest.

President Johnson's call for "reconciliation" with North Vietnam and Communist China and his recognition that if Hanoi and Peking reject peace a long war lies ahead go far to restore the balance that was established in his Baltimore speech last year and that has too often been ignored ever since.
George Alan Smith has resigned as executive administrator of the American National Theater and Academy, a post he assumed last September.
BONN, July 12--Five seamen from the British trawler Loveden were taken aboard a channel ferry today at Bremerhaven.
NASHVILLE, July 12 (AP) --The Methodist Publishing House exhibited today the new Methodist hymnal, with pre-publication orders totaling 2,150,000 copies.

THERE are some deals that leave all four players dis satisfied. The diagramed deal was played at the Cavendish Club last week, and West began in a state of gloom. He felt that the worst was about to happen to him and he was nearly right.
The New York Stock Exchange will introduce today its Common Stock Index a market barometer measuring the price trends of more than 1,250 issues listed on the Big Board.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 13--The authoritative newspaper Armed Forces Daily Mail accused North Vietnam today of "complete subservience" to Communist China.
The New York City school system has been selected by state education authorities to develop a prototype "school for the year 2000."

A Democratic New Jersey Congressman charged yesterday in Washington that national Communist party leaders had conducted a summer youth leadership school at a camp in Ringwood, N. J., in northern Passaic County.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., July 13 Ernest Gledhill, a senior sales executive of the Pacific Mills Worsted Company, a division of Burlington Industries, Inc., died of cancer this morning at his home at 11 Beechwood Road here. He was 61 years old.
Montefiore Hospital evacuated about 150 of its 620 patients yesterday in preparation for an a11-day work stoppage today by close to 1,000 nonmedical employes.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 13--A Westerner who was in Hanoi when American planes struck fuel tanks near the North Vietnamese capital for the first time said today that he had been assured that very few civilians were killed in the raids.
William D. Ogdon, who has been a member of the editorial board of The New York Times for 20 years, will retire today.
The nation's electric power production rose 15.4 per cent in the week ended July 9, from the level in the corresponding 1965 week, it was reported by the Edison Electric Institute yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, July 13--Dr. Newcomb K. Chaney, research consultant for the United Gas Improvement Company and a developer of the gas mask used in World War 1, died Sunday at his home in suburban Rose Valley. He was 83 years old.

LAS VEGAS, July 13 A wanderer in the West needs no more than clear eyes and open ears to discover that this huge area of majestic mountains and arid plains has benefited perhaps more than any other from the Federal Treasury but that it also distrusts, maligns and complains about "Washington" more than any section except the South.

PARIS, July 13 Andre Zeller, one of four generals arrested, stripped of their rank and sentenced to long prison terms following their unsuccessful Algiers uprising against President de Gaulle in 1961, was pardoned today under an amnesty.
LISBON, July 13 (UPI) Two oil tankers collided in heavy fog off the Azores today. One vessel burned fiercely for hours, but neither ship was reported in danger of sinking.
Delmore Schwartz, editor, critic and poet, died early Monday in the Columbia Hotel, 70 West 46th Street. He was 52 years old.

The stock market took another tumble yesterday. The bulk of the decline occurred in the first two hours of trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Prices revived slightly in the early afternoon on reports of progress in the airline-strike negotiations but slipped downward again toward the close.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 13 The editors of Saigon's three English-language newspapers know that G.I.'s are interested in sports, so they publish the baseball box scores and many action pictures.
The appointment of John A. Hornbeck as president of the Sandia Corporation was announced yesterday. The appointment becomes effective Oct. 1.
BUENOS AIRES, July 13 Preoccupation with Argentina's standing abroad dominated the first Cabinet meeting of the new military Government today.
LONDON, July 13 (AP) Jim Brown of the Cleveland Browns, of the National Football League, the leading groundgainer in pro football history, will announce his retirement tomorrow.
CHERRYVILLE, N.C., July 13 (UPI) Two Seaboard Air Lines freight trains collided head-on and exploded near here today killing one trainman and injuring three others.
MONTAUK, L.I., July 13 The surf fisherman is a special sort. His reward comes not in large or frequent catches, but in the sport and the surroundings.
LONDON, July 13 Britain ran 105-million ($294-million) in the red in her overseas trading accounts last month, the Board of Trade reported today.

Members of the art world and distinguished representatives of many other fields were among the friends and associates of Malvina Hoffman who paid their final respects to the sculptor yesterday. Miss Hoffman died Sunday at the age of 81.
Jose Torres will defend his world light-heavyweight title against Eddie Cotton Aug. 15, Cain Young, Torres's manager, said yesterday.
BROOKLINE, Mass., July 13 (AP) Mal Anderson of Australia overwhelmed Sammy Giammalva of Houston, 6-2, 6-1, tonight in an opening-round match of the United States pro tennis championship at Longwood.

Bus-traveling followers of form were nicked for a little more "breakage" yesterday. Jamaica Buses, Inc., which operates routes from New York City to Aqueduct Race Track, Roosevelt and Yonkers Raceways, has received permission to increase its fares.

Municipal laws, the City Charter, the State Constitution and past court decisions on referendums are being poured over by the Corporation Counsel's office in an effort to thwart a possible referendum here on the civilian-controlled review board of complaints against the police.
Edwin D. Etherington, 41 years old, resigned yesterday as president of the American Stock Exchange to become the 12th president of Wesleyan University at Middletown, Conn., his alma mater.

MOSCOW, July 13 (Reuters) Alexei Nikanchikov, a 26year-old Soviet Union fencer whose best previous effort was third place in the 1965 championships, captured the individual epee title today in the world fencing tournament, according to Tass, the official Soviet press agency.
HONOLULU, July 13 (UPI) The freighter Export Champion reported an "out of control" fire between decks today and radioed that she was diverting to Midway.
LONDON, July 13 Three letters written by the late Sir Winston Churchill when he applied for membership in the bricklayer's union in 1928 were auctioned here today for 420 ($1,176).
The Sony Corporation put on a most successful but wholly unexpected demonstration of its new portable video tape recorder here yesterday.

The Board of Education last night promoted Frederick H. Williams to the post of assistant superintendent in charge of integration programs. He is the fourth Negro to become an assistant superintendent in the city school system.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 13 The first Newport Opera Festival opened at Festival Field here last night with an audience of 4,000 persons, all but a few of whom sat it out during a brief shower.
PARIS, July 13 (AP) Denis Hutchinson of South Africa and Sebastian Miguel of Spain tied for the lead today at the halfway point of the French open golf tournament.
ST. LOUIS, July 13 (UPI) The lower Middle West was seared by the sixth day of a heat wave today. It was cooler from the Great Lakes to the Pacific Northwest.
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., July 13 Reginald E. Marsh, a New York architect, died yesterday at Lawrence Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived here at 1 White Plains Road.
The worst July heat wave in the city's history was aggravated yesterday by a record-setting 101 degrees, 5 degrees above the previous mark for a July 13, set in 1954.

John G. Fitzgerald, assistant foreman in the pressroom of The New York Times, died yesterday at Mid-Island Hospital, Beth Page, L.I. He was 44 years old and lived at 167 Atlantic Avenue, Massapequa Park, L.I.
The following quotations are selling prices in United States dollars and cents for banknotes of New York. These rates do not apply to regular exchange business transacted by...

GROSSE POINTE, Mich., July 13 Mr. and Mrs. Alfred J. Fisher Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith Elizabeth Fisher, to David Philip d'Ambrumenil, son of Sir Philip and Lady d'Ambrumenil of London.
WASHINGTON, July 13 The Senate voted today to put $6.2-billion in Federal aid into a massive cleanup of the nation's water resources.

MOSCOW, July 13 (Reuters) Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India and Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union discussed world problems, including Vietnam, for almost three hours here today. This was their first formal round of talks since Mrs. Gandhi's arrival yesterday.

BROOKLINE, Mass., July 13 Mr. and Mrs. Henry J. Stein have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Clare F. Stein, to Dr. Allan G. Rosenfield, son of Dr. and Mrs. Harold H. Rosenfield. Both families are of Brookline. The wedding is planned for this month.
Federal grand juries have been investigating charges that millions of dollars a year are being transferred by Americans to foreign banks to avoid tax and stock security laws.

MOSCOW, July 13 Two American women who were detained at Moscow Sheremetyevo Airport for three days after their arrival without visas were released tonight and allowed to join their travel group in a hotel.
Mayor Lindsay assured a woman radio listener last night that the Ku Klux Klan "would not have a happy home in New York City"; promised another...

The Italian Line announced here yesterday that it would place the 33,340-ton liner Leonardo da Vinci in the New York-West Indies cruise trade next winter and probably add the larger Raffaello or MichelAngelo the following year.
George Whitmore Jr. was released from jail shortly after noon yesterday, on $5,000 bail pending an appeal.
WASHINGTON, July 13 Following are the parties involved, the issues in dispute, and a brief summary of the effects of the airline strike:
CHICAGO, July 13 (AP) Olympia Site, making his first stakes start, took command of the field in the stretch today and won the $32,000 Hyde Park Stakes at Arlington Park.

RICHMOND, July 13--William B. Spong Jr., the apparent winner in a close Democratic primary upset of Virginia's conservative oligarchy, set the stage today for a major struggle for control of the state's Democratic party machinery.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 13 Israeli and French officials signed an agreement here today for the development and operation of a 2,125-mile underwater telecommunications cable frbm Tel Aviv to Marseilles.
Mayor Lindsay acted yesterday to initiate the expansion of the former World's Fair Hall of Science into a full-fledged science museum.
The Newmont Mining Corporation and the Magma Copper Company, which is controlled by Newmont, each announced yesterday a sharp gain in their six-month earnings.

At the last odds-flash for the Astoria Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday, the greater part of the crowd of 23,630 gasped in disbelief. The board, registered Leonard P. Sasso's Lady Brilliance at 1 to 5 the exact odds were 3 to 10 against five rivals in the test for 2-year-old fillies.

The British Broadcasting Corporation has signed a longterm agreement with Hartwest Productions, Inc., of New York for exclusive distribution in this country of all radio programs produced by the B.B.C. Transcription Service.
HAVANA, July 13 (Reuters) Cuba has established a National Council of Civil Defense to coordinate political and mass activities in case of war.

Nine performers, an orchestra of five girls, a 22-member singing and dancing chorus and 21 scenes divided into three acts will be presented in "Cabaret." The $500,000 musical is due in mid-November at the Broadhurst, produced and directed by Harold Prince, sponsor of "Fiddler on the Roof" and "Superman."
WASHINGTON, July 13 A proposed regulation under which a special type of mutual fund would lose its present tax advantage was announced today by the Internal Revenue Service.
The election of John F. Bookout Jr. as vice president in charge of the Denver exploration and production area of the Shell Oil Company was announced here yesterday.

ORLEANS, France, July 13 (Reuters) Lucien Aimar, a 25year-old Frenchman who began the 22-day, 2,650 mile Tour de France bicycle race as a mere support rider, seems almost certain to win when the race ends tomorrow.
A rapid increase in the Soviet ICBM force is causing concern among some officers in the Pentagon.
WASHINGTON, July 13 A Pennsylvania Republican moved today to kill a plan to build two big dams in the Grand Canyon area of the Colorado River.
GENEVA, July 13 A ripple of impatience was evident today at the World Conference on Church and Society among participants from underdeveloped nations.

MILWAUKEE, July 13 (AP) Medalist Arne Dokka, seeking to become the third player to win the title in successive years since the tournament was inaugurated in 1922, breezed into the third round of the National Public Links golf championship today with a 6-to-5 rout of Herb Bolden, Denver's municipal champion.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 13 Lieutenant General Suharto, Indonesia's de facto ruler, indicated today that he would be the First Minister in a new Cabinet that would also include five Deputy First Ministers and 24 Ministers.
MUKDAHAN, Thailand, July 9 The United States is operating in Thailand on the basis that there can be no real economic development in the northeast unless there is security in the villages.

GLEN COVE, L.I., July 13 The long "cold war" that has involved the Soviet Union, Nassau County and this North Shore city over the payment of property taxes has been resolved through the intervention of Arthur J. Goldberg, United States Representative to the United Nations.

THE crinkle cotton from Switzerland that has been all the rage since early spring in Paris for shirt-style over- blouses and has become almost as popular for similar shirts on this side of the Atlantic, may now be had in French-made dresses at Bloomingdale's.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., July 13 An autumn wedding is planned by Miss Marguerite Sandra Steen and Bruce Shaw Denham. Mr. and Mrs. S. James Steen have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Denham.

WASHINGTON, July 13 The Associated General Contractors of America objected strongly today to an unusual guaranteed work plan submitted by Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz to settle a key construction labor dispute.

GENEVA, July 13 Aleksei A. Roshchin, the chief Soviet negotiator at the 17-nation disarmament talks, said today that he was "very much disappointed" by President Johnson's statement last week on the issue of the proliferation of nuclear weapons.

"Macbeth," on a little screen with a phonographic commentary, drew a knot of spectators yesterday at the American Library Association Conference. An exhibit of children's books nearby gathered an equal crowd. It looked like a poll of new and old interests among librarians.
One-hundred nonunion musicians are working in Michigan with the union footing the bill.
The heat wave had driven most persons inside the airconditioned buildings. Normally at the lunch hour, the talkers; the jesters and the...
WASHINGTON, July 13 Luci Baines Johnson and her fiance, Patrick J. Nugent, applied for their marriage license today at the United States District Courthouse.

ST. ANDREWS, SCOTLAND July 13 (UPI) Jack Nicklaus of Columbus, Ohio, the new British Open golf champion, shot a twounder-par 70 over the 6,996yard Old Course today to send the 54-hole $50,000 Scottish tournament into a three-way tie.
WASHINGTON, July 13 The South Vietnamese Air Force may soon receive a fleet of jet aircraft.

Mr. and Mrs. Max Halpert of New York and Westhampton L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter Miss Carole Fern Halpert, to Andrew Levitt. He is the son of Mrs. Robert A. Siegel of New York and White Plains and Albert Levitt of New York.
WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) An Air Force general who commanded United States attacks on North Vietnam predicted today that continued.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., July 13 Henry M. Duys, board chairman and Former president of H. Duys Co., Inc., a tobacco concern at 10 Hanover Square, New York, died last night at Glen Cove Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived on Centre Island here.
GRENADA, Miss., July 13 (AP) City policemen arrested 35 Negro pickets who were parading through downtown streets today, drumming up support for an economic boycott against white merchants.

Sitting in the cab of his 60foot-high crane on Seventh Avenue between 32d and 33d Streets, John Tarallo wiped the sweat from his eyes yesterday. He was waiting for a signal to lift the last statues off they ledge over the main entrance of the old Pennsylvania Station.
The manufacturer of Buitoni spaghetti, nationally advertised as a protein-enriched, low-calorie product, was accused by the Government yesterday of making fraudulent claims.
Four of the five highway projects that Arthur E. Palmer Jr., the Mayor's new arterial coordinator, said yesterday had top priority were developed originally by his predecessor, Robert Moses.
SATURDAY THE RABBI WENT HUNGRY, by Harry Kemelman (Crown, $3.95). Detective story.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 113 on Tuesday from 112.6 on Monday.
With 70 miles to go in yesterday's 250-mile Around-Long Island marathon, the crews of the two leading boats indulged in some rare relaxation. They broke open the soft drinks.
The General Instrument Corporation has acquired a 1-million-share block of the 10.9 million shares of common stock of Universal Controls, Inc.
Eight Negroes filed complaints of police brutality yesterday in connection with the bottle-throwing brawl in Coney Island Tuesday night in which 16 Negroes were arrested, most of them teen-agers.

Avon Products, Inc., a cosmetics distributor, announced the election here yesterday of Wilbur R. Shook as vice president, Mr. Shook continues as treasurer, a post he has held since joining the company in 1961.

Charles W. Hanson, president emeritus of the New York City and New York State Councils of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of America, died Tuesday at his home at 168-10 14th Avenue, Beechhurst, Queens. He was 83 years old.
WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) President Johnson today nominated Rear Adm. Paul E. Trimble to be assistant commandant of the Coast Guard with the rank of Vice Admiral.
SALISBURY, Conn., July 13 (UPI) Everett Crosby, brother and business manager of Bing Crosby, died of throat cancer tonight at Sharon Hospital. He was 70 years old.

Prices of cocoa futures rebounded yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange following the setback of the day before when prices fell 20 to 40 hundredths of a cent a pound. At the close of trading yesterday, prices were .25 to .38 cent higher on the sale of 3,254 contracts of 30,000 pounds each.

The Old Order is crumbling at last in the Old Dominion. If unofficial returns from the Democratic primary are correct, only Harry F. Byrd Jr., son of the stubborn conservative whose machine dominated Virginia politics for more than three decades, has bucked the tide and narrowly won nomination for the United States Senate seat to which he was appointed last November.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 13 A military aide of President Tito has been linked to wire-tapping by the secret police of Communist officials, including the residence of Marshal Tito himself, according to reports here.
Philip Rosa, an associate editor in the nineteen-twenties of the old Life magazine, died Friday at his home at 500 West 122d Street. He was 76 years old.

FAIRFAX, Va., July 13 Miss Harriet Carol Curry and Douglas Audenried Grier plan to be married on July 30. Their engagement has been made known by Miss Curry's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Joseph Curry. Her fiance is the son of Mrs. Thomas C.Grier of Tyrone, Pa., and the late Mr. Grier.

TOKYO, July 13 (AP) Communist China brushed aside tonight President Johnson's offer of a reconciliation in Asia and contended that his renewed pledge to stand behind South Vietnam again threatened war on the Vietnamese and Chinese peoples.
The Brooklyn Dodgers of the professional football Continental League will play five home games at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island, next season.
The International Finance Corporation announced yesterday a $1.6-million investment in Colombia to assist expansion of the South American country's production and marketing of beef cattle.

GOOD news from Central Park. After a dullish "All's Well That Ends Well" by the New York Shakespeare Festival and after an execrable "macheth" in its mobile theater, I expected little of the new production. But a hefty measure of praise is due "Measure for Measure."

COPIAGUE, L.I., July 13 John Tartamella, executive vice president of the Greater New York Joint Council of the Journeymen Barbers International Union of America, died yesterday in his home at 416 Oak Street. He was 75 years old.

Doctors Hospital has agreed to pay $100,000 to Emery Deutsch, the bandleader, and his wife, Marjorie, to settle their claim that their son suffered permanent brain damage during his birth at the hospital eight years ago.
ST. LOUIS, July 13 With another National League All-Star victory out of the way, the baseball world returned its attention today to its main business, the pennant races.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 13 The Riverside Yacht Club won the Syce Cup today when Mrs. Horace A. Sawyer Jr. clinched the women's sailing championship of Long Island Sound with 17 points for the five-race round-robin series.

ST. LOUIS, July 13 Today was another scorcher. The fifth straight day of sweltering heat when the temperatures soared over the 100-degree mark in this sunbaked metropolis. But it no longer mattered to the cast that had assembled here for the hottest of All-Star games yesterday. Everyone had completed his escape elsewhere before nightfall.

WASHINGTON, July 13 The Justice Department conceded today that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had been authorized for years to plant electronic eavesdropping devices on criminal suspects premises, until President Johnson stopped the practice last summer.
A coincidence that amounts to a meteorological conspiracy is behind the unrelenting hot weather here.
SAIGON, South Vietnam July 13 (Reuters) Thich Tam Chau, the moderate Buddhist leader, today announced that he would be taking two months sick leave until after the September general election.
Sterling Drug, Inc., announced the election yesterday of Walter N. Plaut as a vice president.
Music lovers who flocked to the Central Park Mall last night came for one concert but got two instead. Since admission was free, the evening was quite a bargain.
WASHINGTON, July 13--President Johnson said today the seas held the ultimate answer to world food shortages and must be exploited for the good of all mankind.
The trend toward consolidation of Wall Street investment houses continues. Two separate announcements were made yesterday stating that discussions were being held among four concerns.
William Golden is a publicity and advertising ex ecutive with Metro-GoldwnMayer. He is also the owner of Ch. Webline Golden Jubilee, C.D., an Irish setter known to dog fanciers as Pat.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 13 Dr. James Madison Nabrit Jr. was sworn in at the United States Mission today as deputy permanent representative to te United Nations.
The engagement of Frank Sinatra to Mia Farrow, the 21-year-old actress, was announced here yesterday by Miss Farrow's mother, Maureen O'Sullivan, the actress.
Governor Rockefeller yesterday announced plans to recruit and train people from "hard-core unemployement areas" in New York City to help fill 5,000 available jobs in state agencies.
POUND RIDGE, N.Y. When Elizabeth Ann Tou- pin asked her younger daughter recently what she would like for her birthday, there was the briefest pause before the reply.

A FRIEND called the American Stock Exchange yesterday and said: "This is a big day for you, Ted. What color tie and suit are you wearing? It's something you should remember." "Just a second and I'll find out," replied Ted Etherington, the...
The Chesapeake and Potomac Telephone Company sold yesterday $25-million of debentures in the most expensive borrowing for the Bell System since 1923.
The National Labor Relations Board charged the General Electric Company here yesterday with illegally refusing to bargain with a union negotiating team representing the company's employes.

Emile Griffith, never taking a backward step in the first defense of his world middleweight title, hooked, butted and shouldered through the classic defenses of Joey Archer last night and hammered out a majority decision over his taller, heavier challenger at Madison Square Garden.
Ground will be broken early next week for a $1.5-million shopping center in Baldwin Harbor, L.I.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 13 Mr. and Mrs. George Erskine Rice have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Trawick Rice, to Ens. Charles Henry Harper 4th, U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. Harper 3d of Port Washington.

The New York Philharmonic veered sharply last night from the main route of the Stravinsky Festival it is presenting at Philharmonic Hall this month, and offered a song recital by Elisabeth Schwarzkopf, who was accompanied at the piano by John Wustman.

IN a recent decisive 30-board match, Jericho High School clinched the Long Island High School Chess League Championship by overwhelming Lawrence High, 22-8. On the march toward the victor's crown, Jericho also defeated Glen Cove. Mecham and Great Neck South in the finals section.
CINCINNATI, July 13 (UPI) Don Heffner was dismissed today as manager of the Cincinnati Reds and Dave Bristol, a coach, was appointed interim manager.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, July 14 United States Navy jet fighters shot down a Communist-built MIG-17 in an aerial duel with six MIG's near Hanoi yesterday, a United States military spokesman said today.

WASHINGTON, July 13 Majority Leader Mike Mansfield may ask the Senate to go into executive, or secret session tomorrow when the bill to expand supervision of the Central Intelligence Agency is reported to te floor.

Additional pressure on the Federal Maritime Commission is being brought to bear by the steamship industry in an effort to have the regulatory agency promptly issue a declaratory order on the controversial question of military cargo procurement by competitive bidding.
Harry M. Stevens, Inc., the hotdog concessionaire who was knocked out of the ring at Madison square Garden half a century ago, is getting a rematch.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 13 (AP) Grier Jones, a 20-year-old Oklahoma State University sophomore, scored a 6-and-5 triumph today over Dave Haberle of the host Edina Country Club in the first round of the Trans-Mississippi amateur golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) --The Administration's foreign aid authorization bill sailed through its first House test tonight when attempts to cut the time period to a single year failed by a vote of 122 to 86.

Mayor Lindsay took just 45 seconds, beginning at 4:56 P.M. yesterday, to sign five bills under which $217-million in new city taxes will be collected. The quiet ceremony ended four months of bitter wrangling here and in Albany over the new imposts.

BERKELEY, Calif., July 13 (UPI) Sam Bell, the director of the ill-fated United States-Poland track meet, which became the "all America invitation" after the Poles canceled, said today that eight more Americans had accepted invitations for the weekend event.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 13 An international incident in which the United States is only coincidentally involved developed at Roosevelt Raceway this morning when Armbro Flight, the Canadian-owned winner of last week's $100,000 International Trot, was withdrawn from Saturday night's $25,000 Gold Division of the Challenge Cup Trots.

DETROIT, July 14 (UPI)--A system to pipe voiced warnings and directions into cars and enable a driver to dial from his auto for an ambulance or a tow truck was unveiled today by the General Motors Corporation.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 13 Mrs. Allan A. Ryan of The Creek and Mrs. Brenard D. Freeman of Inwood posted a 34, 37-71 today to take the lead in the Women's Long Island Golf Association 36-hole betterball-of-partners championship at the Maidstone Club.

HOPKINSVILLE, Ky., July 13 Mr. and Mrs. George Lloyd Seay have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Bonnie Anne Seay, to Stephen Matthew Schuster Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Schuster of New York.
WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) The Justice Department filed an antitrust suit today to block the proposed $385-million sale of a part of the TideWater Oil Company to the Phillips Petroleum Company.
LONDON, July 13 Mrs. Sandra Payson Meyer of New York and George Weidenfeld, a publisher here, announced today in The Times of London that they plan to marry soon.

Hilliard J. Coan, who was ousted May 24 as chairman of E.J. Korvette, Inc., sold 46,150 of his common shares in June, it was disclosed yesterday in an insider report released by The New York Stock Exchange.
ROME, (AP) Italy's top designers unveil their fall creations this week. The selection promises to put shapeliness and frills back into high fashion.
"WE are striving for the Total Look," a spokes- man for Stern's said, pointing to one of the five new model rooms on the store's seventh floor.
WASHINGTON, July 13 The first signs of progress in negotiations to end the six-dayold airline strike appeared today as bargaining resumed after an overnight breakdown in the talks.
GREAT RIVER, L.I., July 13 Mrs. Joan St. John of the Babylon Yacht Club captured today the Morgan Bowl, emblematic of the women's sailing championship of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association.
WASHINGTON, July 13 Two Czechoslovak diplomats made an attempt to plant an electronic listening device in the State Department but were foiled by a department employe, it was disclosed today.
MEXICO CITY, July 13 A former chairman of Mexico's dominant Institutional Revolutionary party has suddenly become its most bothersome gadfly.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) President Johnson signed today the authorization bill providing a pay raise of 3.2 per cent for members of the armed forces and $17.4-billion in military buying. The authorization was passed by Congress yesterday.
A dynamic little string band from Puerto Rico was the novelty at last night's folk concert at Lewisohn Stadium.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 13 Annual school budgets were approved by the taxpayers yesterday in five Suffolk school districts that hold July elections.

The overwhelmingly Democratic City Council strongly endorsed Republican Mayor Lindsay yesterday in the city's dispute with the Port of New York Authority over the $525-million World Trade Center in Lower Manhattan.
With less than a year left before President Johnson loses his broad authority from Congress to conduct trade negotiations, the Kennedy Round of bargaining sessions in Geneva is moving into high gear.

WASHINGTON, July 13 Chairmanships of at least two major Congressional committees will change hands next January if yesterday's unofficial returns in Virginia's Democratic primary are confirmed by the official canvass.
TEHERAN, Iran, July 13 The Iranian Government is considering the purchase from the Soviet Union of surface-to-air missiles for defense of the Persian Gulf, according to authoritative sources.
ROME, July 13 (Reuters) Milton A. Gordon, a New York investor, stid tonight that he would ship at least $100-million of Rumanian canned ham and pork to the United States over the next 10 years.
Benefiting from high volume and improved prices in chemicals and plastics, the Monsanto Company turned in the best quarterly results an its 65-year history in the three months ended June 30.

MILWAUKEE, July 13 Stanley Smith of Pasadena, Calif., defeated Australia's fifthranking player, William Bowrey, in the United States claycourt tennis championships today, and joined Dennis Ralston of Bakersfield, Calif.; Cliff Richey of San Tngelo, Tex.; Tony Roche and Owen Davidson of Australia and Frank Froehling 3d of East Orange, N.J., in the quarter-finals.
LONDON, July 13 (Reuters) Italy, a two-time winner of the World Soccer Cup, lived up to its promise as a likely finalist in the 1966 series tonight by gaining a 2-0 victory over Chile.

Arthur E., Palmer Jr., the Mayor's transportation administrator, said yesterday that he had resolved all his differences with state highway officials over new road projects proposed for New York City.

The ancient Greeks and Romans took it for granted that mid-July would be hot and uncomfortable, as it has been. They blamed it all on bright Sirius, the Dog Star, which, their astronomers reported, rose and set at approximately the same times as the sun at this season of the year. They thought it provided the added heat that made men and animals so miserable on earth.
In most discussions of the transfer of a home, the emphasis usually is on the buyer and his problems and expenses. But the seller, too, has much to contend with, par-...
Raybrn S. King, president of Rayburn S. King, Inc., funeral directors, died yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived at 265 West 81st Street.
ST. LOUIS, July 13 (AP) The death toll attributed to a current heat wave continued to mount in the St. Louis metropolitan area today as one official expressed concern it might reach several hundred.

CHICAGO, July 13--Violence erupted again tonight in a Negro neighborhood on the Near West Side. Windows were broken, rocks were thrown, and Molotov cocktails were hurled from a public housing project. At least two persons were shot.

Barry Stetson of Eastchester, an unseeded player, joined the top three favorites in the junior division semi-finals of the Easttern junior and boys tennis championships yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens.
HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., July 13 Three parachutists staged a perfect skydiving exhibition here this evening, but ended their 6,000-foot fall in the arms of the law.

WASHINGTON, July 13 The State Department's vision of the kind of Europe and Atlantic alliance it wants was outlined on Capitol Hill today by Under Secretary George W. Ball, but Senate liberals criticized it almost as much as they usually do when policy on Vietnam is at issue.

WATERTOWN, Mass., July 13 Mr. and Mrs. John Pallotta have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Johanna Antoinette Pallotta, to Dr. Michael John Stephen of New Haven. He is the son of Dr. Theodora Stephen of Oxford, England, and the late Prof. Henry Stephen.
PARIS, July 13--The French, who once felt punished if they were required to go abroad, have come to love travel and officials here say this is why France is losing so much money on tourism.

Repeal of the breakage law that went into effect at the New York thoroughbred race tracks a year ago was asked by the New York Racing Association in its annual report to the State Racing Commission, issued yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 13 A spokesman said today that Secretary General Thant was concerned about the possible fate of United States airmen captured in Vietnam and equally concerned about all victims of bombing and of fighting.
CLEVELAND, July 13 Former Mayor Ray T. Miller Sr. died today in his home at Shaker Heights, apparently of a heart attack. He was 73 years old.
THE American West was finally won in many ways most decisively by Amer ican armies in the roaring eighteenforties thrusting southward toward Mexico City, the most dazzling city on the continent.

A supporter of one of the candidates in a disputed Brooklyn primary election walked through an unguarded lobby Tuesday night into a deserted office where records of the vote were being kept. A guard is supposed to be on duty in the lobby to prevent unauthorized visitors from entering the building.
The spot rate on the British pound checked its recent slide with a moderate gain yesterday in fairly active trading on foreign-exchange markets here.
Parks Commissioner Thomas P.F. Hoving announced yesterday that five municipal outdoor swimming pools would be kept open until midnight during the heat wave.

GENEVA, July 13 Dr. Nahum Goldmann, President of the World Jewish Congress, said today that any deferment of West German payments to the aging Jewish victims of Hitler's Germany involved these survivors of Nazi terrorism in an unacceptable "race between justice and mortality."
The Playboy bunny will soon don its nation's fighting uniforms. But fear not, the move is not an attempt to cover up anything.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., July 13 Gov. Otto Kerner signed an executive order today to curtail segregation in housing.
Mayor Lindsay will make a personal effort today to try to end the 80-day-old shutdown of the World Journal Tribune, Inc.

In rejecting the flexible and generous terms recommended by a Presidential emergency board and all attempts at arbitration of the airline strike, the leadership of the International Association of Machinists is taking an unreasonable and irresponsible stand, deliberately flouting the public interest.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) House Republicans said today there were "rumors floating around" that the Administration may have dropped antitrust suits against companies whose executives contributed to the Democratic party. Klein Terms Pearson 'Left Wing' Julius Klein said here yesterday his friendship with Senator Thomas D. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, was an innocent one.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) The Atomic Energy commission asked Congress today to approve a "significant strengthening" of the nation's effort to harness the hydrogen-bomb reaction to produce electrical power.
New-car sales fell more than 21 per cent in the first 10 days of July from the 1965 level, according to reports received yesterday from Detroit.
WASHINGTON, July 13 The Johnson Administration urged Congress yesterday to halt the rapidly escalating rate war among financial institutions for the savings dollar.

CHICAGO, July 13 The bond of a 240-pound Negro youth accused of beating a 150-pound white soldier on a subway train to the cheers of 25 mostly Negro passengers was raised from $2,500 to $15,000 by Judge Saul E. Epton in North Boys Court. The judge acted after learning that the attack suspect had lied to him in previous testimony.

THE Late Show has been playing on and off Seventh Avenue this week. Normal Norell made the titans of retailing come to his showroom Monday evening in black tie to see his fall collection. Tzaims Luksus invited them to look at his clothes at midnight Tuesday at L'Etoile.
WASHINGTON, Thursday, July 14 Scientists lost contact with the Surveyor 1 spacecraft on the moon late last night, apparently for good.
WASHINGTON, July 13 The Administration succeeded today in forcing the cancellation of a 5 per cent price increase on molybdenum announced six days ago.
Prices declined on a broad front yesterday on the American Stock Exchange in light trading.
WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) The House Commerce Committee voted today to make Federal safety standards effective on 1968 model cars.
PARIS, July 13 The French Cabinet approved today a record 1967 budget providing for the equivalent of $22-billion with something for everyone.

TO remove stubborn stains or marks from shoes made of Corfam poromeric material, a damp cloth and soap, mild detergent or saddle soap may be used, according to E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., makers of the leather substitute.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 13 Application to operate an ultra-high-frequency television station in eastern Long Island has been filed with the Federal Communications Commission by the owners of radio stations WRIV in Riverhead and WALK in Patchogue. The final decision on the application is expected in the fall.

WASHINGTON, July 13 Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation observed meetings between William Henry Whalen, a retired Army lieutenant colonel, and Soviet diplomats here from 1959 to 1961, officials said today.
A legislative committee will hold public hearings on the operation of Surrogates' Courts this summer in the state's mayor cities.
The election of Gordon L. Fullerton as a senior vice president was announced here yesterday by Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., a subsidiary of the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange continued to drift off yesterday, but a slight upturn occurred near the close.

Pennsylvania Station succumbed to progress this week at the age of 56, after a lingering decline. The building's one remaining facade was shorn of eagles and ornament yesterday, preparatory to leveling the last wall.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 13 The number of enemy soldiers and former enemy sympathizers defecting to the Saigon Government has almost doubled this year, according to a survey made public today. The study was made by the Minister of Information.

LONDON, July 13--Five British fishermen who left the trawler Loveden after a mysterious radio SOS were charged tonight with piracy. They will appear before a magistrate's court tomorrow at Grimsby, the east coast port from which the trawler sailed.

New York City is losing half a million dollars a day in tourist revenues as a result of the six-day-old airline strike, the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau found yesterday in a survey of tourist businesses.

CHICAGO, July 13 Plans to establish a resident professional theater in Chicago were announced today by Mayor Richard J. Daley, whose Committee for Economic and Cultural Development will sponsor the project. The committee had been studying the feasibility of such a theater for two years.

JACKSON, Miss., July 13 Holmes County Deputy Sheriff T.J. Evans, accused in a civil rights suit of beating a Negro woman in the Holmes County Jail last May, has agreed to payment of damages to the woman for settlement of the case, a Federal court was told here Wednesday.
Frederick David Clark of 333 East 79th Street, who had recently engaged in real estate development in the Canary Islands, died Monday in New York Hospital, after a long illnes. His age was 35.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 13 (UPI) Charles O. Viar's Bay Phantom, invading the East for the first time this year, went to the front at the start of the $16,500 Rumson Handicap at Monmouth Park today and led all the way to win the sixfurlong race by 2 lengths.
The Wheeling Steel Corporation has come to the defense of the Plastering Institute of Greater New York, whose battlecry is "Keep New York Plastered."

Mr. and Mrs. Murray Martin of 315 East 65th Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lucy Adelle Martin, to Gioacchino Sebastiano Gianino, son of Mr. and Mrs. Antonio Gianino of Boston.

A $200-million real estate deal, one of the largest involving a single property in the history of New York City, has paved the way for construction of a 52-story office skyscraper in the block just north of Pennsylvania Station.
Unless the Governor vetoes a ludicrous proposal just enacted by the New York Legislature, another patently unenforceable piece of censorship legislation will become law.

UNITED NATIONS, July 15 (UPI) The Czech mission to the United Nations today formally rejected as "absolutely unfounded." United States charges that one of its members had tried to "bug" the offices of high-ranking United States State Department officials.
CHICAGO, Friday, July 15 Roving gangs and snipers in the predominantly Negro West Side exchanged gunfire last night and early this morning with heavily reinforced police patrols.

WASHINGTON, July 14 The House Rules Committee, in a rare move, issued a report today accusing Representative Adam Clayton Powell of dodging committee efforts to question him about a $250,000 anti-poverty investigation made under his jurisdiction.

A low bid of $1,000,746 $431,000 less than had been estimated for the job was received by the city yesterday for beginning the rehabilitation of the West Side Highway. The over-all $30-million job is scheduled to take four years.

Facing what Prime Minister Wilson officially acknowledged yesterday as a renewed financial crisis, the British Government clamped down the tightest credit restrictions in recent memory and warned that further stern measures would follow to rescue the beleaguered pound.

ALBANY, July, 14 The Lindsay administration has asked Governor Rockefeller to veto bills that would mandate what it called "astronomical costs" on the City University and would add $1.6-million to the city's pension costs.
PARIS, July 14 The French Foreign Legion marched again today, on a particularly joyous Bastille Day here.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 14 Mr. and. Mrs. David Hillman have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Churchill Hillman, to Morrison Coates Huston Jr., son of Mrs. E. Howard York 3d of Villanova and Mr. Huston of Devon.
A blueprint for clearing up a "bitter and acrimonious" controversy over waterfront work assignments has been issued after weeks of study by the permanent port arbitrator.

MANHASSET, L.I., July 14 Leopold Schorr, a principal of the New York accounting firm of Peat, Marwick, Mitchell Co., died yesterday in the North Shore Hospital here after an illness of several months. He was 59 years old and lived at 166-25 Powells Cove Boulevard, Beechurst, Queens.

WASHINGTON, July 14 By a margin of only two votes, the House of Representatives averted today a crippling blow to the $4.1-billion foreign aid authorization bill. The vote was 193 to 191 on a Republican-sponsored motion to reduce the twoyear authorization to a single year and to trim $250-million from the $1-billion ceiling on long-term loans for economic development.

LONDON, Friday, July 15 A Welsh nationalist upset the Labor party early today in a by-election setback for Prime Minister Wilson. The winner will be the first member of the party to sit in the House of Commons.
Mayor Lindsay appealed last night to members of the Drug and Hospital Employes Union for an immediate end to their work stoppages, which spread yesterday to four voluntary hospitals.
Shrugging off an increase in the British bank rate, the stock market rallied yesterday, recapturing part of the ground lost in the declines of the preceding two sessions.
ST. PAUL., July 14 (AP) Jacky Cupit used a masterly shortiron game today to shoot a six-under-par 65 and take a one-stroke lead in the first round of the $100,000 Minnesota Golf Classic.
West, Weir Bartel, Inc., has announced the appointments of three senior vice presidents and the election of a fourth to the agency's board.

FORT DIX, N.J. July 14 Three soldiers held in a barracks here for six days were freed this morning when the Army decided not to prosecute them for antiwar statements. However, the men were ordered to board awaiting plane for Vietnam, and when they refused, they were arrested on charges of insubodination.
The United States Court of Appeals here ruled out yesterday as "inherently vague" the loyalty oath requirement of the influential Directors Guild of America, the motion-picture directors' union.
LONDON, July 14--The Government clamped down today the tightest credit restrictions in recent memory and warned that further stern measures would follow to rescue the beleaguered pound.
The American Stock Exchange began yesterday its search for a new president to succeed Edwin D. Etherington. Indications were that the quest would proceed on an urgent basis.
The historic 110-year-old Strong Place Baptist Church in Brooklyn, which was vandalized three months ago and later abandoned by its dwindling congregation, was occupied once again yesterday.
WIESBADEN, Germany, July 14 (AP)--Countess Elizabeth Von Soden of Stuttgart won the first title in the 1966 world shooting championships today.
NEWARK, July 14 A three-day strike by Local 825 of the Operating Engineers Union, which had halted work on more than $100-million in road and building construction, was called off today.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia July 14 Koca Popovic, a richman's son who became a Com munist, was unanimously ac claimed as Vice President of Yugoslavia today by the 670 mem bers of the Federal Assembly
WASHINGTON, July 14 Dr. Barnaby C. Keeney, former president of Brown University, was today sworn in as chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities.
MOSCOW, July 14 Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin charged tonight that the United States was guilty of "vandalism and barbarism on an international scale" in Vietnam.
The Aeolian Chamber Players will begin a three-year residence on the campus of Sarah Lawrence College this fall under a grant of $101,000 from the Rockefeller Foundation.

Mayor Lindsay and Anthony J. DeAndrade, international president of the Printing Press men's Union, met early today on the deadlocked negotiations between the union's Local 2 and the World Journal Tribune, Inc.
CHICAGO, July 14 An alarm clock rang. Corazon Amurao knew it was 5 A.M. because she had set the alarm last night when she and her roommate went to bed.

While the Democrats battle among themselves over a candidate for Governor, the Republicans have set up an organization that, they hope, will become the most comprehensive campaign apparatus ever formed by the party in this state.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 14 The first four seeded players William Tully, George Gondelman, Bradley Drowne and Irving Suntag won quarter-fi nal matches today in the New York men's 35-and-over tennis championships.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 14 Adlai E. Stevenson 3d informed the United Nations today of the organization in Chicago of an international institute as a memorial to his father.

Mayor John V. Lindsay and Jamaica's acting Prime Minister, Donald Sangster, were lifted to the top of a light pole yesterday for the unveiling of a plaque bearing Jamaica's coat of arms. The ceremony took

Mayor Lindsay, acting under the authority of the State Legislature, yesterday appointed 17 trustees of the Old Met Opera House Corporation, a nonprofit group formed to try to save the old Metropolitan Opera House at Broadway and 39th Street from demolition.

Hal Holbrook's solo performance in "Mark Twain Tonight!" is expected to be televised next season as a 90-minute special show by the Columbia Broadcasting System. The actor completed a successful Broadway engagement last month.
The rise in the British bank rate, though widely expected, kept the London stock market on a downward path in limited volume yesterday.
Tentative agreement was reached yesterday on a twoyear contract giving the city's 675 lifeguards wage increases of 14 to 28 per cent.

The week-old airline machinists' strike has yet to ground high-flying airline stocks but airline stock analysts are casting a weather eye at earnings prospects as vacation days pass by with the planes in the hangars.
Doyle Dane Bernbach, Inc., appears to be developing something of a reputation as a spe- cialist in corporate ad campaigns.

WASHINGTON, July 14 Secretary of State Dean Rusk warned North Vietnam today that the trial and punishment of captured American pilots as "war criminals" would be regarded as "a very, very grave development indeed.

The head of the Buitoni Foods Corporation, which the Government has accused of fraudulent advertising in saying that its spaghetti was low in calories and protein-enriched, said yesterday he would "be happy to cooperate" in changing Buitoni labels if the Food and Drug Administration required such action.

Brooklyn Bridge won the Queens County Chamber of Commerce Purse, the feature on the program at Aqueduct yesterday. The 4-year-old colt, owned by Mr. and Mrs. Winston Guest, was able to take the mile event by three lengths over the Tartan Stable's Chinatowner, with the Greentree Stable's Peter Piper next in the field of eight.
CARTHAGE, Mo., July 14 (AP) Explosions rocked a Hercules Powder Company plant near here today, but workmen had a 20-minute warning and officials said all had escaped death.
ULAN BATOR, Mongolia, July 14--Mongolia's sprawling capital struggled today to overcome the effects of a disastrous flood that has taken scores of lives and left thousands homeless.
WASHINGTON, July 14 The negotiations to end the week-long airline strike have reached "a serious impasse on a number of issues," a Federal mediator said today.

PARIS Every time July 14 rolls around and France celebrates Bastille Day, revolution and royal decapitations, Americans respond with emotional enthusiasm as old allies and fellow revolutionaries of the same eighteenth-century vintage.

WESTBURY, L.I., JULY 14 Chicago King, a 4-year-old gelding who never had paced a winning mile in faster time than 2:02 1/5, improved his best by 12/5 seconds in capturing tonight's feature invitation pace before 20,940 at Roosevelt Raceway.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 14 Adam Malik, Indonesia's Foreign Minister, today denied reports that the Soviet Union had not been invited to a conference of Indonesia's creditor nations scheduled to open in Tokyo July 19.

PITTSBURGH, July 14 (UPI) The Pittsburgh Pirates took the National League lead by 2 percentage points tonight with a 10-4 victory over the Chicago Cubs behind the heavy hitting of Roberto Clemente, Jose Pagan and Donn Clendenon.
The appointment of C.R. Schaeffner as director of Litton Industries' Fast Deployment Logistics Ship project has been announced by the company.

WASHINGTON, July 14 A Republican Congressman said today that there were many un answered questions surrounding the Justice Department's decision to drop an antitrust case involving a big Democratic party contributor August A. Busch Jr., president of the Anheuser-Busch Company, the nation's largest beer producer.

The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company will build a 22story office building at Broad and Water Streets on the site that until recently had been designated for a new headquarters for the New York Stock Exchange.

The increase in the Bank of England's bank rate to 7 per cent from 6 per cent had relatively little impact on bond prices here. Government bond prices declined slightly while corporates rose a little.

A lawyer filed charges with the civilian complaint police review board yesterday alleging that three policemen had been illegally detained, searched and arrested by superior officers in the department.

New York State needs 4,000 more school librarians, and New Jersey 2,000. These figures were given yesterday by Mary V. Gaver, president-elect of the American Library Association, to illustrate national shortages.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (UPI) An examiner for the Civil Aeronautics Board recommended today that Pan American World Airways be given the right to carry passengers between the West and East Coasts on its international flights.
CINCINNATI, July 14 Miss Margaret McAllister and Lieut Kenneth G. Ward, U.S.A.F., graduates at Ohio Wesleyan University, will be married here on Aug. 6.
That woman playing Bingo or that man idly looking around a shop may be an inspector from the City Department of Licenses.

WASHINGTON, July 14 In response to pressure from the Senate, Secretary of State Dean Rusk announced today that he would appoint a special aide with the rank of Assistant Secretary to direct and supervise. United States help to millions of refugees around the world.

DUBLIN, July 14 Fifteen years almost to the day when the old Abbey, Theater was burned down, a new and resplendent Abbey Theater will open here on Monday night. President Eamon de Valera, who laid the foundation stone of the new building on Sept. 3, 1963, will be there with a gathering of notable contributors to the artistic and cultural life of Ireland.
The fighting in Vietnam continued last week to demonstrate the limitations of the missile.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 14 All hands for the flight of Gemini l0 practiced their parts today as final preparations began for the nation's next space mission, scheduled to begin late Monday afternoon.
Attended swearing in of Dr. Barnaby C. Keeney as new chairman of the National Endowment and Council for the Humanities; gave luncheon honoring Australian Prime Minister Harold Holt.

The East 60's will be the scene of a walking tour at 2:30 P.M. Sunday, Aug. 7, sponsored by the Museum of the City of New York. The tour will meet at Hunter College on Park Avenue between 68th and 69th Streets.

Good News, a 64-foot yawl built 27 years ago anti rejuvenated last winter by her owner, Jakob Isbrandtsen of New York, was near Scotland's Orkney Islands yesterday in the trans-Atlantic race from Bermuda to Denmark.
The Sunshine Mining Company disclosed yesterday that it may make a tender offer for all the outstanding shares of U.S. Industries, Inc., in exchange for Sunshine securities.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 14 Preliminary reports from provincial authorities indicated today that about 700 candidates, an unexpectedly large number, had filed for election to this fall's constituent assembly, which is to draft a South Vietnamese constitution.

The city's Transportation Administration promised yesterday to make a new study of complaints that converting Fifth Avenue to one-way traffic had disrupted bus service and vehicular flow in Greenwich Village and lower Fifth Avenue.
PARIS, July 14 Lucien Aimar, a shy young carpenter wearing the Ford colors, won the 53d Tour de France today, despite a lionhearted final drive by the favorite, Raymond Poulidor.

The most intense July heat wave in the city's history sent the temperature to 95 degrees yesterday, but the Weather Bureau promised substantial relief today with the arrival of cool air from Canada. The high for today should be in the middle or low eighties, the bureau said.
PROVO, Utah, July 14 (AP) Part of a ski chair lift broke in a rugged Wasatch mountain canyon this afternoon and spilled eight persons 50 feet, killing two and seriously injuring the others.
A $309-million deal for the purchase of Tidewater Oil Company properties on the West Coast by the Phillips Petroleum Company was completed last night despite Government opposition.
