Samuel Blumberg, a lawyer who represented trade associations and manufacturers, died yesterday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 84 years old and lived at 30 East 65th Street.

Plans by the German Atlantic Line to put a new German luxury liner on the trans-Atlantic run by 1969 became firm yesterday when final financial arrangements were completed for construction of the $22million ship.
HARTFORD, July 14 Gov. John N. Dempsey announced today the resignation of Paul J. Driscoll as a state Public Utilities Commissioner and Raymond S. Thatcher as state Controller.
LONDON, July 14 (AP) The statement of account of the Bank of England for the week ended yesterday (in thousands of pounds) follows:

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 14 Carl McAdams, Bill Yearby, Pete Lammons and Jim Waskiewicz are the four rookies considered most likely to succeed among the 30 who reported today on the opening day of the New York Jets training camp at Peekskill Military Academy.

BOONTON, N.J., July 14 Mrs. George Dwyer of White Beeches took a long step toward her third straight New Jersey Senior Women's Golf Association championship today when she carded a 48, 45 93 at The Knoll Golf Club in Boonton.

Savings accounts at the nation's more than 6,000 savings and loan associations dropped by an estimated $1.2-billion in the period from July 1 through July 8, informed sources in Washington said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (UPI) The White House said today that working press credentials would be denied Women's Wear Daily, a fashion trade newspaper, for prematurely releasing embargoed news material on the bridesmaids' gowns for the wedding of Luci Baines Johnson.
WASHINGTON, July 14 Scientists on earth have lost radio contact with Surveyor 1, apparently forever.

WASHINGTON, July 14 Railroad freight carloadings and intercity truck tonnage in the week ended July 9 which included the Independence Day holiday, were both ahead of the volume in the corresponding week of last year.

A Federal grand jury indicted eight Queens real estate salesmen yesterday on charges of inducing former members of the armed services to lie about their assets to obtain Veterans Administration insurance on mortgages.
RICHMOND, July 14 (AP) A canvass confirmed today the defeat of Representative Howard W. Smith in his bid for renomination in Tuesday's Democratic primary.
Sandy Koufax, who "lost" his curve ball two weeks ago, still hadn't found it last night when the second half of the major league baseball season opened at Shea Stadium.
MIAMI, July 14 (AP) Tropical storm Celia, the third in this year's season, spun toward the Bahamas today with top winds of 50 miles an hour.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 14 Diane Matzner, 17 years old, of West Hempstead L.I., won the 18-years-and-under division of the girls' Eastern clay court tennis championships today by defeating Judy Dixon, 16, of Essex Fells, N.J., 6-1, 6-0, at the Round Hill Club.

PHILADELPHIA, July 14 Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Irwin have announced the engagement op Mrs. Irwin's daughter, Miss Carolyn Frances Keel, to Thomas Blumer Hovey, son of Chandler Hovey Jr. of Brookville, L.I., and the late Mrs. Nancy Blumer Hovey.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP)--Senator Stephen M. Young, Democrat of Ohio, protested today what he called the attempted intimidation of witnesses in the Senate ethics committee's investigation of misconduct charges against Senator Thomas J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederick O. McKenzie of 923 Fifth Avenue and New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Adelaide Keene McKenzie, to Jean Andr Sviatopolk-Mirsky, son of Princess Stanislawa SviatopolkMirsky of Grau-Du-Roi, France, and the late Prince Andr Vladimirovitch Sviatopolk-Mirsky of Kiev, Russia.
BRUSSEL, July 14 The agricultural ministers of the European. Economic Community postponed tonight until next Thursday a final drive to resolve a string of price and marketing issues.

Stravinsky greatly admired Tchaikovsky's music, and Rimsky-Korsakov was Stravinsky's respected teacher. But if the Stravinsky festival concert by the New York Philharmonic at Philharmonic Hall last night was supposed to illustrate the influence the earlier pair had on the younger man, the point was lost.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 113.1 on Wednesday from 113 on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, July 14 Following are the parties involved, the issues in dispute, and a brief summary of the effects of the airline strike: THE PARTIES The Interna- tional Association of Machinists and Eastern, National Northwest, United and Trans World airlines.

NEENAH, Wis., July 14 A September wedding is planned by Miss Mareia Clark Catlin and John E.D. Coffey Jr. Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. John Blanchard Catlin, parents of the future bride. Mr. Coffey is the son of Mrs. Coffey of Babylon, L.I., and the late Mr. Coffey.

Alfred Hitchcock's "Torn Curtain," the director's 50th film, which opens here July 27, has been sharply criticized by the National Roman Catholic Office for Motion Pictures for its "gratuitous introduction of premarital sex between its sympathetic protagonists."

BUENOS AIRES, July 14 The two-week honeymoon between the new military regime of President Juan Carlos Ongania, and the powerful labor unions dominated by supporters of the former dictator, Juan D. Peron, appeared near an end today.

WASHINGTON, July 14 Business inventories rose by $1.4-billion in May, a rise that was considerably more than the average of about $1-billion a month in each of the three previous months, the Commerce Department reported today.
DETROIT, July 14 (UPI) Fred Gladding and Orlando Pena, a pair of relievers, put down a ninth-inning rally tonight to save a 4-3 triumph for the Detroit Tigers over the Baltimore Orioles.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) The Government's new and revised auto safety standards, which are expected to become the basis for general vehicle safety standards, were approved today.

WASHINGTON, July 14--In both the United States and Britain these days the main opposition to President Johnson and Prime Minister Wilson on Vietnam policy is coming not from the Conservatives in London or from the Republicans in Washington but from the American Democrats and the British Socialists. Everything is a little mixed up.
Burry Biscuit's ice cream division to Compton Advertising, Inc., Chicago.

UTICA, N. Y., July 14 (AP)--Gail Sykes of Schenectady, the medalist; 18-year-old Lancy Smith of Snyder, Debbie Austin of Kenwood and Mrs. Albert Bower of Pelham gained the semi-finals of the state women's amateur golf championship today.
THREE new groups of model rooms on Macy's ninth floor focus on comfort, leisure living and the teen- ager.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., July 14 (AP)--Brigitte Bardot, the French movie star, was married shortly after last midnight to a 33-year-old German industrialist and sportsman, G nther Sachs.

MILWAUKEE, July 14 Charles Pasarell of Puerto Rico and Martin Riessen of Evanston, Ill., filled the two remaining quarter-final brackets in the United States clay-court tennis championship today at the Town Club. Nancy Richey of San Angelo, Tex., reached the semi-finals in the women's singles.
HARTSDALE, N.Y. July 14 George Ball, who recently won the national senior claycourt title, advanced to the final of the Westchester senior tennis championships today.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 14 The Ladies Village Improvement Society will hold its 70th annual fair July 29 on the, grounds of the 17th-century Mulford Farm fronting the Main Street green here. Mrs. John L. Northrop, Mrs. Irwin Tiedeman and Mrs. John Putnam are chairmen.

The Western Union Telegraph Company reported yesterday first-half net income of $9,775,000, equal to $1.08 a share. This compared with restated first-half earnings of $7,677,386, or $1.02 a share, in the corresponding 1965 period.

Robert D. Goldstein, Richard F. Kerr and Louis Levine were appointed yesterday as operating vice presidents of Abraham and Straus, the Brooklyn unit of Federated Department Stores, Inc. Mr. Goldstein was also named director of management information systems.

LINCOLN Mass., July 14 Mr. and Mrs. Archibald W. Adkins have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Adkins, to Richard MacAlester Kirby, son of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Kirby of New York.

ANAHEIM, Calif., July 14 (UPI) Rich Reichardt singled in the bottom of the 10th with the bases loaded tonight to score Bob Rodgers with the winning run as the California Angels defeated the Boston Red Sox, 3-2.

Livingston L. Wingate, recently restored as executive director of Haryou after a battle over finances, faces a new fight from members of his board of directors who want to oust him from the Harlem antipoverty organization.
VIENTIANE, Laos, July 14 About 75,000 North Vietnamese are working in the Ho Chi Minh Trail area of southeastern Laos, Western diplomatic sources said today.

Dollar Brand, a jazz pianist from South Africa, brought the "Jazz in the Garden" series to the threshold of the avant-garde last night with a program that managed to be both provocative and irritating a reasonably healthy balance.

Capt. Heinrich Lorenz, a retired senior shipmaster for North German Lloyd who sailed in the North Atlantic for more than 40 years, died Wednesday night at Bad Kreuznach, West Germany, after a short illness, according to word received by the line. He was 67 years old.

The killer of eight nurses in Chicago yesterday added another chapter to the voluminous annals of wholesale slaying. Mass murder was an ancient crime long before the celebrated exploits of Bluebeard and Jack the Ripper.
WASHINGTON, July 14 The Johnson Administration suggested today that it might, "under certain circumstances," permit some trade with Communist China.
The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation yesterday reported record secondquarter and first-half sales and earnings.
MOSCOW, July 14 (UPI)--The Soviet Union accused Communist China today of playing into the hands of United States propagandists by charging Soviet-American "collusion" in air raids on North Vietnam.

MILWAUKEE, July 14 (AP) George Demling, who quit his job as a supply clerk in Louisville to play in the national public links golf tournament, routed Arne Dokka, the medalist and defender, 5 and 4, to gain the semi-finals today.
The "wildcat" strike of nonmedical personnel at some of New York's major voluntary hospitals is immoral, illegal and indefensible.
MANILA, July 14 (UPI) The Philippines today became the fourth foreign nation to commit a sizable force to South Vietnam, joining the United States, Australia and South Korea.
Charles Belous, Deputy County Attorney for Nassau and a former New York City Councilman, died Wednesday in his home at 10 Cliff Way in Port Washington, L.I. He was 59 years old.
Two relatives of Delmore Schwartz laid claim to his body yesterday at the mortuary of the City Medical Examiner, 520 First Avenue.
ATLANTA, July 14 (UPI)--Joe Torre hit a two-run homer in the ninth inning tonight to give the Atlanta Braves a 7-6 victory over the Houston Astros.
PARIS, July 14 (AP) Denis Hutchinson of South Africa won the French open golf championship by a stroke today on the 6,525-yard, par72 La Boulie course with a 274.

"Land Under the Pole Star," by Helge Ingstad, Norwegian explorer and scholar, which St. Martin's Press will issue on Aug. 1, is a study of the founding of the Greenland settlements in the tenth century and their disappearance in the fifteenth.
The leasing of office space here rose sharply last month, continuing the fast pace set in the previous months of this year.
CHICAGO, July 14 Eight student nurses were killed here early this morning in one of the most savage multiple murders in the history of crime.
CHICAGO, July 14 (AP) Wayne Causey's run-scoring double with two out in the eighth gave the Chicago White Sox a 2-1 victory over the Cleveland Indians tonight.

Reflecting the huge demand for paper products, record sales and earnings were reported yesterday by the Scott Paper Company, the Container Corporation of America, the Union Camp Corporation and Champion Papers, Inc.

WASHINGTON, July 14 After an extraordinary closed session, the Senate turned aside today an attempt to enlarge the committee supervising the activities of the Central Intelligence Agency. The vote was 61 to 28.

PANAMA, July 14 The National Department of Investigation said today that a student had confessed implication in the killing of another whose mysterious death set off riots in the city of Colon last June 6. The riots caused the death of two students and more than $1million damage.

EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., July 14 (AP) It appears wings may not be mandatory for certain types of flying, judging from the success of a new craft intended to play an important part in American space flight.
JAMES GALANOS, the Californiabased designer who looks as if he might have been wafted here on a stiff breeze, unfolded his latest fashion statement at the Plaza Wednesday.

Money-market conditions continued tight during the week ended Wednesday despite an apparent easing in a key indicator of monetary policy, according to figures issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

The Administration's wageprice guidelines may not be dead, as demonstrated by the Government's success Wednesday in rolling back the molybdenum price increase. But the tone of industry-Government price conflict has definitely changed.
WASHINGTON, July 14 Prime Minister Harold Holt of Australia charged today that Britain and Western European countries had turned their backs on developments in Southeast Asia.

PHILADELPHIA, Miss., July 14 (UPI) Neshoba County Hospital, battling with the Federal Government over certification for Medicare, said today that 26 elderly Medicare patients would have to pay their own way or leave.

The Senate has given a powerful thrust to the fight for cleaner air and water in America. Without a dissenting vote it has passed and sent to the House a $6.2-billion, six-year program to eliminate water pollution and a bill authorizing $196 million over three years to combat air pollution.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., July 14 Mrs. Ralph Shirkes of Briar Hall scored 39, 43 82 at the Pelham Country Club today and won the low gross prize in the one-day tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association by two strokes.

ROCKVIILLE CENTRE, L.I., July 14 The engagement of Miss Judith Chemers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Chemers, to William Frederick Levine, son of Nassau County Court Judge Manuel W. Levine and Mrs. Levine of Port Washington, has been announced by the future bride's parents. A wedding in October is planned.

BOSTON, July 14 "Substantial progress" has been made among the 10 leading financial nations toward "agreement on fundamental principles" in creating a new international monetary reserve asset in the future, Under Secretary of the Treasury Frederick L. Deming said tongiht.

BONN, July 14 Three leaders of West Germany's Social Democratic party addressed the people of both Germanys tonight with speeches they would have made in the East German city of Karl-Marz Stadt today if the Communist Government had not backed out of a planned exchange of debates.

A 58-year-old former investigator for the city's Alcoholic Beverage Control Board was indicted yesterday on charges he had impeded the long-run New York County grand jury inquiry into corruption in the State Liquor Authority.
The election of Herbert B. Daitch as a trustee of the Bronx Savings Bank was announced by John M. Nosworthy, president.
After a day of cautious trading, grain and soybean futures closed with moderate to heavy losses on the Chicago Board of Trade as a result of a rash of late selling.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) The Air Force intends to make contracts with universities to provide scientific teams to investigate promptly and in depth sightings of unidentified flying objects.
The conflict between Israel and the Arab world over the waters of the Jordan River began in 1954, when Israel announced plans to tap the Jordan's waters to irrigate the barren Negev.
SADDLE RIVER, N.J., July 14 For the new queen of Wimbledon, tennis has "got to be fun; otherwise it's just no good."

MONTREAL, July 14 (AP)--A collision between a British freighter and a Canadian ore carrier yesterday off the eastern tip of Montreal Island played havoc with small pleasure boats anchored at a nearby boating club.
Rabbi Elmer Berger, executive president of the American Council for Judaism, took issue yesterday with a proposal of the World Council on Jewish Education to establish full-time Jewish day schools.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 14 United States Air Force fighter planes defending bombers over North Vietnam shot down two MIG-21's with air-to-air missiles northwest of Hanoi today.
With a bit of good fortune and a little financial razzledazzle, the city has picked up $1-million that it did not expect to have in its treasury in midJuly.
THE annual Pro-Am tour- nament of the Middle Bay Country Club in Oceanside, L.I., one of the oldest and most successful of such events, was played Wednesday night.
On a movie lot at Elstree, England, yesterday, Jim Brown confirmed his retirement from pro football.
A bitter disagreement between the Lindsay administration and the Port of New York Authority broke into the open yesterday as their negotiations over the World Trade Center reached a serious deadlock.
WASHINGTON, July 14 A board fence 23 times longer than the one Tom Sawyer was ordered to Whitewash is being tackled by Washington teenagers with as much enthusiasm as Tom's willing victims had.
Walter L. Darfler, 66 years old, has been elected president of Halsey, Stuart Co., a major Chicago investment banking concern.
United States Commissioner of Education Harold Howe 2d urged the nation's big cities yesterday to consider breaking up their school systems into a number of independent school boards.
PHILADELPHIA, July 14 (AP) The Philadelphia Phillies ended Gaylord Perry's sevengame winning streak as they scored a 5-0 victory and dropped the San Francisco Giants to second place tonight.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 14 (AP) Don Mincher hit a two-run homer and Jim (Mudcat) Grant and Pete Cimino held the Washington Senators in check as the Minnesota Twins posted a 3-1 victory tonight.

BALTIMORE, July 14 The engagement of Miss Lambryn Mavrikos to Dr. Nicholas John Pappas Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Pappas of Savannah, Ga., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. John Mavrikos, parents of the future bride.

WASHINGTON, July 14 Part of the genetic machinery of a virus is demonstrably present and active in the living cells made cancerous by that virus, according to a report published today in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.
MOSCOW, July 14 The rebuff by John Steinbeck to the plea last week by Yevgeny Yevtushenko, the Soviet poet that he speak out against the war in Vietnam has not yet been published here.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) The Democratic party's elite fund-raising organization, the President's Club, has told Congress it took in more than $1million in the first five months of this year.
GENEVA, July 14 Christians and their churches should promote radical and even revolutionary social change, the World Conference on Church and Society was told today.
American track and field officials arranged a meet yesterday to replace the canceled United States-Soviet Union competition July 23 and 24 at the Los Angeles Coliseum.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 14--The Soviet Union put a snag today in the slow progress being made by the committee of experts on plans for future financing of the United Nations.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange rallied sharply yesterday recovering more than half of their losses from the preceding three days of decline.

In the middle of yesterday afternoon at Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx, Al Whittaker, the administrative coordinator of laboratory services, walked down the main corridor in the central building, pushing a 4-foot-high green barrel mounted on little wheels. He wore a white coat and the badge of his high office.
MOSCOW, July 14 The rebuff by John Steinbeck to the plea last week by Yevgeny Yevtushenko, the Soviet poet that he speak out against the war in Vietnam has not yet been published here.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) The Democratic party's elite fund-raising organization, the President's Club, has told Congress it took in more than $1million in the first five months of this year.
GENEVA, July 14 Christians and their churches should promote radical and even revolutionary social change, the World Conference on Church and Society was told today.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 14--The Soviet Union put a snag today in the slow progress being made by the committee of experts on plans for future financing of the United Nations.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange rallied sharply yesterday recovering more than half of their losses from the preceding three days of decline.

In forcing the cancellation of a 5 per cent price increase posted by producers of molybdenum, the Administration has served notice that it does not intend to abandon the controversial wage-price guideposts in its war against inflation.
TORONTO, July 14 (Canadian Press) "Like Father, Like Fun," a comedy by Eric Nicols, opened here tonight at the Royal Alexandra Theater in a warmup for Broadway.

CHICAGO, July 14 (AP) Carefully delineated investigative procedures set out only three days ago were followed to the letter today, and will be followed, the police said, in questioning anyone in connection with the murder of eight student nurses.
CINCINNATI, July l4 (AP) Dal Maxvill drove in four runs and Lou Brock socked a two-run homer as St. Louis defeated Cincinnati, 9-7, tonight after the Reds won the opener of the double-header, 9-2.

In the chapel of the First Presbyterian Church here yesterday afternoon, Miss Mary Kathryn Taylor, daughter of Mrs. William H.Taylor of Mexico City and the late Mr. Taylor, was married to Joseph L. Boland 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Boland Jr. of Weston, Conn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. James Speer.

SEOUL, South Korea, July 14 The small "open window" to North Korea at Panmunjom has had its blinds drawn for a month and a half as both the United Nations command and the Communists have refused to yield ground in a procedural dispute.
Additional policemen were sent to the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn early this morning following reports of several incidents of minor violence.

CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., July 14 Miss Mary Goode Krone, president of the State Civil Service Commission, was married today to Charles H. Sells of Cross River, former State Superintendent of Public Works. The Presbyterian ceremony was performed at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Krone, by the Rev. Paul H. Young.

Fifty years ago today, with the United States on the verge of war, William E. Boeing formed an aircraft manufacturing company with $100,000 because he believed he could build superior airplanes types that might be attractive to the armed forces.
WASHINGTON, July 14 The Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers eliminated a constitutional provision yesterday that said nonwhites could not belong to the 40,000-member labor union.
The United States Weather Bureau, at 11 P.M. yesterday, made this forecast for Long Island Sound, Montauk to Block Island, New York Harbor, the lower Hudson River and nearby offshore waters.

AREA A There has been little surf fishing around Surf City the last few days. Some fluke have been caught in Barnegat Bay Stripers have been caught off the jetties in Long Branch, along with some fluke, blackfish and kingfish. The bigger boats have been landing six to 12-pound blues at the Acid Waters.
NEW HAVEN, July 14 The Federal Government is hunting beetles in Fairfield County.

For six days the reservation telephone lines of nonstriking airlines have been continuously and frustratingly busy. At 5 P.M. yesterday, for example, the phone at American Airlines did ring, but 245 rings later nobody had answered.

The jubilation of moderate and liberal forces over the evident defeat of Representative Howard W. Smith in Virginia's Democratic primary is tempered by one unpalatable by-product: under the seniority system Representative William M. Colmer of Mississippi will succeed Mr. Smith next January as chairman of the immensely powerful House Rules Committee.

LOVE is all fire; and so heaven and hell are the same place....Eden is a fiery city, just like hell. The truth concealed from the priest and revealed to the warrior: that this world always was and is and shall be ever-living fire. Revealed to the lover too: every lover is a warrior; love is all fire....To be aflame at every point.

WASHINGTON, July 14 The Department of Commerce tentatively predicted today a reduction of about $1-billion this year in the surplus of United States exports over imports, despite a prospective substantial increase in exports.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost of dining in any particular establishment.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation, a major manufacturer of electrical and electronic products, attained the highest sales and earnings for any quarter in its 80-year history in the three months ended June 30. D.C. Burnham, president, noted yesterday that results for the first half were also at a new height.
A musical version of John Steinbeck's "East of Eden" will be presented on Broadway in February by Mitch Miller.

Brian Gottfried, a l4-year-old boy from Cape Coral, Fla., upset Steve Siegel of Teaneck, N.J., the top-seeded player, 6-4, 6-0, to reach the junior division final of the Eastern junior and boys' tennis championships yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, Queens.

ESSEX, Conn., July 14 Herbert Lee Seward, professor emeritus of mechanical and marine engineering at Yale University, died today at the Highland Hall Convalescent Hospital here. He was 81 years old and lived on Sea Lane in Old Saybrook.

The shock produced by the Soviet Government's decision to cancel several Soviet-American sports competitions is itself testimony to the success with which both countries have managed up to now to safeguard their relationship despite the war in Vietnam.
JACK LENOR LARSEN introduced his first collec- tion of fashion fabrics this week, as well as a new collection of home furnishings fabrics.

KANSAS CITY, July 14 Accepting three unearned runs in the eighth inning, the New York Yankees defeated the Kansas City Athletics tonight, 5-4, amid details that did nothing to further the cause of poetic justice.
The Foreign Policy Association has named Zygmunt Nagorski Jr. special assistant to the president for World Affairs Council activities.

SPORTS for sports' sake is a noble ideal that Americans inherited from their British forebears. But once the Soviet Union stepped beyond the Iron Curtain for cautious forays into the realm of international athletics they introduced their own strange concepts. Sports became a propaganda arm of the government.
WASHINGTON, July 14 The Federal Reserve Board took no action today to raise the discount rate in the wake of Britain's move to a higher bank rate in that country.
The spot rate on the British pound made the biggest improvement of recent weeks in active trading yesterday on foreign exchange markets here.
Joseph McBride and his 18year-old son, Terry, won the metropolitan father-and-son golf championship yesterday for the third consecutive year.
TEL AVIV, July 14 Israeli jet planes attacked an antiaircraft position and earth-moving equipment eight miles inside Syria today in what the Israelis said was a reprisal for Arab incursions.

Wielding an oversize pair of shears, Leontyne Price yesterday cut out the first of 45,000 swatches from the gold damask brocade curtain of the abandoned Metropolitan Opera House at Broadway and 39th Street.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) The Senate passed by 77 to 2 today a bill to appropriate $7,064,343,300 in new money to operate the Agriculture Department in the fiscal year that started July 1.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) The key civil rights spokesman for House Republicans endorsed today the open housing provision of the Administration's 1966 civil rights bill.
The Navy awarded two defense contracts yesterday totaling more than $360million.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 15 Syria declared her determination today to carry on with her policy for the "liberation" of Palestine unhindered by "Israeli aggression."
A funeral service for Delmore Schwartz, poet, editor and critic, will be held at 10 A.M. Monday at the Gramercy Park Chapel, 152 Second Avenue, at 10th Street.

BONN, July 15 United States Army headquarters in Heidelberg sent a protest to the commander of Soviet troops in Germany today over the forcing down of an American helicopter by a Soviet helicopter in West German territory yesterday.
The city's 675 lifeguards voted overwhelmingly yesterday to accept a two-year contract with wage increases retroactive to July 1 of $2 and $3 a day for guards and of $5 to $7 a day for supervisors.
A race that fits neatly into the traditional picture of thoroughbred competition in this region, the $75,000 added Dwyer Handicap, will have its 49th running today at Aqueduct.

LAST night's Stravinsky Festival program at Phil- harmonic Hall was the first devoted solely to Stravinsky's music. The emphasis was on chamber music with the historic music drama "l'Histoire du soldat" the focal point.
SALEM, N.H., July 15 Even with a bunch of nobodies in the field, tomorrow's $89,250 Rockingham Special would rate as something special.

PARIS, July 15 (UPI) Thomas Koch and Jose Edison Mandarino won their opening singles matches today to give Brazil an unexpected 2-0 lead over France in their European Zone Group A Davis Cup tennis matches.
Collective bargaining negotiations between the city and the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association and the Uniformed Firemen's Association have broken down.

CHICAGO, Saturday, July 16 National Guard troops patrolled the streets of Chicago's Negro West Side last night and early today. For the first time in four nights there was no major violence in the riot-torn ghetto area.

Dr. Gedeon Eros, director of clinical laboratories at the Brooklyn State Hospital, died Thursday at his home on the hospital grounds at 681 Clarkson Avenue, in the East Flatbush section. He was 67 years old.
OTTAWA, July 15 (AP) Canada will send 10 prepackaged hospitals to South Vietnam for civilian use, the External Aid Office announced today.

Obesity among Americans is a major public health problem that is bound to get worse as the nation eats more and exercises less, a panel of experts concludes. They reach this conclusion in a report soon to be published by the United States Public Health Service.
The Weyerhaeuser Company, the big West Coast manufacturer of timber products and paperboard, realized the best quarterly and half-year earnings in its history in the periods ended June 30.

McGraw-Hill, Inc., in its second acqquisition bid in a week, offered yesterday to acquire Educational Development Laboratories, Inc. in an exchange of stock. The amount was not disclosed. Trade sources estimated the transaction in excess of $10million.

MOSCOW, July 15 Izvestia, the Soviet Government newspaper, published a dispatch from North Vietnam tonight reporting that the Hanoi regime was determined to go ahead with trials of captured United States pilots.

HONG KONG, July 15 North Vietnam denounced peace moves today for the second day in succession and asserted the country's determination to fight until it wins complete victory over United States forces.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 15 The Rev. Hobart Jude Gary, rector of St. John's Episcopal Church here since 1957, has been named rector of St. George's Episcopal Church in Bridgeport, Conn.
PITTSBURGH, July 15 The Consolidation Coal Company today set July 25 as the new record date for a special shareholders' meeting now scheduled for Aug. 16. The previous record date was May 27.
Leslie Fay, Inc., the diversified women's apparel producer that entered the men's wear field late last year, is preparing to venture into its first men's national brand.
MOSCOW, July 15 (AP) Fifteen United States swimmers will compete against swimmers from the Soviet Union and three other nations in an international meet tomorrow.

Thousands of Americans of Greek descent, going to Greece aboard charter flights this summer, are being forced to travel part of the way by rail, bus or boat because of a Greek Government order banning charter flights to Athens.
Mayor Lindsay characterized as "absolutely untrue" yesterday an assertion by the Port of New York Authority that he had reneged on a promise to expedite construction of the World Trade Center.
BRUSSELS, July 15 "Brussels, Brussels, can I make an emergency landing?" a pilot shouted into his microphone today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 15 The first hidden microphone of a vast secret police listening network in the homes of the Communist leadership was discovered by accident June 9 in President Tito's living quarters.
Joseph C. Singer of 380 Bernard Place, Ridgefield, N.J., a former vice president of Revlon International, died Thursday in University Hospital after a long illness. His age was 57.
The spot rate on the British pound slumped sharply yesterday in active trading on foreign exchange markets here. It had made a recovery the day before.

PEKING, July 14 A China in the throes of a "cultural revolution," aimed at eliminating the last vestiges of opposition to Chairman Mao Tse-tung and his thoughts, has published a credo for the guidance of literary workers. The doctrine calls for an unremitting struggle until the last revisionist and the last capitalist disappear from the face of this planet.
Net income of the Colorado Fuel and Iron Corporation, a basic steel producer, fell to $1.14 a share in the second quarter from $1.53 a share in the 1965 period, the company reported yesterday.

HARRISON, N.Y., July 15 Mr. and Mrs. George M. O'Neil Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan O'Neil, to Kevin Connor Lynch, son of the Attorney General of California and Mrs. Thomas C. Lynch of San Francisco. The wedding is planned for September.
LONDON, July 15 (Reuters) Hungary ended Brazil's 12-year unbeaten streak in World Cup soccer competition tonight with a 3-1 victory at Liverpool in a magnificently played match.
Fingerprints showed yesterday that a man found dead in a hotel here was a priest who disappeared from Shelton, Conn., on June 27.
A 16-year-old hero went on the city payroll yesterday as a reward for saving a woman's life last week.

WASHINGTON, July 15 Natural gas companies that formerly used liberalized deprecia- tion rules to save income taxes but then switched back to the old rules when ordered to pass the cash saving on to their customers must nevertheless continue to charge the lower prices, the Federal Power Commission ruled today.
Directors of the Cooper Tire and Rubber Company proposed yesterday in Findlay, Ohio, a three-for-two stock split of the common shares.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) Representative Edward A. Garmatz, Democrat of Maryland, announced today that the House Merchant Marine Committee would open hearings Wednesday on bills to make the Maritime Administration an independent agency.
Will Weissberg, photographer for the Waldorf-Astoria, died Thursday at Maimonides Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 57 years old and lived at 185 Hall Street in Brooklyn.
CARSON CITY, Nev., July 15 Gov. Grant Sawyer of Nevada ordered a state investigation today into reports that millions of dollars in gambling profits are going to the underworld.
DETROIT, July 15 Earl Wilson, a pitcher, pinch-hit a threerun home run in the 13th inning tonight to give Detroit an 8-5 victory over Baltimore.
PHILADELPHIA, Miss, July 15 (UPI) The Neshoba Coun ty Hospital said today it would file suit against a Government agency to gain certification for Medicare.
HORSEHEADS, N.Y., July 15 Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. carried his quest for the Governorship today through an area where delegates and Democrats are almost equally scarce.

CHICAGO, July 15 The only survivor in the murder of eight women in a nurses' dormitory told the police today that she believed she could identify the killer, described as a slender white man about 25 years old.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 15 (AP) Duncan Johnston, a jeweler, has been named heir to a $1-million fortune because he fixed the broken clasp of a handbag a woman had brought him.
ANCHORAGE, July 15 Alaska's oil business is looking so good that representatives of the big petroleum companies are beginning to rival the politicians in their enthusiasm over its prospects.
NONGHOI, Thailand, July 8 At one end of the new Accelerated Rural Development road, amid a humid scrub forest and waterlogged rice paddies, stands the "model village" of Nonghoi.

MADRID, July 15 The Spanish authorities, acting on a court order, seized today the current issue of the Catalanlanguage monthly magazine Serra d'Or, published at the Benedictine monastery of Montserrat, near Barcelona.
WIESBADEN, Germany, July 15 (AP) The Soviet Union won the individual and team free pistol titles in the world shooting championships today.

The City Council of Linden, N.J., late Thursday night rejected bids for a small issue of bonds, bringing to five the number of municipalities that decided this week not to sell bonds because of high interest rates.
The Interstate Commerce Commission has ordered a Sept. 8 prehearing to consider procedural aspects of the Norfolk Western Railway and the Chesapeake Ohio Railway merger proposal.

MOSCOW, July 15 (AP) Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India accused Communist China tonight of rejecting peaceful coexistence and promoting "tension in justification of a dogmatic belief in the inevitability of war."
Rudolph A. Peterson has been elected to the board of the Fund American Companies and its subsidiary, the Fireman's Fund Insurance Company, it was announced yesterday in San Francisco.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 15 (AP) Edgehill Farm's Our Michael, a five-time stakes winner last season, was much the best of the field of six 3-yearolds competing in the six-furlong feature today at Monmouth Park.

WASHINGTON, July 15--Eighteen of the most outspoken Senate critics of American tactics in Vietnam cautioned Hanoi today that any punishment of captured American pilots would seriously injure the forces of moderation here.
WASHINGTON, July 15 The industrial production index rose by eight-tenths of a point in June to 155.8 per cent of its 1957-59 base.

A man who allegedly shot a three-foot arrow into the hip of a woman acquaintance, causing her to bleed to death, was indicted yesterday by a New York County grand jury on first-degree manslaughter charges.
Isabelo Rivera hummed happily as he stirred white mountains of mashed potatoes around in one of the huge stainless steel kettles in the kitchen of Mount Sinai Hospital yesterday afternoon.
QUOGUE, L.I., July 15 Mrs. Austin J. Tobin, wife of the executive director of the Port of New York Authority, was critically burned this morning in a fire at the Tobins' country home here.
GREENWICH, Conn., July 15 Lennart K. Nylander, a retired Swedish diplomat who resided here, died of a stroke yesterday in Greenwich Hospital at the age of 65.
One of the most puzzling reports by the astronauts has been that they are unable to see stars on the daylight side of the earth.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (UPI) Lucy Baines Johnson and Patrick J. Nugent will live in Austin, Tex., after they are married.

WASHINGTON, July 15 A helicopter pilot equipped with a patented helmet-sight can fire accurately by merely looking at his target and pulling the trigger. A control mechanism linked to the helmet keeps the guns aimed along the pilot's line of sight.
WASHINGTON, July 15--The United States formally recognized today the new government of Argentina, which came to power in a coup d'etat two weeks ago.
LONDON, July 15 (Reuters) The Soviet Embassy today refused visas to four United States and two British newsmen seeking to accompany Prime Minister Wilson on his visit to Moscow tomorrow.

AGRAH, Iraq, July 14 A two-day tour of some Kurdish areas of northern Iraq indicates there is hope but not yet assurance of a peaceful settlement of the long guerrilla war with Kurdish rebels led by Gen. Mustafa al-Barzani.

Federal officials intend to review whether overcrowding and shortages of staff and equip- ment disqualify the city's 21 municipal hospitals from receiving Medicare funds, Health and Hospital Department officials said yesterday.

SANTIAGO, Chile, July 15, (AP) The Government of Chile raised the price of export copper today to 70 cents a pound. Industry sources predicted that the move would drive customers to less expensive substitutes.
EDMONTON, Alberta, July 15 (AP) Harry Jerome of Vancouver, B.C., ran the 100-yard dash in 9.1 seconds tonight to match the world record held by Bob Hayes of the United States.

Fred Gorree, an interior designer, leaned over the edge of his roof yesterday morning and surveyed the greenery that his initiative had brought to East 19th Street between Park Avenue South and Irving Place.
At its new level, Chilean copper is still about 2.5 cents a pound below that of the African producers, which sell primarily to the European market.
Larchmont Race Week, a vigorous 68-year-old sailing fixture, will spread boats, mostly one-design, all over the western end of Long Island Sound for eight days starting today.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 15 (UPI) Former Premier Reino R. Lehto died Wednesday after a short illnes at the age of 68. Mr. Lehto served as Premier in 1963-64. Later he was Governor of Uusimma County. The cause of his death was not disclosed.

ATHENS, July 15 A year after his removal as Premier of Greece, George Papandreou sat on the floodlit veranda of his villa outside Athens this evening and waved while a mass of cheering supporters paraded by for three hours.
The city's summer antipoverty program was unable to meet its first payroll yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Bienstock of Forest Hills, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carole D. Bienstock, to Gerald B. Fischer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Fischer of Scarsdale, N. Y. A December wedding is planned.
PARIS, July 15 Ten thou sand people a day are leaving Hanoi under governmentplanned evacuation, according to a French news agency report from North Vietnam today.
OTTAWA, July 15 The program to unify the Canadian armed forces ran into a revolt of admirals today.
SYDNEY, Australia, July 15 Sir William Spooner, a former Minister for National Development, died here last night. He was 68 years old.

Now that the World Trade Center negotiations seem deadlocked, a way must be found to stop the current recriminations between city and Port Authority and to reopen a sensible discussion. The city has presented a strong case for larger payments than were originally envisaged for the use of city land and also in lieu of taxes. The Port Authority should now make a counterproposal, which it has so far refused to do.

DARIEN, Conn., July 15 Mrs. Julia Lancaster Blood of 4 Oak Crest, an honorary deputy sheriff of Fairfield County, died Thursday at Carolton Hospital, Faitfield. She was 86 years old and was the widow of George Blood.
A Federal Court order directing the General Electric Company to explain why it should not be enjoined from continuing to refuse to bargain with a union representing its employes was signed yesterday.

SILVER SPRING, Md., July 15 Mr. and Mrs. Jerome B. Bodnick have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Michelle Louise Bodnick, to Capt. Howard H. Berman, Medical Corps, U.S.A. He is the son of Col. Harry L. Berman, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Berman of Ellicott City, formerly of New York. A December wedding is planned.
VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., July 15 (AP) Residents of Martha's Vineyard reacted angrily today to a proposal that the state build a toll bridge between Cape Cod and the island.

TOKYO, July 15 (Reuters)--The Vietcong killed, wounded or captured nearly 112,000 troops, including more than 47,000 American and "mercenary" soldiers, in the first half of 1966, Hsinhua claimed today.

Talks with the Printing Pressmen's Union aimed at getting New York's merged newspapers onto the streets reached the top-level stage yesterday, 81 days after start of publication was delayed by labor disputes.
WASHINGTON, July 15 A minimum wage bill that complies in all basic respects with the Administration's wishes was approved today by a Senate labor and public welfare subcommittee.

The Republican Coordinating Committee's statement on the United Nations is less important for its specific proposals or election-year criticism of the Democrats than for its resounding support for the world organization. The know-nothing element in the party will find little encouragement in this significant policy pronouncement, which is in the tradition of the Eisenhower Administration rather than the extremist trend of 1964.
A leading French aviation authority, Henri Bouche, is retiring this month at the age of 73 from his post as French representative on the Council of the International Civil Aviation Organization.
GREAT FALLS, Mont., July 15 (AP) A truck smashed into a station wagon leading a camping caravan of teen-agers from Eastern states today, killing five and injuring four others.

Dr. Ernest W. Reid, former president and board chairman of the Corn Products Refining Company, predecessor of the Corn Products Company, died of a heart ailment yesterday in St. Petersburg, Fla. He was 75 years old.

CHICAGO, July 15 "Put the Marines here, put the Marines here," Julia Greenberg shouted as she watched workmen board over the broken windows of her corner variety store on West Madison and Sacramento Streets.

New Yorkers got a breath of relief from the heat yesterday. They were told to expect a sparkling, rainless weekend the sort that makes a visit to the seashore a pure pleasure, instead of a flight from oppression.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) Controller of the Currency James J. Saxon criticized today's restrictions on savings instruments as discrimination against small depositors who buy most of the multiple maturity issues.
LONDON, July 15 A West Indian train guard, barred from a job at one of London's busiest stations by a color bar operated by the white staff and tolerated by the management, won the job today.
In every respect it was a shoddy performance of the Senate majority in barring members of the Foreign Relations Committee from a panel that keeps watch over the Central Intelligence Agency.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 15 The United States is now providing a quarter of Saigon's rice needs to forestall hunger and discontent among the poor, authoritative sources disclosed today.

THERE are thousands of varieties of peaches, but most are classified as either clingstone or freestone. Both have white and yellow flesh and are grown in almost every state in the Union. Clingstones are used chiefly for canning, while freestones are sold fresh as well as for canning and drying.

WASHINGTON, July 15 Bernard L. Boutin, the new administrator of the Small Business Administration, disclosed to Congress today a series of steps aimed at clearing up abuses in the troubled Small Business Investment Company program.
MINNEAPOLIS, July 15 (AP) Bob Smith, a 23-year-old Sacramento State senior, defeated Marty Fleckman today in the feature match of the Trans-Mississippi golf tournament's quarter-final round.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 15 In pro football they move fast these days. The New York Giants and the Pittsburgh Steelers staged a controlled scrimmage a game of sorts-here today only four days after the players involved, mostly rookies, had reported to their traiinng camps.
The London stock market suffered one of its sharpest setbacks this year yesterday as prices tumbled in reaction to Prime Minister Wilson's promise of a continuing tightening of the credit squeeze.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 15 (AP) A Federal district judge ruled today that the national bituminous coal wage agreement of 1950 did not violate antitrust laws.

An offer to build a new opera house at cost on a new site has been made by the real-estate concern that wants to tear down the old Metropolitan Opera House, an aide to Mayor Lindsay disclosed yesterday.

UTICA, N.Y., July 15 (AP) Lancy Smith, a dark-haired teen-ager making her fourth bid for the title, moved into the final of the New York State women's amateur golf tournament today with a 19-hole victory over the medalist, Gail Sykes.

The Fedders Corporation, a manufacturer of air-conditioners, reported yesterday a loss of $317,340 on sales of $14,266,421 in the quarter ended May 31, contrasted to a profit of $1,116,127, or 52 cents a share, on sales of $18,929,516 a year earlier.

GLEN OAKS, L.I., July 15 Dr. and Mrs. Maurice Moore of Rockville Links won today the Charles A. Stillman Memorial Trophy in the 13th annual husband-and-wife championship of the Women's Cross County Golf Association.

MILWAUKEE, July l5--In a succession of stunning reversals, Dennis Ralston of Bakersfield, Calif.; Tony Roche of Australia and Charles Pasarell of Puerto Rico were beaten in the United States clay court tennis championship at the Town Club today.

Announcement has been made here of the engagement of Miss Susan Ruth Blankley to Peter Merrill Watkins of Essex, Conn. Miss Blankley is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W.H. Roy Blankley of New Barnet, Hertfordshire, England. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Armitage Watkins of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., and New York.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) A Missouri housewife and her husband testified today, that she had been addicted to the tranquilizer Equanil, to which she turned after taking Preludin for diet control and energy.
ANAHEIM, Calif., July 15 (UPI) George Brunet scored his fifth straight victory tonight, allowing three hits two of them home runs as the California Angels defeated the Boston Red Sox, 4-2.

LILLY DACHE held the season's most informal hat show Thursday night in the fourth-floor Art Gallery of her East 56th Street headquarters. It was a toss-up as to whether the hats or the paintings were the more colorful but most of the time, it was difficult to see either.
Cooler weather in parts of the Middle West led to selling of soybeans and some grain futures yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.
A crowd of 50,423 saw the New York Mets do everything to the Los Angeles Dodgers for 11 innings last night but beat them.

Records and films are competing with books for the attention of the thousands who have been attending the American Library Association conference in New York. They testify to the growing technological revolution that promises to make the library of the future a far different place from the institution we know today.
The white-haired man stepped slowly into Room 1311 at 201 Park Avenue South and walked up to the receptionist, 19-year-old Dorothy Stratton.
PHILADELPHIA, July 15 (AP) Willie Mays and Jim Hart of the San Francisco Giants hit home runs tonight as Juan Marichal gained his 15th victory of the season, defeating the Philadelphia Phillies, 8-1.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 15 The men and machines of Gemini 10 were declared ready today for their three-day double rendezvous mission, scheduled to be launched from here Monday afternoon.

VINALHAVEN, Me., July 15 Miss Judith Benet, daugh- ter of Mrs. Liles Benet of Cambridge, Mass., and James Walker Benet 2d, of San Francisco, was married here today to Philip Livermore Richardson. He is the son of Mrs. George W. Wheelwright 3d of Sausalito, Calif., and Vinalhaven, and the late Arthur Welland Richardson of Boston.

The lone struggle for nearly a year by a New York Customs appraiser has resulted in a nationwide directive telling Customs officials to refrain from trying to force employes to buy United States savings bonds.

Dr. Louis W. Granirer, a specialist in internal medicine and former chief of the arthritis clinic at Queens General Hospital, died Thursday in New York Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived at 135-02 Rockaway Beach Boulevard in Belle Harbor, Queens.

Dr. and Mrs. Joseph L. Goldman of 1185 Park Avenue have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Jane Goldman, to Sheldon Elliot Steinbach, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Steinbach of New York and White Meadow Lake, N.J. The wedding will take place on Aug. 14.
TOKYO, July 15 (AP) A Peking radio broadcast heard here said that United States planes had again raided Hanoi today.

LAGUNA BEACH, Calif., July 15 To the local art colony of this seaside resort, this is the happiest week of the year. For it marks the beginning of an arts festival that has brought a financial bonanza to the local painters and a cultural windfall to the town as a whole.

WESTPORT, Conn., July 15 "These swimming pools," said Burt Lancaster with a gentle but sweeping gesture of his hand, "are really quite oldfashioned. They don't have adequate filter systems and they aren't heated!"

ONE of the most colorful of the old-time bridge experts, Fred D. Kaplan, died in New York earlier this month at the age of 64. He was a winner of the Vanderbilt and Reisinger trophies and of many other titles, in spite of his lack of restraint in describing the shortcomings of his partners.

MOSCOW, July 15 A delegation of American rabbis has arrived in Moscow on a mission to sort out conflicting reports about the status of Jews in the Soviet Union and to "let the Jews of Russia know that we have not forgotten them."

ALBANY, July 15 Aides of Mayor Lindsay are exploring ways to end the annual litany over city-state fiscal affairs in which the Mayor of New York often pleads for hundreds of millions of dollars of additional state assistance for the city and the Governor of New York generally responds by saying the state can't afford it.
WASHINGTON, July 15 The airline strike went into its second week today with no sign of an early settlement.
BUENOS AIRES, July 15 (AP) Horacio Accavallo of Argentina retained his world flyweight boxing championship tonight with a 15-round decision over the challenger, Hiroyuki Ebihara of Japan.

The Rev. and Mrs. John J. Hicks of Manhattan have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Paula LaRue Hicks, to James Conwell Jr., son of Mrs. Robert Whitaker of St. Louis and the late Mr. Conwell.

Only a week ago British officials were saying that no further measures to deflate the economy and bolster the pound were required at present. Now the Government has boosted the bank rate from 6 to 7 per cent; reduced the lending capacity of banks by another $280 million, and promised still more restrictive measures to come.
CHICAGO, July 15 (AP) Tom McCraw's single highlighted a three-run Chicago rally in the seventh inning tonight as the White Sox defeated the Cleveland Indians, 4-2.

The International Jazz Festival at Comblain-la-Tour, Belgium, will be one of the musical events carried on the new "Bell Telephone Hour" series next season, Highlights on Aug. 6-7 will be filmed on location to be televised later. Among Americans participating will be Benny Goodman and Stan Getz.
BORDENTOWN, N.J., July 15 A Negro barber was accused of racial discrimination today because he refused to cut Negroes' hair.

BOSTON, July 15 A weeklong international investment symposium closed here today with participants, including a number from abroad, headed home on the heels of a prediction that the United States faces a recession in the last half of 1967.

The Mayor walks up and down garbage-strewn alleyways. The Police Commissioner patiently submits to sharp questionning in storefront churches. The city puts sprinkler caps on many of its 9l,000 fire hydrants to provide free hot-weather showers for jumpy youngsters. More patrol cars carrying both a white and a Negro policeman cruise racially tense neighborhoods.

SACRAMENTO, Calif, July 15 (UPI) The National Farm Workers Association has agreed to call off its grape pickers' strike and consumers' boycott against the DiGiorgio Corporation, pending a union representation election.
WASHINGTON, July 15 The Federal Reserve Board put new restrictions today on some of the methods commercial banks have been using to attract savings.

The head of the National Marine Engineers Beneficial Association has asked Mayor Lindsay to revoke all CondonWadlin Law penalties against 17 municipal ferry officers and clear the way for their immediate rehiring with full civil service status.
CINCINNATI, July 15 (AP) Orlando Cepeda hit two home runs tonight before he was thrown out of the game and powered the St. Louis Cardinals to a 9-2 victory over the Cincinnati Reds.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., July 15 Mrs. Page Wilson and Norman Bacon have announced the engagement of their daughter Miss Marjorie Goodyear Bacon, to Mark Peter Krinsky, son of Mrs. Louise Krinsky of St. Paul Minn., and the late David Krinsky. A December wedding is planned.
Four major lumber associations reported a decline of 27.7 per cent in production for the week ended July 9, compared with the level in the corresponding 1965 week.

A drive north from Manhattan to the John Jay Homestead in Bedford, N. Y., and to Boscobel, in Garrison-on-Hudson, offers a fascinating study of contrasting approaches to the furnishing of historic houses today, and some understanding of unanswered questions in the field of Americana.
TORONTO, July 15 (Canadian Press) The Aluminium Company of Canada will not be getting raw materials from Guyana forever, in the view of Prime Minister Forbes Burnham of Guyana.

PAPEETE, Tahiti, July 15 In keeping with the boom times that have come to French Polynesia, the picturesque old wooden buildings that gave Papeete the look of a typical seedy South Seas port in the days of Robert Louis Stevenson are being torn down.
A Deputy Mayor and the Welfare Commissioner agreed yesterday to go to Albany with a group of relief clients who want grants raised "at least to the poverty line."
PITTSBURGH, July 15 (AP) Robin Roberts pitched the Chicago Cubs to a 5-4 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 15 With Canada's Armbro Flight, Roquepine's conqueror in last week's $100,000 International Trot, resting in Chicago, the French mare will have only two motives, pride and money, in the Gold Division of the Challenge Cup Trot at Roosevelt Raceway tomorrow night.
NEW ORLEANS, July 14 (AP) George Price Shaw, a former diplomat, died today at the Veterans Administration Hospital here. He was 73 years old.

How has the higher transit fare affected retail business in New York City? Did the two-week heat wave dent or spur store traffic? Retailers find the answers hard to come by. One reason is that a strong consumer turnout at the stores for hot-weather merchandise has tended to cover up the true impact of the higher city transit fares that became effective July 5.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (UPI) The State Department announced today that an official in the United States Embassy in Prague had been expelled by the Czechoslovak Government for similar American action against a Czechoslovak diplomat who tried to "bug" official quarters here.
MILWAUKEE, July 15 (AP) Dave Ojala of Two Harbors, Minn., and Monty Kaser of Wichita, Kan., gained the final of the national public links golf tournament today.

STAMFORD, Conn., July 15 Gamecock, sailed by Robert Shiels of Darien, Conn., defeated Alliance, with Van Alan Clark of Marion, Mass., at the tiller, in the first Class C race of the North American MultiHull Sailing Association championship regatta on Long Island Sound off the Stamford Yacht Club today.

AT first glance it's a melange of clothes, customers, books, beds and bric-a-brac. Then the picture clears and a Dior may be discovered among the Dacrons, a Ming Buddha among the "miscellaneous bargains."
Prices moved irregularly higher yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.
Murder, robbery, assault and other major crimes have been reduced nearly 60 per cent in the 15 months since the Transit Authority put policemen on every train and in every subway station at night.
Tucked away in Pfc. Richard E. Marks's sea bag in Danang, South Vietnam, was a letter the 19-year-old marine had written but had hoped would never be read.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 15 (AP) Clifford Ann Creed shot a par 72 and took a onestroke lead today in the first round of the $15,000 Lady Carling Midwest open golf tournament at Stoney Creek.

The Broadway musical "It's A Bird... It's a Plane... It's Superman" will end its run at the Alvin Theater on West 52d Street after tomorrow's matinee, the 129th performance, unless "there's an upsurge in business."
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, July 15 (Reuters) Norwegian windjammers were in the first three positions in the 1966 tall ships race from England to Denmark tonight, according to unofficial estimates.

KANSAS CITY, July 15 An ordinary grounder, the sort that is usually recorded "4-3" in score card shorthand, turned out to be a two-run double for Danny Cater in the eighth inning tonight and gave the Kansas City Athletics a 5-4 victory over the New York Yankees.

DAYTON, Ohio, July 15 (AP) A Federal judge returned the Dr. Sam Sheppard murder case to the state of Ohio today and set procedures for bringing him to trial a second time for the murder of his wife 12 years ago.

Robert Cade Wilson Jr., a retired advertising executive, died yesterday in Harkness Pavilion, Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, after a brief illness. Mr. Wilson, 72 years old, lived at 115 East 86th Street.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) Combat fatigue, which accounted for 23 per cent of front-line medical evacuations at one stage of World War II, has virtually ceased to be a problem in Vietnam.
Murder, robbery, assault and other major crimes have been reduced nearly 60 per cent in the 15 months since the Transit Authority put policemen on every train and in every subway station at night.
Tucked away in Pfc. Richard E. Marks's sea bag in Danang, South Vietnam, was a letter the 19-year-old marine had written but had hoped would never be read.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 15 (AP) Clifford Ann Creed shot a par 72 and took a onestroke lead today in the first round of the $15,000 Lady Carling Midwest open golf tournament at Stoney Creek.

The Broadway musical "It's A Bird... It's a Plane... It's Superman" will end its run at the Alvin Theater on West 52d Street after tomorrow's matinee, the 129th performance, unless "there's an upsurge in business."

Christopher G. Kellogg, greatgreat-grandson of John Wanamaker, the founder of the Philadelphia department store, has married Miss Gisela Wollmer, director of the bookshop at Parsons College, Fairfield, Iowa. The ceremony was performed last Saturday in the Lutheran Church in Ottuma, Iowa.

ARDSLEY, N.Y., July 15 The state police said that Dr. Eric Preiss, 38 years old, of Buffalo, was found asleep here today in a parked car containing $101,000 in cash, an automatic pistol, two machetes and two hunting rifles. The car was parked beside the Thomas E. Dewey Thruway.

SAIGON, South Vietnam July 15 (AP) United States jet squadrons struck anew at North Vietnam today in an intensified campaign that an official suggested had now drawn a full commitment of the enemy's defenses. The United States command reported the loss of one plane to ground fire.

The biggest money races on the calendar today, as far as owners of thoroughbreds are concerned, are the 1 -mile Hollywood Gold Cup at Hollywood Park in Inglewood, Calif., and the Monmouth Handicap at Monmouth Park in Oceanport, N.J.
TEL AVIV, July 15--Israel has agreed to a United Nations proposal for a cease-fire on the border provided Syria does the same, the Foreign Ministry in Jerusalem announced today.
WASHINGTON, July 15 Senator Robert F. Kennedy added his voice today to the growing chorus of opposition in Congress to the extension of the West Front of the United States Capitol.
Stock prices edged upward yesterday, although some preweekend profit taking toward the close trimmed many advances.

VUNGTAU, South Vietnam, July 15 In this Vietnamese seaside report, a Vietcong guerrilla major was helping a fetching Vietnamese woman psychiatrist and an American reporter this week to find a fortune in gold bars hidden by the French.

ATLANTA, July 15 (AP) The Southern Christian Leadership Conference said today that the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. had canceled a speech to the World Council of Churches in Geneva, Sunday because of the riots in Chicago.
ALBANY, July 15 (AP) The State Police staged raids on 100 establishments in 40 communities today in what was described as a statewide crackdown on horse-race betting and policy transactions.
LOS ANGELES, July 15 (UPI) Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas, 67 years old, married a 23-year-old college senior tonight in the Encino home of a couple they had not met before the ceremony.

NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., July 15 (UPI) The Justice Department is continuing its efforts to reverse the $385-million sale of West Coast properties of the Tidewater Oil Company to the Phillips Petroleum Company.

Announcement has been made here by Mr. and Mrs. Donald F. Macrae of Reigate, Surrey, England, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sarah Macrae, to James R. Hamill, son of James H. Hamill of Flushing, Queens, and the late Mrs. Hamill.
SPOLETO, Italy, July 15 Add Spoleto to Boston, Philadelphia and New Haven as a Broadway tryout town.
Members of the Drug and Hospital Employes Union refused to work the day shift yesterday at four voluntary hospitals and called a work stoppage at a fifth hospital for the first time.
HANKO, Norway, July 15 (AP) Ernest Fay of Houston won the second race today in a bid for his sixth Scandanavian Gold Cup.
WASHINGTON, July 15 Roman Catholic, Protestant and Jewish leaders protested today that not enough money was being asked for the Federal antipoverty program.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 15 A Dutchess County grand jury was thwarted here today in an expanded investigation of Dr. Timothy F. Leary's Castalia Foundation.

Miss Mary V. Gaver, new president of the American Library Association, last night said that librarians should become "active, not passive and apathetic, participators in our nation's total educational program."

The Coast Guard buoy tender Arbutus went aground in Long Island Sound at 11:20 A.M. yesterday. The mishap occurred in 13 feet of water near Execution Rocks, five miles northeast of the Throgs Neck Bridge. The Coast Guard said there was no damage to the 960-ton vessel or any injuries among her crew.

A six-month musical tour of 12 Asian and African countries might wear out most performers, but not Ginia Davis, a slender and vivacious guitar-playing soprano who recently returned to New York after a trip sponsored by the United States Information Service.

CAPE MAY POINT, N.J., July 15 The state is seeking Federal aid for the construction of eight stone jetties to help keep this small Victorian community on the southernmost tip of New Jersey from falling into the Atlantic Ocean.
DETROIT, July 15 (UPI) Car production climbed to 145,524 units this week in a final spurt of the dying 1966 model run, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.
BONN, July 15 A West German court sentenced two former SS officers to life imprisonment today for murder and complicity in the murder of Polish Jews during the Hitler era.

The Newport Jazz Festival moved into Lewisohn Stadium last night for the first of three successive evenings of a trade whereby the Metropolitan Opera, Lewisohn's regular summer tenant, has spent this week at Newport. Earlier in the week the Newport Folk Festival contributed two programs to the Lewisohn series.
The Lindsay administration is studying ways to replace Robert Moses as chairman of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, his last remaining post of power.

Who's selling Rio Grande shares? On both Thursday and Friday, minutes before the close of trading, a big block of Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad stock crossed the tape in an exchange distribution one seller and assorted member firm buyers.

Two major West Coast steamship lines have asked the Federal Maritime Commission to disapprove the proposed consolidation of American President Lines, American Mail Line and the Pacific Far East Line, Inc., into a single organization.
UPPER MARLBORO, Md., July 16 Eight above zero in January of 90 above in July, this sports car race course fills its paddock with cars and its grandstand and bleachers with people.

THE number of musicals on Broadway last sea son was 13, a fact to make the superstitious gloat: because none of them was first-class and few of them were enjoyable. I thought that "Superman" was the best of the lot, and since some eyebrows (and brickbats) have been raised at this opinion, I might explain how I reached it.

VIEWED strictly as an official, not as a personality, Harry S. Truman was the grimmest President in the 20th century. Woodrow Wilson was far more austere as a man, but Wilson's Presidency was jocund by comparison with Truman's. Wilson had to face hatred, but not contempt. Every wastebasket-emptier in Washington was sure he could run the Government better than Truman could. But he survived.

PARIS, July 16 It is only a room nine feet long and not nearly that wide, but an increasing number of well-to-do French would gladly buy it for several thousand dollars, and the poor of Paris would be lucky to live in it.
SALT LAKE CITY For the vacationist, less time spent traveling means more time for fun and relaxation.

HANOVER, N.J., July 16 Bold Venture, an 8-year-old bay gelding owned by Clem Hoppe of Sparta, N.J., captured two of the three classes to win the junior jumper championship today at the Hanover Farm's horse show.
HONG KONG, Sunday, July 17 North Vietnam announced today that President Ho Chi Minh had promulgated a partial mobilization order.
LONDON, July 16 (UPI) Although Britain refuses to send troops or materials to Vietnam, it is sending a civilian medical team.

PINE MOUNTAIN, Ga. July 16 (UPI) An 11-year-old girl from Riverfall, Calif., Liza St. John, snapped Liz Allen's string of preliminary victories at four today with a first place in tricks during the second round of the Masters water ski tournament at Callaway Gardens.
CHICAGO, July 16 (AP) Short Fall and Margarethen won divisions today of the $30,000 added Beverly Handicap at Arlington Park.
The city has filed its first cases under a dormant statute that could result in heavy fines and possible jail sentences for landlords who violate the rent-control law.

While the rest of Europe has been in a genuine highclass tizzy over the World Cup soccer tournament, London has shrugged off the foreign invasion with hardly a blink and gone on discussing such weighty subjects as the mini-skirt.
PANVEL, India, July 16 A monsoon nearly washed out Agriculture Secretary Orville L. Freeman's tour of this ricegrowing belt today. But no one could honestly say he was sorry.
As the trend toward matchmaking by computer grows, its possible hazards are highlighted by a report from Stanford University, where electronic dating is under way among summer students.

BRANDS HATCH, England, July 16 (Reuters) Jack Brabham, the 40-year-old Australian, driver, scored his second successive Grand Prix victory today, winning the British Grand Prix. He recently was first in the French Grand Prix.

MOSCOW, July 16 United States swimmers won five of nine events today in the controversial Five Nations meet, but the lone world record established was set by a 13year-old Moscow girl in the 200-meter breast-stroke.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 8 There is careful adherence in Iraq to the rule of speaking "of the dead nothing except good." But ordinary Iraqis and government servants in moments of unofficial frankness declare that their new President, Maj. Gen. Abdel Rahman Arif, is a vast improvement over his brother and predecessor, Col. Abdel Salam Arif, who died in a helicopter crash in April.
Over-the-counter issues tossed and turned within a limited range last week.
A number of major advertisers are playing ball with one of the hottest promotional properties of our time professional football.

TOKYO, July 16 (AP) Leaders of South Vietnam's National Liberation Front, the political parent organization of the Vietcong, held a meeting recently to review the situation since the United States stepped up the war in Vietnam in mid-1965, the Hanoi radio reported today.

E.R. Squibb Son, Inc., manufacturer of radioactive isotopes used in the treatment of cancer, said in a telegram to Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz yesterday that it was concerned about the effect of the airline strike on shipments of isotopes to physicians throughout the country.
POLAND'S threat to reject United States mail bearing the American stamp, due July 31, commemorating the Polish Christian Millennium, recalls earlier Iron Curtain curbs on United States stamps.
LONDON, July 16 Portgual snapped a scoreless tie on a "gift goal" by the rival fullback, Ivan Vutzov, today and went on to beat Bulgaria, 3-0, in a Group 3 game of the world soccer cup competition.

A one-bedroom house built on San Francisco Bay a dozen years ago at a cost reputedly well in excess of half a million dollars has been sold twice within the last few months at a fraction of that figure.

The chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Anne Goodwin Parks to Donald Murray Burke. The Rev. Kenneth O. Jones performed the ceremony. There was a reception at the Colony Club.
Despite reports of tight mortgage money, Pennsylvania continues "a recordbreaking pace" in new residential construction, according to William P. Young, the State Secretary of Labor and Industry.

Howden of Winter Park, Fla., and Jack Frederick Howden of Casselberry, Fla. The Rev. Thomas Peterson performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church.
NASSAU, the Bahamas, July 16 (AP) John Ernest Williamson, one of the first undersea photographers, died of a stroke last night at Princess Margaret Hospital. His age was 84.
Ecclesiastical aggiornamento, or updating, is on the minds of every- one these days from Rome to the Bible Belt.

MIAMI BEACH, July 16 (AP) An 18-year-old blueeyed, blond beauty from Sweden, Margareta Arvidsson, was crowned Miss Universe tonight.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 16 The Riverhead Kennel Club held its first dog show today and it will be one that Charlotte C. Clem of Norwood, Mass., will long remember. For Mrs. A.V. Bonney of Oyster Bay, L.I., the best-in-show judge, named the 22-year-old blonde's Shetland sheepdog, Ch. Hatfield's Stardust, for the top award over the field of 880 dogs at Stotsky Memorial Park.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 16 Miss Barbara Julia Finocchi, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Joseph Finocchi of Yonkers, was married today to Dr. William Charles Grimmell of Boonton, N.J., son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Grimmell of Brooklyn and Rockaway Point, L.I.
Deputy Mayor Robert Price asked the Port of New York Authority yesterday to reconsider a decision to spend $810,000 to improve the New Jersey side of the harbor.

J.B. Matthews, a former Methodist minister who embraced leftist ideologies in the nineteen-thirties and later served briefly on the late Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's investigative subcommittee, died of Parkinson's disease yesterday in the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 72 years old and lived at 1 West 81st Street.

The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. is caught squarely in the middle of the current civil rights conflict over "black power" and he is acutely aware of the advantages and disadvantages of his position.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 16 In one of the roughest displays of riding since the major fixture was revived in 1946, John R. Gaines's syndicated Bold Bidder captured the $114,450 Monmouth Handicap at Monmouth Park today.

WASHINGTON, July 16 This week those few New York television viewers not bleary-eyed with heat and summer replacements may have observed, flitting subliminally across their screens in one-minute segments, some lighthearted discussion of highways, water pollution and protecting the dupe-prone consumer.
UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., July 16 (AP) Penn State's distance runners are training in the Colorado mountains in the interest of science and the 1968 Olympic Games to be held in Mexico City.

PITTSBURGH In the moonlight, the city rides like a ship at anchor. Faint in the distance beyond the dark, sharp prow where the two tides rush together the hoarse blast of a diesel towboat reverberates up the deep V of the hill-jostled valley.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 16 A special committee of 14 experts was reported today to have broken the deadlock that had stalled its efforts to agree on arrangements to finance the United Nations.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 16 A specially-designed vibrating shovel was used by Gov. James A. Rhodes of Ohio to help Ohio State University break ground for its $3.1-million Systems Engineering Building last week.
RYE, N.Y., July 16 A $400,000 fire this week at Playland Amusement Park has revived hopes of Rye residents that the park be redesigned. But they apparently are due for a disappointment.

AN automatic film-processing machine will take over the work of film development for photo graphy students in a new approach to photographic education introduced by C.B. Neblette, dean of the College of Graphic Arts and Photography at the Rochester (N.Y.) Institute of Technology.

PHILADELPHIA, July 16 The voice of the poor that was heard so promisingly in the management of Philadelphia's antipoverty program a year ago has been virtually silenced, according to witnesses at an unofficial hearing staged here by Republican Congressmen.

WINNIPEG, Man. Ten years ago, the Canadian grain trade faced a record surplus of 733 million bushels of unsold wheat as a new crop year approached on Aug. 1. Domestic and foreign demand were light, the outlook gloomy.
The largest "new town" of all a multibillion-dollar city designed to accommodate 200,000 persons by 1990 has begun to rise in the Santa Clara River Valley, 30 miles northwest of downtown Los Angeles.
