TOKYO, July 16 One of Tokyo's oldest religious institutions, the 340-year-old Hatsunemori Shinto shrine, announced this week that it was going into trade to keep pace with the tempo of Japan's bustling capital city.
The New York Mets passed two milestones yesterday that symbolized their five years of mixed success in the National League.

MILWAUKEE, July 16 Cliff and Nancy Richey of San Angelo, Tex., again reached the final of the United States Clay Court tennis championships today and have the opportunity tomorrow to become the first brother and sister to win National singles titles together.

OTTAWA, July 16 Parliament began a summer recess this weekend with the Liberal minority Government more confidently in command than appeared possible to many observers when the newly elected members assembled six months ago.
LAGOS, Nigeria, July 16 Nigeria became today the first English-speaking nation to gain associate membership in the European Common Market.
WASHINGTON, July 16 At least two dozen projects are expected to be in operation this fall in the nation's expanding regional programs on heart disease, cancer and stroke.
If the forecasts of the Missouri State Division of Commerce and Industrial Development are borne out, Missouri will continue its upward economic climb through 1967.

IF scientific issues could be decided by majority vote, there is little doubt about the verdict in the case of telepathy and other forms of extrasensory perception, or E.S.P. for short. Today, as in times past, believers probably outnumber skeptics by at least ten to one; as far as experimental evidence is concerned, the burden of proof is still on the believers.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., July 16 Miss Patricia Smith and Charles H. Rathbone 3d, son of Mrs. Allan McDowell of Kent, Conn., and the late Mr. Rathbone Jr., were married here this afternoon in St. Peter's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Hughes Garvin. The bride's parents are Mr. and Mrs. J. Allan Smith Jr. of Morristown.

MOSCOW, July 16 A 13year-old boy from Rockville Centre, L.I., brought tears of joy to the eyes of Russian Jews in the Central Synagogue this morning when he chanted the blessings before and after the reading of the Torah.

CHICAGO, July 16 When a West Side Chicagoan has time for reveries, he dreams of living in a neighborhood where youngsters can leave their bicycles out on the front lawns overnight. Such a prospect is to him the ultimate in security.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 16 Peter V. Cerar of Lloyd Harbor, director of materials for the Avco Lycoming Division of the Avco Corporation, manufacturers of helicopter engines, died in Huntington Hospital today. His age was 52.
A massive redevelopment program that envisions the rebuilding of the downtown center of Hoboken, N.J., has been disclosed by the city's Mayor, Louis De Pascale.
ALAMOGORDO, N.M., July 16 (AP) The atomic age was born 21 years ago today with the first detonation of an atomic bomb in a secluded desert area near Alamogordo.

We libel their kind by calling them dragonflies, and we compound the libel with myths and old wives' tales, describing them as horse-stingers, devil's darning needles, snake feeders and snake doctors. No dragonfly ever stung a horse, sewed up small boys' ears or fed or ministered to any snake. They are not only harmless to mankind; they are among our most helpful insects, feeding almost entirely on gnats, flies and mosquitoes.

WASHINGTON, July 16 The editor of the California Law Review, appointed to serve as a law clerk in the Supreme Court next fall, has been denied the appointment following criticism by conservative spokes men.

CARMEL, Calif. NOT long ago, Dr. Eric Berne tried to play games with Frank Sinatra and nearly got his teeth kicked in. Their playground was The Daisy, a private discotheque in Beverly Hills. Dr. Berne is the author of a best-selling volume of pop psychology called "Games People Play." Mr. Sinatra sings for a living.

PHILADELPHIA, Miss., July 18 (UPI)--A hospital administrator who has been wrangling with the Federal Government over Medicare payments refused today to let another Federal inspection team go through his institution.

LONDON. PETER WEISS'S play "The Persecution and Assassination of JeanPaul Marat as Per formed by the Inmates of the Asylum of Charenton Under the Direction of the Marquis de Sade," as staged in New York by the Royal Shakespeare Company under the direction of Peter Brook, is now on approximately 100,000 feet of film in a cutting room somewhere in Kensington.
TOKYO, July 16 The municipal authorities of Hiroshima announced a nationwide drive today for funds to preserve the atom-bombed city's controversial, and now dangerous, "atomic dome."
BELIZE, British Honduras, July 8 Early every morning a radio station exhorts the 100,000 citizens of this tiny Central American land to "wake up and work."

BETWEEN now and Jan. 1 the structure of radio broadcasting is headed for a formidable up- heaval. In cities of over 100,000 population, duplication of programs on AM and FM stations under common ownership cannot exceed 50 percent of an average week's schedule. For one half of the broadcast hours there must be different programing on the two types of outlets.

The last week of June marked a milestone in Hawaiian history and in shopping-center history. On 50 acres of reclaimed swamp land occurred the dedication of the world's largest splitlevel shopping center.

The commercial seagoing work force of the United States merchant marine is likely to encounter shortages in all seven licensed and unlicensed categories, according to a recent study on shipboard manpower by the National Academy of Sciences-National Research Council.

Secretary of the Treasury Henry H. Fowler is renewing his efforts to bring about a truce in the interest rate war that has erupted across the nation. He supports a pending bill that would impose temporary ceilings on interest rates offered to savers by commercial banks and thrift institutions.
MINEOLA, L.I., July 16 Nassau County and the town of Hempstead are considering plans to acquire 180 acres of ocean front between Lido Beach and Point Lookout for a towncounty beach.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 16 Incomplete data indicate that about 50 South Vietnamese military officers have filed for election to this fall's constituent assembly, Government officials reported today.

Virginia's traditional heroes, such as Washington, Jefferson and Robert E. Lee, are taking a back seat to such names as Firestone, Westinghouse. Goodyear, General Electric, du Pont and Allied Chemical in an advertising campaign that the state's Division of Industrial Development began last week.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 16 President Humberto Castelo Branco" management of Brazil's electoral process this year has produced almost complete public apathy toward politics.

The craft developed what Capt. Douglas Bullard described as "electrical relay trouble." The engines shut down and the craft was left floating helplessly on its hull. It was towed in by a small tugboat.

LONDON, July 16 This has been Harold Wilson's worst week as Prime Minister. The reasons are mainly domestic, and his current trip to Moscow seeking Soviet cooperation in the search for peace in Vietnam seems unlikely to help him much.

CANADA in 1967 will replace her current de finitive stamps with a new 12-stamp series, five of which will include a new portrait of Queen Elizabeth II of Britain. The National Association of Independent Schools, by urging its 760 member schools to offer sex education, has put the spotlight on a controversial question which is generally discussed behind closed doors in order to avoid unfavorable public reaction.

HONG KONG. LAST May, Communist China intrigued the world by un expectedly distributing photographs of a meeting between Chairman Mao Tse-tung, flanked by his deputies, and Premier Mehmet Shehu of Albania. For more than five months the 72 year old Mao had been mysteriously absent from public activity amid reports that he was incapacitated.
JAMESTOWN, N.Y., July 16 Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. has told upstate Democratic leaders that he will receive the endorsement of the Liberal party if he wins the Democratic nomination for Governor.

WHEN the gardener sees green caterpillars riddling his cabbage plants, or imported currant "worms" rapidly defoliating his gooseberry bushes, he feels inclined to declare a "no quarter" war on all the flying or creeping creatures within the confines of his garden. But such indiscriminate warfare would be unfortunate. It would destroy not only foes but also the many beneficial insects whose diet is largely made up of plant pests.

Homeowners in the Cobble Hill area in Brooklyn, which has undergone a great deal of refurbishing in recent years, have established a free Design Advisory Service and have prepared a guide to remodeling old houses.

The fate of Boston's proposed $98-million stadium complex may well be sealed in the next few weeks. The Greater Boston Stadium Authority is now pulling out all the stops to persuade the State Legislature to reverse the June 1 House rejection before the General Court calls its session for 1966, about Aug. 15.

Stewart, noted that 250,000 premature deaths occur each year among cigarette smokers. NANTUCKET, Mass. The shops on Main and Centre Streets have long since taken down their "Will Open" signs, and the bicycle shops on Broad Street were already busy over the Memorial Day weekend. In other words, the tourist season on Nantucket is well under way.

BOMBAY, July 16 The day after the United States bombed the oil installations near Hanoi and Haiphong, Mrs. Indira Gandhi was trapped by reporters under a palm tree in Kerala. What, the reporters wanted to know, was Mrs. Gandhi going to do about the new danger of escalation in Vietnam?

CAIRO, July 16 The Arab League Council declared today the "full support" of the Arab states for Syria in the wake of the Israeli air raid against Syrian earth-moving equipment on the Jordan River Thursday, but the Council shied away from saying countermeasures would be taken.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 16 An aching Armbro Flight was resting in a Chicago stall and an ailing Roquepine was idling away in the local international barn here, as Lord Gordon overtook Noble Victory just before the finish line tonight and won the Gold Division of the Challenge Cup Trot at Roosevelt Raceway.

RYE, N.Y., July 16 The American Yacht Club's 35th annual cruise began shortly before noon today with a distance race from Scotch Caps to Fishers Island.

BROOKS ROBINSON of the Baltimore Orioles went into the All-Star game as the major league league in the key department, runs batted in. He was unanimously voted the outstanding performer of the mid-summer classic, a star among stars.

TORONTO, July 16 Canadian banks generally are glum about proposed legislation under which they will operate for the next 10 years at least. Bankers have two principal reasons for pessimism about a revision of the Bank Act, details of which trickled out of Ottawa last week after repeated delays.

A golf course that has been the cause of both dread and delight will be the site of the Professional Golfers' Association championship this week.

While the Soviet Union has been calling off Soviet-American sports events and threatening to scrap the cultural exchange programs, the less spectacular but possiply more important exchange of scholars appears to be going ahead at full steam.

FLAGS, skies and plagues...a bright stadium...packed bleachers...a place of contradictions." These are words Larry Rivers uses to describe his productidn for the New York Philharmonic's performances of Stravinsky's "Oedipus Rex" this week. It all adds up to what he calls "a timely visual presentation."

A contract to build eight prefabricated houses by a new method for installation at San Lorenzo, P.R., has been given to Carib Homes, Inc., a San Juan concern. The three-bedroom, 726 square foot houses will cost $4,200 each.

UNION, N.J., July 16 Despite protests by teen-aged groups here, the Township Committee this week set July 26 for a public hearing on an ordinance setting a 11 P.M.-to6 A.M. curfew for all youth under 18 years of age.

IN the lobby of Bonn's Foreign Office there is a plaque dedicated to Gustav Stresemann, chancellor in the twenties and winner of a Nobel Prize for his effort to unite the Continent. The inscription reads: "In Memory of a Good European."

SALEM, N.H., July 16 Howell Shepard, chairman of the New Hampshire Sweepstakes Commission, said today he expected this year's sales to total about the same as last year's $3.9 million from 1.3 million tickets at $3 apiece. The first year, with Presidential primaries in New Hampshire helping to spread information about the new venture, 1.9 million sweepstakes tickets were sold for $5.7 million.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., July 16 Miss Lynne Margaret Leisinger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Martin Leisinger, was married here today to Ens. John Everson Chubb Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Chubb of Grosse Pointe, Mich. The Rev. T. Carleton Lee performed the ceremony in St. John's Episcopal Church.

TWO lectures delivered in 1963 shook the world of higher education. In the first, Clark Kerr, presdent of the University of California, spoke of the "multiversity;' unintentionally providing what subsequently became the prime epithet of alienated students and faculty.
The Buildings Department will more than double the number of men assigned to making cyclical inspections of housing in four boroughs starting tomorrow.
ATLANTA, July 16 (AP) Rain washed out the HoustonAtlanta game today after 5 innings with the score tied 1-1.
Horace Clarke hit a grandslam home run in the 10th inning as the New York Yankees beat the Kansas City Athletics, 9-5, yesterday and climbed from ninth to eighth place in the American League.

ST. LEON SUR VEZERE, France Five years ago, a missile millionaire from Malibu Beach, Calif., and a newlywed couple from Paris came to the wooded hills of the Dordogne to escape the ways of the modern world. Now they have teamed up to transform abandoned stone houses into ultramodern residences for other sophisticated, well-heeled fugitives.

CHICAGO, Sunday, July 17 Richard Franklin Speck, 24year-old ex-convict sought in the slaying of eight nurses last Thursday, was seized by police about 2 A.M. today bleeding from his right wrist and left elbow in a transient hotel at 617 West Madison Street.

NUKUALOFA, Tongatapu, Tonga For at least 50 years, Mrs. Bella Riechelmann's Beach House, a weather-beaten old boarding house facing the sea, has been the only place where a foreigner could stay in this quaint little capital of out-of-the-way Tonga. In a few months, this will change.
PHILADELPHIA, July 16 Tony Gonzalez, who scored the tying run in the ninth inning, singled across the winning tally in the 15th as Philadelphia topped the San Francisco Giants, 6 to 5, today.
Fires swept tinder-dry wooded and brush sections of Staten Island, New Jersey and upper New York State yesterday as hundreds of firemen battled the flames.

New Jersey's dream of having a harness-racing track in the Hudson County meadowlands moved a step closer to reality last month when Gov. Richard J. Hughes signed a bill calling for a referendum on whether night racing should be permitted in the state.
Yorkers' first condominium apartment project, the 167-unit Westgate Park, has been given the required approval and permission to sell by the New York State Attorney General.

KANSAS CITY, July 16 Like a band of ill-starred mountain climbers, who have already lost most of their provisions and are thinking no longer of attainment but only of survival, the New York Yankees climbed painfully back up to eighth place in the American League today.

NORTH COLLINS, N.Y., July 16 State and Federal officials are investigating alleged discrimination against Puerto Rican migrant workers here following a wave of tension that has swept over this pleasant, tree-shaded upstate village.

VOLUNTOWN, Conn., July 16 Ten young men invaded the farmhouse headquarters of a pacifist group here late last night, smashed the front door with a pickax, threw a tricycle through one window and rocks through a dozen others and used a crowbar to break the windshields of seven cars parked outside.

MADRID, July 16 The liberal minority in the Spanish Roman Catholic hierarchy appears to have blocked, temporarily, planned disciplinary moves against reform-minded elements in Catholic Action laymen's organizations.
CONCORD, N.H. July 16 The market in major political candidates opened sluggishly this week in New Hampshire.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., July 16 In the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Heart of Mary here this morning, Miss Barbara Leslie Lalanne, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Lalanne Jr. of Scarsdale, became the bride of David Andrew Barber Jr. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Barber of Osterville, Mass.
The two leading Russians in the Piatigorsky Cup Chess Tournament will oppose each other in the opening round today as will the two leading Americans.

A 10-item food menu, with no order costing more than 29 cents, has enabled a roadside hamburger chain to become so successful that it has met the requirements for a listing on the New York Stock Exchange.
Seven United States-flag scheduled airlines have reported new traffic records for the month of June.

As the passengers go aboard the liner United States at Pier 86 in Manhattan, where 46th Street runs down to the Hudson River, their noses are apt to detect something more than the tang of the sea. No wonder. Underneath that pier disgorges the mouth of a sewer.
TOKYO, July 16 (AP)--Morihiro Matsuda, a determined man, is not satisfied with having spent $26,000 to advertise his views on world peace. He wants to do more.

REMSENBURG, L.I., July 16 P.G. Wodehouse, creator of the Jeeves saga, smiled graciously while a black cat buffed its back on the cocktail table, a boxer dog panted complacently and a dachshund loudly lapped water from a red bowl set near the potted plants.

WHITE PLAINS, July 16 Mr. and Mrs. J. Arthur Shier have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Christine Shier, to William Leonard Shaw, both of New York. Mr. Shaw is the son of Mrs. J. Gilmore Fletcher of Manchester, Vt., formerly of Manor, Pa., and New York.

HONG KONG, July l6 The Chinese Communist political purge is "personally guided by Mao Tse-Tung," and is his "crowning gift" to the revolution he has led for 40 years, according to Anna Louise Strong, an American writer who has lived in China for many years.

GENEVA, July 16 (Reuters) Although the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. has canceled a planned weekend sermon here because of the Chicago riots, his voice will still be heard tomorrow in St. Peter's Cathedral.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y. Chautauqua Institution, renowned as a summer temple at which free inquiry is worshiped and encouraged amid rustic lakeside beauty is far different today from what it was in 1874. That is when the Rev....

SAN FRANCISCO combines the best of Europe and the best of the United States. Nature in America is too man-made. The bare hills of the San Mateo peninsula in California are like the hills of Lebanon. Chicago teen-agers are bashful. Paris is a happy capital, and Washington is a sedate one."

Substantial increases in Customs revenues at the Port of New York in the 1966 fiscal year, which ended last June 30, and for last month were reported here last week by Michael Stramlello Jr., Regional Commissioner of Customs.

Henri Levesque, whose Roquepine missed winning last week's $100,000 International Trot at Roosevelt Raceway by a neck, is a man who parlayed 300 francs ($61.80) and a dislike for another man's training tactics into the French equivalent of more than $2-million.
Men's clothing companies, currently enjoying an unmatched period of prosperity, are stepping up their activity in the ownership of the retail stores that sell their goods.

SANTA FE, N.M. Twenty air miles northwest of New Mexico's capital, the terrain undergoes a startling transformation. Sandy, undulating, scrub-covered hills suddenly change to deep, cragged, boulder-strewn canyons, and the normally lazy Rio Grande suddenly roars through 900foot gorges, its waters churning in spume-capped whirlpools.

WASHINGTON, July 16 The Johnson Administration expects to be plunged into a new and agonizing diplomatic crisis Monday when the World Court rules on South Africa's attempt to annex the huge territory of South-West Africa.

BRUSSELS, July 16 Relations between the Belgian and Congolese Governments have deteriorated in recent weeks and are now the tensest since the former Belgian colony achieved independence six years ago.
TOMKINS COVE, N.Y., July 16 For the third time in her 21 years, the Albion Victory was roused from hibernation this week.

FARELLONES, Chile, July 16 (AP) Nancy Green, a slim Canadian brunette, won the women's special slalom with a combined time of 1 minute 48.23 seconds in the first of four warm-up races for the world ski championships today.

A temporary renting office that will be in operation while construction goes on around it has been installed in the future lobby of the Excelsior, a 47-story apartment house now rising at 303 East 57th Street, off Second Avenue.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 16 (AP) Robert A. Forsythe, former chairman of the Minnesota Republican party, was endorsed by the party's state central committee today to run for the United States Senate seat now held by Walter F. Mondale, Democrat.

LOS ANGELES, July 16 (AP) Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas and his fourth wife left on a secluded honeymoon today. A second honeymoon to Communist China is a possibility later this year, they said.

CHICAGO, July 16 (AP) Unless outmoded training practices are changed, some high school and college football players face the possibility of death in hot-weather workouts, according to a group of medical experts.

BUENOS AIRES, July 16 (AP) Both Horacio Accavallo, who successfully defended his world flyweight championship last night, and Hiroyuki Ebihara, the defeated Japanese challenger, agreed today that Accavallo had earned his 15round decision.
ENGLEWOOD, N.J., July 16 Miss Deborah Cameron Glidden and Joseph Richard Saliba plan to marry in September.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 16 Miss Barbara Mary Jankowski, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Edward Jankowski of Union, was married today to Richard Joseph Monks, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Lawrence Monks. The Rev. Joseph Furfey performed the ceremony in St. Genevieve Roman Catholic Church. Mrs. Gerald Christopher O'Leary was the matron of honor, and the best man was Paul Cummins Norton.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., July 16 A C-119 troop transport airplane carrying 34 National Guardsmen to two weeks' active duty lost an engine, and crashed burned tonight, but everyone aboard bailed out safely.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 16 The Kern County Land Company, backed by other big farmers in the Bakersfield area, has begun an assault on a 160acre limitation on farms benefiting from Federal irrigation projects.
FLORISSANT, Colo. This may be the last summer for tourists to dig their own fossils from the rich fossil fields that surround this little Rocky Mountain town.

MADRID, July 15. The hierarchy of the Roman Catholic Church in Spain symbolically combined conservatism and change this week with a ruling that Spanish priests must continue to wear cassocks in public, but might appear in "clergyman" attire trousers, tunic, and ecclesiastic collar whenever it seemed "reasonable" in their "civilian lives."

SANTA MONICA, Calif., July 15 The Rand Corporation, that vast, mystery-shrouded "think factory" overlooking the Pacific, is now observing its 20th anniversary at a time of internal change and ferment.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (UPI) Assistant Attorney General Donald F. Turner's decision to drop an antitrust suit against the Anheuser-Busch brewery was backed by all but one of the key Government lawyers working on the case, a Justice Department spokesman said today.
The Shell Oil Company and the Trunkline Gas Company have signed a contract for the sale of one trillion cubic feet of natural gas.

HEWLETT, L.I., July 16 Trinity Episcopal Church was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Lee Porter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Brinley Porter of Cedarhurst, to David Nelson Page, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nelson L. Page of Darien, Conn.

IF only for a brief period, Judith Anderson will exchange the flowing Grecian drapes for the royal English robes next fall. She will play the title role in Maxwell Anderson's historical drama, "Elizabeth the Queen," at the New York City Center of Music and Drama from Nov. 1 through Nov. 13.

CANANDAIGUA, N.Y., July 16 (AP) Real Reward, with William Hubbard up, registered a half-length victory over favored Paul M in the $2,000 Electro Handicap, today at Finger Lakes race track. Bourbon Blue was third.

CARSON CITY, Nev., July 16 When they can be heard above the clink of silver money and the clank of one-armed bandits, the political gossips of this state call Paul Laxalt a lot of things; apostate, convert, opportunist, bright young man.
BERLIN, July 16 (Reuters) Communist East Germany accused the West German Government today of using James Bond, the international secret agent, in undercover preparations for war.
WIESBADEN, Germany, July 16 (AP) United States shooters set individual and team world records today in the small-bore prone competition at the world shooting championships.

FAR HILLS, N.J., July 16 Mr. and Mrs. William Turnbull have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ellen Ramsay Turnbull, to Robert Hazard Edwards, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Robinson Edwards of Washington.
A new apartment house in Fort Lee, N.J., has its first floor 11 feet above grade allowing 20,000 square feet of space under the building for covered parking for 175 automobiles.

ALL of these books about the world's polar regions are for young people, though at least one will also appeal to adults as a fine piece of reporting. That one is Allyn Baum's "Antarctica," a description of the Southern Continent covering both its early exploration and the current international effort by an army of scientists to assess this most hostile of environments.
Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner suggested yesterday that the Democratic State Committee take a statewide poll of voter opinion on its candidates for Governor and the issues of the 1966 state campaign.

A 12-foot craft of 1917 vintage with a three-horse power engine, a set of oars and an umbrella to shade its passengers on sunny days will be one of the stars of the second Antique Boat Show in Clayton, N.Y.
MILLSBORO, Del., July 16 Harry Sindle of Wares Neck, Va., won two races today as the Dixie District Lightning Class sailing championships opened on the Indian River.
Beginning next month, a homeowner or the proprietor of a commercial establishment may be visited by two men. One will carry a big black book.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 16 (UPI) The security chief of Belgrade and his assistant were dismissed today, Tanyug, the official press agency, reported.

The Sinclair Refining Company has named Charles M. Lynch as general manager of marine transportation in charge of the company's 380,000-ton 12-ship fleet of oil carriers. He succeeds Wendell N. Damonte, who retired this month as vice president in charge of marine transport activities after 43 years with the company. Mr. Lynch has been his assistant.
PARRY SOUND, Ont., July 8 "Please don't swat the blackflies," the auctioneer pleaded through the megaphone. "I'll think you're bidding."

WASHINGTON, July 16 Scientists of the Soviet Union are using the giant Proton 3 spacecraft to search for quarks, subnuclear particles that exist only in theory. Thus, the Russians are deepening the mystery here as to the real purpose of the Proton program.
Beginning next month, a homeowner or the proprietor of a commercial establishment may be visited by two men. One will carry a big black book.
WASHINGTON, July 16 (UPI)--Lynda Bird Johnson returned to Washington from her European tour tonight and was greeted with a warm hug from her mother.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 16 About 50 African students at Salisbury's multiracial University College of Rhodesia and Nyasaland tried today to break up a graduation ceremony in the campus amphitheater.

EVERGLADES NATIONAL PARK, Fla. The excessive rains that saturated southern Florida in June a month that came in and went out like a lion, were a relief to conservationists and officials of Everglades National Park.

Two Greenwich Village leaders are trying to get the city to transform an area clogged by noisy truck traffic and parked trailers into a recreation strip with coffee terraces, restaurants and a floating freshwater swimming pool in the Hudson.

HOLLYWOOD. A GROUP of Negro lead ers this week sat down with representatives of the movie and televi sion industry to discuss two volatile issues: Negro employment in Hollywood and the portrayal of Negroes in movies and TV shows. To no one's surprise, the two groups promptly fell into bitter disagreement on both points.

CHICAGO, July 16 A team of Chicago detectives was on the trail of Richard Franklin Speck within an hour after the discovery at 6:30 A.M. Thursday that eight women in a nurses' dormitory had been slain.
Obviously well pleased with his recent London crusade, Billy Graham, the evangelist, predicted last week that traditional mass evangelism has a bright future.

WILMINGTON, Del., July 16 Miss Katherine Frances Herbert, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Dodwell Herbert, was married today to Ellis J. Adler of San Francisco, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Adler of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and New City, N.Y.

LOS ANGELES, July 16 In the Bel Air Presbyterian Church last night, Miss Leona Antoinette Izmirian, daughter of Mrs. Baizar Izmirian, and the late Mr. Izmirian, was married to Edward Gerrish Thurber, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerrish Thurber of Lawrenceville, N.J. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Thomas Carr.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 16 The marriage of Miss Anne Frances Schneider, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alden James Schneider, to James William Scanlan Jr., son of Mrs. James W. Scanlan and the late Mr. Scanlan, took place this morning.
MINNEAPOLIS, July 16 Mrs. Louis J. Kutcher has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Rochelle Joy Kutcher, to First Lieut. Thomas C. Green, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Myron B. Green.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 16 (UPI) The security chief of Belgrade and his assistant were dismissed today, Tanyug, the official press agency, reported.

The Sinclair Refining Company has named Charles M. Lynch as general manager of marine transportation in charge of the company's 380,000-ton 12-ship fleet of oil carriers. He succeeds Wendell N. Damonte, who retired this month as vice president in charge of marine transport activities after 43 years with the company. Mr. Lynch has been his assistant.
Oil and water are proving to be a highly combustible mixture in the stock market.

NEW ORLEANS, July 16 Hundreds of citizens, angered over plans to build an interstate highway along the Mississippi River in front of the French Quarter, are preparing for another skirmish in what they call "the second battle of New Orleans."

GREENWICH, Conn., July 16 Miss Dianne Louise Moloney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert William Moloney Jr., was married today to John Allen Fisher, son of Mrs. Charles T. Fisher Jr. of Grosse Pointe, Mich., and the late Mr. Fisher.
THE entry list for the national championship point races at Connellsville, Pa., next Saturday and Sunday has passed the 250 mark. The Steel Cities Region of the Sports Car Club of America...

MONTA DEL CUERVO, Spain, July 13 It is so hot in the steppe-like fields of La Mancha, the country of Don Quixote, that even the sturdy little donkeys wilt in the afternoon temperatures of more than 100 degrees.

STAMFORD, CONN., July 16 Miss Juanita Frances Mulaire, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Victor J. Mulaire, was married today to Lieut. Paul D. Cullen, U.S.A, son of Mr. and Mrs. James F. Cullen of Riverside, Conn.
MILFORD, Conn., July 16 Miss Sara Schrock Hemphill and George Bliss Agnew 3d were married this afternoon in St. Peter's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Edward R. Taft.
UTICA, N.Y., July 16 (AP ) Petite Lancy Smith of Snyder played a cautious game today and defeated Mrs. Albert Bower of Pelham, 2 and 1, for the State amateur women's golf championship.

BERKELEY, Calif., July 16 (AP) Ron Larrieu of Santa Monica, Calif., ran the fastest 10,000-meter race on American soil and Art Walker bettered his American triple-jump record with a leap of 54 feet 7 inches today in the all-American invitation track and field meet.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., July 16 In the Swarthmore Presbyterian Church this afternoon, Miss Joan Margaret Duncan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Beattie Duncan, became the bride of Peter Lane Griswold, son of Mr. and Mrs. William E.S. Griswold Jr. of Old Lyme, Conn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. D. Ivor Roberts.
The American Jewish Congress has protested a plan by the Post Office Department to issue a 1966 Christmas stamp reproducing the Madonna and Child.
Twin payloads, instrumented to see if the air of Mars contains organic material such as that associated with life, have been tentatively selected for the two Mariner flights past the planet in 1969.
WASHINGTON, July 16 The deadlocked negotiations to end the nine-day-old airline strike hit a new snag today over one carrier's servicing of military flights.
VANCOUVER, B.C., July 16 (Canadian Press) Five hundred homes on Vancouver's south side were evacuated for five hours today when 2,500 gallons of gasoline spilled into the area's sewer system.

ST. PAUL, July 16 (UPI) A former Professional Golfers' Association champion, Bobby Nichols, putting to perfection, shot a five-under-par 66 to take the lead from Jacky Cupit today after three rounds of the $100,000 Minnesota Golf Classic.

ARCACHON, France Between Bordeaux and Bayonne, a distance of about 135 miles via the major tourist routes, is a thin slice of southwestern France known as the Cote d'Argent. The area's Bay of Biscay beaches, long stretches of smooth, flat sand, including the highest sand dunes in Europe, more than justify its name it as a silvery coast.
ALBANY, July 16 Express bus drivers may be equipped with a device permitting them to turn traffic signals green in their favor if a feasibility study by the state proves successful.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 16 Secretary General Thant appealed today to North Vietnam not to put American prisoners on trial lest this lead to a still greater intensification of the war or even to a third world war. His plea also stressed humanitarian grounds.

AT the end of a long tournament, bridge experts sometimes suffer from combat fatigue. They become accident-prone, and their lapses of concentration often bring about curious results. There were several such deals in the later stages of the recent Reisinger Knockout Championship.

RYE, N.Y., July 16 In Christ's Episcopal Church today, Miss Betty Vernon Torrey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas McChesney Torrey, became the bride of Lieut. Comdr. Samuel Stowell Lusk, U.S.N., Dental Corps. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Franklyn Lusk of Pawnee, Okla.
The pressmen's union and the World Journal Tribune Inc. prepared their positions yesterday for the resumption of negotiations tomorrow.
A 10-room bi-level house has been opened at Heritage Homes on East 72d Street between Avenues W and X in the Bergen Beach section of Flatbush.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 16 A General Electric Company executive has predicted that 65 million residential housing units "a second America" would be built in the next 25 years.

Miss Wendy Marcus and Henry Raymont plan to marry here Sept. 11. Their engagement has been announced by the future bride's parents, Stanley Marcus, president of the Neiman-Marcus stores, and Mrs. Marcus, of Dallas.
Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Goldberg of Brooklyn have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Aileen Rita Goldberg, to Dr. Philip David Ross, son of Dr. and Mrs. Samuel Ross of Fresno, Calif.
Faster economic integration or stagnation is the choice that will soon have to be made by the greater part of Latin America, according to a business conference on the area here last week.

MADRID Spain, which over the centuries has faced foreign invasions ranging from the vandals to the Moors and Napoleonic armies, is now facing its biggest invasion ever a record-breaking number of tourists from all over the world.
GENEVA, July 16 (AP) A Roman Catholic theologian called today for more cooperation between Protestants and Catholics.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) Senate subcommittee approval of increases of more than $2-billion above Administration requests for Federal aid to schools in the next two years was announced today by Senator Wayne Morse.

ROSLYN, L. I., July 16--St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church was the setting today for the marriage of Miss Louise Rutherford Pierrepont, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rutherford Stuyvesant Pierrepont of Locust Valley and New York, to John Dapray Muir. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Brockett Muir of Washington.

SEOUL, South Korea, July 16 South Korea's energetic Foreign Minister, Lee Tong Won, who was in his mid-twenties when the war that devastated his country began 16 years ago, is leading a bold campaign to transform what he calls "a hermit kingdom" into an enlightened Asian force.

Harold Smith is divorced. He pays alimony and it is a strain, but he gets by. He is a professional man making $15,000 a year. He has been paying $5,000 in alimony and support payments and his take-home pay is reduced another $3,000 by taxes, Blue Cross and his employer's pension plan.
A proposal involving a totally new departure in industrial bargaining has been made by Joseph Curran, president of the 35,000-member National Maritime Union.
ESSEN, Germany, July 18 (AP) Mrs. Mary Chapot, of Wallpack, N.J., took first and third places today in an international jumping event at the Essen Horse Show.
PITTSBURGH, July 16 Ron Santo's fifth-inning homer sparked a three-run outburst that carried the Chicago Cubs to a 4-1 triumph over the Pittsburgh Pirates today.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 16 Native Diver, California's stakes champion, made a runaway of the $162,100 Hollywood Gold Cup today and became the first horse to win this prize two consecutive years.

ULAN BATOR, Mongolia, July 16 Cluster of white yurts the canvas-and-felt tentlike dwellings of Mongolians sprouted like mushrooms on the grassy hills outside Ulan Bator today, housing thousands of the city's flood victims.

Harry Yeckes, vice president and secretary of Yeckes-Eichenbaum, Inc., wholesale fruit and produce merchants of 335 Washington Street, died of a heart attack Friday in Blowing Rock, N.C., where he was on vacation. He was 61 years old and lived at 911 Soundview Drive in Mamaroneck, N.Y.

STAMFORD, Conn., July 16 Robert Shiels of Darien, Conn., sailed Gamecock to two victories on Long Island Sound today to take the lead, in Class C, for the North American Multi-Hull Sailing Association championship.
A program designed to relate Judaism and the arts will bring Leonard Bernstein, Isaac Bashevis Singer and others to the Kutz Camp Institute in Warwick, N.Y., between next Sunday and Aug. 24.
More than $54.6-billion has been paid by distillers in excise taxes in the 175 years such taxes have been in effect, according to a study released last week by the Distilled Spirits Institute.

BROOKLINE, Mass., July 16 (AP) Two Australians, Ken Rosewall and Rod Laver, set up another title match for tomorrow by winning in the semifinals of the $23,500 United States professional tennis championships today.

WINCHESTER CENTER, Conn., July 16 Miss Linda Shirer, daughter of William L. Shirer, the journalist and author, and Mrs. Shirer of New York and Torrington, was married here this afternoon to Noel Rae, son of Mrs. Alexander Rae of London and the late Mr. Rae. The Rev. Ernest L. Bengston Jr., performed the ceremony in the Winchester Center Congregational Church.
WASHINGTON, July 16 Luci Baines Johnson is thinking pink.

KING LEAR'S words have a poignancy for those puzzled by the recent tumultuous events in China: "[We'll] hear poor rogues/ Talk of court news; and we'll talk with them too,/Who loses and who wins, who's in, who's out;/And take upon us the mystery of things..." P'eng Chen, the Mayor of Peking and one of the highest ranking members of the Politburo, has lost.

ALTHOUGH James Baldwin and Nat Hentoff have taken the same subway ride between Harlem and Greenwich Village (like commuters between East and West Berlin) the fact that they embarked at opposite ends of the line inevitably shows up in how they viewed the trip. There is an important and instructive difference in tone between their startlingly similar novels about the spectrum of sentiment that defines contemporary relations between Negroes and whites.

The story of Resucci Anne and Roscoe Brokenback is old hat among the port's waterfront workers. But the two characters still play important roles in an intensified safety program that is paying off in dramatically reduced waterfront accident incidence.
MILWAUKEE, July 16 (AP) Monty Kaser of Wichita defeated Dave Ojala of Two Harbors, Minn., 6 and 5, in a scheduled 36-hole final and won the National Public Links golf championship today.
Ground was broken in St. Paul last week for a $10million steel mill, the first of its kind in the upper Middle West.
Spurred by the development of new technology and continued industrial expansion, the independent telephone companies in the Middle West will invest some $252-million in plant and equipment in 1966.

BROOKLINE, Mass., July 16 (AP) Two Australians, Ken Rosewall and Rod Laver, set up another title match for tomorrow by winning in the semifinals of the $23,500 United States professional tennis championships today.

If Mayor Lindsay's legal advisers inform him, as a result of their current researches, that he has the lawful power to replace Robert Moses as chairman of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, he is almost certain to invoke that power. While the Mayor says he has not decided his future course, it is inconceivable that he will continue to tolerate the flagrant defiance of city policy that Mr. Moses has shown repeatedly.
HANOVER, N.J., July 17 Brenda Theobald of Vernon, N.J., swept to victory in three classes and the saddle seat horsemanship championship at the Hanover Farm's horse show today.
BERKELEY, Calif., July 17 (UPI) Jim Ryun set a world record of 3 minutes 51.3 sec onds for the mile run today at the All-America track and field invitation meet.
CALUMET, Mich, July 17 (UPI) Rescue workers braving falling debris and dripping water inched down a mile-deep mine shaft today in a nearly hopeless hunt for a lost little girl.
WARSAW, July 17 (AP) A Polish Roman Catholic Archbishop today asked priests to boycott a project backed by the Communist regime to erect a memorial to Pope John XXIII.
HANCOCK, Mich., July 17 (UPI) A nurse who met a "very pleasant" Richard F. Speck in a hospital here this spring said today he returned to visit her three weeks ago with "a hatred in him."

ATLANTA, July 17 (UPI) Hank Aaron drove in three runs with his 27th homer and a sacrifice fly today to lead the Atlanta Braves to a 9-6 victory over the Cincinnati Reds. The victory was the fourth in a row and the ninth in the Braves' last 11 decisions.
WIESBADEN, West Germany, July 17 (Reuters) Three world records were set today at the world shooting championships.

MIAMI, July 17 The Cuban Government has begun to give new prominence to the once powerful and popular 26th of July Movement, which Fidel Castro founded during his fight against the regime of Gen. Fulgencio Batista.

Jim Ryun, a 19-year-old freshman at the University of Kansas, clipped almost 2 seconds off the world record for the mile at the All-America track and field invitation meet yesterday at Berkeley, Calif.
In terms of profits, the year 1965 was a pretty good one for the advertising agency business.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI) The Senate Preparedness Subcommittee charged today that Defense Department shortsightedness and delays in meeting Vietnam demands had reduced the Tactical Air Command to a role of training rather than combat.
The city told wage earners here yesterday exactly how much will be withheld from their pay to meet the new income tax on residents and the earnings tax on commuters.

Dr. Francis J. Petrie, an oral surgeon and former president of the medical board of Queens Hosp al Center, died of a heart attack Saturday night in his home at 211 West Islip Road, West Islip, L.I. He was 62 years old.

MACON, Ga., July 17 (UPI) The police arrested about 50 Negroes late last tight during a melee at the city auditorium where 7,000 persons were attending a "welcome home show" for Otis Redding, an entertainer.

AFTER several years away from Western chess tournaments, Indonesia returned triumphantly recently when her champion, Ong Yok Hlwa, tied for first place with M. Bobotsov of Bulgaria in the international tournament at Zwolle, the Netherlands.
MONTAUK, L.I., July 17 The Montauk Historical Society will conduct a house tour on Wednesday to benefit its museum fund.
Despite a battle by statisticians, city residents will be allowed to use the same taxable income figure they use on their Federal and state income tax forms on their city returns.
HIGHLAND PARK, Ill., July 17 Miss Linda Anne Benjamin and Bayard Lee Brandt plan to be married in the Bismarck Hotel in Chicago on Aug. 7.

MOSCOW, July 17 (AP) Galina Prozumenshchikova of the Soviet Union broke the women's world record in the 100-meter breast-stroke today, but an elite corps of American swimmers, headed by Don Schollander, took six of eight events for an 11-6 victory over the Soviet Union in the two-day Five Nations meet.

SPOLETO, Italy, July 17 (Reuters) Gian Carlo Menotti, founder and president of the annual festival of Two Worlds, which ended here today, plans to give up his administrative work as festival organizer.

Introduction The 1966 New York State Legislature authorized and the Council of the City of New York enacted the New York City Personal Income Tax on Residents and Earnings Tax on Nonresidents effective July 1, 1966. All wages paid on and after September 1, 1968 are subject to having said taxes withheld.
GEORGETOWN, Me., July 17 Dr. Clarence J. Gamble of Milton, Mass., a leader in birthcontrol research, died Friday in Kennebec Point, where he had been staying. His age was 72.

Charles E. Barnes 3d, art director for 15 years until 1956 and an innovator in billboard design for P. Ballantine Sons, the brewers in Newark, collapsed and died of a heart attack Thursday, while mowing the lawn at his home in Sarasota, Fla. He was 69 years old.
PENETANGUISHENE, Ont., July 17 (Canadian Press) Dr. William E.G. Kynoch of Bridgewater, Conn., a leading wood scientist, died yesterday at his summer home on nearby Georgian Bay. He was 83 years old.

The Soviet economic bloc may be moving toward the worst crisis in its history, a crisis whose resolution could have an important impact on the future pattern of non-Communist nations' international trade.

QUOGUE, L.I., July 17 Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Foss of Quogue and Caracas, Venezuela, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances Lee Foss, to Peter Lawrence Blake, son of Mrs. Duane S. Doolittle of Camden, Me., and the late Andrew Cobb Blake of Santa Barbara, Calif.
CHICAGO, July 17 (AP) The police said today that they had recovered a 12-inch hunting knife that Richard F. Speck sold a few hours after eight nurses were found slain Thursday morning.
A Kansas collegian still in his teens has superseded all the great mile runners of history. At 19, James Ronald Ryun has brought the world mile record back to the United States.
The American Can Company announced over the weekend record sales and earnings for the second quarter and first half of this year.

LONDON, July 17 The Labor Government's emergency economic measures are now expected to be announced Wednesday, a week earlier than scheduled. Mounting pressure on the Birtish pound forced the change in plans.
WASHINGTON, July 17-- Miss Maria Felicitas L. Cabrales and Joseph Elmer Stechschulte plan to be married here on Aug. 20.
CHICAGO, July 17 National Guardsmen patrolled the West Side Negro ghetto here for the third successive night tonight to prevent a recurrence of violence.
Five years old tomorrow, the company that pioneered movies aboard passenger planes finds itself in the midst of a fight, the outcome of which may materially affect its future.

Governor Rockefeller has announced that bids on a $200,000 contract for repairs to the main dock of the State University Maritime College at Fort Schuyler, the Bronx, will be opened in Albany tomorrow.
Salaries of high-level bank officials are "surprisingly low," according to a recently-completed study by Cole Associates, a Boston management consulting concern.

Local 102 of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union won a National Labor Relations Board election here last week by a 24-to-16 vote. The election was at Pier 46 where the Ace Assembly Agency, Inc., is conducting a freight consolidation operation for the out-of-state shipment of clothing and piece goods.

Mrs. Vera Schneider, who initiated a petition urging the city to open the Morton Street pier to sunbathers, said last night that she was against a proposal to moor a ferryboat restaurant alongside the pier.
HONG KONG, July 17--The New York tourist who arrives in Hong Kong after 12,000 miles of travel homesick for a hot pastrami sandwich need no longer fret.

EACH weekend exodus from New York includes the man who isn't trying so much to get away from things as he is trying to return to the arms of his family. It's the man who remains behind during the week to swelter in the city's heat while his family escapes.
CORDELE, Ga., July 17 (AP) Seven white men were arrested today and charged with possessing riot equipment as they entered the Georgia Veterans State Park, where a Ku Klux Klan rally was being held.
WASHINGTON, July 17 The Lawyers' Committee for Civil Rights Under Law will move its activities outside the South to concentrate on relations between the police and slum dwellers in the cities.

WASHINGTON, July 17 The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations must overcome some "rather serious structural problems" to succeed in organizing the new groups of u orkers, according to a top aide of Walter P. Reuther.

TOKYO, July 17 (AP) Peking's New China News Agency said today that the American Negroes' civil rights struggle is embarking upon "the path of opposing counterrevolutionary violence with revolutionary violence."
LONDON, July 17 In his effort to mollify the Labor party's left wing about Vietnam, Prime Minister Wilson is running an increasing risk of alienating his most important friend President Johnson.

Senator Jacob K. Javits announced yesterday that he would press for action this week on an amendment to the foreign aid bill prohibiting Alliance for Progress aid to Latin American countries in which democratic governments are suppressed by military revolts.

WASHINGTON, July 17 The first signs of movement since last Wednesday showed up today in the deadlocked airline labor negotiations. The movement, however, was only tentative, and there still was no indication of an early break toward a settlement of the 10-day-old strike.

Roy McMillan, 36 years old yesterday and a campaigner through 2,082 major league games, was the sentimental hero as they Mets swept a doubleheader from the Houston Astros, 4-2 and 7-5, before a crowd of 29,307 at Shea Stadium. His contributions were heroic, too. He played the entire afternoon, made three hits, scored three runs and started the Mets off to their first triumph.
LAWRENCE, L.I., July 17 Dr. Hyman Lewis Berson, a surgeon died yesterday of a heart attack in his home, 11 Lawrence Avenue. He was 61 years old and had an office at 175 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 17 For much of their 70-hour flight, the Gemini 10 astronauts will be practicing scientists as well as orbiting test pilots.

Democrats in Congress are finally beginning to express their uneasiness over the high post and growing scarcity of credit. Their grumbling comes as no surprise. The party of Andrew Jackson and William Jennings Bryan, Franklin D. Roosevelt and John F. Kennedy has traditionally opposed tight money and high interest rates.

MADRID, July 17--The Spanish Civil War exploded 30 years ago tomorrow. Now, after the three years of warring that cost 500,000 to a million dead and after "27 years of peace" under a dictatorship, Spain again stands at a crossroads.

The boards of Globe-Wernicke Industries, Inc., and the Sheller Manufacturing Corporation, announced over the weekend their approval in principle of terms under which the two companies would be merged into a new corporation.
Jesus Christ is not making an impact on modern society, the Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken told worshipers yesterday in his sermon at Riverside Church.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 17 (UPI) Three persons a trainer, a veterinarian and an exercise boy were placed under suspension by the Hollywood Park Board of Stewards yesterday for violation of the state rule against illegal possession of hypodermic needles in the track's stable area.
TEL AVIV, Israel, July 17 Israel's trade unions today waived increases in cost-ofliving allowances due to 650,000 employes under escalator clauses in wage agreements.
WASHINGTON, July 17-- Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, threw his support today behind a new move to force a vote in Congress on granting home rule to the District of Columbia.

VUNGTAU, South Vietnam, July 17--There are four narrow iron cots to a room, there is no hot water and upon arrival each guest is handed a mimeographed leaflet warning that 80 to 85 per cent of the available girls in town have veneral disease.

FOLEY, Ala., July 17 Mrs. Louise Holland Coggeshall, wife of Dr. Lowell T. Coggeshall, a trustee and retired vice president of the University of Chicago, died today, in her home here. She was 62 years old.
MONMOUTH, Ill., July 17 (UPI)--There are no plans in Monmouth to bring Richard F. Speck back to his home town for questioning about a rape and a murder.

GUATEMALA, July 17 Twenty-eight Guatemalan students and leftists, missing since their arrest in February and March, were shot by firing squads of the head of the former military government, Col. Enrique Peralta Azurdia, two former police agents told the University Students Association last night.

KANSAS CITY, July 17 (AP) Joe Foy's inside-the-park home run in the 10th inning gave the Boston Red Sox a 3-2 victory today after the Kansas City Athletics had beaten them, 3-2, in 10 innings in the opener of a double-header.
PARIS, July 17 (UPI) Brazil completed a 4-1 victory over France today in the European Zone Group A final of the Davis Cup competition by splitting the final two singles matches.
Ten civic and six labor groups announced yesterday the formation of a committee that will press Mayor Lindsay to permit an immediate start on building the $525-million World Trade Center.
ST. LOUIS, July 17 (AP) Bobby Nichols stood off the final-round challenges of Jacky Cupit, John Schlee and Terry Dill and won the $100,000 Minnesota Golf Classic today by one stroke.

LIONEL HAMPTON held a reunion Saturday night at Lewisohn Stadium with almost two dozen of the jazz musicians he has performed with in the last 35 years Among them were Teddy Wilson and Gene Krupa, who, with Mr. Hampton, formed three-fourths of the Benny Goodman Quartet in the nineteen-thirties.
Leo Taubman, piano accompanist and coach to many leading singers, died Friday night at the Hospital for Joint Diseases after a four-week illness. He was 59 years old.

Josh Greco may have aged in the 15 years since he first brought his own company to New York, but it is not apparent from his dancing. The master was his usual imperious, compelling self as the Greco troupe took over Philharmonic Hall for matinee and evening performances on Sunday.

The Electric Boat division of General Dynamics has awarded a $5-million contract to Whaling City Dredge and Dock Company of Groton, and Savin Brothers, Inc., of Bloomfield, Conn., for the construction of a graving dock at its Groton, Conn., plant.

WHITE PLAINS, July 17 Mrs. John J. Murphy has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Joan Patricia Murphy, to James R. Kelly, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis A. Kelly of Watertown, Mass. The wedding is planned for September.
ABOARD THE NUCLEAR SUBMARINE FLASHER This sistership of the ill-fated attack submarine Thresher has been undergoing dramatic builder's trials and is passing her tests with flying colors.
CHICAGO, July 17 Richard Franklin Speck, the suspect in the slaying of eight women in a nurses' dormitory last Thursday, was under heavy guard today.
PITTSBURGH, July 17 Steel men were talking cautiously about their market last week. Lagging orders in the early part of July were causing some officials to speculate on a new trend.

WASHINGTON, July 17 The United States and the other industrial countries will shortly be asked to quadruple, to $1billion a year, their contributions to the World Bank for "easy" loans to poor countries.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 17 Large numbers of South Vietnamese who had been hired to preach support of the Saigon Government were secretly indoctrinated to believe the Government was unworthy of support, it was disclosed today by South Vietnamese sources.

A delicate machine, flown here from the West Coast, proved yesterday something that just about everybody already knew there is more carbon monoxide in the air when cars are around than when they aren't.
WASHINGTON, July 17 Following are the votes of delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll calls in Congress during the week ended yesterday:

The building that housed the old Palladium Ballroom on Broadway, a New York landmark, will be replaced by a 41story office skyscraper. The $12-million tower, the latest of several new buildings planned for the area between Times Square and Central Park, will soon rise on the east blockfront of Broadway between 53d and 54th Streets.

MOSCOW, July 17 The heads of the British and Soviet Governments talked of factories and machinery today. Prime Minister Wilson was the genial salesman and Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin the canny buyer as the two men toured a British industrial fair in Moscow's Sokolniki Park.

CHICAGO, July 17 (AP) Brooks Robinson scored two runs and drove in a third to lead the American league-leading Baltimore Orioles to a 3-2 victory today after the Chicago White Sox had won the first game of a double-header, 5-1, behind Gary Peters.
An offering of 500,000 shares of preferred stock of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York stands out this week in an otherwise routine capital market schedule.
ANAHEIM, Calif., July 17 (AP) Jim Hannan pitched a five-hitter today to give the Washington Senators a 3-1 victory over the California Angels and gain a split of a doubleheader.
What happens when a widow inherits her husband's business?

ST. LOUIS, July 17 (AP) Billy Williams hit a single, double, triple and homer today to lead the Chicago Cubs to a 7-2 victory over St. Louis after Curt Flood had given the Cardinals a 4-3 triumph by leading off the 11th inning of the first game of a double-header with a homer.

"He was pretty rough when he got to drinking he seemed to be unhappy with the whole world," said the minister, who lives next door to the family home of Richard F. Speck on Terry Street, in the eastern section of Dallas.
The appointment of a new customs agent in charge at New York headed the list of appointments announced last week by Lester D. Johnson, Federal Commissioner of Customs.
The election of William C. Reynolds as president and chief executive officer of Philadelphia Shipyards, Inc., has been announced by William A. Clarke Jr., board chairman of the concern.

OTTAWA, July 17 Paul Hellyer, Minister of Defense, today rebuked the admirals who have criticized unification of the armed forces. Mr. Hellyer said "a small group of officers" would not be allowed to dictate Government policy.
THE president of Local 1199, Drug and Hospital Employes Union Leon Julius Davis likes to tend the roses in his garden in Flushing, Queens, or pick mushrooms in the country on weekends.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 17 For the first time in eight weeks, the Yankees managed to construct a three-game winning streak by sweeping a doubleheader today from the Minnesota Twins, 4-2 and 9-6.

Officials of the hospital employes union said late last night that they had reached agreement on wages and benefits for nomedical employes with two voluntary hospitals. They charged, however, that three other hospitals had come to terms over the weekend and then reneged.
Two men were arrested yesterday morning on charges of kidnapping a young woman from Washington Square Park at gunpoint and raping her.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., June 17 Preparations for the launching tomorrow of the Gemini 10 rendezvous and docking mission moved into the final, tensionfilled hours tonight. Space agency officials described the countdown as the smoothest thus far for a manned flight.

PHILADELPHIA, July 17 Mr. and Mrs. John Lawrence Fearey of Chestnut Hill have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Shiland Fearey, to Thomas Adams Walsh, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Burton Walsh of Williamstown, Mass.

Representative Wright Patman, chairman of the House Banking and Curreney Committee, said yesterday that he may sponsor legislation that would bring operations of foreign banks in the United States under Federal supervision:
The Washington Post is negotiating to buy a share of the European edition of The New York Herald Tribune.
