WASHINGTON, July 17 The Senate ethics committee will seek to learn this week what Senator Thomas J. Dodd reported to his friend Julius Klein when he returned from a six-day trip to Germany in April, 1964.
Weary Staten Island firefighters called for reinforcements from Manhattan and Brooklyn again yesterday to help subdue stubborn brush fires over a mile-square area on the southern end of the island.

When Local 1199 of the Drug and Hospital Employee Union was lobbying four years ago for passage of a state law requiring voluntary hospitals to bargain collectively with their unionized employee, the central point in its campaign was that the proposed law would make hospital strikes impossible by compelling impartial arbitration of all disputes over wages or working conditions. The State A.F.L.-C.I.O, opposed the law
WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) The Johnson family attended church services together today, heard a sermon on the work of the Peace Corps in Latin America and a prayer for "Thy servants, Luci and Pat."

UPPER MARLBORO, Md., July 17 Charles Kolb and Tony Belcher of Miami set a record in winning the annual six-hour race on Marlboro's 1.7mile road course today by 14 laps over their nearest competitor. Kolb and Belcher drove a Porsche Carrera 6 and covered 218 laps, far surpassing the previous distance mark for this race.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI) Secretary of State Dean Rusk warned the Soviet Union and its allies today against sending "volunteers" to fight in Vietnam. "It would be very unwise for them to get involved," he said.
Pan American World Airways, reported over the weekend it has ordered two additional Concorde supersonic jet transports.
HYANNIS PORT, Mass., July 17 (UPI) Joseph P. Kennedy, father of President Kennedy, suffered a heart seizure today but was reported much improved a few hours later.
EAGLE, Wis., July 17 Miss Patricia Ann Von Rueden and John Edward Nesbitt will be married next month.
New York Athletic Club runners won both races yesterday at a Road Runners Club of New York event at Macombs Dam Park, Bronx.
Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within 12 months amount to-$94,670,235,521. They consist of Treasury securities as follows:

POUGHQUAG, N.Y., July 17 Politics on a Sunday often is a bore, but it was a ball today at the picnic that Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. gave for Hudson Valley delegates to the Democratic state convention.

Native Diver? Once again, yes, of course. To Eastern horse players he is simply another one of those "West Coast horses." To Californians he is simply The Diver, treated with the respect that Aqueduct's patrons reserved for another old-timer, Kelso.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI) Supreme-Court Justice William O. Douglas has applied to the State Department for permission to visit Communist China.
Arnie Uhrlass of Huntington, L.I., a former Olympian, captured the senior all-round title of the New York State bicycle championships yesterday on Kissena Park's banked track in Flushing, Queens.

Waterfront employers in the port are advertising for workers. Large posters listing permanent jobs on work gangs are being sent to the piers as part of a campaign to fill open positions in the port's traditional gang system.
CHICAGO, July 17 The Chicago in which Richard Franklin Speck moved is a city of degraded men and decayed buildings.

William Byler, executive director of the Association on American. Indian Affairs, announced yesterday the appointment of Iliff McKay, a member of the Blackfoot Indian tribe of Montana, to fill the newly created post of associate director.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, July 17 (UPI) Ondine, an American yawl captained by Sumner A. Long of New York, was listed as the unofficial winner of the Class A Bermuda-to-the-Skaw yacht race today.
MILWAUKEE, July 17 Cliff and Nancy Richey of San Angelo, Tex., made history today by becoming the first brother and sister to win national singles tennis championships together.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 17 The United Nations Development Program Council has approved support for a $2.4-million project designed to expand and strengthen hurricane hunting and weather forecasting in the Caribbean.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI) Growing Communist dependence on food supplies from Western nations was indicated today in an Agriculture Department report showing the Communist countries' imports of wheat reached a record in the 12 months ended June 30.
CHICAGO, July 17 (AP) "I moistened my finger tips and rubbed. I saw a 'B'. I rubbed some more and saw B-o-r-n."

In a $2-million transaction, space has been leased for a gourmet restaurant to be known as the Inn of the Clock in the United Nations Plaza Building, just north of the United Nations headquarters on First Avenue.
Jules Feiffer's fable, "Passionella," will constitute one of three elements of the forthcoming musical, "Come Back! Go Away! I Love You," it was announced yesterday by Stuart Ostrow, producer.

FORT LEE, N.J., July 17 Joseph. T. McCarthy, whose knowledge of New York City surface transportation routes was sought for half a century by the courts, contemporaries and by bus drivers and trolley car motormen, died today at his home here. He was 81 years old and lived at 259 Tremont Avenue.
The Yankees and Mets won double-headers yesterday, giving New York fans a sweep for only the second time since the Mets began playing in 1962.
NEWPORT, R.I., July l7 Newport's first outdoor opera festival ended its five-day run last night with a record attendance of 9,000 for a performance of "Aids" under cloudless skies.

LOS ANGELS, July 17 (UPI) A requiem mass for Police Chief William H. Parker, who collapsed and died last night shortly after a testimonial dinner in his honor, will be celebrated at St. Vibiana's Roman Catholic Cathedral Wednesday morning. James Francis Cardinal McIntyre, Archbishop of Los Angeles, will officate.

ONE of the major issues facing religion today is that of making faiths fashioned in man's pastoral epochs relevant to his scientific and computerized present. Two recent attempts to achieve such relevancy were explored yesterday in television programs on the Columbia Broadcasting System.

FISHERS ISLAND, N.Y., July 17 Charles R. Bennett, sailing the 41-foot fiber-glass yawl Corinthia under charter, and Andrew Schoettle, with the new California-27 sloop, Tiffin, were the trophy winners today in the distance race that was the first leg of the 35th annual American Yacht Club cruise.

Room air-conditioner shipments rose 9.9 per cent in June from the level a year earlier, the National Appliance Manufacturers Association, a division of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association, reported over the weekend.

DETROIT, July 17 (AP) Chuck Hinton and Rocky Colavito accounted for four of seven home runs hit by Cleveland in the second game today as the Indians completed a doubleheader sweep with a 15-2 victory over the Detroit Tigers.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., July 17 Miss Fern Miller, daughter of Mr. wand Mrs. Milton Miller of Plainfield and Elberon, was married today to Dr. Ronald Fredric Kaplan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Kaplan of West Newton, Mass.

The City Planning Commission has erpressed approval of a plan to preserve two old city piers for their interest as historical items. They are Pier 1 and Pier A, on the Hudson River, adjacent to Battery Park.

Charles Masterson of Brooklyn, the defender, and Stephen Ogilvy of Westport, Conn., the East's top-ranking senior player, gained the third round of the Eastern Senior Clay Court tennis championships yesterday at the Seminole Club, Forest Hills, Queens.
Dr. Erich E. Kleemann of 365 West End Avenue, who had charge of the obstretrics division of the old Lutheran Hospital in Manhattan, died here yesterday after a short illness. His age was 79.

HONG KONG, July 17 Many officers and men of North Vietnam's military reserves have applied to rejoin the armed forces following a partial mobilization order issued by President Ho Chi Minh, the Hanoi radio reported today.

June shipments of acetate yarn and rayon by United States producers declined 3 per cent from the May totals, but were 5 per cent above shipments in June, 1965, the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc., reported over the weekend.
Once, in the not-too-distant past, motels were places to stay en route to a destination. Today, with a shift of emphasis from bedroom to resort, motels are more and more becoming the destination.

Joel J. Tyler, the city's License Commissioner, joined the effort to save the old Metropolitan Opera House yesterday by promising to keep its license intact while there was still hope for the building's survival.

IF Jimmy Brown's decision to retire from pro football is as irrevocable as he in sisr it is, his loss will be a severe blow to the sport. For the Cleveland Browns it will be cataclysmic. Superstars of Jimmy's dimensions arrive so rarely that his absence will have as shattering an effect on Cleveland deatinies as his presence once had on enemy defenses.

GENEVA, July 17-The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. said in a prepared sermon today that the American Negro was "usually greeted by a cold indifference or blatant hypocrisy", when he called on the "so-called white churches."
HANKOE, Norway, July 17 (AP) Ernest Fay of Houston scored his second victory today in the yachting regatta for the Scandinavian Gold Cup.
KELOWNA, British Columbia, July 17 (AP) Mira Slovak of Los Angeles won the first British Columbia Cup for unlimited hydroplane racing today.

Mr. and Mrs. Anton Assar Nordling of Helsinki and Tampere, Finland, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Seija Kaarina Nordling, to Geoffrey Kevin Burke, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Crimmins Burke of 51 East 90th Street and Edgartown, Mass.

Today's decision of the International Court of Justice in the South-West African case will whichever way it goes add a new dimension to the fight of the African nations against perpetuation of white minority rule in southern Africa. It will be deeply significant not only for the Africans but for the United States and Britain, for the Court itself and for the United Nations, with which it is linked.

The Association of the Bar of the City of New York announced yesterday the formation of a 20-member panel of lawyers and judges to recommend changes in the State Constitution, which, it said, "is in a condition of increasing obsolescence."

LEONIA, N.J., July 17 In Calvary Lutheran Church here this afternoon, Miss Laura Nina Gagliardi, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Giocondo Gagliardi of West Englewood, became the bride of Edward Albert Stettner of New Brunswick. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Stettner of Massapequa Parik, L.I.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 17 An Air Force jet carrying Henry Cabot Lodge, the United States Ambassador, developed mechanical trouble today but landed safely.

ATHENS, July 17 The Government of Premier Stephonos Stephanopoulos said today that Prof. Andreas Papandreou, son of the former Premier, George Papandreou, had taken part in Communist activities in his youth.

JUSTICE is a quality that is often absent from a bridge deal, but few deals can be quoted as outstanding examples of injustice. The hand in today's diagram is one of the few. It was reported by Paul Hayden from a student game played at Tufts University this summer.
A BARLEY and mushroom casserole may offer a change of pace from potatoes and pasta in a summer menu. Made with chicken broth, the casserole is an excellent accompaniment to barbecued chicken.
An increase in short-term parking rates at Kennedy International Airport, effective Aug. 1, was announced last week by the Port of New York Authority.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July, 17 (AP) Clifford Ann Creed sank a five-foot birdie putt on the first hole of a sudden-death playoff and defeated Sue Maxwell for first place in the $17,500 Ladies' Professional Golfers' Association Midwest

A committee representing a citywide organization of 5,000 welfare recipients has demanded to see the city's relief rolls, so they can organize the welfare clients, Commissioner Mitchell I. Ginsberg, disclosed yesterday.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 17 (AP) An armed robbery in which a Negro policeman wounded a Negro suspect was followed by a near-riot in this City's Negro Fillmore district early today.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July I7 The 68th Larchmont Yacht Club Race Week that began yesterday with only partial success because of wind failure, came into full bloom today with a sparkle of southerly and southwesterly airs on Long Island Sound.

Mrs. Dorothy Verrill Rhodes, an advertising and publicity director in cosmetics and fashions and a pioneer woman aviator, died on Thursday in St. Vincent's Hospital. She was 72 years old and lived at 5 West Eighth Street.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 17 Buried Treasure, owned and ridden by Alice Lyons of St. James, L.I., made a clean sweep of the green working hunter division, scoring a perfect 20 points, today at the Southampton Horse Show.

WASHINGTON, July 17 The second-quarter growth in the nation's total output of goods and services, the gross national product, was $10.8billion, well below the hectic pace of the preceding two quarters, the Commerce Department reported today.

Howard J. Samuels said yesterday that he had firm commitments for nearly 250 of the 573 votes needed for the Democratic nomination for Governor, thus making him a "fighting underdog" in the four-way race.

MANILA, Monday, July 18 (UPI)--Communist Huks were suspected of killing a town mayor and five others on a highway today. The victims were traveling to attend a conference here that had been called by President Ferdinand E. Marcos.
Developments this past weekend have demolished any faint hopes that there might be peace negotiations and a cease-fire in Vietnam in the near future.
Five pieces of hand-wrought antique jewelry that were stolen at Kennedy Airport on May 10 while being sent back to the Louvre in Paris were recovered here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 17 A "silent protest" over the war in Vietnam will be staged opposite the church in which Luci Baines Johnson will be married Aug. 6.

Two policemen were struck by flying soda bottles and a third was bitten on the hand early yesterday as an unruly crowd of about 200 persons gathered at the scene of an automobile accident in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn.

ROSTOCK, Germany, July 17 The ninth Baltic Sea Week, East Germany's major effort each year to develop closer relations with its Scandinavian neighbors and eventually to obtain diplomatic recognition, ended tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, July 17 (AP) An error by Tony Taylor, the Phillies' second baseman, in the eighth inning started a Los Angeles rally, which gave the Dodgers a, 3-1 victory over Philadelphia today in the second game of a doubleheader. The Phillies had won the opening game, 3-0.

ON the moving of June 20, 1963, Stig Erik Constans Wennerstrom, a colonel in the Swedish Air Force, parked his car as usual near a government building in Stockholm and started to walk across a bridge called the Riksbron toward the Foreign Office, where he was assigned as a disarmament adviser. "As he did so," Thomas
A City Hall spokesman indicated yesterday that New Yorkers might have to wait for months to learn whether they can obtain free transfers between buses and the subway.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) Deputy Secretary of Defense Cyrus R. Vance reported today that about twothirds of North Vietnam's oilstorage capacity had been destroyed by air raids. But he said it was too early to assess the effect of the bombing on infiltration into South Vietnam.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., July 17 Mrs. Ethel Gay Kunzig of 30 Locust Lane, widow of Philip H. Kunzig, a lawyer, and a direct descendant of Pocahontas and John Rolfe, died today in Lawrence Hcspital. She was 80 years old.
OF the six new model rooms on Altman's seventh floor, at least three are experiments in mixing periods and styles.

CAMLO, South Vietnam, July 17--Waves of United States Air Force B-52 bombers dropped tons of bombs this morning on a patch of jungle three and a half miles south of the belt of neutral territory separating North and South Vietnam.

John J. Cassese, the president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, denied yesterday that he was bigoted in his opposition to a civilian-dominated police review board. But he strongly reiterated his denunciation of the board, which was appointed last week by Mayor Lindsay.

Taxpayers who think the city will never be able to keep tabs on payments under the new personal income tax are in for a disillusionment. The city has a highly trained auditing force, including investigators and collectors.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 17 (AP) For the second time in less than a year, Lieut. (jg.) Robert F. Adams of the Navy has been rescued from North Vietnamese territory. His jet bomber was shot down last Tuesday in the same area in which a surfaceto-air missile struck it on Oct. 5.

PITTSBURGH, July 17 (AP) The Pittsburgh Pirates whipped San Francisco, 7-4 and 7-1, today and took over first place by one game from the Giants in the National League pennant race. A crowd of 35,184, the largest this season at Forbes Field, saw the doubleheader.

Nearly 80, per cent of the 200 television stations affiliated with the Columbia, Broadcasting System have asked the network to supply a late evening entertainment show Mondays through Fridays. The stations have to provide their own programing after 11 P.M., when network service ends.

A patrolman awaiting a hearing before the new civiliandominated police review board on charges of brutality was cheered yesterday by residents of a Negro street in Coney Island after he had saved the life of a newborn baby.

A three-year delay in carrying out a controversial plan to combine the city's vocational and academic high schools was proposed yesterday by Dr. Bernard E. Donovan, the Superintendent of Schools. Last year, the Board of Education endorsed a plan to substitute comprehensive schools for the academic and vocational schools by 1970.
WASHINGTON, July 17--The United States will make a major effort this week to induce industrial countries to provide more help in the food and agriculture problems of developing countries.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) Adm. William F. Raborn, who resigned last month as head of the Central Intelligence Agency, said today that many criticisms of the agency "have been largely based on inaccuracies and haven't been justified at all."

FARMINGTON, Conn., July 17 Mr and Mrs. Frederick T. Gear have announced the engagement of their, daughter, Miss Jean Graham Gear, to Samuel Hazard Gillespie 3d. He is the son of S. Hazard Gillespie, former United States Attorney of the Southern District of New York, and Mrs. Ruth R. Gillespie of New York. A wedding in August is planned.
SPOLETO, Italy, July 16 Ezra Pound, the 80-year-old American expatriate poet, broke his customary silence of recent years today to read publicly from his works.
MOSCOW, July 17 (AP) Two American rabbis spoke today from the pulpit of a Russian Baptist Church. They called for understanding by all religious people in this land of official atheism.
BOSTON, July 17 (UPI) Richard Cardinal Cushing said today that the United States was waging a war against "evil men and evil ways" in Vietnam.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 18--The Rev. Ian Paisley, leader of Northern Ireland's extremist Protestant faction, led 1,000 of his followers today to the Belfast courthouse, where he and six others were charged with unlawful assembly.
Peter C. Canellos, a thirdyear student at the Columbia University School of Law, has been named editor-in-chief of the Columbia Law Review for the 1966-67 academic year.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., July 18 --Mr. and Mrs. Walter E. Tolles of Cove Neck have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Wesley Tolles, to Robert Edward Cole, son of Mr. and Mrs. LeRoy A. Cole of Oyster Bay.
Two men accused of having stolen $44,800 from two messengers of a Bronx saving and loan association on Feb. 7 interrupted their trial yesterday to plead guilty.

WASHINGTON, July 18-- Andrew F. Brimmer, the newest member of the Federal Reserve Board, warned banks today that "reserves are likely to become less rather than more readily available" and that they must "act promptly to bring their loan growth under better control."

HOUSTON, July 18--The Gemini 10 rendezous and docking exercise was designed to tell space officials, among other things, how much electricity there is in space and whether any of it builds up on a spacecraft.

When he died last February at the age of 70, Buster Keaton left a heritage of 66 years of show business that accidentally dropped him into films in 1917 where his inventive, acrobatic genius made him equal but apart from the rare likes of Harold Lloyd and Charlie Chaplin.
Three warning shots were fired outside police headquarters yesterday as a 17-year-old prisoner was recaptured in a fourblock chase after he attempted to escape from the arresting policeman.

ALBANY, July 18--Assembly Speaker Anthony J. Travia credited two Queens High School Juniors today with helping to influence the Governor and the Legislature in the enactment of a City University aid bill.

The 20-cent fare sought by seven private bus companies here could bring the city as much as $900,000 a year in extra franchise taxes. In addition, the city could save the several hundred thousand dollars a year it now pays the companies for transporting schoolchildren.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Tuesday, July 19--The Gemini 10 astronauts rocketed into orbit late yesterday afternoon, caught and linked up with an unmanned, satellite. Then early this morning they maneuvered deeper into space than man has ever ventured.
DETROIT, July 18 (AP)-- The first of the auto industry's 1967 models rolled off an assembly line today as Ford's Wixom, Mich., plant turned out about 75 Thunderbirds and Lincoln Continentals.
THE HAGUE, July 18-- The South-West Africa case decided today by the International Court of Justice is the biggest--in time and paperwork--ever to come before the tribunal.

WASHINGTON, July 18-- The Federal Maritime Commission, acting with unusual dispatch, decided today to hold a hearing on the Department of Defense's controversial plan to subject ship cargo procurement to a competitive bidding system. The new system is scheduled to go into effect on Aug. 20.

WATCH HILL, R.I., July 18 --Announcement has been made here by Mrs. Rebekah Harkness of Holiday House and New York of the marriage of her daughter, Miss Anne Terry Pierce, on May 2 in St. Thomas, the Virgin Islands, to Anthony Wallace McBride of New York and St. Thomas. The ceremony was performed aboard a ship by the ship's captain.
ANCHORAGE--Up her in the sub-Arctic, where newcomers often swear that banking practices are a little more flexible, the bankers are singing the "Tight Money Blues" with the rest of the country.
NEW DELHI, July 18--The North Vietnamese consul general in New Delhi said today that American pilots held in North Vietnam were "war criminals" and Hanoi had the right to put them on trial.

The pressmen's union and the World Journal Tribune, Inc., resumed negotiations yesterday but reported no progress toward an agreement that could end the 85-day-old shutdown of the new publishing enterprise. The other nine newspaper unions have reached contract settlement with the corporation.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) --Charles Cogen, president of the American Federation of Teachers, said today that the number of teachers in the country should be doubled, from the present 1.5 million to 3 million.

JIM RYUN and his coach, Bob Timmons, were answering questions last month, the day before the Amateur Athletic Union's national outdoor track and field championships at Randalls Island. "Are you worried about the 3-minute-52-second barrier in the mile?" one interrogator asked. "Worried about 3:52?" Timmons repeated. "We're concerned more with the 3:53.6 barrier."

MUNICH, Germany, July 18 --Wilhelm Bungert defeated Keith Diepraam, 12-10, 6-2, 6-3, and clinched a victory for West Germany over South Africa in the Group B final of the European Zone Davis Cup tennis tournament.

MOSCOW, July 18 (Reuters)--Leading Soviet cultural figures, including Galina Ulanova, the prima ballerina, and Aram Khachaturian, the composer, appealed today to leaders in the arts in the United States to protest against what they called "the criminal war" in Vietnam.
A Frenchman who was allegedly linked to a major narcotics smuggling scheme was sentenced yesterday to five years in prison for trying to smuggle himself into the country.
WASHINGTON, July 18--The Public Health Service today tightened its control on the testing of drugs on humans and opened a broad study on the moral and ethical problems involved.
Steel production eased sixtenths of 1 per cent last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

Roger L. Stevens, the former Broadway producer who is now chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts and of the National Council on the Arts, is so irritated by the state of American criticism that he intends to help rectify the situation with Federal money, he told an annual writers' conference at Columbia University yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) --Sammy Davis is fighting a Federal tax claim of $227,483, contending thousands of dollars in expenses disallowed by the Internal Revenue Service were essential to his position in show business.

ALBANY, July 18--Acting Governor Malcolm Wilson directed the chairman of the State Commission for Human Rights today to make an onthe-spot investigation of alleged discrimination against Puerto Rican migrant workers at North Collins, N.Y.

Mrs. Anna Brandenburg Cohen, widow of Elias D. Cohen, who at his death in 1956 was senior vice president of what is now the National Starch and Chemical Corporation, died yesterday in her home at 320 Central Park West, She was 84 years old.

We are capitulating to Local 1199 because our sister institution--Mount Sinai-- was unwilling to take the beating we did and fiight for the principle, as well as the law, which says there should be no strikes against helpless people in hospitals.
BERLIN, July 18--East German Communist officials said today that donations collected over a period of weeks from private citizens for North Vietnam have exceeded $2-million.

Reginald A. Le Quire of 1 Bank Street has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Antoinette Lurana Le Quire, to Newton B. Schott Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Schott of Rockaway, N.J. A wedding in August is planned.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI)--Construction spending slipped to an annual rate of $73.7-billion in June, as housing outlays dropped by 2 per cent, the Commerce Department reported today.
WASHINGTON, July 18-- President Johnson signed today a bill for an immediate 3.2 per cent pay increase for Government workers, but he expressed concern over its potential inflationary impact.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 18 --Larchment Race Week, with the weekend sailors shaken out, settled down to a competition for those seriously seeking championships today and there were lots of them.
The International Court of Justice today delivered its judgment in the second phase of the South-West Africa cases (Ethiopia v. South Africa, Liberia v. South Africa).

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 18 (AP)--Joe Namath, 1965 American Football League rookie of the year, led drills from his quarterback post as the New York Jets officially opened their 1966 training camp today at the Peekskill Military Academy.

In asking the rich countries of the world to quadruple their contributions to the World Bank, George D. Woods, its president, is forcing them to re-examine their entire philosophy of development aid. Mr. Woods wants at least $1 billion a year for the International Development Association, the subsidiary of the World Bank that specializes in providing long-term loans on very liberal terms to the developing countries.
A stepped-up city antinarcotics drive that seeks to harness the efforts of private, semiprivate and official agencies got under way yesterday.
The Lehman Corporation, a large closed-end investment company, reported yesterday net assets as of June 30, of $432,992,377, or $35.49 a share, compared with $397,663,285, or $32.60, last year.

Leroy Joseph Kallmeyer, an executive assistant for the Latin American Group of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, died Saturday of a heart attack while on vacation in San Juan, P.R. He was 55 years old and lived at 92 Borglum Road, Manhasset, L.I.

Six Negro civil-rights leaders will appear on "Today" next Tuesday when the National Broadcasting Company television program allots two hours (7 to 9 A.M.) to the topic, "The Black Establishment: A Closeup Look at the Civil Rights Movement."
BONN, July 18--West Germany's Chancellor, Ludwig Erhard, a strong supporter of the free economy, is finding it necessary to revise some of his basic economic tenets.
The Coast Guard charged the docking pilot of the British tanker Alva Cape yesterday with negligence in a collision off Staten Island last month that cost the lives of 33 seamen.

The two-week period of grace during which holders of unanswered parking tickets can pay them without added penalty is explained by the Police Department and the Criminal Court as a prelude to a vigorous enforcement drive.

Irving Saltzman, founder and former president and chairman of the Premier Knitting Company, manufacturer of women's garments, died Sunday in his home at 1401 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, He was 75 yars old.
Whitney M. Young Jr., executive director of the National Urban League, left here yesterday for a 10-day unofficial visit with Negro servicemen in Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, July 18-- Representative Adam Clayton Powell warned today of an endless cycle of violence and destruction" if the nation ignored "black power."
Mayor Lindsay walked through the littered streets of East Harlem last night and found music, laughter and misery mixed in a steamy blend.
Braulio Baeza pleased many in the crowd of 31,655 at Aqueduct yesterday by guiding Mrs. Joseph Derrico's Cavans Rose to an easy triumph in the feature race at 1 1-16 miles on the turf.

HOUSTON, July 18--Miss Lucinda Pickford Steven, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Pickford Steven, was married here Saturday to Robert Cameron Duncan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger Fenn Duncan of Concord, Mass. The Rev. Leslie Pugh performed the service in the First Congregational Church.

ROME, July 18--Agreement for the establishment of a joint committee of the Roman Catholic Church and the World Methodist Council to explore possible common studies and action in a framework of Christian unity was announced today.

Much of the controversy over Lyndon B. Johnson's selection as John F. Kennedy's running mate in 1960 was "a misunderstanding," President Kennedy's press secretary, Pierre Salinger, says in a book to be published in September by Doubleday.
A balloon almost twice as large as any hitherto launched was flown from New Mexico yesterday as the initial step foward an unmanned landing on Mars.
There undoubtedly are many art lovers who do not appreciate seeing a comic-strip dialogue balloon ascending from the mouth of an authentic preColumbian figure--especially in advertising.

Whether he does best as a runner against the clock or a racer goaded by competitors, a track man's real challenge is to himself. It is the frailty of his own muscles, lungs and heart that he must overcome.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 18-- Syria, is considering the acquisition of Soviet surface-to-air missiles in an effort to strengthen her air defenses, according to diplomatic reports from Damascus.

JERSEY CITY, July 18 (AP) --Anthony (Tino) DeAngelis, serving 20 years in a Federal penitentiary for, manipulating a $150-million food oil swindle, was sentenced today to two to three years in State Prison. Three associates also were sentenced.

WASHINGTON, June 18--A Federal appeals judge began hearing today a suit that lawyers described as the first major attack on de facto pupil discrimination in a large American city. The suit is against the public school system in the District of Columbia.

Like flocks of Gooney birds that had forgotten how to fly, rows of grounded airliners stood wingtip to wingtip beside their hangars yesterday at New York's three major airports while negotiators in Washington struggled to find a solution to the 11-day-old airline strike.

ATHENS, Ga., July 18 (AP) --Joseph Howard Sims, 41 years old, a Ku Klux Klansman facing 10 years in Federal prison for crimes against Negroes, pleaded guilty today to a charge of assault with intent to kill his estranged wife.

WASHINGTON, July 18-- North Vietnam's order of partial mobilization was viewed today by American officials as primarily a domestic propaganda move designed to rally a home front that has shown signs of war-weariness.

HOULTON, Me., July 18 (AP) --Bernard E. Esters, a retired publisher of weekly newspapers who headed the National Editorial Association in 1952 and was thereafter chairman of its legislative committee, died here today. He was 68 years old.
WASHINGTON, July 18-- The Administration's $3.4-billion foreign aid request began its usual stormy passage through the Senate today with the promise of unlimited debate on two score amendments.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) --A Congressional subcommittee that visited South Vietnam said in a report tonight a military victory is possible without a complete solution to that country's economic and political problems.
Following are brief biographies of the regular members of the International Court of Justice at The Hague and of the two ad hoc members selected by the opposing sides to sit in this case:

PITTSBURGH, July 18 (AP) --Lindy McDaniel, the fourth San Francisco relief pitcher in two innings, stopped a Pittsburgh threat in the ninth inning tonight and saved the Giants' 3-2 victory over the first-place Pirates. The triumph moved the Giants within two percentage points of the National League lead.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI) --For the seventh time, the Interstate Commerce Commission rejected today the application of a disabled Atlanta Negro for a permit to set up a truck line.

THE HAGUE, Tuesday, July 19--The Government announced today that it had told the charge d'affaires of Communist China's Embassy to leave the country within 24 hours. A statement by the Ministries of Justice and Foreign Affairs said that following the mysterious death of a Chinese engineer, the charge, Li Enchiu, had been declared persona non grata.

The shooting of a woman in the racially troubled East New York section of Brooklyn last night set off a string of disorders that brought more than 200 extra policemen into the area--the same one in which three persons were hurt and 11 arrested last Friday night and Saturday morning.

CHATTANOOGA, July 18-- Mr. and Mrs. Louis Winer have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Shoshana Winer, to Dr. Bertrand Agus, son of Dr. and Mrs. Haim Agus of Brooklyn, New York, and Loon Lake, N.Y. An autumn wedding is planned.

PEARL RIVER, N.Y., July 18 --William L. Hauswirth, manager of the old Carlton House in New York for about 20 years until 1951, died Friday in the Hillcrest Nursing Home, Spring Valley. He was 84 years old and lived at 133 East Central Avenue.

STATELINE, Nev., July 18-- Federal authorities began a new chapter today in the national campaign against water pollution by proposing a program for Lake Tahoe that is essentially preventive rather than remedial. The previous 38 Federal pollution abatement actions over the last decade, ranging from coast to coast, have dealt with aggravated instances of waterway contamination.

PARIS, July 18--Mrs. Ngo Dinh Nhu, sister-in-law of the late President of South Vietnam, Ngo Dinh Diem, has published a long interview in France that is both sympathetic to Vietnamese Communists and violently anti-American.
WASHINGTON, July 18-- The Treasury bill rate rose again at today's auction and just fell short of reaching 5 per cent for the first time, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
City antipoverty officials began distributing checks yesterday to pay employes in the summer program to combat poverty.

The Chase Manhattan Bank opened yesterday the first American banking office in Saigon, The full-service commercial office, situated at 28/30 Rue Nguyen Van Thinh, will also serve as a depository for the United States Treasury.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) --Representative George W. Andrews of Alabama introduced today a resolution calling for the House Judiciary Committee to investigate the moral character of Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court.
A funeral service was conducted yesterday, morning for Delmore Schwartz, the poet, editor and critic, who died of a heart attack in a midtown hotel last week at the age of 52.

Howard J. Samuels, who says he has firm pledges of 238 of the 573 delegate votes needed for the Democratic nomination for Governor, challenged his rivals yesterday "to come out and show us where their strength is."
LONDON, July 18--The Bank of England intervened again on the foreign exchange market here today as the pound came under renewed selling pressure, but the pressure was not so severe as last week's.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., July 18 --Ask Billy Haughton to single out the best of the 121 standardbreds in his huge harness racing stable and, without hesitation, the top-flight reinsman will say, "Romulus Hanover."

AMESBURY, Mass., July 18 --Dr. and Mrs. James Francis Whitten have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Chrisjean Clark Whitten, to Paul William Stooshnoff, son of Mrs. William Stooshnoff of Calgary, Alberta, and the late Mr. Stooshnoff.

PARIS, July 18--Ambassador Charles E. Bohlen of the United States met with Foreign Minister Maurice Couve de Murville today on problems related to the evacuation of American bases in France. The meeting came after Mr. Bohlen had signed a new consular treaty between France and the United States.

ATLANTA, July 18 (AP)-- Eddie Mathews's third hit of the game drove in Felix Millan with what proved to be the winning, run in the eighth inning today as the Atlanta Braves beat the Cincinnati Reds, 9-8.

Speculators were back in force in the soybean futures market yesterday. Lack of rain over the weekend in some major growing areas encouraged their buying, along with a forecast of some higher temperatures for the start of the week.

Representative Adam Clayton Powell will appear in State Supreme Court here this morning to answer two charges of criminal contempt that carry possible jail sentences, his office in Washington said yesterday.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, July 18 (AP)--Tina, a United States entry, captured the second race in the 6-meter class today and became the favorite yacht to win the 110 Cup.
EDWARDS Air Force Base, Calif., July 18 (UPI)--An electronic brain capable of guiding a manned spacecraft to a landing on earth was tested today in the X-15 rocket craft.
The spot rate on the British pound recovered partly from its Friday setback in active trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday.

Arguments in two lawsuits concerning the old Metropolitan Opera House went officially unheeded yesterday when presiding Justice Irwin D. Davidson of the State Supreme Court removed himself from the cases. The hearing was rescheduled for Aug. 2.
WASHINGTON, July 18--Following are the parties involved, the issues in dispute, and a brief summary of the effects of the airline strike:
E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc.--the nation's largest chemical producer--reported yesterday its highest sales and earnings for any quarter in the three months ended June 30.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) --Agreement was reached today to end a three-and-a-half-weekold strike of bakery workers against the National Biscuit Company.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) --The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today the revocation of the brokerdealer registration of Costello, Russotto Co. of Beverly Hills, Calif., for what it said were violations of the anti-fraud provisions of the securities law.

Edward G. Fischer, former general station master at Grand Central Terminal, who was known as "Mr. Courtesy," died Sunday in Cross County Hospital, Yonkers. He was 72 years old and lived at 130 West 183d Street, the Bronx.

Beethoven's Symphony No. 3 (the "Eroica") and Stravinsky's "Le Sacre du Printemps" will be conducted by Leonard Bernstein in the first two of 12 free New York Philharmonic concerts to be played in New York City parks this summer.
Welfare Commissioner Mitchell I. Ginsberg has agreed to study the possibility of creating a complaint review board in the Welfare Department to investigate alleged violations of clients' rights.
BONN, July 18--President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia arrived in Bonn today for a four-day state visit.

VOLUNTOWN, Conn., July 18--When 40 per cent of the men of this village leave their modest homes each morning they drive from its tree-shaded streets 27 miles to Groton, Conn., to build nuclear submarines.

The Rev. Jerome Harris, an Episcopal priest whose last post was that of vicar of St. John's Church in Springfield Gardens, Queens, died Sunday at his residence in the Concord Hotel, 130 East 40th Street. He was 72 years old.

Mayor Lindsay has asked Edward J. Logue to reconsider a preliminary recommendation that the City Planning Commission be absorbed by a central agency with control over every phase of housing and redevelopment in the city.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 18 (AP)--Mrs. Henry Potter Russell, San Francisco social and cultural leader, died last night in Children's Hospital. She was 69 years old.
The bond market reflected yesterday a growing feeling that the Federal Reserve discount rate would not be raised until late summer.
A change in the senior management of the Mosler Safe Company was announced here yesterday.
A significant increase in the number of deaths in the city was recorded during the last two weeks of unusually hot weather, the Department of Health reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) --The House Public Works Committee reported today that 46 per cent of the vehicles checked in 13 state inspection programs "were rejected for some deficiency."

HOUSTON, Tuesday, July 19 --The Department of Defense, which monitors objects orbiting the earth, was unable early today to identify two "satellites" that the crew of Gemini 10 saw on its first revolution of the earth yesterday.

METUCHEN, N.J., July 18-- Three players shared medal honors today in the qualifying round for the 13th annual Garden State Women's Golf Association match-play championship at the Metuchen Golf and Country Club.

The Port of New York Authority announced another major expansion project for the New Jersey side of the harbor yesterday. Deputy Mayor Robert Price promptly denounced the move as "a rape of the city."
One of the most unusual "man-bites-dog" situations on Wall Street in recent years appeared yesterday to be working out--just the way its protagonists had predicted.

LONDON, July 18 (UPI)-- Brazil faces its sternest test in 12 years of World Soccer Cup competition tomorrow night when, confronted with the possibility of elimination from the tournament it has won twice in succession, it meets Portugal at Liverpool in a Group 3 match.

TOKYO, July 18--A leading Japanese legislator, just back from Peking, said today that the current political convulsion in Communist China is a struggle for leadership between a city elite and men with a peasant background.

Wall Street traders, reflecting on last week's dramatic news that the Kennecott Copper Corporation planned to buy Peabody Coal for $465.5-million, guessed yesterday that the Pittston Company would be the next coal company on the block.
The Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation announced yesterday in Toledo, Ohio, the appointment of Edward J. Detgen to the new post of vice president for national affairs.

GENEVA, July 18--Raul Prebisch, Secretary General of the United Nations Trade and Development Conference, complained today that the Scandinavian countries were failing to cooperate on a projected study of ocean shipping rates.

PHILADELPHIA, July 18 (AP)--Larry Jackson scored his fifth straight victory and second successive shutout as he pitched the Philadelphia Phillies to a 4-0 victory over Sandy Koufax and the Los Angeles Dodgers tonight.
WIESBADEN, Germany, July 18 (AP)--The United States won four more titles--two team and two individual--today for a total of 10 in the world shooting championships.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 18 --Brazil is to make her bid in Paris this week for the formation of an international financial consortium to underwrite a billion-dollar share of this country's National Development Program.
THE HAGUE, July 18--A legal attack by black African nations against South Africa's system of racial separation, apartheid, failed today in the International Court of Justice.

LONDON, July 18--The surprising denouement of the great South-West Africa case in the World Court today seemed to some observers to demonstrate what the Supreme Court of the United States made clear long, ago: A court that declines on procedural grounds to decide the merits of a case may really, underneath the stated reasons, ...

The Motion Picture Association of America, having recently faced the problem of profane language in. "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?", must now decide whether to give its seal of approval to the new Paramount film, "Alfie," in which an abortion figures prominently in the plot.

CHANNEL 13 concluded a two-part series on urban poverty last night. It was perhaps inevitable that the programs were long on problems and short on solutions. In that, they reflected the nation's dilemma.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI) --The House voted unanimously today to offer overseas servicemen upto 10 per cent interest on savings they deposit with the Government.
Retail sales of men's and boys' wear are expected to rise 5 per cent this year to more than $14-billion, according to Louis Rothschild, executive director of the Menswear Retailers of America.

WASHINGTON, July 18-- The nation's largest brokerage house said today it had maintained a "static" attitude toward investment in the common stock of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company since the Federal Communications Commission announced plans for its sweeping investigation of A.T.

Underwriters led by Glore Forgan, Wm. R. Staats, Inc., offered yesterday 800,000 shares of Wean Industries, Inc., common stock at $24 a share. The secondary offering is the first public sale of the company's stock.

A RARE bid that is sometimes misused is the jump shift by a passed hand. Such a bid obviously indicates a long, strong suit and a hand not far short of an opening bid, but it also suggests a partial fit with the opener's suit.
BRUSSELS, July 18--Belgium, with an eye on the booming American economy, has just sweetened the inducements for investment in the declining or underdeveloped areas of the country.
A. Lewis Spitzer, a lawyer with an office at 60 East 42d Street, died yesterday at the home of a brother, Henry, of 944 Park Avenue. He was 66 years old.
Shareholders of the Marine Capital Corporation have adopted a plan for the complete liquidation and dissolution of the company.
The Department of Parks has proposed that a 55-year-old Victorian building in Central Park be used as a Fire Department museum.
PARIS, July 18--Marc Chagall today made over to the French Republic 67 works that will ultimately be displayed in a museum to be built at Nice on the Riviera to his specifications.
ELIZABETH, N.J., July 18 --The airlines strike has proved a blessing to residents of the Elizabethport section of this city. And they don't care if it never ends.

A MORE tortured and circuitous road to fame than the one taken by John James Audubon would be impossible to imagine. PEKING, July 18--Communist China has formally offered its territory, as a rear area for the Vietnamese Communists in their struggle against the Americans.

Dr. George A. Roberts, 47 years old, has been elected president and a director of Teledyne, Inc., a Hawthorne, Calif., manufacturer of electronic instruments and components, it was announced yesterday.

"Chu Chem," the "Zen Buddhist-Hebrew musical" starring Menasha Skulnik and Molly Picon, will have its New York premiere at the George Abbott Theater on Jan. 4 instead of Nov. 29, it was announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 18 (AP)-- Boog Powell and Frank Robinson hit consecutive home runs to spark a four-run second inning against Juan Pizarro tonight as the Baltimore Orioles defeated the Chicago White Sox, 5-3.

TRENTON, July 18--Educators and industrialists gave warm endorsements today to a State Senate bill to establish a separate state Board of Higher Education with cabinet status. The aim is to raise the standards of college and graduate studies in New Jersey.
CHICAGO, July 18--The Illinois National Guard resumed patrols in the West Side Negro area tonight after a day of relative calm in the neighborhoods where rioting raged three nights last week.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 18--Two of baseball's most frequently used expressions, "hang in there" and "bench," figured prominently in the 6-4 victory the New York Yankees scored over the Minnesota Twins today before an unexpectedly large Monday afternoon crowd of 18,604.
ROME, July 18--Their names are just Alba and Francesca. They might well be more talked about than the clothes being shown this week by the Italian haute couture.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 18-- Sam Howe 3d, a once-a-year tournament player, knocked Lew Gerrard of New Zealand out of the 67th annual Pennsylvania lawn tennis championship with a surprising 6-4, 1-6, 6-4 first-round victory at the Merion Cricket Club today.
The strong showing of business in the first six months of this year was fortified yesterday by the heavy flow of favorable midyear earnings reports.

JACKIE CAIN and Roy Kral achieved a triumph of sorts last night at the Rheingold Central Park Music Festival. The singers, whose sly and swinging songs are usually tailored for intimate nightclubs, were fed as an appetizer to an audience of more than 4,000 in the Wollman Memorial Skating Rink.
After a firm start, prices drifted down yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI)--The Agriculture Department said today that world wheat production this year may reach a record 9.4 billion bushels on the basis of present indications.

Advertising firms have a legitimate part to play in election campaigns; but the cool professionalism of their operations in California politics is chilling. The fate of Ronald Reagan, conservative Republican candidate for Governor, has been entrusted to a concern which two years ago handled Nelson Rockefeller's primary campaign against Goldwater. And Democratic Gov. Edmund G. Brown has signed on with the firm that commercially promoted Barry Goldwater in 1964.

MADRID, July 18--On the official holiday today marking the 30th anniversary of the start of the Spanish Civil War, thousands of Spaniards filled highways and resorts, virtually elbowing the foreign tourists out of the way.

MOSCOW, July 18--The Soviet Union declined today to intervene with North Vietnam or to accept any responsibility for the fate of captured United States airmen under threat of being tried in Hanoi as war criminals.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) --Citing the increased demands of the Vietnam war, the Commerce Department raised by 3.5 per cent today the volume of aluminum that producers must reserve for defense and related orders during the fourth quarter.
WASHINGTON, July 18-- The airline labor negotiations bogged down again today as both sides failed in their tentative efforts to break a deadlock in the 11-day-old strike.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI) --The Soviet Union has agreed to a meeting of Russian and United States technicians this month to discuss the question of Russian fishing operations off American shores, particularly the West Coast.

Mrs. Warren Brandt of New York and Water Mill, L.I., and Mr. Jack Borgenicht of New York and Long Valley, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Berta Borgenicht, to Arnold D. Kerr, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Oszer Kierszkowski of Suwalki, Poland.

There is a nightclub comic in Las Vegas who does a routine in which he impersonates a mythical foreman of the LBJ Ranch showing a visitor around the place. At one point, in a cornpone accent, the foreman says, "This really is God's country around here."

WASHINGTON, July 18-- A panel of American diplomats, intellectuals, and military men called today for a concerted effort to modernize the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and to use it as a "foundation" on which to build closer Atlantic political and economic unity.

PHILADELPHIA, July 18 (AP)--Bishop Fred Pierce Corson, president of the World Methodist Council, said today that birth control pills should be restricted and subjected to the same controls as dangerous drugs.

CHICAGO, July 18--A Filipino nurse, sole survivor of the murder of eight student nurses last Thursday, spent more than two hours at the City Hall jail today waiting to view Richard F. Speek to see if she could identify him as the killer.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) --A 40-pound piece of stone fell from the West Front of the Capitol within the last few days, the House Speaker, John W. McCormack said today.
BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., July 18--Two skippers from the American Yacht Club of Rye, N.Y., sailed their cruising yachts to division victories today in the club's 35th annual race across Block Island Sound.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 18--United States fighter-bombers striking. North Vietnam have had an unusual level of success in recent days, a military spokesman said today.
CAPETOWN, July 18--Prime Minister Hendrik F. Verwoerd said tonight that the verdict of the International Court of Justice at The Hague represented "a major victory for South Africa."
WASHINGTON, July 18--A new program to provide legal services for 600,000 low-income residents of New York City will be established under $3.4-million grant from the Office of Economic Opportunity.
The wholesale commodity price index maintained on Friday the level it reached on Thursday, which was 113.3.

LONDON, July 18--A story of murky financial transactions and violence was recounted today at a preliminary court hearing on the death last month of the head of a British offshore pirate radio station.

Regulations proposed last Friday by the Federal Reserve Board to hold down the spiraling interest rates being paid for consumer savings accounts will have little effect on bank operations in New York, bankers surveyed yesterday suggested.
BINGHAM CANYON, Utah --The Kennecott Copper Corporation's $100-million expansion program at its Utah mine, mill and concentrating facility is rapidly nearing completion.
Miss Caroline Bayard Stockton and Ronald S. Rankin plan to marry in September.
New Yorkers who have been ignoring parking and jaywalking summonses will have two weeks to pay fines without additional penalties before a stiff police enforcement program begins.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) --President Johnson was told today that the Peace Corps expected to build 1,000 two-room schools abroad and to bring 500 foreign volunteers to this country by next June.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 18 (AP)--A man's foot, hanging to his leg by an inch-wide strip of muscle, tendon and skin, was reattached more than three weeks ago after surgery.

The United States Court of Appeals here upheld yesterday the conviction of a woman lawyer, her law clerk, and a man previously convicted of a narcotics violation, on charges of having conspired to bribe and intimidate a Government witness.
Prices on the London stock market took another sharp tumble yesterday, but some industrial issues began to recover near the close of trading.

UNITED NATTONS, N.Y., July 18--Friends of Sir Percy Spender at the United Nations were not surprised when he cast the vote that broke the 7-7 tie in the World Court on the South-West Africa case today. They know him as a man of strong convictions who is oblivious to ...

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 18--Delegates of African states reacted sharply today when they learned that the International Court of Justice had rejected their complaint against South Africa's administration of the mandated territory of South-West Africa.

Five voluntary hospitals, their affiliates and a union of nonmedical employes announced agreement yesterday on a wage increase. The settlement ended a week of erratic work stoppages that led to the partial closing of several hospitals in the city.
DUBLIN, July 18--The old Abbey Theater company opened an immaculate new theater here today, and looked back nostalgically at past controversies and glory and forward to new controversies and hopes.

That lofty glitter on the lower Manhattan skyline these days is not Superman. It is they American Telephone and Telegraph Company's familiar and just-regilded "Golden Boy" atop the company's headquarters at 195 Broadway.

TEL AVIV, July 18--The Government introduced a bill in the Knesset (Parliament) today that would fine factory owners, shopkeepers and artisans 1,000 Israeli pounds ($333) for working on the Sab bath or religious festivals.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., July 18-- Dr. and Mrs. Jacob Dranitzke have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joan Dranitzke, to Kenneth S. Grossman, son of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Grossman of New York and Westhampton Beach. A late fall wedding is planned.

ATHENS, July 18--Sypro Markenzinis, the 55-year-old chief of Greece's small Progressive party, announced today that he had sold his book, "Political History of Modern Greece," for a "minimum of $50,000" to Papyros, a Greek publishing concern.

Shearson, Hammill Co., member of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday the election of James M. Robertson as a vice president. Mr. Robertson continues as manager of the company's New York municipal bond underwriting division. He formerly was an assistant vice president.
PARIS July 18 (AP)--Michel Jazy, former holder of the world record for the mile, said today he would like to run against Jim Ryun, who bettered Jazy's mark in Berkeley, Calif., yesterday.
CLEVELAND, Tuesday, July 19--Rioting broke out last night in the all-Negro Hough area of Cleveland. A woman was shot and killed and four policemen were injured by bricks and bottles.

The Commonwealth Edison Company announced yesterday it had ordered from the General Electric Company a second nuclear generating unit for a planned power station near Cordova, Ill. Indicated cost of the new unit was $80-million.

GENEVA, July 18 (Reuters) --A review of the current market situation in selected commodities is to be prepared by a 28-nation committee of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development at a meeting here next fall.
Stock prices eased in quiet trading yesterday.
The General Reinsurance Company announced here yesterday the appointment of Walter J. Hildenbrand and William C. Clark as vice presidents.

Charles Masterson of Brooklyn, seeded first, defeated Charles F. Fix of Kearny, N.J. 6-1, 6-0, and reached the quarter-finals of the Eastern senior clay court tennis championships yesterday at the Seminole Club, Forest Hills, Queens.
CAIRO, July 18--The Government has charged members of the illegal Moslem Brotherhood with having planned a third attempt within a year to assassinate President Gamal Abdel Nasser.
A new controversy developed yesterday over the pace of the city school system's integration and reorganization efforts.

With Gemini 10 in orbit, astronauts Young and Collins have begun their complex series of experiments, Successful completion of their mission would represent another major step toward a manned landing on the moon.
LONDON, July 18 (Reuters) Rudolf Nureyev and Dame Margot Fonteyn will head the touring Royal Ballet Company troupe that will make a 16week visit to the United States next April, Sol Hurok said today.

There were a lot of little extras for the Mets as they took their second double-header in two days from the Houston Astros, 4-1 and 6-3, at Shea Stadium yesterday. The little extras proved that now and then things can't be all bad with the New York team.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., July 18 --Mr, and Mrs. Joseph M. Whitehead of Ridgewood and Dorset, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Holly Jane Whitehead, to Thomas Howard Chase. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Howard Chase of Ho-Ho-Kus. The wedding is planned for the fall.
HANKOE, Norway, July 18 (AP)--Ernest Fay of Houston won the Scandinavian Gold Cup yachting trophy today for the fifth time and the second straight year.
LONDON, July 18--Charles Creed, owner of one of the oldest fashion houses in London, died here last night. He was 56 years old.
The United Fruit Company, which has been actively diversifying its activities in the last few years, plans to add another food-service chain to its operations.
MONTREAL, July 18-- Nurses manned pails and other professionals performed menial tasks in 140 hospitals throughout the Province of Quebec today, as 32,500 nonmedical employes stayed off their jobs.
WASHINGTON, July 18--A backlash from the demand for greater auto safety threatens to decrease safety in the air, airline sources charged today.

Sales of luxury cooperative apartments in Manhattan during the first six months of this year rose by more than $4.9million over the total for the comparable period last year, according to a survey made by John W. Lonsdale, chairman of Pease Elliman, Inc.
DETROIT, July 18--Some of the Ford Motor Company's 1969 model automobiles will include collapsible front-end structures especially designed to reduce the force generated in a collision.

THE amazing ability of waterfowl populations to make a comeback after a siege of adversity is indicated by the latest Federal survey of their numbers in Canada, Alaska, North and South Dakota, western Minnesota and eastern Montana.
The International Court of Justice, often called the World Court, as established by the Charter of the United Nations as the organization's principal judicial organ in 1945.
WASHINGTON, July 18-- Luci Baines Johnson disclosed today that she and her husband-to-be's first home after their marriage would be an "old brick" duplex house in Austin, Tex.

LONDON, July 18 (AP)-- The American musical "Funny Girl," starring Barbra Streisand, grossed 225,000 ($630,000) during its 14-week London run, the theater management reported today. A spokesman said; "We played to a full house and maximum standing capacity for every performance Miss Streisand played."

WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI) --A former Polish diplomat now under death sentence at home has estimated that at least 38 of the 50 members of the Polish military mission in West Germany last year were actually intelligence agents.

BARRINGTON, Ill., July 18 (AP)--The defending champion Mrs. Barbara Fay White Boddie, shot a five-under-par 71 today to win the 18-hole qualifying medal in the Western amateur women's golf tournament.
NEW ORLEANS, July 18-- Vice President Humphrey said today that if he had to live in a city ghetto with rats nibbling on his children's toes, he might "lead a mighty good revolt" himself.

The New York Court of Appeals wound up its term the other day with a number of rulings that sharply contradicted the usual contention of enforcement officials that the courts are "handcuffing" the police and "coddling" criminals.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., July 18--The world chess champion, Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, drew with his countryman, Boris Spassky, the recent challenger for the title, in the first round of the Piatigorsky Cup Tournament last night at the Miramar Hotel here.
SEOUL, South Korea, July 18 --South Korea's ruling Democratic Republican party is engaged in what it calls a "quiet march forward" to the threshold of next year's presidential and assembly elections.

TORONTO, July 18 (Canadian Press)--George and Viola MacMillan, husband and wife mining team, pleaded not guilty today to two charges of fraud involving trading in the shares of Windfall Oils and Mines, Ltd.
LANSING, Mich., July 18 (UPI)--Unionized city employer closed down some city services and sharply curtailed others today as they defied a state law prohibiting strikes by public employes.
Gruen Industries, Inc., a watch manufacturer, announced here yesterday the election as directors of Frederick Peyser Jr., J. Bernard Quigley and Fred A. Robinson.
WATERFORD, Conn., July 19 "Exult each patriot heard," the prologue begins, "this night is shewn a piece which we may fairly call our own."
WASHINGTON, July 19 Following is the transcript of President Johnson's news conference today on fiscal affairs:

At the head of the stretch, Kenny Knapp found space not much, but enough to fit a horse next to the rail. His mount, Imam, responded and went on to score by a neck over Hurricane Tim in a driving finish at Aqueduct yesterday before a crowd of 26,192. The event was the feature race, a $10,000 affair on the turf course over a mile and a sixteenth.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 19 At least 150 people of rightwing and conservative leanings, including one former Premier, have been arrested in Syria in the last two days, according to reliable information from Damascus.
The impasse between the pressmen's union and the World Journal Tribune, Inc., deepened yesterday and the contract negotiations were recessed until next Monday morning.

WASHINGTON, July 19 A prominent economist suggested today that the Federal Communications Commission take into account the declared objectives of national economic policy in its current investigation of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) The Agency for International Development said today that the resignation of Wilbur D. Bacon, head of its $400-million commercial import program in Vietnam, had been accepted, effective Oct. 1.

PARIS We may not know until the last minute whether, in threatening the trial and execution of American airmen as war criminals, Hanoi means what it says or is simply trying to stave off further U.S. action against North Vietnam. The Czechoslovak news agency, often used by Hanoi to convey warnings, has predicted that trials would start either today (July 20) or Aug. 4.

A resolution enabling participants in the state's medical assistance program to seek medical services from any qualified institution, agency or physician was adopted last night by the State Board of Social Welfare.

Mr. and Mrs. Alfred T. Sforza of 360 East 72d Street have made known the engagement of Mrs. Sforza's daughter, Miss Jonne Elizabeth Wenzel, to Frederick Martin Sevekow Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Sevekow of Freeport, L.I.
WARREN, R.I, July 19 The $200,000 automated pusher tug Mohawk, designed to run without an engine-room crew or a cook, was launched here today with a Catholic priest as a passenger.
Several thousand motorists, many of them clutching thick bundles of frayed green parking tickets, turned up at Traffic Courts throughout the city yesterday.
Maimonides Hospital in Brooklyn will raise its room rates for patients $8 a day beginning Aug. 1. It thus becomes the first hospital to order a rate increase following Monday's union wage settlement.
HOUSTON, July 19 (AP) The Houston Astros sold Jim Gentile, the first baseman, to the Cleveland Indians today for Tony Curry, an outfielder, and cash.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 19 The Rev. Ian Paisley, moderator of the Free Presbyterian Church of Ulster, has until 1 P.M. tomorrow to sign a bond bail or go to jail for three months.
Representative Adam Clayton Powell appeared in court here yesterday for the first time in response to a $160,000 judgment he owes a Harlem widow he defamed more than six years ago.
PAPEETE, Tahiti, July 19 (Reuters) France exploded a nuclear bomb dropped from a plane for the first time at dawn today.

HOUSTON, July 19 "Satellites" that the Gemini 10 astronauts saw on their first orbit of the earth yesterday were pieces of an exploded Saturn Apollo rocket, the Defense Department said this afternoon.
Stocks closed lower in more active trading; volume, 5.96million shares.

Senator Robert F. Kennedy reiterated yesterday that he was not now supporting anyone for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination. He added in a telephone interview that he was undecided what position he would take before the Democratic nominating convention opened on Sept. 6.

VUNGTAU, South Vietnam, July 19--The pacification program in South Vietnam is running into new difficulties even before the men who are to do the pacifying reach the hamlets in the Communist-dominated countryside.
WASHINGTON, July 19 Housing starts and new orders for durable goods both declined slightly in June, the Commerce Department reported today.

WHEN selecting fresh peaches, the fruit should be fairly firm, free of bruises, have fresh unwrinkled skin and a background of yellow color. A blush or redness is not always a sign of ripeness. Peach pie a la mode is a favorite way to enjoy the seasonal fruit. Here is a recipe for the pie.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) Norris E. Phillips, president of the Ceramic Tile Manufacturers of the United States charged today Japanese wall tile was being dumped in this country at 35 to 45 per cent below prices in the Japanese home market. He said it was in a systematic effort to take over the United States market for ceramic tile.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., July 19 Bert Nevins, a press agent who publicized schoolmates for cash when he was 16 and later established the Mrs. America contest and persuaded the Dwight D. Eisenhowers to dunk doughnuts at a Presidential campaign reception, died today at his home. She was 56 years old and had moved here from New York in 1956.

Money is tight. The stock market is in the doldrums. The latest batch of statistics confirms that business activity has slowed down and, if some forecasters are right, will slide right into recession.
GREENWICH, Conn., July 19 Odd Hultgreen, president of Comac Engineering, Inc. here, died today at his home, 79 West Brother Drive. He was 60 years old.

ULAN BATOR, Mongolia, July 18 Communist China seems at least for the time being, to have written off Mongolia as a hopeless case in the Chinese-Soviet dispute. How far the cooling of China toward the Mongolians has gone was demonstrated last week when Ulan Bator suffered the worst flood in Mongolian history.

Konrad Heiden, a German refugee who devoted much of his life to a remorseless journalistic pursuit of Adolf Hitler and the Nazi party, died Monday at Beth Abraham Hospital, the Bronx, after a long illness. He was 64 years old.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., July 19 (AP) Frank Sinatra and Mia Farrow, 21-year-old actress, were married today in a ceremony attended by a few friends.
MONTEREY, Calif., July 19 (AP) Jerry Lewis, his secretary and three men escaped injury today when Mr. Lewis's $350,000 cabin cruiser sprang a leak and broke up on the rocky Monterey coast.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Wednesday, July 20 A 35year-old American astronaut stuck his head and shoulders out of the cabin of the high-orbiting Gemini 10 yesterday afternoon to photograph the view from 245 miles out in space.

While a manned and unmanned satellite had previously been joined together in space, never before yesterday had the men in such a composite vehicle used the additional rocket power made available by the docking maneuver for significant, useful work. In effect, Astronauts Young and Collins made Gemini 10 a "trailer in space" when they employed the Agena 10 rocket to send the linked vehicles into the highest orbit yet traversed by man.
HOUSTON, July 19 Space officials were still unable tonight to determine why Gemini 10 had used twice as much fuel in its first day of flight as had been expected.
CHATTANOOGA, July 19 (AP) Two seeded players were defeated today in second-round play of the national boys' and girls' l4 and 12-year-and-under tennis championships.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., July 19 A procession of somberlooking chess players from around the world filed past rows of swaying palm trees here this morning, paused to sign some autographs for waiting admirers, and then entered a small auditorium to begin the day's competition.
WIESBADEN, Germany, July 19 (AP)-Ken Jones of the Lackland Air Force Base, San Antonio, Tex., shot a perfect 100 and won the individual trap shooting title in the world shooting championships.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, July 19 (Reuters) The American-owned yawl Carina arrived yesterday to become the winning Class B craft in the 3,500mile Bermuda-to-Denmark yacht race.
KANSAS CITY, Kan., July 19 Dr. Sam E. Roberts, a nose and throat specialist, died of a heart attack today in his home. He was 78 years old.
"Born Free" at the Coronet and Loew's State Theaters.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 113.8 on Monday from 113.3 on Friday.
WASHINGTON, July 19 The Johnson Administration has given its support to a Hudson River bill that would provide only voluntary protection against construction of Federal facilities in the valley.
In a major step to expand trade with Japan and the Far East, the Port of New York Authority will open a trade development office in Tokyo this fall.
NEW HAVEN, July 18 Armed with motion pictures and brochures, a dozen state police officers are covering Connecticut in a new campaign against sexual molestation of children.

BERKELEY HEIGHTS, N.J., July 19 An explosion of undetermined origin rocked the Berkeley Chemical Company plant on Summit Avenue early today, blowing out the front and sides of a distillation building and windows in adjacent buildings. No one was hurt.
WHAT keeps "Show Boat" afloat is its songs. The dialogue is a bit warped, the daring subjects are a bit weather-worn, but those songs! Oh, Jerome Kern, thou art mighty yet.
A proposed $153-million merger of the United Artists Corporation, a major film company, into the Consolidated Foods Corporation was announced yesterday.

Leaders in government, finance, business and industry attended the funeral yesterday of Mrs. Austin J. Tobin, wife of the executive director of the Port of New York Authority. About 500 people filled the Roman Catholic Church of St Vincent Ferrer, 869 Lexington Avenue, at 66th Street, for the requiem mass. The mass was celebrated by the Very Rev. R. J. McCann, prior and pastor of the church. The Rev. Joseph Allen acted as deacon.

LONDON, July 19 Prime Minister Wilson returned emptyhanded today from talks in Moscow on the Vietnam war and immediately began putting together a package of measures to deal with Britain's economic crisis.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 19 Charles Pasarell of Puerto Rico, the defending titleholder, just managed to get home ahead of a heavy downpour and defeat Lenny Schloss, after having yielded a set to the youthful Baltimore newcomer in the Pennsylvania lawn tennis championship at the Merion Cricket Club today. The scores were 6-3, 5-7, 6-1.
WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate rejected an amendment today to authorize foreign assistance for two years instead of one:
DULUTH, Minn., July 19 (AP) Some Duluth city employes started a sitdown strike today in a wage dispute with the City Council, and first results were spotty.
AT SHEFFIELD Yorkshire beat Nottinghamshire by 229 runs. Yorkshire 234 for nine wickets (65 overs) and 243 for tour declared; Nottinghamshire 163 for eight (65 overs) and 85, Yorkshire 12 points.

WASHINGTON, July 19 Peking's statement yesterday that the vast territory of Communist China "is the rear area of the Vietnamese people" is believed by officials here to have no immediate bearing on the war.

City Councilman Woody Kingman, Republican of Manhattan, called on the Lindsay Administration last night to keep Pier 42 at the foot of Morton Street in Greenwich Village from being turned "into another honky-tonk tourist attraction."
TENAFLY, N. J., July 19--Miss Ellen Jarrett McFadden and Marvin Lee Todd plan to marry in October.
WASHINGTON, July 19 President Johnson moved today to cut through bureaucratic procedure that has delayed more hydrant showers, portable swimming pools and pool lighting for the capital's youngsters.
WASHINGTON, July 19 The Senate rejected today a bipartisan move to authorize the foreign aid program for two years instead of the single year urged by its Foreign Relations Committee.

The London Stock Exchange made a partial recovery yesterday from its recent slump, although traders continued to be apprehensive about additional deflationary measures that the Government has said would be announced today.
ST. LOUIS, July 19 (AP) Charlie Smith singled home Bob Tolan in the 12th inning, tonight, giving the St. Louis Cardinals a 10-9 victory over the Atlanta Braves.
A new Federal Reserve Board regulation aimed at holding down the interest rates that commercial banks pay for fixedmaturity time deposits appeared yesterday to have backfired, at least partially.
ALBANY, July 19 The Republican legislative campaign organization hired a drama coach today to teach candidates how to introduce themselves, shake hands, stand and sit.

BONN, July 19 The West German Supreme Court ruled today that political parties would henceforth receive no subsidies from the Federal, Government. Until the decision, political parties in the Bundestag, the lower house of the Parliament, could demand support from public funds.

BARRINGTON, Ill., July 19 (AP) The former national amateur champion, Jean Ashley of Colorado Springs, was upset and eight matches went the distance in the first round of the 66th Western women's amateur golf tournament today.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) A report today that housing starts had fallen to the lowest level since the recession of early 1961 has caused the nation's home builders to call an emergency meeting for July 27 to discuss depressed housing conditions and to lobby on Capitol Hill for more mortgage money.
BRUSSELS, July 19 (Reuters) The European Common Market's executive commission has recommended anti-inflationary measures to its member countries, sources disclosed here today.
The First National City Bank has announced here the appointment of Robert D. Arnold and Walter Gless as vice presidents.

The R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, the leader of the tobacco industry, turned in record sales and earnings for the three months ended June 30, according to the midyear report issued yesterday by A. H. Galloway, president.

WASHINGTON, July 19 Great political and military events have a way of starting in quiet ways with small commitments that are scarcely noticed in the beginning. America's Cuban and Vietnamese policies illustrate the point, and we may be on the verge of slipping into another commitment this time against the will and intention of the Administration.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (UPI) Representative Wayne L. Hays, aroused over plans of some protesters of the Vietnam war to picket the wedding of Luci Baines Johnson, said today he would introduce a bill to prohibit any demonstration.

AKRON, Ohia, July 19 Billy Casper is one golfer here who hopes for strong winds. If they blow at eight miles an hour or more during the Professional Golfers Association championship that starts on Thursday, Casper will be happy.

SEOUL, South Korea, July 19 Twenty youths intruded into the Japanese Embassy in Seoul today to protest Japan's decision to admit three North Korean technicians prior to the export of plant facilities to North Korea.
