WQXR announced yesterday that it will carry live this fall the weekly concerts of the New York Philharmonic. It also said that it will carry on FM (frequency modulation) only the Saturday afternoon broadcasts of the Metropolitan Opera.

TOKYO, July 19 (AP) Defense Minister Lin Piao's daily newspaper, Chiefang Chun Pao, declared today that Communist China was "ready at any time to join the Vietnamese people in wiping out U.S. aggressors."

"AROUND THE WORLD UNDER THE SEA," an adventure in color, directed and produced by Andrew Marton for Ivan Tors Productions and Metro-GoldwynMayer release, at neighborhood theaters. Lloyd Bridges, David McCallum, Shirley Eaton and Brian Kelly have leading roles.

A demand by the Operating Engineers Union, Local 14, for higher wage and benefit improvements than other con struction workers have received is threatening to halt $1.1-billion in construction in the city.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, July 19 President Joaquin Balague confirmed last night that he had appointed former Provisional President Hector Garcia Godoy to be the Domincan Ambassador in Washington.

The stock market was staggered early yesterday by reports that the North Vietnamese would bring to trial captured American pilots as war criminals. Prices recovered about half their losses by the close, but at the end of the day losses of a point or more were common.

Mrs. Mildred Pender Clark, founder and editor of a pharmaceutical guide, "Unlisted Drugs," and wife of Louis J. Clark, a freelance writer, died Monday at James Ewing Hospital, 1250 First Avenue, after a long illness. She was 56 years old and lived at 95 Mezzine Drive, Cresskill, N.J.
Charles Richard Ferlin, a founder of the Overseas Press Club, died at Bellevue Hospital last Wednesday. He was 70 years old and lived at 158 West 58th Street.
WASHINGTON, July 19--President Johnson signed today a package of four bills designed to give citizens more rights in civil litigation against the Government.
ENGLEWOOD, N.J., July 19 Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Cooper have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janet Cooper, to Philip G. Futterman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Futterman of New York.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 19 (UPI) Clashes between proSukarno and anti-Communist youths in the Central Java city of Jogjakarta were reported today to have led to the hospitalization of at least 35 high school students.
The New York Obstetrical Society has come out in support of liberalization of New York State's 84-year-old abortion law, which permits abortions only to preserve the pregnant woman's life.

ATTLEBORO, Mass, July 19 Mr. and Mrs. Frederick V. Murphy Jr. of Attleboro and Falmouth have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Suzanne Virginia Murphy, to Allen Richard Rule, son of Mr. and Mrs. Elmer A. Rule of Columbus, Ohio.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) A compromise plan to spend more than $4.2-billion on the civilian space program in the fiscal year that started July 1 including a speed-up of unmanned probes of Mars was reached by a Senate-House conference committee today.

GREAT RIVER, L.I, July 19 Wayne Dias of the Babylon Yacht Club, won three straight races today, but the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's junior championship went to Chris Andon of the Westhampton Yacht Squadron.

WEST NEWTON, Mass., July 19 Miss Nancy Diane Kaplan's engagement to Steven S. Fischman has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Kaplan. Her fiance is the son of Mrs. Jack Lazarus of Riverdale, the Bronx, New York, and the late Benjamin Fischman.
WASHINGTON, July 19 The striking machinists' union decided today to break off negotiations tomorrow and to take a vote on the industry's best offer for settling a 12-day-old airline strike.

ROME, July 19 When it comes to showing off a very long stretch of leg, the British are the bravest of them all. In this city of wild eye make-up and eccentric, wired hairdos, most pretty Romans, and even adventurous adoles cents, don't wear the miniskirt. The Italian haute couture designers, who are showing their winter collections this week, are not a timid bunch, but they choose to show only the kneecaps.
There was a sharp expansion in industrial waterside plant locations in the second quarter of 1966, Braxton B. Carr, president of the American Waterways Operators, Inc., reported yesterday.
Severe thunderstorms lashed the city, its suburbs, and parts of New York State, New Jersey and Connecticut late yesterday.
New York at San Francisco Fisher (6-9) vs. Marichall (15-4).
The Aluminum Company of America reported yesterday that it had set records in the second quarter for sales, net income, production and shipments.

THE HAGUE, July 19 Communist China's senior diplomat here left the country today under an expulsion order as Dutch authorities investigated the mysterious death of a visiting Chi nese engineer who had been abducted from a hospital.

HOUSTON, July 19 (AP) Dick Farrell walloped a threerun homer and pitched the Houston Astros to an 8-2 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies tonight in the first game played over a surface completely covered with artificial grass.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, July 19 (UPI) Tina of the United States was reported to be leading the Six-Ton Cup yacht race today before the last leg of 40 miles.

WASHINGTON, July 19 Two North Vietnamese diplomats were reported today to have declared that captured American pilots would be tried as war criminals. At the same time, President Ho Chi Minh hinted that the prisoners would not be executed.

PHILADELPHIA, July 19 Eugene Buffington Simonin, the retired board chairman of C.F. Simonin Sons, Inc., a vegetableoil refining concern, died here yesterday. He was 72 years old and lived in Chestnut Hill.

ROSLYN HEIGHTS, L.I., July 19 Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Rosenfeld have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mimi Arlen Rosenfeld, to Randy Stephen Harris, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Harris of New York.
WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) The Senate ratified today, 87 to 0, two protocols aimed at strengthening enforcement of the Northwest Atlantic Fisheries Treaty.
The astronauts piloting Gemini 10 were confronted yesterday by two potential radiation hazards: a natural one in the South Atlantic and a manmade one in the South Pacific. Neither proved serious.

WASHINGTON, July 19 Julius Klein, an interna tional public relations man addicted to name-dropping, a major general in the Army reserve with seven decorations, a Taft Republican with bipartisan connections, was known simply as "Dutch" Klein when he was a star re porter for Hearst's ...

WASHINGTON, July 19 Administration officials were surprised and saddened by South Africa's victory yesterday in the International Court of Justice, but they were also relieved by the delay of a dreaded diplomatic crisis.

DENVER, July 19 Mrs. and Mrs. Robert Wasem of Denver, formerly of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marjorie Wasem, to G. Douglas Burck of Greenwich, Conn. He is the son of Mrs. Barbara Douglas Dixon of Cedar Rapids, Iowa, and Charlevoix, Mich., and the late Gail J. Burck of Pasadena, Calif.

The first architectural competition held by the Parks Department since 1907, and the second since Central Park itself was designed as the result of a competition in 1858, has proved one thing conclusively: You can't beat the original architects, Olmstead and Vaux.
CLEVELAND, July 19 (AP) A pinch-hit sacrifice fly by Smoky Burgess in the ninth inning lifted the Chicago White Sox to a 5-4 victory over the Cleveland Indians tonight.
John J. Villaire, a shipbuilder for nearly half a century, died Monday at his home, 432 85th Street, Brooklyn. He was 87 years old.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 19 Jimmy Fisher of the host club defeated Dick Siderowf of Birchwood on the first hole of a sudden-death playoff today to win the 14th annual Ike golf championship with a five-under-par 211 at the Wykagyl Country Club today.
A major campaign to increase its sales of women's wear, both in dollars and in percentage of total store volume, has been started by Bond Stores, Inc.

WASHINGTON, July 19--President Johnson stepped up pressure on Congress today to keep expenditures within limits proposed by his Administration. He still withheld, however, the ultimate threat--a tax increase proposal.
JAMESBURG, N.J., July 19 Warren W. Wilentz, a former Middlesex County prosecutor, is the choice of top New Jersey Democrats to oppose Republican Senator Clifford Case in November.

GENEVA, July 19 The United States warned the Soviet Union today against any demand for a ban on consultations on nuclear defense among Western nations as part of the projected treaty to halt the spread of atomic weapons.

STANTON, Del., July 19 (AP) Feature Picture, never better than seventh in nine previous starts in two years, and Restless Cloud won the first two races today to create a $1,924,60 daily double at Delaware Park. It was the largest double of the meeting.
WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) Jim Perry pitched a twohitter and drove in two runs as the Minnesota Twins whipped the Washington Senators, 4-0, tonight to sweep a doubleheader.
OCEANPORT, N. J., July 19 (UPI)--Chavalon broke clear in the stretch at Monmouth Park today to win the $6,000 feature race by two lengths.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, July 19 The last boats were arriving in Copenhagen today in the race from Bermuda after having had fair winds all the way, leading to an unusually fast crossing of the Atlantic.
BLIND SPOT, by Joseph Harrington (Lippincott, $3.95). Detective story.
A small, lightweight, portable refreshment stand designed by a 29-year-old architect was declared the winner yesterday in a contest sponsored by the Parks Department.
The Coast Guard yesterday adjourned a hearing into charges that a docking pilot contributed negligently to a collision off Staten Island last month that cost the lives of 33 seamen.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, July 20 An American jet fighter was shot down by a Communist MIG over North Vietnam yesterday and two other United States planes were shot down by antiaircraft fire, a military spokesman said today.

CAMLO, South Vietnam, July 19 A detachment of 70 United States Marines was badly battered yesterday when hundreds of North Vietnamese soldiers, blowing bugles and whistles, attacked them just south of the North Vietnamese border.
The presidents of two companies recently acquired by the Liggett Myers Tobacco Company were elected yesterday to the board of the producer of Chesterfield, L, Lark and Oasis cigarettes.
CHICAGO, July 19 (AP) The Chicago North Western Railway said today its consolidated net income of $14,622,776 for the first half of 1966 was the highest of any January-June period in its history.
Several high appointments were announced yesterday in advertising and public relations.
Continuing reports that North Vietnam might bring to trial American flyers as war criminals tended to strengthen prices of some leading world commodities in futures trading yesterday.

STONINGTON, Conn., July 19 Mr. and Mrs. Harrison Leach Jewett have announced the engagement of Mrs. Jewett's daughter, Miss Katharine Metcalf Chambers, to Lieut. Oren Boyd Cooke, U.S.N.R., son of Mr. and Mrs. James William Cooke of Maiden, N. C.
WASHINGTON, July 19 Following are the parties involved, the issues in dispute, and a brief summary of the effects of the airline strike:
LONDON, July 19 (Reuters) Portugal virtually eliminated today from the World Cup championships one of soccer's most powerful teams, Brazil.

A right-wing group has mounted a personal attack, through a telephone recording, on Algernon D. Black, chairman of the new civilian-dominated police review board, calling him a "Communist sympathizer."
The decision of the International Court of Justice to throw out the South-West Africa case will baffle laymen and arouse fierce debate among international lawyers.

WASHINGTON, July 19 Julius Klein testified today that he urged Senator Thomas J. Dodd to intercede on his behalf with German officials in 1964 in an attempt to salvage his reputation and save a $150,000a-year public relations contract.

JERUSALEM, (Israeli Sector), July 19 (AP) The Ford Motor Company is proceeding with plans to establish a car assembly plant in Israel, Shual Lipshitz, director of Frd's Israeli distributor, the Palestine Automobile Corporation, confirmed this week.
NATIONAL division championship races at Con nellsville, Pa., and Area One championship events at Thompson, Conn., scheduled for Saturday and Sunday, have attracted a total of 400 sports cars.
At about 3:45 yesterday afternoon, 20 musicians suddenly arrived at 99th Street between Park and Madison Avenues.

NEW ORLEANS, July 19 Count and Countess L. Longer de la Gueronniere of New Orleans and Bedminster, N.J., have announced the engagement of the Count's daughter, Miss Sylvie-Anne de la Gueronniere to Thomas Dee Waite. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Dewitt Monroe Waite of Adams, N.Y.
The Loew's Building at 1540 Broadway on the east side of Times Square which has been seeking tenants for the first time in 40 years, is approaching full occupancy again.

Last April, Leonard Marks, director of the United States Information Agency, came to New York to talk informally with a somewhat exclusive group in the advertising world--the public relations executives of leading agencies.

THE Mayfair Bridge Club, at 119 West 57th Street, one of the oldest and bestknown clubs in New York City, changed hands last week. The club is almost as old as contract bridge itself, and for more than a quarter of a century has been managed by one of the game's great personalities, Harry Fishbein.
A proposal for the creation of six new superliner berths in the waterfront area above 42d Street has been made to Mayor Lindsay by the Port of New York Authority.

WASHINGTON, July 19 Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach today proferred a two-step compromise to opponents of the controversial open housing section of the Administration's civil rights bill, which is expected to come to a crucial debate in the House next Monday.
BRASILIA, July 19--President Humberto Castelo Branco promised Brazil a new constitution today that would provide increased executive power for future presidents.
NEW DELHI, July 19 Prime Minister Indira Gandhi confirmed today that she had moved closer to the Soviet view on how to end the war in Vietnam.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 19 Mr. and Mrs. Herbert M. Gorfinkle have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Evelyn Gorfinkle, to Howard Schneider, son of Mrs. Abraham Schneider of Jamaica Estates, Queens, and the late Mr. Schneider.

THE PRESIDENT Received credentials from the new Ambassador of Zambia; met with National Security Council; briefed reporters on talks with the chairman and ranking Republican members of House and Senate Appropriations Committees to ask them to stay within the Administration money requests; lunched with Secretary of State Rusk and Defense Secretary McNamara; met with Democratic Congressional leaders; saw A.F.L.C.I.O. President George Meany; held news conference.
The spot rate on the British pound closed unchanged yesterday at $2.7873 in active trading on foreign-exchange markets here.
Rayonier, Inc., a chemical cellulose producer, announced here yesterday the election as a director of William R. Bowdoin, vice chairman of the Trust Company of Atlanta, Ga.
LANSING, Mich., July 19 (AP) Striking municipal employes asked Gov. George Romney for help today in settling their two-day dispute with the city of Lansing.
The Public Service Electric and Gas Company announced yesterday the election of Edward R. Eberle as executive vice president, effective Sept. 1.

LONDON SHOW IS DUE IN NEW YORK OCT. 24 Patricia Routledge and Peter Bayliss have been signed to repeat on Broadway the roles they created in the London production of "How's the World Treating You?" The attraction will open here Oct. 24 at the Music Box. Elaine Perry and Charles Hollerith Jr. are the producers.
A cheerful United Artists executive picked up his telephone yesterday afternoon and asked: "So what do you want? Seven cases of sardines?"
CHICAGO, July 19 Richard F. Speck, suspected of slaying eight student nurses last Thursday, was confronted today by the lone survivor of the mass murder.
WASHINGTON, July 19 (UPI) Mrs. Jenny Webb Ruark, former wife of Robert Ruark, the late columnist and novelist, died last night at the age of 49.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday bankers' outstanding dollar acceptances in the United States on June 30 totaled $3.42-billion, up $2-million over the level at the end of May. The new total is $64-million higher than that of June, 1965.
LONDON, July 19--Peter A. Goudie, a British newspaperman who founded the United States Army newspaper Stars and Stripes, died today at his home near Aberdeen, Scotland. He was 87 years old.
A State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that the stagehands union could not limit its membership to relatives.

CHICAGO, July 19 (UPI) Don Pavletich's homer on Ferguson Jenkins's first pitch to him with two out in the 18th inning gave the Cincinnati Reds a 3-2 victory over the Chicago Cubs today in the longest game of the major league season.

Paperboard production rose 3.6 per cent with 379,400 tons in the week ended July 16, from 366,100 in the corresponding 1965 week, it was reported by the Paperboard Group of the American Paper Institute yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) Maj. Gen. William Richard Schmidt, World War II commander of the 76th Division, died yesterday at Walter Reed General Hospital of a heart attack. He was 76 years old.

Geraldine Page and Anthony Quayle have joined Peter Ustinov in starring roles in "Barefoot in Athens," which the National Broadcasting Company will televise next season. The Maxwell Anderson play will open the "Hallmark Hall of Fame's" 16th season.

SINCE Yogi Berra left the Yankees, they have not had a resident, universally acknowledged movie critic. Now Pedro Ramos, the Cuban who fell in love with cowboy pictures and cowboy paraphernalia at an early age, is making a strong bid for that vacant position.
WASHINGTON, July 18--After three months of pessimism and two weeks of optimism about the war in Vietnam, the Johnson Administration now insists that it never indulges in anything but realism.

BONN, July 19 West Germany's Social Democrats, who emerged as the strongest party in North Rhine-Westphalia after an upset victory in last week's state election, apparently will be bypassed in the formation of a new government.
WHEN a wild animal gains a certain degree of fame or notoriety for one reason or another, such as for unusually large size, or great age, intelligence or ferocity, someone is quick to name it.

LOWVILLE, N. Y., July 19 In the pre-dawn gloom today, a series of thunderclaps woke the farmers of Lewis County. The skies opened, and for the first time in a month this droughtstricken area felt a drenching rain.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, July 20 (AP) A leading South Vietnamese official called today for the withdrawal of guerrillas and regular troops to North Vietnam, to be followed by negotiations for the reunification of Vietnam.
Forty Negro tenants moved early yesterday morning from two Brooklyn apartment houses after a series of violent outbursts between Negroes and Puerto Ricans in the racially tense Brownsville section.
WASHINGTON, July 19 The $1.75-billion House bill to continue the antipoverty program was delayed again today partly because Representative Adam Clayton Powell, Manhattan Democrat, was absent.

Edward R. Gay, who retired two years ago as vice chairman of the board of the St. Regis Paper Company, died of a stroke Monday night in his home on Long Meadow Road, Tuxedo; N.Y. He was 67 years old and also lived at 47 East 87th Street.

Max Newman of 320 East 42d Street, New York County commander of the United SpanishAmerican War Veterans for 10 years, died Monday night in the Veterans Administration Hospital in Manhattan. His age was 89.
Mayor Lindsay pacified a volatile crowd of 1,000 Negro and Puerto Rican demonstrators in Brooklyn yesterday by walking unescorted through their midst as they shouted for an end to segregated schools.
DAYTON, Ohio, July 19 (AP) Unionized city employes struck for higher wages today in defiance of a court order, stopping all but the most essential city services.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., July 19 Mr. and Mrs. George Edward Garland have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lois Ledwith Garland, to Willis Garson Ryckman 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ryckman Jr. of Charlottesville, Va.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange fell shorply following reports that Hanoi would place captured American pilots on trial as war criminals.
Mr. and Mrs. Marcus Walter have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Emily Walter, to Robert Mikulewicz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fabian Michaels of Closter, N.J.
The Consolidated Edison Company of New York raised nearly $50-million through an offering yesterday of preferred stock priced to yield 5.75 per cent.

When a Government employe stands up against the whole weight of the bureaucratic structure above him to defend a principle, he demonstrates true courage. And when his persistence ultimately compels his superiors to reverse a blind and self-serving ruling, he has won a victory for us all. Such men help preserve American liberty.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 19 The leadership of the Lutheran World Federation disclosed today that the East German Government had barred the federation from holding its fifth international assembly in Weimar in 1969.
The Federal Reserve Board has been generally credited with, or attacked for, the tight-money warfare on the inflation front.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 19 Bob Stieglitz of the American Yacht Club, one of the topflight helmsmen in the 210 Class, sailed Three Belles adroitly from a poor start today, finished first around a 12-mile triangle and then had all his good work ruined by misfortune.

The Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation announced here yesterday it had achieved record earnings in the second quarter for the 15th consecutive three-month period. This produced a high in profits for the first half.

All evidence of cancer has disappeared at least temporarily-from one of four pa tients who underwent an expemental tumor exchange at Roswell Park Memorial Institute in Buffalo, an institute spokesman said yesterday.

ALBANY, July 19 The State A.F.L. C.I.O. charged today that some railroads were violating provisions of the recent partial repeal of the state's Full Crew Law. It asked Governor Rockefeller to intervene.
WASHINGTON, July 19 The essence of the argument over American pilots held captive by North Vietnam is whether they are prisoners of war In the usual sense or "war criminals."

CHICAGO, July 19--City officials expressed concern today that an apparent alliance between civil rights organizations and youth gangs on the West Side was giving the gangs the prominence and importance they seek for basically criminal ends.

George Backer, politician, publisher, playwright and many other things in his 63 years, has written a first novel. It deals with the speculative fever of the nineteen-twenties and focuses on the character of a financier modeled on James Forrestal.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (UPI) The House Republican leader, Representative Gerald R. Ford of Michigan, accused Vice President Humphrey today of making "incredibly irresponsible" remarks about racial violence.

The Community Service Society of New York announced yesterday that Thatcher M. Brown Jr. would head its $2million fund appeal beginning in October. Mr. Brown is a managing partner in the investment banking firm of G. H. Walker Co.

BALTIMORE, July 19 (UPI) Frank Robinson drove in five runs with two homers tonight and paced a 19-hit attack that gave the Baltimore Orioles a 13-3 victory over the Detroit Tigers. The victory increased Baltimore's league lead over Detroit to 9 1-2 games.

CLEVELAND, July 19 A Negro man was killed tonight as sporadic street violence surged through a rundown neighborhood on this city's East Side for the second straight day. At least 21 persons were injured.

Ezra Parmalee Prentice, who served as Republican State Committee chairman of New York in 1910 and 1911 after Theodore Roosevelt ousted the party's Old Guard, died Monday at Craig House in Beacon, N.Y., after a long illness. He was 88 years old and lived at 200 East 66th Street.
New York City will open an office in Washington today to keep the Federal Government informed about what the city needs in continuing Federal aid. The emphasis will be on money.

The arrest of Richard F. Speck for the slaying of eight student nurses last week in Chicago has raised a number of issues usually associated with sensational crimes: the propriety of pretrial publicity, the effects of Supreme Court rulings on the rights of suspects, and the implications of a pos sible insanity defense by Speck.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 19 The 36 members of the African bloc met today to plan their next move in their struggle to wrest South-West Africa from the grip of South Africa and apartheid.
WASHINGTON, July 19 The United States, in a cautious diplomatic overture toward closer relations with Mongolia, offered emergency relief assistance today to her flood victims.
WASHINGTON, July 19 The total flow of aid to the less developed countries, public and private, reached a record figure of $10.98-billion last year, up about $1-billion from 1964.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 19 There was much speculation today among political figures and businessmen here about whether South Africa was now in a position to incorporate South-West Africa's administration into that of the republic. The step would amount to annexation.

The Canada Dry Corporation' earnings for the three months to June 30, its first fiscal quarter, will be "slightly lower" than the $746,000, or 29 cents a share, reported in the similar period last year, Roy W. Moore Jr., president, said yesterday.

The American Electric Power Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday record earnings for the six and 12 months ended June 30 and for June. Donald C. Cook, president, put net income for 12 months at $83,573,000, equal to $1.85 a share. This was 7.7 per cent higher than the $77,623,000, or $1.72 a share, reported in the like 1965 period.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., July 19 Two teen-agers were among those who excelled on the Concord Hotel's rugged 7,200-yard course today as play in the 44th annual New York State amateur golf championship got under way.

Rain brought a temporary halt to the Yankees' four-game winning streak last night, but the players lost no sleep over it. After the game with he Kansas City Athletics was called off, they went home gladly to catch up on the rest they had lost on their way home.

The appointment of Robert W. Furman as vice president of the newly formed marine department of Cargocaire Engineering Corporation, was announced yesterday by Oliver Dyer Colvin, president of the company.
WARSAW, July 19 (Reuters) Several hundred demonstrators stoned the United States Embassy here today, damaging first-floor windows, in another outburst of Polish feeling over Vietnam.
PARIS, July 20--President de Gaulle spent 45 minutes today with Jean Sainteny, a former Government minister who recently completed a special semiofficial visit to Hanoi.
BERLIN, July 20--President Habib Bourguiba flew to West Berlin today to see the Berlin wall and to meet with Mayor Willy Brandt. The Tunisian leader is on a four-day state visit to Germany.
ALBANY, July 20--Tinges of green broke out in droughtbrowned pastures across the state today, and farmers' weathered faces crinkled with broad grins in the aftermath of yesterday's drenching rains.
Maj. Michael Collins moved about in space yesterday with the aid of bursts of nitrogen gas from a special gun he held in his hand.

Assemblyman Moses M. Weinstein, Queens Democratic leader and majority leader of the Assembly, who is always an easy winner in an election, has a 32-year-old Republican opponent this year who is proclaiming himself "Fearless Farber."

BARRINGTON, Ill., July 20 (AP)--A former national amateur champion, Barbara MoIntire, and a Curtis Cup-player, Mrs. Carol Sorenson Flenniken, were upset today in the second round of match play of the 66th women's Western amateur golf tournament.

BONN, July 20--President de Gaulle, who will have his semiannual talk here tomorrow with Chancellor Erhard, is expected to make clear his view that West Germany's attitude toward the continued stay of French troops is now the acid test of relations between Bonn and Paris.
There is interesting news for those who believe that the airline and office-equipment stocks are flying too high in today's market, a Wall Street study finds.

WASHINGTON, July 20-- The Senate Ethics Committee has brushed aside an attempt by Senator Thomas J. Dodd to challenge its authority to inquire into the use he made of proceeds from testimonial dinners.
PEKING, July 20 (Reuters) --Peking Jih Pao published an announcement today that Peking Wan Pao, the capital's only evening newspaper, would suspend publication temporarily tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, July 20--A Wall Street professional called the common stock of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company today "a very sound stock with somewhat less than average growth prospects for its earnings and dividends."

A basset hound named Sophia, a Pekingese called Dukie and a marmoset responding to Charlie Brown showed up yesterday morning at the Americana Hotel for a sneak preview of what mankind has in store for them.
The state ruled yesterday that 600,000 commuters could not deduct their new New York City earnings tax from their state income tax returns.

ROME, July 20--Pope Paul VI appealed to the Government of North Vietnam today to treat Amrican prisoners according to "international norms" and to seek every means toward a "just and honorable solution" of the war.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) --Luci Baines Johnson gave a surprise shower at the White House tonight for one of her bridesmaids who will be married Aug. 20.

The Port Authority's plan to build a huge new containership terminal near Elizabeth has the highly important objective of keeping the Port of New York competitive with such rivals as Philadelphia and Baltimore. Its merits must not be obscured by the continuing controversy between this city's administration and the Authority over the World Trade Center.
LONDON, July 20--"The King's Mare," which opened at the Garrick Theater tonight, was adapted by Anita Loos from the French of Jean Conolle. It isn't easy to see why she should have bothered.

STATELINE, Nev., July 20-- Federal officials reached a formal agreement today with representatives of California and Nevada on an unusual engineering program to avert the threatened pollution of Lake Tahoe.
L. James Wade Jr., 41 years old, was elected yesterday as president and chief executive officer of the General Portland Cement Company, Chicago.
HOUSTON, July 20 (AP)-- Mrs. Michael Collins watched a roast cook on a backyard rotisserie today while her husband made history on a 28-minute "space walk."
PITTSBURGH, July 20 (UPI) --Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company announced today the purchase of a Bellingham, Wash., cement plant from Kaiser Cement and Gypsum Corporation.
WASHINGTON, July 20 --A conference under Red Cross auspices to assure proper treatment of all prisoners of war was proposed to North Vietnam today by President Johnson.
"Don't tell me the business is dying on the Lower East Side," growled Herman Fishkin, a burly and cheerful jobber and retailer who has spent 50 years on Orchard Street.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 20 (UPI)--Mrs. William A. Croll's Like A Charm, ridden by Don Brumfield, romped to a fourand-a-half-length victory in the 21st running of the $23,165 New Jersey Futurity at Monmouth Park today.

PEKING, July 20--Communist China is starting to hit back at implied and overt Soviet suggestions that, despite its angry declarations, China's real long-term aim is to find an accommodation with the United States.

LOS ANGELES, July 20 (UPI) --Donn Clendenon hit a threerun homer to cap a six-run rally in the seventh inning tonight to give the league-leading Pittsburgh Pirates an 8-5 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers. Clendenon drove in five runs in all.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., July 20--Age lost a struggle with youth today in the second round of the New York state amateur golf championship as 54-year-old Joseph Biasone of Syracuse was beaten by 17-year old Nick Raasch of Fayetteville.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange fell sharply yesterday for the second consecutive day.

NEW DELHI, July 20--Marvin Zim, Time magazine bureau chief in New Delhi, was arrested in Lucknow today on charges of taking photographs of proceedings in the Assembly of Uttar Pradesl State. Photographers are barred from legislative assemblies.
WASHINGTON, July 20-- President Johnson warned today that disturbances by Negroes in big-city slums could jeopardize civil rights gains.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 29 (AP)--Gov. Edmund G. Brown has signed antiriot legislation sought by Los Angeles authorities who feared a recurrence of racial violence, the Governor's office said today.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) --The House Commerce Committee reversed itself today and watered down a provision in the auto safety bill to require used cars to meet the same Federal safety standards as new cars after 1970.

WASHINGTON, July 20-- The Senate dealt a series of blows to the Administration's foreign aid program today, cutting $250-million from its funds for economic development loans and imposing stiffer terms on what was left.
"Show Boat" is getting an extra two-week run at the New York State Theater.
The July contract for soybeans, the object of some frantic speculation in recent weeks, went off the board yesterday with a quiet but noticeable downturn in price.

The judge assigned to decide whether there should be a new Democratic primary in the 19th Congressional District because of charges of fraud said yesterday he might disqualify himself because of his "close personal friendship" with one of the candidates.

Supporters of Supreme Court Justice Samuel J. Silverman spent $61,696.06--about $5,000 less than the backers of Justice Arthur G. Klein--to win the Democratic nomination for surrogate for him in the June 28 primary, according to records made available yesterday by the Board of Elections.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP)--Six years of litigation over illegal price-fixing in the electrical equipment industry drew to a close today with a Philadelphia concern's agreemeet to pay $89,200 in damages to the Federal Government and the Tennessee Valley Authority.

WEST HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 20--Mr. and Mrs. George F. Bertsch have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Marcia Bertsch, to Richard Parker Billingham. He is the son of Mrs. Charles Sagar of Short Hills, N.J., and the late James Billingham.
Stock prices tumbled yesterday in the sharpest setback this month.
COPENHAGEN Denmark, July 20 (AP)--Tina, an American-owned Six-Meter Class yacht that was completed only three weeks ago, won the threerace competition for the 67year-old One Ton Cup today.

Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Rosenfeld of 180 Riverside Drive have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Tessa Naomi Rosenfeld, to Arnold Henry Dratt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Dratt of Massapequa Park, L.I. The wedding will take place on Oct. 9.
WASHINGTON, July 20-- Senator Robert F. Kennedy moved today to block political deals for State Supreme Court judgeships in Manhattan and the Bronx.
The end of a naval construction program that has revolutionized sea power and changed the dimensions of strategy will be marked today in a ceremony at Groton, Conn.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., July 20--Mr. and Mrs. Albert B. McCloskey have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Pamela Joan McCloskey, to William Frederick Woodbury Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Woodbury of Falls Church, Va., formerly of Valley Stream.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) --Six years of litigation over illegal price fixing in the electrical equipment industry drew to a close today with a Philadelphia concern's agreement to pay $89,200 in damages to the Federal Government and the Tennessee Valley Authority.
HOUSTON, July 20--Gemini 10 astronauts have seen at least three objects in space during their flight, but this is not considered unusual by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.
City Council President Frank D. O'Connor and Howard J. Samuels, the upstate industrialist, picked up delegate support yesterday in their quest for the Democratic nomination for Governor.
NANTUCKET, Mass., July 20--Charles McGill Thomas Jr. of Washington, a wholesale fish dealer, died yesterday at his summer home here. He was 44 years old.
Phyllis Curtin will replace Jane Marsh as soprano soloist with the Boston Symphony Orchestra in Beethoven's Ninth Symphony Aug. 21 at Tanglewood near Lenox, Mass.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 20 (AP)--The Syrian delegation received instructions from Damascus tonight to ask for a Security Council meeting on last Thursday's air attacks by Israel at the site of Arab work projects to divert the Jordan River and its tributaries.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP)--With an apologetic smile, President Johnson told reporters today he would prefer "to just step aside" from discussing arrangements for his daughter Luci's wedding.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 20--A special committee of 14 experts advised the United Nations today to halt the rapid increase in meetings, conferences and publications to avoid inefficiency and financial problems.
Francis V. Collinge, a partner in the accounting firm of Arthur Andersen Co., died Tuesday of a heart attack at the Chicago Wesley Memorial Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived in Chicago.
CLEVELAND, July 20--Scattered looting and fire-bombing continued today in the riot-scarred Hough area as hundreds of Ohio National Guardsmen and policemen sought to restore order.
A strike by 1,200 operating engineers that could idle most of this city's 200,000 construction workers was called last night to begin at 8 A.M. Monday.

Arthur S. Langlotz, who retired three years ago as head of Langlotz Co., commission men of Brooklyn and Valley Stream, L.I., died yesterday in his home at Winter Haven, Fla. He was 74 years old and had moved to Winter Haven from Valley Stream in December.

TORONTO, July 20 (AP)-- Mike Belkin, the Canadian-born star from Miami Beach, moved into the fourth round of an international tennis tournament here last night by defeating Fred Reaume of Toronto, 6-4, 6-2.

WASHINGTON, July 20-- Delaware asked the Supreme Court today to declare unconstitutional the "winner take all" system under which all of a state's electoral votes are cast for the Presidential nominee receiving most of the state's popular vote.

WASHINGTON, July 20--A Senate subcommittee heard a recording today of police interrogators eliciting a confession from a murder suspect as the panel began an investigation of the impact of the Supreme Court's new limitations on confessions.
Mayor Lindsay has given $5,000 to Sydenham Hospital in lieu of the salary cut he pledged to take when he took office.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., July 20--Arthur E. Laubenstein, an organist, accompanist and composer, died today in East Orange General Hospital after a short illness. He was 71 years old and a resident of Orange.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 20-- Although the ultimate miracle of beating Juan Marichal eluded them, the New York Mets continued their sudden drive toward glory by defeating the San Francisco Giants in 10 innings today, 3-2.
BOSTON, July 20 (UPI)-- The concept of black power was endorsed today by a group representing the 12 major Protestant denominations in Massachusetts.

In a pulse-tingling threehorse finish, Edward R. Scharps's Native Prince took the $27,850. Great American Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday, beating Philip Godfrey's Hermogenes by a neck. Successor of the Wheatley Stable was third a half-length farther back in the 5 -furlong dash for 2year-olds.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., July 20 (AP)--Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower and Gov. George Romney of Michigan talked politics for an hour and a half today. Both said they avoided discussing Republican Presidential prospects for 1968.

CAPE KENNEDY, Thursday, July 21--Maj. Michael Collins of the Air Force stepped out of Gemini 10 into the void of space early last night, and maneuvered himself to a nearby Agena rocket vehicle that had been in orbit since last March.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., July 20--Mrs. Patricia Stewart Edrich of New York paced the field into the quarter-finals of the New Jersey State women's singles tennis championship today at the East Orange Tennis Club.

A gunman who confessed invading a Park Avenue apartment with two others and stealing $110,000 in jewelry was sentenced yesterday in Manhattan Criminal Court to 15 to 20 years in prison. The two other men have not been apprehended.
Austin N. Heller, the city's new Commissioner of Air Pollution Control, announced plans yesterday to seek Federal funds for his department.

WASHINGTON, July 20(AP) --Canada, at the request of the United States, approached the North Vietnamese Government in Hanoi Monday about threats to try American airmen as war criminals, the Canadian External Affairs Minister, Paul Martin, said today. There was no apparent result.

CHICAGO, July 20--William Neill, Chicago port agent for the National Maritime Union of America, said today that the name of Richard F. Speck was in the union's hiring hall files because of an act of Congress.

CHICAGO, July 20 (AP)-- Jim O'Toole pitched a five-hitter as the Cincinnati Reds beat the Chicago Cubs, 5-1 today and swept a double-header. The Reds had rallied for four runs in the ninth inning to win the first game, 5-4.
Prices on the London stock market slipped back again yesterday as traders awaited news on Prime Minister Wilson's new deflationary measures.

ROME, July 20--Rich Roman men, aware that the Italian couture collections are now being shown be cause women always talk about them, think it would be nice if their wives made the world's best-dressed list.

TORRINGTON, Conn., July 20 --George A. Vondermuhll, long a partner and officer of William Iselin Co., New York factors, died today at Charlotte Hungerford Hospital following surgery. He was 82 years old and lived at Litchfield near here and at 115 East 79th Street, New York.

WASHINGTON, July 20-- President Johnson announced today that he would visit Tennessee, Indiana, Illinois and Kentucky this weekend. It is "part of the President's job," he said, to visit various parts of the nation.
EDISON, N.J., July 20-- Lieut, Col. Roderick F. MacKenzie, retired, of 30 Ovington Avenue, a career Army officer from 1925 to 1957, died Monday at Walson Army Hospital, Fort Dix. He was 63 years old.
Mayor Lindsay has gone to private industry for help in taking some of the heat out of the long hot summer of New York teen-agers.
TRENTON, July 20--A Federal report said today that the Delaware was "a dirty river."
THE next thing you know, we'll have computerized ghosts. They are over due in the hard-breathing march of contemporary fiction toward bigger and better diabolism.
LONDON, July 20 (Reuters) --London's couturiers to tally abandoned the clinging ultra-short skirts and plunging necklines in their fall "cover-up" collections, which end today.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI)--Six Midwest Governors went to the White House today to tell President Johnson they did not like the proposed increase in tolls on the St. Lawrence Seaway.
TALK about cool programing, leave it to the Na tional Broadcasting Company to waft the mid-July viewer to Irkutsk, situated somewhere below zero in Siberia.
HOUSTON, July 20 (UPI)-- The Philadelphia Phillies made 20 hits off six Houston pitchers tonight and scored a 13-9 victory over the Astros.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 20-- Nurses in 33 hospitals around San Francisco Bay handed in resignations today and pushed their wage disputes a step nearer crisis. The resignations take effect Aug. 30.

American shipping executives carefully watched the Washington scene yesterday as organized labor played a major role in a legislative drama that will shape the future of the nation's maritime industry.
The blue-jeaned guitar and banjo players in Washington Square Park will be competing next month with their archrivals, performers of Mozart and Prokofiev.
The Yankees were efficient, snappy and economic last night as they extended their winning streak to five games.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 20-- Victor Seixas' athletic durability has taken on a legendary aura in the Philadelphia area, and today the 42-year-old former national and Wimbledon tennis champion gave the most convincing demonstration of his extraordinary lasting powers.
With no end to the war in sight, the continuing losses of United States aircraft in Vietnam lend emphasis to the latest report of the Senate Preparedness Investigating subcommittee.
With the recent agreement with Canada to open passenger service to Montreal, Aeroflot, the Soviet Union's airline, is now serving 50 countries, according to Tass, the official press agency.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., July 20--Mr. and Mrs. Ivor Balding of Old Westbury and Camden, S.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Balding, to Hartley Parker Shearer. He is the son of Mrs. Clifford Roberts of New York and F. Hartley Shearer of Naples, Fla.

DEMILITARIZED ZONE, in Vietnam, July 20--The South Vietnamese Government returned 13 captured North Vietnamese soldiers to their homeland today to mark the 12th anniversary of the 1954 Geneva accords, which partitioned Vietnam.

PHILADELPHIA, Miss., July 20 (UPI)--The Neshoba County Hospital was certified for the Medicare program today after a week-long battle in which the administrator threatened to evict 26 Medicare patients and take the case to Federal court.
HOUSTON, July 20 (AP)-- The Houston Astros purchased Gene Freese, a third baseman, from the Chicago White Sox today for an undisclosed amount of cash and a minor-league infielder, Jim Mahoney.

Van Cliburn, not unexpectedly, drew the largest crowd of the season to Lewisohn Stadium last night. Estimates of the total varied, even official ones, but it seems likely that there were at least 18,000 to hear Mr. Cliburn play two piano concertos with the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra--the Brahms Second and the Rachmaninoff Second.

WASHINGTON, July 20-- President-elect Rene Barrientos Ortuno of Bolivia said today that if his government lagged in its accomplishments, he would not object to being deposed by a military coup d'etat.
One of the most delightful settings for jazz these summer nights is the churchyard of St. Mark's on-the-Bouwerie on Second Avenue at 10th Street.
Short-term interest rates appear to be making an attempt at stabilization.

The Transit Authority advised the Board of Estimate yesterday that it would be impossible to provide free transfers between bus and subway lines unless the subway fare was raised to 25 cents and all bus fares to 20 cents.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 113.6 on Tuesday from 113.8 on Monday.
Keystone Custodian Funds, Inc., manager of 13 investment funds, announced yesterday that two of its bond funds would be combined Aug. 1.

The disclosure that citywide adoption of the comprehensive high school will be delayed by three years comes as a disappointment. The plan gives promise of both improved education and better integration. The case against the separate vocational schools, with their often predominantly Negro enrollment and their obsolescent curriculum, is convincing--as is the case for secondary education that combines high-quality academic and vocational studies more interchangeably under one roof.

An exhibition at the Whitney Museum of American Art will be the basis of a one-hour television program in which the National Broadcasting Company will depict the history of the country through paintings and sculpture.

Eugene Power, board chairman of University Microfilms, Inc., believes that demand publishing--the production of books only after they are ordered, will gain an important place in the book industry in the future.

THE Stravinsky Festival in Philharmonic Hall last night brought together Igor Stravinsky and Italian music, though the piece de resistance was a performance of "Oedipus Rex," which is a long way from the Italian spirit.

The Lindsay administration's $4.5-billion budget stands in "precarious balance," but the city has "turned the corner" with a sounder fiscal operation. That was the view yesterday of the top officers of the Temporary Commission on City Finances.

THE New York master Michael Valvo scored 5-0 to capture top honors in the recent First Westchester Open at the Mt. Kisco Boys' Club. Twenty-four players from New York, New England and Canada took part in this five-round Swiss system.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP)--The Minnesota Twins made it three straight and 10 out of 12 for the season against Washington tonight, beating the Senators, 3-1, behind the six hit pitching of Dave Boswell.
American Airlines, Inc., announced here yesterday a moderate increase in its secondquarter and first-half sales and earnings, compared with 1965 levels.
Montefiore became yesterday the second hospital in the city to order an increase in room rates following a wage increase granted to nonmedical and semiprofessional workers Monday.
BUENOS AIRES, July 20-- Mounting labor unrest, continuing inflation and lack of funds are rapidly dividing the supporters of President Juan Carlos Ongania.

WASHINGTON, July 20-- Senator Edward M. Kennedy proposed today that both Communist and Nationalist China be seated in the United Nations, but his suggestion was quickly rejected as premature by President Johnson.

A vest-pocket industrial park, which will offer about 120,000 square feet of space for light industry, will be built on a fouracre site in New Hyde Park, L.I., by Mascioli Associates, Long Island builders.

VICTORY in the two most important New York Championships--the Reisinger Knockout Teams and the Goldman Pairs--in the same year is a double that has been accomplished only three times. This year a New York expert, Boris Raymond, almost added his name to the list: he was a member of the team that won the Reisinger Trophy event, and he would apparently have won the Goldman Open Pair title but for a scoring error.
The election of John P. Dowling, C. Barrett Leary and Daniel N. Quigley as vice presidents in the metropolitan division of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company was announced here yesterday.

AKRON, Ohio, July 20--There were indications tonight, on the eve of the Professional Golfers' Association championship, that several policy changes were in the making for the P.G.A. at the insistence of the golfers.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 20 --Prudence persevered at Larchmont Race Week today. It was to be junior regatta day for 800 boys and girls 13 to 17 years of age, from 35 yachts clubs, with races scheduled in the afternoon.

Seated in reclining beach chairs and on wooden milk boxes supplied by the audience, the Municipal Concerts Orchestra gave a shortened but enthusiastically received concert in a Brooklyn park last night.

Elliot Martin and Lester Osterman have booked the Alvin Theater for their forthcoming revival of "Dinner at Eight," the George S. Kaufman-Edna Ferber play. It will open Sept. 27. Tyrone Guthrie will attend to the direction. The cast includes Robert Burr, Mindy Carson, Ruth Ford, Arlene Francis, June Havoc, Jeffrey Lynn, Darren McGavin, Walter Pidgeon, Pamela Tiffin and Blanche Yurka.
WASHINGTON, July 20-- The House approved $58.6-billion for defense spending today, the largest single peacetime money bill in the nation's history.

WASHINGTON, July 20-- President Johnson told a news conference today that he was "distressed" about the tight money situation. But he indicated in another context that he was still much more worried about the possibility of inflation.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP)--The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today it planned to launch a spacecraft next month designed to orbit the moon closely enough to take pictures of the Surveyor I now on the lunar surface.
The spot rate on the British pound rose sharply on foreignexchange markets here yesterday after Prime Minister Wilson's announcement of new measures to bolster sterling.

WASHINGTON, July 20-- President Johnson, who has been an outspoken and effective champion of the civil rights cause, inadvertently exposed today the central difficulty of a problem that is becoming increasingly racial rather than legal, economic or constitutional.
BALTIMORE, July 20 (AP) --The Detroit Tigers said tonight that acting Manager Bob Swift and their shortstop, Dick McAuliffe, were suffering from bacterial food poisoning.

HOUSTON, July 20--When he crawled out of his Gemini 10 space capsule today to enjoy the view from 250 miles out in space, Maj. Michael Collins was not leaving a flying object for the first time. This time, oddly enough, he was safer.
NASHVILLE, July 20 (UPI) --Obscenity charges against Lawrence Kerrigan, a theater manager, were dropped today and he promptly showed the film "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf" before a packed house.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 20 --Mrs. Jean Drummond Ijams of New York, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Drummond of St. Louis, was married this afternoon to Edward M. Crane Jr. of Princeton, N.J., president of the D. Van Nostrand Company, Inc., the publishers. He is the son of Mrs. Crane of Rumson, N.J., and Delray Beach, Fla., and the late Mr. Crane.
The East Hampton, L.I., township has banned sleeping on the beach at night and littering.
Scheduled airlines in the United States maintained their record of flying safety in 1965 according to a report released here yesterday by the Society of Actuaries.
LONDON, July 20--Prime Minister Wilson cut deeply into Britain's private and public spending today in a major effort to rescue the pound.

Charles Masterson of Brooklyn, seeded first, reached the semi-final round of the Eastern senior clay-court tennis cham pionship yesterday by defeating Dr. Robert E. Lake of Forest Hills, Queens, 6--2, 6--1, at the Seminole Club, Forest Hills.
The Middle South Utilities, Inc., expects to almost double its generating capability over the next five years, Gerald L. Andrus, president of the holding company complex, disclosed yesterday.
The unpopular economic actions announced by the British Government yesterday sharply reduce the possibility of a forced devaluation of sterling.

Car-theft rings that steal to the customer's order are not exactly a novelty--the police in Hauppage, L.I., arrested 16 persons last February in a steal-to-order Cadillac theft operation. But yesterday, Queens District Attorney Nat H. Hentel announced the breakup of such a ring that supplied customers with impressive extras.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) --The Rev. Robert T. Woodworth, pastor of the Open Bible Tabernacle in Baltimore, quoted the Bible today in opposing President Johnson's open housing proposal.
The Police Department commissioned its first steel-hull launch yesterday with a full measure of ceremony, but just half the National Anthem.
WASHINGTON, July 20-- A bill to outlaw the Ku Klux Klan and other "clandestine terror" organizations received a qualified endorsement today from Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach.
The CIBA Products Company announced yesterday an increase in prices of all its standard bisphenol "A" epoxy resins, effective today.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP)--Exports by the United States climbed 5 per cent during June, registering their best monthly performance since March and the second best total for the year, the Commerce Department reported today.
WASHINGTON, July 20-- The House Interior Committee rejected today an attempt to kill two dams proposed for the Grand Canyon as part of the $1.7-billion Central Arizona Project.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, July 21--Two more United States warplanes were shot down by North Vietnam yesterday, the United States command announced today. The seven Americans aboard--six of them on one plane--were listed as missing.

Hands behind his back, Rabbi Theodore Robinson swayed slightly, as Orthodox Jews do when they pray, and watched the traffic on the Grand Concourse. "The neighborhood is deteriorating, there's no getting away from it," he said with a shrug. "We had 140 families seven years ago and now we have 60. Even the big synagogues on the avenue are having trouble."
WASHINGTON, July 2-- Mayor Lindsay formally opened New York City's first permanent office in Washington today and indicated that it was going to get a lot of work.
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., July 20 (AP)--Mrs. Charles N. DeRose, wife of the publisher of The Hampshire Gazette of Northampton, died last night at the age of 53.
WASHINGTON, July 20--Following are the parties involved, the issues in dispute, and a brief summary of the effects of the airline strike:

YONKERS, July 20--A total of 1,143 applications for stalls has been received at Yonkers Raceway, where a 74-night second-half harness racing meeting will begin on Monday night. Ted Gibbons, the racing secretary, said there were 692 stalls on the grounds.

The labor members of the tripartite panel set up to cover the city's labor negotiations with its employes will meet next Tuesday in connection with a controversy that has led the policemen and firemen to break off their bargaining with City Hall.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., July 20 (UPI)--A grocery was dynamited tonight in a Negro neighborhood that was the scene of widespread violence and firebombings the two previous nights.

Mrs. Nance Donohoe McGurrin, wife of James McGurrin, County Clerk of New York County, died Tuesday, in the Beth Israel Hospital. She was 69 years old and was the daughter of the late Representative and Mrs. Michael Donohoe of Philadelphia.
LONDON, July 20 (UPI)-- Hungary swept into the quarterfinal round of the World Cup soccer championship today by defeating Bulgaria, 3-1. The victory eliminated Brazil, the defending champion.
BOSTON, July 20 (AP)--Bob Rodgers's pinch-hit single in the 10th inning enabled the California Angels to beat Boston, 1-0, in the second game of a double-header tonight.

David Wolfe Biller, executive editor in the Special Projects department of Harcourt, Brace World, Inc., 757 Third Avenue, died Tuesday in St. Vincent's Hospital after a short illness. He was 54 years old.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) --The head of the Federal antipoverty program said today he had suspended more than $500,000 in grants to aid seasonal farm workers and migrants in Lowndes and Wilcox Counties in Alabama pending an investigation of charges by Gov. George C. Wallace.
Two groups of poor people protested yesterday that if their homes were rehabilitated they would not be able to afford the new rents.

WARSAW, Poland, July, 20 (Reuters)--More than 1,000 Polish priests defied a church ban to attend the ceremony as the cornerstone of a memorial to Pope John XXIII was laid in Wroclaw, it was reported today.
ROME, July 20--The right of an Italian man to kill an erring wife, daughter or sister or their illicit lovers with virtual impunity may soon be ended.

POPE PAUL'S visit here last year was unprece dented and historically and visually impressive--indisputable facts that are once again carefully illustrated by "A Pilgrimage for Peace", the color documentary that arrived at the Trans-Lux Theater yesterday.
HOUSTON, July 20--The Gemini 10 crew went through a safety check of their breathing equipment this afternoon before the "space walk" by Maj. Michael Collins.

Net income of the Dow Chemical Company rose 22 per cent to a record $62.8-million, or $2.10 a share, in the first six months this year from $51.2-million, or $1.69 a share, cleared in the 1965 period. This reflected a sales increase of 15 per cent to $646-million from $561.4-million.
The short interest position on the New York Stock Exchange at mid-July reached the second highest level in history, although the month's increase above June amounted to only 126,732 shares.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) --The Senate Foreign Relations Committee today eliminated President Johnson's proposed Peace Corps exchange program.
Mr. and Mrs. Samuel G. Gay have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sandra Dolores Gay, to Douglas Terry, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Terry.

WASHINGTON, July 20-- The Federal Maritime Commission late today ordered two trans-Atlantic passenger steamship conferences to do away with two rules affecting the sale of steamship tickets and the conduct of travel agency affairs. The order is expected to have far-reaching effects on the sale of steamship tickets.

A MATCH show is an informal event at which no championship points are awarded. It provides excellent experience for training dogs and people for the show ring. It's a local affair and entries and crowds are usually comparatively small.

With stockholders of both the Pennsylvania, and the New York Central railroads scheduled to gather at separate meetings today to vote on the merger of the Central into the Pennsylvania, the Interstate Commerce Commission announced yesterday that the earliest effective date for the consolidation would be Sept. 30.

TOKYO, July 20 (Reuters)-- Mao Tse-tung, Chairman of the Chinese Communist party, was sun-tanned and appeared in good health when he met 14 Japanese writers at a villa in the Wuhan district last Sunday, one of them said here today.
BARCELONA, Spain, July 20 (AP)--Anselmo Maria Cardinal Albareda died today of cancer at the age of 74.

WASHINGTON, July 20-- The United States proposed to the other industrial countries today the establishment of a world food reserve to help meet emergency famine situations in the less developed countries.

About 100 unionized workers for the State Division of Employment picketed Governor Rockefeller's office at 22 West 55th Street yesterday to stress their demands for higher wages. They also protested what they called political favoritism in job assignments.
A new type of mortgage investment company, which shortly will seek to raise $100million from institutional investors, is quietly being put together here.

The Lindsay administration yesterday declined to comment on the proposals of the Port of New York Authority for a "consolidated" passenger liner terminal on the city-owned waterfront on Manhattan's West Side.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., July 20 --The president of the District Attorneys Association of New York State said here today that "a Pandora's box of troubles" would be opened by the Court of Appeals if it construed as retroactive the United States Supreme Court's decision on confessions.
WEISBADEN, Germany, July 20 (AP)--William Blankenship of Columbus, Ga., won the center-fire pistol event at the world shooting championships today and helped the United States take the team title.

There may be economy, convenience and fun is driving a motorcycle or motor scooter, but statistics, reinforced by the cautious attitude of insurance companies, emphasize that two-wheeled vehicles are more dangerous than cars.
The combination of a liberalized attitude of the Federal Power Commission and 42-inch pipe seems to be adding up to savings for metropolitan householers on their gas bills in the months to come.
CHICAGO, July 20 (AP)-- Seven hundred more National Guardsmen were ordered released from duty tonight in a West Side area torn by violence last week.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, July 20 (Reuters)--President Joaquin Balaguer submitted a measure to Congress today to dissolve the Dominican Sugar Corporation.
Directors of the Northrop Corporation and the Hallicrafters Company approved yesterday new terms for their consolidation first proposed last January.

The Board of Education agreed yesterday in a meeting with community leaders of troubled East New York to allow neighborhood use this summer of Thomas Jefferson High School, its swimming pool and athletic field.
Ted Robinson Jr., a former movie and book critic for Newsweek magazine, died Tuesday in a plunge from his 19th-floor room at the Manhattan Towers, Broadway and 76th Street. He was 56 years old.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., July 20--Miss Joan Lynn Oppenheimer and R. Benjamin Cohen plan to marry next spring.

GENEVA, July 20--The United States formally accepted today a Soviet proposal to widen the scope of negotiations now under way in the United Nations to establish rules to govern the exploration of space.

DELRAY BEACH, Fla., July 20--Mr. and Mrs. W. Cottingham Allen of Delray Beach, formerly of Cleveland, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Renee de Russy Allen of New York, to Richard N. Rand Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Rand of Darien, Conn.
CHICAGO, July 20--Richard F. Speck, the 24-year-old accused slayer of eight student nurses, asked the public defender today represent him.
PHUOC TUY PROVINCE, Vietnam, July 20 (AP)--In a rubber plantation southeast of Saigon--the exact spot still is secret--a 3,000-man Australian task force has set up camp.

TOKYO, July 20--Members of the Japan Chamber of Commerce and Industry are studying a proposal to send a factfinding mission to Communist China, according to the authoritative daily financial newspaper Nihon Keizai.
The combination of a liberalized attitude of the Federal Power Commission and 42-inch pipe seems to be adding up to savings for metropolitan householers on their gas bills in the months to come.
CHICAGO, July 20 (AP)-- Seven hundred more National Guardsmen were ordered released from duty tonight in a West Side area torn by violence last week.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, July 20 (Reuters)--President Joaquin Balaguer submitted a measure to Congress today to dissolve the Dominican Sugar Corporation.
GENEVA, July 20--Margaret Mead, the anthropologist, urged today that churches "be shaken loose from their imprisonment within the archaic forms of a vanishing society."
BAYONNE, N.J., July 20-- William Rubin, counsel to the City of Bayonne and a member of its legal department for 35 years, died Monday while conferring in a client's home here. He was 62 years old.
Q. Mr. President, what is your reaction to the talk from Hanoi about possible war crimes trials for American prisoners and what might be the consequences of such an action?

HICKSVILLE, L.I., July 20-- Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Hecker have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathleen T. Hecker, to William G. Schiffmacher 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Schiffmacher Jr. of Westbury.
NEW DELHI, July 20--India is recalling her consul general in Saigon for having defended the United States bombing of oil installations in North Vietnam.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., July 20--Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union, the recent challenger for the world chess title, defeated Wolfgang Unzicker of West Germany in their adjourned second-round game of the Piatigorsky Cup Tournament at the Miramar Hotel here last night.
The City Planning Commission, voting 5 to 2, approved yesterday New York University's plan to build a library on its Washington Square campus.
HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 20 --Vandals desecrated the Northport Rural Cemetery here last night, breaking into two burial vaults and propping a skeleton in a mausoleum window.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP)--The Maritime Administration added seven ships today to its blacklist of vessels that have called at North Vietnam ports since last June 25.
"THERE'S more to the food of North Africa than couscous," according to Mrs. Ray Shaw.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 20 --In a move that may alter and enrich the nation's theatrical landscape, the Federal Government will become the principal angel next fall for professional acting companies here and in New Orleans.

PARIS, July 20--President de Gaulle is flying to Bonn tomorrow amid predictions that a formula will be found that will permit French troops to remain in West Germany in spite of their withdrawal from the integrated command structure of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
BOSTON, July 20--Like dope pushers fighting over a junkie, race tracks and politicians are stepping up their terri torial battles for the patronage of the $2 bettor.
DAYTON, Ohio, July 20 (AP) --City employes voted tonight to return to work and the city commission voted not to invoke a state law that carries heavy penalties for public employes who strike.
LONDON, July 20--William Oliver Smedley was committed to trial today on a charge of manslaughter in the slaying last month of the head of one of Britain's pirate radio stations.
KARACHI, Pakistan, July 20 --Attorney General Syed Sharifuddin Pirzada was appointed Foreign Minister of Pakistan today, succeeding Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, the pro-Peking Minister who resigned June 18.
PARIS, July 20--The North Vietnamese charge d'affaires here said today that Hanoi was not likely to negotiate because of increasing American military pressure.
WASHINGTON, July 20--The airline labor negotiations took a sharp turn for the worse tonight within hours after the Johnson Administration thought it had avoided a six-day break in bargaining.
Angry antipoverty workers from the Lower East Side, who have been running projects for more than two weeks without pay, staged a sit-in protest yesterday at the city's summer program office.
A woman and four men were held in $20,000 bail yesterday in Brooklyn Criminal Court on charges of assault and robbery in the holdup of a bar.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 20--The Rev. Ian Paisley, moderator of the Free Presbyterian Church of Ulster, an extremist group, began serving a three-month sentence today in Belfast prison.

ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., July 20-- Newfoundland is impatiently awaiting a decision by Quebec's new Conservative government on whether Quebec will buy nine million horsepower of electricity from a project to be developed at Churchill Falls, Labrador.

BALTIMORE, July 20 (AP) --Boog Powell's two-run homer capped a three-run rally in the fifth inning that sent the Baltimore Orioles to a 10-7 victory over the Detroit Tigers tonight and extended the Orioles' American League lead to 10 games over the second-place Tigers.

PHILADELPHIA, July 20 (AP)--Three members of the Philadelphia Orchestra, who want to become musicians in residence at the University of Washington in Seattle, were restrained today, by a temporary injunction, from playing professionally with any group except the Philadelphia Orchestra.

It had to come. The harsh and sweeping deflationary measures that Prime Minister Harold Wilson has now administered to Britain's economy are essential if domestic inflation is to be curbed and foreign confidence restored.

BOSTON, July 21 Dr. Helen W.Deane, a noted professor of anatomy at Yeshiva University in New York who in the McCarthy era, while she was teaching at Harvard University, became the center of a controversy, died yesterday after a long illness at the New England Baptist Hospital. She was 49 years old and lived at 541 Pelham Road, New Rochelle, N.Y.

GROTON, Conn., July 21 One thousand shipyard laborers angrily confronted 150 antiwar pickets staging a "silent vigil" here today as the submarine Will Rogers was launched. The vessel, the last of the nation's Polaris submarines, was christened by Mrs. Hubert H. Humphrey.
Mayor Lindsay appealed to both sides yesterday to head off a strike threatened for Monday that could idle most of the 200,000 construction workers in the city.

The strike against the airlines by the International Association of Machinists drags on. President Johnson was accurate in observing that "the patience of the public is being tried," but he also noted that there is no law that can compel the strikers to return to work.
Religious, political and civil rights groups in the city are mounting a major campaign to fight efforts by the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association to kill the civilian-dominated review board.
WASHINGTON, July 21 Eugene H. Nickerson said today that he thought the war in Vietnam would be an issue in New York's gubernatorial campaign this fall, and would hurt the Democratic candidate.
LONDON, July 21 (UPI) A 74-year-old woman from Washington, D.C., flew across the Atlantic alone Saturday, but she managed to keep it a secret until today.
LONDON, July 21 (Reuters) Lady Guthrie, wife of the head of the British Overseas Airways Corporation, Sir Giles Guthrie, was wounded by a shotgun early today in a struggle with a burglar.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 21 The sixth annual Newport Folk Festival began here this evening in clear weather with several innovations planned to display folk culture to a mass audience in new ways.

TRENTON, July 21 A meeting of New Jersey organization Democrats summoned to endorse Warren W. Wilentz as a candidate for the United States Senate was converted today into a platform for debating United States policy in Vietnam.

WIESBADEN, Germany, July 21(AP) Gary Anderson of San Anselmo, Calif., and the United States team set world records today in capturing the individual and team titles in the three-position free-rifle event of the world shooting championships.
A small new plane manufactured by a small new company with an unusual history has gone into full production after receiving certification from the Federal Aviation Agency.

WHITE PLAINS, July 21 Miss Barbara Ann Flesch and Frank Michael Resnek were married this afternoon at the Jewish Community Center of White Plains by Rabbi Lawrence W. Schwartz. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Richard Charles Flesch of Scarsdale and Mr. and Mrs. David O. Resnek of Chestnut Hill, Mass.
Mrs. Eva M. Lytle Beecher, for 30 years resident manager of Dug-Out, Inc., a veterans' service organization here, died Wednesday at her home, 151 West 86th Street. She was 85 years old.
Mayor Lindsay said at his City Hall news conference yesterday that he was "very, very much concerned" about the impasse in efforts to end the partial newspaper stoppage.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) A spokesman for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People opposed today a House bill aimed at alleged terrorism and violence by groups such as the Ku Klux Klan.

HOUSTON, Tex., July 21 (UPI) The next United States manned voyage into space is set for Sept. 7, and the two astronauts may fly to a record altitude of 750 miles into the radiation belt surrounding the earth.
Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that he was now satisfied that the controversial heliport atop the Pan Am Building was a "sound operation and a safe one."

Shepherded by an anxious stage crew, the scenery of Act I of the Metropolitan Opera's new "La Traviata" rolled silently onto the main stage of the new opera house at Lincoln Center yesterday afternoon.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 21--The Gemini 10 astronauts brought their three-day double-rendezvous mission to a smooth end today with an accurate splashdown in the Atlantic Ocean.

The Soviet Union has withdrawn permission for the Columbia Broadcasting System to produce two television programs there. One was to be a documentary on the 50th anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution, the other, a cultural show on which American and Russian singers would appear.

WASHINGTON, July 21 The Senate has been nibbling President Johnson's foreign-aid bill to pieces this week. It has not only reduced the money substantially, but made the terms of development loans harder, and refused to authorize the program for more than a year.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) A hearing examiner for the Federal Trade Commission held tonight that Carlton Fredericks, a writer and lecturer on nutrition, should be barred from representing any book or publication as new if it previously appeared in essentially the same form or content.

A wide cross section of the motoring public shuffled along lines leading to Traffic Court cashiers' windows yesterday as New Yorkers flocked to pay long overdue parking tickets before new, heavier penalties go into effect July 29.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 21--South Vietnam's troubled economic situation took a slight turn for the better last week, but inflation remained an extremely serious economic and political problem.

Grain prices declined again yesterday in active trading. As prices broke in the morning, a large number of stop-loss orders were activated, quickening the decline. A forecast of muchneeded rain for the weekend was one reason for the heavy selling.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., July 21 Dr. Benjamin J. Silverstein, a private physician in Newark for 54 years, died today at St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston. He was 77 years old and lived at 67 South Munn Avenue here.

One more milepost was passed yesterday by the Pennsylvania and the New York Central Railroads in their route toward a merger. Stockholders of both systems at separate meetings here and in Philadelphia approved the conditions required for the merger of the roads by the Interstate Commerce Commission.
WASHINGTON, July 21 The Consumer Price Index for the first six months of this year showed its highest increase in eight years, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.
HOUSTON, Tex., July 21 (AP) Anxiety gave way to jubilation today as wives of the Gemini 10 astronauts followed the final phases of the space mission.
It has taken the worst flood in Mongolia's history, with its accompanying heavy toll of human life and property damage, to evoke from Washington the first official gesture toward Ulan Bator.

Police Headquarters announced yesterday that 60 Manhattan children would be weekend guests at the homes of policemen as part of Operation Friend, a community project held by the police and residents of the upper West Side.
When a City Hall car arrived at William West's home yesterday morning to take him to ceremonies honoring a policeman who had saved his infant son's life, he was afraid to go.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 21 Stanley Smith of Pasadena, Calif., scored the most notable victory of his career today in the Pennsylvania lawn tennis championships at the Merion Cricket Club after giving up a set in a display of sportsmanship with few parallels.
LONDON, July 21 The Earl of Shaftesbury and Mrs. Bianca Le Vien were married today at the Caxton Hall Registry Office.

TOKYO, Friday, July 22 (AP) Communist China rallied nearly a million people in Peking today to demonstrate support for North Vietnam against "United States aggression," according to the official Chinese press agency, Hsinhua.

The flight of Gemini 10 was probably the most productive and most important manned experiment in space to date. It demonstrated that a genuine quantum jump has been accomplished in man's capabilities in that strange and deeply hostile realm beyond earth's atmosphere. It will require the work of generations to realize the full potentials of man's new abilities that were first exercised these past few days.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) The Federal Communications Commission today sought assurances that International Telephone Telegraph Corporation will not engage in broadcasting activities if allowed to acquire the American Broadcasting Company.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William Parsons of 114 East 84th Street and Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Llewellyn Swayne Parsons, to George Putnam Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Putnam Smith of Cambridge and Manchester, Mass.
