Time, Inc., set records in revenues and earnings in the three and six months ended June 30, the nation's largest publishing company reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) President Johnson, apparently convinced that public appearances increase his popularity, will add a new dimension Saturday to his election year travels by stressing his role as Commander in Chief.
The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that it had disciplined two officers of a New Orleans member brokerage house in connection with statements regarding the company's capital position.
TROY, N.Y., July 21 The 155-man Troy police force canceled all days off today as racial tensions troubled this Hudson River factory city.

WASHINGTON, July 21 The war in Vietnam cost $5.8-billion in the fiscal year ended June 30, final budget results for the fiscal year revealed today. This was $1.1-billion more than had been estimated in the January budget.

The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation approved yesterday the merger of two small California banks. Far from being a routine regulatory action, the move showed every sign of escalating into an incident of international scope between the United States and Canada.
United States newsprint consumption set new highs in June and in the first half of 1966.
Two of New York's filmunion locals are being cast as the heavies in a drama involving the boom in feature-film production here.

Shipyard workers and two major shipbuilding and repair companies are conducting negotiations for a new contract to replace a three-year agreement expiring at the end of the month. The labor group is the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 21 The Security Council was summoned today to meet next Monday afternoon to consider Syrian charges of Israeli acts of aggression.

Following an inquiry from Senator Robert F. Kennedy, the Department of Justice has withdrawn its effort to force an organization that is aiding political prisoners in South Africa to register as a foreign agent.
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 21 Dave Herman's moon face lighted up as he spoke in semi-awe about Sherman Lewis, his football teammate at Michigan State and now his prospective teammate on the New York Jets.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) The body of a Peace Corps volunteer, Thomas J. Hassett of Utica, N.Y., has been found near his work site in Nepal, Peace Corps headquarters said today.
MOSCOW, July 21 (AP) Communist Chinese students want "to set the strongest fire" to what they call their criminal system of education, a Soviet newspaper reported today.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) The State Department has told Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas that it will approve his request for permission to travel to Communist China, officials said today.

The managements of Radio City Music Hall and 20th Cen tury-Fox are discovering that crime pays. Fox's romantic comedy-adventure, "How To Steal a Million," set a nonholiday, opening-week record at the nation's largest showcase by grossing $227,477 for the seven-day period ended Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) The American Nursing Home Association rejected today the Government's formula for reimbursing nursing homes for the care of Medicare patients.
In its reckless assault on the foreign-aid bill, the Senate majority threatens to inflict a heavy political blow against the best interests of the United States.
The Canteen Corporation announced here yesterday that it had agreed to manage the hotel and eating facilities of the Tower Plaza Hotel, a new, 500room structure in Las Vegas, Nev.

WASHINGTON, July 21 Senator Robert F. Kennedy of New York berated the Senate today for "tearing apart" the $3.4-billion foreign aid authorization and chided the Johnson Administration for not working harder for the bill.
The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday it would move its electronic systems center a massive computer complex for floor and back-office brokerage work outside

FAIRPORT, N.Y., July 21 A September wedding is planned by Miss Mary Kathleen Cunningham and William Kirk Swann 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. Swann Jr. of Knoxville, Tenn. Their engagement has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Geoffrey Everett Cunningham, parents of the future bride.
WASHINGTON, July 21 The negotiations to end the 14day-old airline strike resumed in earnest today as the machinists union scrapped its plan to break off talks for five days.

Texaco, Inc., earned $157,041,580, equal to $1.17 a share, in the June quarter this year, compared with $143,875,714, or $1.07 a share, in the second quarter of 1965, for a gain of 9.1 per cent. With the exception of the first quarter this year, when net reached $175.9million, the June quarter was the most profitable of any quarter in the company's history.

INWOOD, L.I., July 21 Mrs. Charles Leichner of Muttontown and Mrs. Pat Cici of Cedar Brook added a 41, 38 79 today to their opening-day 75 and won the Women's Cross County Golf Association better-ball-of-partners tournament at the Inwood Country Club with a total of 154. Par for the 5,888-yard course is 37, 36 73.
The Nevada State Banking Superintendent, Preston E. Tidvall, ordered yesterday all six state-chartered banks to reduce interest rates on automatically renewable time deposits.
Customers' net debit balances, which show the borrowings of individual investors on margin, declined by $2-million during June to $5,795,000,000, the New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 21 The Saratoga Performing Arts Center had its first world premiere tonight. Edward Villella's "Narkissos" was danced by the New York City Ballet Company, the group in residence for the month of July in the newly established festival.
CHICAGO, July 21 Public Defender Gerald W. Getty said today that he would enter a "not guilty" plea for Richard F. Speck, suspected of murdering eight student nurses last week in Chicago.
Sperry Rand, always a speculative favorite, has begun to draw attention of cautious investors as well.
Plans for urban renewal projects that will cost a total of about $7.6-million in New York and New Jersey have been disclosed by Ancott Associates of New York, the sponsors.
SAN DIEGO, July 21 (AP) A Broad-scale drilling and research program of the ocean bottom was announced today by Scripps Institution of Oceanography and the National Science Foundation.

MYSTIC, Conn., July 21 Mrs. Mary L. Jobe Akeley, geographer, explorer, mountaineer and author of many books and articles recounting her adventures in many parts of the world, died at Great Hill, her home here, Tuesday. She was 80 years old.

The Allied Chemical Corporation registered its tenth consecutive quarterly record by establishing new highs in sales and income in the quarter ended June 30, Chester M. Brown, chairman and president, announced yesterday.

"I DON'T believe much in lofty sentiments," J.M.G. LeClezio confesses in his "Introductory Letter" to these nine short stories. "In their place I see an army of insects or ants, nibbling in all directions. Sometimes these tiny black arrows join together, and men lose their mental balance. For a few minutes, a few hours, chaos and...

WESTON, Conn., July 21 Lealand R. Gustavson, a widely known magazine and book illustrator, died yesterday after a short illness at the Westport Manor Convalescent Home in Westport. He was 67 years old and lived at Kettle Creek Road here.

GLEN RIDGE, N.J., July 21 Mal Lindstrom and Dr. Gerald Dederick established a tournament record today when they shot a 30, 38 68 to win the 21st annual New Jersey State Golf Association Scotch four- somes championship at the Glen Ridge Country Club.
LONDON, July 21 Uncertainty in the markets and among financial experts greeted the British Government's emergency economic program today.
After 20 years of varied jazz explorations, Jimmy Giuffre has pulled all the threads together to mold one of the most broadly based styles in jazz today.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., July 21 A grant from the state council on the arts will enable Pace College Westchester and the Music for Westchester Symphony Orchestra to bring professional orchestral music to central and northern Westchester county.
CHILI, N.Y., July 21 The mutilated bodies of two teenaged schoolgirls who had been missing 25 days were found yesterday near this Rochester suburb.

An initial public offering yesterday of Medicenters of America, Inc., common stock at $10 a share was quickly sold out and rose to a premium. The 150,000-share offering was managed by the Equitable Securities Corporation. Late in the day the stock was quoted at 14 14 . The Memphis-based company licenses and proposes to own and operate facilities for patients, mainly those who have received intensive hospitalization.

HONG KONG, July 21 (Reuters) Communist China said tonight that the Chinese engineer whose death in The Hague caused a diplomatic incident, jumped out of a window after United States agents had induced him to defect to the West.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., July 21 A circuit judge issued a temporary injunction today preventing Illinois from applying Gov. Otto Kerner's new open occupancy order to two Springfield real estate brokers.

Rabbi Zvi Eisenstadt, a member of the presidium of Agudath Israel and of the Union of Orthodox Rabbis, died Wednesday of a heart attack in the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 65 years old, and had lived at 319 Crown Street, Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) Spurred by increased payrolls and Social Security benefits, personal income in June climbed by $3.4-billion to a record $576.4-billion on a seasonally adjusted annual basis.

Teledyne, Inc., of Los Angeles, said yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle with the National Rolling Mills Company, of Malvern, Pa. a steel fabricator, to acquire that company in a stock transaction valued at about $11.6million.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) A Mississippi Representative said today that his Northern colleagues kept silent about rioting in Negro areas of their cities.
NEW ORLEANS, July 21 (AP)--The Federal Government filed suit today to desegregate the schools of Plaquemines Parish (County).
A man the police picked up yesterday on a narcotics charge turned out, they said, to be a fugitive wanted in a murder for which another man had been convicted.
NANTICOKE, Pa., July 21 (UPI) Twenty miners were overcome by smoke today when fire broke out in the shaft of a mine where 150 men were working. Some of the miners were trapped for as long as an hour.

The closing of the doors of the stately Hudson County Courthouse earlier this year echoed across the country. When the judges left their marble-colonnaded courtrooms for functional modern quarters in a new building next door, they made a move that is being made, in one form or another,...

PARIS, July 21 Carette, a character actor who appeared in 115 films made in France, never playing a leading role but better-known by face here than many stars, died yesterday of burns following an accident. He was 68 years old.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 21 Dr. Fred Norris Robinson, a leading authority on Chaucer and Celtic philology, died today at Harvard University's Stillman Infirmary. He was 95 years old.
GENEVA, July 21 (AP) The Soviet Union challenged today the United States' contention that its nuclear weapons were guarded by foolproof electronic locks.
Savings banks here fresh from their success in pushing a major expansion of their branching and lending powers through the last session of the New York Legislature are now preparing a new campaign.
PHILADELPHIA, July 21 John J. Clutz, director of research for the Pennsylvania Railroad, died last night at Jefferson Hospital after heart surgery. He was 62 years old.
WASHINGTON, July 21 Freight traffic generated by carloadings on U.S. railroads and intercity truck tonnage in the week ended July 16 were both ahead of the corresponding week of last year.
LONDON, July 21 "Except ye utter by the tongue words easy to be understood, how shall it be known what is spoken?"
LOS ANGELES, July 21 (AP) John Kennedy was hit by a pitch with the bases loaded in the 10th inning tonight, giving the Los Angeles Dodgers a 4-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.
HOUSTON, July 21 (AP) Mike Cuellar came out of the bull pen to help Dave Giusti gain his 10th victory of the season tonight as the Houston Astros defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 3-2.
The City Human Rights Commission has asked the Supreme Court to direct the owner of a house in an all-white section of Brooklyn to sell it to two Negro women.

ROME, July 21--There are grumbles. After four days of Italian couturier fashions, Sydney Gittler, vice president and coat buyer of Ohrbach's, said a few tart words. He thinks that most of the Italian designers now showing their winter collections are "designing for the theater or for Gina Lollobrigida."
Two Staten Island youths were arraigned in Criminal Court yesterday on charges of attempted arson of a home at 519 Tompkins Avenue.
HOUSTON, July 21 The Gemini 10 crew left 22 pieces of equipment in space, but most of it was in one big bag to avoid unnecessary littering of space.

JERICHO, L.I., July 21 Gen. Francis of the Wheatley Hills Golf Club won the medal today with a 35, 37 72 as the Long Island Golf Association amateur tournament opened at the Meadow Brook Club. Par for the 6,696-yard course is 36, 35 71.
LONDON, July 21 The Government took steps today to control use of the increasingly popular drug, LSD-25.
WESTBURY, L.I., July 21 Interloper, a 6-year-old bay horse who dotes on distance the farther he travels, the faster he trots rallied to capture tonight's $10,000 main event at Roosevelt Raceway.

The operations of the Crown Zellerbach Corporation in the three and six months ended June 30 achieved the highest sales and earnings for these periods in its history, according to the midyear report issued yesterday.

Fifty women prisoners will be moved beginning Sept. 1 from the overcrowded Women's House of Detention here to Westfield State Farms, at Bedford Hills, N.Y. The Westfield unit is a women's penal institution of the State Department of Correction.
The state assured Edwin Cordarre yesterday that after spending 23 of his 36 years in prison, he could remain free.
Application of space age technology to traffic control is near, Henry Ford 2d said yesterday.

The Texas Utilities Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday June quarter operating revenues of $71,470,199, compared with $65,523,354 a year earlier. Net income rose to $13,390,952, equal to 53 cents a share, from $12,773,424, or 50 cents a share, one year ago.

BALTIMORE, July 21 (AP) Frank Robinson rapped out four hits, including two homers, and drove in three runs tonight as the Baltimore Orioles whipped Detroit, 6-4, and increased their American League lead to 11 games over the slumping second-place Tigers.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, July 22 (AP) Two United States planes went down over North Vietnam yesterday, raising the total lost in the war to 300, United States military headquarters reported today.

The Democratic judicial convention for Manhattan and the Bronx will nominate early next month four candidates for Supreme Court Justiceships, whose election is virtually assured in these predominantly Democratic areas. We are glad to see that Senator Robert F. Kennedy is demanding their selection without political deals and after public rating of the candidates' qualifications by the bar associations.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) A Federal judge upheld today the right of the Secretary of State to withhold a passport from Staughton Lynd, who has been critical of United States policy in Vietnam.

PROVIDENCE R.I., July 21 Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Franklin Vaughan have announced the engagement of Mrs. Vaughan's daughter, Miss Isabel Perry Hitz, to Stephen Dodge Goff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Darius Lee Goff of Warwick Neck.

MOSCOW, July 21 (AP) The Soviet youth newspaper accused a United States diplomat today of spreading anti-Soviet feeling among foreign students in Moscow and of gathering intelligence. The United States Embassy denied the charges.
CLEVELAND, July 21--A young Negro mother was critically wounded by police gunfire today as she and four members of her family fled spreading disorders on the city's East Side.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 21 Like some runaway space vehicle headed for the outer planets without even stopping at the moon, the New York Mets soared into unexplored realms today by crushing the San Francisco Giants, 14-3, for their sixth victory in succession.

Mrs. Rosalinde Schmetterling Spies of 10 East End Avenue and Shepard Spies, also of Manhattan, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Hermine Spies, to Jerrold Lee Morgulas, son of David Morgulas of 169 East 69th Street and the late Mrs. Morgulas. The wedding will take place on Sept. 11.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) Jim Merritt tied an American League record for consecutive strike-outs and hurled a three-hitter tonight as he pitched the Minnesota Twins to a 1-0 victory over the Washington Senators.
WASHINGTON, July 21 The 15 nations that provide 90 per cent of the world's foreign aid agreed today to give much greater attention to the rapidly worsening food problem.
A rally in the final hour of trading took most of the sting out of another decline in the stock market yesterday.
Saw Prime Minister Forbes Burnham of Guyana and later gave White House luncheon in his honor; received a pledge of full support for U.S. policy in Vietnam from the Thai Prime Minister.

THE Brooklyn tournament of the Greater New York Bridge Association has been held in Manhattan for the last several years, but the association's board of directors has chosen to retain the traditional name. Play begins this afternoon at the New York Hilton Hotel, and the schedule is:

The six members of the all-America golf team will get an extra treat when they are honored at an Aug. 9 dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria. That afternoon, dinner officials said yesterday, the collegians will play a round at the Westchester Country Club with Dave Marr, now defending his Professional Golfers' Association championship.

JERSEY CITY, July 21 A woman physician, who "saved" the trees along Kennedy Boulevard here, and a 77-year-old lawyer and former county judge are among the "interested citizens" mounting a campaign to save the Hudson County Courthouse from demolition.
WALPORZHEIM, Germany, July 21 Britain will make substantial reductions in her military forces in West Germany following an impasse reached in financial talks between the two nations today.

DARIEN, Conn., July 21 Dr. Daryl W. Pelletier, a school superintendent in Pearl River, N.Y., has been named superintendent of the public school system here. He succeeds Dr. Gregory C. Coffin, who resigned earlier in the year to take a school post in Illinois.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 21 Howard McMichael, an old hand at winning honors in the International One-Design Class on Long Island Sound, took a stride toward another one today on the sixth day of Larchmont Race Week. The afternoon was less than satisfactory for wind but not entirely bad.

AKRON, Ohio, July 21 Sam Snead limped along the 7,180yard Firestone Country Club course today but his score was a sprightly two-under-par 68 and he shared the first-round lead with Al Geiberger in the Professional Golfers' Association championship.

AFTER reading a commission report on the causes of last summer's racial riots in the Watts area of Los Angeles, Ralph Sidney Locher, the mild-mannered Mayor of Cleveland, said that there was "no impending furor" in his city. Now Mr. Locher (it rhymes with poker) is trying...
LANDER, Wyo., July 21 (AP) The body of Arthur Saltus, 18 years old, of Morristown, N.J, was recovered early today from the Wind River mountain range about 35 miles northwest of Lander.

WASHINGTON, July 21 On a trip to California in February, 1964, Senator Thomas J. Dodd his reported to have charged the air travel to both the Los Angeles Junior Chamber of Commerce and the Senate Subcommittee on Juvenile Delinquency.
SUN VALLEY, Idaho, July 21 (AP) A memorial to Ernest Hemingway was dedicated today in the area where he often came to write and hunt.
With a comeback reminiscent of past glories, the Yankees extended their winning streak to six games yesterday with a 4-3 11th-inning victory over the Kansas City Athletics at the Stadium.

POUND RIDGE, N.Y., July 21 Mrs. Irving Kaufmann and Mrs. Robert Benheim both of the Century Country Club advanced today to the final of the Women's Tri-County Golf Association championship at High Ridge Country Club.
An 11-year-old Negro boy was killed by a sniper's bullet last night shortly after fighting broke out between Negroes and whites in the East New York section of Brooklyn.
The spot rate on the British pound continued to improve yesterday in quiet trading on foreign-exchange markets here.
Inspector Charles Eugene McCarthy peered into the police car, scanned the number of walkie-talkies and then stepped quickly into the Fourth Precinct on Ericcson Place, near the Holland Tunnel.
WASHINGTON, July 21 In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals the following proceedings were had today:

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 21 Keene Daigerfield, a steward representing the New Jersey State Racing Commission, trained his binoculars on Irish Charger in the sixth race today at Monmouth Park. Then he shifted them to the jockey, Luis Flores, a 24-year-old Panamanian. The six-furlong event was almost half over. Daigerfield thought something was amiss, so he quickly telephoned all the patrol judges and instructed them to watch Flores's actions.

For nine years, ending last January, the earth apparently had a natural satellite that finally plunged into the atmosphere according to a report in the current issue of the British scientific journal, Nature.

PARIS Washington departed from previous policy this week when it initiated negotiations with France to explore possible reactivation of American bases and pipeline facilities here in case of emergency. These installations are now being evacuated as a result of General de Gaulle's withdrawal from NATO's integrated structure and command.

WHITE PLAINS, July 21 Greg Powers, the 20-year-old champion at the Country Club of Darien, won the medal today in qualifying for the 47th annual Westchester amateur golf championship at Westchester Hills Golf Club.
TEL AVIV, July 21 A young tractor driver who was abducted late Monday night from an Israeli vineyard and taken to Egyptian territory, reappeared this morning.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., July. 21 (UPI) The body of Otis A. Glazebrook 3d, an executive of the Canada Dry Corporation, was found by the State Police today in Lake Placid. Mr. Glazebrook, who was 46 years old, had been missing from his summer home here since early last night.
IN the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe. Chicken with lime Rice Buttered green beans Avocado and lettuce salad Grapefruit and orange sections

MONTAUK, L.I. For Margaret Cousins, journey's end every Friday night is an 18th century cottage on almost three acres of clifftop land, with only the occasional sway of a pine branch to interfere with a view that seems to stretch clear across the Atlantic.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) Secretary of State Dean Rusk expressed surprise today at the dismissal by the International Court of Justice of a complaint against South Africa's system of racial Separation.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, July 22 (AP) A young Buddhist monk who was presumed to have set himself afire, was quoted by the police today as having said he had not attempted suicide. The police said he told them he thought someone had tried to kill him.

The Board of Estimate voted yesterday to increase the fare from 15 to 20 cents on the 74 subsidiary bus lines of the Transit Authority in Manhattan and the Bronx and on the seven private bus lines in the city.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, July 21 Ondine, Sumner A. (Huey) Long's much-traveled 57-foot aluminum yawl from New York, added the 1966 trans-Atlantic race from Bermuda, to the many triumphs she has scored in ocean races in all parts of the world.

WASHINGTON, July 21 A joint Congressional Committee offered a blueprint today streamlining Congress. But the committee stopped far short of urging sweeping changes that critics insist must be made in the cumbersome machinery.
Mayor Lindsay paid a condolence call last night on the family of Eric Dean, the 11-yearold boy who was slain by a sniper's bullet earlier in the evening in East New York.
PASADENA, Calif., July 21 (AP) The United States spacecraft Surveyor I has taken its last picture of the moon's surface.

John J. Pflieger, a 68-yearold retired exporter and importer who likes sailing around ocean waters in a 26foot boat that was designed for limited waters, was the object of a Coast Guard air search yesterday in the vicinity of Antigua, in the Leeward Islands.

AREA A Mackerel on the offshore fishing grounds are the big action of the moment. They weigh about three-quarters of a pound each. The bottom fishing remains good with ling the principal catch. The blues are spotty, and taken well offshore when they can be found.
Business borrowings at major banks in New York and Chicago, a key indicator of credit demand, increased during the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
Saint-Saens's "Samson et Dalila," rained out at Lewisohn Stadium on Tuesday, was presented last night by the Metropolitan Opera.
GENERAL ASSEMBLY Special Committee on Apartheid Discussed World Court decision on South-West Africa.
Charges of "lies and double talk" have been leveled at Mayor John V. Lindsay and the city administration in a report issued by the Brooklyn Library Council.
A rare Roman bronze sculpture goes on exhibition today at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, which has shown it twice before and now has it for keeps.
Short-term securities prices continued to rise early yesterday although Treasury bills lost their early gains.
STEUBENVILLE, Ohio, July 21 Miss Barbara Jane Flynn and William Allen Churchill, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Randolph Churchill of Greenwich, Conn., will be married Aug. 20.

WASHINGTON, July 21 The alliance of seven Western states supporting the $1.7-billion Lower Colorado River projects bill was shaken today as the House Interior Committee voted for an independent study of importing water into the Southwest.
It's been a long time between soft carbonated drinks for Benton Bowles, Inc., but yesterday the agency's fountain bubbled over.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) Following is the list of American prisoners captured in Vietnam made available today by the Defense Department. Hometowns were not disclosed.
Charles A. Buckley, 76-yearold former Congressman, was re-elected to his sixth successive term as Bronx County Democratic leader at a meeting of the organization's executive committee yesterday.

BONN, July 21 Chancellor Ludwig Erhard told President de Gaulle today that he "hopes and expects" that when he pays a return visit to Paris next January a permanent solution will have been found for the problem of keeping French troops in West Germany.
Sites in four of the city's five boroughs have been selected for 26 small parks and playgrounds, the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority announced yesterday.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange declined slightly yesterday after having moved irregularly and narrowly in moderately active trading.
ULAN BATOR, Mongolia, July 18--Any prospects of an establishment of diplomatic relations between Mongolia and the United States have been dimmed by the backlash of the war in Vietnam.

UPPER BROOKVILLE, L. I., July 21--Lou Backiel of the Garden City Country Club posted the best gross score today, a 38, 41--79, in the Long Island Seniors Golf Association tournament over the Mill River Club course. Par for the 6,310-yard course is 35, 35--70.
WASHINGTON, July 21 Stricter controls over the pesticide industry and drastic reduction in aerial spraying over populated areas were recommended in a Senate subcommittee report made public today.

BARRINGTON, Ill., July 21 (AP) Mrs. Barbara Fay Boddie, 26 years old, of Shreveport, La., seeking her third straight tle, and 17-year old Jane Hunsberger of Camarillo, Calif., reached the semi-finals of the women's Western amateur golf tournament today.

The athletes are restless. In the wake of the agreement between the National and American Football Leagues and the probable curbing by management of salary and bonus escalation; several of the players have taken a stand with regard to wage increases. They want more now.
ATHENS, July 21 Greek Communists have spurred an international protest campaign against the Greek Government's effort to ban the 60,000-strong Communist-led Lambrakis youth organization.

The First Boston Corporation, New York investment banker, announced yesterday the election of Albert M. Wojnilower as vice president. Mr. Wojnilower continues as economist, a post he has held since joining the company in 1964.
An 18-year-old youth who reportedly threatened to kill two elderly sisters in their apartment at 248 West 17th Street was captured yesterday after he was shot in the leg by a patrolman.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 21 Theodore Cushing Lyman, retired vice president and treasurer of the former John T. Lyman Inc., architectural woodworking concern here, died yesterday at Mountainside Hospital. His age was 65.
HOUSTON, Tex., July 21 (UPI) Dr. Charles Berry, personal physician to the Gemini astronauts, said today he thought Maj. Michael Collins had remained clear-headed throughout his "walk" in space.
WASHINGTON, July 21 A long-established system that had the effect of keeping Negroes off Federal juries in the South has been struck down by a Federal appeals court.

To grasp the significance of the Federally supported theater projects that will begin operation in Providence, R.I., and New Orleans next fall, you have only to examine the indicated attendance figures. In Providence, where the theater will hold 1,000, a total of 40,000 high-school students from every...
WASHINGTON, July 21 Truman Capote said today that a recent Supreme Court decision restricting the police power to question suspects penalized the innocent and the victims.
NEWARK, July 21--A 30-year-old unemployed restaurant worker killed his common-law wife and three children today and then committed suicide by slashing his own throat, the police reported.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., July 21 The world chess champion, Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, suffered his first defeat in the Piatigorsky Cup Tournament here last night, losing to Lajos Portisch of Hungary in the third round.
Mrs. Zaidee Cobb Bliss Good year died yesteday in her summer home at Center Island, L.I. She was 86 years old and lived at 215 East 72d Street.
WASHINGTON, July 21 The United States is holding 19 North Vietnamese sailors as prisoners, apparently with a view to their possible exchange for captured American airmen.

THE mind of the child-molester was explored on Channel 13 Wednesday night as a dozen sexual psychopaths at a mental hospital in the state of Washington racked their souls in a session of group therapy.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., July 21 The defeats of Bill Tryon, the defending champion from Elmira, and Bill Bogle, a 43-year-old Poughkeepsie banker who had been finding the New York State amateur golf championship a breeze, marked the play on the Concord Hotel course today.
The Life Insurance Company of Virginia in Richmond announced yesterday the formation of the First Fund of Virginia, a mutual fund.
NEW DELHI, July 21 The United States has made strong representations to the Indian Government over aspects of the Indian-Soviet communique issued last Saturday in Moscow.

Capt. William Willis, who sailed twice across the Pacific alone on a raft, has been spotted by an American merchant ship 360 miles east of Boston on his current solo voyage across the Atlantic in an 11 foot ketch rigged sailboat, the Little One.
AUSTIN, Tex. July 21 The David W. Robertsons have been back from a year in England only a month, and they are being plagued by newsmen and apparently have been asked to leave their new home.
The New York Railroad Association has agreed to participate in a labor-management committee that will seek to resolve disputes over how to implement the state's recently amended Full-Crew Law.
The London Stock Exchange closed generally firmer yesterday, with industrial shares registering the best gains.
The National Marine Engineers' Beneficial Association threatened yesterday to tie up American shipping in the port if the city failed to rehire 17 former ferryboat officers.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 20 The Yugoslav state security officers dismissed in connection with the ouster of former Vice President Aleksander Rankovic have been charged with having "too close links" with the Soviet secret police organization.

The Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service announced here yesterday that it would halt next month for an indefinite period the transportation of servicemen and their dependents aboard M.S.T.S.transports in the North Atlantic.
Knickerbocker Hospital became the 15th voluntary hospital to reach a wage and benefit settlement with Local 1199 of the Drug and Hospital Employes Union.

When the feature race at Aqueduct ended yesterday, one person appeared certain he knew the winner. He was Eddie Belmonte, the chance-taking jockey who rode the Hobeau Farm's Winnie, the only filly in the sixfurlong sprint.
TOKYO, Friday, July 22 (Reuters) The North Korean Government has proposed a conference of nations concerned on the unification of North and South Korea for the first time in 10 years.
The Port of New York last year handled the largest volume of foreign water-borne trade in its history close to 51 million long tons of general and bulk cargoes.
WASHINGTON, July 21 The clamor from Capitol Hill for President Johnson to "do something" about the two-weekold airline dispute continues to mount.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost of dining in any particular establishment.
Frederick O'R. Hayes will be the city's new Budget Director. His selection has ended a long search for a man to fill one of the most complex and demanding posts in the city administration.
CLEVELAND, July 21 A lack of effective leadership in both the white and Negro communities was blamed today for the riots that have swept the Negro ghetto here.
A newly formed committee of about 3,000 physicians and dentists yesterday asked Congressional leaders for restrictions on New York's Medicaid plan.

The International Nickel Company announced yesterday that because of the strike at its Ontario mines and refineries it had temporarily suspended all shipments of nickel to customers in the United States.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 21 Finance Minister John Wrathall presented today to Parliament a budget that was considered surprisingly routine for a nation that has been faced with virtually worldwide economic sanctions since it unilaterally declared independence from Britain last November.
Councilman Woodward Kingman of Manhattan's Second District opened a neighborhood office yesterday to serve as a sounding-board for the community.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 21 Secretary General Thant reported today to the Security Council that recent developments in Cyprus "may lead to a dangerous increase in tension" and "may even result in a possible threat to the peace in the island."
The Howard Johnson Company announced yesterday the appointment of four new executive vice presidents.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) The House accepted today, by a voice vote, a compromise $5-billion civilian space program for the fiscal year 1967.
GENEVA, July 21 (Reuters) The United States and the Soviet Union agreed today to a treaty article barring any state from claiming sovereignty over space, including the moon and other planets.
ROME, July 22 Long hemlines came rushing back last night in the collection of Alberto Fabiani.

The travel industry yesterday hailed a new ruling by the Federal Maritime Commission that prohibits ship-passenger conferences from demanding that travel agents deal exclusively with conference lines.
Some maids and other household employes who work in New York State no longer have to worry about being laid off when their employers go off to Florida or Europe for the winter.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) The White House said today that President Johnson had invited all Governors, Senators and House members from four states to join him tomorrow for a swing into Indiana, Illinois and Kentucky.

TOKYO, July 22 (Reuters) Leading Japanese steel makers are debating this week the possibility of large-scale mergers which would create giant companies comparable to major steel concerns in the United States.
A psychiatrist from Grand Forks, N.D., has hired a 70piece London orchestra just to record some music he can't find in the record catalogues.
PARIS, July 22 The French Government has decided to go ahead with the building of a purely "national" computer industry, but it has also decided to cut the coat to fit its cloth.

The health of the retailing sector of the economy was underscored yesterday with word that leading chain stores and mail order houses registered a solid 11.5 per cent in- crease in first-half sales over the 1965 level.
LONDON, July 22--A bill extending the legal grounds for abortions performed by doctors won approval in principle in the House of Commons today by a wide margin.

Dr. Emanuel Rosenwasser, a 71-year-old dentist, was found beaten and shot to death yesterday in the bathroom of his office at 301 West 20th Street, near Eighth Avenue, in the Chelsea district. He lived at 805 Park Place, Brooklyn.

BRUSSELS, July 22 In what is supposed to be the homestretch drive to decide on Kennedy round agricultural offers, ministers of the European Common Market have been meeting here for two days with few results.

JERICHO, L.I., July 22 The defending champion, John Baldwin of Plandome, and Gene Francis of Wheatley Hills, the medalist, led the way into the quarter-final round of the Long Island Golf Association amateur championship today at the Meadow Brook Club.

A huge green and white trailer truck, parked at a playground at New Lots Avenue and Barbey Street, was the command post for the massive last night in the racially-troupacification effort of the police bled Brownsville-East New York section of Brooklyn.
ALBANY, July 22 State Controller Arthur Levitt has alerted his auditors to watch for state spending patterns that could signal the need for a tax increase next year.

The Board of Estimate acted sensibly, if reluctantly, in raising the fare on buses from 15 to 20 cents. Unless it had taken this step the Transit Authority would have been required, by the legal provision that it must have a self-sustaining fare structure, to increase the subway fare to 25 cents. Clearly it is far better to impose uniform fares on subways and buses.
Poverty, neglect, blight, crime, ethnic tensions and racial fighting among some of New York's last youth gangs combine into an explosive formula in the East New York-Brownsville section of Brooklyn.
The Pennsalt Chemicals Corporation has announced in Philadelphita the election of Wilmoth C. Mack as a vice president.

William H. Bodine was elected yesterday president of the Savings Association League of New York State. Mr. Bodine, who had served as the league's executive vice president for the last one and a half years, joined its staff in 1955 as executive assistant to the president.
Received credentials from Ambassador Louis Owanga of Gabon and Ambassador Albert Edgar Ritchie of Canada.

A pair of 3-year-olds will go out of their class, one of them for a second time, in the $100,000 added Brooklyn Handicap at Aqueduct today, and they are accorded an excellent chance of beating a quartet of older horses in the 1 -mile race.
An afternoon gold-stock rush added a glint to an otherwise quiet and generally lower stock market yesterday.
All but a handful of the 150 employes now working at the struck World Journal Tribune, Inc., were sent on their vacations last night.
OCEANPORT, N.J. July 22 (AP) Luis Flores, 24-year-old Panamanian jockey, was suspended indefinitely today by the stewards at Monmouth Park for using an electrical device in a race yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 22 The Office of Economic Opportunity opened a new venture in housing for the poor today.

CHATEAUROUX, France, July 22 In the middle of the afternoon in this peaceful little town, 700 French workers who repair planes at an American air base here suddenly demonstrated yesterday against the closing of their factory, and squads of helmeted uniformed riot police moved in to drive them off.

Igor Stravinsky chose the works that were heard at last night's Stravinsky Festival concert at Philharmonic Hall, according to the program. It was an interesting but not a surprising choice that included the current "in" composers with styles akin to those of Stravinsky himself. But the interest generated from reading the titles waned long before the program reached its halfway mark, and the concert as a whole was a consummate bore.

POUND RIDGE, N.Y., July 22 The All-Century Country Club final of the 16th annual Women's Tri-County Golf Association championship today was won by Mrs. Irving Kaufmann, who defeated Mrs. Robert Bendheim, 3 and 2, at High Ridge Country Club.
The London Stock Exchange was dull and idle most of the session yesterday but scattered buying caused prices to edge up over a broad front, bringing about a firm note at the close.
Tiffany glass, which is making its way back to the parlor after 30 years in the attic, is now being offered for sale in an ever-increasing variety of antique shops.
Interior Secretary Stewart L. Udall was accused yesterday of "assisting the demise of the great park system he was pledged to protect."
WASHINGTON, July 22 (UPI) The Senate approved today President Johnson's nominations of 12 new Federal judges five for United States Courts of Appeal.
BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., July 22--This opulent community, which has traditionally been niggardly in supporting its cultural institutions, seems to be experiencing a modest renascence.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) The Lewis and Clark Trail Commission has confirmed the action of 10 states in designating the route for the new Lewis and Clark Trail, the Interior Department reported today.

Mrs. Cecile Amdur Geist, widow of A. Joseph Geist, lawyer and former member of the Board of Higher Education, died yesterday at Brooklyn Jewish Hospital. She was 63 years old and lived at 466 Beach 136th Street, Belle Harbor, Queens.

CARMEL-BY-THE-SEA, Calif., July 22 Miss Carolyn Endres Turner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Pickett Turner Jr. of Dayton, Ohio, was married tonight to Norman Hartland Bouton Jr., son of Mrs. Bouton of Palo Alto, and the late Mr. Bouton. The Rev. David S. Hill performed the ceremony at All Saints Episcopal Church.

OLD WESTBURY GARDENS, L.I, July 22 From May to October, visitors come to Old Westbury Gardens to see the magnificent Phipps Estate, with its art-filled mansion and 70 acres of tree-lined walks, flowered alcoves and formal gardens. There was an added inducement this evening in the form of a concert on the lawn by seven gifted members of the Metropolitan Opera Studio, and many hundred lovers of music and nature were on hand.
WIESBADEN West Germany, July 22 (Reuters) The United States continued to dominate the world shooting championships today, picking up its 17th gold medal by winning the clay pigeon team title.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 22 (AP)--Gaylord Perry lost a no-hit bid in the eighth inning and finished with a two-hitter tonight as the San Francisco Giants beat Philadelphia, 4-1. Perry struck out 15 batters.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) A leader in the organization of Small Business Investment Companies advised the Congress today to keep the program going but to change some of the rules.

A leading crimminal expert derided today as "arrant nonsense" the contention of Truman Capote that the two killers who were the subjects of his book "In Cold Blood" would have gone "scot-free" if they had not confessed.

CHICAGO, July 22 Five youths were shot and wounded in teen-age gang territory on Chicago's South Side last night and early today only a few hours after leaders of two gangs there had pledged a truce in a highly publicized meeting with Police Superintendent Orlando W. Wilson.
More than 1,000 extra policemen moved into the racially troubled East New York section of Brooklyn last night to contain outbreaks of violence.

TROY, N.Y., Saturday, July 23 "They're mad at the world, but we have reached the 'in' crowd," a local civil rights leader said last night as he talked about the group of restless young Negroes who have kept racial tensions high in this upstate city.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 22 North Vietnam has sent what may be an entire infantry division of 8,000 to 10,000 men into South Vietnam's northernmost province of Quangtri, a United States military spokesman said today.

Thirty years after the outbreak of the civil war Franco Spain is caught up in currents of economic and social change that are creating disturbing eddies in the nation's political life. Rapid industrialization and emergence from economic isolation are transforming Spain into a modern nation.

WEST CALDWELL, N.J., July 22 Mrs. Mary Snyder Lawrence, a professional watercolorist who was active in art and women's club circles, died Wednesday at the Montclair Community Hospital at the age of 89. She was the widow of Chester B. Lawrence and lived on Fairfield Avenue here.

WASHINGTON, July 22 The index of primary market prices increased one-tenth of 1 per cent to 106.3 during the week ended July 19, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. Farm products advanced in price while processed foods moved lower. Industrial commodities averaged unchanged.

WHITE PLAINS, July 22 Mr. and Mrs. Burt Lee have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith Peggy Lee, to Theodore Michael Bulow, son of Mrs. Harry N. Bulow of Larchmont and the late Mr. Bulow. A December wedding is planned.
WASHINGTON, July 22 Following are the parties involved, the issues in dispute, and a brief summary of the effects of the airline strike:

LAWRENCE, L.I., July 22 Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Beck have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Helen Beck, to Richard David Kreiss, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney J. Kreiss of Woodmere. The wedding is planned for Oct. 16.
The Art Dealers Association of America has charged Sears, Roebuck Co., Vincent Price and The Los Angeles Times with making "false and misleading statements" regarding the sale of art.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) The Justice Department announced today it had reached a $250,000 settlement in its antitrust damage suits against United Merchants and Manufacturers, Inc., of New York City.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 23 (AP) A dispute that tied up ships in East and West Coast ports since yesterday, when marine engineers walked off their jobs, was settled today.
The fare on the 74 subsidiary bus lines of the Transit Authority and the seven private bus lines in the city will go up to 20 cents at 12:01 A.M. tomorrow.

Even before they move into 24 middle-income projects now under construction here, 7,500 families have been told that their monthly rents or carrying charges in the city- subsidized housing are going up $1.25 to $3.50 a room.
WASHINGTON, July 22 The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) announced today the formation of a "consultative group" for coordination of aid to Peru.

LOS ANGELES, July 22 (AP ) The widow of a Negro motorist, who was shot to death by a white policeman as he sought to rush his wife to a hospital in the belief that she was in labor, gave birth to a son tonight.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) The House Republican leader, Gerald R. Ford of Michigan, said today that a statement by Vice President Humphrey could have contributed to some current racial disorders.
HOUSTON, July 22 (AP) Larry Dierker pitched the Houston Astros to a 5-2 victory over the league-leading Pittsburgh Pirates tonight despite home runs by Bob Bailey and Willie Stargell.

THOUGH written by a scholar, these essays by the Gurney Professor of English Literature at Harvard are aimed at all those who consider books and reading a necessary adornment to life. To be sure, only those who can measure their learning with his will come away without having added something to their sum of knowledge.
PARIS, July 22 (Reuters) The NATO defense college was closed here today. It will be moved to Rome.

ROME, July 22 (AP) Pope Paul VI has approved a recommendation for two Roman Catholic-Lutheran joint committees, one to study mixed marriage and the other to deal with theology, the Vatican announced today.
The New York Telephone Company reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the three and 12 months ended June 30.

MIDDLETOWN, N.J., July 22 (AP) Four persons including a Catholic priest were killed and another was injured today in a head-on collision between a car and a tractor-trailer a mile south of downtown Middletown.

The engagement of Miss Barbara Joan De Canto to Robert Lyon Mayall has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas A. De Canto of the Bronx. Mr. Mayall is the son of Mrs. Herschel Mayall of Airemont, N.Y., and the late Mr. Mayall of Boston.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 22 An East Orange pro, Paul Moran, scored a 36, 32-68 to gain the individual title in the pro-senior tournament at the Montclair Golf Club today and teamed with his partners to take the top three places in the 60-and-over age group.

SAIGON, Saturday, July 23 A Navy pilot shot down over Communist territory more than six months ago was plucked from the jungle by a helicopter this week aftter a daring escape from a prison camp and a grueling march through rugged terrain.
TEL AVIV, July 22 Israel's Ambassador to Bonn deplored today what he called "hypocrisy" in Israeli attitudes toward present-day Germany.

LOS ALTOS, Calif., July 22 (UPI)--Lynn Vidali, a 14-yearold swimmer from San Francisco, set a women's 200-meter individual medley record of 2 minutes 29 seconds today at the Far West swim championships.
A 13th man accused of being a member of a ring that extorted money from homosexuals surrendered yesterday at the office of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) A Social Security Administration spokesman said today there were 133 counties in Southern and Border states that had no hospitals cleared for Medicare participation, though there were hospitals in the counties.
The General Electric Company is entering a new business organic fibers.
An Omaha man who is recovering from a rare brain operation that removed a malignant tumor is disproving some of the traditional textbook concepts of what the brain can and cannot do.
The United States Weather Bureau, at 6 P.M. yesterday, made this forecast for Long Island Sound, Montauk Point to Block Island, New York Harbor, the lower Hudson River and nearby waters.
Copper futures dropped the full 2 cents-a-pound limit in some contracts yesterday after wire bars in London slumped 2 cents a pound.

DC International, Inc., one of the nation's largest trucking companies, announced a loss yesterday for the 26 weeks ended July 2. The company, until recently known as the Denver-Chicago Trucking Company, had expected to show a substantial profit.

Deputy Mayor Timothy W. Costello has disclosed that Federal authorities are "delighted" with the success of New York City's summer Urban Corps program and have agreed to make it a year-round operation.

CHICAGO, July 22 (AP) The Illinois Appellate Court reversed today a lower court order that had postponed a scheduled annual meeting of stockholders of Crucible Steel Company. The company is the object of a fight for control.
Financial institutions united yesterday in expressing opposition to a proposals by the Johnson Administration and the Federal Reserve to impose controls on rates paid on savings accounts.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Saturday, July 23 (AP) Policemen and a crowd of several thousand people battled early today outside a Belfast prison where a firebrand Protestant preacher and two other ministers are held.
About 100 state employes demonstrated yesterday for more comfort, chanting, "It's too darn hot," in weather that was too pleasant for their purposes.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (UPI) Luci Baines Johnson's forthcoming wedding has aroused so much public interest that President and Mrs. Johnson are planning a showcase display of past White House wedding memorabilia.

PHILADELPHIA, July 22 (AP) Jerry Wolman, owner of the Philadelphia Eagles of the National Football League, exercised an option today and purchased the Yellow Cab Company of Philadelphia and two of its subsidiaries for $5million.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, July 23 A young Buddhist monk died last night of burns suffered when his robes caught fire outside a Saigon political cocktail party, the police announced today. They said his deat hwas murder.

CLEVELAND, July 22 By day, the Negro section here is a sun-dappled, decaying slum filled with quiet people going about their business. By night, it is dotted with fires and filled with armed patrols and jeering residents.
WASHINGTON, July 22 Canada pledged another $10million today in soft-loan funds for Latin America to be administered by the Inter-American Development Bank.

Mrs. Mary W. Sprague Nicholas, the wife of Peter H. Nicholas, a vice president of Russell Marketing Research, Inc., died yesterday in the Neurological Institute of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center after a brief Illness. Her age was 46 and she resided on Jericho Road, Syosset, L.I.

VIENNA, July 22 (AP) A former Polish diplomat says Poland has worked out plans for a four-nation federation in Eastern Europe to halt the political and military disintegration in the Soviet bloc led by Rumania.
ATHENS, July 22 The Greek Government agreed tonight to cede a 2,700-acre seaside estate to the Greek Orthodox Archbishopric in America for a summer camp for American children of Greek origin.
A program of Italian pagentry called "Festa Italiana," will make its American debut at Madison Square Garden on Sept. 29, running through Oct. 12.

BALTIMORE, July 22 (UPI) Brooks Robinson's two-run homer in the first inning and the six-hit pitching of Jim Palmer tonight helped the Baltimore Orioles defeat the Chicago White Sox, 3-1. The victory was the Orioles' sixth in a row.

FREEHOLD, N.J., July 22 A murder indictment has been returned in the death of a 52-year-old retired Army colonel whose body was exhumed from Arlington National Cemetery after the mysterious death of the woman physician who signed his death certificate.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., July 15-- Some weeks ago, Gov. Grant Sawyer of Nevada replied sharply to Gov. George Romney of Michigan when in a speech here Mr. Romney suggested that the election of a Republican Governor might be good for family life and moral values. Mr. Sawyer, a Democrat, demanded to ...
Some serious ethical questions have been raised about the President's Club, that extraordinarily successful fund-raising organization run by the Democratic National Committee.
THE HAGUE, July 22 The Netherlands Government strongly protested today Peking's accusation that it had aided United States agents in an effort to persuade Mr. Hsu to defect.

Edwin W.C. Ludewig, acting assistant commissioner of environmental health services and director of the bureau of foods and drugs for the city's Department of Health, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived at 178 East 77th Street.

The Sun Chemical Corporation will make a tender offer to purchase a minimum of 350,000 shares of common stock of the Harshaw Chemical Company, Cleveland, at $40 a share, Norman E. Alexander, president of Sun Chemical, announced yesterday.
TOKYO, July 22 Charges that Japanese physicists are contributing to scientific knowledge in Communist China will be investigated by the Government, Minister of Education Umekichi Nakamura said today.
CHICAGO, July 22 Two court-appointed heart specialists reported today that Richard F. Speck had suffered an inflammation of the heart sac rather than a heart attack.
There's a new design in buses and usually well-rounded circles are wondering whether there shouldn't be a civilian review board for the Transit Authority.

AKRON, Ohio, July 22 Although the 7,180-yard, par-70 Firestone Country Club course showed signs of wilting today, Sam Snead's game withstood the test as he assumed the 36hole lead in the Professional Golfers' Association championship. A second round of 71 gave the 54-year-old campaigner an aggregate of 139 and a onestroke advantage over Al Geiberger and Don January.
WASHINGTON, July 22--The airline strike dragged into its third week today with no sign of an early settlement.
Gold is hard to recover in many of the world's gold mines, and the mines in the United States are no exception.
MIAMI Doug Bull of the United States won the Beacon Challenge Cup series today in the International Dinghy Association regatta after finishing fifth in the final race.
GENEVA, July 22 The International Committee of the Red Cross said tonight that it was continuing its efforts in behalf of all victims of the war in Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (UPI) The Senate gave final Congressional approval today to a bill authorizing $5,000,419,000 this fiscal year for the space program. Much of the money was earmarked for manned flight to the moon.

"HE is such a dull dog to have such influence," a Western diplomat once remarked or Liu Shao-chi, the "organization man" who is Communist China's chief of state. The gaunt, gray figure of Mr. Liu emerged yesterday from the shadows, where he organizes, arranges, indoctrinates, ...
New-car sales of the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation rose in the second 10 days of July from last year's level.

WHITE PLAINS, July 22 Craig Harmon of Winged Foot, the defending champion, won two matches today and led the way into the quarterfinal round of the 47th annual Westchester amateur golf championship at the Westchester Hills Golf Club.
WASHINGTON, July 22 Two electronics engineers were granted a patent this week for a system that, they believe, assures continuous and efficient communication ...

GENEVA, July 22 The Rev. Dr. Eugene Carson Blake, secretary general-elect of the World Council of Churches, said today that the church must "march with those in the society who alone cannot win their battle for justice, freedom and equality."

GENEVA, July 22 The United States and the Soviet Union agreed today that the military might visit the moon and other celestial bodies provided their sole aim was "scientific research or any other peaceful purpose."
HONG KONG, July 22 Communist China today made the head of a Dutch diplomatic mission in Peking hostage for the safe departure from the Netherlands of a Chinese technical delegation.
SINGAPORE, July 22 The Malaysian Government today offered surrender terms to Communists in Sabah and Sarawak.
Mary Hemingway, the widow of Ernest Hemingway, won the right yesterday to have a jury trial determine whether the book "Papa Hemingway" had violated her right of privacy.

VUNGTAU, South Vietnam, July 22 The war has finally come to Vungtau, not with bombs and bullets but with 4,000 American and Australian troops and the wine, women and song young soldiers bring in their wake.
LAKE CHARLES, La., July 22 (AP) Charles L. Coltman, public-information officer for the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization, died today in a hospital here. He was 53 years old.

WARSAW, July 22 (AP) The Communist Government proclaimed itself heir to 10 centuries of Polish history today with a dazzling military review featuring everything from spearmen to rocket troops and supersonic MIG-21 jets.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., July 22 Showing no concern that his opponents were 30 years or so his senior, Nick Raasch of upstate De Witt won twice today to reach the final of the New York State amateur golf championship.
PHILADELPHIA, July 22 (AP) Philadelphia antipoverty officials, with most of the vote counted, said tonight they were "encouraged" by the turnout in the city's special poverty election.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) Eight Senators urged the Interstate Commerce Commission today to speed the final approval of the merger of the Pennsylvania and New York Central railroads.

The spot rate on the British pound dipped slightly in active trading on foreign-exchange markets here yesterday. After a fair amount of movement, the currency closed at $2.7911, down 5 points from Thursday.

DETROIT, July 22 (UPI) The Ford Motor Company began its production of 1967 cars this week, Ward's Automotive Reports said today. Industry production dropped as other plants began tooling for 1967 models.
RICHMOND, Va., July 22 The State Board of Elections certified today that Senator A. Willis Robertson lost to William B. Spong Jr. by 611 votes in the Democrat primary election July 12.

THE Brooklyn Championships continue this after- noon at the New York Hilton. The main event of the day will be the Open Pair Championship at 1:30 and 7:30. In the final day of play tomorrow the experienced players will be struggling for the Open Team title, but there will also be an extensive program for novices.

QUINCY, Mass., July 22 (AP) Superior Court Judge Edward O. Gourdin, one of the first Negroes named to the state's Superior Court bench and a former Harvard and Olympic track star, died last night in Quincy City Hospital at the age of 68.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (UPI) A spokesman for the American Civil Liberties Union testified today that a bill aimed at the Ku Klux Klan was so broad it conceivably could encompass United States spies, Congressmen, labor unions, policemen and college fraternities.

BARRINGTON, Ill., July 22 (AP) Mrs. Barbara Fay Boddie of Shreveport, La., seeking her third straight championship, and Peggy Conley of Spokane, Wash., will meet tomorrow in the 36-hole final of the women's Western amateur golf tournament.
"Can I get out by tonight?" asked a middle-aged man hopefully at American Airlines stand-by counter at Kennedy International Airport yesterday morning.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 22 Israel asked the Security Council today to meet urgently to consider complaints of aggression against Israeli territory by Syrian armed forces.

NANTUCKET, Mass. Behind the mullioned win dows of a shop almost at the foot of Main Street is a collection of highly unusual fashion and interiors fabrics, most of which are woven on looms at the back of the shop and in a large room on the second floor.
Gold and mining issues were strong in an otherwise irregular market on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.
BEDFORD, Mass., July 22 Masked bandits carrying machine guns held up the crew of a Brink's, Inc., armored truck today and escaped with $131,000 in cash and $16,000 in negotiable checks.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 22 The Actor's Workshop was pronounced dead today at the age 14. The end came after the Chamber of Commerce declined to provide a $75,000 transfusion.

RYE, N.Y., July 22 Pettus Vinton Hoyle of Boat Lane here, retired editor of Tobacco Leaf, a trade paper published in New York, died yesterday in a nursing home at Bridgeport, Conn. He was 89 years old.

Sponge the "organization" that jeered at Mayor Lindsay in East New York Thursday night and later staged an antiNegro demonstration that provoked a reply in gunshots, beer and soda bottles really is not an organization at all.
LONDON, July 22 (UPI) Unbeaten Portugal, driving toward the world soccer championship, will keep its line-up intact against underdog North Korea tomorrow in their World Cup quarter-final match.
BARMOUTH, Wales, July 22 (AP) Eleven passengers including five children, drowned today when a small excursion steamer hit a wooden bridge and overturned.

A color film is being planned around "The Trial," Gunther Schuller's operatic adaptation of the Franz Kafka novel, which will be given its world premiere in October by the Hamburg State Opera Company.

Gasoline supplies in the United States fell to 184,349,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday from 187,436,000 in the preceding week and 191,890,000 barrels in the corresponding week a year ago, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.
CHICAGO, July 22 (UPI) The St. Louis Cardinals hit four home runs today as they defeated the Chicago Cubs, 9-4. The victory extended their winning streak to five games, their longest of the season.
Lew Burdette, who began his major league career with the New York Yankees in 1950, came back to the Stadium last night and defeated his former teammates, 6-4, for his 200th major league victory.
The Dow Chemical Company has raised prices on selective magnesium mill products an average of 3 per cent.

Sidney Bernstein, a leading Off Broadway producer, whose interest was "in plays that, loosely speaking, comment make some comment," died of a heart attack yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 56 years old and lived at 55 East Ninth Street.

An 11-year-old boy and a 54-year-old man killed by snipers. A 3-year-old boy critically wounded by another sniper. A young mother and three children wounded in still another episode. From East New York and from Cleveland come these latest instances of needless death and suffering. The scene changes, but the story of Harlem and Watts and West Side Chicago is being repeated.
Both sides in the construction industry dispute rejected state and city mediation offers yesterday as plumbers threatened to go on strike Monday with operating engineers.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 22 Two 21-year-old residents of this suburban town were accused today of breaking into a cemetery mausoleum and robbing bodies of wedding rings, diamond broaches and gold dental fillings.
TOKYO, July 22 (Reuters) The Japanese economy is well on its way to stable growth after a recession in 1964-65, a Japanese Government report said today.

BONN, July 22 Mayor Willy Brandt of West Berlin said today that the threatening tone of recent East German propaganda reminded him of the line taken just before the wall separating East and West Berlin was built in August, 1961.

GROTON, Conn., July 22 The nuclear-powered submarine Flasher, called the best attack craft of her kind in the world, was commissioned by the Navy here today preparatory to being assigned to the Pacific.

LOS ANGELES, July 22 A twice-discarded 35-year-old pitcher and three prominent members of the "yout" of America carried the New York Mets to their seventh consecutive victory, 3-0, over the Los Angeles Dodgers tonight.

LONDON, July 22 (AP) A 17th-century painting that had been bought at a country auction this year for five shillings 70 cents was sold today at Christie's, the auction house, for the equivalent of $4,116.
BONN, July 22 Adam Opel, A.G., the West German subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation, has a plant in the city of Bochum that is built on top of a hole in the ground.
OSLO, Norway, July 22 (Reuters) An international conference on color television ended here today after failing to agree, on a unified European system.

CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., July 22 Mr. and Mrs. James P. Terzian have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathryn Terzian, to Stanton Howard Cramer, son of Dr. and Mrs. Howard I. Cramer of Ardmore, Pa. The wedding is planned for Oct. 1.

Mr. and Mrs. Herman Durell of Jamaica Estates, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Iris Alvina Durell, to Gerald Hillman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Hillman of Woodside, Queens. The wedding is planned for Sept. 5.
LONDON, July 22 (AP) An official of Britain's railway system apologized today to more than 200 commuters for delivering them to the wrong station.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., July 22 The University of Michigan has joined the growing ranks of colleges that are planning new theaters on their campuses.

The Union Carbide Corporation reported yesterday the ninth successive quarterly sales and earnings record for the three months ended June 30. The chemical company also recorded its best results for any half-year in the first six months of 1966, Birny Mason Jr., chairman, said.

Congoleum-Nairn, Inc., directors declared yesterday a 100 per cent stock distribution and an increase in the quarterly cash dividend to 40 cents a share on the stock outstanding. Both are payable Aug. 19 to stock of record Aug. 5. Shareholders had received 25 cents a share in prior quarters of this year.
WEST ORANGE, N.J., July 22 Mrs. Wilson S. Elmore of Essex County fired a 42, 36, 78 today to win a Women's New Jersey Golf Association tournament at the Rock Spring by a stroke.

Negro women picketing a recruiting office in Harlem, and a group of Negro clergymen deliberating in a church only a few blocks away gave widely differing views yesterday of what they meant by the term black power.
Mayor Lindsay took the advice of some of his more acerbic critics literally yesterday. He put his commissioners behind bars.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 22 After countless stonedustings, draggings, spraying, raking and harrowings, Paul (Tex) Tankersley will stonedust, drag, spray, rake and harrow the Roosevelt Raceway track for the last time tomorrow night when the Nassau County harness racing course ends its current meeting.
NORWALK, Conn., July 22 Christian Miller, a former vice president of the Edwards Company, communications and signaling equipment manufacturers, died today. He was 86 years old.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 22 The last Australian was eliminated from the Pennsylvania men's lawn tennis championship singles today with the defeat of Owen Davidson by Stanley Smith of Pasadena, Calif., at the Merion Cricket Club.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., July 22 (UPI) A meeting that could hold the key to Jacksonville's racial peace ended today with Negro leaders giving no indication whether they were content with the city's integration progress report.

WASHINGTON, July 22 Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today that more intensive military steps against North Vietnam, such as bombing the port of Haiphong, could lead to a broadened conflict, with the danger of a nuclear conflagration.
KADUNA, Nigeria, July 22 An atmosphere of peace has finally returned to this vast Northern Region in the wake of the week-long rioting that took at least several hundred lives last month.

GROSSE POINTE FARMS, Mich. The kicky, kooky young look is out in Grosse Pointe. But that was to be expected because, as one of the major purveyors of fashion in this rich suburb is quick to explain, "It was never in."

Four members of a delegation sponsored by the Congress of Racial Equality were ejected from the United States mission to the United Nations after having refused to leave shortly before 6 o'clock last night.

TELEVISION finally got around to doing some- thing for this country's least vocal minority the aged. Government statistics indicate that there are about 19 million people over 65 living in the United States today, but TV's notorious solicitation of the young and their dollars has all but disbarred older residents from participation in the mixed blessings of mass culture.
WASHINGTON, July 22--Senator J. W. Fulbright charged today that "under the emerging Asian doctrine the United States is taking on the role of policeman and provider for all of non-Communist Asia."

WHITE PLAINS, July 22 J. Hubert Anderson of Green Meadow Road in Pleasantville, an executive editor in the educational division of The Read- er's Digest at Chappaqua, died of a heart attack here last night. He was 50 years old.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) Senator Thomas J. Dodd accused North Vietnamese leaders today of "legal skulduggery" in citing the Nuremberg trials as justifying their threats ...

CHILI, N.Y., July 22 At the swimming hole in Black Creek the sun was warm today, but instead of ringing to the usual shouts of children swimming and diving the area was so quiet that the chirp of a bird deep in the brush could be heard.
Bond prices continued to advance yesterday at the close of the first general weekly rally in the market in more than a month.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 22 Dr. Philipp Frank, mathematician, physicist and philosopher of science, died here last night at age 82. He had been a professor at Harvard University from 1939 until his retirement in 1954.
MOSCOW, July 22 (AP)--Soviet cultural authorities are rerouting the jazz group of Earl (Fatha) Hines, the American pianist, away from Rus- sia's two largest cities, Moscow and Leningrad.

The appointments of Allison S. Greham as public relations consultant and of George S. Mikroulis as special public relations consultant for its Greek division were announced yesterday by Basil C. Zacharis, vice president of Chandris Lines, Inc.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, July 22 (Reuters) Fourteen more yachts crossed the finish line today in the 3,600-mile Bermuda-to-Denmark race.
Four major lumber associations reported a decline of 7.6 per cent in production for the week ended July 16, compared with the level in the corresponding 1965 week.
Seven-year-old Rosalina Rivera left her tenement apartment on West 77th Street yesterday morning, walked around the corner to Public School 87 and was introduced to a new life.

MONTREAL, July 22 Limited services were being maintained with the help of volunteers at 139 hospitals throughout Quebec Province today, as a strike by approximately 32,500 nonspecialized workers ended its first week.

CAIRO, July 22 President Gamal Abdel Nasser tonight accused the United States of delaying a new aid program for the United Arab Republic because of policy conflicts over Israel and Communist China and Egyptian friction with Saudi Arabia.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 22 (UPI) The United States Agency for International Development mission reported today that 22 International Voluntary Services workers had arrived in Vietnam to assist in farm and community development programs.

A seven-story inverted step pyramid on Madison Avenue, a fortress of brooding granite that the Whitney Museum of American Art has built as its new home, is in the last stages of being readied for its opening on Sept. 28.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach said tonight the Federal Government was "prepared to offer any assistance which might be requested or which might reasonably be expected" to help halt the racial riots in cities.
NEW HAVEN, July 22 The Yale Alumni Fund, the oldest and largest unrestricted university gift plan in America, has exceeded $4-million for a year for the first time.
The whites gathered yesterday on the south side of the junction of Livonia and New Lots Avenues in East New York, and spoke only among themselves.
Some of New York City's classiest pool-hall hustlers have lost a home.
The Coast Guard announced yesterday the transfer of International Ice Patrol headquarters from Argentia, Nfld., to New York and the closing down of its air stations at Argentia and Bermuda.
NORTH ADAMS, Mass., July 22 Daniel J. Hawthorne, president of the City Council and former city auditor, died today of a heart attack in his home. He was 61 years old.

WASHINGTON, July 22 Senator Thomas J. Dodd conceded today that his office had submitted two bills for air travel to Los Angeles in February, 1964, but he insisted that one of them was for his wife's transportation.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) Senator Herman E. TalMadge, Democrat of Georgia, introduced a bill today to allow teachers an income tax deduction for any reasonable cost they incurred in obtaining further education in their field.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 22 Howard McMichael, sailing his International One-Design Class sloop, Kangaroo, continued today on his way to a Larchmont Race Week championship. He gained his fourth successive victory today after finishing sixth on the opening day.
CLEVELAND, July 22 The Hough area simmered quietly today.

Although the fabled Liberty ship the Richard Henry Dana has been sold for scrap her name will live on, for yesterday the ship's brass builders' name plate was presented to the Marine Historical Association at a ceremony at Mystic Seaport, Mystic, Conn.

CAMP DRUM, N.Y., July 22 The crack of rifles and roar of convoy trucks are familiar sounds at this National Guard and Army Reserve summer training center. But for the lawyers, advertising men and computer programers here for two weeks this year the sounds have taken on a more ominous note because of the war in Vietnam.
HONG KONG, July 22 Peking appears to be making a new and determined effort to divert the United States from further escalating the war in Vietnam.

Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. has been making behind-the-scenes charges that there is a year-old deal between City Council President Frank D. O'Connor and Democratic "bosses" to obtain for Mr. O'Connor the nomination for Governor.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 22 The Gemini 10 astronauts flew here today for the second step in what has become the ritual welcome for returning space voyagers.

COLUMBUS, Ga., July 22 (UPI) Garland T. Byrd, a candidate for Governor of Georgia, won a Federal court suit today that he said would prevent the Government from forcing communities to bus Negro students outside their districts, against their wishes, to obtain racial balance.
DETROIT, July 22 (UPI)--The Chrysler Corporation pulled out of stock-car racing today, effective next year. It urged the Ford Motor Company, its major competitor, to do the same.
GENOA, Italy, July 22 (Reuters) The police protected Italy's World Cup soccer players from about 700 fans who hurled tomatoes and insults when the beaten team arrived by air from England early today.
LONDON, July 22 John French, one of Britain's bestknown fashion photographers, died last night in a hospital in Surrey. He was 58 years old and had been ill with cancer about a year.
BERLIN, July 22 Party groups were sent out three days running earlier this month to East Berlin's major film theater, the International, to stage protests against the movie shown there.
Herman Kobbe, an architect who ran for Lieutenant Governor of New York as a Socialist in 1934, died on Thursday at his home in Kingston, Jamaica. He was 81 years old.
LUSAKA, Zambia, July 22 The Government announced today that Zambia would resume the export of limited amounts of copper through Rhodesia.

The chairman of the state's new Narcotic Addiction Control Commission predicted here today that from 7,000 to 10,000 users of narcotics would be committed to public care when treatment becomes compulsory next April 1.
SHELTER ISLAND, N.Y., July 22 The American Yacht Club cruise ended without a race today.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) Leaders of the House of Representatives started a collection to buy a wedding present for Luci Johnson, but when she learned about it tonight she asked them not to do so.
TRENTON, July 22--A Madison barber has lost his license for two weeks for cutting the hair on a Negro boy "in an unprofessional manner."

WASHINGTON, July 22 Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., Democrat of North Carolina, proposed today a constitutional amendment that would overturn a Supreme Court ruling limiting the police power to question suspects.
