SANTA MONICA, Calif., July 22 The United States chess champion, Bobby Fischer of Brooklyn, moved into a three-way tie for first place by the end of the fourth round of the Piatigorsky Cup Tournament at the Miramar Hotel here last night.

Broaddus Johnson, a former group sales supervisor for the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company here, died Wednesday in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived on Further Lane, East Hampton, L.I.
BAASTAD, Sweden, July 22 (AP) Fred Stolle of Australia defeated a limping Manuel Santana of Spain, 6-1, 6-4, 10-8, today in the feature match of a two-day tournament of tennis champions.

STOCKHOLM Sweden hopes to greet a record number of American tourists this summer, and Homecoming Year celebrations, planned for visitors of Swedish descent, are expected to be the major reason for the increase.
NEW DELHI, July 23 Man's fate may be written in the stars, but India's leading astrologers differed sharply today on how to read them.

The Chamber of Commerce of Greater Philadelphia has opened a drive to help finance the construction of a $1.5million oceanics research and development laboratory at the University of Pennsylvania's School of Medicine.

IT is axiomatic in the travel industry that, just as there is no one who works harder than the tourist, there is no one more indomitable in the face of odds and obstacles than the pleasure traveler. The strike by the International Association of Machinists, which shut down five domestic airlines at the very peak of the summer travel season, gave the great American tourist one more opportunity to rise to the occasion.

THE way things are being planned in television, anyone with an act will be in great demand for late evening shows. If Johnny Carson and Mery Griffin have declined to give you a spot to sing, dance, tell jokes, discuss your new book or just sit and shoot the trivia, do not be forlorn.
COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., July 23 (AP) The 2,500,000th visitor passed through the Baseball Hall of Fame today. He was Harry Taube of Holland. Ohio, who was accompanied by his wife and two daughters.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., July 23 Miss Milbrey Ewing Sebring, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Orvel Sebring of Villanova, was married today to Dr. Richard Beverly Raney Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Raney of Chapel Hill, N.C.
The Lila Motley Cancer Foundation has pledged $50,000 to purchase a new scanner for the Lila Motley Radiation Pavilion at the New York University Medical Center.

LOS ANGELES, July 23 The civics books say that political candidates compete on the basis of differing stands on "issues." But California's contest for Governor is illustrating how much the competition is turning to carefully managed psychological warfare.
TOKYO, July 23 North Vietnam has established an of- ficial 11-member committee to investigate United States "war crimes" in Vietnam, the Hanoi radio announced today.
BRUSSELS, July 23 In what must be regarded as a sign of the changing times, four important European banks have published a joint study entitled "Capital Markets in Europe."
HAVANA, July 23 (Reuters) Cuba opened today a Soviet-style Palace of Marriages for civil wedding ceremonies.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 23 Justice Bohdan Winiarski, Poland's representative on the International Court of Justice, is a non-Communist whose association with the Communist regime in Warsaw is expected to end concurrently with his service at The Hague.

MOSCOW, July 23 The United States sharply rejected today Moscow's charge that a United States air raid July 7 on targets in the vicinity of the North Vietnamese port of Haiphong had endangered four Soviet merchant ships.
ST. LOUIS, July 23 (UPI) The St. Louis Blues of the National Hockey League announced today the expansion of their farm system to five teams.

James MacGregor Burns, chairman of the department of political science at Williams College, has proposed a "silent armistice" in Vietnam that might lead to a cease-fire and open the way to negotiations while protecting basic United States interests in the Pacific area.

"The Brain Drain" sounds like the title of a science fiction motion picture or the name of a lurid form of psychological welfare. But in educational circles the term is being applied with mounting concern to the draining away of brainpower from other countries, especially the less developed ones, by the United States to meet personnel needs here.

CUTTYHUNK, Mass. Nothing new on Cuttyhunk this year. That's the thing about this lit tle island. It is much the same today as it was 50 years ago, and only slightly different from 100 years before that.

BONN, July 23 The headquarters of the United States Army, Europe, at Heidelberg, and its subordinate command, the United States Seventh Army, at Stuttgart, will be merged, it was announced today. The combined headquarters will be in Heidelberg.
HONOLULU, July 23 (AP) The word from President Kennedy's son is that his name is no longer John-John. It's John.
MOSCOW, July 23 (Reuters) Moscow has its first new telephone directory in four years.
LOS ANGELES, July 23 John Pennel pole vaulted 17 feet 6 inches for a world record today in the Los Angeles Times International Games.
FARELLONES, Chile, July 23 (AP) Heidi Zimmermann of Austria won the women's giant slalom today in warmup competition for next month's world Alpine championships.
WIESBADEN, Germany, July 23 (UPI) The United States was shut out on the final day of competition today, but took top honors in the 39th world shooting championships.
THIS is the time of year when the hot, sticky weather is attributed to Sirius, the Dog Star. For dog owners, the dog days mean extra care must be taken of their pets.
LONDON, July 23 Unbeaten Portugal rallied from a threegoal deficit today to beat North Korea, 5-3, and more into the semi-finals of the World Cup soccer tournament.

Charles Masterson of Brooklyn, the defending champion, and Dr. Theodore Schein of Woodcliff Lake, N.J., advanced to the final of the Eastern seniors clay-court tennis tournament yesterday at the Seminole Club, Forest Hills, Queens.
COOS BAY, Ore., July 23--Neutralization of the Vietnam issue in Oregon's senatorial battle was sought today by the Republican state convention in session here.

Panels of foam plastic sandwiched between sheets of aluminum were used to sheathe a low-maintenance beach house in the oceanfront resort community of Kismet on Fire Island, N.Y.

SARASOTA, Fla., July 23 (UPI) A physician was arrested tonight and charged with the three-year-old murder of an Army officer in New Jersey.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 23 (AP) The handwritten note pasted to a garishly painted door of the maternity clinic reads: "I do not want to be disturbed. I am very tired." It is signed "Tri Quang."

DESPITE efforts in recent years of several singers of American Indian origin to popularize Indian music, the oldest traditional musical form on this continent re- mains something of an eso- teric mystery.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) Wilfrid E. Johnson has agreed to sell more than $200,000 worth of General Electric stock after being nominated as a member of the Atomic Energy Commission, Senator John O. Pastore said today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 23 (Reuters) Two high Yugoslav security officials a minister and his assistant in the Montenegro state government were dismissed last night and new men named to replace them, the official newspaper Borba said today.
BOSTON, July 23 (UPI) Kenneth L. Blue, one of the most successful club crew coaches in the country, was named head coach at Boston University today.

POT ISLAND, Conn., July 23 Thimble Islanders, summer residents of a Connecticut archipelago from which Captain Kidd once sailed forth, are fighting to keep what they call civilization away from their booty: 32 islands of peace and quiet, remoteness and relative obscurity.
BRISTOL, Tenn. July 23 (UPI) Chrysler's decision to pull out of stock-car racing next year was looked on favorably by most of the leading NASCAR drivers here for tomorrow's Volunteer 500.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 23 A turnout of 36,761 fans, the third highest of the meeting, did little to improve the overall turnstile count, as Roosevelt Raceway's second 52-night session terminated tonight. FELIX SCHLAG, designer of the Jefferson nickel, is about to achieve belated recognition. When the Mint carries out its planned Aug. 1 switch of coin-dating from 1965 to 1966, the nickels will have an additional change; they will display Mr. Schlag's initials.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 23 Ten young women will be presented at the Doric Debutante Cotillion on Aug. 27. The annual event, sponsored by the Women's Architectural Auxiliary of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects, will be held at the Elms, the mansion built in 1901 as a summer home for Edward J. Berwind, the Philadelphia coal industrialist.
BAASTAD, Sweden, July 23 (AP) Jan-Erik Lundquist of Sweden upset Fred Stolle of Australia, 5-7, 6-4, 1-6, 7-5, 8-6, today and gained the final of the four-man Cup of Champions tennis tournament.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., July 23 In Our Lady of Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church here this afternoon, Miss Gail Elizabeth Conti, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. Edward Conti, became the bride of James W. Fraser of Easton, Pa. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. William A. Fraser of Akron, Ohio.
WASHINGTON, July 23 (UPI) Military authorities reported today that there had been no established slip-ups in the behavior of American prisoners of war in Vietnam.

THIS spring, the members of the Men's Gar den Club of Rockland County let weeds and rabbits overrun their own gardens while they built another a fragrance garden at the Vacation Camp for the Blind in Spring Valley, N.Y. Amateurs all, the men have devoted nearly every Satur- day morning since mid-March to the project.

Richard C. Fieldhouse was busy the other morning. He flicked a key on the 40-line telephone turret that fills the back of his desk at Garvin, Bantel Co. and said, "Sam, you just bought 10 at 5 from Mother."

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., July 23 (AP) Casey Stengel and Ted Williams will be inducted into Baseball's Hall of Fame Monday, an event that probably will cause a monumental traffic jam in this quiet, lakeside community.

AS the number of home gardeners increases, devastating drought seems to be decreas ing the nation's water supply. There is no need for despair, however. Resourceful gardeners and scientists have devel- oped ways to drub the drought ranging from the use of salt water to the construction of small "solar stills."

WHITE PLAINS, July 23--A new reapportionment plan for Westchester County that would retain the representation of town governments, that has been in effect for 263 years is being proposed by officials for a November referendum.
LOS ANGELES, July 23 The seven-game winning streak of the New York Mets came to an end today in predictable circumstances, but not quite in predictable style.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 23--Secretary General Thant declined to say today whether he planned to ask for reopening of the Geneva Conference on Vietnam during his visit to Moscow next week.

One threw right-haanded and hit home runs, the other threw left-handed and pitched shutouts. One was named Mickey Charles Mantle, the other Edward Charles Ford.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) Four Republican Congressmen from New Jersey called tonight for a "full and complete investigation" of the national cemetery system. A resolution to establish a select House committee was introduced by William B. Widnall, Peter H.B. Frelinghuysen, Florence P. Dwyer and William T. Cahill.

WASHINGTON, JULY 23 The Department of the Interior, which has specialized in wide open spaces, came up today with a plan to give city dwellers more room for walking, hiking, bicycling and horseback riding.
Murray Olyphant, a retired assistant vice president of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, died Friday in Doctors Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived at 139 East 66th Street and Niantic, Conn.

TROY, N.Y., July 23 (AP) A Rensselaer County Court judge has dismissed indictments against Norman H. Briggs, a former Troy insurance man who disappeared in 1960 and turned up five years later working as a cowboy in Wyoming.

Montgomery Clift, a moody, sensitive actor who often played moody, sensitive young men on the screen, died yesterday of a heart ailment in his house at 217 East 61st Street. He was 45 years old.

TO understand in depth the political thought of Charles de Gaulle demands an effort which many statesmen and diplomats must now be kicking themselves for having made too late. When his political ideas are studied what is striking about them is how early they were formed, how logically they hang together and how extensively they have been applied in terms of French national policy particularly since de Gaulle's return to power in 1958.
COPENHAGEN, July 23 (AP) Princess Margrethe, the heir to the Danish throne, is trying to make second lieulieutenant.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 23 Some people think that South Vietnam is not ready for elections, but the politicians certainly are. As of this week, about 630 of them had filed for the Sept. 11 balloting to elect a "constituent assembly" which will draft a constitution leading toward full, elected democratic government.

LET us be grateful this hot summer for some won- derful screen comedies that do more than provide entertainment and a certain amount of mental relief from the constantly gnawing anxieties of the war in Vietnam and racial strife. Let us be grateful for some movies that excite us with confidence and hope that humor has been reborn or rediscovered as a basic commodity of the screen.
A new record in grain shipments and an 18-year record for coal shipments was established in June by Great Lakes bulk vessels, the Lake Carriers' Association reported yesterday.
TEHERAN, Iran, July 23 The economy of Iran is growing faster and more sturdily, perhaps, than that of any other Middle Eastern country with the possible exception of Israel.

GEORGETOWN, Guyana This little country, wedged between Brazil and Venezuela, has practically everything for the real traveler. No bigger than Kansas, Guyana is a land of mountains, jungles, great rivers and broad savannahs. They are all here 2,000 miles, eight hours by jet and a $346 economy-class ticket from New York.

AMONG the artists who have given modern sculpture its characteristic forms, the name of Julio Gonzalez (1876-1942) occupies an important place. He was not, to be sure, the first to create the open-form directmetal constructions that are now virtually inseparable from the very idea of modern sculpture. The Russian Constructivists preceded him in that endeavor by more than a decade.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. A boom in construction of new tourist facilities, which started more than a year ago, is continuing in this resort area. Last year, five new luxury motels were opened and another was doubled in size by the addition of 120 rooms.

NORMAN O. BROWN calls his new book "a continuation of a voyage begun with 'Life Against Death'." Certainly it continues a tendency implicit in his earlier book's title and nowadays implicit all over the place in the catch-phrase about being "on the side of life": the tendency to equate the two basic instincts Freud discerned, Eros and Thanatos, simply with "good" and "bad."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, July 24 (AP) Vietcong mortar crews fired 20 or more shells at a United States military complex east of Danang last night, wounding seven men, damaging four helicopters and causing some slight structural damage at a 400-bed Navy hospital.

LINVILLE, N.C., July 23 Miss Cameron De Camp, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Allen Ledyard De Camp of Linville and Charlotte, was married today to William Ballin Whitman Jr., son of Mrs. Whitman of Evanston, Ill., and the late Mr. Whitman.

FREEPORT, L.I., July 23 (AP) Guy Lambardo is calling for a slow down in speedboat racing.
MANILA, July 23 (AP) More than 500 Communist terrorists in central Luzon are getting massive help in arms and equipment from undetermined sources, President Ferdinand Marcos said today.
WASHINGTON, July 23 There will be a tintinnabulation of the bells before Luci Johnson's noon wedding Aug. 6.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 23 (AP) Tony Taylor drove in four runs and Cookie Rojas three as the Philadelphia Phillies routed the San Francisco Giants, 8-0, today behind the three-hit pitching of Jim Bunning. Rojas hit two homers and Taylor a homer and a double.
Invitations have been mailed for the Diamond Centennial Ball, to be held at the Americana Hotel on Oct. 27. The ball will be limited to 1,000 persons.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., July 23 Nick Raasch, 17-yearold high school senior from upstate DeWitt, won the New York state amateur golf championship today, 1 up, in the 36hole final on the Concord Hotel's challenging new course.
CHICAGO, July 23 (AP) A record fleet of 159 boats got away today in the 333-mile Chicago-to-Mackinac Island race. There were hazy skies and a 5-mile-an-hour southwest wind.
SALEM, N.H., July 23 (AP) Receptive came on with a closing burst of speed and won the $15,000 Manchester Handicap today at Rockingham Park.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 23 Richard Rick, paunchy and somewhat tired, finally got to rest today but sooner than he really wanted.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) The House Banking Committee will agree Monday on an interest ceiling and other provisions to dampen interest-raising competition between banks and savings and loan associations, Chairman Wright Patman said today.

NORWALK, Calif., July 23 (UPI) Donald Novis, a leading lyric tenor of the late 1920's and 1930's died at the Metro- politan State Hospital here this afternoon after a brief illness. He was 60 years old and until recently had lived in Newport Beach, Calif., where he was a recreation director.

Dr. Francis W. Currin died yesterday at St. Mary's Hospital, Brooklyn, where he had been chief of radiology until he retired two years ago. He was 75 years old and lived at 35 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., June 23 Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union, the recent challenger for the world chess championship, moved into a four-way tie for first place in the Piatigorsky Cup Tournament last night at the Miramar Hotel here. He drew his adjourned fourth-round game with Bent Larsen of Denmark.
TROY, N.Y., July 23 Three Negroes were seized in this racially tense city early this morning and charged with having started two fires with Molotov cocktails.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., July 23 Ken Wilson of Riverdale, the Bronx, a 29-year-old freshman at the College of Police Science, paddled to an easy victory in the 10,000-meter kayak singles event in the national canoe championships at Orchard Beach today. The races were contested over the Hunter Island Olympic canoeing course.

ONE of the persistent mysteries of the book business is the question of what principles, if any, guide American publishers in importing suspense novels from England. Regularly every season some unreadable British books appear here, and some of the high points of the British year are turned down by every American house.

SEVENTEEN years have passed since the Palestine War, and historians are still searching the ruins of Western liberalism and the British Mandate for a proper understanding of the rise of Israel. Of these two latest efforts, Barnet Litvinoff's "To the House of Their Fathers" is the less successful. It is essentially a series of loosely connected biographies of British and Jewish Zionists.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 23 (UPI)--Forgotten Dreams outran the odds-on favorite, Tumble Wind, and pulled away in the stretch today to capture the $146,350 Hollywood Juvenile Championship at Hollywood Park. This was the nation's first major stakes of the year for 2-year-olds.

PALISADE, N.Y., July 23 De Witt C. Peters, an American artist and the founder of the Haitian Art Movement 22 years ago, died of a heart attack today at the home of a friend, Charles Baker, at Sneeden's Landing here. He was 64 years old and ddivided his time between Port au-Prince in Haiti and a home at Piermont near here.

KEARNY, N.J., July 23 Top-seeded Stephen Ogilvy of New Rochelle, N.Y., defeated Alan Harvey of Rutherford, 6-4, 6-2, today to lead the field into the third round of the New Jersey state men's seniors singles tennis championships at the Arlington Players Club.

CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., July 23 The marriage of Miss Susan Virginia Grier to David Frederick Knoll, son of Mrs. Gustav Knoll of Alexandria, Minn., and the late Mr. Knoll, took place here this afternoon. The bride's parents are Mr. and Mrs. William Amos Grier.

A truck drivers' strike has begun to slow New York's $1billion construction industry, which is threatened with further strikes by operating engineers and plumbers tomorrow.

Stocks declined for the week with investment grade and glamour issues hard- pressed in dull trading; volume, 29,315,720 shares. Corporate bonds were off in less active trading; transactions, $40,300,700.

The issuance of a new nautical chart covering a portion of one of the nation's busiest waterways Block Island Sound and the east entrance to Long Island Sound has been announced by the Coast and Geodetic Survey.

The Yale Athletic Association has issued its annual call for ushers and rope guards who would serve at all football games to be played in the Yale Bowl this fall, including the exhibition game between the New York Giants and Detroit Lions for the Albie Booth Memorial Fund, Sunday, Aug. 21.

Miss Elsa Miriam Doskow, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ambrose Doskow of 25 East 86th Street, was married yesterday afternoon to Nicholas Steven Freud, son of Mrs. Frederick Freud of New York and the late Dr. Freud.

Schocken Books, Inc. will publish on Sept. 9 "Two Tales" by S.Y. Agnon, the Israeli who has been acclaimed as today's leading writer in Hebrew and has been nominated for the Nobel Prize. LEADVILLE, Colo. Old H.A.W. Tabor, one of Colorado's pioneer silver kings and known to opera-goers as the husband of Baby Doe, would probably be glad to learn that his elegant suite in the opera house he built here in 1879 is being restored.

WASHINGTON, July 23 The Negro protest movement in America is following the normal pattern of most revolutions. It is not waning with the first signs of Negro progress, but getting bolder and more demanding.
TRENTON, July 23 The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that the state's controversial new Congressional reapportionment was unconstitutional.
CLEVELAND, July 23 A 29- year-old Negro motorist was killed by shotgun fire today and the police held two white men as suspects in the slaying.

A major attack on rent control, designed to force decontrol of most apartments in New York City renting for more than $200 a month, has received a setback in the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court. But a strong possibility exists that the suit will be renewed.

PARIS The success of the first direct-dial telephone call from the United States to Europe last month could mean a major communications breakthrough for tourists. If such scientific progress continues, the day may not be far off when a visitor will be able to make a local call in a Continental city without developing a desire to rip the phone from the wall.
Thomas J. McElhany, a re- tired Broadway character actor, died of a heart attack on Friday in his home at 152 East 22d Street. He was 75 years old.

LIVERPOOL, England, July 23 Prime Minister Wilson journeyed to this industrial port today for the reopening of the subterranean night club where the Beatles got their start.

The winner was Grand Master Nicholas Rossolimo of New York, who scored 7-1 without losing a game outright.

Roberts of Lakewood, N.J.

COVINGTON, Tenn., July 23 (AP) Heavily guarded by state troopers, a small band of civil rights marchers hiked through West Tennessee today in a quest of "free elections" and better employment opportunities.

THE Museum of Modern Art's new Matisse ex- hibition, which opened last week, could quite appropriately have been subtitled "The Birth of an Old Master." It is not a large show 64 paintings in all nor is it a dramatic one.
CINCINNATI, July 23 (AP) Rain forced postponement of tonight's scheduled National League baseball game between Atlanta and Cincinnati. The contest was rescheduled as part of a double-header tomorrow.

BIRMINGHAM, Mich., July 23--The marriage of Miss Linda Louise Brandt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Brandt Jr., to Ivor Anthony Stoddard took place this afternoon. The bridegroom is a son of Mrs. Hugh Fenwick of Aiken, S.C., and the late Louis E. Stoddard.

LONDON. AS a festival centered on contemporary British music, Cheltenham until now has resembled a one-legged man. Geared to the old-fashioned symphony concert and lacking any means of putting on opera, it has been poorly placed to reflect the general aversion of young composers to the traditional apparatus of the symphony orchestra and (in England at any rate) their growing appetite for writing for the theater.
A TUMULTUOUS, vigorous, responsive performance by the Ta- trai String Quartet of all six of Haydn's Erdody Quartets (Op. 76) has been released on the imported Qualiton label from Budapest.

DOORS that stick or bind are a frequent cause of annoyance in many homes yet the cure is usually quite simple. In many cases the trouble is due to loose or improperly mounted hinges. The condition can be corrected by simply tightening the loose screws, or by carefully inserting a few cardboard shims behind the hinge leaves.
A 28-year-old robbery parolee from the Bronx was ordered held without bail in Criminal Court yesterday on a charge of shooting a 16-year-old girl because she had stared at him.
KHABAROVSK, Siberia, July 23 Here in eastern Siberia on Russia's Amur River frontier with China echoes of the Vietnam crisis seem strangely muted.
Samuel Lustbader, a retired builder, who erected many buildings for the city in the nineteen-twenties and thirties, died Friday in his home, 445 East 86th Street. He was 91 years old.

LOS ANGELES, July 31 Bob Friend, who extended the New York Met winning streak to seven games by defeating the Los Angeles Dodgers, 3-0, Friday night, still felt a little extra glow of satisfaction about it today.

LOUISVILLE, July 23 Miss Susan Hale Spalding, daughter of Mrs. Shinkle Spalding and Peter Spalding Jr., was married today to Andrew Trowbridge Hall Munroe. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Munroe of Washington and New York.
Five riders of the United States Equestrian Team, along with Coach Bert DeNemethy and 16 horses, returned yesterday from a seven-week tour of European horse shows.
CARMEL, N. Y., July 23--A 16-month-old whippet from Newington, N. H., scored her first best-in-show award at to day's 899-dog Putnam Kennel Club event held at the Kent School grounds.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 23 In the esoteric language spaceman speak, the word for success is "nominal" that is, everything went according to plan. They are using the word freely and happily to describe the three-day mission of Gemini 10.

HOUSTON, July 23 (AP) Bob Veale of the Pittsburgh Pirates was forced to skip his turn on the mound against the Houston Astros tonight when back pains sent him to Methodist Hospital, where he was examined but not hospitalized.
INDIANAPOLIS, July 23 Following is the prepared text of President Johnson's speech today at the Indianapolis Athletic Club:

MINEOLA, L.I., July 23 In a thousand appearances before 173,000 persons, members of the Nassau County Police Department have been trying to find what residents expect of the police and to tell the residents what the police expect of them.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 23 (AP) Tequillo, who had been purchased here earlier in the meeting by Paul Benshoof, an Iowa cattleman, upset a strong field of 3-year-olds at Monmouth Park today to win the $57,350 Choice Stakes.

TOKYO, July 23 "No American businessman ever comes to Japan just one time," a New York buyer based in Tokyo declared recently. "After making the deal, he always has to come back to find out what happened."
People carrying furniture on their backs or moving it on rollers across the sidewalk yesterday told of the fear that has swept pockets of the Brownsville-East New York section of Brooklyn.

WAYNE, Pa., July 23 Miss Ruth Yvonne Cox, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wilbur H. Cox of Springfield and Moorestown, N.J. was married this evening to John Frederic Page of Hartford, son of Mrs. Charlotte K. Page of Haverhill, N.H., and Miller Place, L.I. The Rev. Joseph H. Laird performed the Episcopal ceremony in Old St. David's Church.
MONTICELLO, N.Y., July 23 (AP) Romeo Hanover sped to his eighth straight victory today in the $7,496 Henry Thomas Pace at Monticello Raceway.
ONE of the nicest things about Philharmonic Hall is that it seems to encourage the presenta tion of cultural entertainments of an unconventional nature.
Considerable attention, both professional and public, has been called to the plight of New York City's famed Bellevue Hospital by an article that appeared in this newspaper a few weeks ago.
"If we don't agree, nobody can make us agree. Neither side has the power to force the other to do anything it doesn't want to."
The need to clothe America's combatants in Vietnam has created a series of problems in connection with civilian apparel. Deliveries, supply and pricing are all affected.
THE history of any art is the history of the world in which it was made. Or ought to be. Garff B. Wilson's "History of American Acting" at least recognizes this obligation.

CHATTANOOGA, July 23 (AP) Patty Ann Reese of St. Petersburg, Fla., won the national girls' 14-years-and-under singles tennis title today with a 3-6, 6-4, 6-4 victory over Karin Benson of North Miami Beach, Fla.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 23 The latest headache for Sargent Shriver and his Office of Economic Opportunity came this week from Excelsior Springs, just outside Kansas City.

THE simple, touching and comic view of French village life and and love exposed in "The Baker's Wife" 26 years ago, which justifiably has risen to the status of a classic, appears to be well on its way toward being transformed into an English-lan guage film. In the projected remake if all transactions go smoothly, that is Zero...

FRANKFURT, Germany, July 23 (AP) Ross Newdick of New Zealand shot a six-under-par 66 today to take a one-stroke lead at the halfway mark of the German open golf championship with a 36-hole total of 136.

SERQUIGNY, France The strains now being experienced by NATO were dramatically heightened by General de Gaulle's unilateral policy but are by no means limited to the problem of relationships with France.

Prime Minister Harold Wilson's stern measures for ending inflation in Britain and defending the pound abroad have provoked some predictable reactions. The trade union movement has voiced opposition to Mr. Wilson's call for a voluntary freeze on wages; British bankers were reported as feeling that his drastic belttightening did not go far enough; and foreign confidence has been slow to revive.

HOLLYWOOD. REALITY has always been a rather unpopular item in the movie colony. The studio czars long ago handed down the dictum that the typical moviegoer doesn't want to see life as it is but rather as he would like it to be or as Hollywood imagined it to be. Hence the evolution of "Hollywood reality": War became John Wayne beating back the Indians; Virtue was Doris...

JAKARTA. A GOVERNMENT clerk works for 30 or 40 cents a month while the minister of his de- partment banks thousands of embezzled dollars in Switzerland or New York. Shiny new Mercedes-Benz limousines nose down streets and lanes packed with pedicabs and horse-drawn carts. Influential politicians and businessmen live comfortably in high-ceilinged Dutch-built homes and millions of their countrymen cower in leaky hovels surrounded by foul-smelling open sewers.

ANGEL RECORDS has again taken a lead in the development of 4- track stereo tape pack aging. It was among the first to produce serious music tapes to play at the slow speed of 3 inches per second instead of the standard 7 i.p.s., which is used still by most other major producers.

An order by the Allied Joint Chiefs of Staff almost halted the secret negotiations that led to the surrender of German troops in Italy in 1945, Allen W. Dulles, who conducted the negotiations, has disclosed.
LONG BEACH, L.I., July 23 A comprehensive oceanographic curriculum at the secondary-school level is being developed as a part of the planning for this oceanfront city's $6.5-million high school.

WASHINGTON, July 23 Ten years have passed since the major effort to help economic development of the world's poor countries began to acquire momentum. In that time the rich nations have poured the staggering sum of $51.5-billion of foreign aid into the poorer part of the world, not counting $30-billion of private capital.
"IT'S about time I went back," George Axelrod, the film writer and producer, announced the other day from his home base in California.
A test program to determine if modern steel and glass bus shelters will encourage the use of mass transportation was started last week in Detroit the home of the automobile.
WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) Senator Russell B. Long said today he was planning an investigation of drug prices and Federal health programs.
A long trapezoidal site and setback requirements under the new zoning resolution have contributed to an unusual advantage for 10 tower suites in a new apartment building on the East Side.

With the interest equalization tax three years old and due to expire one year from today, a leading Wall Street investment banker has called for a critical re-examination of United States policy on international finance.

A fuel that was once a drag on the market and is now the life-blood of modern aviation may soon become too scarce to meet the rapidly expanding needs of the jet age, according to aviation fuel experts.
BUENOS AIRES, July 23 The new military regime closed Argentina's only satirical political magazine today.
HONG KONG, July 23 Hanoi hailed today the readiness of the Communist bloc to send volunteers to Vietnam but gave no hint of any immediate intention of accepting the offers.
A house of curves is being offered in a community of higher-priced homes that is being developed on 540 high rolling acres near Huntington, L.I.
The long-dormant Cary Plaza, originally planned as a multimillion-dollar luxury apartment-hotel project, will be revitalized and completed as a 630-room "luxury hotel" in downtown Dallas.

PASCO, Wash., July 24 (UPI) Wild Bill Cantrell of Detroit put the Miss Smirnoff into high gear today and drove the big unlimited hydroplane around the two-mile Atomic Cup course at an average speed of 111.386 miles an hour, the fastest time trial this season.
A former aide to President Kennedy suggested yesterday that an independent group look into charges that the Warren Commission's investigation of the assassination was inadequate.

BARRINGTON, Ill., July 23 (AP) Peggy Conley, a teenager from Spokane, Wash., pulled one of the major surprises of the season today in defeating the defending champion, Mrs. Barbara Fay Boddie of Shreveport, La., 2 and 1, in the title match of the women's western amateur golf tournament.
PITTSBURGH, July 23 The marriage of Miss Susan Lee Criep, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Leo H. Criep, to Ivan Santa-Cruz son of Mr. and Mrs. Hernan Santa-Cruz of Santiago, Chile, took place this evening.

PARIS. DO they? Or don't they? Only the producer knows for sure, and he isn't telling. Neither, for that matter, is Jeanne Moreau, Maria Schell or Emmanuelle Riva, or such stars as Marcello Mastroianni, Alain Delon and Vittorio Gassman. So the question is a current guessing game for moviegoers.

THE prosperous little country of Switzerland, itself one of the world's leading tourist attrac tions, sends proportionately more travelers abroad than any other nation, according to a survey conducted by the International Union of Official Travel Organizations.
The economy showed two faces last week. New orders for durable goods and housing starts, closely watched economic indicators, weakened further.
The clock was turned back a quarter of a century at Yankee Stadium yesterday, but the intervening years appeared to have wrought no startling changes.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Albert M. Chambers of 911 Park Avenue of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia Jane Chambers, to Richard Joseph Keim, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin P. Keim of Highland Park, Ill.
With the Vietnam conflict entering a stage of feverish ground fighting, attention is again focused on the role that textiles play in the war effort.

CLEVELAND, July 23 (AP) Fred Whitfield's two-run home run in the seventh inning today gave the Cleveland Indians a 6-5 victory over the Detroit Tigers, ending the Indians' losing streak at four games.

EVERYBODY knows that the most interesting things in Canadian literature these days are happening in the Province of Quebec. It's the familiar situation of a revolutionary movement creating the kind of atmosphere of excitement and discovery in which good literature is brought to its painful birth. It is tempting to compare the new situation in French Canada today to that existing in Ireland in the years before 1919.
CHICAGO, July 23 (AP) Abe's Hope withstood a claim of foul today and won Arlington Park's $54,800 Assault Handicap by a head from Rom O'Nello.

PARIS, July 23 Fifty Frenchmen, all in their midthirties and early forties, will begin careers in factories soon. Their age would normally work against them, but, in this case, it is acceptable because the men are all Roman Catholic priests.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 23--The National Aeronautics and Space Administration released today a picture taken when Gemini 10 was at its highest altitude--475 miles. It shows more of the earth's curvature than has ever been photographed before by a United States astronaut.

PUEBLO, Colo., July 23 Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Ellis have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Ellis, to Craig Scott Newhouse, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter S. Newhouse Jr. of Riverside, Conn. A fall wedding is planned.

The name and mailing list of Max Schling Seedsmen, Inc., a 60-year-old mail-order horicultural and gift company, have been purchased by the Barth-Spencer Corporation of Valley Stream, L. I., which will operate it as a division.

A GLIMPSE of tragedy is not the most entertaining activity for a summer Sunday after noon, but anyone who has not seen the July architecture show at the Museum of Modern Art and is interested in the current cultural climate would be advised to go today, since this is the last day.

GENEVA, July 23--A resolution condemning "the massive and growing American military presence in Vietnam" was adopted here today at a world conference of more than 400 Christian theologians and laymen.

CHICAGO, July 23 The Illinois Commerce Commission has opened a state-wide investigation of the promotional practices of competing gas and electric utilities to induce developers and builders to use their energy supplies.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., July 23 Mr. and Mrs. J. Brooke Johnston have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carol Elizabeth Johnston, to Richard Ives Hofmann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred A. Hofmann. An October wedding is, planned.
TOULOUSE, France, July 22 For the exiles, the 30th anniversary Monday of the revolt that overthrew the Spanish Republic was a bitter date.
HOUSTON, July 23 Bill Mazeroski's run-scoring single copped a four-run rally in the eighth innings that carried the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 4-3 victory over the Houston Astros tonight.

The economy of the tenth Federal reserve district has shown greater stability than that of the country as a whole in recent years, although the rate of growth has not been as fast, according to a study made by the Kansas City Federal Reserve Bank.

WASHINGTON, July 23 When Senator Robert F. Kennedy met in Capetown last month with Ian Robertson, the student who had invited him to South Africa, the Senator reportedly asked if the room might be "bugged."
A New Jersey homebuilder has erected a "research house" to test hundreds of components and finishing materials for possible inclusion in the model homes of a new vacation community.
BLACKPOOL, England, July 23 (UPI) Brian London ended his first week's training today for his heavyweight title bout with Cassius Clay Aug. 6 in London.
CLEVELAND, July 23 Mr. and Mrs. Clark Evans Bruner have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lydia Clark Bruner, to Paul Henry Oppmann Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Oppmann of Shaker Heights.

BEDFORD, Mass., July 23 (AP) The police said today that they had a sketchy description of three bandits and the name "Lennie" as apparently their only clues in the $131,000 holdup of the Brink's Inc. armored truck yesterday.

LONDON, July 23 On the day that Prime Minister Wilson disclosed his emergency economic program, the House of Commons discussed among other subjects the right of women to sit in certain seats and the supply of filing cabinets for members.

Since time immemorial the hilltops have been special places. The old gods dwelt there, and only those who were favored by the gods could even visit their sacred precincts. Rain and lightning came down from the hills. Eagles nested there. Men lived in the valleys and looked up unto the hills in awe.

IN the years before World War II, every town in America had a ball club to glorify its name. On summer Sunday afternoons, excitement packed thousands of ball parks across the country. Baseball, the national pastime, was loved by Americans in a way no other game could match, and every kid who ever shagged a fly ball nursed dreams of growing up to be a Major Leaguer.

SINGAPORE, July 23 (Reuters) The Vietcong and the North Vietnamese Government accused the United States today of atrocities in the Vietnam war, including widespread use of poison gas and "precisely deliberate raids on populated areas" intended to "massacre the civilian population."
THE DALLES, Ore., July 23 (AP) Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas said today he had not been invited to visit Communist China.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 22 To combat the growing of hashish, the Lebanese Government has persuaded a large number of farmers in the country's fertile Bekaa valley to raise sunflowers instead.
MEXICO CITY, July 21 Mexico's university students are demonstrating their traditional power and militancy, and the academic and governmental authorities seem reluctant to move against them.
BRIDGEPORT, N.Y., July 23 (AP) Neil Walts of Fulton won the 16-yard singles event in the New York State amateur trapshooting competition today with 200 hits on 200 targets.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., July 23 Mr. and Mrs. William E. Newcomb of New Canaan and Chester, Vt., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sherry Newcomb, to Kurt Achenbach, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernst A. Achenbach of Zurich, Switzerland.

MOSCOW, July 23 (Reuters) Nuritdin A. Mukhitdinov, a former member of the Soviet Communist party's ruling Presidium, has been given a relatively minor post as deputy head of a Government committee, Izvestia reported today.
John Pennel pole vaulted 17 feet 6 inches to set a world record yesterday at the Los Angeles Times International track and field meet.

EARLIER this summer, the great Blue Team of Italy won its eighth consecutive Bermuda Bowl title in world championship competition. The annual record of this event will be available later this week from the American Contract Bridge League, 33 West 60th Street, New York 10023, for $2.50 postpaid. Its 224 pages include a full history of pre- vious championships.

FORT BRAGG, N.C., is a sprawling Army post of some 200 square miles, three times as large as the District of Columbia, most of it still covered with long-leaf and loblolly pines, its building areas planted with magnolias. It is named, a post history notes, for Gen. Braxton Bragg, whose defeat at Bentonville in an attempt to stop the march of Gen. William Tecumseh Sherman marked the end of Confederate resistance in North Carolina.

WOODSTOWN, N.J. The only regularly scheduled, professional Wild West rodeo this side of the Mississippi is rounding out its 12th consecutive summer season here in southwestern New Jersey, giving this otherwise somnolent farming community the air of a frontier cowtown.

WASHINGTON, July 23 People who guard their telephone statements and who worry that their premises are "bugged" were given some cause to relax when the Justice Department recently renounced its long-standing double standard of conduct on privacy.

CAIRO, July 23 Hiwar, a Lebanese magazine, has been banned by Egyptian authorities following leftist accusations that the magazine received subsidies from the Central Intelligence Agency and was "a C.I.A. organ."
With 15 captains already signed up, the 15th annual Maine Retired Skippers Race off Castine, Me., expects participation records when the event is held Aug. 21.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 23 Charles Pasarell of Puerto Rico, the defending titleholder, was beaten in the semi-finals of the Pennsylvania Lawn Tennis championships today and Karen Krantzcke of Australia won the women's crown.

Soundproofing is as much a matter of shielding apartment occupants from noise originating within their own quarters as it is of protecting them against sounds from neighboring suites and from outside the building, according to a prominent builder.

AURORA, Colo., July 23 (AP) By a margin of more than 2 to 1, Colorado Democrats voted today to back President Johnson's military action in Vietnam.

The engagement of Miss Lynda Frances Siegel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Siegel, to First Lieut. Joseph Charles Zengerle, U.S.A., son of Mrs. Anthony Coletta of Pitman, N.J., and Joseph Zengerle of Washigton, has been announced by the future bride's parents. A November wedding is planned.

DARIEN, Conn., July 23 Mr. and Mrs. William T. French have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Victoria Ann French, to Stephen Burritt Morris, son of Mr. and Mrs. Grinnell Morris of Oyster Bay, L.I.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 23 (Reuters) Riot policemen turned a high-pressure water hose today on 100 youths taking part in a march to protest the imprisonment of the Rev. Ian Paisley, leader of the extremist Free Presbyterian Church.

PEKING, July 23 (Reuters) A Chinese Communist leader told physicists from Asia, Africa, Latin America and Australasia today that Chinese scientific and technological achievements in the future would leave the West far behind.

XIENG NGUEN, Laos, July 21 Seven years ago, this sleepy village tucked in the narrow Nam Khane valley among the jagged, jungle-covered mountains of northern Laos was a stronghold of the pro-Communist Pathet Lao.
WASHINGTON, July 23 A research project is to begin here this fall to help answer one of the most tragic puzzles facing medical science.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 23 Gov. Orval E. Faubus once again is the central figure in the Democratic primary for Governor here, although he is not running for re-election.

Questions of literary interest should be addressed to the Queries Editor, New York Times Book Review, Times Square, New York, N.Y. 10036. The inquirer's name and address must be included along with a stamped, self-addressed envelope. The editor will publish those that seem to have the greatest general interest. Others are answered by letter.

A multimillion-dollar scheme for the redevelopment of Coney Island with a climatecontrolled pleasure dome was advanced last week. It would create a year-round recreational center, a convention hall, parking facilities, new shops and housing.
PHILADELPHIA, July 23 A local pharmaceutical company has joined the Philadelphia Housing Authority in a $2.4-million project to rehabilitate about 70 houses.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 23 (Reuters) The high council of the Unified Buddhist Church appointed a militant monk today as acting chairman of the Buddhist Secular Affairs Institute, center of the Buddhist protests against the Government of Premier Nguyen Cao Ky.
An extra force of firemen stood on the alert in the East New York section of Brooklyn yesterday--each man knowing that he could be the next target of a bottle or a rock.
Giovanni Buitoni, chairman of the Buitoni Foods Corporation, yesterday reasserted his belief that the labels on his company's products are not misleading.

Miss Mary Jo Robb, daughter of Mrs. Francis J.M. Robb of Flushing, Queens, and the late Mr. Robb, was married yesterday morning to John David Murphy, son of Mrs. John G. Murphy of Jamaica Estates, Queens, and the late Dr. Murphy.
LONDON, July 23 Mr. Sayigh, the editor of Hiwar, expressed confidence today that the ban on his magazine in the United Arab Republic would be temporary.
The Lake Survey District of the United States Army Corps of Engineers has announced establishment of a Great Lakes Research Center that in time should be of benefit to recrea- tional yachtsmen.
MOSCOW, July 23 (Reuters) Izvestia, the Soviet Government newspaper, called tonight for the election of more African, Asian and Communist judges to the International Court of Justice.

TOKYO, July 23 Countless American servicemen who helped to free Guam from Japanese occupation 22 years ago this month knew an intense young Guamanian priest, called Father Calvo, as a fiery leader of island partisans.

The big stores are doing well on the basis of dollar volume data. Since the beginning of June, department store sales are running fully 16 per cent ahead of last year's level, indicating that in the soft goods and home furnishings field, consumers have made no retreat similar to that in the automotive field.

New England's business for the June quarter continued at high levels, but with some tapering from the accelerated rate of the first three months this year, a combination of industry studies here reveals. Compared with the level a year ago, both civilian and military volume ran sharply higher along with order backlogs.
The Korean War had a tremendous economic impact on the West, and 15 years later, in mid-1965, a similar impact is being felt because of the Vietnam War.
PHILADELPHIA, July 23 (AP) Work was held up the other day at the new student nurses' residence for Memorial Hospital because a cat decided to have kittens in the new walls.

On Greene Street, just north of Waverly Place, patches of cobblestone thrust upward through an overlay of blacktop among the few remaining touches of an older New York in a 10-block area lying north and east of Washington Square.

MIAMI, July 23 Peter Warrer of Denmark ended the United States' domination of the 1966 International Optimist Dinghy Association regata by winning a three-race series today at Pelican Harbour Yacht Club.

SUMMIT, N.J., July 23 Miss Germaine Edon Hamrick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Earle A. Hamrick Jr., was married this evening to Peter Gwillim Kreitler, son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Kreitler of Short Hills. The Rev. Allen Tinker performed the ceremony in Christ Church Summit (United Church of Christ).

BRYN MAWR, Pa., July 23 Miss Maris Inglis MacLeod, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Inglis MacLeod of Villanova, was married today to James Langley Van Alen, son of Mrs. Walter D. Fletcher of New York and Charlottesville, Va., and James H. Van Alen of New York and Newport, R.I.

The biggest ovation during Yankee Old-Timers' Day celebrations has always been reserved for Joe DiMaggio. And again the Yankee Clipper was welcomed with enthusiasm by the crowd of 34,042 during yesterday's program before the modern-day Yankees' regular game with the California Angels.

NEW HAVEN, July 23 Two Connecticut college teachers who are disciples of Senator Wayne Morse of Oregon are running for Congress on platforms advocating a negotiated withdrawal of troops from Vietnam.
It is generally agreed by those in control that the steamship passenger business in New York will never be the same again.
MT. HOPE, W.Va., July 23 (UPI) An explosion ripped through a soft-coal mine near this southern West Virginia community today killing seven workers and injuring two others.

KINSHASA, the Congo, July 23 (Reuters) The Congolese Press Agency reported today that violent disturbances had broken out in Kisangani (formerly Stanleyville) with fighting between white mercenaries and Congolese Army troops.

Miss Frances Elizabeth McManus and Joseph Arthur Garvin were married yesterday morning in St. Thomas Aquinas Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn. The bride's cousin, the Rev. Richard V. Tierney, performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass.

GLEN RIDGE, N.J., July 23 Miss Carolyn Holmes Hopgood, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roy C. Hopgood, was married this afternoon to Robert Lee Seaman. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Farand Robert Seaman of Laurel Hollow, L.I.

TOURS. ONE of the most positive steps to- ward international cultural accord has been taken and without the brassy sounding of propaganda trumpets by the Russian planist, Sviatoslav Richter, who is the main attraction and guiding spirit of the Touraine Music Festival.

Mayor Lindsay met with 50 residents of the troubled East New York section of Brooklyn for three hours yesterday and emerged with a pledge that they would make every effort "to cool it off, to calm it." In the racially tense halfsquare-mile area, calm prevailed through the day and into the evening as the police saturated the neighborhood.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 23 The bill has come due for those who took part in sit-in demonstrations in the Sheraton Palace Hotel and new car showrooms here in the spring of 1964.

Not many violinists would dare accept the virtuoso challenge of scheduling Sarasate's "Zigeunerweisen," Saint-Saens's "Introduction and Rondo Capriccioso" and the Second Concerto of Wieniawski, all in a single evening.
CHICAGO, July 24 (AP) The United States Savings and Loan League has urged the Con- gress to raise the amount of insurance coverage on savings accounts to $35,000.

BALTIMORE, July 24 (AP) J.C. Martin drove in two runs with a misjudged triple and a broken-bat single as the Chicago White Sox edged Baltimore, 4-0, today and ended the Orioles' seven-game winning streak.

MUNSTER, Ind., July 24 Tony Lema, one of professional golf's most popular performers, was killed today with his wife and two other persons when their small plane crashed and burned on a golf course. He was 32 years old.

GENEVA, July 24 (UPI) A proposal that more than 400 Christian theologians and laymen stage a march on behalf of "a just world order" was narrowly voted down here today after heated debate at a conference sponsored by the World Council of Churches.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 24 North Vietnamese Army regulars pounded two companies of United States marines tonight with intense fire from thick jungles three miles south of the demilitarized zone dividing North and South Vietnam.

Mrs. Cleo Medley Cottrell, since 1963 a specialist in home management for the New Jersey extension service of Rutgers, the State University, died Saturday of cancer in Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. She was 53 years old and lived at 10 Landing Lane, New Brunswick, N.J.
The prompt acquisition of 100,000 acres of scenic land in the Hudson Valley was urged yesterday by a commission headed by Laurance S. Rockefeller.

The tempo of underwriting activity picks up this week as both the corporate and municipal schedules list some large sales as well as several smaller ones. In bidding for securities, investment bankers will have in the back of their minds next week's $250-million bond offering by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.
PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., July 24 The Potomac Boat Club of Washington captured the kayak singles, the doubles and fours to win the national canoe championships today at Orchard Beach Lagoon.

William T. Nemerov, vice, president of Russel Taylor, Inc., coat manufacturers of 512 Seventh Avenue, died Saturday in Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals. He was 65 years old and lived at 263 West End Avenue.

It's moving time once again for the devotees of the trotters and pacers. The first fact to which the punters should be realerted, as the sulky sport switches from Roosevelt Raceway in Nassau County to Yonkers Raceway tonight is that post-time at the Westchester track will be 8 o'clock, 15 minutes earlier than it had been through 52 nights of action at Westbury.
HARLAN, Iowa, July 24 In this plentiful land of corn, hogs, cattle and wheat, the promise of the Great Society is dulled.
PITTSBURGH, July 24--Steel people were talking a little less about a September surge last week.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 24 (AP) Mario Andretti, the United States Auto Club driving champion, overcame a spinout on the first turn and an empty fuel tank on the last lap today to win his fourth straight championship car event in the 150-mile Hoosier Grand Prix.

JERICHO, L.I., July 24 Pete Bostwick Jr., a 31-yearold Wall Street broker, sent his stock as a golfer soaring today by easily beating George Gennity of Bayside in the Long Island amateur championship final at the Meadow Brook Club.
Senator Jacob K. Javits said yesterday that he had decided that the Republican party's nomination of Arthur G. Klein for Surrogate in Manhattan was "a grave mistake."
MIAMI, July 24 (AP) The fourth tropical storm of the season became a hurricane in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean today while another tropical storm arose in the warm tropical Atlantic.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 24 Twenty-six New York Jets, four St. John's University cheerleaders and a goat named Lindo earned $100 to $150 apiece today by acting in a musical being filmed for television. No score was kept, but both football and the theater looked like losers.
WASHINGTON, July 24 At the end of its third week, the Medicare program was reported going smoothly with civil rights difficulties in some areas of the South still the only major problems.
Transportation Administrator Arthur E. Palmer Jr. has undertaken a study on the possibility of reviving the 15cent fare during non-rush hours for the elderly living on fixed incomes.

MORRISTOWN, N.J. July 24 Mrs. Catherine Clement Bangs, a former president of the American Birth Control League, died yesterday in Morristown Memorial Hospital. She was 72 years old and lived here and at 14 East 90th Street, New York.
The New York Stock Ex- change's net revenues, reflecting a sharp increase in trading volume, rose to $2,875,400 in the first half of 1966 from $105,300 during the corresponding period last year.
The Northern liberal, fearful of extremism, is cutting back sharply on contributions to the more militant civil rights organizations.

Lucia Chase and 70 members of the American Ballet Theater, of which she is co-director, returned to New York on Saturday night after a six-week tour of the Soviet Union. The company performed in Moscow, Leningrad, Yalta and Kharkov under the auspices of the United States Department of State.

CROTON, N.Y., July 24 Miss Tania Khodjamirian, daughter of Mrs. Ardashess Khodjamirian of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Khodjamirian, was married today to Mark Allen Walker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Walker of New York.

LOS ANGELES, July 24 A double shutout, the first enjoyed by Manager Walter Alston of the Los Angeles Dodgers in his 13-year regime and only the third endured by the New York Mets in their five-year history, concluded a four-game series in Chavez Ravine today.
A funeral service for Montgomery Clift will be held tomorrow morning at Frank E. Campbell's, Madison Avenue and 81st Street.
The Monmouth County, N.J., prosecutor said yesterday that he would make public today an indictment charging a 34-yearold physician with murder in the 1963 death of a retired Army colonel.
Standard Poor's Corporation will downgrade the city's credit rating today, just 24 hours before the city is to receive bids on a new loan of $112,929,000.
GRAND BLANC, Mich., July 24 (AP) Judy Kimball and Gloria Ehret gained a sixstroke victory today in the $21,000 Yankee Women's Open.

State Controller Arthur Levitt disclosed yesterday that he was investigating whether the state should erect an office building in Harlem rather than lease space in the proposed World Trade Center in downtown Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, July 24--Secretary of the Treasury Henry H. Fowler said today he was confident that "specific agreement" on providing new monetary reserves for the world could be reached "in the coming year."

ZANDVOORT, the Netherlands, July 24 (AP) Jack Brabham, the experienced Australian auto-racing driver and manufacturer, won the Dutch Grand Prix today in a RepcoBrabham and virtually clinched the world driving championship for the third time.

The Eastman Kodak Company turned in its most sparkling performance, with sales, earnings and employment the highest in its 65-year history, the midyear report of Albert K. Chapman, chairman and William S. Vaughn, disclosed over the weekend.
President Ho Chi Minh said that there was "no trial in view" for American prisoners held in North Vietnam, in a cablegram received yesterday by the Columbia Broadcasting System.

ESSEX FELLS, N.J., July 24--Frank A. Assmann of 57 Oval Way, a former director and head of the tin-plate division of the Continental Can Company, died yesterday in the Orange Memorial Hospital. His age was 78.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., July 24 Theodore Corday, president of Corday Productions, Inc., and a pioneer producer and director of daytime serial dramas in radio and television, died here yesterday. He was 58 years old.
A new effort will be made today to end the 91-day-old shutdown of the World Journal Tribune, Inc., when the pressmen's union and the new corporation resume negotiations after a five-day recess.
WASHINGTON, July 24 The House Commerce Committee has agreed on all except one provision of an auto safety bill the Administration regards as stronger and better than its own original proposal.

LOS ALTOS, Calif., July 24 (UPI) Greg Buckingham of Santa Clara, Calif., set a world record for the 200-meter individual medley today with a time of 2 minutes 13.1 seconds in the Far Western swimming championships.
LONDON, July 24 Pele, Brazil's star soccer player, criticized today in an interview the defensive tactics used in the 1966 World Cup tournament.

GRAND MASTER ARTHUR BISGUIER of Yonkers, who scored 7-1 in the recent Eastern Open Chess Tournament in Washington, just missed first place because a tie-breaking count gave the award to Nicholas Rossolimo of New York, whose game point score was also 7-1.

BAASTAD, Sweden, July 24 (AP) Sweden's Jan-Erik Lundquist crushed Manual Santana, of Spain, the Wimbledon champion, 6-1, 6-2, 6-3, in less than an hour today to win the four-man Cup of Champions round-robin tennis tournament.

CINCINNATI, July 24 (AP) Joe Torre's second homer of the game, in the 10th inning, gave Atlanta a 5-4 victory and a split of a doubleheader with Cincinnati today. The Reds won the first game, 4-3, also in 10 innings.

Events tonight: Festival from India, presenting Ali Akbar Khan, sarode player, following a film showing of Ray's "Kanchenjungha," Philharmonto Hall, 8; Mario Escudero, flamenco guitarist, Brentano's...
Samuel D. Spector, a senior trial attorney with the customs section of the Department of Justice for more than 30 years, died Saturday in his home at 20 Plaza Street, Brooklyn. His age was 66.
THE Open Pair Championship in the Greater New York Bridge Association's Brooklyn Championships Saturday was a close struggle between two of the strongest pairs in the field.

Gamble-Skogmo, Inc. a retailer of general merchandise, announced over the weekend that its tender offer for almost onethird of the shares of First National Stores was unsuccessful and that all shares tendered would be returned.
It was announced over the weekend that Peter Schwed had been named publisher of Simon Schuster, the trade division of Simon Schuster, Inc.

United States airlines have expanded their growth and improvement program for the period 1966-1970 to 825 airplanes valued at $4.8-billion, Stuart G. Tipton, president of the Air Transport Association, announced yesterday.
BRUSSELS, July 24 The six members of the European Common Market took a long step forward here today toward forging their separate economies into one.
ATHENS, July 24 Aristophanes this week proved to be as politically up-to-date as he was in 405 B.C., when he first presented his comedy "The Frogs" here.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 24 (AP) Willie Mays cracked his 22d homer of the season and the 527th of his career today as the San Francisco Giants beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 4-1.

THE third annual Shaker Kitchen Festival at Han- cock Shaker Village, Hancock, Mass., is scheduled for Aug. 8 through 13. Shaker sisters will demonstrate and offer tastings of Shaker foods each day from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. according to the following schedule:
PITTSBURGH, July 24 (AP) Dr. George W. Grier, founder and professor emeritus of the University of Pittsburgh's radiology department, died yesterday at his home. He was 83 years old.
LOS ANGELES, July 24--The Federal Government's program for legal aid to the poor won a surprising victory today as the nation's largest association of trial lawyers dropped its earlier opposition.
TWICE a year Abraham Straus presents in its model room a decorating problem worked out in terms of popular trends in home furnishings.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) Some of the reasons the United States has not closed the port of Haiphong were disclosed tonight.

PASADENA, Calif., July 24 (AP) Surveyor 1 bounced two to three inches when it touched down on the moon at a speed of seven miles an hour on June 1, a study of information radioed by the spacecraft showed today.
BRISTOL, Tenn., July 24 (AP) Paul Goldsmith of Munster, Ind., driving a Plymouth, won the Volunteer 500 lap stock car race by two car lengths at Bristol International Speedway today.

ROCKY POINT, L. I., July 24--Ann Snyder of Huntington, L. I., captured her seventh United States Equestrian Team equitation class--more than any other rider in the country--today at the Fox Hill Stables Horse Show.
Second-quarter earnings of the Republic Steel Corporation climbed 11.5 per cent to $1.72 a share from $1.54 in the 1965 period, the company reported over the weekend.

Emily M. Scully, a psychologist at the Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken, N.J., and an authority on adolescent behavioral problems, died of a heart attack Saturday in her home at 220 East 74th Street. She was 60 years old.

CONNELLSVILLE, Pa., July 24 Bobby Brown of Huntington, L.I., Mark Donohue of Stony Brook, L.I., and Ed Lowthey of McMurray, Pa., were the outstanding winners on an 11race Sports Car Club of America national championship program here today.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., July 24 Mimi Kanarek of New York upset Mrs. Patricia Stewart Edrich also of New York today and won the New Jersey State women's singles tennis championships at the East Orange Tennis Club.

The announcement by the City Bar Association that it has formed a special committee on revision of the State Constitution is another indication that things are at long last stirring in respect to the highly important constitutional convention next year.

SYRACUSE, July 24 (UPI) Former State Senator and Assemblyman Lawrence Rulison, a Republican, died in Upstate Medical Center in Syracuse yesterday after a long illness. He was 49 years old. Mr. Rulison represented the 44th Senatorial District from 1958 until his retirement in 1964, and Onondaga County's First Assembly District from 1945 until 1958. His widow and seven sons survive.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., July 24 Serendipity, the runner-up in the national high-point race last year, captured the large pony hunter championship at the New Jersey Professional Horsemen's Association horse show today under a strange rider.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI) President Johnson attended church services today with his daughter, Luci, who appeared to be exhausted.
DILLON, S. C., July 24--Miss Nancy Blue McKethan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. McKethan, was married today to Robert Wordell Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. James C. Miller of Great Neck, L. I.
HAVERFORD, Pa., July 24 Clark Graebner won the Pennsylvania lawn tennis championship today, marking the first time he has carried off the cup in a major grass-court tournament in this country.

PICTURE if you will the round, doublechinned face of the Montreal Canadiens' Gump Worsley imprinted on a pillow. Consider wearing a pair of bathing trunks modeled by Bobby Hull, or opening a bottle of beer with the cryptic grin of Gordie Howe adorning the label.
A Ford Foundation grant of $90,000 was made yesterday to Northeastern Univerprogram to train college students for careers in police work.

CHICAGO, July 24 (AP) Lou Brock, who earlier had scored from first base on a single, hit a three-run homer in the 10th inning to give the St. Louis Cardinals a 7-4 triumph over the Chicago Cubs in the second game of a doubleheader today.

The Pennsylvania Railroad, the largest surface carrier in the United States, reported yesterday a 32 per cent rise in its system consolidated net income for the second quarter and a 27 per cent gain for the first half.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., July 24--Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Hugo Linder have announced the engagement of Mr. Linder's daughter, Miss Sara Farm Linder, to Harry Sherwood Yates, son of Mrs. William Ernest Yates of Brooklyn, New York, the late Mr. Yates. A November wedding is planned.
COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., July 24 (AP) Ted Williams and Casey Stengel will be inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame tomorrow with Commissioner William D. Eckert presiding at the festivities.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., July 24 Hoyt Perry of the Pequot Yacht Club of Southport, Conn. the national champion 12 years ago, today won the first annual Atlantic Class alumni race held at Hempstead Harbor.
"Only a minimal number" of inexperienced teachers will be assigned this fall to schools in disadvantaged areas, the Superintendent of Schools disclosed yesterday.

CLEVELAND, July 24 (AP) Mickey Stanley's run-scoring single in the 10th inning gave the Detroit Tigers a 2-1 victory today over Cleveland after the Indians had won the first game, 3-0, behind the hitting of Joe Azcue.

WASHINGTON, July 24 A subcommittee of the Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee has tentatively scheduled a hearing for tomorrow on the proposal of Senator Wayne Morse to end the 17-day-old airline strike.

The people at Benton Bowles, Inc., undoubtedly had an effervescent weekend. Armed with $4.5-million in Canada Dry beverage business, they went home on Friday to celebrate the acquisition of yet another client, the Vick Chemical Company.
ACCRA, Ghana, July 24 The United States has decided to participate in Ghana's first international trade fair, scheduled to be held next Feb. 1 to 19.

Tom Tresh hit two home runs, Joe Pepitone hit one and Mel Stottlemyre gained his ninth victory as the New York Yankees took two games from the California Angels, 9-1 and 4-1, yesterday at Yankee Stadium.
FARELLONES, Chile, July 24 (AP) France's George Mauduit won the men's giant slalom today in the last of the tune-up races here for the world Alpine ski championships at Portillo, Chile, Aug. 4 to 14.

HOUSTON, July 24 (AP) Willie Stargell hit a pinch-hit three-run homer in the seventh inning today to break a 5-5 tie and help the National Leagueleading Pittsburgh Pirates gain an 11-6 victory over the Houston Astros.

The engagement of Miss Masako Mori, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Akira Mori of Kyoto, Japan, to William Heywood MacArthur of New York, son of Harvey Heywood MacArthur of Dongan Hills, S.I., and Mrs. Whitemore Whittier of Portland.
WAYNE, N.J., July 24 Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Fendrich have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Fendrich, to George B. Breznay Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Breznay of Ashley, Pa.

The New York Philharmonic's extraordinary Stravinsky Festival, which began June 30, ended Saturday night in solemn grandeur as Igor Stravinsky himself led the orchestra and the Camerata Singers in a moving performance of his "Symphony of Psalms."

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 24 Miss Jaquith Lee DuBois, daughter of Mrs. H.W. Campbell of West Park and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and the late Louis DuBois of New Paltz, was married this afternoon to Edmund Seymour Bartlett. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Lord Bartlett of Washington, Conn.
LENOX, Mass., July 24 Three expert young American singers made a strong impression in their anxiously awaited appearance with the Boston Symphony Orchestra at Tanglewood this afternoon.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 24 Mr. and Mrs. DeWitt Clinton Snyder have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Suzanne French Snyder, to Terence Michael York, son of Mrs. Georgia York of Princeton, N.J. and Eugene Livingston York of New York.
Lewis S. Rosenstiel chairman and president of Schenley Industries, Inc., has presented gifts amounting to $2.5-million to Protestant, Catholic and Jewish causes to mark his 75th birthday.
A three-alarm fire badly damaged a row of unoccupied three-story frame dwellings about noon yesterday in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn.

THIS can be said about Leslie A. Fiedler: he is never boring. Outrageous, yes and erratic, acutely perceptive, self-indul- gent, boisterous, visited by flashes of rare brilliance, given to exercises in huckstertrickery, and downright nervy in his exploitation of the obvious. But never boring. This fact alone makes one forgive a great deal.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., July 24 Harry Weiss, for 15 years editor of the now defunct Weekly Philatelic Gossip in Holton, Kan., died here last night at the Homestead, a nursing home. He would have been 78 years old today.

Two Episcopal priests one a rector, the other a university chaplain preached a joint sermon yesterday and agreed that both the church and the campus have a long way to go before their preachments catch up with their practices.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 24 Craig Harmon, a young man of 20, is a conscientious golfer.
BROOKVILLE, L.I., July 24 Fontaine Riker Clark, chairman of the board and until two years ago president of the American Foreign Steamship Corporation in New York, died...
ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., July 24 "Trans-Canada Highway Begins Here," a sign proclaims on the grounds of the new Confederation Government building here.
SUFFERN, N.Y., July 24 Miss Cena S. Goldstein, an alumna of Douglass College, was married here today to Michael D. Hampden, who was graduated from Haverford College and the Harvard Law School.
LOS ANGELES, July 24 Sparked by Tommie Smith's remarkable leg of 43.8 seconds, a United States four-man team today ran the 1,600-meter relay race in a world-record time of 2 minutes 59.6 seconds.

WASHINGTON, July 24 A House Democrat influential in economic affairs proposed today that Congress enact standby legislation permitting the President to increase, but not to decrease, taxes during the coming period when Congress is in adjournment.

The joint committee established by Congress last year to review its internal operations has now produced a unanimous report proposing numerous housekeeping improvements but no basic reform. This modest result was to be expected in view of the restricted mandate which Congress gave the committee.

DANANG, South Vietnam, July 24 (AP) A captured prisoner and reconnaissance by United States marines touched off Operation Hastings, which has become one of the largest the marines have staged in Vietnam.

Edward N. Costikyan, 1965 Democratic city campaign manager, said yesterday that he had "always understood there was some kind of understanding" for Frank D. O'Connor to get the Brooklyn and Bronx Democratic leaders' support for Governor this year.
SEATTLE, July 24 (AP) Former Gov. Arthur B. Langlie died in a hospital here today after a long illness. He would have been 66 years old tomorrow.
HONG KONG, July 24 North Vietnam today dismissed all compromise proposals to end the war in Vietnam in a detailed restatement of its fourpoint program.
TOKYO, Monday, July 25 (AP) Mao Tse-tung, the Chinese Communist leader, swam eight miles downstream on the Yangtze River near Wuhan July 16, the Peking radio said today.

A woman taxi driver was shot yesterday morning in the right shoulder by one of her three passengers after they attempted to rob her on Kelly Street near Longwood Avenue in the Bronx, the police reported.

The scheduled airlines have $4.8-billion worth of new jet aircraft on order for the next five years. Stuart G. Tipton, president of the Air Transport Association, said yesterday in releasing a survey of equipment on order.

LONDON, July 24--Prime Minister Wilson and his Government, feeling the weight of opinion abroad, are moving toward legislative enforcement of their proposed wage freeze instead of reliance on voluntary cooperation.

OUST, France, July 23 In this village high in the Pyrenees, France is seeking to resolve her problem of what to do with conscientious objectors.

A Bronx meat processing concern that will rehabilitate a vacant building in Harlem is among five recipients of low-interest loans granted to manufacturers by the New York City Industrial Development Corporation.

Concessions by both the Soviet and American delegates last week permitted the conferees to advance rapidly toward a draft treaty intended to insure that space exploration will serve peace.

BARNEVELD, N.Y., July 25 --Miss Christine Martha Evans and Craig Dixon Spafford plan to marry Aug. 27. Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. William Evans 3d, parents of the brideto-be. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stirling Weston Spafford of Wilbraham, Mass.

Two scientists "intimately" involved in making the atomic bomb will testify that the key evidence used to convict Julius and Ethel Rosenberg and Morton Sobell of espionage, was "completely false," a lawyer for Sobell asserted yesterday in Federal Court.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 25 --Miss Diana E. Davis will be married in September to Abner Kingman Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Kingman of Montreal. The parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Newlin F. Davis, have announced the engagement.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange tumbled yesterday to their second-worst setback of the year.

WASHINGTON, July 25-- President Johnson announced to day that he had accepted with "deep regret" the resignation of Edwin O. Reischauer as Ambassador to Japan. U. Alexis Johnson, Deputy Under Secretary of State, will succeed him.

ALBANY, July 25--The law firm of former Governor Thomas E. Dewey was paid $63,982.67 by the state to defend a Republican-drawn legislative reapportionment plan, records at the State Department of Audit and Control showed today.
WASHINGTON, July 25-- President Johnson's 1966 civil rights bill narrowly cleared its first parliamentary obstacle in the House of Representatives today.
New York City has begun a major campaign to halt the cigarette bootlegging that deprived the city last year of $13-million in taxes despite rising sales.
ANAHEIM, Calif., July 25-- A $15-milllion addition to Disneyland was unveiled here today. Called New Orleans Square, it is intended to represent that city as it was in the eighteenfifties.
Mayor Lindsay plans to fly to California this afternoon to attend a closed meeting of the National Association for Community Development on the Berkeley campus of the University of California.
