CHICAGO, July 25--Mayor Richard J. Daley set up a 23member citizens' committee today as an alternative to a citizen review board for the Police Department.
PRADES, France, July 25-- From all over the world, but especially from Spanish Catalonia, they came to hear Pablo Casals open his 90th-birthday festival at Prades tonight.

CHICAGO, July 25--The state completed today presentations to the grand jury of some of its evidence--apparently the bare minimum--against Richard F. Speck, 24 years old, accused of slaying eight student nurses.

Representative Adam Clayton Powell, contending that legal papers were improperly served, sought yesterday to quash a court motion that he be jailed for 30 days in connection with a $160,000 judgment he owes a Harlem widow he defamed.
NEW DELHI, July 25--Prime Minister Indira Gandhi directed her economic planners tonight to redraft India's five-year plan, which began in April.
WASHINGTON, July 25-- Theodore Herz, a partner in the accounting firm of Price Waterhouse Co., died yesterday of a cerebral thrombosis. He was 57 years old.

The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, called the 3M company, reported sharp increases yesterday in sales and earnings for the three and six months ended June 30. The total exceeds any quarter or halfyear period, in the company's history.

WASHINGTON, July 25--A bill calling for the dredging of two ship-maneuvering areas and the widening of a portion of the channel in Newark Bay was introduced in the Senate today by Senator Clifford P. Case.
TOKYO, July 25 (Reuters)-- The North Vietnamese press agency today began distributing the first 10,000 words of what it called a "black book" on the activities in Vietnam of the United States.

Mr. and Mrs. Boris Eckers of Hollis Hills, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Bonnie Eckers, to Richard Jay Goldberg of Island Park, L.I., son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Goldberg.
Steel production dropped 1.8 per cent in the week ended last Saturday, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 25--The garden of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Kazickas at 14 Egypt Lane will be the setting the afternoon of Aug. 4 for a preview of the fall and winter ready-to-wear collection designed by Sophie of Saks Fifth Avenue with the assistance of Stephen Erklin. Proceeds will benefit the Guild Hall.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., July 25--The London Symphony Orchestra arrived here today to give 16 concerts that city leaders hope will erase Daytona Beach's image as a center of "sex, sand and suds."
The Control Data Corporation, a computer manufacturer, announced yesterday in Minneapolis the election of George A. Strichman as a director.

CAIRO, July 25--Evoking the "Spirit of Suez" President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic has toughened his line against Arab rivals and, challenging the West anew, has moved to reassert himself as the unchallenged leader of the Arab world. The Egyptian President, long a master of political...

NEW DELHI, July 25--Opposition legislators, led by the Communists, blocked all proceedings in the Lower House of Parliament today as they began a determined assault on the Government's economic policies.

PHILADELPHIA, July 25-- Dr. William J. Kroeger, coinventor of the recoilless rifle and senior scientist at the Frankford Arsenal here, died Saturday at Temple University Hospital. He was 60 years old.
The national director of the Congress of Racial Equality indicated yesterday that Negro discontent with President Johnson's Vietnam policy might have contributed to the recent urban racial outbursts.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., July 25--Mrs. Billie Jean King made her first American appearance yesterday since winning the Wimbledon championship. She defeated Elizabeth Blackford of Seattle, 6-0, 6-0, in the first round of the 40th annual Eastern grass court championships.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 25 (AP)--Edwin O. Reischauer, who resigned today as United States Ambassador to Japan, has been elected a university professor at Harvard University.

WASHINGTON, July 25-- The House Banking Committee approved "emergency" one-year legislation today setting a maximum interest rate of 4 per cent that banks could pay on time deposits of less than $100,000.

TOKYO, July 25--Japan and the Soviet Union agreed on closer economic ties but remained far apart on a delicate territorial issue in long talks today between the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, and his Japanese counterpart, Etsusaburo Shiina.

COBALT, Conn., July 25-- Mr. and Mrs. Ian Shedden have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne MacLean Shedden, to Dr. Robert Jon Neviaser, son of Dr. and Mrs. Julius S. Neviaser of Washington, D.C.A. December wedding is planned.

The marriage of Mrs. Susan Dawson Cordes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Balloch Dawson of Washington and Brooklin, Me., to Weston Dugal Thomas, son of Mr. and Mrs. Weston Gage Thomas of Delray Beach, Fla., took place here at the Unitarian Church of All Souls yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) --The West German Government has asked the State Department to join in an appeal to the United States Supreme Court in which three German shipyards are seeking payment for work done on three American ships, officials disclosed today.
Mayor Lindsay described the Surrogate race in Manhattan yesterday as "a very unfortunate situation."
LOS ANGELES, July 25 (AP)--Elliott Roosevelt, Mayor of Miami Beach and son of President Franklin D. Roosevelt, was sued today for $1,545,000 over a deal to buy an apartment building.
Frank Sinatra will star on a musical show to be televised Wednesday, Dec. 7, from 9 to 10 P.M. by the Columbia Broadcasting System.

The Democratic gubernatorial campaign, all sweetness and gentlemanly good form until now, is beginning to take a more normal coloration. If there is anything New York's Democrats enjoy more than clobbering the G.O.P., it is fighting with one another. The first step in turning this year's decorous campaign into a free-for-all has just been taken by Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr.

Within the next few days the Office of Education expects to close an agreement with an independent research group for a study of the Federally supported theaters in Providence, R.I., and New Orleans. In the fall these theaters will begin a striking experiment--a series of free morning and afternoon performances of classic and modern plays produced and acted by professionals for highschool students.
GENEVA, July 25 (Reuters)--The Soviet Union and the United States agreed in principle today that countries are liable for damage caused to other countries by objects launched into space.
WASHINGTON, July 25--The Treasury bill rate retreated substantially at today's auction from Bills last week's record level, the Treasure disclosed tonight.

A theater party on the evening of Sept. 24 at the Metropolitan Opera's first performance of Richard Strauss's "Die Frau ohne Schatten" at its new building in Lincoln Center will aid the Musicians Emergency Fund.

The United Aircraft Corporation reported yesterday firsthalf net income of $21,604,898, or $1.85 a share on 11,664,275 common shares, against $21,152,649, or $1.83 a share on 11,169,372 shares, a year earlier. Shipments and billings reached a record $762,847,141, compared with $665,194,677.

SEAFORD, L.I., July 25-- Msgr. William A. Delaney, pastor of St. James Roman Catholic Church, Hicksville Road, died Thursday at Mercy Hospital, Rockville Centre, L.I., after a short illness. He was 66 years old and lived at the church rectory at 80 Hicksville Road.
LONDON, July 25 (UPI)-- Cassius Clay hammered the heavy bag with bare fists and sparred seven rounds today as he began training for his Aug. 6 heavyweight title defense against Brian London.

The Pacific Lighting Corporation reported yesterday gains in operating revenues for the first half and 12 months ended June 30. Net income for the half edged ahead of the 1965 period but fell below the level of the 12 months ended June 30, 1965.

Mr. and Mrs. Alexander E. Shanley of the Bronx have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alexia Ann Shanley, to Lieut. George Y. Jumper Jr., U.S.A.F., son of Colonel Jumper, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Jumper of Loomis, Calif. The wedding is planned for late next month.
The city will press for a measure in the next Legislature that would revoke the ownership registration of drivers who failed to pay for three or more parking tickets received over an 18-month period.

Commodities went their own way yesterday without showing much concern abut the declining stock market. The force of supply and demand was apparently much more interesting to many traders than lack of confidence expressed by a declining market.
HOUSTON, July 25--After much late-inning turmoil, the New York Mets emerged with a 6-4 victory over the Houston Astros in their first confrontation with "Astroturf" tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, July 25 (UPI)--Joe Frazier, unbeaten 1964 Olympic heavyweight champion, scored a technical knockout over Billy Daniels of Brooklyn tonight when Daniels was unable to start the seventh round following his fourth knockdown. It was scored as a sixth-round knockout.
New York City will have to pay its highest interest rate in 34 years when it seeks to borrow $112,925,000 in the municipal bond market today.
LONDON, July 25--Parliament voted tonight, 328 to 247, to nationalize the steel industry, and the Conservative Opposition vowed to do everything in its power to frustrate the measure.
SUMMIT, N.J., July 25-- Mrs. William Tracy of Essex Fells, eight times a runner-up, today won the Women's New Jersey Golf Association's 43d annual stroke-play championship.
GREENWOOD LAKE, N.Y., July 25--Conservation Rangers here obtained a warrant tonight for the arrest of a man who allegedly refused to help fight a forest fire last Saturday.
Residents of Cooper Square on the East Side won a round yesterday in their 10-year battle with City Hall over the redevelopment of their neighborhood.

Treasury bills, notes and bonds all rose in price yesterday as the market headed into the week that the Government is expected to announce its plans to refund $9.1-billion of securities maturing next month.
The interim earnings report of the Armco Steel Corporation added materially yesterday to the growing belief that halfyear profits of the steel industry may be less than those of a year ago.
GENEVA, July 25--A worldwide conference of more than 400 Christian theologians and laymen called today for the acceptance of "radical" action for promoting rapid social change.
MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., July 25--Dr. Henry A. Rogan of Pleasantville, a physician, died yesterday in Northern Westchester Hospital at the age of 63.
A small, informal group of amateur divers plunges somewhere into the Atlantic off the East Coast each weekend to discover sunken wrecks, drift through their eerie passageways and search for trophies.
Stocks prices fell sharply yesterday in the worst market setback since the assassination of President Kennedy 32 months ago.
Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc., and the AlbertoCulver Company have parted, though there is some disagreement between the agency and the client as to why.
LEXINGTON, Ky., July 25 (AP)--Johnny Longden, the former jockey, paid $200,000 tonight for a thoroughbred son of Bold Ruler. The price was the highest paid at an auction for a yearling.
WASHINGTON, July 25--The mystery of how many times Senator Thomas J. Dodd was reimbursed for air fare to California in February, 1964, deepened today.

CLEVELAND, July 25--Common Pleas Judge Thomas J. Parrino ordered today a special grand jury session to investigate the week of racial rioting in the Hough area of the city and to try to determine its causes.
MOSCOW, July 25 (AP)-- Soviet and American fishing officials began talks here on United States complaints that Russian ships have been catching too many fish off the American coasts.

The New York Central Railroad reported yesterday an 80 per cent increase in its earnings for the first half this year. The railroad's results for the quarter to June 30 were the highest for that period in the company's history.
The Massachusetts Investors Trust, the country's oldest and largest open-end common stock fund, reported yesterday its net asset value a share was $16.03 on June 30, down from $16.78 on March 31.

The Glen Alden Corporation, a diversified company with interests in the textile, theater and building materials industries, is planning to enter the apparel manufacturing and retailing business through the purchase of the controlling interest in the B.V.D. Company, Inc.
HANOVER, N.H., July 25 --The fourth annual Con- gregation of the Arts, which began at Dartmouth College here on June 27 and will run about nine weeks, is again a major international festival.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 25 (UPI)--Greentree Stable's O'Hara rallied in the stretch to capture the 25th running of the $85,650 Sunset Handicap today by two lengths at Hollywood Park as the favored Native Diver faded to sixth.

HOAGY CARMICHAEL, the composer, played the piano in the Sheraton-East ballroom recently. Some members of his audience rested on bergeres, down sofas and a Louis XIV bench. Others leaned against a row of television sets.
An indictment charging Miguel Arroyo, a 42-year-old Brooklyn grocer, with the fatal shooting of a boy was dismissed yesterday. Another man has been charged with the crime.

URAL ALEXIS JOHNSON, a career diplomat for 31 of his 57 years who has been named Ambassador to Japan to succeed Edwin O. Reischauer, is no stranger to the East nor to some of the unpleasant aspects of its recent past, Mr. Johnson was United States vice consul in Muk- den, Manchuria, in December, 1941; when the Japanese struck at Pearl Harbor. He was placed under house

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 25 --The New York Jets, who got through their first week of practice without an injury, prepared today for Wednesday night's rookie game with the Boston Patriots at Lowell, Mass. Weeb Ewbank, the Jets' coach, will pay close attention to the performances of his rookie centers and tight ends.
Far too few Negroes and Puerto Ricans attend the City University, Mayor Lindsay said yesterday in an address at City College.
MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 25 (UPI)--The 56-foot cutter, Blitzen, was spotted tonight by the Coast Guard 30 miles from the finish line in the annual Chicago-to-Mackinac yacht race.

Negotiations yesterday between the pressmen's union and the World Journal Tribune, Inc., failed to produce an agreement to end the 92-day-old strike that has prevented the new enterprise from publishing.

HONG KONG July 25--A report of a nine-mile swim in the Yangtze River by Mao Tse-tung was the principal news today in all Peking papers, which hailed the "wonderful health" of the 72-year-old Communist leader.
Thirty-seven persons in three cities have died from a heart ailment that may be linked to very heavy drinking of beer.
The three major bond-rating services look upon municipalities much as a prosecuting attorney might look upon a defendant in a criminal case.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP)--Ricky Paulsen, 9 years old, got action when he sent a letter to President Johnson.

PARIS, July 25--Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara today criticized a tendency of some North Atlantic allies toward what he called a double standard in their views of the necessity for the alliance.
PARIS, July 25--The French haute couture collections for winter started here today, but there was no pos- sible way of knowing this in the salon of Louis Feraud.

PARIS, July 25 (AP)--A five-year defense plan approved by the North Atlantic defense ministers today gives special attention to the flank areas of Europe--especially the southeastern region--and orders a study on new financing for a mobile force that could help defend them.
LOS ANGELES, July 25-- Jacob D. Fuchsberg, a New York lawyer, was elected today to his third term as president of the Roscoe Pound-American Trial Lawyers Foundation.
WASHINGTON, July 25-- The Office of Economic Opportunity has opened a new venture in housing for the poor.

The hoists and giant cranes on construction sites throughout the city were motionless yesterday, and plumbing work was halted because of strikes that could soon slow and later halt work on $1-billion worth of construction projects here.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., July 25--Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union, the recent challenger for the world chess championship, and Lajos Portisch of Hungary have tied for the lead after drawing their fifth-round game in the Platigorsky Cup Tournament at the Miromar Hotel here last night. Each has scored three points out of five.
MOSCOW, July 25--Streets in the residential quarters of Moscow were strangely silent this evening.
Merchants in the East New York section of Brooklyn complained of declining business yesterday, as the police continued augmented patrols in the area and the streets remained quiet.
The spot rate on the British pound remained unchanged at $2.7911 after moderate trading on foreign-exchange markets here yesterday.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 113.5 on Friday from 113.8 on Thursday.

VIENTIANE, Laos, July 25 (AP)--Prince Khamphan Panya, half-brother of King Savang Vatthana of Laos, died of a heart attack in Bangkok last night. The Prince, who was 49 years old, had served as Ambassador to Washington from 1962 until a heart ailment forced him to retire in 1965.
MEXICO CITY, July 25 (UPI)--Entrance requirements for Cuban exiles coming into the United States via Mexico have been eased, the United States Consul General, Antonio Certosimo, said today.

FREEHOLD, N.J., July 25-- Dr. Carl A. Coppolino, a 34year-old physician, writer and hypnotist already under indictment here in the strangling of a retired Army officer, was indicted today by a Sarasota, Fla., grand jury on charges of murdering his wife.
Luggage retailers, buoyed by the surge in travel and the general health of the economy, congregated in New York this week to plan their buying for the big Christmas season.

WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L.I., July 25--The Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's annual Cruise Week regatta got underway today with several close finishes. The size of the fleet fell far below expectations, with only 220 craft.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 25 (AP)--Juan Marichal pitched a six-hitter as the San Francisco Giants defeated the first-place Pittsburgh Pirates, 2-1, today and moved to within 2 percentage points of the National League lead.

Standard Poor's lowering of New York City's credit rating is neither timely nor warranted. Coming just before the city is forced to borrow in an already strained money market, the downgrading of its credit will increase its costs while diminishing the attractiveness of its obligations.

President Ho Chi Minh's statement that there is "no trial in view" for American military prisoners in North Vietnam is a victory for the moral influence of world opinion. That victory transcends the fate of the captive airmen, for it offers hope that common sense and common humanity ultimately may prevail against the ever greater barbarism the war in Vietnam daily inflicts on both sides.

MINSK, U.S.S.R., July 25 (AP)--The Soviet Union, competing without some of its stars, held a slim 74-72 lead over Poland at the end of the first day of the first dual track meet between the two Communist countries, Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported today.

MAPLEWOOD, N.J., July 25 --Lester A. Palmer, who for 40 years served as starter, scorer and general supervisor of golf tournaments in the New York metropolitan area, died Saturday in his home, 5 Fairview Terrace. He was 75 years old.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 25 (AP)--With support from B-52 bombers and Naval guns, United States marines hunted along North Vietnam's border today for trails of a North Vietnamese Army division believed to be shattered and on the run for sanctuaries in the North and in Laos.
The New Jersey Turnpike Authority disclosed yesterday that it expects to raise $180million between now and midSeptember to expand the northern section of the heavily used toll road.

MUNSTER, Ind., July 25 (UPI)--Federal aviation investigators gathered many eyewitness reports today saying the engines sputtered before a chartered plane carried Tony Lema, the golfer, his wife, and two other persons to a fiery death on a golf course yesterday.

Francis J. Le Maire has joined the American Title Insurance Company, Guaranteed Title division, as vice president and manager of the White Plains office. Mr. Le Maire, a lawyer, has been active in title insurance for 30 years.

Dr. Zachary R. Cottler died of a heart ailment yesterday at Brooklyn Jewish Hospital, where he was an attending urologist and vice president of the medical staff. He was 58 years old and lived at 1006 East 19th Street, Brooklyn.

Frank O'Hara, a poet-critic and an associate curator of paintings and sculpture exhibitions at the Museum of Modern Art, died last night at Bayview Hospital, Mastic Beach, L.I. He had been struck by a taxicab on Fire Island Sunday morning. Mr. O'Hara was 40 years old and lived at 790 Broadway.
The Boeing Company's board of directors gave the final goahead yesterday for building the giant 747 jetliner--the world's biggest commercial air transport, capable of carrying 490 passengers.
WASHINGTON, July 25-- Premier Nguyen Cao Ky of South Vietnam has called for an armed confrontation with Communist China now rather than later.

BONN, July 25--Chancellor Ludwig Erhard suffered another blow to his prestige today when the Christian Democratic party barely managed to retain control of the state government of North Rhine-Westphalia.
WASHINGTON, July 25--The Senate overrode its Foreign Relations Committee today and voted a two-year authorization for the Alliance for Progress with Latin American countries. The vote was 54 to 31.
MIAMI, July 25--Cuba's ruling Communist party has removed the first secretary of the party in Camaguey province, the Havana radio said today.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (UPI)--Luci Baines Johnson has chosen a 300-pound, sevenlayer wedding cake, topped not with the traditional wedding bells or miniature bride and groom but with real lilies-ofthe-valley, the White House announced today.

Samuel Schneider, president of Schneider Reich, Inc., 79 Fifth Avenue, manufacturers of boys' and students' clothing, died Sunday in Liberty, N.Y., where he was on vacation. He was 86 years old and lived at 11 Riverside Drive.
OCEANSIDE, L.I., July 25-- The engagement of Miss Sandra Adrian Jacobs to Charles Adams Rose, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Sanford A. Jacobs, parents of the bride-to-be.
NIEDERBRECHEN, Germany July 25 (UPI)--A bus carrying Belgian children home from an Alpine vacation plunged off a bridge on the autobahn today, killing 33 people.
PEKING, July 25 (Reuters) --China's young men and boys have been told by the Communist Youth League that there is nothing shameful in lending a hand with household chores.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 25 --Lieutenant General Suharto, who is in effect Indonesia's ruler, today was named chairman of the Presidium of a new Indonesian Cabinet. Most of the political allies of President Sukarno who remain have been excluded from the Cabinet.

PATERSON, N.J., July 25-- Msgr. William F. Louis, vicar general of the Roman Catholic diocese of Paterson from 1964 to last October and administrator of the diocese from then until last February, died yesterday in St. Joseph's Hospital. His age was 61.
A man followed a fireman up a long aerial ladder in the Bronx last night and entered a flaming fifth-floor apartment intent, not on rescue, but on burglary, the police reported.

THE HAGUE, July 25--Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, James Callaghan, said tonight the six-month wage-price freeze requested by the Labor Government was not necessary to restore balance to Britain's external payments.

SANDS POINT, L.I., July 25--Mr. and Mrs. Thomas D. Flynn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Christine Alice Flynn, to John David Eberts, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edmond H. Eberts of Montreal.

HOUSTON, July 25--As the New York Mets ar- rived here for a three-game series with their fellow expansionists, the Houston Astros, and the Yankees rested in New York, it was an appropriate moment for another attempt to place the two New York teams in perspective.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 25--For the 214th time in 18 years the Security Council met today to discuss conflicts between Israel and her Arab neighbors.

Mrs. John F. Kennedy and her two children, Caroline, 9 years old, and John Jr., 5, arrived at Kennedy International Airport aboard a commercial airliner yesterday morning, looking tanned and healthy following their seven-week holiday in Hawaii.
MONTICELLO, N.Y.--"What should I do with $100,000 to invest?" an elderly lady asked a stock market lecturer last week at Grossinger's.
WASHINGTON, July 25-- A diverse group calling itself Americans Want To Know left on a "fact-finding mission" to Cambodia tonight to determine whether the Vietnam war is spreading.
The Board of Elections urged the city yesterday to set up a voter registration program throughout the city running from Aug. 1 to Sept. 3.

TRACING the cause and establishing the responsi bility for a fish kill--some substance in the water that is fatal to fish--is a task taken right out of detective fiction, since the toxic material and fish often rapidly vanish.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., July 25--Casey Stengel and Ted Williams were inducted into Baseball's Hall of Fame today in resplendent ceremonies that crowded, thrilled and touched this country village where baseball was born a century and a quarter ago.

CUYAHOGA FALLS, Ohio, July 25--The engagement of Miss Jennifer Ann Hesketh, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Hesketh, to Rodger Irvin Thompson, son of Mr. and Mrs. William B. Thompson, has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be.
DETROIT, July 25 (AP) The United States auto industry headed into the final days of its 1966-model run this week, with a small number of 1967's already showing up in production reports.

THE Open Team event, which concluded the Greater New York Bridge Association's Brooklyn tournament Sunday, was won by a five-man squad comprising Sol Robinow, Robert McPherran, Jacqui Mitchell and Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd Ribner, all of New York.
Prices rose fractionally in light trading on the London Stock Exchange yesterday as investors continued to study the implications of the Government's austerity program announced last week.

PRINCETON, W.Va., July 25 (AP)--Two young sisters burned to death today in the back seat of their mother's car as she drove along the West Virginia Turnpike, unaware of a fire engulfing the back seat of the car, the state police said.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 25 (UPI)--The United States Navy airman who escaped from a North Vietnamese prison watched from hiding as Communist soldiers beheaded a companion who escaped with him, United States military sources said today.
KHARTOUM, the Sudan, July 25 (Reuters)--Premier Mohammed Ahmed Mahgoub resigned today after a defeat in a Constituent Assembly censure vote.

Gov. Richard J. Hughes of New Jersey warned yesterday that he would resort to his veto power, if necessary, to block what he termed unreasonable demands by New York City over the proposed World Trade Center.
WASHINGTON--It isn't misplaced charity to sug- gest that the restaurants of Washington have a certain wayward charm.

VIENTIANE, Laos, July 23-- Facing the teeming market here, with its squatting vegetable vendors and sandaled Laotian housewives are two big treeshaded villas guarded by impassive young Laotians who carry Soviet-made weapons.

MEXICO CITY, July 25--Mr. and Mrs. Albert Harkness Jr. of Mexico City and Matunuck, R.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances Harkness, to Carl Eric Peterson, son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Gunnar Peterson of Woods Hole, Mass.
ULAN BATOR, Mongolia, July 18--Petula Clark's haunting voice echoed through the dimly lighted lobby of the Ulan Bator Hotel. Her recording of "Downtown" is the hit of Ulan Bator's younger set.

LIVERPOOL, England, July 25 (Reuters)--West Germany reached the World Cup soccer final tonight with a 2-1 victory over the Soviet Union in a bruising match in which a Soviet winger, Igor Chislenko, was banished in the 44th minute for kicking a German player.

NEWARK, July 25 (AP)-- A New York concern that was allegedly enriched by the manipulations of Anthony DeAngelis agreed to pay $110,000 outright and abandon $725,243 in claims in Federal Bankruptcy Court today.
One of Wall Street's most sacred maxims, "A broker's word is his bond," may be amended shortly by the following phrase, "But there's nothing like getting it down on paper."
One of Wall Street's most sacred maxims, "A broker's word is his bond," may be amended shortly by the following phrase, "But there's nothing like getting it down on paper."
The Carte Blanche Corporation, a service affiliate of the First National City Bank, announced here yesterday the election of G. Wrede Petersmeyer as a director.
"The whole thing can be summed up in one word--uncertainty." That's how Alan N. Brenits, who heads the research department of Herzfeld Stern, evaluated the stock market's slide yesterday.
NEW YORK, N.Y. (Special) --After decades of familiar "deodorants," women are turning to an advanced new type of formula. And by the thousands they are finding it far more effective.

GRIGORI KOZINTSEV'S commentary on four of Shakespeare's plays and on Shakespeare generally will stimulate the reader in two ways: when he agrees with him and when he doesn't. In one case he will appreciate the fruitful insights into the poet's work; in the other the arguments will be a whetstone against which the reader can sharpen his own disagreements.
WASHINGTON, July 25-- The House Commerce Committee unanimously approved today an auto safety bill requiring the establishment of mandatory Federal standards for new and used cars and tires.
Al Davis stepped down yesterday as commissioner of the American Football League and was replaced by Milt Woodard, the former assistant commissioner and secretary-treasurer.
Record net earnings of $128.6million for the first six months of this year were reported yesterday by the Standard Oil Company (Indiana).
The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation reported yesterday new highs in telephone revenues, manufacturing sales, and consolidated net income for the second quarter and first half.

YONKERS, July 25--Nearly everything about tonight's dry, warm-weather reopening of Yonkers Raceway, which launched its 74-night, secondhalf meeting, was good, including the crowd of 24,089 and the mutuel handle of $1,932,154.
HOLLYWOOD, July 25--Albert McCleery has been named executive producer-director of the Pasadena Playhouse, it was announced today. He succeeds C. Lowell Lees, who resigned.
GENEVA, July 25--Over the opposition of Western maritime nations, the shipping committee of the United Nations Board Trade and Development voted today to undertake a study of ocean freight rates.
LONDON, July 25 (AP)-- The World Soccer Federation suspended three Uruguayan stars today and recommended disciplinary action against England's team manager, Alf Ramsey.
Donaldson, Lufkin Jenrette, Inc., members of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday the election of George D. Gould and Carl H. Tiedemann as executive vice presidents.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 25--Chemicals lethal to plant life were sprayed over 59,000 acres of crops in Vietcong-controlled territory in the first six months of this year, American military officials reported today.
HOUSTON, July 25 (AP)-- Gemini 10 astronauts flew home today to rejoin their families and to finish describing for officials details of three days in space.

RECIFE, Brazil, July 25--A terrorist bomb killed three people today in a crowd gathered at the city airport to welcome the majority party's presidential candidate, General of the Army Artur Costa e Silva.
BEZIERS, France, July 25 (Reuters)--Karen Muir, a 13year-old South African swimmer, set a world record of 2 minutes 27.1 seconds for the women's 200-meter backstroke tonight.

Prof. D. Wayne Woolley of Rockefeller University, an internationally known authority on vitamins, hormones and enzymes, died of a heart attack Saturday in a hotel in Cuzco, Peru. He was 52 years old. He had remained active in research although he became blind nine years ago.

Edward Eastman Iremonger of 425 West 23d Street, vacation sales manager for United Air Lines, died Sunday in the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. His age was 62 and he formerly lived in Plainfield, N.J., where he had served on the Common Council.

A. $4.2-million Federal grant to train jobless and unskilled youths in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn was announced yesterday, but city antipoverty officials said they knew of no plans to put additional money into the racially troubled East New York section.

MOSCOW, July 25 (AP)-- Secretary General Thant of the United Nations said on his arrival today that he was going to discuss "ways and means of improving the international situation" with Soviet leaders. He made it clear that this included Vietnam.

Hirsch Jacobs went to the races at Aqueduct yesterday as a spectator. But after the eighth race, he was in the winner's circle, accepting congratulations for the victory just recorded by Isidor Bieber's 3-yearold filly, Well Played. The achievement, not to be noted ordinarly, marked a monumental point in Jacobs's four decades as a trainer. The victory was the 3,500th of his career.
PRAGUE, July 25 (AP)-- President Ho Chi Minh gave a new hint of leniency today for American airmen held captive in North Vietnam.
Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. proposed a "deal" last year to win the backing of Robert F. Wagner for the Democratic nomination for Governor, a top aide in the Beame-for-Mayor campaign said yesterday.

BALTIMORE, July 25--Mr. and Mrs. Eric Lloyd Bergland have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Mower Bergland, to Robert Daniels Falconer Jr. of Westport, Conn., son of Mr. and Mrs. Falconer of Toledo, Ohio.
A compact, heavy duty aircooled air-conditioner has been developed as an economical means of making older office buildings competitive with new centrally air-conditioned structures.

Congressional action has plainly become the only realistic hope for a quick end to the paralyzing airlines strike. The Senate Labor Committee will hear from members of President Johnson's Cabinet today precisely how serious the strike's impact has been. We hope its hearing will be followed by swift passage of legislation to get the planes back into the air and thus restore normalcy to a key segment of the nation's transportation lifeline.
Philadelphia Laboratories, Inc., announced yesterday the election of Harold F. Boardman as president and a director.
Stock prices registered yesterday the steepest decline in 32 months.

The re-election of Charles A. Buckley to his sixth two-year term as leader of the Bronx County Democratic organization brings to a halt efforts to mod- ernize that antiquated machine. A real opportunity to oust the 76-year-old boss has been lost through a combination of circumstances, which were foreshadowed...

BALTIMORE, July 26 (UPI) Rocky Colavito and Leon Wagner slammed two home runs each and Fred Whitfield blasted one tonight to pace the Cleveland Indians to a 7-4 victory over the league-leading Baltimore Orioles.
WASHINGTON, July 26 Corporations issued a record $10.1-billion in new securities for cash in the first half of this year, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

Jesse Gray, the Harlem rent strike leader, was ordered last night by Criminal Court Judge Arthur Braun to appear in Family Court this morning to answer a charge of nonsupport brought by his estranged wife, Rosa.

Held Cabinet meeting; lunched with Secretary Rusk and acting Defense Secretary Vance; sent Congress a report on activities of the Commodity Credit Corporation for the fiscal year ended June 30; received report from Whitney M. Young Jr., executive director of the National Urban League, on his recent trip to Vietnam.
Francis Edwards Faragoh, a writer of screenplays, died Sunday in a San Francisco hospital after a short illness following a tracheotomy. He was 71 years old.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange continued to weaken yesterday although declines were not as severe as on Monday when the market turned in its second-worst performance of the year.

NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., July 26--Eugene H. Nickerson, Nassau County Executive who is seeking the Democratic nomination for Governor, tried today to win over county delegates who have committed themselves to support Frank C. O'Connor for the nomination.
With the economy poised somewhere between Wall Street's fears of a recession and Washington's fears of inflation, the guessing game on the outlook for business ac-tivity has become wide open.

BETHESDA, Md., July 26 Mr. and Mrs. Llewellyn C. Thomas have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ellen Beall Thomas, to Richard Alan Henshaw, son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Richard Henshaw of Gambier, Ohio.
Organized labor threatened yesterday to resign from a special panel set up here to avoid crises in negotiations between the city and public employe unions.

WASHINGTON, July 26 Senator Mike Mansfield, the Senate majority leader, called on the Johnson Administration today to dissociate itself "completely and at once" from proposals for an invasion of North Vietnam and an armed confrontation with Communist China.

BALTIMORE, July 26 The 36,000-ton tanker Valley Forge, capable of carrying 17 types of petroleum products and chemicals at one time, was launched here today at the Sparrows Point shipyard of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation.

NECTARINES were known to the Chinese 2,000 years ago, but it has taken plant breeders a great deal of time and effort to achieve the large blush variety we find in markets today. In the last 12 years, the nectarine harvest in this country has increased from 38-million pounds to 152-million
MIAMI, July 26 Some 5,000 deer and other wildlife in a 900square-mile conservation district were threatened today with extinction by a man-made flood in Florida's Everglades.
WASHINGTON, July 26 Senator Robert F. Kennedy said today that there was "a distinct possibility" he might not endorse any candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor of New York.

The retirement of Dr. Samuel I. Kooperstein as medical director of the Port of New York Authority effective Friday was announced yesterday. Dr. Kooperstein has been with the agency for 38 years; the last 24 years as head of the medical department.

CHICAGO, July 26 Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Charles Gaecke have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jean Laverne Gaecke of Boston, to Joseph Meredith Boyd Jr., son of Mrs. Boyd of Elmhurst, Queens, New York, and the late Mr. Boyd.
WASHINGTON, July 26 Following are the parties involved, the issues in dispute, and a brief summary of the effects of the airline strike:
The New York Central Railroad said yesterday that it planned to discontinue all its long-haul passenger trains by the end of this year.
Prince Khampan, former Laotian Ambassador to the United States, died Sunday in Bangkok, Thailand, after a heart attack. He was 58 years old.

The Rumanian Folk Ballet has called off its scheduled summer appearances in the United States because of "public opinion in Rumania," according to Osta, the official Rumanian concert bureau in Budapest.
WASHINGTON, July 26 The Senate passed a $2.06-billion authorization for economic foreign aid today $409-million below the Administration's request.
Representatives of key New York film unions took sharp exception yesterday to charges made here last weeK that local labor costs are substantially higher than those on the West Coast.
WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) Secretary of Defense McNamara returned tonight from the Paris meeting of NATO North-Atlantic Treaty Organization defense ministers.

Sanford Weil Stark of 25 East 77th Street and Naples, Fla., a furniture sales representative, died yesterday of a heart attack in Southampton (L.I.) Hospital at the age of 62. His clubs included the New York Athletic and Atlanta Athletic.

Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. and Frank D. O'Connor angrily pursued their debate yesterday over Mr. Roosevelt's charge that Mr. O'Connor had made a "deal" with two party leaders a year ago to get the nomination for Governor.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., disclosed yesterday declines in net income for both the six and 12 months ended June 30. However, operating revenues for both periods ran higher than those in the comparable 1965 spans, the firsthalf report showed.
The Bronx Zoo plans to construct a two-acre buffalo island in the Bronx River.
WASHINGTON, July 26 The House Commerce Committee opened hearings today on a Senate-approved "truth-inpackaging" bill designed to simplify the housewife's marketing task.
The F.W. Woolworth name, which has appeared on company-owned variety stores for the last 87 years, will in the near future be emblazoned on many small, independent stores around the country.
About 15,000 commuters were delayed yesterday by trouble on the Pennsylvania Railroad and the Long Island Rail Road.
MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 26 (UPI) Blitzen, a 56foot cutter that won last year's Chicago-to-Mackinac yacht race did it again today.
OBERAMMERGAU, Germany, July 26 (AP) The Judas of the 1960 Oberammergau Passion Play has won a victory in his campaign to remove anti-Semitic overtones from the worldfamous drama.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI) William H. Whalen, the former Army officer who is under indictment for conspiring to sell military secrets, was taken to an Army hospital to- day after complaining of chest pains.
World ship-building activity at the end of the second quarter rose to a new high Lloyd's Register of Shipping reported yesterday.

Earnings of the United States Steel Corporation fell in the second-quarter and first six months of this year from 1965 levels, Roger M. Blough, chairman, told his regular quarterly news conference yesterday.

LYNBROOK, L.I., July 26 Mr. and Mrs. Leo L. Haskell have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carol Jean Haskell, to Lawrence J. Feldman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel S. Feldman of Quincy, Mass.
FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 26 The Turk and The Nutcracker Drill provided the news today at the New York Giants' training camp.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 26 (UPI) Rescue planes and ships, hampered by bad weather, criss-crossed the Pacific today in a search for Brig. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell Jr., who vanished with two others on a flight to Honolulu.
Cautious bargain-hunters and nervous sellers confronted each other in the stock market yesterday in the wake of the sharp drop in prices on Monday.

The current fight over the proposed $34-million extension of the West Front of the United States Capitol is generating enough heat and smoke to obscure a $75-million Capitol Hill project going ahead in near-secrecy that informed observers are con-...
DETROIT, July 26 (AP) The first Negro resident of the Detroit area's most exclusive section is "surprised and shocked" at the hostility that greeted him. Despite it, he said, "I'm there to stay."
NORWALK, Conn., July 26 Miss Kathryn Janet Roen and James Gordon Woodward, former Peace Corps volunteers in Liberia, were married today.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP)--A Federal Trade Commission examiner said today that Campbell Taggart Associated Bakeries, Inc., of Dallas, the nation's second-largest chain baking company, should divest itself of nine bakeries it acquired since 1954.

WASHINGTON, July 26 Roy Wilkins said tonight that without an uncompromised open housing section the Johnson Administration's 1966 civil rights bill "will not be sufficient" to prevent "heartbreaking developments that could be ugly as well."
The bond markets were more concerned yesterday with new issues than with price movements for already outstanding securities.

VIENTIANE, Laos, July 23 Although he has endorsed the Vietcong "anti-imperialist" struggle against "imperialism," Prince Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia has sharply condemned pro-Communist forces in neighboring Laos for claiming Cambodian territory.
The Chemical Bank of New York Trust Company has appointed Lord Cobbold to its international advisory board, William S. Renchard, chairman, announced yesterday.

The Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway, the topmoney-maker of the nation's transportation companies in 1965, reported a consolidated profit yesterday of $26,012,549, or 99 cents a common share, for the three months to Sept. 30. In the like 1965 quarter, the carrier reported earnings of $25,617,231, or 98 cents a share.
The revenues and earnings of the world's largest oil producer the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) set records in the second quarter and first half of this year.

PASSAIC, N.J., July 26 The engagement of Miss Judith Abby Hurevitz to Joel Bernstein has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Charles Hurevitz, parents of the bride-to-be. Mr. Bernstein is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Bernstein of New York.

MIAMI, July 26 (AP) The fifth tropical storm of the season churned harmlessly past the Leeward Islands today with top winds of 50 miles an hour, but the Weather Bureau predicted it would grow stronger tomorrow.
Mrs. Edythe Angell Kearns, former wife of the late Jack Kearns, manager of Jack Dempsey and other boxing champions, died Monday in her home, 140 West 72d Street. She was 68 years old.
A thoroughbred who has shown signs of greatness and of being injury prone returns to the races today in the $25,000 added Gravesend Handicap at Aqueduct.
Trading was extremely active yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Prices moved up the limit during the day and closed at that level up 100 points of 1 cent a pound.
The American Broadcasting Company will televise this fall the third annual World Surfing Championship, which is being held in the United States for the first time this year.

An engineering wonder achieved by South American aborigines before the time of Columbus has been discovered largely through aerial photography. It consists of a far-flung system of parallel ridges constructed with mathematical precision at right angles to certain waterways, particularly in the lowlands of Colombia.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 26 Mr. and Mrs. Gerard Joseph Forney of San Francisco and New Delhi have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne-Marie Forney, to Jerome Sorenson Fenton, son of Jerome D. Fenton of Carmel and Mrs. Elizabeth C. Fenton of New York.

Dewey B. Holland, a vice president and head of the production department of Doremus Co., New York advertising agency, died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital after a short illness. He was 67 years old and lived at 68-60 108th Street, Forest Hills, Queens.
A new treatment program that will attempt "to turn the tide of narcotics addiction in the city" was announced yesterday by Mayor Lindsay. Dr. Efren Ramirez, the city's

J. Raymond Jones, the New York County Democratic leader, said yesterday that he and Senator Robert F. Kennedy had agreed to screen State Supreme Court candidates publicly prior to the coming judicial convention. He called a screening session for tomorrow night.

The team that the New York Yankees have harassed most persistently this season has been the defending champion Minnesota Twins. But the Twins turned on their tormentors last night and, largely through the stout pitching of a 21-year-old extrovert named Dave Boswell, overpowered the Yankees, 6-3.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., July 26 The Wimbledon champion, Mrs. Billie Jean King, had to play at the top of her game today to defeat 16-year-old Patti Hogan in the second round of the Eastern grasscourt tennis championships and the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 26 A South African expedition is reported to have found the last survivors of a legendary tribe of River Bushmen in the Okovanggo swamps in northern Bechuanaland, the British protectorate in southern Africa.
Bulova Watch Company, Inc., which last year test-marketed its Accutron electronic watch in the women's field, is extending its production in preparation for a full-scale entry into that market.

The sharpness with which the Conference on Church and Society that ended in Geneva Monday criticized American policies in Vietnam reflects not only a concern for peace but also a fundamental shift of the balance of power within the World Council of Churches.

The Committee for Independent Political Action on the West Side announced yesterday that its candidate for Representative in the 19th Congressional District would be James Weinstein, chairman of the committee. The incumbent is Representative Leonard Farbstein, a Democrat.
OCEANPORT, N.J., July 26 (AP) Horn Quarter, a 3-yearold daughter of First Landing, led most of the mile and a sixteenth to win the feature at Monmouth Park today by a length and three-quarters.

EAST NORWICH, L.I., July 26 Daniel Edlind of the Garden City Country Club scored a oneover-par 37, 35 72 today to lead the field in the Long Island sectional qualifying for the Metropolitan Golf Association's amateur championship. The round was played over the 6,870yard Pine Hollow Country Club course.

DARIEN, Conn., July 26 In St. John's Roman Catholic Church this morning, Miss Wendy Knox, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Van Santvoord Knox Jr., was married to Ens. John Bulkowski, U.S.N. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Bulkowski of Abington, Mass.

Frank G. Breyer, a partner in the chemical engineering firm of Singmaster Breyer, 235 East 42d Street, died yesterday at the E.J. Noble Hospital in Alexandria Bay, N.Y. He was 79 years old and had homes on Axeman Island, Gananoque, Ont., and at Summerland Key, Fla.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., July 26 Ken Wilson of the New York Athletic Club and Mrs. Marcia Smoke of the Michigan Paddling Club scored their second victories today as the two day American trials for the world canoeing championships ended.

The city plans to press next year for state legislation to revoke the registration of automobiles for which three or more parking tickets have not been paid. This welcome weapon in the war against scofflaws would extend a principle that already applies to drivers who ignore summonses for moving violations. The idea is so good one wonders why the city didn't push for it while the Legislature was still in session this year.
CHICAGO, July 26 (UPI) Manager Leo Durocher of the Chicago Cubs was hospitalized here today with congestion and fever resulting from a cold.
MIAMI, July 26 Danish skippers won two of the first three races in the Danish-American challenge series today, but Americans were 1, 2, 3 in the standings when the day's sailing ended.
THIS offshore fishing season is certain to go down in the books as one of the more curious. The swordfish have gone somewhere other than where the fishermen are, and they remain a puzzle.

WASHINGTON, July 26 Imports rose 2 per cent in June to $2,114,900,000, seasonally adjusted, marking the fourth consecutive month in which imports have exceeded $2-billion, the Department of Commerce reported today.
WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) Comdr. Eugene A. Cernan received his Navy astronaut wings today from Adm. David L. McDonald and was confronted with a question from the Chief of Naval Operations.
THE cups and saucers that Roy Lichtenstein sculp tured have become real dinnerware produced by the Jackson China Company and sold by the Durable Dish Company.
OTTAWA, July 26 About 800 Ontario farmers drove their tractors on southern Ontario highways today to protest low milk prices and other grievances.
YADKINVILLE, N.C., July 26 (AP) An Air Force fighter plane crashed and burned tonight in a wooded area near Courtney, in North Carolina's Northern Piedmont area.

Ranking players of Australia, England, France, South Africa and New Zealand will compete in the Southampton invitation tennis tournament. Chuck McKinley of Port Washington, L.I. will defend the cup he won last year.

New Jersey authorities sought last night to extradite Dr. Carl A. Coppolino from Florida on a charge of having strangled a retired Army colonel. Florida officials, meanwhile, prepared to arraign the physician this morning on a charge that he had murdered his first wife.

Macy's New York is expected to announce soon that it will join with Alexander's Department Stores, Inc., in opening major stores in a new Brooklyn shopping center with boatdocking facilities for waterborne customers.

Brison Wood, former treasurer of Honeywell, Inc., died on Monday at Roosevelt Hospital, where he had been a patient for three days. He was 66 years old and had lived at St. Croix in the Virgin Island since his retirement 10 years ago.

LOS ANGELES, July 26 Damage suits against public officials who violate Negroes' rights can become the "secret weapon" of the civil rights effort, the nation's top personal injury lawyers were told today.

Paperboard production rose 2.5 per cent with 424,800 tons in the week ended July 23, from 414,600 tons in the corresponding 1965 week, the Paperboard Group of the American Paper Institute reported yesterday.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., July 26 State officials opened a box taken from the cornerstone of the Illinois State Capitol today and found a bottle of whisky presented to Abraham Lincoln "as an emblem of his administration."

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) The State Department said today that Poland had agreed to receive mail bearing a controversial United States stamp to be issued July 30 marking a thousand years of Christianity in that country.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 26 (Reuters) Indonesia's new 29-ministry Cabinet must act quickly to drop the country's policy of undeclared war with Malaysia so that the economy can be repaired, political observers said here today.
The Negro community of East New York buried 11-year-old Eric Dean yesterday with a plea for racial peace.

The MG Car Club's 14th annual 1,000-mile international rally will be run from Wednesday to Saturday next week. It will have a high-performance section over the Lime Rock course. Special prizes for this run have been provided by the Nisonger-KLG Corp. of New Rochelle, N.Y. Other trophies...
LONDON, July 26--Britain's highest court, the House of Lords, overthrew today the doctrine that it may never change one of its own decisions.
WOODBURY, L. I., July 26--A barbecue will be held on the grounds of the Waldemar Medical Research Foundation on Aug. 7.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 26--Mayor Lindsay predicted here tonight that his fusion administration would be able to withstand political challenges from a Democratic organization led by Senator Robert F. Kennedy.
BRUSSELS, Wednesday, July 27 The Common Market agreed early today on final offers it will make in tariff-cutting talks with the United States.

THE telephone rang in the kitchen early Monday evening just as Lieut. Charles Oscar Henry was biting into a slice of leg of lamb. When he hung up the phone three minutes later he sat down, stared at his wife, Lida, and three children, and said with a smile: "C'est la vie, C'est
Daniel L. Street broke a strong and enduring Southern tradition yesterday in being elected to the presidency of the Brown-Forman Distillers Corporation.

Mrs. Elizabeth MacFarlane Whitman of Madison, N.J., prominent in church, civic and political activities, died of cancer on Monday in her home. She was 57 years old and was the wife of the Rev. Dr. Lauris B. Whitman, executive director of the department of research of the National Council of Churches.

The British pound was practically unchanged yesterday as the spot rate fell to $2.7909 from Monday's level of $2.7911 in light trading on foreign exchange markets here. Activity has decreased each day since last Thursday.
A crowd estimated at "over 75,000" people filled the Sheep Meadow in Central Park last night to hear Leonard Bernstein conduct the New York Philharmonic.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 27 Incomplete returns early today indicated that a racial moderate and a segregationist would face each other in a runoff primary, Aug. 9 for the Democratic nomination to succeed Gov. Orval E. Faubus.

EXETER, N.H., July 26 Mr. and Mrs. Elliot G. Fish have announced the engagement of Mrs. Fish's daughter, Miss Caroline Johnston Davis, to Andrew Gumpert Janover, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Janover of New York.

Mrs. Grace Geraldine McNaught Dodds, wife of the Rev. Carl J. Dodds, pastor of Memorial Methodist Church in Albertson, L.I., died Monday in Manhattan Veterans Administration Hospital. She was 46 years old.

"THE man who's gonna whup me," Cassius Clay had said, "is now 10 years old. There's a little bitty boy somewhere, walking around the sidewalks, and he doesn't even know yet he's gonna get interested in boxing."

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and Airport Parking Company of America announced yesterday changes in terms for their merger agreement. The two companies said the changes were due to Treasury regulations.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, July 27 Premier Nguyen Cao Ky said today that he had "no desire" to invade North Vietnam, but if his country's allies were not ready to keep fighting up to 15 years in South Vietnam "then we have to destroy the Communists in their lair."
BOSTON, July 26 (API) Joe Foy hit two home runs tonight to lead the Boston Red Sox to an 8-5 victory over the Kansas City Athletics.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., July 26 Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union, the recent challenger for the world chess title, moved into the lead in the Piatigorsky Cup Tournament after drawing his sixth-round game with Miguel Najdorf of Argentina, at the Miromar Hotel here last night.

ONE buys a new, expensive, better-make refrigerator and finds that its front is "decorated" with nonremovable adver- tisements for the company and that its sides do not extend back far enough to meet the kitchen wall. One drives a car known for its "sensible" design, and discovers that a little bump on the bumpers renders the engine and trunk compartment lids inoperable.

GARRISON, N.Y., July 26 Back in 1892, there was only one good excuse for building the big granite railroad depot that is now being refurbished by the residents of this tiny community about 50 miles from New York City: railroad tycoons wanted to wait for their trains in style.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 26 (AP) Jim Hart, who had gone hitless in 18 times at bat, broke his slump with a three-run homer today as the San Francisco Giants beat Pittsburgh, 8-3, and moved past the Pirates into first place in the National League, by a full game.
The election of J. Eliot McCormack as a senior vice president was announced yesterday by the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc.

A simple Episcopal funeral service was held at St. James's Church at Madison Avenue and 71st Street yesterday morning for Montgomery Clift, the 45year-old screen actor who died of a heart ailment here Saturday.

PHILADELPHIA, July 26 (UPI) The world-renowned Philadelphia Orchestra "will not play if we are unable to agree on a contract with the musicians before Sept. 15," C. Wanton Balis, president of the Philadelphia Orchestra Association, warned Tuesday.

TOKYO, July 26 (UPI) North Vietnam took the unusual step today of rebroadcasting three telegrams to Americans saying that no trial of American war prisoners was in view and that the prisoners would be treated humanely.
The city was forced to pay yesterday an interest rate of 4.65 per cent the highest in 34 years to borrow $112,925,000.
Mrs. Stelle Hyman Rogers of 175 East 62d Street died yesterday in Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospital after a long illness. She was 60 years old.

Latecomers to performances at the Metropolitan Opera at Lincoln Center will be allowed to watch the stage on closed-circuit television, but they will no longer be able to push their way to their seats during performances.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 26 The Security Council suspended consideration today of Syrian and Israeli charges of aggression against each other. The council decided to await a report by the United Nations truce supervisory organization on the scene.
CHICAGO, July 26 (AP) The Illinois Supreme Court issued an order today further delaying the annual stockholders' meeting of Crucible Steel Company, objective of a fight for control.

MOSCOW, July 26 Disturbed by a serious increase in crime, the Soviet Union announced today measures for greater central administration of the police and for harsher penalties for criminals and hooligans.

ATLANTA, July 26 (AP) Mike Shannon's two-run homer in the eighth inning enabled the St. Louis Cardinals to beat the Atlanta Braves, 4-3, tonight. The victory was the eighth in nine games for the Cards.
MOSCOW, July 26--A group of 22 American rabbis conducted a memorial service today in Kiev at Babi Yar, where thousands of Jews were shot by the Nazis after the capture of the city in World War II.
Reflecting an increase in quarterly sales and earnings, directors of Burlington Industries, Inc., announced yesterday a 5-cent increase in the quarterly dividend.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., July 26 Mrs. Stephen Christopher Meigher Jr. has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Ann Denise Meigher, to Dr. Henry Louis Smith 2d, son of Dr. and Mrs. Opie Norris Smith of Greensboro, N.C.

CLEVELAND, July 26 (AP) The general policy committee of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen announced today that it endorsed and approved a proposal to unite with the Order of Railway Conductors and Brakemen and the Switchmen's Union of North America.
The Theo. Hamm Brewing Company, St. Paul, Minn., announced yesterday the election of Roy M. Westly as executive vice president.

WASHINGTON, July 26 The Senate's two leaders today classified the airline strike as an emergency that might require special legislation. But the Senate still was waiting for word tomorrow on whether the Johnson Administration agreed.
PARIS, July 26 The North Atlantic Alliance came one step closer today to giving permanent status to its special committee on the sharing of control of nuclear weapons.
The American Trial Lawyer's Association has urged Congress to act on legislation that would wipe out "archaic" limitations on the liability of shipowners in sea disaster cases.

RICHARD PETTY, the Randleman, N.C., stock car driving star, has joined the Chrysler team for the Trans American six-hour sedan race at Danville's Virginia International Raceway on Sunday. He will pilot a Plymouth Barracuda. David Pearson, the current Grand National leader...

ESSEX FELLS, N.J. July 26 Mrs. Vera Curie Morris, the wife of Walter S. Morris, vice president and treasurer of Model, Roland Co., Inc., members of the New York Stock Exchange, died Friday of cancer in Mountainside Hospital in Montclair. She was 48 years old and lived at 13 Avon Drive.

The New York chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union contended yesterday in a Brooklyn courtroom that burning an American flag on a street corner could be "a most practical and effective way" to demonstrate for civil rights.

MIAMI, July 26 Premier Fidel Castro complained tonight that traditional Communist parties in Latin America opposed his strategy of armed struggle, which he described as the only correct way to obtain power.
CHICAGO, July 26 (UPI) Willie Horton hit three singles and a double tonight, driving in all the Tigers' runs as Detroit defeated the Chicago White Sox, 3-1.
Layoffs of nonstriking construction workers began yesterday as the strike by hoisting engineers, plumbers and some truckers slowed construction in several parts of the city.

WASHINGTON, July 26 A proposed giant "dossier bank" that could pull together all the scattered statistics about any American was pictured today as an unforgiving, unforgetful judge that would never give a person a second chance.

Sylvester K. Stevens, a historian, appealed yesterday to the United States District Court in New York (Southern District) to stop Helen Clay Frick, daughter of Henry Clay Frick, from pressing a legal action she has brought against him in Pennsylvania. A committee of 14 historians is supporting Dr. Stevens's suit.
Garment manufacturers in New York are seeking hundreds of additional workers to meet their fall and winter apparel production schedules.
The General Motors Corporation, the nation's largest manufacturing concern, suffered a substantial decline in earnings in the second quarter as sales slipped and costs climbed.
HOUSTON, July 26 The Mets downed the Houston Astros, 5-4, tonight for their 15th victory this month, a club record.
The city government will soon institute a new method for finding out what it should be doing and how it can do it most efficiently.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) The National Aeronautic Association said today the Soviet Government had approved the flight to Moscow of a Lockheed Hercules cargo plane that will carry three small sports planes to compete in the world aerobatic championships.
WASHINGTON, July 26 An early showdown between the Senate and House loomed today over efforts to block extension of the Capitol's West Front.
A $1-million Federal grant that was rejected by the Freeport, L.I., school board has been switched to the East New York section of Brooklyn for an experimental school program.
CAN Americans, to whom plumbing is a birth right, find happiness in a world where hot water is a luxury?"

The purchase by Glen Alden Corporation of 1 million shares of the B.V.D. Company, Inc., and its proposed tender offers for the remaining 2.3 million shares could add substantially to its earnings, a company source indicated yesterday.
Stock prices fell at the opening yesterday on the London Stock Exchange, but then held steady and closed with only fractional losses.
This is not another story about Wells, Rich, Greene, Inc. This is a story about all of the stories about Wells, Rich, Greene, Inc.

LONDON, July 26 It would be impossible, or at least almost impossible, to conceive of two dance troupes more different than the Georgian State Dance Company, which yesterday opened a London season at the Royal Festival Hall, and the Sierra Leone National Dance Troupe, currently playing a London season at the Sadler's Wells theater.
Northrup R. Knox of East Aurora, N. Y., will captain the United States polo team that will compete in the Cup of the Americas and world 30-goal tournaments this fall in Buenos Aires.

The Soviet Union's track and field team defeated Poland yesterday as their two-day meet ended in Minsk. The Russians were lucky. Had they faced the Americans, as they were scheduled to, comparative performances show they would have been routed.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) President Johnson's longstalled proposal for some 60 demonstration cities to attack slums got a nudge before the Senate Housing subcommittee today but its massive sweep was slashed drastically.
It was a great night for singing at Lewisohn Stadium, and one of the largest audiences of the Metropolitan Opera's current season was on hand to savor every gorgeous moment of it.
CINCINNATI, July 26 (AP) Deron Johnson's three-run homer broke a 6-6 tie in the eighth inning and lifted the Cincinnati Reds to a 9-6 victory over the Chicago Cubs tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 26 In a landmark decision recognizing air pollution as a national problem, the Federal Power Commission authorized the El Paso Natural Gas Company and the Transwestern Pipeline Company today to increase gas deliveries to the smog-ridden Los Angeles area.

PELHAM, N.Y., July 26 Mr. and Mrs. John A. Curley have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eileen Marie Curley, to George Walker McGoldrick, son of Mrs. Warren P. McGoldrick and the late Mr. McGoldrick.
WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI)--The Defense Department identified these 7 men from the New York area today among 37 United States servicemen killed in action in Vietnam: ...

Martin Fuchs has been appointed head of the construction department of National Shoes, Inc., replacing Jap Lipow, who has retired. The shoe chain has 10 new stores scheduled for completion this year and plans an average of 20 more each year through 1970.

The Maryland Shipbuilding and Drydock Company announced yesterday that it had reached agreement with Local 31, Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers, on a new three-year contract. The company said the contract called for 34-cent package increase over the period ending Aug. 1, 1969. The contract will be signed tomorrow.

An off-duty patrolman who assaulted a man during an argument about the strength of drinks at a party was penalized 30 days' pay and placed on probation for one year yesterday by Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary.

ON a clear day or cloudless night, four seasons a year, a bird's-eye view of Manhattan is something to publish abroad, but even with its towering buildings only half a dozen restaurants or so celebrate the fact. There is now, however, a new and engaging restaurant that hovers several hundred feet above the pavement, the Copter Club in the heliport lounge of the Pan Am Building.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 26 C. Hamilton Moses, one of Arkansas's most prominent corporation lawyers and a former president of the Arkansas Power and Light Company, died here last night, He was 79 years old.

TOKYO, July 26 Edwin O. Reischauer, the Tokyo-born Harvard professor of Oriental studies who became the American Ambassador here in 1961, acknowledged today that his departure from the Embassy later this summer would mark the end of a special era in the diplomatic relations between Japan and the United States.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 26--On a recent night in North Vietnam a column of 20 tarpaulin-covered trucks rolled down Highway 1 loaded with supplies destined for North Vietnamese soldiers fighting in South Vietnam.
CLEVELAND, July 26 The Ohio National Guard began withdrawing troops today from the riot-ravaged ough area as members of a special session of the county grand jury inspected the devastation.
LONDON, July 26 Leaders of organized labor approached agreement with the Government tonight on a modified form of the wage freeze sought by Prime Minister Wilson.
BOSTON, July 26 A new way of combating hospital surgical infections by massive flow of air through the operating room was described here today.
WASHINGTON, July 26 The Treasury auctioned $1billion in one-year bills today at an average discount rate of 4,964 per cent.
HOLLYWOOD, July 26--Nathan Goldstone, a film agent for more than 30 years, died of a heart attack Sunday at Cedars of Lebanon Hospital. He was 62 years old.
A major overhaul of traffic patterns at Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts is under way, in preparation for the opening of the new Metropolitan Opera House on Sept. 16.

PARIS, July 26 This was the day to give a girl a bunch of violets. Paris turned purple. It was the color, in all its different shades, that seeped through the salons on the second day of the French haute couture collections for fall.
The American Tobacco Company announced yesterday it had record consolidated sales and net income in the second quarter and in the first half of 1966.

KENMORE, N.Y., July 26 Mr. and Mrs. J. Walter Olstad, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Thoro Louise Olstad, to Malcolm Anson Coutant, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Z. Coutant of Laurens.

Benefiting from new products developed in its research laboratories, Merck Co., Inc., turned in the highest sales and earnings for any quarter and half year in its 83-year history in the three and six months ended June 30, Henry W. Gadsden, president, reported yesterday.
The food budget for the city's families is taking another beating.
MUNSTER, Ind., July 26 (UPI) Investigators found approximately $24,000 in the luggage of Tony Lema, the professional golfer who was killed Sunday in the crash of a small plane.

The Bil Baird Theater, New York's newest puppet playhouse, will present two matinees a day tomorrow through Aug. 9 free for preschool children as part of Project Head Start, the kindergarten program for underprivileged youngsters.

PHILADELPHIA, Miss. July 26 (UPI) The arrest of two white men in connection with shots fired at the property of two education officials and a civil rights headquarters was disclosed today by the Neshoba County Attorney Rayford Jones.

PARIS Just ten years ago Nasser startled the world by grabbing the Suez Canal. This dramatically advertised move was Cairo's answer to Secretary Dulles's renege on his previous promise to help build a Nile High Dam. The direct consequence was invasion of Egypt by Israel, France and Britain, who were subsequently expelled by international pressures.
The Traffic Executive Association-Eastern Railroads, has leased 36,000 square feet of space for its administrative headquarters in the 29-story office tower being constructed at 2 Pennsylvania Plaza.
Bulls and bears both agreed that the trouble in the stock market was not resolved yesterday.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 26 United States bombers struck in central and southern North Vietnam yesterday, leaving military camps, fuel depots and a train in flames.

BELLPORT, L.I., July 26 More than two dozen boats capsized today in the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's Cruise Week regatta as a blustery southwester whipped up white caps and swells and took a heavy toll. Only 106 boats in a starting fleet of almost 200 finished.

MANY declarers failed to find the most effective line of play in the diagramed deal, which was played in the Open Team event in the Brooklyn Championships last Sunday. Readers who wish to test their dummy-play should cover the East-West hands and decide how they would play in four hearts after a lead of the diamond king from West.
OTTAWA, July 26 A nationwide railway strike on Labor Day is being discussed by unions representing 115,000 workers.

BOSTON, July 26 (UPI) Bandits with blazing submachine guns wounded two guards and sprayed a crowded hospital with bullets today in a $68milloin armored car holdup, the second in greater Boston in four days.

GENEVA, July 26 The Soviet bloc ruled out today all negotiation on a treaty to halt the spread of nuclear weapons as long as the United States wanted to retain the option of having arrangements for sharing them within the Western alliance.

OTTAWA, July 26 A commission of inquiry cleared the Liberal Government today of charges that it had unfairly treated the late George Victor Spencer, who was accused of having aided Soviet agents, by having dismissed him from the postal service.
WASHINGTON, July 26 Down on the farm things are looking up, President Johnson and Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman agreed today.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI) Publishers of The Overseas Weekly, have filed suit in Federal District Court here for an order to require Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara to permit distribution of the newspaper through post exchanges to United States troops in Vietnam and other Pacific areas.
CHICAGO, July 26 The Cook County grand jury today indicted Richard F. Speck, 24year-old drifter and ex-convict, on charges of murder in the slaying of eight student nurses here on July 14.

WASHINGTON, July 26 In a letter to the Senate ethics committee, the director of the Central Intelligence Agency has said that Senator Thomas J. Donn conferred with the agency about the case of Bogdan N. Stashinsky before and after his trip to Germany in April, 1964.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) Patrick J. Nugent and his parents will arrive in Washington next Monday to attend a big diplomatic reception introducing Luci Johnson and her fiance to the heads of the diplomatic corps.

GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Jury 26 (AP) The Bank of Guyana increased today to 6 per cent from 6 per cent its yearly interest rate for rediscounting eligible paper and for granting loans and advances to banks.
The United States Court of Appeals here has ruled that the members of the Publishers Association of New York City must bargain individually with the printers union.
NEW DELHI, July 26 New strains have developed in India's relations with West Germany precisely when India can least afford them.

LONDON, July 26 (AP) Bobby Charlton scored two goals tonight and sent England into the final of the World Cup soccer championships with a 2-1 victory over Portugal. England will meet West Germany for the title on Saturday.

The American Merchant Marine Institute said yesterday that it has urged President Johnson to expedite United States ratification of pending international conventions for the simplification of shipping documentation.

WASHINGTON, July 26 Three of the four top policy jobs in the State Department are now either vacant or about to be so, and while there are many competent men around, no outstanding replacements have appeared to claim the posts.

SINGAPORE, July 26 Six leaders of two underground Malay organizations were arrested today on charges of having plotted to overthrow the Singapore Government and of having planned to incite racial violence next month, the police said.
LONDON, July 26 Two Laborites who voted against steel nationalization yesterday, Woodrow Wyatt and Desmond Donnelly, were severely reprimanded today by John Silkin, the Government party's chief whip.

A quotation from The New York Times included in a portion of a "black book" issued Monday by the North Vietnamese press agency was from an article printed Feb. 12, 1950, in the Sunday News of the Week in Review section.

THE HAGUE, July 26 In an apparent victory for the United States, the Group of Ten, which represents the world's leading financial powers, agreed today to bring less-developed nations into the discussions on the reform of the international financial system.
A daring daylight assault and robbery near a downtown police station in Athens nine days ago has seriously handicapped excavations on Crete financed in part by a New York businessman.

BONN, July 26 Belgian soldiers this evening carried the bodies of 28 children and five adults killed in a bus accident yesterday through silent rows of Belgian relatives and West Germans to waiting army ambulances.

WASHINGTON, July 26 President Johnson endorsed today a recommendation of Whitney M. Young Jr., executive director of the National Urban League, that more Negroes be promoted to officer ranks in the armed forces.
Frank Chapman, a retired opera and concert singer and a founder of the American Guild of Musical Artists, died of emphysema yesterday morning at his villa near Florence, Italy. He was 66 years old.

Winnie, the only filly in a field of five that included Greentree Stable's Malicious, captured the $27,150 Gravesend Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday by a head, in the excellent time of 1:09 4-5. She carried 113 pounds in the six-furlong race.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower has been in Walter Reed Army Hospital here since Monday for what an aide called "routine tests."

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) Gen. Frantisek Moravec, acting chief of staff and chief of military intelligence for the Czechoslovak Government in Exile during World War II, died after a heart attack yesterday. He was 71 years old.
The Ford Motor Company reported yesterday a decline in profits and a gain in sales for both the quarter and six-month periods ended June 30.
