BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Thursday, July 28 (Reuters) The police cordoned off part of North Belfast today after thugs attacked two homes of Roman Catholics in a fresh outburst of religious hostility.
LOS ANGELES, July 27 Melvin M. Belli, the flamboyant lawyer who defended Jack L. Ruby, has been banned from the convention program of the trial lawyers organization he once headed.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 27 (UPI) A four-day search for a plane carrying Brig. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell Jr. and two other persons on a flight to Honolulu has uncovered no traces, the Coast Guard said today.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI) The nation's crime rate jumped 46 per cent over the last five years to reach a total in 1965 of 2,750,000 serious crimes, or an average of five a minute, J. Edgar Hoover said today.
Pan American World Airways reported yesterday that its earnings for the second quarter climbed to $20,355,000, or $1.31 a share, from the year-earlier figure of $9,139,000, or 64 cents a share.
Savings banks in New York State are moving to take advantage of legislation signed into law last month that allows greater freedom in establishing branches.
BRUSSELS, July 27 (Reuters) Paul-Henri Spaak, Belgian statesman and one of the founders of the European Common Market, has decided to retire from political life, it was announced today.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 27 Miss Pamela Harrison Turnure, who was White House press secretary to Mrs. John F. Kennedy, will be married in the fall to Robert Nelson Timmins, a senior partner of J.R. Timmins Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange.
Top police officials met last night with leaders of the United Council of Organizations, representing Negro civil rights groups.
Four Bronx primary elections will be re-run under a court ruling that there were substantial irregularities in the June balloting. No date has been fixed for the new elections.

Second-quarter earnings of the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company slipped o $15,482,000, equal to $1.51 a share, from $15,952,000, or $1.50 a share, in the corresponding 1965 quarter, it was reported yesterday.

THE Providence County Kennel Club show goes outdoors on Saturday. After holding 50 winter events, the Rhode Island organization will have a summer unbenched affair at the City High School Stadium as a supplement to its indoor fixture.

WASHINGTON, July 27 The Red Cross of the National Liberation Front of South Vietnam has given indirect assurances to the United States that American prisoners held by the Vietcong will be treated humanely.
The city is studying the possibility of reducing the fare to 15 cents during non-rush hours on the seven private bus lines.
The commanders of Navy, Army, Marine and Air Force bases have been requested by the Defense Department to open military swimming pools to underprivileged children during the remainder of the summer.
BOSTON, July 27 (AP) Edward L. Casey, former allAmerica football player and head football coach at Harvard, died yesterday. He was 72 years old.

BONN, July 27 The Defense Ministry disclosed today that Secretary of Defense McNamara wanted to limit some of West Germany's Starfighter fighter-bombers to the use of conventional weapons and that the Defense Ministry is opposed. The Starfighter is now assigned to carry nuclear bombs exclusively.
The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday that outstanding commercial paper declined by $663million, or 6 per cent, during June to a total of $10,709,000,000.
The sleek 20th Century Limited clicked quietly out of Grand Central Terminal on schedule last night.

Fred Talbot was hit hard and often last night by the Minnesota Twins, but the Yankee outfielders were usually waiting in the right place and helped the right-hander post a 6-3 victory at Yankee Stadium.

Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson said yesterday that the truth of charges of a year-old "deal" by City Council President Frank D. O'Connor to obtain the nomination for Governor should be determined by the Democratic party.
Three hundred and fifty teamsters ended their strike yesterday against building materials dealers and resumed deliveries to hundreds of construction sites in the city.
Secretary of Defense Robert S.McNamara was the target of heavy attack yesterday from spokesmen for what they call the nation's "fourth arm of defense"--the merchant marine.
TOKYO, July 27 Japan and the Soviet Union agreed today to hold regular conferences on the foreign minister level to consolidate the improving relations of the two countries, long traditional foes.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) The Federal Aviation Agency relaxed its proposed restrictions at Washington National Airport today sufficiently to permit continued nonstop service to all cities within 650 miles and to a few as far away as 1,000 miles.

When properly used, a good commercial bank can be one of the most useful and convenient of financial institutions because of the wide range of services it offers. But, of course, a person would have to be familiar with those services to enjoy their advantages.

Miss Jean Ellen Margolis and Jack I. Hentel, graduates of Cornell University, were married yesterday evening by Rabbi Joseph H. Wise at the Whitestone (Queens) Hebrew Center. Cantor Jacob Kastin assisted.
YONKERS, July 27 Ten races are carded for tomorrow night at Yorkers Raceway, with the $100,000 Empire Pace for 4-year-old sidewheelers topping the program.
Governor Rockefeller returned yesterday from a three-week vacation on the French Riviera and promptly praised Mayor Lindsay for his handling of the racial disturbances in East New York.
BALTIMORE, July 27 (AP) Three home runs, including Frank Robinson's 30th of the season, paced the Baltimore Orioles to a 7-1 victory over the Cleveland Indians tonight.

Many Government bond dealers predicted yesterday afternoon that the Treasury's offering of 5 per cent certificates and notes its highest interest coupon since shortly after World War I would attract a broad response from investors.
Three big Western railroads whose merger bid was rejected by the Interstate Commerce Commission in a, 6-to-5 ruling last April petitioned the Commission yesterday to reconsider its decision.

PHILADELPHIA, July 27 The Delaware River Basin Commission charged Walton, N.Y., today with polluting the West Branch of the Delaware River and jeopardizing the quality of water in New York City's Cannonsville Reservoir a few miles downstream.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 27 A national "pressure bloc" of suburban officials was proposed here today to prevent crisis-ridden cities from "swallowing" prosperous suburbs.

New York's international banking community may soon have another member. A group of Chinese investors representing the Bank of China, a major Taiwan commercial bank, has filed an application with the New York State Banking Department for a charter for a new bank to be called the Chinese American Bank.

TORONTO, July 27 Two hundred Ontario farmers, shouting slogans, stormed through the corridors of the provincial Parliament buildings in Toronto today, demonstrating for higher milk prices and other Government aid.
Mayor Lindsay began yesterday a detailed survey of all Federal aid received by the city as part of his program to make maximum use of government funds.

WASHINGTON, July 27--Barry Goldwater urged President Johnson today to spend the next two or three weeks in the big-city Negro ghettos "talking straight from the shoulder and heart without the thought of a vote in his mind."
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 27 (AP) Two banks in Westchester County were robbed today by masked men, one for more than $22,000 and the other for $6,500, police said.

Miss Judith Fife, president of the Gordon Heights Development ad Building Corporation of 110 West 34th Street, died yesterday in St. Barnabas Hospital, the Bronx. Her age was 58 and she lived at 35-36 76th Street, Jackson Heights, Queens.

A union representing several thousand park employes called a one-day work stoppage yesterday for next Tuesday that could leave beaches here without lifeguards and parks without recreation and maintenance personnel.

PARIS, July 27 Michel Goma, the designer at Jean Patou, who scored a big success today with his winter collection, said backstage after the show that he had two types of girls in mind for his new clothes. The first Goma girl is young, likes to dance a lot and "zips around in a little car." For her, Goma has come up with twirly-skirted skating dresses that curve out from a snug yoke.
BONN, July 27 The West German Government expressed today its "deep regrets" over the United States Senate vote of censure condemning Bonn for supporting the sale of a steel mill to Communist China.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 27 (AP) Howard O. Kinsey, a former ranking American tennis player, died yesterday. He was 66 years old.
SPRINGS, L.I., July 27 Painters, writers and museum officials paid their last respects here today to Frank O'Hara.

CHICAGO, July 27 (UPI) Tommy Agee drove in four runs with a double and a sacrifice fly tonight, backing up John Buzhardt's seven-hit pitching, as the Chicago White Sox defeated the Detroit Tigers, 5-0.

Sol Kittay, chairman and president of the B.V.D. Company, Inc., attempted yesterday to allay possible apprehension on Wall Street that his sale of B.V.D. stock presages his departure from the company or a lessening of his role.
LONDON, July 27 (Reuters) The police searched London's fashionable Hampstead suburb tonight for the killer of a Negro girl whose nude, slashed body was found tied up in a brown paper parcel.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) More than 1,000 stones in the west front of the Capitol are cracked and beyond repair, the assistant Capitol architect, Mario Campioli, told Congress today.

Intensive negotiations were held during the day and evening yesterday between the pressmen's union and the World Journal Tribune, Inc., in an effort to reach an agreement that would end the 94-day-old shutdown of the new publishing enterprise.
LONGHAIRS they may be; intellectuals they're not. The 10-years-old-and-younger set is apparently going to have tresses from head almost to toe this year.

SYDNEY, Australia, July 27 Sir Norman McAlister Gregg, the eye surgeon who discovered that German measles in a pregnant woman could lead to mental retardation in her child, died here today after a brief illness. He was 74 years old.
ATHENS, July 27--Michael Cacoyannis, the Greek film producer, announced today that no one would read the scenario of his next production until it was released.
DURING the third General Assembly of the United Nations in Paris, Paul-Henri Spaak turned to Andrei Y. Vishinsky, the Soviet delegate, and said:
ATLANTA, July 27 The Federal Government was accused by a new Negro medical and dental organization today of channeling Medicare payments to "many" hospitals that still discriminate against Negroes.

WASHINGTON, July 27 the State Department took the position today that South Africa was still responsible to the United Nations for its administration of South-West Africa, despite the refusal of the International Court of Justice to rule on the status of the mandated territory.

New Jersey's Supreme Court chose to skirt the issue of gerrymandering in invalidating the new Congressional district lines fixed by the Legislature. Instead it ruled that the new lines created: unjustifiable population inequities, thereby violating the oneman, one-vote doctrine established by the United States Supreme Court.

SALZBURG, Austria, July 27 (Reuters) Grace Bumbry, the American soprano, provided the first high point of this year's Salzburg Festival when she sang the title role in "Carmen" to a jubilant audience here tonight.

The efforts of Helen Clay Frick to suppress a book critical of her father, steel magnate Henry Clay Frick, are understandable as acts of filial devotion. But success for the lawsuit she has initiated would have a stifling effect on the integrity and independence of research estimates of America's leaders, even a halfcentury or more after their death.

Paul Spitzer, a vice president of the Rode Horn Lumber Corporation, Brooklyn, and well known among Hungarian-American contract bridge players, died of a coronary thrombosis yesterday in his suite at the Nassau Hotel on East 59th Street. He was 64 years old.

Constitutional Convention Said to Spur Little Interest Two speakers at the closing Session of the League of Women Voters summer meeting expressed concern yesterday at the apparent lack of public interest in the New York State 1967 Constitutional Convention.

LOWELL, Mass., July 27 Two of the smallest candidates for jobs in pro football, Sherman Lewis and Sammy Weir, were big factors for the New York Jets as they defeated the Boston Patriots, 14-13, tonight before a crowd of 8,109 at was the annual game for rookies and last year's unused talent of the American Football League teams.

Stock prices rose yesterday as the market showed its first advance in eight sessions. Prices moved to the highest levels of the day around noon, weakened on renewed profit, taking in the early afternoon, and then firmed toward the close.
WASHINGTON, July 27 Mrs. Clara Bogart Burrage, wife of John D. Burrage, a retired examiner in the United States Patent Office, died here today at the age of 79.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 27 Two California farm labor groups announced a merger plan today, presaging a showdown battle with the Teamsters Union in the state's agricultural valleys.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) President Johnson presented two Air Force pilots today with certificates attesting that they set new speed and altitude records last year.
MOSCOW, July 27 (UPI) The Soviet Government, expanding the order on new criminal laws announced yesterday, said today that swearing in a public place now would be classified as "petty hooliganism."
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 27 Secretary General Thant's office passed on to the Security Council today two reports on investigation of charges of aggression by Syria and Israel against each other.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) A national conference on "black power" will be called by Negro leaders for the Labor Day weekend, Sept. 3-4, in Washington, it was announced today.

LONDON, July 27 Underneath the shrill debate over Prime Minister Wilson's emergency economic program, a more fundamental concern is being expressed by qualified observers. It is that the Labor Government may have missed, in the crisis over sterling, a vital opportunity to recast Brit ain's world role in terms of the needs of her long-range economic salvation.

CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., July 27 Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Young have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ilene Terry Young, to Mark Gasarch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry D. Gasarch of Harrison, N.Y.

CHICAGO, July 27 A plea of insanity by Richard F. Speck, a 24-year-old seaman and exconvict who is charged with murdering eight student nurses, appeared in formulation today when Gerald W. Getty, public defender, said he would seek a blue ribbon panel of psychiatrists to give Speck a mental examination.
Four Olympians head the United States team that will compete in the world canoeing championships in Grunau, East Berlin, Aug. 13, 14.
C.W. Cook, president of the General Foods Corporation, strongly criticized yesterday Government proposals to standardize packaging.

BUENOS AIRES, July 27 (Reuters) Thousands of Argentines stood in torrential rain today chanting "Argentina champion" to give their defeated World Cup soccer players a heroes' welcome at the international airport.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 27 Charles Weingarten, a lawyer and former president of the Connecticut Zionist region, died here last night in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 19 Edgemarth Hill Road, Westport.
Bruce Kaplan, a 21-year-old pre-medical student who scored 14.6 points per game last season, was elected captain yesterday of the New York University basketball team for the 1966-67 season.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., July 27 A tiny, 17-year-old California girl defeated Mrs. Billie Jean King, the champion of Wimbledon, today.
Leslie H. Warner, president of the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation, has been elected a director of the Continental Can Company.

LOS ANGELES, July 27 (AP) Lou Johnson's pinch-hit single in the 12th inning scored Nate Oliver from second base and gave the Los Angeles Dodgers a 2-1 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies. The triumph extended the Dodgers' winning streak to six games and moved them within one-half game of the National League lead.
THE French make polygamy prosy. They tend to domesticate extramarital affairs. The upshot, we see again from today's book, is likely to be a sort of installment-plan systemization of love.
WASHINGTON, July 27--The Johnson Administration asked the Senate today to hold off legislation to end the airline strike for a few more days while a final effort was made to negotiate a settlement.

MOSCOW, July 27 Premier Aleksei, N. Kosygin, who has been having a summer busy with visiting dignitaries, made another trip to the airport today to meet a foreign leader. This time the guest was Premier Abdel Rahman al-Bazzaz of Iraq, with which the Soviet Government would like to develop relations as close as its ties with the United Arab Republic.

LONDON, July 27 (AP) Henry H. Fowler, the Secretary of the Treasury indicated today that 10 of the world's major financial powers have made a substantial step forward toward a new kind of international currency to plug the gap of dwindling gold and dollars as world trade expands.

The American Association of Advertising Agencies has formally registered its opposition to provisions of the "truth-inpackaging" bill that is currently the subject of hearings by the House Commerce Committee.

PISA, Italy, July 27 (AP) william Holden, who arrived a few days ago at the nearby spa of Montecatini for a brief vacation, was involved in a fatal automobile accident 12 miles north of Pisa last night. He and his passengers, two New York girls, escaped injury.
Chemical additives that are applied to cotton during the ginning process are causing concern among textile manufacturers.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP)--The House Rules Committee cleared today a bill to create a Cabinet Department of Transportation to cope with the problems of all forms of interstate transportation.
The nation's electric power production rose 11 per cent in the week ended July 23 from the level in the corresponding 1965 week, it was reported by the Edison Electric Institute yesterday.
The arraignment of Dr. Carl A. Coppolino on charges that he murdered his first wife was postponed yesterday for five weeks by a Florida court because his lawyer is on vacation.

The Ford Motor Company will push the accelerator to the floor next year when it embarks on an expanded racing program at a cost of more than $10-million, roughly $4 for every car it sells domestically.

PHILADELPHIA, July 27 (AP) Directors of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company increased today the regular quarterly dividend to 60 cents from 40. Stuart Saunders, chairman, attributed the rice to a steady improvement in earnings and expectations of continued good business.

PHILADELPHIA, July 27 The engagement of Miss Sandra Ruth Turner, daughter of Mrs. Lucile Post Turner and Henry Crosby Turner Jr., to Dr. Myron Lowell Belfer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ira M. Belfer of New York, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents.

The only conclusion possible from Secretary of Labor Wirtz's testimony on the airlines strike is that politics is the chief yardstick the White House applies in determining when the cut-off of an essential service creates a national emergency.
The American Stock Exchange managed a moderate comeback yesterday to end eight consecutive sessions of losses.
Norman Reeve Van der Veer, a career naval officer who retired as a lieutenant commander in 1931, died following a stroke on Monday in his home at Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 82 years old.

JOHNSON CITY, Tenn., July 27 Mr. and Mrs. William Trevor Swoyer Jr. have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Winifred Swoyer, to Neil Roger Herrick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence J. Herrick of New York.
KENNETH E. BATTELLE, who simply as Kenneth is one of the best-known of American hairdressers, is entering big business.

A Democratic organization candidate for State Senator in the Bronx surrendered yesterday on two indictments involving his alleged offer to fix a narcotics case for $100,000. He had denied the allegations before a grand jury.

WASHINGTON, July 27 The United States protested to the Soviet Union today against "arbitrary changes" in the scheduled tour of the Earl (Fatha) Hines jazz group. The United States suggested the Soviet Union was violating the spirit of the cultural exchange program.

THE New York State Conservation Department will make a major revision of the permit system for groups hunting deer this fall. At the same time the department will increase sharply the number of permits to be issued.
STOKE MANDEVILLE, England, July 27 (AP) American girls won six gold medals in swimming today, raising the United States team total to 23 in the 15th annual International Paralympic games.

MIAMI, July 27 (AP) The threat of the fifth tropical storm of the season to the United States mainland faded sharply today when it shifted to a more northerly track and showed no signs of developing stronger winds.
The drive for reform of the international monetary framework is moving ahead but at a rate that is disappointingly and perhaps dangerously slow.
The Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, minister emeritus of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, has been named president of the New York Theological Seminary.

The Commercial Solvents Corporation and Merck Co. Inc., announced yesterday they would cooperate in the development of compounds that had shown potential in animal health and nutrition and in fertility control in domestic animals and humans.

LONDON, July 27 The Labor Government abandoned tonight its cherished goal of achieving a 25 per cent increase in the gross national product by 1970. Deputy Prime Minister, conceded that the figure would have to be lowered because of a disappointing economic performance.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 27 (AP) Two ninth-inning errors at third base by Jim Davenport of the San Francisco Giants paved the way for two runs that gave the Pittsburgh Pirates a 5-3 victory over the Giants today and possession of first place, in the National League. The Pirates lead the secondplace Giants by 2 percentage points.
Increased pier employment opportunities in Jersey City and Hoboken helped set a six-year employment high for June, the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor reported yesterday.
FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 27 (UPI) Pete Gogolak hit on eight of 10 field-goal attempts today as the New York Giants held a half-hour session for special units.
The election of Charles C. Gadsden as a vice president was announced here yesterday by Indian Head, Inc., a textiles producer.

The Israeli Mime Theater, starring Claude Kipnis, will play its first engagement here beginning Sept. 6 at the Theater de Lys. The production will run for four weeks. Luben Vichey, a former basso of the Metropolitan Opera Company, is sponsoring the visit. Eight previews will be given between Aug. 31 and Sept. 5. The theater group was started in 1964 and has traveled extensively in Europe.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 27 Two United States Air Force planes were lost today over North Vietnam.

HOLLYWOOD, July 27 Lew Wasserman, president of M.C.A., Inc., and Universal City Studios, was elected today chairman of the board of the Association of Motion Picture and Television Producers. The announcement was made by Jack Valenti, president of the association.

Three Democratic City Councilmen, parents of a total of 16 children, demanded yesterday a Council inquiry into "skyrocketing" food prices. Large households, they contended, are being especially hard hit by the upward trend.

KHARTOUM, the Sudan, July 27 (Reuters) Parliament today elected Sayed Sadik alMahdi Premier to replace Mohammed Ahmed Mahgoub, who was forced to resign earlier this week after Parliament voted a censure motion against him.
BOSTON, July 27 Emergency patients in a hospital in New England will have their heart conditions analyzed almost instantly in Washington, in a project that is to begin in about a month.

GALLUP, N.M., July 27 (AP) A Frontier Airlines twin-engine DC-3 crashed while taking off from the Gallup airport today. Five of the 16 persons aboard were injured, but two did not require hospitalization.
MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 27 (AP)--The victory of the defending champion, Blitzen, a 56-foot cutter owned by two Milwaukee men, in the 333-mile Chicago-to-Mackinac yacht race, was confirmed today.

It was a grand night for singing Tuesday evening, when more than 300 people from all walks of life converged on New York University's Loeb Student Center to sing Bach's Mass in B Minor, simply for the joy of doing it. The program was the last in a series of six public 'summer sings" sponsored by N.Y.U., and directed by David Randolph, conductor and commentator.
SOMERVILLE, Tenn., July 27 (UPI) About 100 Negroes ended a 62-mile, five-day West Tennessee Freedom March tonight under escort of the city, county and state police.

Joey Bishop will be the host of a new 90-minute late evening variety show that the American Broadcasting Company network will begin televising next April. It will be presented from 11:30 P.M. to 1 A.M., Mondays through Fridays.
The wholesale commodity price index maintained on Tuesday the level it reached on Monday which was 113.3.

MOSCOW, July 27 (Reuters) Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin has assured U Thant he wants him to continue as Secretary General of the United Nations when his term of office expires in November, informed sources said here tonight.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 27 The provisional agenda for the 21st General Assembly, which opens Sept. 20, was made public today. There are 90 items on it.

Studies of a possible merger of the Continental Insurance Companies of New York and the Continental National American Group of Chicago have been discontinued, according to a joint announcement yesterday by the chairmen of the large and unrelated insurance groups.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) John McShain, Inc., of Arlington, Va., was selected today as general contractor for the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, to be built on the bank of the Potomac River here. It will cost more than $40-million.

Broken windows, crumbling brickwork, defective exit doors, poor lighting and other violations of the building code have been discovered in almost half the city's public schools. Several do not have certificates of occupancy the city's sign that a building is safe.

A two-day test of the ability of vertical take-off and short take-off aircraft to supply emergency transportation to Manhattan will be held in October, the Federal Aviation Agency announced yesterday.

LONDON, July 27 The Government of Ghana reversed itself today and again sought the extradition here of Kwesi Armah, former Ghanaian Minister of Trade and High Commissioner to Britain, on a charge of stealing government funds.
CINCINNATI, July 27 (UPI) Pete and Leo Cardenas slammed home runs and drove in five runs between them to lead the Cincinnati Reds to an 11-2 victory over the Chicago Cubs tonight.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 27 The engagement of Miss Barbara Jeanne Reichel to Thomas William Mattingly Jr., son of Brigadier General Mattingly, Medical Corps, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Mattingly of Bethesda, Md., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Reichel.
Spot sterling was slightly higher in moderately active trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. Following some commercial demand, the currency closed at $2.7912, up 3 points from Tuesday.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., July 27 --Helmuth C. Redemann, an importer of ceramics from Germany, with offices at 220 Fifth Avenue, New York, died of a stroke on Friday on the liner Statendam, which arrived in New York today from Rotterdam, the Netherlands. He was 62 years old and lived at 281 Garth Road here.

MANY of the bridge clubs in New York have members of that select band of enthusiasts who play the game every day. Such a player was Paul Spitzer, a lumber company vice president, who died yesterday at the age of 64.

WASHINGTON, July 27 Members of Congress clashed repeatedly today with advocates of a huge, computerized data bank that would pool statistics on millions of Americans and, it was said, possibly violate their secret lives.

There is no off-season in education. Millions of students who only weeks ago closed their books for the regular school term are now enrolled in summer sessions that have become virtual extensions of the traditional school year, far different in quality and character from the warm-weather sessions of old.

NOW that the Wisconsin Supreme Court has ruled, 4-3, in favor of baseball concerning the move of the Braves from Milwaukee to Atlanta, what next? Is baseball permanently secure from antitrust action? Is another expansion of the major league enhanced, delayed or unaf- fected? Will Milwaukee get, sooner...
The Armco Steel Corporation has announced in Middletown, Ohio, the election of J.S. Thomas as vice president in charge of raw materials and purchasing.

IN the first round of the Piatigorsky Cup Tourna ment being played in Santa Monica, the Soviet stars Tigran Petrosian, the world champion, and Boris Spassky, the recent challenger for the title faced each other. And the United States champion, Bobby Fischer of Brooklyn, faced Sammy Reshevsky of Spring Valley, N.Y., many-time former champion.
WASHINGTON, July 27 The Treasury offered to pay 5 per cent interest today, the highest rate since 1921, in order to sell new securities in replacement of paper maturing in August and November.

Now that its long-cherished goal of merging with the Pennsylvania Railroad is virtually achieved, the New York Central announces that one of its first actions will be to cut service by discontinuing longhaul passenger trains. The Pennsy gives its harbinger of similar tidings to come by seeking to abandon service between New York and St. Louis. These are decidedly not the kind of benefits the public had been led to expect from a merger.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 27 (UPI) The California Supreme Court ruled today that topless exhibitions did not violate the state law on outranging public decency.

Construction and permanent mortgage financing of $1.7-million has been arranged for a shopping center now rising on a 16-acre site at the intersection of Park Avenue and Oak Tree Road in South Plainfield, N.J.

MIAMI, July 27 The engagement of Miss Mary Frances Freeman of Villanova, Pa., to the Rev. Dr. James Ray Petty of King of Prussia, Pa., has been announced by Wilbern Marvin Freeman and Mrs. Thelma Miller Freeman, parents of the bride-to-be. Dr. Petty is the son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Aden Petty of Clarksville, Tex.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., July 27 The united States chess champion, Bobby Fischer of Brooklyn, drew his adjourned fifth-round game with Wolfgang Unzicker of West Germany after 77 moves in the Piatigorsky Cup Tournament at the Miramar Hotel here last night. At adjournment, Fischer had the winning prospects, but missed several opportunities.
The Lindsay administration is seeking a layman as Hospitals Commissioner, even though the $32,500-a-year job has always been filled by a physician.

Summertime jobs for college students have long been provided by business concerns in the United States. They have become practically an adjunct to the educational process, supplying not only income for the student, but also valuable working experience.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July ly 27 South Vietnam's Economics Minister declared today that the country's rampant inflation had been "arrested earlier than expected" and that "in a very short time stability will set in for good."

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., July 27 To the sound of the surf and regional American accents in Daytona Beach something new has been added a ripe British accent. The members of the London Symphony Orchestra, almost 100 strong, with another 70 of so in the form of wives and children, arrived a few days ago for the Florida International Music Festival, supplementing the local vocabulary of sound in more ways than one.
TEL AVIV, July 27 The sixth annual Israel Festival of Music and Drama opened traditionally tonight, but before it ends Aug. 27 it will have introduced many innovations.
Two Brooklyn boys were held on a charge of juvenile delinquency yesterday in connection with the fatal shooting of a youth and the wounding of another.

"The passenger train as we know it is dead." That's the flat statement of Pierre Bretey of Hayden, Stone, Inc. Nonetheless, Mr. Bretey, a leading rail analyst, has just completed an unusually bullish, 74-page study of the nation's railroads.

BUENOS AIRES, July 27 Copies of the Uruguayan weekly news magazine Marcha were confiscated by police agents last night as the new military regime moved to tighten control over the press. At many newsstands, the police also seized copies of Epoca, a leftist Montevideo newspaper.
Mayor Lindsay, whose departure from San Francisco International Airport was delayed more than two hours, called the airline strike a "tragedy" as he returned here last night.

Hobart Nixon Hare, formerly a vice president of the investment firm of Hare's, Ltd., died of cancer on Monday at King Edward Hospital, Bermuda. He was 51 years old and lived at Jennings Bay, Southampton Parish, Bermuda.

The appointment of William T. Marx to the new post of senior vice president for employe relations and communications was announced here yesterday by the Celanese Corporation, a chemicals and fibers producer.

WASHINGTON, July 27 The Senate passed a $792-million military foreign aid bill today after it had cut $100-million from the ceiling recommended by the Foreign Relations Committee. The vote for passage was 82 to 7.
The Standard Oil Company of California reported yesterday record sales and earnings for the second quarter and first half of this year.

Mrs. Eva Herst Gold, the founder in 1917 and first president of the Jamaica Section, National Council of Jewish Women, died Tuesday in her home at 172-70 Highland Avenue, Jamaica Estates, Queens, after a long illness. She was 87 years old and the widow of William Gold, a real-estate investor.
WASHINGTON, July 27 Senator Mike Mansfield, Democrat of Montana, called today for an early two-step reduction in the number of United States troops and dependents in Europe.
Rain that broke the drought in various parts of the country Tuesday and yesterday reached the New York area last night.

WASHINGTON, July 27 Michael V. O'Hare, a former aide of Senator Thomas J. Dodd, denied today the Senator's charge that he had been responsible for any double billing of Mr. Dodd's air travel expenses.

NEW DELHI, July 27 President Johnson's proposal for an Indian-American foundation has quietly been shelved for the time being to avoid further embarrassment to Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's embattled Government.

HOUSTON, July 27 The Mets ended their most successful road trip with a sigh of relief tonight. Jack Hamilton let the tying run get to third base with one out in the bottom of the ninth inning and then struck out the next two batters to protect a 3-2 victory over the Houston Astros.
WASHINGTON, July 27 Repeated efforts to block or delay authorization for construction of two dams in the Grand Canyon were rejected today by the House Interior Committee.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 27--A fiery segregationist who identifies with the politics of Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama led the ticket in the Democratic gubernatorial primary here yesterday.
William J. MacKenzie Jr., a general partner in the stock brokerage concern of Burnham Co., was elected yesterday as a governor of the American Stock Exchange.
The Boy Scouts of America have named Clark B. George, vice president and general manager of WCBS-TV, as Scout Commissioner of the Greater New York Councils.
Small but persistent selling brought widespread declines on the London Stock Exchange yesterday.
KINSHASA, The Congo, July 27 The Congolese Government rounded up 10 headquarters staff officers of the Frenchspeaking Sixth Mercenary Commando here today and put them under detention at Camp Kokolo.

PHILADELPHIA, July 27 Harry A. Batten, advertising executive, civic leader and financial adviser to the nation's astronauts, died today of a heart attack. He was 69 years old and lived at the Barclay Hotel on Rittenhouse Square.
PARIS, July 27 (Reuters) President de Gaulle expressed satisfaction today over the new agreement on farm-tariff proposals reached by the European Economic Community.

MADISON, Wis., July 27 (AP) The Wisconsin Supreme Court foiled Milwaukee today in its attempt to stay in baseball. It awarded the vagabond Braves to Atlanta and rejected MilwauKee's bid for another major league franchise immediately.

The ship-repair industry is facing a costly and embarrassing anomaly: Its declining volume of work in recent years has so depleted the reservoir of skilled and unskilled manpower that it does not have enough men to handle business being offered.

Miss Mary Louise MacCalmont's engagement to Peter John Polombo Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Polombo of Wyckoff, N.J., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. William F. MacCalmont of Silver Lake, S.I.

CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., July 27 Dr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Nelson have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Susan Nelson, to Thomas Atwood Easton, son of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas W. Easton of Oakland, Me.

WASHINGTON, July 27 Fearful of fairly widespread defections in their own ranks, Democratic leaders are counting heavily on Republican help in salvaging the open housing section of the civil rights bill.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., July 27 Henry S. Rowen, a 41-year-old economist, was appointed today as president of the Rand Corporation, the secret research organization that concentrates on defense planning.
Rain on the Western plains dampened the enthusiasm of some corn and soybean speculators yesterday. and they sold out positions in active futures trading.

TRENTON, July 27 The New Jersey Education Association said here today that it was prepared to drop its longstanding opposition to the Hughes administration's proposed reorganization of public higher education in the state.

The executive board of the Communications Workers of America will meet here this morning to discuss a possible national strike against the Western Electric Company by more than 22,000 installers of telephone equipment. A strike could disrupt phone service across the country.
A Federal judge sealed at a closed hearing yesterday a copy of an alleged sketch of the atomic bomb that Julius and Ethel Rosenberg purportedly turned over to the Soviet Union in 1945.

WASHINGTON, July 27 Barry Goldwater revived today what used to be a substantial love affair between him and the Washington press that he first alienated and then denounced during the 1964 Presidential campaign.
The Republican leaders of Manhattan and the Bronx made public yesterday a list of 23 potential candidates for their party's nominations for State Supreme Court justice in the First Judicial District.

A 17-year-old Negro youth was arrested yesterday and charged with the fatal shooting of 11-year-old Eric Dean, also a Negro, in the racially troubled East New York section of Brooklyn last Thursday night.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 27 The San Francisco Opera has attracted 2,000 new subscribers so far for the fall season, and chartered planes will bring operagoers from at least eight cities, including Honolulu, Denver, Salt Lake City and Seattle.

A portrait of the gigantic, odd-looking California condor, until now conspicuously absent from the New-York Historical Society's collection of paintings done by Audubon for his colorplate folio, "The Birds of America," has just been given to the society. It probably completes the brilliant series.

Sales and earnings of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation rose in the second quarter, the company reported yesterday. Profits for the first six months of the year also climbed despite a slight drop in sales.

GUATEMALA, July 27 The Guatemalan Congress last night approved a broad decree granting immediate amnesty to all political prisoners and persons now being tried for so-called political crimes committed between Nov. 1 1960 and yesterday.

The police yesterday gave only the name, address, age, race and occupation of the youth they arrested for the slaying of 11-year-old Eric Dean in East New York last Thursday. They refused to tell more about the prisoner or the circumstances of his arrest.
CHICAGO, July 28--A preliminary charge of murder against Richard Speck, accused slayer of eight student nurses, was dismissed in Felony Court today at the request of the state's attorney's office.
New Yorkers, freshly hit by higher taxes, higher transit fares and higher prices for bread, milk and other essential foodstuffs, now face the likelihood of higher charges for electricity and steam.
The Board of Water Supply announced plans yesterday for building a $238-million tunnel to carry water from Hillview Reservoir in Yonkers south to Manhattan and east to Queens.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) --Gold star lapel buttons would be issued to the next of kin of military personnel who died or die in Vietnam and other combat operations under a bill sent to the Senate today by its Armed Services Committee.
A Civil Aeronautics Board examiner has recommended that Braniff International be allowed to buy Panagra, the airline owned jointly by Pan American World Airways and the W.R. Grace Steamship Company.
CHICAGO, July 28 (UPI)-- Six teen-agers were wounded last night and early today in an apparent eruption of street fighting between two Negro gangs that agreed to a "truce" only last week.

WASHINGTON, July 28, (AP) --Senator Frank J. Lausche, Democrat of Ohio, said today that Cleveland, Rochester and Brooklyn, scenes of recent racial disturbances, were "clearly training grounds for the worst that is yet to come."
Several executive promotions in publishing and advertising were announced yesterday.
The fight for control of the Harshaw Chemical Company grew more complicated yesterday with these developments:

Although faced recently with increased interest rates, the General Motors Acceptance Corporation and the C.I.T. Financial Corporation registered moderate gains in earnings in the first half of 1966, separate reports disclosed yesterday.

Edward Newman, a former newspaper reporter whose articles on such subjects as organized crime, politics and the parole system won wide notice, died yesterday at Good Samaritan Hospital in Suffern, N.Y., after abdominal surgery. He was 44 years old and lived at 78 Hall Avenue, New York, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, July, 28-- Southern Democratic Senators, long advocates of easy money, raised cries of alarm on the Senate floor today about the sharp increase in interest rates, symbolized by yesterday's offer by the Treasury of 5 per cent on new securities.

SARASOTA, Fla., July 28.-- Gov. Haydon Burns of Florida said today that he would not extradite Dr. Carl A. Coppolino to New Jersey until after he is tried in Florida on a charge of murdering his wife with a drug.

YONKERS, July 28--Bret Hanover, under the mildest of urgings by his trainer-driver, Frank Ervin, negotiated the last half mile in 0:58 4/5 and the final quarter in a remarkable 0:28 3/5 tonight at Yonkers Raceway. The $100,0000 Empire ...

PARIS--Three months ago an influential American in Saigon confided that there wasn't any danger of "losing" the promised national election in South Vietnam, adding: "No hostile government will get in. We'll see to that."
WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP)--A sharply divided Senate Finance Committee approved today a bill that would require the states to meet Federal standards for unemployment insurance.

WASHINGTON, July 28-- There are two quite different ideas in Washington these days about how to treat Britain. In the present British economic crisis all officials here want to be kind, but looking to the future, some think Washington must be generous, and some think Washington must be cruel to be kind.
Although their contract with the Western Electric Company expired at midnight yesterday, the 24,344 members of the Communication Workers of America, will continue to work at least until Aug. 20.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 28--United States fighterbombers flew a record total of 542 sorties against enemy positions in South Vietnam yesterday, an American military spokesman said tonight.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., July 28 --Mrs. William J. O'Donnell has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Eileen O'Donnell, to Donald B. Reilly, son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Reilly of Port Washington, L.I. A November wedding is planned.
AUSTIN, Tex., July 28, (AP) --A handsomely appointed 10room Presidential office suite that became a campaign issue in the 1964 election stands empty, silent and double-locked today.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI)--President Johnson saluted today the patriotic energy of junior high school students in Sioux City, Iowa, whose efforts led to the issuance of a postage stamp honoring United States servicemen.
MOSCOW, Friday, July 29 (AP)--Pravda said today that "thousands of West German mercenaries" are supporting the United States in Vietnam.
The United Shoe Machinery Corporation is borrowing money for the first time in 50 years.
WASHINGTON, July 28--A $5.8-billion program of Federal aid for elementary and secondary schools was cleared today by the House Education and Labor Committee after weeks of squabbling among members.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 28--Stephen M. Harris, a city planner who specialized in urban renewal, died today at the Bayberry Nursing Home here after a long illness. He was 54 years old and lived at 16 Bancker Place.

Dr. Bernard Wilkens, assistant clinical professor of psychiatry at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons and a senior research scientist at the New York State Psychiatric Institute, died yeserday of a heart attack while visiting friends. He was 43 years old and lived on Riverside Drive.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI)--The American Newspaper Guild called today on the Justice Department to investigate "with great vigor" proposed mergers of newspapers to prevent the violation of antitrust laws.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 28-- The State Supreme Court here has corrected a clerical error by the Suffolk Liberal party that had caused an unwanted rivalry between two Democratic candidates for the State Senate.

The Propeller Club of the United States urged Congressional action yesterday to remove a statutory ceiling that prevents the Post Office Department from paying United States ship operators the same price they pay foreign operators for transporting mail:

Great American Industries, Inc., notified its stockholders yesterday that A. Mele, treasurer of the company, "inadvertently" violated Section 16 of the Securities Exchange Act by selling shares he held in the company without notifying the S.E.C. of his action.
LONDON, July 28--Fundamental reform of British divorce law was advocated in a report published tonight by a study group appointed by the Archbishop of Canterbury.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 28 (AP)--Seven Americans arrived today and will begin a nine-day tour of frontier areas Saturday for a private investigation of contentions that the Vietcong use Cambodian soil for refuge and supply lines.
The spot rate on the British pound moved slightly higher in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. The currency closed at $2.7916, for a gain of 4 points.

THE Summer National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League begin tonight in Denver. Five thousand players, including many New York stars, will take part in the three major championships and numerous minor events that fill the 10-day program.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) --The Senate approved by a vote of 85 to 0 today an authorization of more than $10-billion to continue the country's highway programs for fiscal years 1968-69.

Otto H. Hafner, president of Stechert-Hafner, Inc., one of the world's largest booksellers, died of a heart attack Wednesday in his office at 31 East 10th Street. He was 68 years old. Mr. Hafner's company, which also has offices in London, in Paris, in Stuttgart, Germany, and in Bogota, Colombia, imports and exports books in many parts of the world.
New Jersey will become today the newest state to have an arts council when Gov. Richard J. Hughes signs a bill establishing it.
The Consolidated Edison Company asked the Public Service Commission yesterday for permission to raise its charges for electricity and steam and to lower its charges for gas.
The cost of the nuclear ship Savannah is being disputed in two actions involving Federal agencies and the New York Shipbuilding Corporation of Camden, N.J.
Stanley Steingut, the Democrat leader in Brooklyn, made public yesterday names of 19 potential State Supreme Court candidates and asked the Brooklyn Bar Association for recommendations on them.
Encouraging words--from either a fellow-sufferer or a third party--are the best help for a fat person trying to lose weight, according to two studies made public this week.
IT was in Mir, Czarist Russia, when Shneor Zalman Rubashev, now Schneor Zalman Shazar, the President of Israel, was 8 years old. It was in 1897, around Christmastime:
WASHINGTON, July 28-- The Senate voted today to stop funds for the proposed extension of the West Front of the Capitol until a survey has been made of the cost of repairing the present walls.

Macy's and Alexander's department stores announced plans yesterday to establish adjacent store sites and undertake the joint development of a $40million regional shopping center in the Mill Basin section of Brooklyn.

Longshoremen unloading the Swedish-flag freighter Antigua walked off the job at the United Fruit Company's pier in Weehawken yesterday to protest against company attempts to reduce the size of work gangs from 20 to 18 men.

NEWARK, July 28--The resignation of Cyril D. Tysen as executive director of the United Community Corporation, the Newark antipoverty agency, was announced today by Rabbi Joachim Prinz Jr., U.C.C. acting president.

ORISKANY, N.Y., July 28, --Nassau County Executive Eugene Nickerson made a plea for Democratic party unity today in the wake of charges of political "deals" involving Frank D. O'Connor and Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr.
METEGHAN, N.S., July 28. --A 168-foot model of the famous Yankee clipper Flying Cloud left the harbor here last night under tow for Newburyport, Mass.

MOSCOW, July 28 (AP)-- Pravda gave a lengthy description today of the conferences the United States and Chinese Communist Ambassadors have long held in Warsaw. The newspaper's aim apparently was to stress that the Chinese had regular contacts with Americans and to arouse suspicion about the matters discussed.
The price of a quart of milk in New York and New Jersey will go up a cent on Monday and will probably go up another cent by Nov. 1.
The police have stopped arresting most Bowery derelicts, and the derelicts don't like it.
Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that he was beginning a campaign to enlist the support of labor in his effort to stimulate business in the city.
LONDON, July 28, (AP)-- Two British soldiers trying to row across the Atlantic from America to England were reported today to have gone almost halfway.
A State Supreme Court justice ordered Representative Adam Clayton Powell yesterday to pay $600 a week to a Harlem widow to satisfy a claim for $160,000.
A mass of ice reportedly comparable in size to Manhattan Island has torn loose and begun sweeping down a glacier valley near the Alaska-Canadian border.
LONDON, Ont., July 28 (PI) --Sandra Haynie shot a threeunder-par 69 today and took a one-stroke lead after the opening round of the 54-hole Supertest Open at the Sunningdale Country Club.
WASHINGTON, July 28-- President Johnson announced today the start of a new Federal aid program to provide comprehensive medical health care to children in low-income neighborhoods.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 28--The acting principal of Rhodesia's multiracial University College, Professor Alan Milton, accused the Government today of having provoked a situation in which there was a danger of violence.

ANDOVER, N.H, July 28 --Delegates to a churchoriented conference at Hillsboro, N.H., made a field trip to the Addison Gallery of American Art at Phillips Academy today to explore creativity in the arts.

BADEN-BADEN, Germany, July 28 (UPI)--John Newcombe of Australia defeated Jaroslav Drobny of England, former Wimbledon champion, 6-2, 6-2 today to reach the quarter-finals of the Baden-Baden tennis tournament.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP)--Vice President Humphrey said today "riots and violence cannot be tolerated or con- doned." But along with putting them down, he said, there must be an intensified attack on "slumism," which he said was a factor in such disorders.
LONDON, July 28--The British Government promised tonight to accelerate legislation to combat the growing problem of narcotics addiction.
President Zalman Shazar of Israel received warm tributes and salutes here yesterday at the start of a seven-day visit to the United States.
The nation's electric utility industry has enlisted the aid of Henry Dreyfuss, the in- dustrial designer, to create a new line of transmission structures.

BUENOS AIRES, July 28-- The Argentine Government moved today to ward off financial ruin for thousands of small businesses that normally banked with credit-union cooperatives before they were closed July 11 by the new military regime.

EVANSTON, Ill, July 28-- Stokely Carmichael, national chairman of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee, said today his organization would "join hands" with the Black Muslim leader, Elijah Muhammad, and with the Revolutionary Action Movement.

A 32-year-old Brooklyn butcher was charged yesterday with having cashed stolen United States savings bonds worth $10,000 last fall while dressed in the white jacket, trousers and shoes of a doctor, and wearing a stethoscope.

OSSINING, N.Y., July 28-- Dr. Benjamin Howard Everitt, for nearly 70 years a pastor or executive of the Presbyterian Church, died today at the Delaware Hospital in Wilmington. He was 92 years old and lived at 36 Hamilton Avenue here.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., July 28--Bent Larsen of Denmark, by a sensational sacrifice of a queen, defeated the world chess champion, Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, in the seventh round of the Piatigorsky Cup Tournament at the Miromar Hotel here last night. As White in a Sicilian Defense, Larsen forced checkmate in 30 moves.
An investigation of all nursing homes in the city by the Buildings Department has disclosed rats in cellars, overcrowded and stifling rooms, and fire hazards.
Representative Adam Clayton Powell said yesterday through a spokesman in Washington that a major shake-up had taken place in the administration of the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem.
FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 28 --Ted Holman is the only rookie in the Giants' camp with permission to raid the ice box every night.

The Lewisohn Stadium concert by the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra, with Ignace Strasfogel conducting and Benny Goodman as clarinet soloist, scheduled for last night was canceled because of the threat of rain. It had been postponed from Wednesday, when it was ...

BUDAPEST, July 28 (Reuters)--France and Hungary today signed a series of pacts here that Foreign Minister Maurice Couve de Murville described as heralding a new era of French relations with Hungary and the other Communist countries of Eastern Europe.
A Federal grand jury in New York yesterday indicted two former officials of the Yale Express System, Inc., on charges of filing false financial statements with the Inter- ...
BLOOMINGTON, Ind., July 28--Indiana, the Hoosier State, is observing the 150th anniversary of its statehood this year, and it has a new opera to add musical dignity to the celebration.
DUBLIN, July 28 (AP)-- The death of Maura Kelly Laverty, the Irish playwright and author, was announced here yesterday. She was 59 years old.
KINSHASA, the Congo, July 28--The Congolese Government today accused former Premier Moise Tshombe of plotting an insurrection with white mercenaries and Katangan troops.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., July 28, (UPI)--District Court Judge John Sexton ruled today that a Nevada law requiring ministers to be licensed by the state to perform marriage ceremonies was unconstitutional.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP)--Flying a modified polar route, planes will bring wounded United States servicemen from South Vietnam to the Washington area in just over 24 hours starting next week.
WASHINGTON, July 28, (AP)--Luci Johnson and Patrick J. Nugent have their marriage license and it is safe in the White House awaiting their wedding Aug. 6.
BOCA RATON, Fla., July 28 --Dr. William H. Grimditch, an electrical engineer who played a prominent role in the development of television, died yesterday at his home here. He was 69 years old.

CHAMBERSBURG, Pa., July 28--Mr. and Mrs. Frank Daniel Butz have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Ella Butz, to Michael Stephen Needleman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Needleman of Forest Hills, Queens, New York.
It was another up-in-themorning, down-in-the-afternoon day in the stock market yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP)--The Defense Department identified today 27 United States servicemen who had been killed in action in Vietnam. Among them were Navy Hos pitalman 3d Cl. Maxwell S. Frantz of East Aurora, N. Y., and Marine Corps Pfc. Franklin C. Eucker of Orange, N. J., and James R. Nash of Brick Town, N. J.

WASHINGTON, July 28-- Lobbyists for the country's licensed real estate brokers have urged them to "generate an immediate wave of indignation" against the open housing section of the Administration's civil rights bill.
GENEVA, July 28--The Government of North Vietnam gave new assurance today that it followed a "humanitarian policy" toward "enemies captured in war."

NEW LONDON, Conn., July 28--The competitors in the New York Yacht Club cruise, a racing event loaded with class and tradition, assembled here today for a start tomorrow of port-toport and closed-course competition that will take the squadron to Newport, R.I., on the first run.
WASHINGTON, July 28-- Carloadings on United States railroads and intercity truck tonnage in the week ended July 23, were both ahead of the corresponding week of last year.

WASHINGTON, Friday, July 29--President Johnson summoned negotiators in the 22day-old airline strike to meet with him at the White House at 9 A.M. today in what could be the first major break toward a settlement.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) Secretary of the Navy Paul H. Nitze approved today the establishment of a 12-member Academic Board of Advisors for the Naval Academy at Annapolis, Md.
A $4.1-million system of twoway radios for the city's buses was unanimously approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate.
GENEVA, July 28--The United States outlined today an international system for monitoring peaceful nuclear activities as a check against clandestine weapon development.

Reflecting a 27 per cent rise in half-year sales, the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation lifted its net earnings to $26.9million from the $22.6-million for the period last year, the company reported yesterday.

The whine of a jet engine broke the eerie quiet at La Guardia Airport's parking aprons yesterday. In the cockpit of one of 19 strike-grounded planes, two supervisory mechanics in white coveralls flipped toggle switches and pushed buttons as they ran through the engine-start check list.

SAIGON, July 28 (AP) Colonel Deatrick, commander of the First Air Commando Squadron at Pleiku, spotted Lieutenant Dengler while on a reconnaisance mission just north of the North Vietnamese border as his A-1 Skyraider swept over a deep valley crossed by a stream.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 28--The new leader of South Vietnam's militant Buddhist organization said today that its power had been shattered, but he ruled out any compromise with the Government of Premier Nguyen Cao Ky.
BELO HORIZONTE, Brazil, July 28--Soldiers patrolled the streets around National Student Federation Headquarters today to prevent the meeting of a congress called by the outlawed federation.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 28 (UPI)--Johnny Schlee, a rookie on the professional tour, fired nine birdies at his opposition over the windswept Speedway course today for a sixunder-par 66 and the first-round lead in the $92,000 Speedway Festival open golf tournament.

TORONTO, July 28--Pro football, American style, began its most serious challenge to the Establishment, meaning the Canadian Football League, here tonight when the Toronto Rifles played the Montreal Beavers at Varsity Stadium.
Livingston L. Wingate, the controversial executive director of the Haryou antipoverty agency, has suggested that his board of directors help work out terms for his resignation.
STOKE MANDEVILLE, England, July 28 (AP)--The United States dropped a 32-25 decision to Argentina today but remained in the running for the basketball title in the Paralympic games.

The American Home Products Corporation realized a 15 per cent increase in half-year earnings on a sales gain of 12 per cent, it was reported yesterday by the widely diversified producer of pharmaceuticals, toiletries, foods, chemical specialties and housewares.

Prime Minister Wilson's visit with President Johnson was originally set up to discuss the troubling problems of the war in Vietnam and the future of NATO in Europe. But the main topic on the agenda almost urely will be the even more troubled state of Britain's economy and Mr. Wilson's desperate efforts to save the pound.

TOKYO, July 28 (UPI)-- The call by Premier Nguyen Cao Ky for an invasion of North Vietnam brought a sharp protest today from North Vietnam to the International Control Commission. The commission, set up in 1954 at the end of the French-Indochina war, consists of representatives of Canada, Poland and India.
LONDON, July 28 (Reuters) --Noel Coward's play "Suite in Three Keys," which has been playing to capacity crowds here for more than three months, will go to the United States early next year.

WASHINGTON, July 28--A high-flying U-2 reconnaissance plane disappeared today after the pilot had apparently lost consciousness and failed to make a scheduled turn off the Florida coast, the Defense Department announced.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 28-- Bishops of the Greek Orthodox Church of the Orient have gathered here in an effort to end a conflict over ecclesiastical elections.

WEMBLEY, England, July 28 (UPI)--Lanky Jose Torres scored from point-blank range with only two minutes left tonight to give Portugal a 2-1 victory over the Soviet Union and third place in the 1966 world soccer championship.

CARACAS, Venezuela, July 28 (UPI)--Two girls from the United States who are working with a private social organization were assaulted by three knife-wielding thugs in a Caracus slum recently but escaped with minor injuries, officials reported today.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Mary Helen Flentge of Cape Girardeau, Mo., and Howard Hanscom Flentge of Heidelberg, Germany, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances Millington Flentge, to William David McCoy. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Robert McCoy of Roanoke, Va.
BATAVIA, N.Y., July 28 (AP)--Doll Story, the medalist, opposes a 15-year-old veteran of five years of tournament competition tomorrow and the State junior girls' golf championship.
WASHINGTON, July 28-- President Johnson is expected to inform Prime Minister Wilson tomorrow of the Administration's support for Britain's new austerity moves.
CHATTANOOGA, July 28 (AP)--Claude McClure, the 24-year-old soldier who was released by the Vietcong and ran into trouble with American authorities, is back in the Army again.
Four floods that caused more than $200,000 in damage and delayed the opening of the Harlem Meer swimming pool and skating rink in Central Park have been attributed to an inadequate drainage system.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., July 28--The nation's first women's Job Corps center closed tonight, a victim of hostile elements in the community and uncooperative city government. During its 18 months in this city, the center tried vainly to combat gossip that its girls had loose morals.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 28 --President Sukarno tenaciously defended his dwindling power and prestige today after having installed a new Cabinet dedicated to reversing his policies of the last few years.

Joseph Morrison Naab, vice president and treasurer of the Leslie Company of Lindhurst, N.J., manufacturers of whistles for marine and industrial use, died yesterday in the New England Medical Center in Boston of complications following an operation for euremia. He was 74 years old and lived at 60 Madison Place, Ridgewood, N.J.

"Good mornin'! How ya doin'? Have a pleasant trip." This is the sort of cheerful greeting dispensed along with subway tokens by a man who is becoming known as the jolly good fellow of the 86th Street downtown IRT subway station on Broadway.
SAN DIEGO, July 28 (UPI) --Lieutenant Dengler was reported recuperating today in a heavily guarded room at the Navy Hospital here.

The appointment of Nick Anderson as director of the Cunard Line in North America was announced by the company yesterday. He will assume the post on Jan. 1, when the present joint managers, Vincent A. Demo and Charles J. Moran, retire.

LONDON, July 28--David Carver, international secretary of P.E.N., described today as "depressing" charges by the Union of Soviet Writers that his organization was hindering contacts between Soviet and non-Communist writers.

WASHINGTON, July 28-- Richard Helms, the new director of the Central Intelligence Agency, was sharply criticized in the Senate today because of a letter he wrote praising an editorial denouncing Senator J.W. Fulbright, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee.

Deputy Mayor Robert Price a former radio station owner told broadcasters yesterday that radio and television editorials should "come on like 'Gangbusters'" to arouse attention. He advocated the use in them of sound effects to alert listeners.

PARIS, July 28--Alfredo Cardinal Ottaviani has ordered that the Roman Catholic Church's approval be denied future books on psychology by a French priest-pysician who has just written a book on sexuality.
Events tonight: "Festival From India" program, the film "Kanchenjungha," Philharmonic Hall, 6, repeated at 8 with Ali Akbar Khan, sarode player, at the second showing; concert ...
The Trade Bank Trust Company announced yesterday the election as a director of Max Stern, president of the Hartz Mountain Products Corporation, a pet-food producer.

The Commonwealth Edison Company reported yesterday that operating revenues for the first half rose to $311,083,096 from $295,274,626 a year earlier. Net income rose to $57,804,708, or $1.38 a share, from $54,121,284, or $1.30 a share on fewer shares, in the 1965 half.
Johnny Persol will move into the heavyweight class when he meets James J. Woody at Madison Square Garden on Aug. 25, the Garden announced yesterday.
The World Journal Tribune, Inc., remained unable to publish its merged newspapers yesterday for the 95th day as negotiators continued efforts to reach agreement with the pressmen's union.
Most issues on the American Stock Exchange were on a seesaw yesterday. They rose in the morning and fell in the afternoon.

While the strike that has kept 60 per cent of the country's airliners on the ground goes into its fourth week, Congress and the White House are up in the air about who should accept responsibility for ending the break in the nation's transportation lifeline.
Three New York City residents have been chosen by the Ford Foundation for on-the-job training in museums or in professional theaters, opera or ballet companies or symphony orchestras.

Miss Renee Ann Stark, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Stark of 118 East 60th Street, was married last evening to Stephen Jay Marcus, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Marcus of 118 East 60th Street and Bal Harbour, Fla.

LOS ANGELES, July 28-- The nation's most smog-plagued area adopted a regulation today controlling even the ingredients of house paint, in an effort to lessen the eye-smarting fumes emitted daily into the air.

LAKE BLUFF, Ill., July 28 (AP)--Top-seeded Linda Tuero of Metairie, La., needed an extra set today to defeat ninthranked Connie Capozzi of Middletown, Ohio, in the quarterfinals of the national girls' l6 and under tennis tournament, 6-2, 0-6, 6-1.

Additional details concerning the sale of a million shares of the B.V.D. Company, Inc., and the forthcoming public tender offer for the remaining shares by the Glen Alden Corporation, were disclosed yesterday.
S. Mort Zimmerman, a Dallas entrepreneur who controls a string of banks in the South, emerged yesterday as the new dominant figure at the Underwriters Trust Company.
Never before has a big municipal bond issue been sold to so many separate buyers as the $112,925,000 New York City offering of bonds now on the market. The "5-bond or ...

BAY SHORE, L.I., July 28 --Henry Post Jr. of the Babylon Yacht Club continued today to make a strong bid for outstanding-skipper honors in the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's annual Cruise Week regatta. Post sailed his No. 13811 to a fourth straight triumph today in the Sunfish Class's odd-numbered division to remain one of four skippers still undefeated in the series.
ENSENADA, Mexico, July 28 (AP)--Two Russian vessels tied up here belong to the Soviet Navy and their mission is to collect scientific data for the military.
The Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced yesterday in Pittsburgh the election of Robert E. Kirby and Marshall K. Evans as directors.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., July 28 --A British women's team that has been too busy practicing golf to stop for its customary afternoon tea faces the United States in the opening Curtis Cup matches tomorrow.

The Soldiers,' Sailors' and Airmen's Club, Inc., will benefit from an international haute couture fashion show at Alexander's department store on Sept. 26. There will be two showings, morning and afternoon.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 28 --An autumn wedding here is planned by Miss Judith Quinn and Edwin A. Kartman. Dr. and Mrs. Alonzo W. Quinn have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Ben Kartman of Wilmette, Ill., and the late Mrs. Kartman.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 113 on Wednesday from 113.3 on Tuesday.

Three United States producers of aluminum signed yesterday a 25-year agreement with the Government of Jamaica under which they will build an alumina plant at the cost of $175-million. Partners in the project are the Rey- ...
WASHINGTON July 28 (UPI)--Senator Robert F. Kennedy, Democrat of New York, proposed legislation today that would raise Social Security benefits an average of 50 per cent.

Grand Splendor made a fine effort in the stretch to win the 1 1-16-mile feature race on the turf at Aqueduct yesterday. The 4-year-old filly, running in the silks of the Tartan Stable, scored by 2 lengths over Murray Stable's Barletta, with James Cox Brady's In the Dell next in the field of nine fillies and mares.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 28 (AP)--K.A. Konegen's Polynesian Play, ridden by Donald Brumfield, found the sloppy going to her liking at Monmouth Park and led most of the way in the six-furlong feature, just lasting to earn a head decision today.
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 28--The Yankee game was on television, and Mickey Mantle had just belted a wrong-field home run. Joe Namath shook his head in obvious admiration and said:

A corner in the Lincoln Center area that is viewed as the possible site of a new office building has been sold to an investing group headed by Henry Baker, real estate broker, for cash over mortgages of $1,075,000.
Government securities prices declined yesterday in the first full day's trading following the Treasury's announcement of its $14.9-billion refinancing.
The Board of Estimate opened the way yesterday for the city to start the redevelopment of Harlem, Bedford- Stuyvesant and other slum areas.
California's savings and loan commissioner gave his backing yesterday to the principle of statewide savings-and-loan operations in that state, something that up to now has not been permitted.

The marriage of Mrs. Kathleen Nichols Haulenbeek of New York and Palm Beach, Fla., widow of P. Raymond Haulenbeek, to Edward Van Pelt of Bryn Mawr, Pr., and Palm Beach took place here yesterday afternoon. The Rev. Dr. Irving S. Pollard performed the ceremony in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church.
In the United States, laws governing divorce, and the strictness with which they are interpreted, vary widely from state to state.
CHICAGO, July 28 (AP)-- Don Buford's double scored Ken Berry with the winning run tonight as the Chicago White Sox edged the Detroit Tigers, 2-1.
FORT BENNING, Ga., July 27--The war in Vietnam is altering the tactical organization of the Army.

BERLIN, July 28--The East German Communists have quietly improved communications in this divided city by restoring a direct Telex line, a teletype transmission wire between East and West Berlin interrupted 21 years ago at the end of World War II, it was announced today.
The Anaconda Company, a major copper producer, announced here yesterday the appointment of Guillermo Carey and Henry E. Gardiner as vice presidents.

If a good jazz musician can be excused for blowing an occasional clinker, a good jazz series should be granted the same forgiveness. After five varied and provocative concerts, the weekly "Jazz in the Garden" series at the Museum of Modern Art stumbled last night with a group called the Saints and Sinners.
GOODWOOD, England, July 28 (UPI)--Gaulois, a 3-year-old colt owned by Queen Elizabeth, romped home three lengths ahead of Vivat Rex to win the $12,714 Goodwood Cup today.

WASHINGTON, July 28--Secretary Robert C. Weaver of the Housing and Urban Development Department announced today the appointment of Judah Gribetz as administrator and Mrs. Anne M. Roberts as deputy administrator of the New York regional office.

SEVERAL months ago a novel was published that may well be the finest novel about India since E.M. Forster's "A Passage to India" and that will certainly be one of the finest novels of any kind published this year. Yet, with the notable exception ...

The Sponge spokesman who posed for pictures last week with Mayor Lindsay at a meeting to ease tension in troubled East New York turned up in Brooklyn Supreme Court yesterday as a defendant in a burglary case.
BONN, July 28--Franz Josef Strauss, former Minister of Defense, won another round today in his year-long legal battle with Rudolf Augstein, publisher of the West German news magazine Der Spiegel.
James S. Rockefeller was elected yesterday as a director and finance-committee member of the Monsanto Company.
An attempted rally after a quiet opening failed to develop, and prices on the London Stock Exchange closed with widespread losses. Many issues hit new lows for the year.

Some progressive steps to reduce politics in the nomination of judicial candidates are being taken in the wake of the upset by Senator Robert F. Kennedy and the Reform Democrats of the bipartisan deal for Manhattan surrogate. Although the new measures do not go far enough, they are welcome signs of a changing attitude in both major parties.

The Communications Satellite Corporation said yesterday that revenues from operating the Early Bird satellite totaled $2,107,000 for the first half of 1966 while income from temporary cash investments was $4,472,000.

LONDON, July 28--Britain's offshore pirate radio stations, unauthorized providers of a steady stream of commercials and pop music to millions of listenets, would be outlawed under a bill submitted to Parliament today by the Government.
ATLANTIC CITY, July 28-- "If that were sewage, you'd know exactly where it would end up--right along that beach."
Two Democratic-sponsored polls of state voters are reported to have indicated that Governor Rockefeller could be defeated by any of several possible Democratic nominees.

NORTH AMITYVILLE, L.I., Friday, July 29--The Suffolk County police blocked the main roads leading into this predominantly Negro community last night after a series of street incidents following an outdoor rally whose aim had been to improve community-police relations.

Dr. and Mrs. Simon S. Silverman of Flushing, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Victoria Jane Silverman, to Stuart Alan Rouff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Rouff of Binghamton, N.Y.

The Southern Pacific Company, which for years has been the most profitable of the nation's railroads, reported yesterday that net income before tax adjustments rose to $30,762,676, or $1.13 a share, in the second quarter from $27,802,714, or $1.03 a share, a year earlier.

ATLANTA, July 28 (UPI)-- Lou Brock got a triple and two doubles and drove in three runs tonight in leading the St. Louis Cardinals to a 7-5 victory over the Atlanta Braves. The triumph was the Cards' 10th in their last 11 games.

TRENTON, July 28.--The chairman of the State Senate's education committee called on New Jersey's Department of Education today to investigate charges that the state colleges had suppressed academic freedom, muzzled undergraduate newspapers, hired unqualified teachers, graduated unqualified students, intimidated critics and buried professors in a morass of red tape.

MERRITT ISLAND, Fla., July 28--Mr. and Mrs. Howard Vincent Cooperider have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cornelia Wood Cooperider, to Capt. Walter Busill Tully Jr., U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Tully of Chatham, N.J.

CAIRO, July 28--The United Arab Republic announced today plans for a $126,500,000 expansion of the Suez Canal. The move is designed to hold the lucrative oil transit trade, which is threatened by the trend toward giant-size oil tankers.

The Building Trades Employers Association said yesterday that the majority of construction projects in the city had been "affected drastically" by the strike of hoisting engineers and construction plumbers.
SKOVSHOVED, Denmark, July 28 (AP)--The 72-foot ketch Ticonderoga won Class A honors today in the 360mile Elsinore-Skaw race, part of the Royal Danish Yacht Club's centenary program.
Gerald Tsai Jr., who manages the fastest-growing mutual fund in the country, turned slightly cautious toward the stock market in the second quarter of 1966.

ELLENVILLE, N.Y., July 28--Kenneth J. Lyman, the 31year-old Democratic Assemblyman from the 75th District in the Bronx, who last month won the nomination for re-election in November, died here today of a heart attack.

Dr. William McGill Burns, president in 1939-40 of the Second District Dental Society of the State of New York, died yesterday in the Veterans Administration Hospital in Brooklyn. His age was 67. He lived at 90 Magnolia Avenue in Garden City, L.I., and had an office there at 825 Franklin Avenue.
