The House of Representatives is now engaged in the unseemly spectacle of deciding who shall be allowed to discriminate against Negroes and who shall be required to treat them fairly.

OAKLAND, Calif., July 28 (AP)--Tony Lema and his wife, Betty, were buried today in the East Bay, where he rose from a caddy to a professional golfer of international stature. The couple were killed in the crash of a private plane in Indiana on Sunday.
The complaints of five members of the National Maritime Union seeking to upset the election of national officers two months ago have been dismissed by an inquiry panel.
NEW DELHI, July 28--India announced today that she had received pledges of $132.8million from four Western European countries to help finance her liberalized import program.

MOSCOW, July 28--The Union of Soviet Writers denounced P.E.N. International today for having permitted "anti-Soviet and anti-Communist" writers to take the rostrum during the 34th congress of the world literary organization in New York last month.

The engagement of Miss Renee Emeline Stern to Stephen Nelson Steinig has been announced by Mrs. Carl Stern of New York, mother of the prospective bride. Mr. Steinig is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice H. Steinig of Brooklyn.
Second-quarter earnings of the Anaconda Company soared to $3.31 a share from $2.42 in the 1965 period, the company announced yesterday.
BALTIMORE, July 28 (UPI)--Gangs of white youths surged into an east Baltimore Negro district tonight following an anti-Negro rally outside Patterson Park.
CONCORD, N.H., July 28 (AP)--Former Gov. Wesley Powell filed today as the sixth candidate seeking New Hampshire's Republican nomination for the United States Senate.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., July 28--Charles Pasarell of Puerto Rico and Clark Graebner of Beachwood, Ohio, rivals for a place on the United States Davis. Cup team, will meet here tomorrow in the quarter-finals of the Eastern grass court championships at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

The First Presbyterian Church of New York was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Miss Joan Hamlin, daughter of Harris A. Hamlin and the late Mrs. Hamlin of Nyack, N.Y., to John Ellis. He is the son of the late Rudulph P. Ellis and the late Mrs. Minette H. Ellis of New York and Norwalk, Conn.

MONTHEY, Switzerland, July 28 (UPI)--Landlocked Switzerland, with the help of United States business, is building a submarine for scientific research on North America's Atlantic coast.

NOW that Wisconsin's Supreme Court has ruled that the Braves may stay in Atlanta, baseball people can get back to worrying about things like the airline strike and the Baltimore Orioles. Except in Atlanta, of course.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 28 (AP)--The National Aeronautics and Space Administration today set Aug. 9 as launching day for the first of five Lunar Orbiter spacecraft. They are to go into orbit around the moon and photograph sites where United States astronauts may land.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 28-- Coach Weeb Ewbank said today he would begin trimming his squad tomorrow, after he had taken a second look at films of last night's rookie game between the New York Jets and Boston Patriots.

AREA A--Boats running offshore from Brielle are finding bluefish in the 6-to-10pound class and mackerel. Some are finding 50-pound tuna, but bottom fishing is off. Beach fishing around Surf City is poor, but sometimes kingfish are picked up. There are plenty of blowfish. There is some fluke fishing in the bay, and party boats are getting seabass. Again, there are reports of tuna catches offshore.

The 12th Robert Flaherty Film Seminar is planned for Sept. 3 to Sept. 9 at Arden House in Harriman, N.Y. The annual meeting of international filmmakers is devoted primarily to discussion and screenings of documentary, semidocumentary ...

LOS ANGELES, July 28 (AP)--The American Civil Liberties Union was granted a temporary injunction today against Government requirements that Medicare applicants state whether they are members of Communist-dominated organizations.
Weather continues to keep grain traders on their toes. Secretary of Agriculture Orville Freeman confirmed that yesterday when he said, "This weather has been jumping all around."
Despite record sales, net income of the Chrysler Corporation fell in the quarter and six months ended on June 30, the company announced yesterday.
BALBOA, C.Z., July 28--Bids for widening the last bottleneck in the Panama Canal channel from 300 to 500 feet will be sought next month, according to an official source.
MOSCOW, July 28--Secretary General Thant has postponed his departure for a day to meet with Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party's General Secretary, it was disclosed tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 28, (AP)--Representative Adam Clayton Powell, Democrat of Manhattan, said today that racism and political punishment were behind a proposal to split the House Education and Labor Committee, which he heads.

WASHINGTON, July 28-- The $1.7-billion Colorado River Basin project was approved by the House Interior Committee today amid charges that it was an "evil" bill and that "nefarious dealings" had pushed it through the panel.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI)--Senator James O. Eastland, Democrat of Mississippi, called on the State Department today to demand expulsion of a Czechoslovak official at the United Nations charged with espionage.
BOSTON, July 28--The only two surgeons known to have attached auxiliary heart pumps to human beings agreed today that the devices had helped the patients whose lives they were trying to save.

LOS ANGELES, July 28-- California officials are fighting to reinstate the convictions of seven confessed murderers who may soon go free because of a quirk in the confessions rule of the California Supreme Court.

STOVEPIPE WELLS, Calif., July 28 (UPI)--Jean Pierre Marquant, French explorer, completed today a 102-mile hike through Death Valley, one of nature's hottest and driest places, and had to be persuaded to take a rest.

Litton Industries, Inc., the big West Coast diversified electronics producer, is planning to expand its educational business activities through the $71.45million acquisition of the American Book Company.

PARIS, July 28--Greatcoats with long skirts that hide the tops of boots marched out today in Marc Bohan's winter collection for Christian Dior. Under the coats, tween the uniforms of Czarist troops and West Point cadets, are ladylike suits or dresses that end a bit below the kneecap.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) --Charges and denials of "tainted documents" today marked pretrial proceedings in a $2-million libel suit brought by Senator Thomas J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, against Drew Pearson and Jack Anderson, the columnists.
There has been a growing amount of talk recently about motorcycles, particularly about accidents and fatalities among drivers of the machines.
WASHINGTON, July 28--Two hundred people from Nassau County, L.I., came here by bus today to demand $600,000 more for the county's Economic Opportunity Commission.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI)--Senator J.W. Fulbright has given a first-person confirmation that the Central Intelligence Agency "made the case" for the disastrous Bay of Pigs invasion.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) announced yesterday it had approved loan equivalents of $130-million for Japan, South Africa and the Malagasy Republic. The largest of these, a $100-million loan to the Japan Highway Public Corporation, is designed to help build a section of the 333-mile TokyoKobe expressway.

TOKYO, July 29--Thousands of delivery boys on bicycles, balancing precarious towers of lacquered boxes in trays held on one hand, added more than the normal uncertainty and color to Tokyo's narrow, winding residential streets today.

LAKE BLUFF, Ill., July 29 (AP)--Linda Tuero of Metairie, La., and Kristy Pigeon of Danville, Calif., breezed to semifinal victories today in the national tennis tournament for girls 16 years and under.

Outstanding letters of credit of Latin American countries confirmed by 11 reporting banks declined $5.6-million during June to a total of $255.4million, the Federal Reserve of New York reported yesterday. The decline followed four monthly increases.
Bond prices continued to decline yesterday, and short-term interest rates continued to move upward.
Tight money and high interest rates are becoming increasingly basic issues for the man in the street.

"Aida," the most performed opera in the Metropolitan repertory, was sung again last night in a concert version at Lewisohn Stadium. WASHINGTON, July 29 -- A Senate investigation of sharp consumer price increases for milk, bread and other staple foods in New York and other big cities was set in motion today.

MOSCOW, Saturday, July 30 (Reuters)--Secretary General Thant of the United Nations warned before leaving here for New ork today that the Vietnam conflict might turn into a major war "if the present trend continues."
COLUMBIA, S.C., July 29 (AP)--A Federal judge ruled today that L. Maurice Bessinger can continue to refuse to serve Negroes food for consumption on the premises at his five drive-in restaurants.

WHITE PLAINS, July 29 --Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Bert S. Kleinsinger of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Roberta Kleinsinger, to Clifford Michael Detz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur I. Detz of East Meadow, L.I. The wedding will take place in October.
ESCONDIDO, Calif., July 29 (UPI)--Earl Faison, who had played out his option with the San Diego Chargers, came back into the fold of the American Football League club today.
LONDON, July 29 -- The Labor Government, in a climactic move to break Britain's pattern of economic crisis, demanded today a six-month freeze on all wages and severe restraint on prices.
A young man who ripped his 4-F draft card five months ago was sentenced to a year in jail in Manhattan Federal court yesterday after refusing to carry a card in the future.
Mayor Lindsay has directed his commissioners to take a "hard look" at the sudden increases in food prices and turn over to Federal officials any evidence they uncover of "collaboration."

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., July 29--Clark Graebner repeated his victory of last week over Charles Pasarell today and Cliff Richey narrowly averted defeat in the quarter-finals of the Eastern Grass Court championships.

BOSTON, July 29--An 80foot long high-speed planing boat employing gas-turbine engines and incorporating other aerospace techniques was unveiled this week by United Aircraft Corporate Systems Center at nearby Quincy.

RYE, N.Y., July 29--William Ziobro of Union City High School in Scotch Plains, N.J., today won the Metropolitan Golf Association's 49th junior championship tournament with a 2-and-1 victory over James Dwulet of Manasquan River, in an 18-hole final at the Apawamis Club.

LOS ANGELES, July 29 (AP) --A judge ruled today that Chevrolet's Corvair automobile was not negligently designed. Judge Bernard S. Jefferson of Los Angeles Superior Court decided in favor of General Motors, Chevrolet's parent corporation, in a $250,000 suit by the parents of a 16-year-old by who was killed in a Corvair.

THE hamburgers sizzled over coals, a pretty girl with a guitar sang lazy folk songs, and men and women in casual attire stood in the flickering light of torches, swirled the ice around in their drinks and admired the view.

TWO likable American youths, one de- termined to remake the world, the other completely at home in it, are the heroes of two charming comic novels that run the risk of getting lost in the late-summer search for serious culture and highpitched entertainment.
WASHINGTON, July 29--A grant of $300,000 to the Modern Language Association of America was announced today by the National Endowment for the Humanities.
MIAMI, July 29 (AP)--Nine of 19 men charged with looting the Five Points National Bank of $620,000 surrendered today and were released on $1,000 bonds, the United States Marshal's office said.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 29 (UPI)--Juan (Chi Chi) Rodriguez, on a diet of liver pills to gain weight, fired his best round of the year today, a sixunder-par 66, and tied Johnny Schlee for the 36-hole lead in the $92,000 Speedway Festival open at 138.
OLEAN, N.Y., July 29--Frank D. O'Connor called today for a secret ballot on the nomination for Governor at the forthcoming Democratic state convention.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., July 29 --The United States women's amateur golf team took a major step toward retaining the Curtis Cup today. Playing decisively in both the foursomes and singles against the representatives of the British Isles, the Americans established a 7-2 lead.
LONDON, July 29--An eminent British archeologist said today he was "almost certain" that Camelot--King Arthur's legendary castle--had been found.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (UPI)--Dr. William H. Stewart, Surgeon General of the Public Health Service, said today that many Americans were getting typhoid vaccinations needlessly.

BALTIMORE, July 29--Officials of the National States Rights party were forbidden by court order today to hold any further public meetings in an effort to avoid a recurrence of the racial violence that occurred here last night.

LONGMEADOW, Mass., July 29--Mrs. Victor Karel Wagner Jr. and Thomas Walter Clark of Teheran, Iran, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Ward Clark, to Gary Francis Seifert, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Seifert of Upper Nyack, N.Y. The wedding is planned for September.
MRS. LYNDON B. JOHNSON will wear coat, dress, hat and shoes of yellow for the wedding of her daughter Luci on Aug. 6.
BELGRADE, July 29 (UPI) --Mihajlo Mihajlov, who plans to publish an independent opposition magazine in Yugoslavia, was questioned for three hours by Yugoslav officials today and released.

BERLIN, July 29--Talks on wall-crossing permits for West Berliners broke down today amid new signs that the Communists would demand recognition of the East German regime as the price for future arrangements.

Fred W. Friendly, former president of news for the Columbia Broadcasting System, yesterday urged broadcasters to take an editorial stand on national and world issues, even if they make people angry in the process.
A continental-style outdoor cafe with striped canopies and avocado-green umbrellas has brought new life to the preVictorian setting of Central Park's Bethesda Fountain.

KINSHASA, The Congo, July 29--The uprising by Ni- gerian Army insurgents reflects the mounting dissatisfaction of young southerners in and out of the army with the Government of Maj. Gen. Johnson T. U. Aguiyi-Ironsi.

NEW ORLEANS, July 29 (AP)--A Pensacola, Fla., man taken into custody by an airborne agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation was held in jail today on Federal charges stemming from the theft of a 44-foot schooner.
ROCKPORT, Mass., July 29 --Randolph Marshall Saville, a leader in the Boy Scout movement and a life underwriter for the Connecticut Mutual Life Insurance Company, died Wednesday. He was 69 years old.

LAUREL, Miss., July 29, (UPI)--Rifle bullets were fired early today into the home of a Negro minister who said has life had been threatened by a white man who had resented his family's entering a restaurant.

Eighty-one years ago the French ship Isere, carrying the 300-odd copper sections of the Statue of Liberty in her hold, docked at Bedloes Island after a rather stormy trans-Atlantic crossing. The less-than-tranquil voyage was symbolic, for this magnificent monument to liberty and Franco-American friendship that rises in Upper New York Bay has been a sometimes rollicking storm center ever since.
VENCE, France, July 29 (UPI)--Edward Gordon Craig, theatrical producer, stage designer and son of the actress Dame Ellen Terry, died at his home here today. He was 94 years old.

Premier Ky's call for an invasion of North Vietnam and a military confrontation with Communist China requires much more forthright repudiation than it has had from the Johnson Administration. The mild disclaimers issued by the White House and the State Department can hardly be considered a sufficient response.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 29-- The rarity of two yachts finishing even for first place on corrected time was a highlight of the New York Yacht Club cruise competition that began today with a run from New London.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 29 (AP)--A Chinese Communist diplomat attached to the embassy in Damascus has defected and asked the United States Embassy there for political asylum, diplomatic sources in the Syrian capital reported today.
SPRINGFIELD, July 29 (AP)--Associate Circuit Judge Howard White granted a temporary injunction today restraining, enforcement of an open housing order against 154 real estate salesmen and brokers.
Stock prices declined in light trading yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 29-- Richard Helms, director of the Central Intelligence Agency, assured the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that the student exchange program had not been used as a cover for C.I.A. agents abroad.

TOKYO, July 29 (AP)--Two Japanese concerns have agreed to cancel their planned exports of copper wire to North Vietnam as a result of pressure from the United States and Japanese Governments, official sources said today.

CATLO, South Vietnam, July 29 (UPI)--United States Navy and Coast Guard patrol boats staged a demonstration today for Ambassador Henry Cabot Lodge, and the shooting brought return fire from an Australian LST crew that thought it was a Vietcong attack.

Mayor Lindsay appealed yesterday to the pressmen's union and the World Journal Tribune, Inc., to begin publication of the new company's merged newspapers while an outside panel studies the dispute between the two sides and makes recommendations.

The evolution of intelligence, culminating in the mind of man, began in large measure with the formation of social structures by ancestors of the apes and monkeys, according to a study published yesterday in the journal Science.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) --California's consumer counsel charged today that a national food manufacturer had reduced the amount of instant mashed potatoes in its package to conceal a 36.6 per cent price increase in less than four years.

ROME, July 29--Italy's two Socialist parties reached agreement today on a program of reunification that will produce a strong new party of the moderate left capable of eroding both Communist and Christian Democratic strength.
Secret Service agents yesterday recovered $80,000 in stolen United States savings bonds from a Brooklyn bank deposit box allegedly rented by Eugene Bleecker, a butcher, who was arrested Wednesday.

WHITE PLAINS, July 29-- I. James Brody, a former state and New York City official who retired eight years ago as an accountant in private industry, died today after a long illness at White Plains Hospital. He was 73 years old.

The City Housing Authority indicated yesterday that it would have to raise rents for more than 140,000 families in its projects if the Consolidated Edison, Company was allowed to raise its rates for electricity.

LONDON, Oct., July 29 (Canadian, Press)--Kathy Whitworth of San Antonio, Tex., combined a first-round 71 with a two-under-par 70 today to take the lead after two rounds of the 54-hole, $15,000 women's open.

SANTA CRUZ, Bolivia, July 29--The Gulf Oil Corporation is about to begin exporting crude oil from its rich fields in the tropical lowlands of eastern Bolivia, just five years after its first discovery there.

"South-West Africa: The Last Pioneer Country," Thomas Molnar's new book, discusses the South-West Africa case recently decided by the World Court in favor of the Republic of South Africa and against Ethiopia, and Liberia. It will be published Aug. 29 by the Fleet Publishing Corporation. Mr. Molnar is the author of "Africa: A Political Travelogue."
CHICAGO, July 29--Mickey Mantle slugged his way past Lou Gehrig into sixth place on baseball's career list of homerun hitters tonight as the New York Yankees defeated the Chicago White Sox, 2-1.

The spot rate on the British pound dropped 12 points to $2.7904 in quiet trading on foreign-exchange markets here yesterday. Traders noted that there was little fluctuation throughout the day and that the currency usually turned weaker before a weekend.

With the excitement of an art connoisseur and the nostalgia of a man who has lost a home President Zalman Shazar of Israel gave an enthusiastic lecture to Mayor Lindsay yesterday on two paintings by his old friend and fellow-refugee Marc Chagall.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP)--The Pentagon made public today the names of 11 men killed in the fighting in Vietnam. The Army listed four, the Marines six and the Navy one.
MILWAUKEE, July 29--The Pabst Theater, which closed June 1 after having been Milwaukee's main legitimate theater for 71 years, was given new life tonight.
PARIS, July 29 (Reuters)-- France will help her steel industry with loans equivalent to $600-million, according to a Government spokesman.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) --A Virginia couple appealed to the Supreme Court today to strike down that state's law banning interracial marriages.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., July 29 --A Sept 3 wedding is planned by Miss Leslie Ann Flygare and David Hathaway Koether. Mrs. Enoch J. Flygare had announced her daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard A. Koether of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., formerly of Bronxville.

UNION, N.J., July 29--Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Slavin have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Slavin, to Vincent A. Mulligan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry D. Mulligan of Elizabeth. The wedding will take place Aug. 27 in St. Genevieve's Roman Catholic Church, Elizabeth.

Shareholders of Norris-Thermador Corporation, at a special meeting in Los Angeles yesterday, approved a two-for-one stock split of the common stock, an increase in the authorized shares to 10 million from 2.5 million and changing the name of the company to Norris Industries, Inc. The company makes commercial and military products and has more than 5,000 employes.
CHICAGO, July 29--The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. began a new drive today against housing segregation. He said his supporters would begin allnight vigils in real estate offices.
James S. Anderson, who is 56 years old, has resigned as president and a director of the Babcock Wilcox Company, manufacturers of steam-generating equipment and other industrial products.

MOSCOW, July 29 (UPI)-- Soviet Union weightlifters set three world records today in their high-altitude test competition held at Chei in the Caucasus Mountains, Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported.
LONDON, July 29 (Reuters)--The gavel at Sotheby's, the art auction house, hammered out a record-smashing 1965-66 season, it was announced today.
PARIS, July 29--Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon said today that the United States' goals in Vietnam were not understood by its allies in Europe.

Daniel K. Ludwig, one of the largest shipowners in the United States as well as one of the nation's wealthiest men, plans to team up with William K. Whiteford, former chairman of the Gulf Oil Corporation, to invest in a new stock brokerage house that hopes to go into business by mid-August.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 29--American warplanes attacked North Vietnam yesterday in record numbers, a United States military spokesman said tonight.

MONTREAL, July 20 (Canadian Press)--European visitors to the 1967 World's Fair in Montreal may have to pay only $240 instead of $300 for a roundtrip flight between London and Montreal if a proposal by Air Canada for a special 1967 fare is agreed to by the International Air Transport Association.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) --The Communications Satellite Corporation announced today the signing of an agreement with the National Aeronautics and Space Administration for the launching of two new Comsat satellites this fall.
LAGOS, Nigeria, July 29-- Mutiny broke out in the Nigerian Army today. Dissident troops seized the country's leader, Maj. Gen. Johnson T.U. Aguiyi-Ironsi.

WOODSTOCK, N.Y., July 29 --Schoenberg's "Erwartung" and Bartok's "Bluebeard's Castle" are among the 20th century's more esoteric operas. Nothing would seem more unlikely than their production as a double bill in a tiny rustic theater tucked away in the woods outside a New York village of 6,000.
A City Welfare Department investigator was accused yesterday of Stealing $594.90 from a welfare recipient and the department.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 29 (Reuters)--The Soviet commercial bank established in Zurich with a share capital of 10 million Swiss francs last month can go into business following approval from the Swiss authorities.

WASHINGTON, July 29-- The index of primary market prices decreased one-tenth of 1 per cent to 106.3 during the week ended July 26, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. Farm products moved lower in price while processed foods advanced. Industrial commodities averaged unchanged.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 29--Mrs. Murray Gordon of Elmwood, who scored, 40, 38-78, won the first gross prize today in the one-day tournament of the Women's Tri-County Golf Association at Hampshire Country Club.

GENEVA, July 29--The European Economic Community completed this week a blueprint for agriculture without which the Common Market could not attain its full stature... and make its name a true description. But the nature of its plan creates profound problems for the six-nation group in its relations with Britain and with the United States.
Winds north to northeast at 15 knots, becoming northeasterly 10 to 15 knots Saturday night and easterly 10 to 15 knots Sunday.

MIAMI, July 29--The Miami Herald and the Miami News announced an agreement today that will transfer all production and business operations of The News to The Herald but leave The News as an independent entity with complete control of its editorial policies.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., July 29--Grand Master Bent Larsen of Denmark took the undisputed lead in the Piatigorsky Cup Chess Tournament when he drew the eighth-round game with "his American opponent Sammy Reshevsky of Spring Valley, N.Y., at the Hotel Miromar here last night. A 19move Dutch Defense, with Reshevsky as White, ended by a repetition of moves. Larsen has now amassed 5 points.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company estimated yesterday that rate revenues totaling $84.7-million a year for television and radio program-transmission services would be necessary to provide the Bell System with an 8 per cent rate of return on its investment.
It will be 'Ladies Day' at Delaware Park and Monmouth today, with fillies and mares battling for prizes in two $100,000 added stakes.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) --The Commerce Department's Environmetal Science Services Administration said today one of the two cameras aboard the Essa 1 weather satellite had failed.
Four major lumber associations reported a decline of 9.3 per cent in production for the week ended July 23, compared with the level in the corresponding 1965 week.

The Tidal Handicap at Aqueduct will serve as the feature today of the summer getawayday program for New York City's thoroughbred-track-onthe-subway. The season of the Saratoga break is upon us, and for the next four weeks the flat-racing activity will be held at the upstate spa.
WASHINGTON, July 29-- The United States Space Agency is considering a new escape system to rescue workmen from a missile-launch gantry in case of explosion or fire.

LONDON, July 29 (Reuters) --Twenty-two athletes from England and West Germany will trot on to the field at Wembley Stadium tomorrow to cap one of the world's most emotional sports competitions --the World Cup soccer championship.
The touchy issue of who will study the steel-import situation was settled today when the Senate Finance Committee instructed its staff to review the question.

ALBANY, July 29--Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz ruled today that the state's English literacy requirement would remain in effect for voters in this year's election, except for Puerto Ricans who have completed at least six years of schooling.

EASTCHESTER, N.Y., July 29--Mrs. Mandel Doppelt and William Tamis of Brae Burn won the 32d annual sisterbrother tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association by seven strokes at Vernon Hills Country Club today with a 37-36--73.
And now from Brooklyn another star emerges into the spotlight of the Plaza Hotel's Persian Room.

The Mets' legend still lives. The New Yorkers reverted to past form last night, committing three errors in the eighth inning that permitted three runs and a 7-4 victory by the last-place Chicago Cubs before a crowd of 26,507 at Shea Stadium.

Mrs. Anna Estelle Colgan Walsh, a retired school teacher, and the widow of James F. Walsh, a credit manager for the Brooklyn Union Gas Company, died yesterday in her home, 1125 Lorimer Street, Brooklyn. She was 85 years old.

Encroachment on the parks for nonpark use is always a shame, but one such encroachment has the force of tradition and public necessity behind it. That is the Fire Department's use of an open space in each borough for a communications center designed to function through any disaster. The department now plans to replace its obsolete communications center on the Seventy-ninth Street transverse in Central...

The first New York area issue of the Home Finders Directory will appear this Sep tember. The directory, which is distributed free to personnel directors of major companies, is designed to help relocating executives in new areas.
MEXICO CITY, July 29-- (UPI)--Troops were sent to the West Coast port of Ensenada today to prevent crew members of two Soviet ships from going ashore. About 150 crewmen were involved.
Capt. Leroy J. Alexanderson, the master of the United States Lines' flagship United States, became commodore of the line's 52-ship fleet yesterday.

ST. CATHARINES, Ont., July 29 (CP)--The host St. Catharines Rowing Club, champion for the last five years, won two events at the 84th Royal Canadian Henley regatta today to maintain its point lead in the third day of competition. There were 12 final events held.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (UPI)--Canadian delegates walked out of the American Newspaper Guild convention today but returned after the union restored a Toronto man to a Guild office.

HIGHLAND PARK, N.J., July 29--Dr. and Mrs. Harry Ehrlich have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janet Irene Ehrlich, to Gilbert Sandler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Sandler of Perth Amboy. The wedding will take place on Aug. 21.

ASPEN, Colo., July 29--Con- stantinos A. Doxiadis, the 53- year-old Greek architect and the father of "ekistics, the science of human settlements," today became the third recipient of the annual Aspen Award.
Continental Airlines announced yesterday it had a record net income of $6,347,000, or $1.95 a share, for the first six months this year.

YONKERS, July 29--Now that the great Bret Hanover has marched off with $55,000 as a result of an impressive victory in last night's Empire Pace at Yonkers Raceway, Bonjour Hanover, his full sister, appears ready to pick up her share of the loot.
Despite a weak start, grain prices rallied yesterday.

Brig. Gen. Ralph G. DeVoe, retired., who in World War II had been commanding officer of the Army's Halloran General Hospital at Willowbrook, S.I., died yesterday at Harkness Pavilion, Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 83 years old.
The election of Richard L. Berry as a vice president of Owens-Illinois, Inc., has been announced in Toledo, Ohio.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 29 (AP)--Brooks and Frank Robinson each drove in a run tonight as the American Leagueleading Baltimore Orioles defeated the Minnesota Twins, 3-0, behind the combined eighthit pitching of Jim Palmer and Eddie Fisher.
MOSCOW, July 29 (AP)-- The Soviet Government has revised its list of areas closed to foreigners, closing some regions that had in theory been open and arranged for Mr. Stout to Siberia.

WASHINGTON, July 29--Prime Minister Wilson warned here today against further escalation of the war in Vietnam. The British leader also reiterated the determination of his Government to pursue all necessary economic measures, harsh though they may be, to resolve his country's economic crisis.

CLEVELAND, July 29 (UPI) --A grand jury investigating last week's slayings, fire bombings and looting in the East Side Negro slums returned eight indictments today. It also questioned four members of the W. E. DuBois Club, an organization that has been labeled a Communist front.

MOSCOW, July 29--Soviet authorities are beginning to express alarm over delays and obstructionism in a priority program of finding jobs for the flood of youngsters who were graduated from the country's high schools last month.
WASHINGTON, July 29--Dr. James W. Teener, space physicist at the Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory, died of cancer yesterday at this home in Silver Spring, Md. He was 42 years old.

Announced a settlement after a White House meeting of negotiators in the airline strike; met with British Prime Minister Harold Wilson and later gave White House luncheon in his honor; announced the upgrading of the rank of the commanding general in the field in Vietnam to lieutenant general.

TEL AVIV, July 29--Participants in an annual AmericanIsraeli "dialogue" nodded in assent today as a speaker declared that "the mere fact that any one of us could have been in the gas chambers is enough to keep Jewish identity for this generation at least."

PHILADELPHIA, July 29-- Mrs. Suzanne Braman Rounds, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold P. Braman of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was married here this evening to John Watters McClenahan, son of Mr. and Mrs. James McClenahan of St. Albans, Hertfordshire, England.

BALTIMORE, July 29 (AP) --Luci Baines Johnson of Washington and Susan Johnson of Baltimore both will be married Aug. 6. The wedding date is one of many things the girls, who are unrelated, have in common.
PARIS, July 29--Coco Chanel, who is certainly not the most placid personality in the French haute couture, tried hard today to upset Pierre Cardin and did not.

MOSCOW, July 29--Pravda charged today that Lieut. (jg.) Dieter Dengler, a United States Navy pilot rescued recently in the jungles of North Vietnam after escaping captivity, was a West German military officer serving in American disguise.

TRENTON, July 29 (AP)-- Gov. Richard J. Hughes signed into law today a bill creating a State Council on the Arts. "I am proud the time has come in our society when government can aid the arts," he said. "The artistic experience belongs neither to the public sector nor the private sector-- it belongs to the citizen."
A deal to divide four State Supreme Court nominations in Manhattan and the Bronx among three groups of Democrats was reported yesterday.

NORTH AMITYVILLE, L.I., Saturday, July 30--Suffolk County officials met with representatives of this predominantly Negro section yesterday to discuss disorders Thursday night in which eight persons were arrested.
City Controller Mario A. Pro-- caccino said yesterday that the Transit Authority had told him that fares would go to 25 cents on July 1, 1967, "unless some way is found to get more money."

KANSAS CITY, July 29 (AP)--Lew Krausse, the pitcher, hit a two-run double and Bert Campaneris added a tworun single in a four-run second inning as the Kansas City Athletics defeated Detroit, 4-1, tonight.

BABYLON, L.I., July 29-- Nine skippers assured themselves of class championships today on the fifth day of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's Cruise Week regatta. The series concludes tomorrow in this same port with 19 of the class winners still to be decided.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., July 29--The Florida In- ternational Music Festival, by far the most ambitious to come to the American Southeast, got under way last night. A foreign orchestra officiated. For this month-long series, the London Symphony Orchestra has been flown in, with Colin Davis as its conductor. Mr. Davis is a young Englishman whose work has lately been attracting a great deal of international attention.
WASHINGTON, July 29.-- President Johnson announced tonight a settlement of the 22-day airline strike about 12 hours after he had intervened to prod negotiators for an accord.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, July 29 --Sixteen Opposition members walked out of Parliament today because Finance Minister Ukka Banda Wanninayake spoke in English in presenting Ceylon's budget, rather than in Sinhala, his native tongue.
Mayor Lindsay declared yesteday that the assignment of city employes to jobs was "a matter of executive responsibility alone" and was not open to collective bargaining.

NEW ORLEANS, July 29 (AP)--A three-judge Federal panel today ordered the Louisiana Legislature to reapportion both houses on a "one-man, one-vote basis by Jan. 1. If it does not, all legislative candidates will be forced to run at large in the election next year. The court reluctantly agreed to set guidelines for the Legislature to follow in redrawing the electoral districts but refused to get into specifics.
ATLANTA, July 29 (AP)-- Denis Menke rifled a two-out, run-scoring single in the ninth inning tonight to give Atlanta a 7-6 victory over San Francisco.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 29 --President Sukarno's demand that Malaysia hold referendums on self-determination in Northern Borneo before Indonesia changes her opposition to Malaysia was denounced by authoritative Indonesian sources today as "not representing the views of the Government."
THE New York Philharmonic broke another at- tendance record last night when it brought more than 50,000 persons to the Music Grove in Brooklyn's Prospect Park.
TOKYO, Saturday, July 30 (Reuters)--All members of the Japanese Cabinet resigned today in a procedural step to clear the way for a reshuffle.

PITTSBURGH, July 29 (AP) --Jose Pagan's two-out, threerun double sparked a four-run rally in the eighth inning that helped the league-leading Pittsburgh Pirates to a 5-3 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies tonight.
The American Natural Gas Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday operating revenues of $369,609,563 for l2 months ended June 30. This compared with $353,603,745 a year earlier.
The nation's only sanatorium operated by laymen exclusively for the care and cure of alcoholic Roman Catholic priests is expanding its operations to the East Coast.
SHORT HILLS, N.J., July 29--Franklin Conklin Jr. of 33 Fairfield Drive, an industrialist and a civic leader, died yesterday in St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston. He was 80 years old.
A compact, horizontal furnace with forced-draft combustion and two-stage heating has been developed by the Carrier Air Conditioning Company for commercial, industrial and large house applications.
CHICAGO, July 29 (AP)--A Cook County grand jury returned eight revised murder indictments against Richard Speck late today in the deaths of eight student nurses.
MOSCOW, July 29 (UPI)-- American scientists have protested the use of a Moscow scientific conference as a forum for an attack on United States policy in Vietnam.
STOKE MANDEVILLE, England, July 29 (UPI) -- Israel scored an 32-27 upset victory over the United States today in a basketball semi-final of the International Paraplegic Games.

GREENSBORO, N.C., July 29 (AP)--The University of South Carolina lost its halfshare of the 1965 Atlantic Coast Conference football championship today when it was penalized by the conference for giving illegal aid to two varsity players.
The Navy awarded contracts yesterday to the three companies that have been contending for a huge assignment involving the largest shipbuilding project in peacetime Navy history.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (UPI)--President Johnson said tonight that the only road to peace was to teach aggressors to leave their neighbors alone. Addressing a testimonial dinner for the House Democratic leader, Carl Albert of Oklahoma, Mr. Johnson affirmed his faith in the United States ability to fight Communism in Vietnam and still maintain progress at home.
News of a proposal by the British Government to freeze incomes, prices and dividends weakened most issues yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.

MOSCOW, July 29--U Thant met for more than 90 minutes today with Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party chief, and was reliably reported to have found him as unyielding on the question of negotiations on Vietnam as was Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin earlier this week.

The names of three men to serve as fact-finders in the wage dispute involving physicians, dentists and other medical aides who work for the City Health Department were made public yesterday by the American Arbitration Association.

The crime and violence perpetrated by narcotics addicts, plus the incalculable personal and social misery the drug habit engenders, give all New Yorkers a stake in the success of the ambitious drive against addiction the city has just launched. Dr. Efren Ramirez, the new narcotics coordinator, is starting out with a $5.5 million appropriation to reach addicts in the street and help them break the habit.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 29--Jordan and Mali asked the Security Council today to condemn Israel for "wanten aggression" in an air attack on a Syrian engineering works near the Jordan River July 14.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 29 (UPI)--A Coast Guard plane spotted debris tonight in the area of the Pacific where a DC-3 carrying Brig. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell Jr. disappeared six days ago.
Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that he was "concerned and worried about the situation in East New York and of other areas of the city" where racial tension is high.

The West German Research Institute for Ocean Packaging plans to begin next year another study of a problem of growing importance to shippers and ship operators--the effects of the sea and of weather on cargoes carried in containers or on pallets.
NEWARK, July 29--Four boys aged 12 to 14 were charged today with juvenile delinquency and trespassing in the slaughtering of 25 lambs Thursday evening in a local stockyard.

Store networks will require more links in the sprawling metropolitan areas as the population continues to concentrate in and around big cities, the head of one of the nation's largest department store chains, said yesterday.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, July 29--The apparent breakdown of ministerial talks here this week on methods of maintaining and strengthening the East African Common Market has cast a further shadow over the future of the organization.
LOS ANGELES, July 29 (UPI)--Don Schollander broke his world record in the men's 200-meter free-style today in the highlight of the first day of the eighth annual Los Angeles invitation swim meet.

Freed three weeks ago after serving 10 years for the slaying of his common-law wife, Almars Elksnis, 34 years old, was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of passing counterfeit $10 bills.
BOSTON, July 29 (AP)-- Attorney General Edward W. Brooke dropped prosecution today of indictments against three former Massachusetts state officials.
A FRESH opportunity to reassess the field of folk art is offered in the new Eleanor and Mabel Van Alstyne Collection of American Folk Art at the Smithsonian Institution in Washington.
MR. JOHNSON--Both sides have come to the White House studio to report that they have now reached agreement on the terms of a settlement of the airline strike.

A Senator who has called for a Congressional in- vestigation of price increases in milk, bread, butter and eggs remembers when his father, pastor of the Wesleyan Methodist Church of Avon, S.D., received the better part of his small salary in potatoes and cabbages.

NEW DELHI, July 29 (UPI) --India's largest residential university, at Benares, closed indefinitely today because of continued "indiscipline, rowdyism and violence by sections of students," university authorities said.

DENVER, July 29--A horde of bridge enthusiasts, only slightly diminished by absences because of transportation problems, began play here tonight in the Summer National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) --Attorneys for Senator Thomas J. Dodd listed his 1965 net income today as $50,650 and said it dropped sharply this year as a result of attacks by, Drew Pearson and Jack Anderson, the columnists.

WASHINGTON, July 29-- A sweeping reform of the Federal jury system, the least controversial section of the Administration's 1966 Civil Rights Bill, survived its first test in the House of Representatives today by a margin of better than 2 to 1.

MONTREAL, July 29 (Canadian Press)--A group of directors, supported by the United States-controlled Canadian Channing Corporation, Ltd., compelted a double victory today by being elected to the board of Commonwealth International Leverage Funds, Ltd.

As assistant United States attorney told a Federal judge yesterday that the Atomic Energy Commission was opposed to the general publication of a copy of an alleged sketch of the atomic bomb that Julius and Ethel Rosenberg purportedly turned over to the Soviet Union in 1945.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 29--Alabama Republicans, who only six months ago were favored to take control of the state, opened their nominating convention today in a new political climate that makes them underdogs in the November election.
LONDON, July 29--Mrs. Sandra Payson Meyer of New York and George Weidenfeld, the London publisher, were married here yesterday at the Caxton Registry Office.

Mayor Lindsay, responding yesterday to disclosures of hazardous and unhealthy conditions in nursing homes in the city, called the conditions "shocking" and said the city would, if necessary, close violation-ridden homes.
LONDON, July 29--Mrs. Sandra Payson Meyer of New York and George Weidenfeld, the London publisher, were married here yesterday at the Caxton Registry Office.

Mayor Lindsay, responding yesterday to disclosures of hazardous and unhealthy conditions in nursing homes in the city, called the conditions "shocking" and said the city would, if necessary, close violation-ridden homes.
MIAMI, July 29--Cuba will receive $35-million in heavy agricultural and road-building equipment from France, the Havana radio reported today.

A plan for the redevelopment of part of East Harlem, proposed by two Columbia University architecture students as a thesis for their masters degrees, has won a top design award and may be utilized by a community group making an over-all plan for the area.

LA JOLLA, Calif., July 29-- St. James-by-the-Sea Episcopal Church was the setting this evening for the marriage of Miss Sallie Ford Bell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Heffelfinger Bell of Chandler, Ariz., to Robert Sumner Colman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Woodruff Colman of Hartland, Wis. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Robert M. Wolterstorff.

Electrical and Musical Industries, Ltd., of Britain, the world's largest maker of phonograph records, is planning to acquire SE Laboratories (Holdings), Ltd., for stock and cash totaling $7.28-million, it was announced yesterday.

The disclosure that Leonard Marks, director of the United States Information Agency, has enlisted publicity men from advertising agencies to "do something" about selling the American image abroad puts the cart before the horse, or the media before the message. There is nothing wrong per se in having PR men lend professional advice. But it is another matter when image-makers become policy-makers.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP)--The Senate passed by voice vote today a bill to open the way for suits to test the constitutionality of Federal grants and loans to church-related schools, colleges and other institutions.

A sketch in memoriam of a man whose accomplishments are indelibly imprinted in the annals of art will appear next week as the sole content of the summer issue of the Bulletin, a publication of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

Canadian National Railways announced yesterday net railway operating income of $15,518,000 for the first half. In the same period last year, the figure was $44,000. The large increase was attributed to the movements of grain exports.

ANAHEIM, July 29 (AP)-- Ed Kirkpatrick brought California from behind with a tworun homer in the eighth inning tonight as the Angels snapped a four-game losing streak with a 2-1 victory over Cleveland.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 29-- At a political dinner in Niagara Falls earlier this week, Eugene H. Nickerson, candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor, was being introduced to delegates to the nominating convention.
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 29 --The New York Jets dropped Eddie Robinson Jr., Bob Walton and Bob Windham, all rookies, today.
The Chase Brass and Copper Company, a subsidiary of the Kennecott Copper Corporation, announced yesterday that it would reduce prices on some mill products, effective Monday.
ESTERHAZY, Sask.--A new crop of "K-babies" is expected shortly in the wheat-growing province of Saskatchewan.

"Lower the Admiral's flag!" ordered Capt. Scott Burns Jr. Then, as the Navy band played "Auld Lang Syne," Rear Adm. Redfield Mason walked slowly across the parched grass of the parade ground at the defunct Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn to receive a farewell from his fellow officers and friends.

All-day negotiations between representatives of striking engineers and plumbers and the city's major contractors failed yesterday to end a five-dayold strike that is slowly crippling all building in the city.
For the second day in succession, longshoremen refused to unload the Swedish-flag freighter Antigua at the United Fruit Company's pier in Weehawken, N.J.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (UPI)--Senator John C. Tower charged today that the chair- man of the United States Mari- time Commission had written a letter under Government frank to friend in Texas supporting Mr. Tower's Democratic opponent.
Thousands of motorists waited in long, restless lines in the city's Traffic Courts yesterday to pay overdue parking tickets on the final day of the city's two-week grace period.
First quarter freight revenues of common carriers by water showed an increase of more than $8-million over that of 1965, according to a report issued last week by the Interstate Commerce Commission.
OKLAHOMA CITY, July 29 (AP)--Representative Adam Clayton Powell, Democrat of Manhattan, urged Negroes today to develop "black political power" so they can share fully in community life.

ALBROOK AIR FORCE BASE, C.Z., July 29--A vast new communication network providing voice radio contact between the air forces of 13 Latin American countries and the United States Air Force's Southern Command is serving as a strong tool for hemispheric solidarity.

MIAMI, July 29--Sweden sailed into the lead in the team championships of the International Optimist Dinghy Association regatta today as the United States Skipperss paid costly penalties for three violations of racing rules.

SEOL, South Korea, Saturday, July 30 (AP)--A patrol boat of the South Korean Navy fought a 30-minute gun battle yesterday with nine North Korean vessels, possibly sinking one of them, the Navy announced today.
The Western Union Company has announced the appointment of John M. Evans as vice president and general counsel.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) --The South Vietnamese Embassy denied tonight that tax money from a Saigon racetrack was "personally appropriated" to Premier Nguyen Cao Ky and distributed by him.

Moerdler, demanding that something be done about the lack of hot water, the gaping holes in the floors and "rats as big as puppies" that are part of their daily lives.

THE HAGUE, July 29--What strikes an American first about The Hague is the appearance of the people--fairer and more trim than other Europeans, and dressed more in the American styles, especially the women, who wear bright colors.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 29--The charred wreckage of the United States U-2 that disappeared yesterday was reported to have been found today on a hill in west-central Bolivia.

The Vietnamese war passed a milestone of sorts last week. The number of American battle deaths in Vietnam since 1961 reached the figure of 4,440. This was more than the number of Americans killed in the American Revolution (4,435), the War of 1812 (2,260), the Mexican War (1,733) and the Spanish-American War (385). The same week there were other announcements and statements indicating that the milestone would soon be left behind.

DETROIT, July 30 Detroit's Mayor Jerome P. Cavanagh opened a determined, last-minute bid today to overtake former Gov. G. Mennen Williams in their Democratic nomination race for the Senate.

Reidar E. Gundersen, who retired last month as a vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, died yesterday at the Benedictine Hospital in Kingston, N.Y. He was 65 years old and lived at 21 Ravine Road in Tenafly, N.J.

NOMINATIONS for the most unlikely sight on a New York City street are in order. Check one or the following four: (1) a brontosaurus ambling out of an auto; (2) a pedestrian waiting for the light to change; (3) a chamber orchestra giving a concert; (4) a slumlord on his hands and knees, washing down a stoop. Obviously No. 3 wins hands down.

CHICAGO, July 30 The New York Yankees led with their ace, Mel Stottlemyre, today in an effort to wrest sixth place from the Chicago White Sox. But the ace was trumped by Gary Peters, who pitched Chicago to a brilliant 6-0 victory and held the Yankees to three widely scattered hits.

The three offerings, it is hoped, will at least partly satisfy American (and British) collectors, who are legally unable to buy Canada's special $20 commemorative gold coin.

SAIGON. SIXTY miles northwest of Sai gon, Nui Ba Den Black Lady Mountain rises abruptly from the surrounding forests like a peasant's conical hat tossed on a green carpet. Somewhere in the thickets north of the Black Lady, and probably not far from the Cambodian border, lies an elaborate complex of huts, bunkers and tunnels composing the headquarters of an organization known as C.O.S.V.N. the Central Office for South Vietnam.

Eastman of West Babylon. The Rev. William Ayres performed the ceremony aad celebrated the nuptial mass in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church.

The Government apparently has been listening, because the Department of Agriculture early this year sold corn from its stock to reduce prices and thus help the fight against inflation. Corn helps fatten the hogs that turn up in the form of ham, bacon and pork roasts on dinner tables.

LINCOLN, N.M. The first weekend every August, this is a town that belongs to a New York City (maybe Brooklyn) boy who grew up to be Billy the Kid. The Kid was a symbol of the lawless West, but his friends, and many of his biographers, found excuses for his six-gunning and shotgunning; next weekend, when he rides reincarnate through this quaint backwater, the aura will be largely good-guy.
CHICAGO, July 30--Serious crime in Chicago increased 12.3 per cent in the last month compared with the same period a year ago, police superintendent Orlando W. Wilson reported this week.

Soon after the raspberries are harvested, the plants should be thinned out. All canes that bore fruit this year should be cut to the ground. In addition, the raspberry plants sucker profusely. These suckers should be cut to the ground so that each plant has about seven sturdy canes. Always wear gloves and long sleeved shirts when working around raspberries.

INTERNATIONAL nomads are landbased mammals belonging to the order of primates. A division of the species of Homo sapiens, international nomads are sometimes designated by the collective term "jet set." Continually in orbit, they can be found on any continent except Antarctica though their number is apt to be sparse in northern and eastern Europe and parts of central and northern Asia. Mrs. Alfred Levy of Saarbrucken, West Germany, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Dr. Marie-Louise Levy, to John Andrew Kennedy Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Kennedy of Washington.

LONDON This is a generation of British college students who count a vacation wasted if not spent a long way from home, and many of them now add North America to their list of conquests abroad. Inexpensive trans-Atlantic charter flights, bargain bus tickets and odd jobs along the way bring America within reach of student budgets.

STOKE MANDEVILLE, England, July 30 (AP) America's women won four more gold medals in track today, but Britain's handicapped athletes topped all the medal winners in the windup of the 15th annual games for paraplegics.

BONN Wits have gotten into the habit of talking about the "Elysian Curtain," referring to the awkward barrier caused by French withdrawal from NATO's organization and command structure. "Elysian," of course, derives from the Elysee Palace, de Gaulle's home.

New York City, still wrestling with the question of whether to impose compulsory metering of water here, has asked 70 cities in 28 states to report on how their metered water systems operate.

THE complete recording of Wagner's opera Lohengrin, which will be released by RCA Victor this week, is a news worthy event for several reasons. But the five-record album falls short of what one expects of an ideal "Lohengrin" recording (LM 6710; stereo LSC 6710).

SWANSEA, Wales, July 30 (Reuters) Alan Jones, Glamorgan County's opening batsman, hit 161 runs not out against the West Indians today to enable the Welsh team to declare its innings closed at 337 for eight wickets on the first day of the three-day match today.

TO THE EDITOR: I AM writing on behalf of my colleagues at the Museum of Modern Art to express the grief and shock we all feel at the loss of Frank O'Hara. ST. LOUIS, July 30 (AP) The St. Louis Cardinals gained their sixth straight victory tonight by beating the Los Angeles Dodgers, 3-1, behind the six-hit pitching of Al Jackson. The triumph was their 12th in the last 13 games and moved them within six games of the National League lead.
