MANILA, July 31 (UPI)-- The presidential press office tonight confirmed reports that President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines had sought to bring the Vietnam war to she conference table by sending an envoy to Peking.
PHILADELPHIA, July 31-- Dr. Philip Q. Roche, a prominent psychiatrist and author of "The Criminal Mind," died yesterday of a cerebral hemorrhage in Chestnut Hill Hospital. His age was 63.

Compiled by Congressional Quarterly WASHINGTON, July 31-- Following are the votes of delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in Congress during the week ended yesterday:

NYACK, N.Y., July 31--Ted Fontelieu of the Cedar Point Yacht Club of Westport, Conn., rallied in the closing stages of the final race of the Thistle Class Atlantic Coast championship regatta today to take third place and win the over-all series.
New profit peaks were reached by the nation's manufacturing and service industries in the first six months of 1966, despite the moderated rate of increase from the feverish pace the year before.

Mrs. Libbie Baron Coleman, the wife of David Coleman, senior partner of Coleman Co., stockbrokers, and chairman of the executive board of Ward Foods, Inc., died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 64 years old and lived at 55 Central Park West.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP)--Senator Joseph S. Clark, Democrat of Pennsylvania, was sharply critical today of William McChesney Martin Jr., chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, for trying to cool off inflation by "taking it out of the hides" of homebuilders and small-business men.

Anthony J. De May Jr., president of A.J. De May Company, Inc., of 28 Water Street, foreign-freight forwarders, died of a heart ailment on Saturday at Victory Memorial Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 58 years old and lived at 552 Lenox Road, Baldwin, L.I.

Thomas Daniel Yutzy, managing partner of the public relations firm of Dudley-Anderson-Yutzy, with offices here and in Washington and Atlanta, died yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital after a brief illness. He was 63 years old and lived at 415 East 52d Street.

The issue of whether the state should put at least some of its offices here in Harlem rather than in the projected World Trade Center downtown has begun to divide city and state officials on partisan lines.
PEKING, July 31 (Reuters) --Eight thousand persons swam in a giant phalanx across Peking's Lake Kunming today to celebrate tomorrow's Army Day.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., July 31--Now that the opening night is a matter of history, the Florida International Music Festival is stressing informality. Opening night last Thursday was a dressy affair, but since then audiences have been urged to come in informal dress. That means in anything more than a bikini.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) --Attorney General Nicholas deB Katzenbach said today quest, had done some investigating of the Connecticut Democrat's affairs but was now holding off pending the completion of a Senate inquiry.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 31--The outspoken Bishop of Kimberley and Kuruman, the Right Rev. Clarence E. Crowther, intends to cancel an intended visit to his California home if the South African Government does not assure that he will get a re-entry visa.
It is now official. July was every bit as hot as you thought it was.

SAN JOSE, Calif., July 31-- Many residents of the big, rapidly growing Santa Clara County will find their names indexed within the next year in a centralized computer system, which will provide at least sketchy information in personal "dossiers" to authorized inquirers in seconds or minutes.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 31--The oldest thoroughbred race track in the United States, Saratoga, will open its 103d season tomorrow. A meeting of 24 racing days is listed for the bucolic, attractive course, which has been in operation--with only slight interruption--since 1863.

Miss Renee Rochelle Spielman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Spielman of 180 West 93d Street, was married last night to Kenneth Randolph Baylor. Mr. Baylor is the son of Mrs. Emanuel N. Baylor of New York and the late Mr. Baylor.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 31 (AP)--Eddie Watt, a rookie pitcher, and Eddie Fisher, working in relief, limited the Minnesota Twins to five hits today as the Baltimore Orioles posted a 4-0 victory. The Orioles' triumph spoiled Jim Kaat's bid for his 15th pitching victory for the Twins.

BERKELEY, Calif., July 31 (AP)--A 20-year-old Berkeley youth, reported by friends to be under the influence of the hallucinatory drug LSD for the first time, jumped from a third-story window to his death early today.

BUENOS AIRES, July 31-- The military Government suspended today all classes in Argentina's national universities and high schools to head off what it described as mounting unrest among leftist students.
The awarding of grants totaling $1.25-million to three ballet companies was announced yesterday by the Ford Foundation.

CINCINNATI, July 31 (AP) --Leo Cardenas stole home in the fifth inning to cap a fourrun rally that sparked Cincinnati to a 10-6 victory over the Houston Astros, which gave the Reds a split of their doubleheader today.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 31--Premier Nguyen Cao Ky said today that he would not be a candidate for President in elections planned for next year.
Michael E. Nolan, of Mechanicville, N.Y., who retired in 1955 as bridge and buildings supervisor of the Boston Maine Railroad, died yesterday at St. Peter's Hospital in Albany. He was 79 years old.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) --J. Edgar Hoover believes the Communist party has surfaced as a "unified, hard-hitting, wellorganized conspiracy" to promote a class revolution in the United States.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., July 31--Mrs. Donna Floyd Fales of New York won the women's Eastern Grass Court Tennis championship today with an attack of such power and cleverness as to break down the resistance of Rosemary Casals, and Tony Roche of Australia defeated Clark Graebner of Beachwood, 6-4, 6-4, 6-3, for the men's title.

CHICAGO, July 31--Joel Horlen and Tommy John pitched Chicago to a double victory over the New York Yankees today by scores of 4-1 and 5-0 as the White Sox-continued to thrive on the hottest pitching in baseball.
Mayor Lindsay discounted rumors yesterday that Senator Jacob K. Javits would replace Governor Rockefeller this year as the Republican gubernatorial candidate.

MIAMI, July 31--Thirtyseven members of Cuba's Government-controlled cultural establishment today reproached the Chilean poet Pablo Neruda for going to the United States for the recent P.E.N. congress. Mr. Neruda, a literary innovator and an extreme leftist, has exerted wide influence in Latin American intellectual circles.

ST. LOUIS, July 31 (AP)-- Dick Stuart, who had driven in two runs with a single and a homer earlier in the game, doubled to send home the tying run with two out in the ninth and scored on John Roseboro's single, sparking the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 6-4 victory today over the St. Louis Cardinals.
MOSCOW, July 31 (AP)-- The 360-member Central Committee of the Soviet Communist party will meet tomorrow informed sources said today.

MEXICO CITY, July 31--The biggest exhibit of American industrial goods ever staged in Latin America is scheduled to open here tomorrow in an effort to increase the declining United States share of trade with Mexico, its fifth best world customer.

LOS ANGELES, July 31-- A surging crowd of 3,000 persons, many in bizarre masks and costumes, tried to jam into a frowsy dance hall last week to attend the second anniversary party of a small weekly newspaper.
Hassenfeld Bros., Inc., announced over the weekend the appointment of the Fletcher Richards Company, Inc., as the agency for a little doll with a big budget.
LA CORUNA, Spain, July 31 (AP)--A matador's sword, shaken off by a dying bull and hurled through the air, today narrowly missed Generalissimo Francisco Franco's daughter in a crowd at a bullfight.
BUENOS AIRES, July 31-- The rectors of four of Argentina's eight national universities have resigned following the military regime's decree taking over the institutions.

PASADENA, Calif., July 31 (UPI)--Rink Babka of the Pasadena Athletic Association arrived late for the start of the discus competition and missed his first two tries, but he made up for it with his career-best throw of 207 feet 4 inches today in the highlight of the first annual Rose Bowl invitation track meet.

BOGALUSA, La., July 31 (UPI)--Police Chief Claxton Knight said today that the slaying last night of Clarence Triggs, a Negro, was "definitely not" a racial murder and said he expected an arrest in the case "within 48 hours."

SAN FRANCISCO, July 31 (AP)--Dr. Thomas N. Burbridge, former San Francisco president of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People who is a research scientist at the University of California, has turned down an invitation from President Johnson to visit the White House.
Bob Shaw, the tall righthander purchased from the Giants last June, provided a glowing touch to a glowing month for the Mets yesterday by pitching Westrum's Wonders to a 2-to-1 triumph over the Cubs.

Miss Claire Lucille Fusco, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Otto Francis Fusco of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married here yesterday afternoon to Dr. Vincent A. Sellitti, son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Sellitti of Brooklyn. The Rev. Donald Chiavello, performed the ceremony in St. Patrick's Cathedral. He was assisted by the Rev. Robert Moher.

It will be mostly sunny today in the Middle Atlantic States. Scattered showers and thundershowers are forecast for the upper lake region, upper Mississippi Valley and the Gulf and Plains States. Fair to partly cloudy skies are expected elsewhere. It will be warmer over the lower lake region, Ohio and Mississippi Valley, New England and the central plateau region. Cooler temperatures are forecast in the upper lake region and Northern Plains States.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) --The strike that has grounded five major airlines since July 8 has made thousands of air travelers aware for the first time of the existence of the local-service airlines.

SHAKESPEARE and music may be food for the soul, but waiting for them creates a need for more material sustenance. So seekers of free culture in Central Park generally come armed with picnic baskets containing anything from a cold hamburger to a complete meal with wine and linen napkins.
Aircraft machinists in the New York area, who decisively rejected the proposed new contract, complained angrily yesterday that it would take too long for them to reap most of the contract's benefits.

DANVILLE, Va., July 31-- Bob Johnson of Columbus and Tom Yeager of Marion, Ohio, won a 400-mile Trans-American sedan championship race today over Virginia International Raceway's 3.2-mile course. Their victory, in a Mustang, gave Ford the lead in the eightrace series, with four races still to go.
Three types of hospital employes are often called nurses, but there are great differences in their training. The three categories are:
TROY, N.Y., July 31--Dr. Frank M. Sulzman, a retired eye, ear, nose and throat specialist, died Friday at the age of 90.
A 50-year-old Brooklyn restaurateur was held yesterday on charges of felonious assault after, the police charged, he shot and wounded three men outside his restaurant.

ATLANTA, July 31 (AP)-- Hal Lanier rapped four straight singles and drove in two runs in leading San Francisco to a 4-3 victory today over the Atlanta Braves. The Giants snapped a four-game losing streak.
SKOVSHOVED, Denmark, July 31 (AP)--American yachts again dominated the European Dragon Class championships today in the third of five races on the sound here.
WOODS HOLE, Mass., July 31--The Woods Hole, Martha's Vineyard and Nantucket Steamship Authority announced yesterday that it had returned the $200,000 hydrofoil Flying Cloud to its builders.
PITTSBURGH, July 31--Steel mills faced rising costs, rising imports and moderately strong demand last week.

BETHANY, Conn., July 31-- An Afghan, Ch. Holly Hill Desert Wind, who will celebrate his fifth birthday next month, won his 20th best in show at the Elm City Kennel Club's 46th all-breed show today at the Bethway Kennels and Stable show grounds. There were 783 dogs entered.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 31--The settlers of Almagor, an Israeli border village overlooking the site of recent clashes with Syria, have decided to exploit a spontaneous tourist boom.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI)--Senator Edward M. Kennedy said today that although he had not read the Warren Commission Report he was convinced Lee Harvey Oswald alone assassinated President Kennedy.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 31 (UPI)--Former President Harry S. Truman's personal physician diagnosed his intestinal ailment today as "severe colitis, but there is no cause for alarm."
TOKYO, July 31 (AP)--North Vietnam protested to the International Control Commission today against the raids on the zone.

LAGOS, Nigeria, July 31 (Reuters)--Northern-led military dissidents, who oppose plans to eliminate regional divisions in Nigeria and unite the country, continued negotiating with the military regime today in an apparently strong position to force major governmental changes.

KINNELON, N.J., July 31-- Pebble's Dawn, ridden by Philip Embury, a University of Denver freshman, won two of the three classes to capture the open jumper championship at the Smoke Rise horse show today in his first appearance of the year in the division.

Scandinavian Airlines, which is owned by Sweden, Norway and Denmark, will be carrying 21,342 passengers today, the 12th anniversary of the system, according to Tore H. Nilert, president of S.A.S., Inc., in New York.
The bond market this week faces its most significant testing period of the summer.
LONDON, July 31 (AP)-- Britain, which dissociated herself from United States bombing of oil depots in the outskirts of Hanoi and Haiphong, today supported the raids in the demilitarized zone.
MIAMI, July 31--Food rationing in Cuba has been extended for another year, the Havana radio announced today. It said new ration cards, valid until July, 1967, would be issued tomorrow.

LOS ANGELES, July 31 (UPI)--Claudia Kolb, a 16 year-old high school junior from Santa Clara, Calif., broke the world record in the women's 200-meter individual medley today as the eighth annual Los Angeles invitation swim meet ended a three-day stand.

MONTREAL, July 31--The seventh annual Montreal Film Festival opened this weekend, but its directors were already setting their sights on what they plan as their mightiest effort--next year's festival, which will be integrated into Expo 67, Montreal's world's fair. This year's program which include some 60 feature-length and short films, will end Thursday night.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., July 31--Margaret Housmann of Great Neck, L.I., scored a triple in the equitation division of the Meadow Brook Hounds horse show today, winning both the medal and Maclay classes and capturing the horsemanship chamionship.

GREENVALE, L.I., July 31 --Leonard Bernstein conducted the New York Philharmonic here last night before a record audience attending a performance of the Long Island Festival on the campus of C.W. Post College.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 31--Informed military sources said here tonight that bombing raids in the demilitarized zone between North and South Vietnam were likely to continue.
The odds have been shortening on dark-horse candidates for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

Airlines will be required to show that their planes can be emptied of passengers and crew in 90 seconds, rather than in the two minutes currently allowed, under proposed rules scheduled to become effective later this year.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., July 31--A three-year crusade by television station WJXT to "clean up" the Jacksonville city government is nearing the decisive stage. A county grand jury has begun a six-month investigation of numerous allegations by station reporters of corruption and waste of public funds.
A Queens rabbi was charged in Criminal Court yesterday with attempting to perform an abortion on a 26-year-old pregnant woman.
Mrs. Joan Bergere Drayton, treasurer of the Hour of Music, Inc., an agency that promotes the talents of young musicians, died yesterday in her home at 30 East 62d Street. She was 57 years old.
KHARTOUM, the Sudan, July 31 (Reuters)--The Sudan's new Premier, Sayed Sadik alMahdi, announced tonight after four days of consultation that he had succeeded in forming a new coalition Government.

James Shepard Dennis of Santa Barbara, Calif., a former director of the International Minerals and Metals Corporation and of the United New Jersey Railroad and Canal Company, died yesterday of a heart attack at a hospital in Zurich, Switzerland, where he maintained a residence. He was 78 years old.

WASHINGTON, July 31-- John E. Horne, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, foresees "some potential daylight ahead" in the difficult mortgage money situation, but he believes that "the possibility of restoration of an easy mortgage market is far more remote."

PHILADELPHIA, July 31-- Whitney M. Young Jr., executive secretary of the National Urban League, told the opening session of the league's 59th annual convention today that a major effort must be made to reach the "unreachables," the marginal and the alienated men and women who are emerging from the ghettos.
WARSAW, July 31 (AP)-- Poland announced today price increases on tobacco and fish, price cuts on television sets, refrigerators and lard, and pay and pension raises for 2.5 million workers.

BOSTON, July 31--Miss Susan Alice Yacubian was married this afternoon to Stephen Frederick Klein, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ruben Klein of Mount Vernon, N.Y. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. Kourken A. Yacubian of Belmont and the late Mr. Yacubian.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI)--Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach assailed the real estate lobby on Capitol Hill today and predicted passage for the open housing section of the new civil rights bill.

The Bristol-Myers Company, drug manufacturing concern, is expected to lease more than 600,000 square feet of space in the block-square office skyscraper being built by Rudin Management on the east side of Park Avenue between 51st and 52d Streets.

New frustrations faced thousands of patrons and employes of the five struck airlines last night. They had been counting on the resumption of normal operations this morning until the machinists voted down the negotiated strike settlement.

Every few years municipal officials "discover"--as Building Commissioner Moerdler has just done again --that thousands of elderly New Yorkers are vegetating in nursing homes under conditions of intolerable squalor.

The World Journal Tribune, Inc., and the pressmen's union are expected to say today whether they will accept a factfinding panel to make recommendations for settling the dispute that has prevented the new enterprise from publishing for 98 days.

Filmed highlights of Gian Carlo Menotti's recent festival in Spoleto, Italy, will be televised in color on Sunday, Sept. 25, from 6:30 to 7:30 P.M. The program of opera, symphonic and chamber music will mark the seasonal premiere of the "Bell Telephone Hour" over the National Broadcasting Company network.
The third of this summer's four concerts by the Naumburg Symphony Orchestra took place last night on the Central Park Mall in the balmiest possible weather.
OMAHA, July 31 (AP)-- The police broke up a disturbance early today at the scene of the July 4th weekend racial outbreaks in this city's predominantly Negro section.

"Love in E Flat," a comedy by Norman Krasna, has been scheduled to arrive here around Christmas under the auspices of Alfred de Liagre Jr., producer of "The Voice of the Turtle," "The Madwoman of Chaillot" and the Pulitzer Prize drama, "J.B."
The Kewanee Oil Company and the Harshaw Chemical Company announced over the weekend that they had reached a preliminary agreement on a plan to merge, with Kewanee as the surviving corporation.

PADANARAM, Mass., July 31--Walter S. Gubelmann's 71 -foot yawl, Windigo, and Danforth Miller Jr.'s new Columbia 50, Blixtar, were the first-and second-division winners, respectively, on a New York Yacht Club cruise run from Newport today. The event needed saving early through a course-cutting expedient and it ended with a fine turn of speed.
TEANECK, N.J., July 31-- Miss Arlene R. Cohen, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Godfrey Cohen, became the bride today of Martin T. Katzman. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ira Katzman of Englewood.

NORTH MIAMI BEACH, Fla., July 31 (UPI)--A gang of robbers who had lookouts with walkie-talkies overpowered a department store guard early today, looted two safes, and escaped with more than $50,000 in cash and jewelry.
LONDON, July 31 (AP)--The president of one of Britain's leading scientific societies blamed professional prejudice today for the blackballing of Prince Philip from honorary membership.
The United States Coast Guard, founded by Alexander Hamilton in 1790 primarily to put down smuggling, will be 176 years old on Thursday.
THE PARTIES--The International Association of Machin ists and Eastern, National, Northwest, United and Trans World airlines.

MOSCOW, July 31--Soviet harness racing officials, ambitious to enter the big leagues at international tracks, have made a request to send two trainers to Yonkers Raceway for half a year of work and study with American experts.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 31 --If the Long Island Expressway finally reaches its terminus here on eastern Long Island by 1970, as promised, can the people be far behind?
WASHINGTON, July 31-- Supporters of civil rights legislation are openly nervous as the House moves toward a key vote this week on the controversial open housing proposal.

The Mayor's plan for a top planning council to establish goals and priorities through a cost-effectiveness approach is important for reasons that go beyond the computers and advanced mathematics it will bring into play. Basically, it means applying systematic common sense to the city's problems. By asking the right questions, it forces administrators to think more creatively and broadly.
Four Negro teen-agers were arrested yesterday morning in the stabbing of five white youths in the racially mixed Ridgewood section of Brooklyn Saturday night.

PERSISTENT hot weather throughout the country, the airline strike and the pressures attendant to winning and losing brought about annual temper tantrums a little earlier than usual on the baseball scene.
The new Center for Maritime Studies at Webb Institute of Naval Architecture is getting under way and has named Rear Adm. William A. Brockett, as interim executive director.
Retail jewelers from across the nation began to arrive here over the weekend for the National Jewelry Trade Show.
MERIDEN, Conn., July 31-- A Japanese jazz band gave a concert of traditional New Orleans jazz here Friday night, cheered on by 250 members and guests of the Connecticut Traditional Jazz Club.

IRKUTSK, U.S.S.R., July 21-- The young man in the Limnological Institute on the shores of Lake Baikal solemnly said: "Do you realize that once the waters of the lake become polluted it will require 400 years to refill the basin with pure water?"

BROOKLINE, Mass., July 31--In Temple Kehillath Israel, Miss Deborah Lois Baron, daughter of Mrs. Morris Baron and the late Mr. Baron, became the bride today of Michael Ellis Goldberg, son of Dr. and Mrs. Samuel Goldberg of Eastchester, N.Y.

The brutal attack by Argentine police, some of them shouting anti-Semitic and anti-Communist curses, on defenseless university students and professors last weekend inevitably reminds the world of the similar tactics used by Hitler's storm troopers in the 1930's.

THE style of the Argentine grand master Miguel Naj dorf is, above all, opportunistic. Because, he is imaginative, combinative and attacking, Najdorf makes his presence felt in the strongest company. He is also feared as a sly tactician, supremely competent at adjusting to new developments.
The city administration warned smokers here yesterday that any individual buying cigarettes at cut rates from out of state was liable for $1.40 tax on each carton.

KANSAS CITY, July 31 (AP) --The Detroit Tigers took two games from the Kansas City Athletics today, 5-4 and 7-1, winning the opener with three runs in the ninth inning after having been held to one hit until then.
ARVIKA, Sweden, July 31 (UPI)--Neal Steinhauer of the United States won the shot-put and the discus throw in an international track and field meet today.

The Fifth Avenue Synagogue was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Miss Marcia Pauline Zeisel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Aron Zeisel of Bradley Beach, N.J., to Howard Philip Goldberg. He is the son of Mrs. Sol Goldberg of East Orange, N.J., and the late Mr. Goldberg.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., July 31 --Abram J. Feuer of 87 Brite Avenue, a partner in the brokerage firm of Gartman, Rose Feuer, 1 Wall Street, New York, died yesterday of a heart ailment in White Plains Hospital. He was 56 years old.

Mayor Lindsay strongly defended the city's economy yesterday against a City Planning Commission report that said it was lagging in a period of tremendous national growth and probably would fall behind more. Saying he was "surprised" at the release of a report based on what he called outdated statistics that did not reflect actions of his administration to help business, the Mayor snapped:

Mayor Lindsay charged yesterday that he had inherited "one of the worst" antipoverty apparatuses in the country and that the Federal Government had "defaulted" on antipoverty money promised to the city.

CHICAGO, July 31--Angry crowds of whites chanting "white power!" hurled bricks and bottles at 550 Negro and white supporters of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. today during a civil rights march through an all-white neighborhood.

DENVER, July 31--A Florida team moved into a substantial lead in the foursession master mixed team championship that began here last night. Lee Ferer, Gratian Goldstein and Jane Jaeger, all of Miami Beach, and Robert Reynolds of Coral Gables scored 20 points to head the field of 130 teams.
"SAM is a fighter of the first order when he be lieves in something. When it comes to compromise, he doesn't even know how to spell the word."

ANAHEIM, Calif, July 31 (AP)--Leon Wagner drove in two runs with his 16th homer and a single and Rocky Colavito hit his 23d homer for the Cleveland Indians today as the Indians defeated the California Angels, 3-2.

TOKYO, July 31--Premier Eisaku Sato completed a reorganization of his Cabinet and the Liberal-Democratic party today. The shuffle reflected, besides the usual factional tugging within the party, two maior pressures.

NEW DELHI, July 31-- Dr. C.V. Roman, a Nobel Prize winner for physics in 1930, said in Madras yesterday that it was "nothing but sheer raving lunacy" to spend millions of dollars "to shoot men into space and make them walk there."
FASHION shows for children, with marionette models as well as live ones, are being given Saturday afternoons on the third floor of the Allied Chemical Exhibit Center in Times Square.
PARIS, July 31--Emanuel Ungaro, who is young and progressive, and Madame Gres, who is neither, were once again symbols of two extremes in the French fall couture collections last week.
LONDON, July 31 (Reuters) --England's national soccer team received ecstatic acclaim at home today after winning the World Cup yesterday, but reaction from abroad was not all favorable.
In the House debate on the civil rights bill there is danger that an almost entirely false connection is being established between the bill and the recent riots in Northern cities.
BRUSSELS, July 31 (AP)-- The Belgian Foreign Ministry denied today that the Belgian Consul General in Lumumbashi, formerly Elizabethville, was being expelled from the Congo.

WASHINGTON, July 31-- Arthur F. Burns has joined the ranks of economists who believe that an income tax increase would have been good economic policy at the beginning of the year but who oppose it now.
WASHINGTON, July 31-- Machinist union members defied President Johnson and their own leaders today to reject overwhelmingly an agreement to end the 24-day airline strike.

Parks Commissioner Thomas P.F. Hoving called last night for the creation of a special arm of the Police Department that would resemble "a combination of policemen and forest rangers" to patrol the city's parks.
NEW HAVEN, July 31 (AP) --A six-man team was chosen last night to represent the United States at the world gymnastic championships to be held in Dortmund, West Germany, in September.
DALLAS, July 31 (AP)-- Central Airlines cancelled nine flights to Texas, Oklahoma, Missouri, Kansas and Colorado today because of a crew shortage.
LINCOLN, Neb., July 31 (UPI)--Former United States Senator Hazel Abel died from complications of a heart condition yesterday. She was 78 years old.

NEW HAVEN, July 31 (UPI) --Trustees of the New Haven Railroad said today they would file a brief with the Interstate Commerce Commission tomorrow urging the ICC not to postpone further the PennsylvaniaNew York Central railroad merger.

CUMBERLAND, Md., July 31 (AP)--Mario Andretti of Nazareth, Pa., the national driving champion of the United States Auto Club, won the featured 30lap sprint at the Cumberland Raceway today in 12 minutes 39.05 seconds. He won $710.

LeRoi Jones, the playwright, denied yesterday that Allen Ginsberg, the poet, had raised the bail to free Mr. Jones, who had been arrested on charges of assaulting and robbing Shepard Sherbell, the editor of a literary magazine.
ATLANTIC CITY, July 31-- A family of four from West Hartford, Conn., died today when their plane crashed into a bay here while attempting a landing at Bader Field Airport.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 31-- A 5,800-member local of the International Association of Machinists voted overwhelmingly today against a contract proposal that had the approval of its national leaders.

WASHINGTON, July 31-- Rejection by airline machinists of the agreement that their leaders, the airlines and President Johnson announced last Friday brought immediate Congressional action to pass legislation to end the dispute.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP)--The United States Government will pay dislocation allowances to about 400 former General Motors Corporation workers displaced from their jobs when their employer transferred some operations to Canada.
LONDON, July 31--Princess Alexandra, a cousin of Queen Elizabeth, gave birth tonight to her second child, a daughter weighing 7 pounds 8 ounces.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI)--Gil Hodges was given a new two-year contract as manager of the Washington Senators today.
WASHINGTON, July 31-- Partly because of dissension in its ranks, the Administration is expected to delay until fall any diplomatic initiatives to break the deadlock in disarmament negotiations.

RUSH, N.Y., July 31 (AP)-- Fifty-one of 359 shooters posted perfect scores today in the practice round for the 12-gauge title at the world skeet shooting championships at the Rochester-Brooks Gun Club.

The Rev. Dr. Eugene Carson Blake, general secretary-elect of the World Council of Churches, told worshipers here yesterday that the "old, cozy, three-storied universe of heaven, hell and earth" has gone but is not always forgotten.
LONDON, Monday, Aug. 1 (AP)--The British Colonial Office, which once shared the greatest imperial responsibility in history, struck the flag at midnight.

The Federal Maritime Administration had filed 62 charges in the United States District Court, Southern District of Florida, alleging that Eagle, Inc., of Miami, had obtained "improper rates by means of false billing and other unjust devices."

WHITE PLAINS, July 31-- At the Temple Israel Center this afternoon, Miss Esther Miriam Brill, daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Mordecai L. Brill of Dobbs Ferry, was married to Mitchell Alan Weinstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman S. Weinstein of Broomall, Penna.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 31 (UPI)--Billy Casper, the United States Open champion, became the first player to win four tournaments on the pro golf tour this year by capturing the $92,000 "500" Festival open today by three shots. He shot a two-under-par 70 for a winning 277.

LONDON, July 31--The pilot of a British Overseas Airways Corporation VC-10, who agreed to shuttle families of Nigerian Army insurgents from Lagos to Kano in the North before being permitted to fly his regular passengers to London, said today that the mutineers were "terribly polite and correct."
HONG KONG, July 31--A senior military figure has been appointed Acting Minister of Culture in place of Lu Ting-yi, one of the major victims of the purge that is sweeping Communist China.

A waterfront welfare program that instituted a system of self-insurance on April 1 will permit the fund to pay over $1-million more in benefits this year as a result of the move, a dock union official said yesterday.
President Zalman Shazar of Israel made an emotional appeal to America's numerous Jewish organizations yesterday to overcome their rivalries and seek broader unity in secular and religious matters.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Aug. 1 (AP)--The International Control Commission for Vietnam, made up of representatives of India, Canada and Poland, said today that it "views with concern the most recent developments in the demilitarized zone" separating North and South Vietnam.

RALEIGH, N.C., July 31 (AP)--A Negro and a Ku Klux Klansman exchanged punches after a Klan rally today, several hours before the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. told some 5,000 persons he had no use for "black power" if it meant "black supremacy."

WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI)--Attorney General Nicholas deB. Katzenbach said today that it would be both untrue and a "tragic mistake" to say that recent Negro riots in cities across the nation were part of a "national conspiracy."

BARROW, Alaska--The Eskimos and Indians of Alaska, now busy forming native associations that they hope will generate enough political pressure to lift them from their squalor, have rejected overtures from Alaskan Negroes to make common cause in a struggle for equal rights.

LLIVIA, Spain, July 24--Legend has it that Llivia, the only part of Spain north of her border with France, remained Spanish by a lawyer's trick and survives by smuggling. The legend is only partly true.

Now that the House Committee on Interior and Insular Affairs has heard from all the chief disputants in the long controversy over how to protect the Hudson Valley, it should move for effective legislation before Congress adjourns.

Two major agencies have announced appointments in their Canadian operations.
Savings accounts at the nation's 6,230 savings and loan associations dropped by an estimated $1.1-billion in July, sources close to the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said yesterday.

Helme Products Inc., a producer of snuff products and convenience foods, announced here yesterday the election of John C. Griswold as a director.
JAMESBURG, N.J., Aug. 1 Dave Muraskin, a 19-year-old caddie from Forsgate, won the New Jersey caddie championship today with a score of 36, 36 72 at the Forsgate Country Club.

The City Center Joffrey Ballet, formerly the Robert Joffrey Ballet, will present two premieres and four new productions for its initial season at the City Center, Sept. 6 through 25.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 The House Republican Policy Committee announced today that it was opposed to the open housing section of the Administration's civil rights bill. The committee said the provision was politically motivated, unrealistic and divisive.
The mass killing by a sniper in Austin, Tex., yesterday recalls what, until now, was the deadliest rampage ever conducted by one man. It was done by Howard Unruh in Camden, N. J., on Sept. 6, 1949.
ROCHESTER, Aug. 1 (UPI) Ken Barnes of Bakersfield, Calif., captured the world championship in the .410 gauge competition in the world skeet shoot, which began today in suburban Rush.

DETROIT, Aug. 1 (AP) The Justice Department brought a civil antitrust suit against the Florists' Transworld Delivery Association today, charging a conspiracy to set prices in the telegraph sales of flowers.
Stock prices fell sharply yesterday, carrying leading market indicators to new lows for the year.

An increase in the number- of pre-Broadway tryouts during the 1966-67 season was indicated yesterday by Ernest M. Rawley, executive secretary of the Independent Booking Office, which serves 79 legitimate playhouses on the road.

Carl McAdams, the New York Jets' $325,000 rookie linebacker, is expected to miss most of the American Football League season after having suffered a fracture and a dislocation of his left ankle Saturday night in Chicago.
William J. Briordy, a sports reporter for The New York Times, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital of a heart attack. He was 53 years old and lived at 60 East 94th Street.

Frank A. Parker, Frederick (Ted) Schroeder and the late Lieut. Joseph R. Hunt have been voted into the National Lawn Tennis Hall of Fame.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 The Treasury proposed today new tax guidelines on transactions between corporations and their subsidiaries, aimed in part at fostering exports from parent companies in the United States to their affiliates abroad.

Generally lower prices marked yesterday's trading session in commodity futures. The reasons were varied, ranging from a copper workers' strike that did not take place to a spate of hedge selling by Maine potato interests to better weather prospects over the grain belt.

Daniel P. O'Connell, the head of the powerful Albany County Democratic machine for 45 years, threw his support yesterday behind Frank D. O'Connor's campaign for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

The Carnegie Commission on Educational Television told the Federal Communications Commission yesterday that it is encouraging a study of a communications satellite system that would be specifically designed for noncommercial television. It emphasized, however, that it also is studying alternate methods of distributing programs.
WASHINGTON. Aug. 1 (AP) The Senate passed by voice vote today a bill that would provide payment of up to 10 per cent interest on savings deposited by members of the armed services stationed overseas.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the formation of a 12-man advisory committee to make recommendations to the exchange's board of governors for greater uniformity in automation and paperwork procedures.

Herbert Sondheim, who headed his own couture dress house on Seventh Avenue for more than 40 years, died yesterday at Stamford (Conn.) Hospital after a short illness. He was 71 years old and maintained homes in Stamford and at 1010 Fifth Avenue.
A revolutionary nationwide satellite television system that would use profits from the relay of commercial TV shows to finance noncommercial video was proposed yesterday by the Ford Foundation.
